Review Title: In the 28 known galaxies, there is no better film
Review: I just caught a screener and am so blown away. The original came out when I was 6, so I have been a fanatic most of my life. I don't think the legacy of Superman has yet to leave any small boy unimpressed and forever moved to tell the truth, seek justice, and well, you know the rest.I will tell NOTHING of the story. It would rob you of everything good. Besides, I don't think there is anything I could write to make you not go see it. I just have to say that my hat is off to Bryan Singer for making so many important right choices. Sticking with the original John Williams score and having Ottman build from it, the re-working of Brando's archive footage, and most of all, the casting of Brandon Routh makes this such an amazingly familiar bridge from the 80's films with all thew wonder of what can be done with film today. All of the components that are necessary to accommodate your past feelings and emotions bridging them forward to this movie are present and in tact. Great job!!!! Let me say that I was on the fence about Routh from all of the trailers I had seen. I was so thankful that it was not Nicholas Cage donning the blue suit poised to ruin my childhood hero, but I wanted what seemed impossible, I wanted Christopher Reeve back in his prime heroic form. The trailers give no hint of the amazing performance that Brandon Routh has turned in. There are moments that just gutshot you right into Reeve's performances. The half cocked smile, the timbre of his voice, the Clark Kent mannerisms perfected by Reeve are echoed here in Routh's delivery as both an homage and as a great device to tie the past generation into this new ability to tell a story with all of the technology at hand.A big Kudos must go to Kevin Spacey and Parker Posey who are awesome as Lex and Kitty. Not too much humor, but some, not too much banter, but enough, and all of the evil you need to see in order to make him truly the enemy of Superman. Perfection! I know it'd be easier to enjoy if I just told you it sucked completely and didn't try to build it up to something you may not think it is, but I have no doubt about it. The story itself is too rich and wonderful and the trailers give away nothing of what's in store for you. There is no way to be disappointed. Take it from me.

Review Title: Superman Returns: The Official Review (spoiler free)
A different story on a classic superhero.
Review: Brandon Routh does pull it off as the new Clark Kent/Superman. This movie actually stands out from the crowd of comics turned into film (Batman Returns, Sin City, the Fantastic 4, The Hulk, Spiderman, X-men trilogy, etc.) Superman is a unique superhero. The context of his world is different from the corrupted (ba)Sin City or a world with millions of mutants. This allowed the film to have a lighter tone with a good amount of laughs.I didn't expect this film to be different or good for that matter but I loved it. Routh is our generation's Superman, Bosworth is a good Lois Lane, the effects are breathtaking, the story is exciting, and people literally cheered in the theater. Not to mention, Routh was so nice in person.

Review Title: The Man Of Steel is back....
Review: and from the looks of this movie and how much it will be making, I'm very sure he's back for good.On June 18th, 2006, I was one of the lucky 250 patrons who had an opportunity to watch a sneak preview showing of "Superman Returns" here in San Francisco, at the Sony/Loews Metreon theater.Don't worry. No spoilers. Just some small details.From the opening of the movie, fans who have seen the original film will be delighted at the fact that "Superman Returns" truly does feel as more of a 'continuation' from the original "Superman" and "Superman II" starring Christopher Reeve. Even the opening credits will give the classic film fans a bite of nostalgia, simply because of the overall presentation of the opening credits.Director Bryan Singer really does know how to take these 'comic book based' movies to the next level and bring them success (or back from hiatus, depending on how you look at it) all while making the film watcher's experience something a bit different, not only in terms of plot, but his overall expertise and execution of being a really good director.Actor Brandon Routh definitely does extremely well in his performance as the main character "Superman/Clark Kent" and does so with such natural acting ability, you could have sworn that you've seen him act in many other things. (Yes, I really can see him as 'Superman') Actor Kevin Spacey's performance as "Lex Luthor", although not too derived from Gene Hackman's portrayal of the villain, does a great job at bringing a different kind of arrogance to the character. Then again, when has there never been a top notch performance from Spacey? All of the films he's starred in usually have him performing at his best.Actress Kate Bosworth's portrayal of "Lois Lane" wasn't bad, but wasn't great either and for some reason, seems a bit young to be the "Lois Lane" character that fans will remember through Margot Kidder's portrayal in the original Superman films from 1978 to 1987. Personally, I've always seen Lois Lane as a character in her early 30's, not as someone who is as young as Miss Bosworth is, although Bosworth's performance was just enough to be convincing.Overall, Superman Fans WILL be pleased by this 2 hour, 34 minute film that truly shows a triumphant return of the one and only "Man Of Steel".Would I pay to see it again? I plan on it. I'm actually planning on seeing it at the Imax Theater in 3D (select scenes in 3D), so why not? I'm sure I'll enjoy it again.

Review Title: This film does for Superman what Batman Begins did for Batman.
Review: Of all the Superheroes, my favorite has always been Batman and Spiderman,along with the X-men.Because, I have something to relate to with those characters.And they really can exist in real life.Superman has always been my least favorite,not because he is flawed or anything,which he is a bit,it's because he can't exist in real life.But there's something in him that relates to us,as a human.He is lost and doesn't know what to do.He lost his parents,he is confused and he doesn't know what choices to make,and yet he chooses to do what he does.He is a being from another world,and far superior.He lives among us as a friendly human being.And protects us with the power he has.I've always loved Superman for who he is ,but the not the overall character.But after watching this film, I saw something in him that makes him real.People look up at him and consider him god,and their Saviour.He gives hope to people ,he is different from them,and yet he chose to protect them.But deep inside him there is humanity hidden.And this film explodes with warmth and thrills.It comes close to beating Batman Begins and Spider-Man films,and this film completely expresses the essence of this Legendary Character.He was the first of its kind.I can't praise this film enough without spoiling a bit,but I'll try to give you nothing but the praises.I liked the first Superman film,it was one of the first great Superhero films to reign the big screen.It was the greatest superhero film of its time.Even if it looks outdated in its effects and technology,it still retains the charm and sweetness that makes Superman so likable.It was massively entertaining,and still is.But for me,it's now a bit cheesy and cartoonish and lacks a classic villain that Luthor was supposed to be.But Superman:The movie remains to be the first great classic ,like the comic book itself.Last year, we had a reinvention or re-imagination of Batman in Batman Begins.He returned to the screen in a miraculously fascinating way.The character was made riveting and more complex,and the true essence of the character was brought in that film,which makes it the definite Batman Film.Superman Returns follows the same League.This return is nothing but a welcome return.It gives you the very definite version of who Superman really was and is in the comic books and more. The story is so humane, and so close to your heart that you accept Superman for who he is and you feel for his love that he lost.This film is close to the first.You know the story ,and there are big surprises ,so there's no point of mentioning them and I think you should go see it for yourself.The effects were breath stopping along with its action. You will have your eyes fixed at the screen and grip your seat so that you won't even move. This is the best effects 21st century has to offer yet.But to be honest it's still not superior than King Kong.The SFX just stays behind that film.But it is unlike anything you'll see all year,in particular the Plane Rescue sequence.Although,they're nothing Groundbreaking,or remotely as earth-shattering as King Kong.That was the best Special FX 21st century had to offer.The action in this film is filled with so much energy,sheer enthusiasm and excitement that you feel like you're flying right up there with him. Kudos for its SFX .But it's not a film that solely relies on its SFX,it has very little of those and minimized action.Instead it focuses on the story and character like Spider-Man films did.I hated Singer for leaving one of my favorite comic book films and did this.But he has brought so much warmth and love to this film that this is more of a love story of regret than an action film.And for that this man deserves all the praise.From Usual suspects to X-men films, he's always presented his vision in a different manner.The true hero here is Singer himself and I think if he had helled X3,it could've been a far better film than it is.This film propels and brings Superman where he belongs.The original Superman was enjoyable and fun.And it's mainly because Reeve's presence,who brings so much humanity and humour in the character and the film that you simply love the Hero.Here ,it's not Reeves or Brandon Routh,who resembles a lot to Reeves, that make this film more than what it is in comparison to performances. The whole film belongs to Spacey,I'm sorry Routh ,you resemble a lot to Reeves and you were great, but it's Spacey that really has the acting skills.He simply turns Luthor into simply evil character that was rather silly in the original film.Spacey shows who Luthor really is,which was missing in the original film. Routh fits so well as the Man of Steel that you have no complaints towards him.Kate Bosworth as the Love of the steel that melts him whenever he's close to her disappoints.She was lost mostly and too wooden as Lois Lane.Parker Posey is another special mention and so was the rest of the cast,especially Marsden.There are numerous references to the Richard Donner classic.And that just brings you to remember that film.It's as if you're watching that film with more improved quality of effects and looks.And that is both a good thing and a bad thing.Way too many Jesus references in the end.I would say this was a terrific and groundbreaking achievement.Although I would still consider Spiderman 2 my favorite superhero film followed by X-men films,not the third one,and Batman Begins.Then comes this, beating Hulk.This is an exhilarating epic.Superman Returns is an ambitious work.Filled with momentum excitement.Tremendous ,marvellous epic scaled entertainment.It was good but just not great.Its last few reels were disappointing and the surprise it had for us just disjointed the whole story.You can feel the powers that Superman possess but they don't have a lasting impact.Only Pirates will tell how long Superman lasts.

Brandon Routh perfectly portrays both Clark Kent and superman.. the former's endearing awkwardness and the more confident and suave superman. he is the rock that the rest of the movie is built upon. he actually improves upon Christopher Reeves performance. Kevin Spacey is also great as the psychotic lex luthor. although his evil schemes are never really explained very well, his performance makes up for it. the film is beautifully shot and edited, its a sensory thrill ride the whole way through. overall, this might contend for greatest comic book film ever- even better than last years Batman Begins, partly because this has a believable and engaging romance- not the travesty that was Katie Holmes. spot on casting, great acting, and great directing from Bryan Singer make this an all around winner.

Review Title: More Drama that Action-Adventure, But Pretty Damn Good
one of the best Super Hero movies ever
Review: This movie completely blows any of the recent superhero movies out of the water. Spiderman, fantastic four and even singer's previous X-men movies all pale in comparison. Not only does it include incredible special effects, sound, and visual achievements, but the plot is well developed and deeper than most comic/super hero movies ever attempt to go. Superman Returns stays faithful to the original Superman movies and comics and serves as a great update to the storyline. Brandon Routh must be a distant relative of Christopher Reeves, the similarity between the two and their portrayal is striking. Bonus points go to Singer for including Brando clips for Superman's father.In my opinion, a good superhero movie should make the audience want to live in the world which the hero inhabits, or wish that the hero truly existed in reality. This movie does just that- makes you wish there was such a force of truth and justice living in our world.

Review Title: dull and slightly embarrassing to watch
Review: The real problem here still lies with the fact that Director Bryan Singer vastly misjudged what made the first Superman so successful. He actually seems to think that people care about the characters' relationships and the metaphysical plot. Everyone I've spoken to thought those two things were the weakest aspects of the movie. The first Superman was good DESPITE the corny love story and beyond corny plot turns. This one centers on corny and centers on the mundane, and that's why it's dull and slightly embarrassing to watch. It's either that or maybe it's the ridiculous Superman costume that they modernized. Maybe they should've changed the movie's title from Superman Returns to Brokeback Superdude? It's no wonder Bryan Singer recently said the following about this movie… Reflecting on how Superman differs from his previous movies, Singer observed, "The one thing I could say (about that) is the romantic nature of this film. This is different than my 'X-Men' films. It could be called my first chick flick. It's a kind of modern romance in a way played out by very nostalgic characters." Nostalgic or simply played out?

Review Title: Very disappointing, a soap opera with a bit of action thrown in.
Review: I just saw Superman Returns at the world premiere in Westwood. I have been a Superman comic fan since I was a kid (I'm 49 now) and I still watch Smallville. Superman – the character – is the greatest, but this movie was…extremely disappointing. Knowing the director was Bryan Singer, who just did X-Men, I was expecting an action-packed thriller. This movie was more a soap opera with special effects and some action thrown in out of obligation.One of the best parts of a hero-bad guy movie is when the two adversaries meet to duke it out. About 80% into the movie they finally met, and the scene was pitiful. Lex Luthor is famous for being an evil genius. In this movie, he was just evil, but he was very well played by Kevin Spacey. Lex is supposed to use his genius to do battle with Superman. Design a super strong robot armor suit, or some other clever tactic. You can guess how Lex dealt with Superman, the most predictable way possible. Superman is back after being gone for 5 years. He went to find Krypton, which maybe wasn't completely destroyed. (This is not a spoiler). But FYI, Krypton was bathed by the radiation from a red sun. People living there were normal, like us. They only develop super powers here on Earth due to our yellow sun. So, even if Superman tried to fly to Krypton, he would lose all of his powers and die in space when he got close to the red sun. Other gripes: Superman had so much make-up on, at times he looked computer-generated. 'Clark' looked way too much like Superman. Christopher Reeve did a much better job as a slouchy, meek Clark. Brandon Routh might be handsome, but he just looked sooooooo... darn young. How could such a baby-face be a "Super Man?"What I liked: James Marsden playing Perry White's nephew, he was awesome. Great guy, great character, great role. It was cool seeing X-Man Scott Summers without his glasses. Frank Langella...very small role, but great job as Perry White. Sam Huntington as Jimmy Olsen...funny, funny guy. Without him, this movie would have been absolutely humorless.Did these guys show this movie to a test audience? I would love to know how they spent so much money to make such a long and mostly boring movie.

I saw an advance screening of this today, and had to write and say that Superman Returns was amazing.Brandon Routh as Superman is awesome, Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor is amazing and Kate Bosworth, just great as Lois Lane. Even the musical score is really powerful... Bryan Singer should be running all Hero based movies...Great Story, Great Acting, Great effects, probably one of the best movies I've ever seen, I was really overcome with emotion during a couple of scenes...and I was glued to my seat for 2.5 hours... after it was done I wanted to run back in and see it again.Get out of your chair, and go see this movie...now...

Review Title: Pointless to hate, meaningless to love
Review: It's been nearly 20 years since the last SUPERMAN movie, and that one -- SUPERMAN IV: THE QUEST FOR PEACE -- was such a low-tech, silly muddle that it doesn't even seem fair to count it among the first two. (SUPERMAN III was nearly as bad.) Yet somehow, the Man of Steel has kept his place in our hearts. Who does have at least a curiosity about how the new film, SUPERMAN RETURNS, will fare? Certain the special effects have advanced considerably since the 1978's original tagline promised us "you will believe a man can fly." And here, you do. The FX are great and convincing. But... what else? Does it deliver? The answer is a mix of "yes" and "no." SUPERMAN RETURNS, as much as Clark Kent himself, seems to have a split personality. Is it a sequel (as much of its dialogue and title suggest) or a remake (as its style and plot choices indicate)? Well, it's a little of both, and in that conflict lies both its fatal flaw and its salvation. The storyline and tone so closely mirror the original -- especially in the comic flair exhibited by Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey, predictably delicious) and his relationship with ditzy cohort Kitty (Parker Posey). Superman (Brandon Routh, who often appears to have been extruded from a solid piece of manhunk)has been missing for five years and suddenly returns to earth to continue doing good deeds (why he left and why he returns never really make a lot of sense). Meanwhile, Luthor has a plan for world domination that includes, once again, a giant land-grab (even the 1978 jokes about this are recycled). Back at the Daily Planet, Clark continues to pine for Lois (Kate Bosworth), who still can't spell. Then there's Jimmy Olsen, Perry White, Ma Kent -- all the usual suspects. Lois has a boyfriend and a son, too, which is one of the few changes from where we last saw them.There's so much the same that to speak ill of the film is somehow to dishonor its predecessors. But there was a lot of room for director Bryan Singer to improve and reinvent the story, not feel beholden to another 30-year-old movie. But his efforts smack of folly. There are a fair number of moments to enjoy in SUPERMAN RETURNS, but they require an unusual amount of pretending not to notice the obvious. Does it bother anyone else that a 23-year-old (Bosworth, who looks all of... 23) was THE famous Lois Lane -- the same one who Margot Kidder portrayed at 30) when she was 18 years old? (The story makes numerous references to the first two films, including the "My Night With Superman" article that we are now meant o believe was written before Lois could vote.) Or that a 26-year-old (Routh) left the earth at an age when he would still be considered SuperBOY? Or that Lois' son -- who, in the time line, has to be no more than four -- looks to be at least six? Doesn't this all strike you as Hollywood at its franchise-minded worst? At more than 2.5 hours, SUPERMAN RETURNS doesn't need to be as long as it is, and would have benefited immeasurably from a tighter script. But as an entertainment, there have been worse. It's just this one could have been much better.

Let me cut to the chase by paraphrasing the Superman ad campaign: You *will* believe that Brandon Routh can fly. I'm jealous of him because he was born to play this role. His Clark Kent is goofy and endearing; his Superman is invincible and inspiring. I have great respect for Bryan Singer, and congratulations to him for all the work he put into finding his Kal-El; without such an archetypal lead, the rest of the movie would have been irrelevant. I'm baffled as to why they don't have more of Clark and Superman speaking in the trailers for the movie. I think a marketing exec somewhere must have been worried about people saying "But it's not Christopher Reeve"...But that was unnecessary; anyone who thinks that going in will forget it by the time they leave. There are a few parts of the storyline that I'm not happy with; they're meant to bring human dilemmas to Superman, but instead they drag him down into the mundane. However, I forgave most of that when he repeats some of Jor-El's words at the end of the movie. Finally, I'm amazed at Singer's ability to tell such an epic story with almost no on screen violence and death...This is a movie I can't wait to watch with my daughter - she's only 2, but I won't have to wait long...

Review Title: Superman Returns is absolutely worth the $9!!!

Review: Saw an advance screening yesterday...Brandon Routh pulled it off beautifully. He resembles Christopher Reeve's Superman so much it's uncanny. The first time he smiles as Clark Kent, back at work at the daily Planet, it felt like it was Christopher Reeve again.Kevin Spacey is an excellent Lex Luthor. His role was written much better than Hackman's role in the original films. He didn't seem to be coming up with plans that could only work under comic book logic. Admittedly, they could only work in Superman's comic book universe, (Fortress of Solitude, Krypton, Kryptonite, etc.) but the logic of his plan is sound. His character's obsession with real estate resembles Hackman's Lex, but Spacey's Lex is a much less silly version of the role. Hackman is a great actor, but his Lex Luthor was very badly written, IMHO. Nobody could have saved it.The effects were great, the story was great, the acting was overall very good. There were, however, numerous errors in the reality of real things. The end of the scene involving the Mustang (no spoilers here) defies the reality of cars, as an example. Sure it's not the first time a Superman movie, or indeed any comic book adaptation, has made these type of errors, but it would have been better if they did little things like that right, instead of using the "Eh, it's just a movie" excuse.Ultimately, I loved this film. It's a great story well told. It doesn't need to be anything else.

Review Title: It's Nothing New but It IS Dull and Flat.
Review: Like bad action movies of the past with a big budget but no brain, (Can you say Reloaded? Can you say Revolutions? Can you now say Returns?) This movie pretended to be smart but ultimately there was no thought put into the writing. Even the action scenes were on the weak and flimsy side. The entire movie lacked the energy of the original. Not only that, but there was zero chemistry between the stars--who have no personality or charisma, and there was no character development at all. Since the movie put way too much emphasis on the characters, this was a serious problem. This film had some nice effects that quickly became boring as their setup and overuse flowed for far too long. Besides, the one thing those Matrix sequels mentioned above did right was showing off Superman like powers and flying abilities. So, Superman Returns offers NOTHING new.A serious disappointment here.

Superman ReturnsSuperman is my new hero. His sense of justice is so well defined that just the idea of Superman makes people behave. They open doors for each other. They say "Thank you" and "Pardon me." Why? Superman is the model for how to act. But it is Kal-El's kindness and respect, his undying belief in family values that make me wish he really did exist. Superman behaves as we all can…and should. So it is with the visual experience Superman Returns offers: his world is super-realistic. The FX didn't make me think "That's fake;" the effects made me think "I want to live there. I want to live in Superman's world…right now." Superman Returns is the first feature film to be shot entirely with the new Sony/Panavision Genesis camera system. This 70mm high definition digital camera was worth every penny of the $209 million dollar budget that was spent on it. From the opening titles to the end credits the clarity of the film makes for absolutely seamless transition between reality and magic. Superman has never looked better.Director Bryan Singer took on the daunting task of resurrecting post-Christopher Reeve Superman. Imagine making an Indiana Jones sequel without Stephen Spielberg and after Harrison Ford was paralyzed and then died. First, you have audience expectations which are off the chart. Second, you have essential elements such as Kryptonite, Jor-El, Lex Luther, Lois Lane, and The Daily Planet newspaper that must be introduced in a way that will inform new viewers while not boring loyalists. Third, you have to advance the series with an original yet respectful story line. It is like asking someone to thread five needles at the same time. This seemingly impossible task was accepted by the young Bryan Singer, who made a name for himself directing 1995's The Usual Suspects. He followed with Apt Pupil (1998) and X-Men, X2 (2000, 2003). If you consider that this Superman sequel has been in development for Bryan Singer's entire career then you get some idea of what a potential trap he was walking into. Now that the dust has settled and Superman Returns is a reality, Singer definitely accomplished what few thought possible: he resurrected a hero.The story picks up where it was left after Superman II (1980). Kal-El has gone on a mission to visit what is left of his home planet of Krypton. Unfortunately, we do not get join Kal-El on this journey, but that is just one of the few objectionable decisions made by screenwriters Dan Harris & Michael Dougherty. Their picture is a tremendously entertaining one that accomplished an extraordinarily difficult task of satisfying everyone from the critics to the 13 year old who wants to fly. Kal-El returns home after five years to a changed world. Superman is compelled to protect earthlings from each other.Superman loyalists can breathe a sigh of relief. The fact another Superman sequel is slated for 2009 is proof that the Man of Steel is here to stay. Singer dedicated Superman Returns to Christopher and Dana Reeve, but everyone should embrace Superman's focused pursuit of justice. The question "Is Superman needed?" plays a large role in the movie as well as in real life. To both, the answer is Yes.Grade ASuperman Returns Cast: Brandon Routh, Kate Bosworth, Kevin Spacey Director: Bryan Singer MPAA Rating: PG-13 Runtime: 157 minutes Release Company: Warner Brothers

Review Title: possible spoiler. in regards to cast members from the '50s to today
Should have taken a longer break
This is not an ordinary movie
Review: This is not an ordinary movie. What we are dealing with here is the embodiment of truth and justice (the American Way has been upgraded to the World Stage). Superman is not just any Comic Book Hero... he is the quintessential Super Hero. Fun and Campy throughout this was enjoyable and action packed with great CGI at the start leveling to crystalline structures later that lacked veracity. You can take a break in the movie at the 3/4 point when there is an excess of the water structures and you will come back refreshed to finish the 2 hour 30 minutes (including about 7 minutes of Credits at the end).The new Superman is Brandon Routh, who is relatively free of a past of major roles that may have prevented us from believing him to be Superman. I don't watch much TV, especially the situation shows on the networks and those were his credits before this Superman. Fortuately, he was born in Iowa which is pretty close to the Kansas of the Kents, so his accent is right on. Kate Bosworth steals the show, however, as she has much more display of depth of emotion than Routh as Superman. Kevin Spacey is good as Lex Luther, but we still are looking at him in this movie and thinking it the character is Keven Spacy.

Review Title: Not as good as I imagined, but still stellar
Review: I think my expectations had risen to Star Wars-like levels for this movie. Just saw a press screening in Bangkok and have to say that I loved, loved it, but wanted more. I think it could have been trimmed by about fifteen minutes, needed a few longer shots of Superman kicking ass and saving people.. but what was there was amazing. The special effects were nearly flawless, Routh both channelled Christopher Reeve and made the part his own, Spacey owned and Bosworth did a much better job than I thought she would. Singer really laid a solid base for continuing adventures that I hope will be even bigger and better. I propose letting only Bryan Singer direct superhero movies from now on.

Review Title: Good effects, but ultimately emotionally uninvolving
Superman Returns! The movie in which Superman returns!
Review: Superman Returns! The movie in which Superman returns! He doesn't get a very warm welcome though… As always there are plenty of bad guys lining up to shoot at Superman! And as always they seem to think that even if their first 16 bullets have bounced harmlessly of his chest the 17th might be the one to miraculously kill him. It might seem pretty stupid for them to behave in this way, but I guess if they were smarter they probably wouldn't have chosen to live a life of crime in the only city in the world that has its own near-omnipresent godlike guardian. Now we all know that in the kingdom of bad men, the bald-headed bad man is king, so it's no surprise to see Lex Luthor up to his old, bald, tricks. Like all bald men, Lex Luthor is a bitter, evil, sinister, malevolent, twisted monster, but unlike your ordinary bald man, Luthor is also intelligent. Baldness and intelligence? - A deadly combination! And Luthor uses every ounce of his evil genius and every inch of his shimmering bald head to pester our hero at every turn! Superman is good-looking, strong, beloved by people everywhere and on top of all that (quite literally!) he has a wonderfully thick and lustrous head of hair! For ladies everywhere (and some men), he really is the full package. It's not hard to see why Lex would be jealous of Superman's package. There are photographs of it thrusting out at him from his morning newspaper everyday. It could even be argued that Superman should bear some of the blame for Luthor's behaviour; he's well aware of the impact that his package can have, and he does insist on rubbing it in Lex's face on a regular basis. It strikes me that Superman has a lot in common with a certain other character. A benevolent stranger sent from above who possesses incredible powers and a heart filled with nothing but love for all mankind, who finds himself persecuted by a handful of small-minded human beings. Someone who many people have devoted their entire lives to worshipping and following his teachings… Someone who has had a major influence on my own life and seen me through some pretty tough times, our Lord and saviour - E.T: The Extra Terrestrial. Unlike E.T though, Superman has the peculiar stroke of luck to fly halfway across the galaxy and land on an alien world only to find that it is populated by people who look exactly like him! What are the odds! There will be no dressing up as an old woman, hiding in wardrobes or fingering small children for Superman! The Superman project has had more than its fair share of controversy. I've even heard people complaining that Superman's 'S' wasn't big enough1 I actually thought that they were saying that his 'ass' wasn't big enough. I thought that the obese citizens of the USA were rising up in protest about the fact that there are very few fat superheroes. Then I realised - they probably can't 'rise up' for about anything! Except maybe to waddle down to McDonalds for another Big Mac! Ha ha ha! Fatties! Anyway nerds, put your nerdish minds at ease and rest assured that Bryan Singer has given Superman's S, and his ass, plenty of thought. He made the right choice with the S, and in the end he had his way with Superman's ass too. You might disagree with what he did, but you've got to admire his determination! Almost every big-name director in Hollywood has been linked to some kind of Superman project in recent years, with all sorts of wacky ideas up for consideration. An ugly Superman? It nearly happened - Tim Burton had plans to make a Superman movie starring Nicholas Cage as some sort of sullen, hunchbacked incarnation of the hero. It's kind of a shame that the we never got to see that version, because Nicholas Cage is obviously a huge Superman-fan. At least he's been given the chance to play the lead in the upcoming Ghost Rider film, so he's still grimly hanging on to the superhero ladder, even if he's only on the bottom rung and other actors keep stepping on his face as they clamber past him to box office success. What about a Superman film directed by Kevin Smith? Jay and Silent Bob Vs Superman! Just imagine, two hours of Superman talking to Jimmy Olsen about Star Wars! With Ben Affleck as Superman! And Jennifer Lopez as Lois Lane (renamed Lois Lopez at the actress's insistence! What a movie that could have been! Or how about Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Superman? When Superman is betrayed by his best friend Judas Olsen, he finds himself arrested and mercilessly tortured by Pontius Lexus! After being krypto-whipped to within an inch of his life, Superman is sentenced to death and forced to carry a glowing green kryptonite cross to the top of the hill where he will be crucified. And all the while a distraught Lois Magda-Lane is forced to stand helplessly by and watch the terrible injustice unfold. Harrowing.In summary, Bryan Singer abandoned his beloved X-men in the blink of an eye when the chance to direct Superman came along, and it's not hard to see why! Like any other red-blooded male, Bryan would much rather be behind Superman, putting everything he has into The Man Of Steel rather than doing the same to some anonymous leather clad man with a hairy back. All we can do is sit back and watch Bryan do what he does best… and it's quite a site to behold!www.chipremington.com - the movie review website that's better than a medium-to-hard poke in the eye

Superman returns! And in a style befitting a worldwide pop cultural icon easily recognizable from that distinctively red-yellow S-shield. Being stuck in production hell for almost 2 decades since the last movie installment, Bryan Singer has resurrected the Man of Steel for the silver screen, with an all new cast made up of fresh faces and veterans, even Marlon Brando, as Jor-El.In the hands of lesser directors, it will be tempting to make a Superman movie consisting of mindless slugfests, capitalizing Supes' invulnerability. Early drafts of a new Superman movie wanted to do just that. In the hands of unimaginative storytellers, this same invulnerability will also prove to be a bane, and therefore translate into a bore. Singer, based on his track record of his successful X-Men movies, in massaging multiple favourite characters and telling a compelling story, weaves his brand of magic into Superman, giving us not only what everyone would come to expect, but also an extremely important factor that makes this movie a winner - He humanized Superman. It's no easy feat, but he pulled it off wonderfully.Being the last son of Krypton, sent here like a messiah with powers to conquer, it is too easy to dismiss him as a boy scout on a mission to save the world from evil doers and natural disasters, and take for granted that he does what he does, because he can. Singer worked plenty of emotions into Clark, as well as Superman, in feeling the isolation of an alien in an adopted home, in always trying to pretend to be what he's not. You feel his pain that despite being around his loved ones, he will never able to always be there for them, because of his higher calling. There are scenes which makes you feel just that - Here's Superman, but OK, now that you're safe and sound, he has to go wrap things up, see you around later. A man yearning to shut out the outside world for quality time, but not being able to do so, for who he is.For someone invulnerable, Singer worked into the story, moments where his invulnerability wanes. And I tell you, even the most stoic critic of Superman, will feel pain and anger when that happens. It's as if Superman was a fellow human being, and seeing him subjected to the cruelties of nasty human thugs, just makes the blood inside you boil. You want to help, but obviously can't since it's just a movie. But you feel just that way.Brandon Routh, a relative unknown, filled the shoes well as the new Clark Kent/Superman. He bore some resemblance to the late Christopher Reeve, and at times even sounded like a youthful version of Reeve too. He did a commendable job in not being over-awed in a role which is under constant spotlight, and he is believable both as the Man of Steel, and as the bumbling Clark. I believe Routh will win fans approval worldwide for his portrayal, and it should endear him as another definitive cinematic Superman. I like the continuation of that bit through conversation that Superman doesn't lie.Kate Bosworth too did a great job continuing the film version of the tough as cookie Lois Lane, though here the character has mellowed somewhat because she's a mommy now. And it's always the little things that count, that she still smokes, still is a klutz at times, and an extremely nice touch to progress from the first two Reeve-Kidder Superman movies, she finally won her Pulitzer Prize, although it was for her story which stung with a criticism on why the world doesn't need Superman. (Look out for that explicit jibe about the Oscars too).And not to forget, Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor, criminal mastermind. Brain over brawn. It's interesting that Superman's greatest enemy has always been Lex, a mere human, but with a desire to eliminate Superman, and here, Lex wastes no time by lapsing into mindless monologues when going one up against our hero. Spacey's Lex is slightly different from Gene Hackman's, in that this one had a little more comedic flavour, though not always intentional. Spacey hams it up a bit, and made it somewhat scary - you'll never know what is going on inside his bald head. And there are some scenes which just crack you up at times, like the gig with the toothbrush (shan't say more).Lex's scenes were slow to begin with, but builds up into a megalomaniac's plot to become a landlord, again tipping the hat and staying true to the Hackman version. That means that there is no LexCorp, but that's just a minor upset. His array of wigs and headpieces are also included, and his female companion in Kitty Kowalski (Parker Posey) brought back shades of Eve Teschmacher from the 1978 movie, in having a thing for Superman and humanity in general. In reference to the earlier movies, Superman's ability to see through lies was also mentioned, and it worked into Lex's brainchild of an idea in having Kowalski put up as a sort of bait.Plenty of nice performances from the supporting characters, like X-Men's Cyclops James Marsden (does he hold the honour of starring in superhero movies from Marvel and Dc?) as Richard White, the Superman alternative of a man who can always be there for you, the family man with no cares of the outside world other than his own family, and Frank Langella bringing veteran clout as Daily Planet's Chief Editor Perry White. Sam Huttington's Jimmy Olsen was a natural too, rounding up our Planet's crew.Singer's Superman might just bring all fans out in the open, and declare that yes, that's the Man of Steel whom we have been so familiar with, taking his rightful place amongst the better cinematic versions of other superhero movies.

For a minute there, I thought I saw Christopher Reeve in Brandon Routh, the new Superman, and he wasn't even born when the original came out."Superman Returns" capitalizes on special effects that the original could not even imagine, almost thirty years ago. The story line is more over the top than the original, too. At first, I was wondering if I was going to like it, but it grew on me.For those of us who got to see the original TV series, there are occasional nods to it in lines in the script, which made me laugh out loud. The others around me never got the joke because they were too young to have seen it.Routh is excellent, as is Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane. Kevin Spacey. however, is deliciously great as Lex Luthor. A great job indeed. He enjoyed making this movie.I wavered between 7 and 9 for this movie as I was watching it, and settled on 9 for the inside jokes as homage to the original TV series and the superb performances by the central characters.

I agree with the previous reviews that the movie was shot beautifully and the special effects in this age of movie making was far beyond the previous Superman movies. However, the cast seemed a little uncomfortable with each other and a few catch phrases were overused. The comic delivery and expression for some of the funnier parts in the movie were spot on and Kevin Spacey portrayed Lex Luthor(comic-book, not Smallville version) perfectly. Brandon Routh was a decent Superman, but not even close to Christopher Reeves when it comes to believing him as an actual person/superhero. A previous review said it was better then Batman Begins and I have to strongly disagree, because the pairing of Chris Nolan and his ability to portray twisted darkness, and Christian Bale who can portray a schizo very well(American Psycho) was perfect. If you love the Superman story and have followed it through the ages, this is a movie to love, but if you aren't familiar with the previous Superman movies, it seems to drag and will not leave a good taste in your mouth.

Review Title: Superman Returns triumphs over all other versions.
Review: "Any defeat, however trivial, may be fatal to a savior of the plain people. They never admire a messiah with a bloody nose." H.L. Mencken I've always thought of myself like Superman: heroic, above the crowd, strong, selfless. The new film Superman Returns reveals that HE is just like ME: weak, self absorbed, righteous, mortal, and wobbly about women. The numerous spot-on insights in this latest installment are testimony that this film may even eclipse the best of Spiderman in exploring the effect being human has on the best of us.At a recent Hollywood party, I lost my hand for a second in a shake with Mike Tyson, the flawed former heavyweight champion of the world. I did speculate, however, that I had never before met someone who was once the best in the world. Superman (Brandon Routh), unarguably the best of us all, is the polar opposite to Tyson, but both are reduced from their lofty cultural thrones because they are not above acting foolish like the rest of us.Although not of our planet, Superman exhibits human vulnerability when he faces Lois's (Kate Bosworth) having a child (This kid is unworldly strong. Could the Man of Steel have acted like a real man that night?), and boyfriend but not husband (Hmm, what's she waiting for? a cape?). All happened when and, maybe because, Superman left for five years to find what was left of Krypton, the source of his only physical weakness, kryptonite.Director Bryan Singer brilliantly bandies about Superman's struggles with Lois and his combat with nemesis Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey), who has kryptonite and cave crystals from Superman's Fortress of Solitude to neutralize Superman and start a new continent on earth. Superman's skirmish with death at Luthor's hand has to be tough on an audience that sees its savior as immortal.The difference in special effects alone between this version and the first in 1978 (expertly directed by Richard Donner) is dramatic: Superman now flies like Baryshnikov, and the universe, from the titles on, looks as real as a night at the Palomar Observatory.But it is in the human struggle that Superman Returns triumphs over all other versions. It makes me think again about the messianic Christ motif and the notion that men, such as Lois's boyfriend, struggle with the idealized superman in the sub consciences of the women they love.Even Lex Luthor loses that battle.

Review Title: Nostalgia reins supreme in Superman Returns
Review: I relived my youth on the weekend. Superman Returns was amazing. Rich in colour. The story was strong with some comedy thrown in to keep it light. The world needs Superman and I'm glad the franchise has been reborn. It's a great first installment, and if this is any measure of what's to come, we're in for a great ride. Brandon Routh does a great job playing Clarke Kent and Superman. Kevin Spacey is a great Lex Luthor. The supporting characters were well cast. Metropolis hasn't looked this good, ever. ...credit to Sydney. The special effects are amazing, and it all adds up to a great movie. Only a few scenes could have been cut, but a terrific effort from Bryan Singer. X-Men's loss, Superman's gain!

I finally got to see Superman Returns last night. Keep in mind, however, that I grew up with the Donner films as a child, was and still am a big fan of the comics, and even wrote my undergraduate thesis on Superman. So I tend to view the character and the franchise with rose-tinted glasses.That being said, with the exception of Reeve's absence, I think Superman Returns trumps the Donner films in almost every way possible. I know, blasphemy, but true.Gone, for the most part at least, is the camp and the self-aware, winking-at-the-audience moments of the previous Superman Films. Like the first two X-Men, singer plays it straight with his hero, and rarely slips into parody. The film's visual style is also quite surreal, which is also a hallmark of Singer. Like New York in the Spiderman films, Metropolis is very much a real American city, but with subtle differences that lets the audience know this may seem like real life, but it's not. It's a world where a man can fly and lift cars over his head...oh, and where shuttle launches happen over major metropolitan areas! The writing is a bit crisper. The music-less bombastic, more subtle. But what about the performances? Kevin Spacey is by far a better Luthor than Hackman, who I contend was terribly miscast. Like the film, Spacey's Luthor lands somewhere between complete fantasy and real life. He's equal parts zany, over-the-top villain and meglomaniacal entrepreneur (much like Phillip Seymour Hoffman in MI:3). Bozworth holds her own as Lois Lane, but not enough to make you forget Margot Kidder. And Routh...well I'm a tad conflicted.I'll be honest in my assessment that I think Routh is a better Superman than Reeve. Reeve's Superman does everything so effortlessly, with little to no uncertainty or strain whatsoever. Routh's take is much different, and far more interesting. There's a grimace on Routh's face when he lifts something heavy. And when Superman lifts something as heavy as I don't know...say an island...it really takes its toll on him. Routh's Superman is one who's a bit more vulnerable, less certain of himself, and definitely more realistic.That beings said, Routh is a terrible Clark Kent. His interpretation of Clark is an abysmal, half-assed attempt at a Reeve impersonation. Reeve's Kent was a very socially awkward, bumbling man..but still a grown-up and a consummate professional. While he lacked grace, he was still a competent, confident reporter. Routh's Clark Kent is a man-child, completely inept and slow in every way possible (though this could be the writer's fault as well as Routh's). In a scene where Clark, Richard, Jimmy, Lois and her son are burning the midnight oil to meet a deadline, Clark comes across as the retarded older son of Richard and Lois, especially in one shot where a portion of beef burrito is hanging out of Clark's mouth.All together, this film is great, and what I believe to be the definitive version of Superman on film, or at least the Superman of my generation (I wasn't born until shortly after the third installment of the original movies). The film has flaws that's for sure, but like Batman Begins, it's got a bevy of awesome scenes and enough heart and soul to compensate for them. Things could've been a whole lot worse. Brett Ratner could've directed it.

I won tickets to the World Premiere and the after-show party to see this. Wasn't convinced that I would enjoy it but I loved it! Kevin Spacey was pure evil - the darkest Lex Luthor yet. And the new boy? Didn't he do well!! Hard act to follow but he came out unbloodied and creditable. I think people will find it hard to accept him at first - but he will win through.The film itself was amusing and definitely different enough to keep us on the edge of our seats. There were parts that made us laugh out loud, which is exactly how a Comic Book Movie should be.Go and see it. Enjoy!

Review Title: Very good film, Not the best comic version ever.
Review: I went for a screening last night with my co-workers to see a screening of superman returns and I must say it was a great movie. The plot and casting for the movie is good, but could have been great is singer would have put more depth into the film, like having Lois and superman actual have a relationship in the film and not hinting that they were (together) in the past. Also I thought there should have been more action in the movie for it being 154 Min's. I was surprised to see that Lex Luther played by Kevin Spacey lived up the personification of evil in stealing ever thing and planning he needed to lure out superman. He was a great lex Luther, but I still like Gene Hackman as lex. Also the added of Lois husband Richard White played by James Marsden was bad casting and acting on his part.The visual effects were amazing and almost as good as the Spiderman movies , but sometimes they look to cheesy like when superman is laying in the solar system and speeding around the earth. The movie should get an Oscar nomination for the score by John Ottman and the special effects award because god knows they spent enough money on it.The casting for superman was very well thought out because they needed an actor who didn't look to old, wasn't a big Hollywood star and wasn't bad at obtaining the necessary look and acting skill it takes to play superman. They found Brandon Ruth who is a great pick for superman. Also Kate Bosworth plays a respectable and intelligent Lois lane. The adding of Marlon Bando from archive footage was great because it gave the people who haven't seen the first superman movie in 1978, to experience Jor-le as superman's father and not adding him in a way that would'nt look to be repulsively and cheesy. Superman's mom Eva Marie Saint was a great choice as well.In all the Supreman Returns movie delivers another great story of the man of steel and a chance for millions of people to see him again in a new light, crafted wonderfully by Bryan Singer and company.

Review Title: Excellent, yet.... something's not quite clicking...
Review: I was as excited for this as anyone was, and I was not let down for the most part. The action sequences are some of the best in recent years and the special effects help too. Brandon Routhe does a fantastic job as Superman and Singer proves yet again he's brilliant when it comes to choosing the right people to play beloved characters (Jackman as Wolverine). Kevin Spacey does a decent job (not amazing but still quite good) as a Lex Luthor, but I do feel as if he tried to make him into something more comical than he should have. The score is something else, too. Amazing seems like the right word. Yet, I walked out of the movie feeling as if something just didn't quite click with me. I loved everything but there was just something that it didn't have. I have to compare it to other recent comic books and have to put Spider-Man 2 as the best. I can't say it's as good because it seems to change its attitude about halfway through the movie. Maybe it was me but I definitely recommend this film to EVERYONE.

I thought that after "The Matrix" trilogy and all the movies post Matrix from that time where the facts were presented in a violent light the success of such a film won't be so high, I thought that people is already full of this way of presenting some aspects. It is like you would write a text all in bold just to smash the attention. And I don't want to be misinterpreted , I don't want to suggest the "Superman Returns" is exceeding in violence by horror or tragedy.Is just you are waking up in a movie which seems like an Arcade Action Game.I'm not saying that the movie is bad or that this type of approach is not suitable for this type of movie, I just want to conclude that lately this seems to be the whole idea of many movies (Poseidon, Ultraviolet, ...) and it seams that the strategy is still working and the producers make big money with this one.Hmm, maybe the computer games are pushing the line far and far...

Review Title: The Superman Movie I've Always Wanted
Review: I am an avid Superman fan (comics, TV, movies.) The Superman mythology means to me more than it means to a lot of other people and I've never really been able to put a finger on why exactly that is until recently. Having grown up with a physical deformity (microtia on my right ear) I have always known what it was like to feel different, to feel like an outcast. My parents always told me that it wasn't how I looked (in Superman's case, where he came from) that would define who I was on the inside or how I could affect other people's lives. Superman is an outcast. He is different. That's how and why I identified with the character and clung to him for dear life my entire childhood. The Christopher Reeve films were my escape growing up. I loved them with all my heart and still do to this day. Between 'Superman 2' and today we really only had bits and pieces of Superman to wet our whistle but nothing that ever captured the essence of the character as well as the original films. 'Lois and Clark' was campy and 'Smallville' only gives us Clark Kent, not Superman. When the first words of 'Superman Returns' were written about on the net long ago, I knew that this would be THE MOVIE. The movie that would define movies for me. A character that I had always been interested in, a passionate director, and passionate writers and actors attached to the film. I grew impatient as I constantly read about and watched video blogs on the production of the film. I saw the teaser trailer on the head of 'Harry Potter and The Goblet Of Fire' and as soon as those classic words from Marlon Brando rang out: 'Even though you've been raised as a human being, you're not one of them' , I was moved to tears. The full trailers only made me more excited to see the movie and finally last night, I got to see it and yes......it was everything that I had been waiting for. An intense love story between Superman and Lois Lane. Clark Kent longing to be cared for like his alter ego is throughout the world. Lex Luthor back and badder than ever. And conflict in the Superman character that no one has ever seen before. Bryan Singer has given me the greatest gift I've ever gotten, a Superman movie with a heart and soul. This film is terrific in every way, shape and form. Acting, directing, photography, special effects, music. It's all there and at the end, I was left with a feeling of fulfillment yet I still wanted more. Superman is back and he is still relevant in today's world of 'bad ass', vengeance driven, dark heroes. Yes my friends, he is back and it looks like he'll be here for a lot longer than he already has.

Having seen it last night I have to say I was grossly disappointed. This movie is booooorrrrriinngah!! Brandon Routh makes an okay Superman looks and sounds wise it's just watching the movie is like watching sap drip from a tree. It's all about pacing. You can make a 3 hour movie feel like an hour an a half. This movie felt like Dune the 4 hour version except no where near as intriguing or complex or good. This movie cost 350 million to make and is in major trouble after this weekend as people yawn there way out of the movie theaters to go tell their friends who are waiting for the crowds to die down not to bother or to wait for DVD. Be one of the those friends and save 15 dollars!! The Problems: Kevin Spacey is playing John Doe from Seven mixed with Verbal Kent. He doesn't make the role his own. He is no real danger for Superman. You know the outcome. The movie, scene by scene, is predictable. Lois Lane has no personality nor does anyone else. Everyone seems bored including Superman,..oh and everyone who is watching the movie.I truly believe this is Bryan Singer's analogous coming out of the closet movie. After you watch it you will see what I mean.Thumbs down to the ground!!!

Review Title: Good Lord ... this movie is terrible
Review: There are three or so truly great sequences ... truly great.But, overall ... the thing is abominable. Superman (for the most part) and Perry (throughout) are understated and believable (I'd like to see both reprise their roles under a different creative team) ... but the rest of the cast is abysmal: Spacey is a scene-chewing twister ham, Parker Posey is an insipidly anachronistic plot device, Lois is a wooden cipher/six-grader-at-dress-rehearsal, Jimmy is an annoying twit, etc., etc.The plotting is juvenile, convenient and way-too-predictable; the CGI is unimaginative, muddy and way-too-obvious; the music is desperate, cliché and way-too-obtrusive. Etc., etc. and way-too-etc. This is one of the WORST films I have ever seen -- even though the "truly great sequences" are the BEST sequences I've ever seen in a superhero movie. They're not enough.In the end, it's nothing more than a big, goofy mess. That said, if you like the Reeve Superman movies ... you'll probably love this one, goofiness and all.

Absolutely perfect. Singer's Superman is a true revival of the super hero right movie ahead of the new Batman. The mixture of the original Superman with Brando, and the opening sequence with the Williams sound track was brilliant. It brought me back to the first time I saw Superman at the drive inn almost thirty years ago. The only thing that could have been left out was Parker Posey as Kitty, or at least less in the film of her would have been better. Spacey was an excellent Luthor. Singer's story was well worth the wait. The special effects for this movie were the best that I have seen on film since Star Wars Episode III. The tag line for the original Superman was "You'll Believe a Man Can Fly!". Well the new Superman only fortifies that position with the special effects laid out in this film. One can only hope that he stays true to this Superman and keeps the franchise strong and faithful!!

Review Title: Another incredible piece of work by Bryan Singer!!!
Review: I actually got to see this film at the premier last week and what a surprise. I expected some special effects and a decent story, but what I didn't expect was an incredible story, complex, easy to follow and overall entertaining. Amazing special effects that seemed to have all the "Block buster" elements rolled into one. Brandon does an amazing job as the "Man Of Steel"(I might add he is genuinely good hearted off camera too), very believable and well done. Kevin is the kind of villain you love, but hate as well. Truly evil and yet hilariously complex. Kate does a good job as Lois Lane, though not as fiery as I would have expected. Her performance is very believable and engaging. This film is without a doubt the MUST SEE movie of the year. We will be seeing again this weekend at IMAX.

what to say about this amazing piece of a movie? fantastic, amazing? the only thing that comes to mind is superman has returned.from start to finish the moment that theme started playing for superman you feel like you could fly the fx were amazing, the scenery and action captivating. next onto the acting never have i seen such emotions portrayed in characters acting in a comic book movie you had anger defeat love and many more. personally i was skeptical after being disappointed in Syngers last comic book movie(x-men 2).i felt like his last movie had too many characters and wasted time on a lot of them but not here the story flows from start to finish. if you love action and diologue you will love this! seriously there are no words to describe the feeling this movie leaves in you it's like a hunger to see it over and over again. thank you Mr. Synger we've waited forever but you made us believe. again.

Review Title: One of the best i've seen
Review: I just got home from the early screening and I must say, from the beginning to the end this was one of the best movies I have seen. It's amazing how much Brandon Routh resembles Reeves from the classic Superman movies. This movie has it all; drama, action, suspense, surprises, and more. The special effects were great and the acting was well done as well. I would have preferred to see an older Louis Lane considering this is five years after Superman II left off but she was portrayed very well still. If you enjoyed reading the comics as a child or watching the movies you will love this film. The movie wasn't rushed and the 2 and half plus hours seemed like they flew by. To every superhero/Superman fan out there this is a MUST SEE!

Brian Singer did an excellent job once again. The characters were on cue, the acting was superb, and the effects were incredible. He did a very good job at keeping the original theme. Kevin Spacey was excellent, Brandon Routh was just amazing, the whole movie was just incredible. It's like they continued from the other four movies, and Routh was just as good, if not better than Reeves. I don't think anyone could have pulled it off as good at Routh. It is the Batman Begins of Superman movies.Even the Trailer for Spiderman 3 before the movie was worth the cost of a ticket.

i have to say the trailers for this movie don't do the movie its justice. Take it from someone who actually works at a movie theater and sees the trailer pretty much everyday, this movie is way better than the trailer shows. yeah its almost three hours long but what movie isn't these days? the cast in its self is excellent. Brandon routh, who i have never heard of before, nails Superman. With the glasses on, he actually looks like Christopher Reeve. Kate Bosworth is great as Lois. Kevin Spacey is chillingly good as Lex Luthor. This whole movie is awesome. While there is some slow parts(and every movie has them) this movie has awesome effects, an interesting twist, and a great story

Hands Down Best Super-Hero movie EVER!!!! this is just a amazing film... in my opinion better than all batman, spider-man, hulk, fantastic four, daredevil films. action, romance, bryan singer. let's be honest, can he EVER disappoint us? i bought my ticket hours earlier before the film and was in the theatre a half hour before the movie... worth EVERY minute. if u liked the original superman movies and comic books, you probably shouldn't see this because a lot of superman fans were disappointed, but i loved this film. kevin spacey does a great job as Lex Luthor and same with brandon routh as his character being Super-man. my friend referred to this film as "butchered". i refer to it as the best super hero movie ever made, over taking my last favorite batman returns with the pengiun. i highly recommend this film. way to go Brian!!!

As someone who really liked Superman I and II (II more than the original)and thought Superman III was OK in certain parts, Superman Returns has too many problems and may be below Superman III, It was 2 1/2 hours, but the time moved along to me, it didn't seem to drag. The problem for me is in the story. It's too disjointed, the editing and story itself just had me saying "huh?" too many times.You can tell they edited out a lot of stuff, especially at the very beginning of the film and the farm scenes. Also at various times of the film it seemed like they made weird cuts and that messes with the flow or sense of it.Bryan Singer said he loved Superman. It didn't show in this script. Kind of a weak story.Brandon Routh is OK. Sometimes he looks like a CGI figure. Kate Bosworth is OK too, but I kept thinking of Margot Kidder's Lois and saying she's too young since this happened 5 years after II.All in all, I give it two thumbs down. Sorry to say. Just doesn't deliver. All the hype and waiting fails to pay off.

After reading some of the reviews about superman returns, I want to ask a question. Did you guys see the same movie as I saw? Because I loved it. It is definitely the movie of the summer. It has all the ingredients a superhero movie must have. I agree that Batman begins and spider man 2 were great movies but you really can't compare it to those movies because they are both different superhero movies. Superman returns is a great movie both technically and commercially. All of you who haven't seen it yet watch it with an open mind and you will love it.My Rating 10/10

Review Title: The Man of Steel is back!!!!...and hopefully for two more films!!
Review: I have been a Superman fan since I was a child...and growing up watching the movies in the 1980's, I was impressed...well, at least until Superman III and Superman IV. After seeing those horrible sequels I thought that there was no hope for the Superman franchise. However, I am here to say that there is hope..and that hope lies in the latest installment..Superman Returns. This movie was very entertaining..both visual effects and plot. The acting was great and new comer Brandon Routh filled the man of steel's boots very well. If you've been reading or listening to all the "Superman is gay" crap that has been floating around the internet..you've just been wasting your time. It's not true. I don't won't to give away the plot details, but trust me...Superman is far from gay. I really enjoyed this film. It made me feel like a little kid again. It definitely shows the human side of Superman through society's eyes in today's time. I hope you will all enjoy the film as much as I did!

Review Title: The single greatest embodiment of what Superman is all about, and one of the greatest films ever made.
Review: Being a lifelong, passionate Superman fan, as well as a great admirer of the original Superman films, I personally could not wait until the release of this new chapter in the saga. That said, it should not come as a great surprise that a couple of friends of mine and I went to see Returns as soon as was possible, and were fortunate enough to catch a 10:00 p.m. show time the night before the official release. And I, I who went in with such lofty expectations, was blown away with film. Simply blown away.This film represents what it really means to be Superman; why Superman is not only the greatest superhero yet conceived (or will ever be conceived), but the single greatest human concept ever conceived; and this film is immensely enjoyable: it is, cinematograpghically, beautiful; the special effects are flawless; the musical score is unforgettable; and the story is both timeless and unique in both its simplicity and its complexity. The casting was expertly done; Brandon Routh could quite easily pass for Christopher Reeves' younger brother, and Kevin Spacey is brilliant in a role that Gene Hackman nailed nearly three decades ago. All said and done, the film is perfect, or at least as perfect as any film really can be.Superman is a character who embodies everything that is great about mankind, which is uniquely ironic, considering that the character himself is not a human at all. Here is a character that was sent to Earth with nearly limitless powers, but with no real incentive to use them for the betterment of society. Despite that, though, Superman does contribute to society, using his powers for good, for the preservation of truth and justice, two of the most ingenious human philosophies ever conceived, just because this is the right thing to do. In a way Superman is a Nietzschean entity; indeed, his name comes from Nietzsche's own concept of the Uebermensch, the man who casts down traditional societal labels of good and evil to do what he knows is the right thing to do. And he is a sort of Robin Hood-esquire entity, helping those weaker than himself just because he knows that it's right to do this; Superman is the penultimate paragon of altruism, and for that reason alone he is the greatest of characters conceived by humans.Superman Returns demonstrates what it means to be Superman; what Superman means to society; what Superman means to you and me; and it does this all in an amazingly beautiful manner. Indeed, if you see one film this year, or, I'd wager to say, the next several years, see Superman Returns. See Superman Returns, and admire it for its beauty, for its plot, for its unforgettable characters, and then, after that, think about what it means to be Superman, and what Superman has to teach us all about ourselves, about society, about the world, and about everything else. See Superman Returns, and be a better human for it.

Review Title: Would any movie have been good enough?
If Spiderman 2 is a 10 and Batman and Robin is a 1, this is an 8
Review: Of the recent superhero movies, this was pretty darn good.I hold Batman Begins in the same category as the Punisher. These are movies where the special effects aren't a big deal, but the action itself is.Superman Returns is much like the Spiderman movies. Spiderman 2 is the gold standard in my opinion. (Spiderman 3 preview was great) The special effects are a major part and there is a love story. The effects were really good, love story...eh...could've been more with Clark and Lois. Thats the good stuff, not Lois and Superman.Oh, how about Cyclops himself being in this for most of the movie? Spacey was respectable as Lex Luther. Parker Posey was good in her role as well as Kal Penn, Kumar himself. (ha ha) Brandon Routh was a great choice, perfect...perfect casting.All in all an enjoyable movie, slighty long in the last 20 minutes or so.

Review Title: a film that risks for greatness but doesn't fly high
Review: I can't say that I'm very much the Superman fan, at least in comparison to some other superheroes that I'm interested in. The whole saga and the like just never seemed all that compelling. But on the other hand, as films, the first two (more really the first one) were rather well done pieces of solid, Hollywood entertainment. While I wouldn't want this review to have to keep comparing to the Richard Donner film, certain things did strike me just on Superman Returns' own terms. Director Bryan Singer has proved with his first two X-Men films that he's not ignorant in the ways of making compelling comic-book entertainment. But here he's got a bigger bill to fill here in terms of making a good enough script (er, one with as much fun as intelligence for the audience), and a cast, aside from the plethora of special effects and visuals at his huge-budget disposal. I wish I could just turn off my mind and just take in everything as it went. As I walked out my friend asked me 'well, what did you expect?' Not much, actually, but that much wasn't even filled to what could have been.It's a bit frustrating too to come across a blockbuster like Superman Returns, because you can sometimes feel the ambition that Singer and his crew and cast are going for. And Singer does provide some interesting, sharp visuals at times. And, as well, sometimes he doesn't. In terms of just action-movie terms it is very well shot most of the way, and fans of the Superman lineage looking for a fresh 21st century feel might be impressed. But, unfortunately, Singer's own ambitions become part of the film's drawbacks. Arguably, the film's near two hour and forty minute running time is overdoing it, and despite the information that the script requires in the last several minutes, one too many an ending is delivered. Certain smaller scenes showcasing, more or less to decent effect, Superman's overwhelming ability to do (predictably) anything to serve and protect at all costs, are also not really needed. And the basic concept at root in the film, even in the 'must-suspend-disbelief' world, is a little tough to swallow. Without revealing too much, under comic-book movie logic it falls a little, well, flat.Now, some of this could go by the wayside if the cast was at the best of abilities, or at least with the correct parts. I wasn't expecting another Christopher Reeve, of course, but it was hard for me to see what Singer saw (aside from his apparent liking of his connection to Clark Kent's awkward/bumbling in Brandon Routh exactly. He gives off a quality of being more wooden and bland than can even be stood considering the man of steel's impervious "human" qualities. Kate Bosworth does what she can, though only so much due to what her somewhat conflicted role requires. A couple of supporting actors are also a little disappointing from Frank Langella and James Marsden. And surprising still is Kevin Spacey, who only occasionally sparks up the kind of appeal that went with his past villain roles. So, in a way, maybe it just all added up to something that worked against what I was going into the film for- it is not bad on the side of technical astuteness and finesse. But that part has to come up against a script with some rough, scatter-shot patches, and a other elements that practically drag the film into a sluggish pace.All of this, however, will be moot for the legions of Superman fans, I would say it would be worth checking out the film at least once on the big screen. But for the non-fans or just the casual moviegoer, I'd say if you do proceed know it might not be the big summer smash that's been hyped to no end for over a month. C+

Like he did with most movie buffs, Bryan Singer first attracted my attention with "The Usual Suspects." The film had some directorial flaws that some of its die-hard fans occasionally tend to overlook - but it revealed true promise in its director."X-Men" was the next step forward - the comeback (or revolution) that comic book movies needed. Today, we've had a string of successful adaptations - "Spider-Man" 1 & 2, "Batman Begins" - but "X-Men" was coming only a few years after "Batman & Robin" had proved the genre dead. Singer resurrected it."X-Men 2" was even better - deeper, darker, and more mature. So when I read that McG had been bumped from the new "Superman" and the directorial reigns had been handed over to Singer, I was thrilled.Unfortunately, the end result didn't quite meet my expectations.I have never really been a fan of the original "Superman" movies - or even the character at all, really. You should bear that in mind while reading my review. I don't read comic books, but I am familiar with the more popular characters, and I have always cherished Batman the most because he's a regular human - with no special powers - trying to do good in the world. He uses his anger not to cause more pain, but to serve justice. Christopher Nolan channeled this superbly in "Batman Begins" - the dark fury of the character - and Singer tries to channel a similar "dark side" to Superman here, but it doesn't really work. It betrays the more lighthearted moments of the movie, and probably the biggest flaw of all is this: when you have an (almost) flawless guy like Superman as your main character in a movie, it's going to be hard trying to get everyone to relate.Singer is smart by trying to expose Superman's (or, really, Clark Kent's) romantic struggles - it shows the nerdy side of Clark: the awkward, fumbling man who wants so desperately to find approval for who he _really_ is in the eyes of his one true love, Lois Lane - but finds she has fallen for his alter ego, the macho Superman. This concept is the strongest element of Singer's film. Critics who have complained that the film is too heavy on romance are missing the point. How exciting would it be to see two hours of Superman - almost invincible - running around being destroyed by nothing before finally, at the end, meeting a true challenge in Lex Luther? The tender human side of this film is what elevates it above the other "Superman" movies, but there is still only so far you can go, because Clark isn't human. There's a classic oxymoron in the name "Superman": as his father (archived Marlon Brando footage) told him, he is not "one of them." He is not a man. He's super, all right. But he isn't a super man.Is this movie good? Yes. Will it please the die-hard Superman fans? Fans of the comics - perhaps. Fans of the original film series - probably not. It's much darker, longer and less humorous (although it still has plenty of comedic moments).I walked away from the film feeling fairly disappointed, simply because for a film that is over two and a half hours long and has so many moments that approach excellence (and even manage to channel the directorial influence of Stanley Kubrick, for goodness sake!), it never quite makes it into the realm of "Spider-Man," "Batman Begins" or even "X-Men." It's a bit of a step backwards for Singer - he seems overwhelmed with the big budget (his opening twenty minutes or so are really, really messy and had audience members in my screening asking what was happening - it's a bit too vague and random), and having to work with past material. It may have been easier for him - based on what he has achieved in the past - to merely start the series over a la "Batman Begins" and separate his project from the previous "Superman" universe.I admire what Singer has done here, in parts, but I think it's easy to see that the $200 million drove him to his brink - he's better working with more intimate productions.I'd recommend this film because it _does_ have some breathtaking moments. But I think with some better editing it could have been cut down to a smooth two hours or so - but even then I have my doubts as to whether the material could have held up. As I said above - translating the character of Superman through the screen is a hard enough task, simply because it's much harder to make his exploits engaging and have the audience relate to them. All considered, Singer did much better on this than most directors probably could have. He actually has created a few scenes here wherein a new side of Superman is revealed - and that is when the film is at its best.

Review Title: Two Good Scenes Doth Not a Good Movie Make
Superman Returns...and I'm glad he is here for good
