Review: I came into SR thinking it would be the 3rd best comic-book movie ever, right behind X2. And it didn't disappoint.Now, I'll begin with the cons first, cause I like being negative. The biggest con is the plot of the film. Lexs plan is not really that good and its been kind of done before. Another problem was that it dragged at the end a bit after Superman 'defeats' Lex, though luckily the last shot was great that it made up for it a bit. It also dragged in the beginning. It showed too much of Lex in the beginning in which I think it should of just stayed focused on Superman/Clark. My last con would be Parker Posey, who I KNEW would be bad. Her character was too predictable and her acting was just bad.Now, the pros. Acting, aside from Posey, was great. Routh wasn't as good as Reeves, but as close as you can get. Bosworth actually was good, though there some times where you just thought, "isnt she like 24 in real life?" Spacey was the best Lex yet. But the two that really made the acting great was Mardsen and Sam Hunnington. Hunnington brought GREAT comic-relief. This film has a good amount of comedy in it, and its mostly thanks to Sam. Mardsen does great acting because he makes the love triangle not seem so ordinary. Usually, you have an asshole be the love interest, or a guy with some issues. Mardsen beautifully plays this stand-up, nice guy who cares about Lois and will do anything for her. You actually kind of root for Lois to be with him. The pacing was good, could have been better, but not a problem. Action was great, especially due to the music. The action+music worked so well together.Overall: A great, fun film with some minor flaws. Def. check it out, and if you can, check it in IMAX 3-D.8.25 / 10 The extra .25 comes from the fact that it was a summer blockbuster that didn't disappoint, and I have to give it credit as this has been a summer full of disappointments.

Review Title: Routh and Bosworth becoming Clark Kent and Lois Lane
Review: This was quite a movie. I was a little worried about the new Superman actor, Brandon Routh. I was hesitant about going to the movie at first just because I am a big fan of the Superman movies with Christopher Reeves as Superman, and Brandon Routh in the previews and movie stills just did not look the part. However I am pleased to tell you that he did a great job filling in Reeves' shoes. It was almost like watching Reeves' all over again, just with enhanced cinematic technology. Routh and Bosworth really did their research into finding out how to act like Reeves and Kidder (Lois Lane). To all you viewers that have not seen it, enjoy! Because once you hear that Superman theme music in the beginning you will be pumped. It is quite a shocker.

Review Title: Fun at the movies: The Superman Experience!
Review: Often times I'll hear about a movie coming out, and I'll get very excited about it. I'll count down the days until it comes, I'll get tickets in advance, I'll buy into all the hype, I'll talk about it for days, and I'll get very tense and nervous as the theater lights dim and the movie begins. Unfortunately for these movies, I often walk out of the theater feeling let down and disappointed and wonder if maybe I should have just been born with out expectations.Having said that, Superman Returns is not by any means one of those movies. I'd waited months for this movie and got more pumped up about it than I'd been about movies in years, and while it may not have been the single best movie of its kind I've ever seen, it was the most fun I'd had at the movies since...oh I don't know...The Lion King. By far. This movie is everything I'd hoped it would be and more. I loved it. And it really wasn't just the movie itself. While absolutely first rate, it's not quite up to the standard Batman Begins and Sin City have set for me as far as the comic book movie genre goes, but a lot of what made Superman Returns so wonderful was the experience.I saw the movie in IMAX 3-D, and if you're going to see the movie, that's the way to go. The IMAX experience really immersed us into the movie and made it that much more fantastic and powerful. The 3-D scenes were terrific, and the crowd was wonderful. They actually clapped and cheered during the movie, they laughed and responded enthusiastically at all the right moments, and many people stood up just to cheer as the end credits rolled. Superman Returns is a strong reminder of why we love going to the movies and how fun and exciting the cinema can be.For anyone reading this that hasn't seen the movie yet, I highly recommend going now while the vibe is still strong, but either way this is not a summer movie to be missed. It is everything you love about Superman and everything you've been waiting for to hit the big screen. Enjoy!

I enjoyed the film a lot and think kids eight and older will enjoy it immensely. Far and away it is the best Superman movie so far of the entire franchise, being just a bit better than the first one with Christopher Reeve, which I also saw on opening day. The movie plays a little with some aspects of the comic's continuity, which comic fans won't like. And the movie has some plot flaws. However, the feeling of being there and sharing in Superman's powers really works. And, unusual in superhero movies, the dramatic relationships and story told really do hang together and create suspense for me.I also like the way the movie shows how there is no easy answer to a lover's triangle when all three people are decent and good people. Some critics will blast it for predictability and simplicity, but I don't think this is the case. Others will say there was no satisfying resolution to the issues the movie raises for itself. While this may be more valid, how many lovers' triangle situations in real life end in a neat and satisfying resolution for all concerned? Yes, there were flaws, and you will hear all about the flaws. For example Superman was gone five years and Lois Lane did not have a child when he left, but now has one who appears to be about nine years old. Or how about that Superman left for five years, returned, and still appears to be in his early 20s.The film's strongest aspect was the great acting by Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor. Spacey brings so much intelligence and sanity to any role he takes that he lifts it up. For the movie's plot suspense to work at all well, you have to believe in the villain's motivation and that he would act as he does given the situation. All of the actors turned in solid performances as well. The story was not really about Lex Luthor. It turned out to be about Supes and Lois's relationship, a fact that I bet surprised even the writer and director once the shooting of the film began.In this Superman, not every plot element was wrapped with a pretty bow tie, but that alone really worked for me and gives me much to think about. I congratulate the director and writer for letting the story go where it seemed to want to, rather than forcing it into just the superhero-fights-supervillain routine. That's what the first one in the series did, despite the fact there was another story there needing exploration too, and why I think this film superior to it.

Brandon Routh went beyond what was expected and portrayed Superman to the T. Kevin Spacey's "Lex Luthor" though was quite a let down. Lex Luther, in the comics, is a criminal mastermind, being one of the smartest men in the world. The guy became the president for god sake. I just don't see this new Luthor having that potential. What should had happened with this movie is Singer should had done is homework gone to Dc and asked what is the biggest superman story you got. A simple Death of Superman movie could had been great. Shoot you could had done a trilogy with the next two films being the return of superman. Instead we got great actors, with a crappy, long, boring storyline. Did i mention it was boring. Ohh not to mention, what horrible twist there were in the movie, not only did they completely destroy the whole Superman Story, but they were completely unrealistic. But the film wasn't all that bad, it did have its moments, by which i mean 1. Where superman makes his "return" appearance. The Special effects somewhat helped me forget about how boring it was. Superman did not hit one bad guy, what they should had done was have Superman knock out Singer, for doing such a bad job, and wasting all the actors time and mine.

Have you ever sat through a movie where the performances were dead on, the music and mood seemed perfect, the special effects were astounding, and the extremely long running time seemed not so long, but then left the theater wondering why it left you feeling nothing and wanting so much more. Welcome to Superman Returns. I attended the 10 p.m. night before showing not with high hopes, but confidence that with a mastermind director at the helm that this would not let down. Well, it really did. First off, I will give kudos to Routh and Company for doing all they could to make this great. He really was Superman. Now, what went wrong? It all starts with action. Now I know that Bryan Singer has brought a great human side to his previous comic book attempts, and he did it with dignity and style. But every comic book fan knows they also drool at the thought of a great action scene so they can watch their favorite hero do his thing. Well, you see the main two action scenes in the previews, one being the plane, and the other, the ship. Both disappoint. They feel short and boring and without tension as to what will happen, they end. We never get to see the man of steel fight anyone, all he does through this movie is pick up heavy things and move them. After this has happened so many times, it just gets redundant. The questions remain unanswered, as if the movie had no point but to make another movie. The loose ends are not tied up, only more are created. I don't want to give anything away because so many people want to see this film, and I don't want (not that it will) my opinion to distract them from seeing it, but the film, for me as well as the people I went with, just felt empty. Not much made sense, the action was boring, Luthor and Superman were face to face for about all of 5 minutes, and the movie is two and a half hours long. I don't want to go into more than this but I will say in summation that I just felt like nothing happened, nothing was resolved, and I just left that theater feeling empty and bored. I'm hoping to see it again just to make sure that maybe I was too tired or it was hot in the theater and it affected my judgement, but I doubt that was the problem. I think most of you will be leaving the theater the same way.

I just saw Superman returns and since there's no room for many words let alone a comment let me sum up this movie briefly and concisely. If you're a Superman fan.... through and through loving every bit of variations that Superman has donned the last few decades get ready to love this movie. I squeaked and loved every bit of it. If you're looking for a no brainer with lots of cool cgi and action then rent King Kong. Superman returns is the 3rd installment that Donner should have made and Singer has done a phenomenal job. I'm going to see it again tomorrow in hopes of absorbing more of the greatness. All I can say for those who thought the movie dragged on..... well too bad this is Superman and all that he is. He's in love with Lois Lane, he overcompensates by trying to take on the world and yeah he has a bit of a hero complex. This was awesome, awe inspiring and a great time Singer has taken a legend in comic fandom and brought it to life in a way that makes me feel like tonight I was a part of something huge. Maybe how movie goers felt in 1978 when the original Superman was released. A must see for any fan or fellow Supehead.

It is so cool to see the Man of Steel back in action. Superman Returns is definitely one of my favorite movies of the summer. Everything seemed so perfect about it...the special effects, the lighting, the sets. Everything was better than I had expected, and I had expected a lot. It will be pretty hard to back it up. Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest has a whole lot of competition for the #1 spot at the box office. I can't even really tell you how amazing it was, and you'll just have to go and see the movie to know what I mean when I say amazing. I think that after you go and see Superman Returns that you're favorite super hero (if not already) will change to Superman. GO AND SEE IT AND YOU WILL BE SATISFIED!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Review Title: It was great.  It's good to have him back.  When do we get more??
Review: I thought the movie was great. It was funny leaving the theatre--people had so many different reactions. I didn't know what to expect. I didn't know if it'd be more along the lines of Batman Begins or on the cheesy side like Spidey. It was 2 and a half hours long, yes. But I felt like the movie moved along more like a book at times--maybe more dry than some people expected. Some people were obviously underwhelmed because of that, but I had the exact opposite reaction. I just loved it. This could be completely dorky and a bit stupid or sentimental, but it seemed like the movie didn't just want to be hi-I'm-superman-fix-problem-fly-away over and over and over. Granted, all superhero movies have to have that. But it also seemed like there were slower moments simply to allow you to just sit back, satisfied, and think "Yeah. That's Superman." There were times that I wished I could have had just a few extra typical heroics or soppy moments to give me goosebumps, but overall I really enjoyed it. I can't wait to see what happens next.Superman Returns is a befitting title. It's not Superman Begins. It's Superman Returns. And that's how I felt when I left the theatre. It just feels good to have him back.

Review Title: Quite simply the best Superman film to date.
Review: If you can't already tell by my display name I am a huge Superman fan. But don't go misunderstanding that thinking it works to this films advantage, if anything it works against it.It knew it would be an extremely difficult task for anyone to make a film about the boy in blue that lived up to my standards, but Bryan Singer did it. Brandon Routh was cast perfectly as the man of steel, his simple mannerisms and lifestyle embody that of the character and the presence he brings to screen is tremendous. His acting is beautifully done and remarkably reminiscent of Christopher Reeves own performance in the original Donner films.The movie itself was tremendous, each character cast and played (in my opinion) perfectly. I can't think of a better actor than that of Kevin Spacy for the role of Lex Luthor and Kate Bosworth did an amazing job as the rigid but vulnerable Lois Lane. I was originally very concerned about the story, but I guarantee you that the film was placed in the best of hands. Bryan Singer and his writers deliver an amazing film that (no matter how much you think you know) keeps you guessing and leaves you breathless and completely satisfied. Take a very hard to please fan's and film aficionado's word for it. This movie is a must see and a tremendous contribution to the Superman franchise.

Review Title: Its all about the Movies again!
Review: I have been a fan of movies all of my life. From the early horror that my father made me watch to so of the strangest things that to this day give me nightmares.I 've been a fan of good and bad, but I have to say this movie has done what most people forget. It has helped lots of people want to go back to the movies. To relive that feeling of youth, which brought you to the movies as a child to see things only you can imagine in your mind.Now, although its hard to live of to Christopher Reeve, this movie was not about who directed it, or about who criticized it, it was about a film that need to be made. I, like most of you, happen to love this movie, and yet there are things I hated about it. But at least it was on the big screen so that I was able to judge for myself.This movie made people in my showing stand up and cheer, while my cousin fell asleep half way through. To each his own. I would recommend seeing this movie if you want to enjoy the movies all over again.

Review Title: A tear fell out of my eye.......
Review: When the opening credits rolled and they played the original Superman music with the amazing visuals, I knew I was watching the right movie. Then it just took off. Everything from Brandon Routh's performance to all of Singers directorial decisions. And to think I am more a X-Men Fan. I think its about time to start getting back into DC. They are on there way. With a successful Batman movie and now Superman. They are choosing cinemas finest directors. Directors who know style and grace at the same time. Congrats Mr. Singer, you might be the guy to bring the Oscar back to comic book movies with Superman Returns.Christopher Nolan and Bryan Singer are Directing Gods!!!

Review Title: Leave out the comparisons and cheer with the rest of the audience.
Review: Reviewers compared the leads across various Superman films, compared story lines, compared departures from the original Superman. I just compared the spontaneous cheers from the audience during this film to those during the Reeve movies and those that I felt as a child with the Reeves television version in the 50's. This movie had children, adults and seniors cheering, clapping and rooting for Superman as if he were real. We were quiet or laughing otherwise - totally absorbed. And there's no doubt about the special effects being some of the best that I've seen in any film to date. If you've ever spent an hour with your eyes racing from panel to panel or had your heart race with the idea of Superman or even just wished that humans and America could be as pure of heart as Superman then go, get your fix of goodness, and cheer with the rest of the audience.

I guess this story takes place after superman II,which is fine by me as III and IV blew (save Richard Pryor). I would have preferred more fist fights between superman and a villain of equal physical ability but i'm also a goof and often wrong, maybe for this installment the less is more thing works. I thought this movie was great (except Lois Lane, Kate whoever was a bad choice,they should have watched some Kidder game tape as it seemed Routh did for his Kent. thank god they kept the classic John Williams theme too! i was afraid they were using the classic theme in the trailers to play on the nostalgia card but i was pleased that it was used through out the film not to much and maybe a bit too little. I liked Spacey as Luthor but i wish they'd have kept Hackman and keeping Brando as Jor-el was cool. nine out of ten.

Review Title: Met each and every expectation and then-some
Review: I gotta say, I went into this movie with the highest of expectations. And one plot point withstanding, it met them all. When I first heard most of the casting I was disappointed, I couldn't see Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor, or Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane. Both of them blew me away. Brandon Routh made a fantastic Clark Kent, though his performance as Superman left me with a little to be desired. All in all however, I was most impressed by our young reporter wannabe Jimmy Olsen, Sam Huntington somehow managed to steal each and every scene he was in. The story concentrated a lot more on the tension between Clark/Supe and Lois Lane, rather than the hero/villain action involving everyone's favorite hero and Lex Luthor. But this seems to be a growing trend among the super-hero movies in general. And it was in no way a bad thing.One final point, the Spiderman3 trailer rolled, gotta say it's the first time I've seen it, and unless I've missed something big, I think it's the first time it's been shown. Gotta see that one too.

Review Title: Not only bad but disgraceful to the Original
Review: It's five years later. Superman leaves all the responsibility of Earth to make some vague excursion to Krypton. This poor explanation is used about 45 minutes into Superman Returns. This is just one of the many problems this film has.Where to start? It all starts with Brandon Routh. He wasn't all that bad. For that matter Kevin Spacey wasn't all that bad either. But Kate Bosworth and Routh have no chemistry. None. They act like high school kids instead of two adults who have met before. Parker Posey continues her terrible comic book acting performances (See Blade: Trinity) here as well.The kid, he's a special kind of bad. Jar-Jar Binks and Ewok bad. Much like the plot which is very similar plot to the first one. Lex Luthor wants to build his own continent using crystals from the fortress of solitude. This would be fine for a 90 to 100 minute movie. Unfortunately this takes 2 hours and 37 mind-numbing minutes to resolve.

In my many years of writing I have never felt so compelled to compose as I do today. Just hours ago I witnessed what may become the best movie of the summer. I say this with full knowledge of the offerings the box office produced. I was left high and dry during Poseidon, completely in the dark during Davinci Code, and I only enjoyed The Break Up. X-3 was, without a doubt, a fine flick, but left too much to be desired. For the seven of you who haven't seen it (thrice) I won't reveal anything, but I will recommend to take some time to watch the movie. It is highly stylized and worth the $10. On to the main event which, as I said before, compelled me to write. Superman Returns entered our minds with the briefest of teasers almost a year ago. It came and went, with rumors of Nick Cage playing the Man of Steel, and even one vicious lie about a CG Christopher Reeves. I do not know offhand the name of the newcomer who wears the red and blue mantle, but he wears it well. If you were to watch the original Superman and then catch the new version, you would be amazed at how well the transition comes off. I won't go into any details because I honestly think the movie needs to be seen fresh. I hate reviews that taint the experience, and I will not fall into that level of disparity. What I will do is give enough teasers to entice even the most comic-book-hating individual. For the....oh, who am I kidding? No one on this list will be unfamiliar with the caped savior of Metropolis. Superman, aka Clark Kent (mild-mannered and a bit dorky), is the last son of Krypton, a planet doomed to destruction by...well that part doesn't even matter. Whether it was a cataclysmic supernova or a computer gone haywire or an intergalactic plague, Kal-El (come on people, Superman's Kryptonian name) was shipped off via Galactic-Express to Earth where chance had him raised by two farmers. He was the ultimate illegal immigrant, but unlike many he earned his keep. And then some. Superman is almost 70 years old, as the comics go, but he is the most revered out of the millions (yep, that many) heroes out there. His powers are seemingly limitless and he has a slew of baddies waiting to put him down. His rival of all time, and the best bad guy in comic book history (Sorry Gandalf) is Lex Luthor, played by Kevin Spacey. I was worried, nay, terrified at the prospect of the soft spoken Spacey taking on a role best done by voice talents and Gene Hackman. Without giving it away, my fears proved unworthy of being thought. The movie will be incorrectly labeled as a continuation of the old movies, or worse yet, a comic-book summer thrill ride. I am here to say that this movie is (apart from being documented fact and worthy of a best picture nod) an homage to the greatest superhero ever created (and by two Jews, no less. We really are behind everything). The level of respect in this movie is on par with the level of reverence given to George Washington. In a summary: SEE THIS MOVIE. If you haven't seen it, go now. I mean literally this second. If you have seen it, go again. You'll want to know this one by heart. I understand it has its faults, as all movies of this scope must, but I came away with a mind blown. PS - Don't ask the inevitable question: Who would win, Superman or Jack Bauer? It's a case of an unstoppable force meeting an immovable object. Time and space collapse, yada yada yada.PPS - Don't ask what would happen if it were Superman vs Chuck Norris because that's a ridiculous question. Everyone knows Chuck Norris IS Superman.

The movie it's self was fantastic! And this from a girl thats read every Superman comic her dad ever owned. The actor, Brandon Routh, fits Supmerman AND Clark Kent to a T, the awkwardness that Clark is suppose to have is right on the money and it's easily forgotten. And since I didn't read IMDb daily, everything was a surprise to me, which made it all the more enjoyable. But do keep your eye out for the 2 guys Lex Luthor kicks out of the museum, they're the writers of this new edition to the Superman epics. Also the bartender in the beginning of the movie is the old Jimmy. Not a big Superman fan, never read the comics? Oh well now's the time to get caught up with everyone else who's fallen in love with the world's best hero, who saves us for a dog eat dog world (hehe, literally in this movie!). Kevin Spacey does an incredible job as well and brings humor to the part of Lux Luthor at times where'd he'd just plain scare the pants off of the 6 year old next to me. Maybe it helps that I saw it at the Galaxy theater next to highland mall, their's is equipped with digital projectors - making the movie in HD quality with the new Gemini cameras the movie was shot with. Over all a great summer movie that knocks the pants off X-Men 3, Bryan Singer you done good.

This installment of Superman starts out very shaky, skipping time periods and playing catch up with an audience that either knows the old series or doesn't really need to.Some might say that this was important to make the movie have weight and back story, but it's not like you need much besides Kryptonite, invincible body, and available alien technology that's able to be stolen.After this 15 minutes at the beginning, though, the movie starts moving very well. There's a one liner after a plane sequence that is pretty amazing.I really liked the atmosphere of the Daily Planet, and I thought Routh did a good job as Clark. What I don't understand is how the movie never felt like it gave either of his personalities distinct moments on screen.Ebert commented that he seemed to be monosyllabic, and this is probably because when he had a real line to deliver (one in the opening and one at the end) they were VERY poorly said.I had no problems with anyone in any particular role, and the effects were great. But the movie started shakily and ended a bit overlong as well.I don't know... I liked it, but I didn't love it.

I just got back from seeing this film, and WOW! This movie is certainly an excellent depiction of what we would want Superman to do. His abilities are shown off several times over, and each time he does them you're mouth just gets wider and wider with either that stupid grin that a five year old gets when he gets his new bike, or the large void in your mouth due to how far open it is. This is just the cinematography, however, the plot itself, whereas it is simple, includes some obvious no-brainers, but every one with a little twist that makes you at least second guess yourself until you are shown what you originally thought.There are also great uses of metaphors in this movie. Without giving anything away, there are quite a few points that show what the characters are thinking or what the movie is trying to display without it being thrown into your face.The acting in this movie is spot-on as well. Brandon Routh plays the perfect Clark Kent, with that awkward clumsiness that I personally thought only Christopher Reeves would ever be able to do as Kent. The surrounding cast also plays a great role, with Kevin Spacey playing a truly diabolical Lex Luthor, who is definitely darker than the Gene Hackman that played Luthor in the previous series. All in all this movie is worth every last penny and I checked at the door on my way out to make sure that I didn't owe anything more, because I felt like I cheated the movie by not paying more. Even if you don't like comic book movies, this is a MUST SEE!

When I went to see this movie I had read all of the bad reviews so I was fully prepared for whatever nonsense I might have to deal with. I agreed that Bosworth did not look right as Lois Lane but after watching the film for a while completely forgot that she didn't visually fit the role so I feel she gave a convincing enough performance. If you're new to this film, it starts off as a continuation of the first two films that were made in the late 70's, early 80's. Superman just gets back from visiting his home planet. You might read some reviews that complain about this movie not explaining why he was gone for five years but the film explains clearly (in a sentence or two) that when Superman gets to his home planet it was just a graveyard. So he did nothing. There's nothing to talk about. His 5 years of absence is probably because his home planet was light years away. In fact, I'll bet it was about 5 light years away. Anyhow, while he was gone his enemy Lex Luther avoided going to jail because Superman failed to come to court to testify. Lex Luther is now out and about devising an evil plan. So here's where the movie begins. On to my review.My quarrel with this film is it does not make you believe it. Personally, as a viewer, I can respect a film that makes me lose myself in it. Seeing as this is a Hollywood blockbuster (think King Kong) you will find yourself in the middle of a few things you might find ridiculous. While entertaining for their visual/action effects, these things keep reminding you that you're watching a movie. Anyways, the thing this film DOES do is make you feel it. Strangely, this film seems to build its grounds more on its romance than its action. Not what one might expect from this film. Every dramatic scene of Superman saving this or that seems to try to communicate with the viewer just how important Superman really is. If you're one for feelings this movie might push you emotionally but if not you'll likely find yourself sitting in a bunch of over-dramatic rescue scenes with a hand full of social drama and mushy romance thrown in. It even has a soap opera twist to boot. (p.s. special effects are great) In summary, yes, Routhe could have done a better Kent. Yes, this film moves a little slow (put my 4yo son to sleep). But overall I found the film to be entertaining and emotionally gripping. I think everyone will be able to enjoy Kevin Spacey's performance as Lex Luthor. Some will even walk out of the theater very happy they made the trip to see this film. I did.

When the credits for this movie first swooshed across the screen my father looked at me and said "I got chills" I nodded and said "So did I" the rest of the movie proceeded flawlessly . The world has a new Superman and his name is Routh. Hackman is a nice guy but Spacey plows him outta the water; I saw the insanity and evil that define Luthor in Spacey something I never saw in Hackman. Kate Boseworth did everything a good Lois should do and more she amazed me. The plot? NO spoilers but it couldn't have been better every angle of the mythos was covered with a stop this movie teaches you everything about Superman you ever need or want to know. There are references to the first two that make you laugh and new aspects added that make you squeal with joy. The TV spots stated that our greatest hero returns June 28 and this movie removes all doubt of whether or not he is worthy of that mantle. After so many years without him, without seeing the famous red cape in popular culture mainstream Superman Returns and everyone will remember why they or their brother tied a red towel around his neck and ran around the house saying "WHOOSH!"

Review Title: Outstanding special effects, good acting, but...
Review: ...trying far too hard at every point to be like the original 1970's film. The Superman mythos has moved on since then, becoming more sophisticated and subtle. The relaunch of the comic in the 1980's set the stage for Lois & Clark, Superman the Animated Series, and of course Smallville. In every one of these recent incarnations, Clark represents the real person and he is consequently portrayed as a likable, competent guy in his own right who gains Lois' friendship and admiration without super-powers. The Superman personna functions to allow Clark to help people with his powers while protecting his personal life (and thereby his loved ones). This all is relevant because the Clark in Superman Returns is the same impossibly meek character people will remember from Christopher Reeve's portrayal. Can anyone buy that the movie version of Clark is a successful reporter at a major newspaper? The movie left me wondering what is the point of Superman even being Clark? Brandon Routh to his credit makes Superman look amazingly sexy and cool, but Clark should be the one Lois takes home at the end of the day (not a spoiler, just a figure of speech). Fans of the TV shows may find it hard to relate to the film Superman.Anyway, the leads are very solid actors but their youth (since the characters should both be about 40) was very distracting for me. Re-using Brando's image and voice was lazy and slightly obscene. Copying dialogue word-for-word from the Donner film in serious moments was just appalling, although it would have worked for a few lighter moments. The central plot had wonderful potential but was harmed by some loose ends and a few 'Hollywood blockbuster roller-coaster ride' moments which belie the otherwise somber tone of the film. I'm glad I went to see this opening night just for the spectacle of Superman in action. Do not go, however, expecting a seamless movie on par with X2 and Batman Begins.

I'm not going to ruin the movie for anyone with gratuitous spoilers, so don't be alarmed... this is just an opinion.I like superhero movies (no more than the average person though). I've seen most of the recent ones (my favorite, thus far, being Batman Begins). Superman Returns is a film of epic proportions that isn't very epic at all. To put it lightly; it drags... endlessly.I can't account for comic book fans (especially the big Superman fans), but I think I can safely say many of the average moviegoers will find Superman Returns to be bland, insufferable, and pointless. The direction by Singer is nice, while the story and script are by-the-numbers. The film takes not a single chance and doesn't seem to believe that its audience might be in the mood for something fresh and different. It does what every superhero movie has done previously...but without much style. It's sad when a movie like this, a movie that cost so much to make (energy and money), becomes such a waste... a perfectly tedious misstep.

This movie wasn't as bad as I thought it would be but it also wasn't as good as I thought it would be. (If that makes any sense at all). My primary concern was the same as everyone else's: will Brandon Routh be able to fill Christopher Reeves' boots? As it turns out he fits them a lot better than I expected. I was very skeptical as to whether or not Routh was going to be able to pull off the double roles of Superman & Clark Kent. But he does so very well. Routh seems to bear a stunning resemblance to the Kent that Reeve created. He seems to maintain his nervous canter and stature. However, his portrayal of Superman seemed to be that of his own. Routh introduced a darker side of the Man of Steel and I don't know if that was necessarily a good thing.The film itself was pretty slow paced, and the editing could have been done a lot better. I was glad on the other hand that the movie didn't do a complete recap of Superman's origins as I had anticipated. The plot line, I will not get too far into because I don't want to supply any spoilers, but I must say that it was the most disappointing part of the movie. The cinematography and the special effects used in the film were definitely up to par. While seeing 'Big Blue' in a realistic flight pattern was invigorating, the action and special effect scenes seemed to be so far and few between that it almost made most of the scenes anti-climactic.All-in-all, I felt that the film itself lacked the intensity that it needed. It lacked the fierceness that a new and re-vamped Superman movie should have. It seemed like a lot of drama and botched attempts at character development, and only a little bit of action. With a budget as big as this movie had I asked myself: where did it all go? I went into the theater with my mind ready to compare Superman Returns with Batman Begins, and it's no wonder that the 'Caped Crusader' is still my favorite Superhero.

Made up for the first 4. Even though it didn't follow the comments, Routh did a great job of living up to Reeve's standards. Everything about the movie was in sync with the first too, everything down to the credits. For Supe fans and non-supe fans alike, this movie is worth seeing. Kevin Spacey is one of the most believable Lex Luthors next to the one played on Smallville. Routh plays Clark and Kal-El with perfection. I'm not going to give away any spoilers here. Brian Singer did a great job of answering the question of weather the DC world needs a Superman or not. It brings back Jar-El from the old classics and it has a great effect on the film itself. As far as comic book movies go this did it. It got all the mythology and the stigma of big blue into a two and a half hour package. 10 out of 10.

About the worst I can say about this film is that I wasn't completely, utterly blown away by it. It didn't totally skyrocket above my expectations. That said, it is definitely a worthy followup to Richard Donner's original, and a very good film in its own right.The new cast did a good job of filling the shoes of their predecessors. I'll take a moment to discuss the most scrutinized casting choice: Brandon Routh, a few awkward moments aside, assumes the role much as Christopher Reeve did. Rather than attempt to be larger than life and behave like an icon, he prefers to play it with more humanity and personality. He never comes across as a "comic book" character. Reeve has owned the role for 28 years at this point; no other actor has been able to earn it up to this point. But Routh put in his dues and he deserves it. He is Superman now. Consider the torch passed.Kate Bosworth plays Lois Lane much as you'd expect. She's tough as nails, a career woman, and is more than just a damsel in distress, but motherhood does add an interesting new dynamic to the character. James Mardsen is good as her live-in boyfriend/fiancée/whatever, and doesn't ever cover his eyes up. Oddly enough, the only original cast members I really found myself missing were Jackie Cooper (Perry White) and Marc McClure (Jimmy Olsen). Their roles are the only ones I felt weren't recast well. The new Perry White was flat and uninteresting, and the new Jimmy Olsen is the Jar Jar Binks of this film. Hopefully they iron out the wrinkles in their performances by the time the inevitable sequel comes around.I was a little apprehensive when I read that Bryan Singer was going to be very faithful to Richard Donner's original vision, since it would be very easy for the project to descend into rehash. But rather than use Donner's film as a template to plug his own actors and lines into, Singer instead fashions his own film with a unique tone, albeit with frequent nods to the original. It's hardly a copy of the 1978 film, but it never misses an opportunity to throw in a few classic chestnuts for the fans. Also, look for Jack Larson and Noell Neil (Jimmy Olsen and Lois Lane from the '50s television series, respectively) in small roles. To further tie this film in with the original, John Williams' original music cues are arranged into the score for great effect, and the opening credits are a modernized version of the classic sequence.The special effects in this film are incredible. There are some action scenes where Routh's performance is mixed with a CGI Superman, but the animation is impeccable enough that it's occasionally genuinely difficult to distinguish between the two. And this isn't Spider-Man. The artists didn't have the luxury of a hero who wears a full body suit and a full-face mask. They had to convincingly recreate Routh's face, hair, and expressions, and they do an admirable job. This is the absolute peak of Hollywood's current computer imagery capabilities.I won't say much about the plot. Luthor's scheme echoes the original Superman film: destroy old land (and the people on it), build new land over it. But that's where the similarities end. This time around, the real estate aspects of the evil plan are almost inconsequential. The focus is placed squarely on Luthor's revenge against Superman, and Kevin Spacey plays the part very well. He plays it a little less silly and a lot more dark and vicious than Gene Hackman did, but there are still a few moments of humor when the villains are around. The casting choice of Parker Posey as Luthor's female sidekick has gotten some attention, but it's not a big deal. Her character is basically a stand-in for the role Valerie Perrine originally played.Much of the plot is Superman and Lois coming to terms with lost love, but it isn't as nauseating as certain journalists seem to be playing it off as. Early reports of the film being a "chick flick" are exaggerated to the point of idiocy. (Of course, Singer deserves some of the blame for this, since he originally made the "chick flick" remark in jest during an interview.) And, as anybody who has read the press summary of the film knows, Lois Lane has a child, whose parentage may be more than it seems.All in all, I'm not sure I'd say it beats Donner's film. But it certainly beats any other screen version of Superman to date. I can't wait to see it in IMAX with the 3D scenes.

Review Title: I'm watching it again and again and again and again...its that good(***Spoiler Free****)
Review: (*****Spoiler Free*****) June 27 2006There are always people that wont like a movie and there are others that like/love. I had strong and high hopes that this is it this is the summer blockbuster hit movie this 2006. I came to the 10pm early screening and brought some people that don't like superman but force them to watch it and told them that this movie is it the best super hero movie of all and also the greatest of them all. As soon as the movie started it was all good no great bringing back the original score for the intro, Marlon Brando, the planet krypton's looks, a little here and there respect for the 2 original movies before it, the opening scene style with letters popping out was amazing goose bumps every where man. Brandon Routh as superman/Clark Kent was good not the best like Chris Reeve's and not even come close to being Clark Kent but gaved respect because it came close so respects to him he is the new superman of this century.Kevin Spacey as Lex Luther was WRONG!!! jks great he did well compare to the others but i personally prefer Gene Hackman's performance as Lex but its all good the movie was great man. Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane is okay i think she is the weakest out of the 3 she isn't the strong girl from the 2 older movies, more like a tune down version of the character but she is HOT finally a HOT girl as the hero's love interest(Comparing to Superman 1&2 and Spiderman movies).Bryan Singer got my respect as a Director the new age Director the new Steven Spielberg of this time and in his prime, respect him fully for bringing back Superman from the ashes. (please bring back X Men back also) Great writers because if it wasn't for the strong storyline of this movie then it will have a missing part. (look for the duo's cameo) The music score is good but sound more like x men 1&2 for me with a superman john Williams remix but good.This movie beats all the other superhero movie no doubt except Batman begins. Overall this movie delivers us the goods because i got some people that don't like the movie and don't even think the movie was good now they watched it they like it. Has everything to it humour, thrills, plots twist, action, love and great special effects and great MOVIE. This has all the themes for all ages, so go out and see it this movie is the bomb and I'm going to watch it again and again and again.

I am sure some die-hard superman fans will strongly disagree, but this movie had some flaws. Lack of character development, big holes in the plot and a let down ending keep this movie from being great. Enjoyable, but not great. Here we see superman returning from his missing 5 year hiatus. Lots has changed while he was off in space, searching for any signs of his home planet. His father is gone, Lex Luther is out of prison and Louis Lane is married and has a child. But things could be worse, for Clark Kent manages to get his old job back. Course, it doesn't take long for ole Lex to come up with a new scheme to take over the world... an 'insane' scheme... that would kill billions... and you guessed it, he has kryptonite. But really, the scheme is sort of dumb and makes no sense. And (no spoiler here) when Superman foils the plan, he does it in such an anti-climactic way that it leaves you wanting more but-kicking action. But I guess we will have to wait for "Superman Returns... Again" in a few years... All of this being said, there were some really good parts. With some really interesting surprises (though sorry to brag, i must admit, i guessed the surprise from the beginning)... But it is a good surprise that I wouldn't dare ruin by revealing it in this review. And most of the special affects were great. As seen in the trailers, when Superman rescues a crashing jetliner... when seen on the big screen, its is pretty awesome. Lastly, i say that I couldn't help thinking throughout the movie... "how come they can not recognize him just cause he has glasses on?" And, at times the movie even made fun of this a bit... I guess, as silly as the premise is, the movie had to stick with some of the basic rules. Overall, comic-book fans will love the movie. There were people (adults) in the theater literally jumping out of their seats with excitement during some scenes, clapping and shouting during others and when the movie was over, many remained seated until the theater emptied. So fear not die-hard fans, you will NOT be disappointed. But, for those of us who never read the comicbook and just want to see a good movie... well, you probably wont be disappointed either... you just wont care to see it a second time.

Review Title: awesome movie, good jokes, needs more action but still great.
Review: great movie i thought, though could have had more action. after we see superman gets shoot in the eye, we want to see more, but we don't see as much as we expect action wise. other then that, many funny jokes, actually made me and my friend laugh, unlike in the movie spider-man. it is definitely worth watching, and if you see it in the theater, make sure you seat close to the screen, it really makes a difference with this movie. the acting was great too. this was probably the best superman performance I have seen so far. And finally, the best part of this movie is how it shows us how very very powerful superman really is, and that he would definitely beat the monkeys out of any hulk, batman, definitely Spiderman. You see him use some powers that I didn't even know he had! My friend kept asking me "did they add this or was it in the original comics?", because no one really knew how much power superman has, and what he can do with it. Basically, he can do anything he wants.

Review Title: Why not just rerelease the first movie?
Review: From the very start since hearing about this movie I've been sceptical about it. I went to the theater keeping an open mind since other movies i was sceptical about recently turned out to actually be good (V for Vendetta for example.) While watching the movie I realised that this movie was never made for people like me. It was made for children and the people who liked the first 2 Superman movies. I was a child when I saw those 2 movies and loved them dearly, in my mind whenever i see Superman on film I'll probably see Christopher Reeve all my life. And this is why they probably chose Brandon Routh, he really does resemble Reeve a lot. But upon seeing the last 2 Superman movies recently.. I thought they were extremely corny and childish; and this movie.. is corny and childish.From the very start I couldn't understand why they were continuing from the first two movies instead of starting from scratch ignoring the last two movies which were unarguably terrible. (like they'd done for Batman Begins) If it was done to honor Reeve's memory then I feel it wasn't necessary. It's not like his Superman movies are going anywhere. They wouldn't have destroyed those movies if they had done something completely different.There are a lot of problems i felt with this movie. I felt it focused to much on the triangle between Lois and Clark and Richard. I felt the "plot" of this movie wasn't interesting and Luthor was a pretty lame villain, which made me sad. One of the only reasons i wanted to see this movie was to see Kevin Spacey play Lex Luthor and i was sad to walk away disappointed when i saw him play Gene Hackman as Lex Luthor instead.A lot of people will love this movie and I will most likely be one amongst a very small minority who didn't like this movie, but this is the way i see it: we have a Superman who's playing at being Christopher Reeve, we have a Lex Luthor playing at being Gene Hackman and we have a movie that's pretty much the same as the movie we saw 20 years ago... and i'll probably the only one to find something wrong with that.

Review Title: An AMAZING and very touching return of the Man Of Steel

Review: This is short and simple. Read other peoples comments if you want more in-depth stuff.I felt it was a disappointing film, that had a weak plot. It kind of dragged on to me, despite what others say about it being a perfect length.I don't know.Not enough action.. the Spider-Man 3 trailer before the movie completely blew the entire movie away, in my opinion.This is no Batman Begins.4/10. It wasn't terrible, but still.. very disappointing.

Review Title: Highly Enjoyable, In Spite of Its Flaws

Review: Bryan Singer outdid himself. I was disappointed when he left X-Men but now that he is part of Superman... wow. Beautiful movie. The story keeps you gripped and the twists are perfect. They don't come a moment too soon. Kevin Spacey is Lex Luthor, Brandon Routh looks just like Christopher Reeves and Lois Lane is played well by Kate Bosworth. The story goes well and little holes exist so everything that happens in the movie is shown and not assumed at all. I have to admit after seeing movies with Spider-Man and Batman and there counter-parts in Peter Parker and Bruce Wayne that I got used to a witty, funny superhero. Superman and Clark Kent may be the strong silent type but I don't find that the least bit discontenting. It's actually a break form the typical super-hero so to speak. Brandon Routh will do well with the franchise, fingers crossed of course... and so will Bryan Singer. Overall this is one of the best superhero movies I have seen. Watch it!

Ordinarily, I'll skip over the whole of the superhero genre, but I was compelled to watch Superman on opening night...This has got to be the most entertaining movie I've seen in my life.Singer knows the audience like he's carrying on a conversation with us, and what's more, he knows to play to the intelligence and prior knowledge base of the die hard fans, while keeping a wonderful and expansive dialog with the new generations.All in allEntertaining, Touching, Visually Spectacular, and IntelligentQuite possibly the most perfect 'night at the movies' movie ever made.

Review Title: Superman Returns in a big way
Review: Superman Returns is the long awaited return of Superman to the big screen, and I have to admit, it could have been much worse! I was fearing going into this movie that it would fall miserably short in comparison to Batman Begins, a wonderful movie that I couldn't help but try and compare to Superman Returns. But I realized something after viewing SP... this movie should in no way be compared to BB because they are two totally different movies. Now back to the review.First i'll start with the cast. I was a bit worried about how Brandon Routh would do in his first staring role in a movie, and I have to admit that he did an amazing job in my book. His chemistry with Kate Bosworth was great and I felt totally pulled in when they are on screen with each other. You can almost feel Clark Kent's pain when he looks at Lois Lane, and since this is a key part of the movie, it enhances the overall experience a ton. Kate Bosworth also shines as a beautiful new version of Lois Lane. I enjoyed her as Lois Lane, but fans of the original movies will some problems with her because she doesn't really bring the wittiness that the original Lois brought. Now before I start getting tomatoes thrown at me for this one, I gotta tell it how I saw it. Now i'll be the first to say that Kevin Spacey is one of the best actors of our time, but I have to admit that I was left a bit disappointed. He looks the part of Lex Luthor very well and I don't think anyone else could have done the job as well as he could. Don't get me wrong, he did an amazing job, but during the first few scenes of the movie I didn't feel much from his performance. It wasn't until later in the movie that he really started to shine (especially in the scene on the boat with Lois Lane and her son).The movie was a bit on the boring side in the beginning, but as the plot began to start unfolding, it starts to pull you in and your along for the ride all the way to the end. Now as a young man raised on popcorn action movies, I did expect more action of Superman beating down villains, but there was hardly any to be found. This is really my only major gripe about the movie. I personally don't remember Superman punching a villain the entire time! Lois Lane's son seemed to do more damage than Superman, which is really kinda sad.All in all I have to say I enjoyed the movie, but if I was the director, I would have added at least a couple punches here for Superman to dish out so he didn't look like such a pussy. Now go out and see this great summer movie thats sure to make a killing at the box office.

Review Title: Superman Returns!!! - I wish he had stayed home

Review: I didn't go into this film with many expectations, having seen comic-book movies at both extremes of the quality scale."Superman Returns" has pacing issues. The first twenty minutes will probably mostly bewilder you if you have not seen at least one of the previous movies (1 or 2). Much of the dialogue is dull, and formulaic subplots drag the film down.Here is the setup, in a nutshell: Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) has hatched a ludicrous get-rich-quick scheme (Isn't he a billionaire already?) that will just happen to kill billions of people, and it's up to Superman (Brandon Routh) to stop him. Note that the main character is Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth), not Superman. In fact, mild-mannered Clark Kent doesn't get much screen time at all.Action sequences are vital to any superhero flick, and "Superman Returns" has several. Early sequences will not disappoint, but later ones are less than spectacular. The movie has excellent special and visual effects, but sometimes it is unclear just what is happening due to short, jerky clips.There is no strong theme to this film. The fun action parts and a good dose of original comedic elements allowed me to endure the parts I found dreary. If I could replay my day knowing what I know now, I'd avoid "Superman Returns" in the theater and rent it after it's released on DVD.

Review Title: Fun, action-packed superhero flick that has a lot of merit.

Review: I'm a huge Superman fan, and I have to say, this movie was awesome. Whoever cast Kevin Spacey for Lex Luther should get a cookie. A really big cookie. He was an excellent villain. Routhe is a surprisingly good Superman, and all the other roles are well filled too. I wasn't a big fan of some of the decisions when I saw them on paper, but I have to say I was pleased with the performances.This movie had everything. It was funny, had edge of your seat excitement, great character development, it was great. BTW, Routhe kinda sounds like Reeves at some points. If you don't like this movie, you're either a superman hater or a film hater. It was awesome. See it. 10/10

Review Title: I enjoyed Aeon Flux more than this.
Review: What were they thinking? Did anyone really watch this before its release? The story is silly, the plot is a waste. Why bother with the kid? Are we to believe that Lois was such a slut that once Superman left she jumped into bed with this guy Richard so quick that no one knows who's the father of the kid?The lighting was dark, Superman looks so pale that he looks like an albino. The sets look like sets during the "big" scenes. Yes, so what, a man can fly in a movie. Its not worth 20 minutes let alone 2 hours and 20 minutes. I feel disappointed and cheated. Perhaps another 100 million would have given them a better script to start.

Plain and simple, the special effects were awesome! Singer did an alright job in that the chemistry between Lois and superman sucked! who is this new guy? I wanted to like him the whole film... its is scary how much he looks like Christopher reeve's though. I liked Kevin Spacey as Lex Luther but wanted more of him.The movie is totally different from the vibe u get watching the previews. True die hard Superman fans may not like this one.You might have done it with the X-men Singer... but Superman falls short in my book. Why the was Kumar in this movie. I kept picturing him as the pothead looking for whitecastle and it totally ruined it. Well that is what I have to say... agree with me or not this movie will make money.

Review Title: Will the Fat Lady Please Sing(er)?!!!
Review: I'm wasting my time, because you know you'll see it anyway... but Superman Returns was a great movie... for the first hour. Brian Singer then proceeds to drag the invulnerable corpse of a film out for another hour and a half. I found myself uttering, "Look, He's NEO!" or "Suddenly we're on the set of The Abyss" or "Now we're on the set of Titanic" or "He really is NEO!" Much to the chagrin of the guy sitting next to me who then turned and said, "I'd like to enjoy the last ten minutes of the movie!" I returned, "Only if you promise it's the LAST ten minutes!"Superman is Super-long, Super-cliché, and Super-shoulda-directed-XMEN3-instead... Oh well.

Review Title: Superman is back with a vengeance
Review: Brilliant! Bryan Singer has directed a masterpiece. The 80's movies were great but face it cheesy lines and some bad acting (seriously Margot Kidder as Lois Lane). This movie has it all: romance, drama, comedy and tons of action. It's the Superman movie you've been waiting your whole life for. Kate Bosworth is amazing as Lois Lane. She fits the mold of the strong woman, but vulnerable when it comes to Superman. Brandon Routh IS SUPERMAN. He's Christopher Reeve incarnate. The writing is amazing and the directing by Bryan Singer is flawless. I've seen quite a few movies this year. This may be the best movie I've seen all year. It really is that good. It's like seeing Star Wars for the first time. I left the theater amazed at this REAL MOVIE! This isn't a typical comic book movie. This is a love story or is it an action movie? I guess it's all of them and frankly I'm glad it took so long to make it this good.

Review Title: And the world cheers as Superman returns
Review: When the idea of Warner Bros. reviving the "Superman" franchise surfaced a few years back, I had my reservations and doubted whether they can pull it off this time after a couple of "Superman" bombs in the '80s. Not even the departure of erstwhile director Brett Ratner and the arrival of Bryan Singer completely cleared it. Yes, Singer did a great job with "X-Men," making not just a great comic-book adaptation but also a movie with intelligence and depth. Still, several questions remain. Could a relatively unknown actor carry the burden of portraying perhaps the most famous superhero of all time? Isn't this sequel made too late, more so after a pair of stinkers left the franchise on a bad note? Besides, I never fully liked the idea of Superman, a superhero almost without any weakness except for a radioactive element that's out of this world. I mean, where's the fun in that? So props, then, to "Superman Returns," particularly to director Bryan Singer and screenwriters Michael Dougherty and Dan Harris for bestowing upon us a more believable demigod of a character, albeit with an unbelievably thin disguise for his secret identity. (But what the heck, this is based from a comic book!) Completely ditching the idea that there were technically four Superman films made, "Superman Returns" starts where "Superman II" left off. Superman (Brandon Routh) comes back to Earth five years after he just suddenly flew off to the remains of Krypton, his home planet, in search of survivors. Upon his return, he learns that Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth) has moved on, and is the author of the Pulitzer-winning article "Why the World Doesn't Need Superman." She is now a mother to Jason (Tristan Lake Leabu) and is engaged to Richard White (James Marsden without the ruby quartz glasses), nephew of Daily Planet editor-in-chief Perry White (Frank Langella).Meanwhile, Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) was released from prison since Superman wasn't around to testify against him. Virtually forgotten by the public, he again formulates his diabolical plan of controlling the world while the rest of the population is sent to a frenzy over the return of The Man of Steel.Well, the plot does seem the fairly common superhero fare that's a dime a dozen nowadays, but the film's more than that, actually. Singer manages to create a masterpiece that equals, if not surpasses, what Christopher Nolan did for "Batman" and Sam Raimi for "Spider-Man" in terms of quality and satisfaction. Granted, Clark Kent doesn't have the advantage of Peter Parker in terms of mask of anonymity, but Singer has achieved to make the superhero's alter-ego into a bumbling nerd believable even as we know he can turn any moment into the stuff most of us mortals can only dream of. Routh, a ringer for the late Christopher Reeve, may not have the commanding presence of the original Superman, but the internal conflict of the script works well because his character is one the audience can a lot more relate with.Bosworth gives a spot-on performance as Superman's love interest Lois Lane, and she and Routh have great chemistry. She has a real confused character to deal with in Lois Lane who is clearly hurt by the sudden disappearance of Superman, and wrote an award-winning article to cover-up for what she felt was lacking inside her, whether she realizes it or not. Bosworth exudes charm while conveying Lois' emotions convincingly, and it's nice to see her getting better as an actress since I first watched her on "Blue Crush." Lex Luthor is about as ludicrously one-dimensional as most comic book villains, but somehow Spacey does a spectacular job of making him entertaining and convincing. He perfectly incarnates the character despite it being rather elementary. It veers close to camp, yet in the end there is sincerity and charisma in his performance.The visual effects are superb but more importantly, Singer and the special effects team don't go amok with the CGI. There's not much choreographed fight sequence or boisterous road chase to showcase them. Instead, they are built gradually along with the film's progression to enhance the story, rather than overpower it. Composer John Ottman employs much of John Williams' score from the original "Superman" while cinematographer Newton Thomas Sigel sets most of the film in a balmy mood. These, along with the minute mannerisms from the original Superman films (just look at the opening credits), give one the feeling that Singer has much respect for the material.My doubts have been finally quelled. With Singer pushing the right buttons and a script that shows earnestness, "Superman Returns" delivers cleverness as often as it does excitement. It is, I might as well say it, super.

Review Title: Puts the other Superman Movies Sequels(after 3 and 4) to shame...

Review: Superman Returns is the real deal! It completely captures the feel and tone of the original film, and the comics, but updates nicely. The humour fits in well and never feels forced. Everyone in the cast is outstanding, particularly Parker Posey and Kevin Spacey, who have some wonderful scenes together. Also, Brandon Routh is at times luminescent. This film is the balm we all needed after the last few years' darkness, sadness and cynicism. It is filled with light and hope and good. I still prefer Batman Begins slightly, but I was always a huge Batman fan. In any case, a film that can make the unbelievable believable, and cause a large sold out theatre full of people to cheer and clap like they did deserves to be seen by everyone, so don't wait! Go and see it! Everyone, but particularly fans of the original film, will be totally taken with this re-imagining. Thank you so much Brian Singer!!!

Review Title: Look, Up In The Sky! The Amazing Review of Superman Returns

Review: OK just got done watching this movie and all i can say is WOW!!! The story line was great....of course it still bugs me that all superman has to do is put on a suit and glasses and no body recognizes him...Brandon Routh--not only does he look like christopher reeves in many shots...but for being an unknown actor he pulled this role off with flying colors (no pun intended)...he had some Huge shoes to fill and i enjoyed watching him as much as watching christopher reeves...Kate Bosworth---i will be the first to admit that i was scared knowing she was going to play this role...i think she is too sweet for it...but i was surprised in a good way...Kevin Spacey---i love his acting...and he is probably the best lex luther i have seen (although the one in smallville pulls of the bald look the best)...he pulled off the intelligence that lex is supposed to have In case you couldn't tell...i really enjoyed this movie and i cant wait to see it again...especially at the IMAX

I thought that Richard Donner's 1978 film, which I recently watched for the second time, came from the right place, but was largely unsuccessful. You would think, then, that I wouldn't get much out of a Superman franchise reboot that is nothing more than a rejuiced version of the Donner films, seeing as how I enjoyed Christopher Nolan's pastiche of all the best Batman elements.It is perhaps true that Bryan Singer's choice of adaptation can be limiting in that he wasn't able or willing to drop anything that perhaps didn't work ideally. Despite this, the film is an incredible, almost miraculous success. I'm really impressed with how well Singer does at creating good riff on something I didn't find that impressive, as I am with his general ability to sustain an un-ironic "earnest" tone without being overly corny (give or take a few minutes) or excessively anachronistic. The best example is Kevin Spacey's Lex Luthor; he took Gene Hackman's Luthor, which I was none too proud of, and made it work (with help from the script I presume). Certainly, there are problems; some scenes go on forever despite their lack of suspense (the filmmakers only get a pass on the "will Superman save them" thing for the first time), and the ending is abrupt in all the wrong ways. Finally, I'm not sure if this will convert you to the pro-Superman camp, but it will satisfy both casual and true believers.

Review Title: Superman's Return is not so Super

Review: My best friend works for Electronic Arts, the company that has the licensed for the "Superman Returns"game. I was one of the lucky people to see a sneak preview of "Superman Returns" this Tuesday night. I will not spoil the movie for anyone. I just wanted to say "Superman Returns" is THE best Superman movie of all time and is a true tribute to Christopher Reeves. There are many surprises and cameos. The story is wonderful. One of the best stories I've seen in the movie theater in a long time. The direction is flawless. The acting by everyone is wonderful. Kevin Spacey is the best Lex Luthor of the franchise. The movie will have you on the edge of your seat. The "Superman Returns" is full of a range of emotions and the action/special fx are jaw dropping! If you are reading this post and you like Superman....put the computer down for a couple of hours and get yourself to the theater. You will not regret it!!!! This summer's blockbuster of the year- "Superman Returns"!!!

I did get to see Superman Returns in the IMAX-3D; which I thought it was excellent. Brandon was excellent, no doubt in my mind that Brandon had some resemblance to the late Christopher Reeve. Kate as Lois was fabulous, I was very observant throughout the film, for some reason Kate had different colored eyes; one eye was blue and the other was like a brownish if I am not mistaken, but overall she was great. Let's not forget about the criminal master mind, Lex played by Kevin. He was fantastic,cocky, smart, and a comedian. The story line was awesome from the beginning to the end. The 3D effects were okay, I thought that the whole movie was going to be in 3D. I guessed wrong. To sum it all up, the movie was super-fantastic, go see the movie you will enjoy it. I know I did.

This summer's Box Office has been mediocre; with only two or three films that still have legs, until now! From beginning to end this film delivers, spectacular C.G. great dialog, and compelling emotional situations. The visuals were on my mind, however they were lurking somewhere behind the thought of Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor or Brian Singer's talent for getting it done right and then this new kid Brandon Routh. Well to my surprise this film is captivating to watch, the landscape is a character with life all it's own. Spacey is outstanding, which some might think is standard, however he is truly diabolical as Lex Luthor with a maniacal twist of humor. Stepping squarely into the red boots and flowing cape Brandon Routh does so as if he were born to be Superman. Not just the strikingly nostalgic similarity between Christopher Reeve, but his fantastic portrayal of Clark and The Man of Steel, absolutely makes you take notice! Quite simply this is the best film so far this summer; make certain to see this in the theatre!

Review Title: Superman Returns with a Roaring Applause
Review: Superman is the greatest hero of all time, his musical theme is one of a few pieces of music that (for me) can actually raise my heart rate and motivation level. I have eagerly been awaiting the release of a new Superman movie for as long as I can remember, and that goes back to when Nicholas Cage was signed onboard to play the Man of Steel. Superman Returns brings back the magic that was in the first two Superman movies. The tagline for Superman (1978) was "You'll Believe a Man Can Fly!" In Superman Return you will again believe that a Man Can Fly. To me Christopher Reeves will be always be Superman. He was the Man of Steel and Gene Hackman was Lex Luthor. The casting could not have been better. Some will accuse Routh and Spacey of doing Reeves and Hackman imitations. I would have to disagree with this. In Superman Returns, Brandon Routh oozes Reeves. Routh embodies everything that made the Reeves performance so charming. Kevin Spacey transforms Hackman's Luthor into an even more diabolical maniac. Kate Bosworth was a much more enjoyable as Lois Lane than Margot Kidder's in the original. The movie expands on the Superman mythos and continues the story of Superman where Superman II left off (thank god, now all of us who really hate Superman III, and absolutely wish Superman IV: The Quest for Peace would go were all bad movies go can find solace that this movie happens before those disastrous incarnations). The connections to Superman and Superman II are cleverly done. There is even a homage to the Superman Lives movie (the one that Nicholas Cage was going to star in) that was never made but nearly $50 million was spent in preproduction. Without giving away the scenes of the movie, I must say the first scene in which Superman is really present was truly the best Superman rescue scene since Superman made his debut in the 1978 movie rescuing Lois Lane and the helicopter. In Returns, I and many other people in a packed theater jumped to our feet in applause when Superman saved the day. I felt like I was in that stadium cheering for America's greatest hero. Batman Begins revitalized the Batman franchise, Superman Returns will do the same for the Superman franchise. I can't wait until Summer 2009, when Superman will Return again, and fight for Truth, Justice and the American Way.

Review Title: Had my doubts. but i must say very good!  Edge of your seat entertainment! A must see!!
Review: I am a huge superman fan, especially growing up through the years and i must say i had my doubts about the movie. but as more pictures and the trailers came out, i quickly became just like a child today, i have to see this movie. the movie was good and even though it took 2 and a half hours to finish, it was all necessary. they spent just enough time to explain what was going on and where he stood in the movie. Brandon Routh did a excellent job playing the man of steel. Kevin Spacy was perfect for the Lex Luthor part. I'm not to sure about the other people that grew up watching Reeves do the part. yes his costume did change, yes there's little things that are different, but hey, its always going to be that way. See this movie! thumbs up!

Review Title: How and why this movie sucked! (spoilers)

Review: Some of the critics I've read panned either the film, Brandon Routh, Kate Bosworth, or the length alone. Don't believe any of them. I'm not a dyed in the wool Superman fan (or superhero fan). But, I wanted to see if the critics were right about the film or wrong ... so my son and I went to the sneak preview.The critics, gladly, are so wrong about this film it takes my breath away ... which is what the movie itself did for me (take my breath away). A lot had to be accomplished in it and a lot WAS accomplished. First, the film had to be expository enough to bring younger audiences into the fold ... those not familiar with the Reeve films. Secondly, it had to convince those who'd seen the Reeve films that Routh is a worthy successor. Some of my friends might hate me for saying this but, frankly, Routh's performance blew Christopher Reeve's portrayal of Superman right out of the water. Routh, in my mind, is clearly now THE DEFINITIVE Superman. Thirdly, the film had to stay true to its action core while giving new insights into the private lives of the main characters. And in doing so, a profound secret (one I won't repeat) is revealed ... giving any future sequel (guaranteed) something to build on.One note. I was especially glad to see Kevin Spacey get the role of Lex Luthor. He plays a brilliant if not demonic Lex ... and as a survivor at the end of the film is certain to return. My only disappointment, but not worth taking away from my score of 10, was the writers' treatment of Luthor's squeeze/moll, Kitty Kowalski. I hope more of her is fleshed out in future incarnations. But, I forgave the writers almost immediately because of their wise decision to NOT include a similar "comic relief" character (ala Ned Beatty) like in the Reeve films. Frankly, I as a film-goer didn't WANT to see comic relief for Lex Luthor ... and hope future incarnations remain as evil as in this film.Every minute of this film was a good minute ... deserving to stay as part of the whole. Kudos to the film editors for not tampering with things too much. This film has to be one of the best films I've seen in a long time ... and THE best film I've seen in the last year.

Hi just been to see early morning release of the movie (in USA right now on holiday) and thought it was absolutely amazing. The action is second to none and the choice to go ahead and shoot the film on the new media was clearly a correct one. The Superman we see in this movie is one that clearly has a human heart and although he is the Man of Steel on the outside, it is his clear human upbringing that we sympathise with and feel his pain throughout the movie. The casting was pretty much spot on and although i had my worries for Lois Lane and some of the lesser characters such as Olsen they all get pass marks. Overall it is a good story line that opens up a whole new path to go down for future movies. Overall an excellent movie that just goes up, up and away from beginning to end.

Review Title: the best comic book movie ever!!!
A great film, but its full potential was obviously not tapped

Review: Thoroughly impressed, good storyline, even for 2-1/2 hours it keeps your interest.....never bogs itself down in any way, good job of casting and keeping up with important details that all fans of Superman will recognize, truly impressed with the lack of commercialization meaning there weren't any blatant "product placements" of any kind that I can remember...all in all it was worth full price, worth 2-1/2 hours and well worth the wait...judging by the fact that 2 screens were showing it the night before it's official release date in our small town (and both screenings were full) this is going to be a big money-maker (thanks to Smallville for bringing in new fans) and I don't really see where anyone will be able to bash the film in any way and be justified in doing it. Brandon Routh takes a few minutes to warm up to but once he gets back into his Clark Kent persona at the Daily Planet,he plays the part admirably, Kate Bosworth is stunning and Kevin Spacey does his normal thing (quiet but convincing in the role of Luthor) by just playing his part and not trying to steal the spotlight from the rest of the cast. A must see!!

Review Title: Not the piece of crap I thought it would be.
Too much CGI! Lois is too young!
Outstanding summer blockbuster worthy of the title.
Review: I didn't quite know what to expect of this one - another lame Hollywood sequel? - and was more or less blown away. Consistently extraordinary effects and visuals combined with sincerity and underplayed expression on the part of Brandon Routh as our new Supe - well done from start to finish (just ignore the obvious breaks in logic, sit back and enjoy the wild, wild ride).This is one of those shows that is not driven by the expensive and stylish effects, but enriched by them. The primary characters are thoroughly drawn, and the two plots (love story and evil genius with world-dominating plot) are balanced. I'll see it again, just for the fun of it.

I went to a 10PM showing last night, (tuesday) to see Brian Singer's next big thing. First, I should point out that I am a comic book fan. I collected them feverishly as a child and will still pick up an issue on occasion. Basically, I have a very in depth knowledge of the character and I do have certain expectations.
