With that said, I should also note that I am *not* a huge fan of the Donner films. I just felt them to be a little too campy and contrived. OK, now to "Returns". As I stated in the title, I am still grinning the next morning. There have only been a few movies that have given me this feeling after watching them. The first Matrix, the first Batman, Both Spidermans, The Lord of the Rings, etc. The movie has its flaws, as I am sure you have heard reading other reviews, but the flaws are easily overlooked. For example, the timing in the beginning and the end of the movie is a little suspect, but the meat of the sandwich, as it were, is phenomenal. There are moments of the movie in which I felt that I "truly believed" in what I was seeing. Brandon Routh carries the Superman mantle to the next level, even beyond Christopher Reeve. Routh's Superman has an air of Nobility and dare I say Godliness that was not present in Reeve's performance. Where Reeve was over the top with his "Boy Scoutiness" (I made up that word), Routh seems to slip it on like an old pair of pants. It just fits. Routh is able to bring the pain of the relationship with Lois to the screen brilliantly. He allows Supes to be "human" without being fragile. Kevin Spacey was, of course, brilliant. I still rank him as the most under-appreciated actor in Hollywood. He has his Oscars, but somehow, that doesn't seem enough. He follows Gene Hackman's performance and flair without imitating him. I do need to point out here that I do not like the Silver Screen Lex Luthor. This is a character that has never been done right with an actor. My Lex Luthor is in the comics or even in the Superman Animated Series. With that said though, Spacey was scary and evil and believable. I just looked back and saw that this is starting to get a little longer than I wanted, so I will end this with two things. One -Sam Huntington finally got Jimmy Olsen right. This is the way this character should be. I am not going to explain it, just watch and you will see what I am talking about. Two -Superman has always, and will always be the quintessential (spelling) Hero. He is everything we strive to be and at moments are. He is our savior. He is our friend. For those of us that are true fans of this genre, Superman is on a different level than all other SuperHeroes. For the first time on film or TV, you will see this. Go enjoy this movie and pay no heed to the critics out there that need to be overly critical to sell papers and further their careers. Watch this movie for the pure selfish reason that after any long day in this "real" world, you need to escape sometimes to Metropolis where a man really can fly!Thank you for reading my ramblings...

The three points out of ten that I'm giving this movie basically apply purely because it's Superman and it's hard to make a completely bad Superman movie. The action will always be exciting and the special effects were (with the exception of two notable scenes) dynamite. A solid mention goes to Kevin Spacey, who gave a creepy performance as Lex Luthor.That being said, the rest of the casting was just horrible. Routh's Superman was a very stale version of Christopher Reeve's Superman... he just didn't emit the still confidence that Reeve had, yet seemed to be emulating his every move. Kate Bosworth never once felt like Lois Lane and even in the last hour, I felt like I was watching a completely different character, and I'm not even going to touch on the poor performance. Other notable casting screwups were Kal Penn (most notable as Kumar of Harold and Kumar) as one of Luthor's henchmen. It should be noted that he had no lines nor any spots of comic relief, he just served as a very unbelievable henchman... which seemed to garner laughs every time he was on screen due to the sheer out-of-placedness of this actor. James Marsden (Cyclops of X-Men fame) felt out of place and awkward in this film. The movie might be the slowest superhero film ever with several wasted scenes. The movie obviously needed to be trimmed up by at least half an hour and I easily think of a half an hour of this film that could be excluded and greatly improve this movie.

Superman has definitely returned in this epic 2 1/2 hour movie. However, with that said ... it could have been better.I won't go into the plot as not to spoil anything for anyone but I will say that the main drag points included the first half of the movie, where the dialog dragged on and there was only a tiny bit of action. Here is where I think most people will find themselves bored and wanting to hit the "fast-forward" button when it comes to the DVD.The second half of the movie was better paced. It may have been a boring film overall for some, but the second half contains the best segments of acting, action, and story. It was a welcome splash in the face that it was not all long and a bore.By the end, I was surprised as many people "liked" it as they did. I had one say it was "crap," but people must really like their Superman to be willing to see his emotional side. That was something I definitely did not expect.If you are looking for an action-packed movie, see X3. If you are looking for a movie with heart, soul, some humor, and a good bit of action, this movie is for you.

I'm a sucker for Comic book movies, always have been and always will be.If it's about a comic book character I will most likely see it unless it is some terrible movie like Catwoman or Elektra. I was excited for this movie to come out and had been anticipating it for months.The plot and screenplay were both very well done. I was trying to think of a way to make a movie with a plot that hasn't been used before for a man who only has one weakness. I was very impressed with the story and the comic book feel of the movie. It still stayed true to the original Superman movies and Kevin Spacey was an excellent Lex Luthor.I don't want to go into the plot or other details, but I was very impressed and I highly recommend it.

Last night I was able to catch the movie Superman Returns. I'd like to preface this review by saying that I have never seen any superman movies, know barely anything about superman, and avoided all press about this movie. I wanted to go in knowing nothing (typical female- the horror!) and see what happens. I wanted a legitimate GIRLS perspective on the flying man in tights, and I think I was successful.Well... I absolutely loved this film. It was entertaining; it kept me excited and enthralled the entire time. The first 10 minutes had me thoroughly confused, because I had no idea what was going on- that is the part where I think knowing something about the other superman movies would help. However, after the basic plot is laid out, the movie gets tighter and more exciting and in typical Bryan Singer fashion, is loud, raucous and fun.So what can I say about the plot that hasn't been said before? Well superman is back after 5 years of tending to some business. The plot does leave some holes and never really answers the question of why he was gone for so darn long. But no matter, the whole movie basically defies logic, so I'm willing to let that go. While he was gone, his love interest, Lois Lane, moved on. In fact she moved on so much that she has a fiancée and a kid! This sets up the most interesting part of the movie- a love triangle between Superman, Lois and her fiancée (a triangle that is a tad controversial I might add). Of course, Lex Luther is also out of prison and scheming up an evil plan that reminded me of something Dr. Evil would hatch.The visual effects were nothing to write home about- very good but nothing out of the ordinary, nothing that we haven't seen before. There were 1,400 fx shots and they had to be done quickly. Watching the credits, I realized that the studio had farmed out shots to many different companies, which perhaps led to my feeling that the effects weren't cohesive -you could almost tell that they were done by different studios. Probably the most exciting sequence both visually and edge-of-your-seat exciting ( I was literally holding my breath the entire time) was in the beginning of the movie, however it was so good it was hard to top it later on. Overall, however the effects kept the movie going, and added to the overall experience.My complaint about Superman is that he is too good- he really has no weaknesses, and cannot feel pain. He can stop anything, he is faster than the speed of light, he is strong, he can be everywhere and anywhere at once, and of course he can see through things. However, Brandon Routh, the new actor filling some big shoes, makes him very sincere and almost naive. You believe his romance with Lois Lane, and although it is very complicated, I liked the couple together. (An interjection: I am always critical of female leads in movies such as these- they are almost always annoying and whiny. Case in point, Kirsten Dunst as Mary Jane annoys me to no end. However, I really liked Kate Bosworth's performance, because she and Brandon Routh had excellent chemistry and she was fun to watch). I haven't read many reviews yet about the movie, but many are saying that it doesn't compare to the originals, Christopher Reeves was much better blah blah blah. My perspective on that is that it doesn't matter. This is a summer movie in which you are supposed to be entertained. It has great effects, a good story, wonderful music I might add, and it's just fun escapism. It's pointless to compare and if you do that, you will always find that the new movie is inferior, because that is the superman curse. The new supermans will never live up to the old ones because they just can't- the old ones were too good. You are setting yourself up to be disappointed if you go in with that mindset and attitude, and that would be a shame! Superman Returns does not reinvent anything, it's not groundbreaking, but it is enjoyable and a good time. There are scenes that perhaps could have been very cheesy and made you laugh, however instead they were very sweet and innocent. I highly recommend seeing this movie, although I recommend doing it MY way: going in with an open mind and see what happens. As for all you girls out there, who like me, don't know much about superman, definitely see this film. It's worth it, and you can still get a lot out of it, and will probably enjoy it more than others who have seen the older Superman movies.:::www.animationchick.com:::

Review Title: Tired of Superman?? Don't think so!!
Review: Many skeptics believed "Superman Returns" would potentially suffer due to a lack of quality and genuine originality, ripping off the other Superman-related TV Shows and movies. And although at times the movie did seem to have certain parallels to other superhero movies, the movie didn't get bruised in any way. It's almost like a crash; we see the sudden adrenaline rush in the most fascinating way. Superman is their hero and they are his family. Metropolis crumbles under the weight of hopelessness and vulnerability now that their savior has disappeared."Superman Returns" to planet Earth and once again reunites with Lois Lane to finally (?) put an end to Lex Luthor. This is a story of hope, survival and (as tacky as it seems) family and love.Five years after Superman disappears (and, coincidentally, so does Clark Kent), he falls directly into his earth-parents' farm after being absorbed into a meteor. He quickly recovers and goes back to work at the Daily Planet where he finds out Lois Lane had been married and now has a child. Elsewhere, Lex Luthor is now out of prison and married to an old billionaire who signs away her possessions with the last breath she has. Lex takes the money, and finds large crystals buried in Superman's Fortress of Solitude that can give him power beyond belief."Superman Returns" is a powerful ode about the most powerful and popular superhero ever. With edge of your seat action sequences, and some plot twists, the movie is as powerful as The Man of Steel himself. What makes this movie more interesting is how we see weakness and vulnerability in Superman. He suffers from the now-healed society which no longer includes Superman, and in one awe-inspiring scene, he is dragged across water and dirt by a human and we see just how humanistic this one man can be.Director Bryan Singer directed this movie almost flawlessly -- and it's no surprise, him being the director of the first two X-men movies. His display of special effects is uncanny, paying tribute to the Spider-man movies with both flying sequences and creating almost a whole city in CGI. Brandon Routh was a really good choice for Superman. His entire face seems almost metal and mannequin-like.There are a few plot holes in Superman though. It does not really start off where the first three ended off. Now Lois doesn't know Clark Kent is Superman, and it doesn't really explain how and where Superman came from, and where he'd been for five years. However there is an obvious motivation for Superman's drive, and a definite character development. Not to mention a footage of Marlon Brando himself.In all, "Superman Returns" is a fun, thrilling, nostalgic movie that keeps you wanting more and more. And while being compared to classics such as the Reeves franchise and even the Hatcher/Cain phenomena, the movie stands alone as the most powerful of them all.

To put it bluntly, I did not know what to expect going into Superman Returns. I had read mixed reviews of the performances and story-line, but was still willing to see a 10pm screening the day it came out.Boy, was I glad I did.Superman Returns is absolutely breathtaking. Not only was the story incredible, but Kevin Spacey brilliant as Lex Luther. Of course, my worries were about Superman himself, and Brandon Routh filled the role marvelously. I cannot imagine a better Superman than himself.Now, the casting worked out well, and so did the story. Though there were a few story lines that strayed from the comic series, the story really flows.As for the film visually, I am going to go out on a limb and say that the special effects were the most realistic of any film I have seen. The scale that this film was on was truly massive, and it was pulled off perfectly. Not only are the destructive scenes great, but the calming love story of Superman/Lane was pulled off very well.And you cannot ignore the homage to Superman I and II. This truly did seem like a continuation of that series.I loved it, and think it may actually have been better than Batman Begins.

This movie was by far the best movie I have ever seen. There were a few twists that really made the movie great. I still feel that The Lord Of The Rings Trilogy are the best movies ever made by man. Contrary to that last comment, Superman Returns is my favorite movie because of the plot and the cinematography was amazing. The Spiderman movies are very good "superhero" movies but Superman Returns went far and beyond just a good "superhero" movie. I feel that they did and excellent job of casting Clark Kent aka. Superman. I highly encourage you to see this movie. There are some very brutal scenes so i would suggest the viewers to be at least 12 years of age.Not only did superman save my day, I think he saved all of summer '06 movies too!go see it!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

The movie was excellent, Brandon Routh played Clark Kent/Superman with ease. It's going to be hard for him to transition to another role but he hit this one out of the park. Kate Bosworth added charisma and sex appeal to Lois Lane, Margot Kidder was good but not exactly the most attractive woman. I was kinda hoping for some kind of connection or cameo from Bruce Wayne, (rumor mill) but that didn't happen. If Hollywood decides to make a Superman/Batman film it will no doubt be a blockbuster with the 2 new caped crusaders at the helm. Bryan Singer stayed very close to the comic series, blended multiple stories but kept it true. Can't wait for the next film!

Bryan Singer has made some of the best comic book movies of all time with the first two X-men. He raises the bar even higher with Superman Returns. The cast was very well chosen, even down to Kate Bosworth who I had my doubts over when I saw previews. Brandon Routh is a stoic, classic hero as Superman, but plays the bumbling Clark Kent with equal aplomb. The action sequences were breathtaking and some of the best CGI work I have ever seen on film. Singer managed to tell a great story about the burden carried by our mightiest hero and it he told with visuals. There was no long dialog to explain why what was happening was so important, it showed you in the expressions on the public's face and the look in Superman's eyes. Kevin Spacey was excellent as usual, walking the fine line between showing the sarcastic humor of Lex Luther and the deeply sadistic maniac underneath. Singer played this movie very straight, there was no tongue in cheek, it was played with great sincerity and obvious reverence for the 1978 movie. This film restores a mighty hero to his rightful place as the world biggest boyscout. The world needs Superman as an example of letting the best sides of our nature be in control. Left open at the end I can only hope many more Superman movies follow that have the gravity and power of this one.

I felt that Singer did a good job with the source material and in making it "dark" like Batman Begins, but it's Superman--you can't really make the material too dark without going against the very persona of Superman himself. Still, Kevin Spacey's performance alone makes Superman Returns *almost* worth the price of admission, but there's nothing really very new or innovative here. At least that's what I thought. But if you want a good summer movie, I'd definitely go see it. Otherwise, I'd wait for the DVD--the showing I went to last night reminded me of why I hate multiplex crowds, although it was a better theater-going experience than normal because everyone was excited to see Superman. I don't think that'll be the case with later showings though.

This film plays like a bad sequel to the original two Superman films. If this really had been the third film, if it really had been "Superman III," this is the one we wouldn't be watching anymore. The two main characters, Superman/Clark and Lois Lane, have nothing interesting or fun to say to each other. The whole "old boyfriend" coming back into your life--and Lois' baby--is so ill-conceived that it's baffling the film was ever made. Lex Luthor is a joke and his big plan is a muddle. The film is relentlessly sour, clumsy, pointless, and then in the big action conclusion suddenly sadistic and unlikable. Superman does nothing but fly around catching things, bigger and bigger things; you know, he can do more than just lift up heavy objects, Singer! Wow, what a disappointment. The lack of originality in this film, the endless length, the absence of any real thrills or fun makes this one of the biggest missed opportunities in recent memory. In every way this is a complete failure, from the casting to the story to the decision to film with that "great new camera." If it weren't for the soundtrack constantly evoking for us the two earlier Donner films, there would be absolutely nothing in here that works. Should you see the film? Of course! Everyone should see the weirdest, saddest train wreck in a summer filled with bad movies.

I went to see the movie last night at 10pm. I liked how the kept the original style of opening credits. Brought back good memories of being a kid watching the first Superman.The storyline was good though lengthy. Over all the story moved quickly but at points did drag. Being primarily a love story the action was subdued but suspenseful.I like the concept of this being more of a love story to bring a light into Supermans more personal side.As far as the acting.. Kevin Spacey has brought back the Lex Luther attitude and look beautifully. By far my favorite actor for the movie. He did not miss a beat with how Lex Luther is in the previous movies,Smallville, and the comics.Brandon Routh.. OK it is scary the resemblance to the young Chistopher Reeve. Overall a good job in a tough shoe to fill. He definitely did Clark Kent well with the bumbling guy act.Kate Bosworth.. needs a little more work getting the Louis Lane part down. She is a good actress but finding a Louis Lane replacement is hard after how well Margot Kidder did.

This movie is not like any other Superman incarnation. It pays homage to the classics - there are notable winks and nods to the comics, TV series, and original movies - plus genuinely silly moments that remind us of the ridiculousness of the whole thing. However, most of the movie is slow, calculated, and depressed, which isn't to say it isn't satisfying to watch.It's understandable that Superman would come back in a funk after five years away, visiting his destroyed homeland and realizing he is, in fact, the last son of Krypton. It's fitting that his Clark persona has gotten rusty in the meantime, that he's neither as bumbling nor as charming as he was before he left.Superman has come back much more alien than before - he barely speaks, and is single-minded and self-sacrificing to a degree unprecedented in the mythology (as far as I know). He's practically given up on the love of Lois Lane, and he's separated himself emotionally from the human race even as he's dedicated himself to saving it (fans of Clark Kent, beware - Clark is totally absent in the last third of the film). And yet, because he is vulnerable and passionate in an understated way, we care for him more than ever. There are moments when he's back to his catch-phrase self, but most of the time, he stares in the face of seemingly impossible-to-overcome obstacles with joyless determination. And we admire him for it.Kevin Spacey is chilling as Lex Luthor. Kate Bosworth is passable as a less obnoxious and slightly more intelligent version of Margot Kidder's Lois Lane. The special effects in this film are as good as you could ask for, but they're not important. There are lyrical moments of breathtaking beauty, which, if you're not a visual person, can get slow, but if you recognize their significance, can really stick with you long after the film is over.However, this film really isn't about Lois, Lex, or the action. The point of this installation is to make you think about what it really means to be Superman, and how depressing that really is. And then appreciate that our hero is still willing to be our hero, because we do, in fact, need him, perhaps more than ever.

Review Title: Superman Returns is a really boring movie.
Review: I was going into this movie the night it opened expecting a action pact adventure with Superman and the villain of all villain's Lex Luther. The movie opens fine in-fact it made me excited. A big story starts to build up about the evil plot Lex Luther is doing ( you don't know what it is exactly.) and then you find out what he wants to do and it is really kind of stupid. Than after that the movie only focuses on the love story between Louis and superman. Than it goes really slow and get's boring. The effects were good and the beginning was good, So I would just wait to watch it on DVD because if you see it in theaters you will be disappointed. If you like Superman don't see this movie because it will ruin it for you.

My husband and I attended the opening of this last night. It was GREAT! I have heard so many mixed reviews, but as die hard Superman fans, from the original Christopher Reeves, to SMALLVILLE (WOOHOO season 6 in Sept.), we have been anxiously awaiting this film. I think Brandon did an amazing job, and he looks so much like Christopher Reeves. I have to assume by the way it ends that we can expect a Superman 5, which would be great. But for all of you who have heard bad reviews, I suggest you go and watch it yourself. I loved it, and when it comes to DVD, it will be added to my Superman collection (which includes the original Superman movies and all the Smallville Seasons except season 5, but when that comes out I'll have it too ;) It's the story of Superman, I love it.

I saw Superman in an advance screening at the movie theater I work at and this pretty much sums it up: the trailer for Spiderman 3 was more exciting than 2 hrs and 40 min of Superman Returns. I do not know much about Superman or the comics which is hard to watch this movie because it just picks up on a story that we don't get to watch. The movie takes place 5 years after Superman has put Lex Luther in jail. Superman left earth to find his home planet and when he returns Lex was released from jail early because Superman wasn't around to testify. He has married an old woman and when she died he got all her fortune and of course he has some evil plan as well. I don't want to spoil the movie for anyone but it involves Lex breaking into the Fortriss of Solitude--okay if this is Superman's home wouldn't it have some sort of alien protection that people couldn't just in it and access the crystals? When "Clark Kent" returns to the Daily Planet, Lois Lane has moved on and now has a kid and is with the father. One thing that bothered me was the complete lack of chemistry between Routh and Bosworth. All in all it just come down to it that this is just not a very good story. I wish they would've just started the story from the begginning and put a new spin on it. Save your money and see X-Men 3 if you want to get your superhero fix.

Review Title: Superman Returns to get rid of that bitter taste that X Men 3 gave us.
Review: Superman Returns starts with an opening title sequence that is made to annoy anyone who isn't watching the movie in IMAX 3D. This is not a 3D movie, except in certain theaters when available. The problem is, it looks like a 3D movie everywhere.The other problem is, I thought one of the largest franchises in the world would be above bullet time. Or, at least, Faster then a speeding bullet time. Still, Routh performs a great Clark Kent, but plays Superman more or less as a pretty boy and not a triumphant hero, lacking the charm of Reeve's original performance. While Gene Hackmen may have played a great evil Genius and went over the top, Kevin Spacey took a psychotic character who was over the top and tried to bring him down a notch. And he literally stole the show.I really don't understand why the people at the Daily Planet are so stupid. Not only does Clark go on leave for five years and Superman Returns the same day, Superman spends a week in the hospital for part of the movie, and by default Clark doesn't show up for work, without calling in or anything.James Marsden probably will never be given enough credit for his performance as Richard White. His character was perhaps my favorite in the movie. He plays Lois Lane's long time fiancé (for five years) and the father of her kid. He is also very nervous of her past relationship with Superman. Now, we all know about the past relationships with Superman, and if the series continues, there will be more relationships with Superman. The writers could have taken the easy way out and made him a jerk, made him stupid, or all sorts of things.In the end, though he obviously lacks the powers, he's as Heroic as Superman in many ways. Lois shows nothing but love for him, and confusion when Superman arrives. She really doesn't want anything to change. Yet Marsden is very aware that she may slip away, but that does not stop him from trying to help her or Superman by the end.And now, the kid. Lois Lane has a kid who she doesn't seem to mind tagging along while they break into a houseboat. You know, that's pretty much child neglect if you ask me. Well, you can predict a lot of this story line, but the movie in general toys with it's predictability, and has a bit of fun with the audience.Keeping with the tone of the Donner/Lester films, this movie has some really dark moments, some massive destructions, but a really strong sense of humor. Unlike the earlier films, it never comes off as disjointed.Again, we have to find ways for human characters to create a challenge worthy of Superman. The Challenge presented does suffice, and while we know Superman is going to win in the end, we see that he is getting hurt pretty badly. Even as Zod had him "kneeling before him" I never once thought the character was in any danger. Hell, he's Superman. As the name implies, he can do just about anything.Like X2: X-Men United this is a long movie. However, it just doesn't feel that way because Singer paced the movie very well. Compare to other Superhero fare, like X-3 which felt as short as it was. Singer knows how to pace movies, and manage to balance several story arcs at once.All in all, it's a pretty good movie. It has it's good, it has it's bad, but I think the good outweighs the bad. If you liked X Men 3, this movie is not for you. It has the wit and intelligence that X Men 3 lacked. It had adventure, character development, and just the right touch of humor.***/****

Review Title: Staying true to the red and blue while making the movie feel current
Review: I thought the movie was absolutely well done in terms of Singer's ability to capture the original essence of the previous Superman movies, but put together with all of those things we love about our movies today. That is the single best thing about this movie. It feels as if you can watch all 4 previous Superman movies and this one would fall right in line. Die hard fans will be appreciative of the plot and the way Superman stays true to his roots, and newer fans will enjoy the way Superman outshines any of the latest superhero movies.The plot was excellent and well thought out, and there is enough action in the movie for some of the guys like me to feel we got our money's worth. Kevin Spacey plays a wonderful Lex Luthor equipped with his criminal intelligence who would have made Gene Hackman proud. The supporting cast also does a great job keeping your eye off Superman. Hats off to James Marsden who plays an excellent job as Lois Lane's fiancé and possible backseat to Superman. Not much you can do when your lady used to date the man of steel, but his behavior of both concern and curiosity is captured well on film.My only quam with the movie is that as a fan you feel as if you live right there in metropolis and want to have your own one-on-one conversation with Superman about where he's been and what he's been up to. And although the reason's are covered in the movie, I personally would have like the to hear the director's cut version. Great flick!!

OK OK, so it definitely has some problems, but that doesn't prevent me from loving it anyway. Singer accomplishes a difficult thing by making the often conceived as boringly perfect Superman relatable with a poetic film just dripping with yearning, pain, and sacrifice. Singer's prowess is undoubtedly his ability to make you feel for his characters (which he does so well in the first two X-men movies), and his choice in making Superman's feelings for Lois and the father/son theme at the core of the film is decidedly brilliant because these are all emotions we can relate to ourselves. Thus those who find Superman boring won't, because he is made extremely human by all of those things. Although the best moments in the film, in my opinion, are the dramatic ones, Superman Returns still provides a ton of good old-fashioned action. See it on IMAX if possible for those breathtaking four scenes in 3D! Kevin Spacey does a lovely non-campy but still entertaining version of Lex Luthor (though a problem here is that his storyline is not as interesting as Superman's story--the film feels less like a film about a hero vs. a villain as much as a drama with action pieces), and Routh is wonderfully believable as Superman and Clark. Bosworth is not particularly interesting as Lois, certainly NOT Margot Kidder's feisty and spunky intrepid ace reporter, but she's likable and believable and serves her purpose in the story. Overall, even with its problems such as a slowly and strangely paced first 45 minutes, the film is strong, solid, moving, and I loved it, especially the last thrilling and moving half. Singer has convinced me that Superman is certainly back, and boy, have we all been missing him!

Review Title: I LOVE this movie, despite its gigantic loopholes and inconsistencies

Review: Singer did a great job with this latest installment. I was initially nervous that Routh wouldn't be able to fill such large shoes, but he pulled out a flawless performance. Within just a few minutes, I quit trying to compare Christoper Reeve with Routh, and easily accepted Routh as the One. Spacey was a credit to the Luthor character, and Parker Posey provided the film with a fabulous scene stealing sidekick. This will be the benchmark for all future hero-genre movies. Technically, the special effects were right on! The old tag line from the first movie about believing a man can fly really holds up here. All the action sequences were fantastic and the tensions between the main characters kept the drama flowing well. I'm a committed Super-fan!

Review Title: Overall an entertaining movie which exceeded my expectations
Review: Don't see it on IMAX 3D! Sure seeing it on the IMAX screen was amazing, but the 3D portions were very poor and I would have much rather seen it on a regular movie screen. They should keep the 3D portions to animated features.When I heard this movie was being made I thought, like most people, how can they replace Christopher Reeve? There was no doubt in my mind that it was a bad idea. Then I saw the first trailer and I couldn't help but be excited. I was worried the movie would not live up to my hopes and expectations, but I was wrong. The action sequences are amazing and adrenaline pumping, although some aren't remotely believable, but who cares, this is Superman we're talking about. Kevin Spacey did a great job with his limited/lacking script for Lex Luthor.Some of the critics say Brandon Routh brought no personality to Superman, and I find it difficult to believe they didn't cast him just because he resembles Reeve. Routh must have done a lot of research on Reeve's portrayal of Superman, because he pulled it over extremely well.Overall the movie had a great balance of action, humour, and cheese to it. The romance portion dragged a bit, but I have to assume the director did this to build the story for future Superman movies. I loved it and will likely see it again on the regular big screen.

Review Title: Amazing movie with a horrible twist.
A fun film, but the plot is more of an excuse than a reason.
Review: Superman returns to earth and Lois is getting a Pulitzer prize for writing the article "does earth really need Superman?" it's a movie about Superman, of course earth needs him, so really there is no question. Excellent effects and the 3-D Imax is amazing. Lois Lane is married and now Superman is back, they really gray out Superman's morals by having him tempting a married woman, though he does keep his distance... by making her fall for him again. I haven't seen a Superman movie where Superman has fewer lines than this one. Good acting by all but the story seems pulled in too many directions to fully capatilize on any one dramatic plot point. Too much hype may be the culprit for my low rating. I'll have to watch Superman 2 again to really get the Lois and Clark relationship, but I do remember the Fortress of Solitude scene that spawned a Asmatic super boy that could have been developed into a cool story instead of an after thought. Lex Luthor wants his Land, Superman wants to be wanted, and Lois wants too much from Super hero Dads. Oh, and never put Sir Richard Branson in cameo roles, it makes it look like he bought his way on to the set to surprise all the viewers. Look at me I'm in Superman, I'm a billionaire.

I saw "Superman Returns" last night in a plush Hollywood movie theater surrounded by devoted Superman fans. That in itself, I must admit, was part of the fun. Brandon Routh is breathtakingly, impossibly beautiful and you can trust that in a Bryan Singer movie stunning looking people will populate the screen. Here, the hero with the sensational eyelashes, works wonders in every single way. There is a hint of Superman as Jesus. Cucifixtion, resurrection, from Father to Son and I bought it wholeheartedly because it deserves to be bought. Kevin Spacey is a fun arch villain. There is nobody as convincingly evil as Kevin Spacey. It was strange, however, to see the lovely Kate Bosworth who played Sandra Dee to Spacey's Bobby Darin in "Beyond The Sea" to be so extremely at odds with each other but I bought Luthor and Lane much more than Darin and Dee. Ultimately Superman Returns is a classy, classic rendition of a perennial tale by one of the most successful aesthetes working on film today. Recommend it.

Whimsical, exciting and bold, SUPERMAN RETURNS brought back magic to me I haven't felt since I was a little kid watching Christopher Reeve in the original films. Brandon Routh was REMARKABLE in the part! He bears such an uncanny resemblance to Reeve in the film, it gave me chills! There could not have been a better choice for Kevin Spacey as Lex Luther. He plays the villain with such suave finesse, giving the character a little bit of his own charm. Kate Bosworth plays Lois as a new woman. She is engaged with a child now, so it is assumed the way she played Lois had to be changed with the times. She is much less vulnerable in this one; much prettier and smarter than Margot Kidder's Lois. Perhaps one of the film's best surprises was Parker Posey as Luther's sidekick, Kitty. Posey is one of today's most underrated actresses. She always has a natural magnetism and she was delightful. The film obviously tries hard not to upset fans of the old Superman, and gives us just enough of the old to balance with the new. The film's only flaw is the last 30 minutes. It is a bit attenuous, could have been 20 minutes shorter, but I loved every minute of it anyways. Being a part of the "old" Superman generation, I have to say that I am pleasantly enticed and I actually hope for more to come. Grade: A

Review Title: The Quiet Triumph of the Man of Steel

Review: It saddens me to say this but unfortunately, I think a lot of people are going to be disappointed with this film - it's definitely full of action and is entertaining, but it severely lacks substance. I felt the performances were weak, especially Brandon Routh and Kate Bosworth. Kevin Spacey was the saving grace of the film. The CGI effects were too over the top and I walked out of the screening feeling unsatisfied given the amount of hype. All I can say is the warm sensation I used to get while watching Christopher Reeve was non existent and everything that embodies superman was somehow lost in translation. Sorry to disappoint y'all, believe me I was disappointed too...I had such high hopes for Superman Returns. :-(

Review Title: Singer is all over the place.
Review: Don't think I'll be adding anything new with my comments, but unfortunately, I belong to the camp that was disappointed. While SR is by no means a bad film, it certainly wasn't as good as it could have been. Singer is all over the place with his themes. Simultaneously, he's trying to pay homage to Donner and Action Comics while also alluding to a greater myth. It's doable, but Superman's humanity is somehow lost amidst an over-worked love story. Routh, who actually does a decent job inheriting Reeve's mantle, spends most of the film moping. Spacey wasn't as bad as I had thought, but he's given barely a page of dialogue and his Lex Luthor never emerges beyond a uni-dimensional foil. Again, this is not a bad film, but with $250mm they could have made an amazing film. Singer does demonstrate the ability to create amazing scenes (the airplane scene, the Atlas scene where Supes catches the Daily Planet globe, the Messianic fall of Supes back to Earth), but let's hope the next venture is better.

Review Title: He's so much more bad ass then I expected
Review: OK so I am not a huge Superman fan, I mean I've seen all the flicks and I know all about the character and I watch Smallville. (I know) So I kind of expected to only sort of like this film. I knew I would be able to judge weather it was good or bad regardless of my enjoyment of it though. Man I was wrong. I loved it! I really must stress that I am way more of a fan of a hero like Batman with all his attitude, and while the first set of films staring Christopher Reeve were definitely brilliant, there was always something missing from them for me. I always felt like though everyone in them did an excellent job and all, I don't know, something about them felt off. This movie has changed all that for me. I am not saying it is better or that Superman I is bad but setting this one up using Superman I and II as a sort of background really worked for me. I don't want to tell you about the plot or anything. I just want to express how impressed I am by all the people involved. Brandon Routh does a superb job of playing Clark Kent as a guy no one really thinks about, he's not the bumbling idiot or anything, just goofy enough that no one wants to notice him. He plays Superman as a more confident and powerful personality (obviously, he's Superman after all) He does this with such grace though, it's really something to see. Kate Bosworth is a really decent Lois Lane, she's not as hard as some reviews have said, she makes sense to me. Obviously Kevin Spacey steals the show sometimes, his Lex Luthor is evil and scary and smart ass all together and it's great, and Parker Posey is a great sidekick to him. I was more surprised about the amount of genuine laughs this flick had then anything else. I really did laugh out loud several times, and I teared up too. It's a great movie it doesn't feel as long as it is and it is one of the most beautifully shot things I have seen in quite some time. There are several iconic scenes that are filmed so beautifully it made me gasp. I highly recommend this film to both young and old.

Review Title: A tear came to my eye as well...
Review: But for a completely different reason. This movie made "The Lake House" look like an action flick. Besides the boring storyline, this movie tries way to hard to be like the movies before it, and it comes out as an old, dried up, done before version of the big, blue boyscout. With a lack of any real fighting, and the fact that Lex Luthor is in the movie for a total of 15 minutes (maybe), this movie might appeal to extreme die-hard fans of the old films, but should come up short to anyone with any level of intelligence.If you are a fan of plot holes, menacing plans of the real-estate kind, and men lifting things, this movie is for you. But, if you crave an actual storyline and good acting, I recommend you watch Batman Begins if you want a newer DC Comic movie. At least Batman fought someone.I will give it this. Kevin Spacey was a good villain... If this were 1983.

The acting was both bad and in some cases overacted(Spacey), the story was really weak, the action scenes were a joke, the CGI was average, the whole movie was just bad. There is nothing good about this movie. The only redeeming factor about this movie was the Spiderman 3 trailer before it which showed how real superhero movies should look like. I was a huge fan of the first Superman but this movie just spits on the original and does not deserve to have the name Superman in the title. Do not waste your money on this, just wait to it comes to a dollar theater or rent it on DVD. The only way i will recommend this movie is if you see it on IMAX, it is still not a good movie but at least you can see the average action scenes on the IMAX screen. 2/10 rating

The first hour is flawless and the opening credits/original score literally sent a shiver down my spine. The Imax 3-D stuff is stunning as well. There were times when it felt as if it was unnecessary however and the movie does drag on a bit at 2:34 of running time... that being said, between the unbelievable special effects sequences and the sheer joy of seeing the Man of Steel back on screen and literally saving the world, i have to say that Bryan Singer and Co. did an amazing job and Brandon Routh is great as Superman. I believed him right away. Lois Lane(Kate Bosworth) seems like a bit of an ice queen throughout, so sympathy for her character is a bit difficult to muster, but her overall performance was great. Kevin Spacey is perfectly evil as Lex Luthor. The use of Brando's voice as Jor-El is another goosebump-inducing concept that works very well.I think any big time fans of the first two Donner films will be not only be pleased but also blown away by the spectacular fashion that earth's greatest hero has been brought back to life. if you aren't a Superman fan, i suggest viewing the first two films before watching this one. It will help you understand what's going on a little bit better, but IS NOT absolutely necessary to enjoy this film which certainly stands on its own.

Review Title: superman returns for more than he bargained for
Great Movie...great directing...great cast. D.C. comics has officially Returned
Review: This movie was GREAT. it was everything more than i expected. Kudos to Bryan Singer for directing. He is a god at making everyones favorite comic heros look real and authentic. A damn near perfect movie. And cast was excellent. Routh nailed Clark Kent perfectly and was an excellent Superman as well. Bosworth had Lois Lane's attitude, and Kevin Spacey is a god and plays everything perfectly.This movie has it all. Amazing real looking directing, kicking action, great timed comic book humor. The only thing I can complain about is that its too bad Singer couldn't have directed this and done the third X-Men.

This was probably the greatest Super Hero Movie I have seen. I have waited for ages for this movie and it was all worth it. I can not believe all the people who are hating on this movie. Please recognize that they have done a fantastic job with this movie. Bradon does an excellent job as Superman and Kevin Spacey was a brilliant Lex Luthor. The movie definitely makes me want to see the sequel already. So many directions could be taken with this Movie, and I hope they explore all the avenues. Superman Return takes you on a fantstic ride into the world of our greatest Hero ever. This movie was moving, was dramatically exciting and was a great adventure. I will definitely see it again in IMAX and regular theather. Welcome back Superman the Earth really missed you.

Review Title: the true Superman- the movie, or the comic book?
Review: Fans of the Superman comic book may find Superman Returns to be a bit of a disappointment. Bryan Singer clearly was a fan of the Christopher Reeve Superman movies, and this film is made with those films in mind. The lure and mythology, however, of the Superman comic book is, essentially, completely disregarded. Certain decisions are always made when bringing a character as beloved as Superman to the big screen that are necessary in connecting to mainstream audiences, but the two Spiderman films as well as Batman Begins were able to connect to the everyday casual fans while remaining true to the character's roots. Mainstream audiences may enjoy Superman Returns just as they did the original 1978 film, but true Superman buffs will most likely be turned off, perhaps even insulted, by the liberties that Singer and his writers have taken with their beloved character.

I saw Superman at a sneak preview last night and I was impressed by the directing but the movie lacked character. A retread of the other Supermen's movies that didn't break new ground. I was impressed by Spacey and Parker Posey's performances. The main problem I had with Superman was the fact that no one could tell Clark Kent was Superman. I wish they could have changed the costume that Superman wears. Batman changed his costume to hip modern outfit, why cant Superman? I wish the film could have been darker like Batman and made it stand out from the other films. Singer did a good job at directing but he did a better job with X-men. The other thing was Lois lane who had no sex appeal like Terri Hatcher in Lois and Clark. Lois lane was a Witch who didn't have any kind of appeal or charm. Brandon Routh was no Reeves or Cain. Routh didn't give that good of a performance. He wasn't in the same league as Spacey. I guess to sum it up, Superman was just a Seen this, Done that kind of Movie.The trailer for Spiderman 3 was ten times better then Superman Returns

Review Title: For what it's worth, I loved it.
Review: Granted, as a teenage girl, my opinion is never taken amazingly seriously, but for what it's worth, I adored Superman Returns. It's been a long time since I've seen the first two Superman movies, but I do remember loving them and I do remember how amazing Christopher Reeves was, but I have to say that Brandon Routh did a good job filling his shoes. He wasn't a Christopher Reeves, but then again, that's because he's not Christopher Reeves. Routh made Superman his own, and I think he did a great job. Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor was genius and his portrayal even shocked me with how far he went with the character. The action scenes were beautiful, as everyone has been raving and the definitely drew me in. This version is darker and grittier, but surprising, I don't remember seeing an ounce of blood. Bryan Singer was able to give it an amazing feel without making it a love letter to violence. Granted, it had it's flaws, but I loved what they did, and with an ending like that, I will be amazingly disappointed if there is not a sequel.Overall, 8/10.

Review Title: It was written as a Thanks .
An okay start to a great movie sequence...
"You wrote that the world doesn't need a saviour, but every day I hear people crying for one. "
Review: Let me just say that it's good, its not mediocre or bad, but its surely good. Everyone i went with (i went to it with 25 people) seemed to have liked it more than i did, which was surprising.The acting was one of the things i thought was top notch, not perfect like the 1978 and 1980 films. Brandon Routh effortlessly became Superman, he looks like Reeve, and sometimes even sounds like him. He was a bit young, but it was very easy to overlook. Kate Bosworth was a good Lois Lane, shes no Margot Kidder, but she was above average. I blame the writing of the character and how Singer directed her, but she was still good. As you would imagine, Kevin Spacey, while barely misses some of the great lines of Gene Hackman, has a wonderful time and does Lex Luthor extremely well. He has a lot of great lines, just for some reason, the magic of Hackman is missing, but can be easily excused. Sam Huntington does a great job as Jimmy Olsen and somehow catches a little magic that McClure just didn't catch, so for once, a cast improvement is made. The rest of the cast does their job well.The action... not much of it. If you expecting Superman to fly around the whole movie tossing stuff around like a Spiderman or Batman film, you are mistaking. While there is enough action to keep everyone satisfied, and the special effects are top notch, the movie runs a bit long for the amount of action it actually has.The comedy... thank goodness, the one thing i loved about Superman was the comedy. It's back and i loved it here. Singer was able to capture the light hearted side of the characters and really play with different situations. There is nothing that surpasses the Otis and Luthor arguments from the first films, but they come very close.The story is great. Lots of twists and stuff you wouldn't expect.So... what is wrong with this movie? What does it miss? It really dosen't miss anything at all. There is nothing bad in this movie... but i will tell you what harms the film the most. PACING. To my surprise, Singer seems to be the one that messed up a little much this time around. While everything he directed was top notch, the editing however was not. The film is top heavy, with great pacing in the first 2 acts mostly, the last act goes on too long and should have been edited differently. Don't get me wrong, the quality of it was good, but people were waiting for the ending to happen, and even with it did, nothing remarkable happened. The ending wasn't bad, it was a little disappointing thats all. It was underwhelming compared to the roller-coaster ride of a movie it was, though there is a little detail of the ending i will not reveal, but it made it kinda worth it.Now... like i said... a lot of people i was with disagreed with me on this, but thats how i saw it. Everyone clapped for the ending, which surprised me, considering how much of a slow ending it was. It was a great movie, one of the best in a while, exceeds the quality of Lester's Superman II cut that we all love or hate, but never is able to surpass Donner's remarkable original film.I give it 8 out of 10 stars. A great, fantastic, awesome film, but somehow does not meet the standard of the first Superman film.

Superman was going to be a very difficult movie to make; for both the actors and the crew. Comparing it to the original superman with Christopher Reeves, it fell short, but only a little short. As a sequel, standing alone, it was fantastic. Kevin Spacey was a perfect cast for Lex Luthor and did a wonderful job. I also liked Parker Posey as Mrs. Kitty. She brought some comic relief to the film and did a god job. Kate Bonsworth did an average Lois Lane; I would have liked to see someone else playing the part, like maybe Kate Beckinsale. Brandon Routh who??? I don't think anyone else could have done any better job than he did. He was the next best Superman you could hope to see on the big screen, paying homage to Christopher Reeves. I liked everything about this film and would definitely recommend seeing it. I am going to see it again tonight.

Hands down, this was the best Superman movie (Visually speaking). Singer should take pride in what I saw was a tribute to the first 2 Superman films. I will say the movie was great. For the most part, it kept a pretty good pace and the updated actors fit perfectly into their roles. Routh was perfect for the title role and Spacey, being one of the best actors of our time, was spot on as Luther. I didn't care too much for Bosworth's Lois Lane, she seemed so awkward and uncomfortable in that part. I'm sure she would have made a decent Lane, had she just chosen a different direction for her character. From the opening credits to the final scene, I felt like this was Singer's way of saying "Thanks for those first 2 Superman movies, now let's add some up to date special effects!" I think this movie set up what is going to be an amazing series for this generation to enjoy as much as we did with the Reeves/Donner films.

Review Title: Despite a rehashed story line, perhaps the best Superman ever done on film.
Review: I just saw this movie as a late night sneak preview, and thought that it was the best Superman treatment that I have ever seen done on film.I'm old enough that I have seen both Chris Reeve and George Reeves step into this role and do it honor, so I figured it might take a few minutes to warm up to Brandon Routh's take on the character, but I can honestly say that he won me over very quickly, and I think he has done an incredible job which would have made his now departed fellow actors proud.Routh has piercing blue eyes in the film (apperently CGI'ed that way, but who cares?), which can be steel hard one moment, and lipid pools of hidden emotions the next (hinting at the burden that the 'Man of Steel' must carry).The contours of his face also lend themselves well to portraying both the 'mild mannered reporter' Clark Kent AND the somewhat more serious and dour Superman.Louis Lane is played by another relative newcomer Kate Bosworth; and Kate did a damn fine job in portraying a Louis Lane who is conflicted, but deeply in love with Superman.Lex Luthor is played in the film by the Acadamy Award winning actor Kevin Spacey, who lends the character a much more serious edge than Gene Hackman did in the last series of Superman films back in the 70's and 80's. Spacey also did a very good job, though I have to admit that one or two of his yelling blustering tirades went a little 'over the top' for my tastes, and didn't fit my personal mental picture of that character, who I thought should have been just a bit more quietly sinister and menacing (on the other hand, Lex is supposed to be an INSANE evil genus, so who am I to say?). Overall, Spacey's performance is intense, energetic, and original, and is perfectly in sync with the somewhat more serious dramatic tone that the director and producers were trying to create for the film.The CGI work and special effects in the film are also very well done, certainly some of the best I have ever seen in a recent film.Although I enjoyed the film a lot, and DO recommend it highly, there is one area where it falls a little below my expectations, and that is in the quality of the script.This is not because it's not suspenseful, or the guys who wrote it couldn't string together some incredible action sequences (they did), but because they also used a lot of rehashed plot threads from previous films. Guys! ; This is NOT the X-men where there were originally NO prior movies, so it needed a newer more ORIGINAL treatment (like the one in the 'Batman Begins' film).I don't know whether it was the writers or producers decision, but the decision to use a 'rehashed' Lex Luthor storyline from a previous film, when the Superman mythos spans hundreds of stories EACH with the potential to be adapted into a film, was a BLINDINGLY STUPID choice that weakened an otherwise excellent film.In fairness, the telling of this new adaptation is quite different, and I did find the film, suspenseful, interesting and engaging, I just think that the writers could have done a much better screenplay if they had pushed the story in a more original direction.So this is why, even though I did say above that this was perhaps the best Superman I had ever seen done on film, it only rates nine stars and not a perfect 10.

Superman Returns what can i say i have never been so excited about seeing a movie ever. I've watched Smallville over the past few years and though a Superman movie would ruin the show for the fact that the show wasn't over and that it was using new actors. But then i heard Bryan Singer wan directing it and that changed most of it I trusted the genius behind X2, then i saw the Preview and Marlon Brondos voice as Jor-El over the Krypton Theme was amazing and made me loose all doubts. The movie itself was well put together, if u like the original Christopher Reves and Richard Donner version you will not be disappointed. This movie has a very similar opening sequence and the music is nostalgic. I had the biggest smile on my face when the opening sequence started. Through out the movie there are many nods to the original and even the old comics and George Reeves version.Overall the acting was Superb you have to trust a director who basically discovers Hugh Jackman. Brandon Routh was great as Superman Kal-El and Clark Kent. He showed emotion when it was needed and never overacted at all. Kate Bosworth has to be the hottest Lois Lane and although she lacked that sass from the original she was believable as a changed and conflicted Lois Lane. Lex Lex Lex, did anyone play Lex Lutor because he was perfect, he was sinister and comical when he needed to be. Kevin Spacey was a great Lex Luthor and he wasn't like Gene Hackmans campy Lex, he was more like Smallville's and the comic books Lex Luthor which i liked. ANd All the supporting actors were on point Parker Posey was funny when she needed to be, James Mardsen was actually likable in this movie, (I didn't like him in Xmen or the Notebook), Sam Huntington (from Not Another Teen Movie) he was funny as Jimmy Olsen. This movie was so great on many levels visually, action wise (although don't expect too much), and most important of all story wise. The story is great and it is very detailed so everything has a reason it is happening. Overall this is a great restart or should i say continuation of the Superman Movie Franchise.

Review Title: Superman returns is apparently tied to the first and second films however it is impossible to know for sure.
If you are a die-hard superman fan sorry this isn't made for you.
ranks right among the best super-hero films
Review: Bryan Singer's "re-quel", if you will, of Donner's late 70's Super flick is a success. He manages to bring freshness to the source material while paying homage to the look and feel of the Salkind produced classics. We can see Singer's affection right from the nostalgic opening credits, all the way through to the final shot. But we can also see how the story has been updated to modern sensibilities. Brandon Routh is more than able to usher in the character into the new millennium, and Spacey's Lex Luthor is spot on. In fact all the supporting cast is quite good, although Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane suffers from looking a little too young to be an experienced reporter and have a 5-year old child. Nonetheless, the action is appropriately Super looking, and the chemistry between Routh and Bosworth is believable enough to carry the emotional heft of the screenplay. Definitely a satisfying and worthy addition to the stable of modern superhero classics like Spider-Man 2 and X2. Can't wait to see the sequel!

Review Title: After as much time, Superman Returns
Review: It's far better of which it had been able to imagine, it enchanted to me. The film fulfills all my expectations, Bryan Singer is a genius and Brandon Routh is the new Superman. With respect to the special effects they are incredible. It's without a doubt the film of Superman that we were hoping to be able to see and some of the scenes of effects are the best ones than never they have been seen in a cinema. The flight scenes are very credible but I liked plus those of Matrix Revolutions. James Mardsen made really worry me to me about a personage who in principle would not have to be there; Parker Posey robs all their scenes; Eva Marie Saint was penetrating and magnificent; Frank Langella, a really fantastic Perry White; Sam Huntington, the best Jimmy of all the times; Kevin Spacey, excellent, seemed to previous but the better and much more cruel one. It's easily the most sinister Lex never seen in screen, a delight to see; Kate Bosworth is deep, obstinate and fighter, as Lois must be. And Brandon Routh IS Superman. He's very similar to Cristopher Reeve, although it needs to its greatness and originality. The chemistry between Brandon and Kate is enormous. The personalities of Clark and Superman were more defined, they really make you see as if they were different people and the special effects are outside this world. It seems that they used Kriptonian technology to do them. The history, script and stage scene of the film, are the one that all we want to see, and so deep that I take it inside.

No spoilers here. Just a review. Batman is my favorite hero. Superman is my 2nd favorite. Quite simply, Superman Returns is awesome. When I go to a movie, I want to be taken someplace. I want to forget about my troubles for a couple hours and put my focus into just getting lost in a movie. At first I didn't know what to expect from this movie. I liked everything Bryan Singer had done thus-far. Everything from his previous movies to his picking the cast for this movie to the costume changes. This movie just got to me. I laughed and I cried. It made me feel everything that I wanted to feel. Bryan Singer had a vision and he brought it to the table and he just kicks ass with it. The shots he created and the feeling he brought to the screen are perfect. Wait until you see the first time Superman actually comes back. Easily the best Superman scene shot on film. The main guy, Brandon Routh nailed it. He wasn't to over the top as Clark Kent and he was just the right amount of klutziness mixed with coolness. As Superman, he embodied the role. He became Superman. From his first appearance to his last one, I felt for him. The whole idea that this person from another planet would sacrifice so much and go through all this internal and external battling should speak to many people. Kate Bosworth also did a great job. She was a little more damsel in distress then expected but a solid job nonetheless. Kevin Spacey owned this movie. I hated him so much for what he was doing that I wanted to see a sequel right then and there and have Superman beat his ass. He just became this evil tyrant and it will stick in my mind for sometime. All the characters after the main 3....Eve Marie Saint, Frank Langella, Sam Huntington who was amazing, Parker Posey, James Mardsen who had a scene where he almost outshines Superman in his act of heroism, and of course Marlon Brando who in basically his last role made the film connect to the past even more, pulled off a great supporting cast who will all hopefully be coming back for more. There are also some great scenes with the little kid which at first I though I wasn't going to like but it then grew on me. I'll say also that the crowd I saw it with at the 10:00 showing on Tuesday, applauded many times. Superman has most certainly returned. Hopefully if we are lucky....he wont be going anywhere.

Review Title: A legendary and mighty adaptation of Superman.....
Review: I came back from seeing this movie at its first public screening, this afternoon at the local theatre. In my opinion, this glamorous and mighty adaptation of the Man of Steel, is nothing but flawless.Brandon Routh portrayed Superman miraculously in his first major starring role of his career as an actor. He, like Christopher Reeve before him, maintained the balance between the clumsy, mild-mannered reporter, Clark Kent, as well as Superman himself. Kudos to Brandon for his contributions to this immortal character. Kate Bosworth cleanly portrayed the ever persistent Lois Lane, although I felt that it needed a little brushing up. This is because she only started her career several years back, and Margot Kidder, in my opinion, performed her role slightly more demanding and persistent to find out who Superman's alter ego is. This Superman film in my opinion, ranks ahead of Superman, and Superman 2. Good job Singer, you directed a masterpiece.

Review Title: Superman Returns to no real parade.

Review: There is a wonderful form of escapism that a good comic book movie should bring. I mean a type in which you do not sit around and attempt to nit-pick some of the trivial questions to cheapen the film's authenticity. Superman Returns captures that emotion perfectly. By no means does this film feel like a fairy tale, but but it it lets you sit back and smile. In short, this is great film to see for pure entertainment. This film is not perfect, but it is still very fulfilling. Some can criticize it for being a bit too fast paced at first or for getting a bit too sappy towards the end. The film however, makes up for this with its beautiful action, masterful villainy, strong acting, and solid character development. Overall, it is fun for anyone who just feels like watching a movie for the sake of having a good time. TINY SPOILERS Starting with the actors, the first observation you can draw is that they all had fun. They all felt an attachment to their characters. Brandon Roeth truly became Superman and Clark Kent perfectly. He was able to make Kent into a caring man who means well both as Clark Kent and Superman. As Clark Kent, the greatest challenge of his is coping with the reality that his romantic life with Lois is be over. Upon coping with Lois as a mother who has moved from her Superman/Clark days he must learn to accept this loss that came with his reasons for leaving. As Superman however, he still realizes the significance in his role as a world savior who must bring Metropolis and the world back in order. That is where the best performance comes in with Kevin Spacey as Lex. Now this was a spectacular performance as expected. Did he play Kevin Spacey? Yes and no. Again, he did his generic act in many parts; a sarcastically energetic, smart-Alec. His passion for genuinely insulting everything was very prominent in this role. Thst element worked well for the part, but playing another Lester Burnham was not the reason I liked him. He manages to bring both the evil element as Lex and the comical element. Things as simple as calling Lois' name while he is brushing his teeth gave him a charmingly evil persona. He also brought the right element of naive arrogance I think comic book super villains typically need. He manages to play a character who can beat Superman and does in fact come seriously close, but can not quite manage. The weakest acting performance, I felt was Kate Bosworth. I did not mind her, but she did not manage to replace Margot Kidder in my eyes. Christoper Reeve and Gene Hackman did performances I will always appreciate and love, but Roeth and Spacey were comparable if not superior to them. Bosworth could not say the same. Her performance was not bad, but it was nothing more than I would have expected. I like the static development of Lois in the film, but Boswarth I felt was too much one emotion by one. First she was bitter and sad in denial; then she was irritatingly motherly (and wait until you see her son in this movie). I never really felt much for her though. Then of course, Lex needs to have a really annoying side kick. Can I blame Parker Posey for her performance? Bryan Singer wanted a character to seriously irritate the audience. It worked. Was she funny? Not really. Spacey played well off of her though, so she was fine. The plot? It's Superman. What do you want, an Oscar-caliber screenplay? Lex wants to sink the United States by creating a new entire continent that he will raise out of the water with with crystals to sell land and create fear in the rest of the world. He is a bitter man who has inherited the entire estate of an incredibly wealth woman who has just died. And now he needs more money. I guess he is not a man to believe that the best revenge is living well. Sounds like a Superman plot to me.The best part of the film is the action. Every shot of Superman flying to the rescue whether he is saving a plane or taking out criminals is fabulous. Yes, you know Superman can accomplish any of these tasks in a pinch. The most exciting element of each action sequence is waiting for him to appear. The the action scenes will just make you want to cheer along with everyone else watching.The first major weakness in the film was less of a problem than I thought it was going to be at first. The first few major elements of what Kevin Dougherty wanted to cover in the story felt a little rushed. I felt that Superman just reappeared to quickly. I like the plot in a film to really get going after I get a solid attachment to the characters. This film is still a follow-up to 80's Superman movies, but that franchise had been on hiatus for nineteen years. It was worth reintroducing the plot a tad more. This however, became less problematic as the film developed and got more into the new material. The film's greatest weakness was the sap; especially toward the end with with everyone'es emotional love for Superman they showed. As far as specific detail, that is for you the reader to find by watching the film. I loved this film as a whole! It was exciting, and thoroughly fulfilling in virtually all the crucial elements of a fun action film. I highly recommend it to anyone who likes campy action and fun characters. Overall rating 8/10

This movie steals a lot of it's plot lines and even several of it's lines of dialog from the 1978 Richard Donner version. What it should have taken instead is the approach, which it misses entirely. The tag-line for the '78 film was "You'll Believe a Man Can Fly" and this summed up the film's attempt to bring verisimilitude to the story. To make you believe in the world that Superman lived in, was to enable you to invest in the story emotionally. If you don't believe in the world he lives in, you don't care what happens to it, or the characters within it. This new movie brings up a lot of promising ideas, and then it doesn't explore them at all, dragging them down to the mundane. As seen in the trailer, Luthor enters the Fortress of Solitude, and is granted access to the accumulated scientific knowledge from dozens of galaxies. And all the writers can think to have him do with it is one stupid, limited, unimaginative thing. And the nature of the Kryptonian technology itself, borrowed from the original film, is not explored beyond one small aspect. There are some great action scenes and special effects, but the last act of the film falls flat. There is nothing to fear, or root for. It just hangs there. Wish Singer had made X3 instead, which would have improved under his guidance, and wish someone more daring had taken on Superman. One word review: Mundane

Review Title: It's Bird, It's a Plane... the Third Act Blows

Review: I will stay spoiler free, I promise. The movie was great, the storyline was good(albeit some minor plot holes, but in truth, name one movie that doesn't, I dare you), and the CGI/FX were amazing. You truly believe a man can fly. The storyline has, in my mind three substantial plot twists, and all three took me by surprise, which is odd, because I'm on the IMDb.com Superman Returns board all the time, and yet, Singer and crew still kept things hidden, or planted enough doubt about those rumors, to nullify them.I enjoyed this movie greatly, and I believe, that the later Christopher Reeve would love this movie. I recommend this movie, to anyone, and everyone.

I just got home after seeing a 10pm "Superman Returns" showing and I really enjoyed it! The pacing was good, character development, and the action, it made me really "Believe that a man could Fly"!!Brandon Routh did an excellent job! He had some very big boots to fill (Christopher Reeve's), skeptics may have thought that Routh couldn't pull it off, he did it with flying colors!!For any Superman Fan, I Highly recommend it, the movie pays tribute to Reeve's performance, and is even dedicated to Christopher and Dana Reeve in the Credits.There were a couple of cheesy lines taken from the other movies, but I sort of enjoyed those too.I do agree that the Superman Chest Logo does look silly with the tiny "S" all over it, but other than that I didn't mind the suit changes.

I had very high expectations when going to see the sneak preview of Superman Returns last night. Needless to say, these expectations were met and then some. Brandon Routh plays both roles (Kent/Superman)astoundingly well. You could not ask for a better Superman in my opinion. The movie delivers in every way you would expect - and then throws in a couple twists that you wouldn't. I won't say anymore except to say GO SEE THIS MOVIE!!!! Fan of Superman or not, this is a great movie that will definitely please. This movie was cast superbly, the writing is great, and it does justice to the Superman legacy. Kevin Spacey plays Lex Luthors' villainy with perfection. "Textbook" Lex (cue maniacal laughter). You love him and hate him at the same time, but ultimately wish him the worst. Great job everyone! I can't wait for a sequel=)

Review Title: Bryan Singer owes Superman an apology

Review: I loved this movie, as does most everyone else it seems. Geat effects, good story, good acting, pretty much a full package. Basically, Superman comes back after a five year journey to the remains of his home world Krypton. Lex Luthor, played extremely well by Kevin Spacey, maybe the best Lex ever, also find Superman's Fortress of Solitude, and lets just say nothing good comes from that. Lois Lane has a child and fiancé, and this of course creates some inner conflict for Clark and Superman. I would say Kate Bosworth, who plays Lois, is the weakest part of the movie. It isn't that she is a bad actress, quite the opposite really, but she is a twenty-three year old (and she looks twenty-three) playing a thirty-something mom of a five year old, and it just isn't convincing. She acts a great Lois, has just the right amount of attitude, but through out the movie you are just too aware of how young she looks. But, she is hot as hell, so who really cares, right? Now, on to the big guy, Brandon Routh. So many have labeled him as a "Superboy" rather than "Superman" and for a while, I agreed. I don't anymore. This guy does look a bit young, as does Bosworth, but he is an excellent Superman and Clark Kent, and to me, is a better Superman than Christopher Reeves, but to be fair, I was never a huge fan of Reeves's Superman. After watching this movie, all my fears about his capabilities as Superman. He looks great in the suit, a lot buffer than photos make it look, and his Clark Kent is dead on. He is the perfect mild mannered, clumsy reporter he should be. I am really looking forward to seeing him play Supe's in th inevitable sequels.The effects are great in this movie. When we see Superman flying, it looks real, completely real. When I first saw Spider-man swinging through New York some years back, I thought "that looks really cool, but you can tell it is computer generated." Not with this movie. The scenes where he saves the burning planes is amazing, it looks real, and is extremely exciting. Everything in this movie looks great, and does our most popular hero a fine amount of justice.People breathed a sigh of relief when Brian Singer (X-Men, X-Men 2) was slated to direct Superman, after his outstanding work on the X-Men movies (in which his absence on the third is apparent), and that sigh was warranted. He did a great job. He knew exactly what he wanted to do with the movie, and exactly where he wanted to take it. This guy should write a book on how to do Super Hero movies, because he is a master, and knowing he will be doing the sequels is comforting. You can tell he loves these characters as much as we all do, and tries to make the movie he thinks most people want to see, rather than the movie he wants to see. I can't wait to see his future work.Superman Returns: 9/10

My family watched the first show this morning in our local IMAX theater. Now that I've calmed down a little bit, I can write here.Truth be told, I had incredibly high expectations for this movie, and they were met...mostly. The reason I gave the movie an 8 instead of a 10 is that I don't think Kevin Spacey makes the best Lex Luthor; he didn't really intimidate me, if you know what I mean. Then again, maybe they should have cast someone less known in that role too. I am so accustomed to watching Michael Rosenbaum play Lex in Smallville, were he really IS the man you love to hate, that Spacey disappointed me. Bring on the hate mail, Spacey lovers!Anyway, I would never spoil a movie for someone. The movie is great, it draws you in and, of course, the special effects are awesome. However, all I really want to say is this. If, when you hear the first stanzas of that famous Superman score, you do not start bawling because:1. Christopher Reeves is gone, AND2. You've waited so long to see Superman again on screen that you feel overwhelmed...then you ARE NOT a Superman fan...or you have no heart and are related to Lex.LONG LIVE SUPERMAN! and thank you, Bryan Singer. You rule.

Review Title: A review for Superman Fans and Non-fans alike.
Look, up in the air! It's another jumbled, loud, poorly-conceived blockbuster!
