Review: All the right ingredients should have made the ideal superhero movie, but sadly the chefs instead cooked up a remake that doesn't equal the fun or quality of Superman I and II.The new film attempts to humanize the story of Superman with quick snapshots of his isolation and longing for Lois Lane. However, they are all dashed in favor of special affects that whoosh by so fast the audience can't even distinguish what's going on. Is it a bird? A plane? No, it's just a blur of red and blue mixed with deafening digital explosions. The only real "whoa" moments that showcase Superman's talents are thankfully done in slow-motion. It's an old trick popularized by the Matrix, but is used wisely here.The new Man of Steel, Brandon Routh looks the part, but needs a few more acting lessons before he should be able to helm such a heavy responsibility. Lois Lane, played by Kate Bosworth, never works up a good rapport or chemistry between her character and Superman, and she hardly shares a word with Clark Kent. His nemesis, Lex Luthor a la Kevin Spacey, doesn't have the same maniacal happiness shown by Gene Hackman.With a running time of 2 1/2 hours, you would think time would be made for a better story and to fill some of the maddening plot holes. Why was Clark gone for five years? Nobody cares to ask. What did Superman find of his home world in that time? People ask, but get interrupted. Why couldn't a better movie come from years of planning, a good villain and competent director? No one knows.

Maybe my expectations were too high. Brandon Routh looks a lot like Christopher Reeves. Kevin Spacey is one of our finest actors. Bryan Singer is an excellent director. They spent YEARS in development on this. . .oh, maybe that's the problem. I don't blame the actors or the director for my problems with this -- I actually think the movie was very well cast and well shot. I loved many of the visuals in the story. What bothered me, though, was the writing. The issue wasn't with the dialogue (which was suitably cheesy - Superman's line after the plane sequence rivaled some of the best Reeves lines and deliveries in any of the other movies) but rather with the weak story. Why couldn't there have been MORE in this story than a tacked on "Is he the father or not" story to the "ooh, Lex wants to take over the world...?" It just didn't carry enough weight to truly herald back the greatest superhero of the last century. Superman isn't supposed to have the angst of the Spiderman or Batman, and this movie didn't even pretend to that, which I admire. However, what made Superman 1 and 2 so great were the plots and real motivations of the characters for their actions, something I found lacking in this film. Here's hoping this is just a bridge movie to a GREAT sequel with a STRONG story -- the actors and visuals are lined up -- no give us a REAL tale to watch!

Everything a Superman fan (the movies or the comics) could want is here: The classic theme by John Williams, spectacular visual effects, repeatedly showing off Superman's powers, and Kevin Spacey. His Lex Luthor is much more evil and sinister, while still retaining the humor of Gene Hackman's original. The Man of Steel himself also did an incredible job. He resembles Christopher Reeve in so many ways, I almost forgot it was a different actor. Kate Bosworth was fantastic as well.I saw the IMAX 3-D version, and I gotta say it was somewhat disappointing. Don't get me wrong, it was great seeing the whole thing on that gigantic screen. You almost feel like you're flying alongside Superman. But the 3-D here feels like a wasted opportunity sometimes. Sure, twenty minutes is better than nothing, but there were other scenes that would've looked great in 3-D as well (Opening Credits for example). Still, it was a very cool experience, and I think I still would've enjoyed it in a regular theater.9 out of 10. Not as good as the first movie but better than the other sequels put together.

Review Title: and people thought X-men 3 was bad.
Review: Bryan singer returns to butcher another comic book series. Despite all the butt kissing this movie got, it is a predictable, drawn out, beat yourself over the head "why did i pay money for this?" movie. It picks up supposedly after superman 2. a movie which if you haven't seen makes you watch this and say huhh????? Exciting at first (referring to the titles and the music's effect,) it takes us almost an hour to get to anything interesting. Holding no significant moral value or intellectual interest, Superman Retarded gets "two fingers away from the pulse, jammed straight up your a**. Say, would anyone like a chocolate covered pretzel?"

Review Title: Good movie, but can't quite match the original or even that sequel
Review: I liked Superman Returns. I believe Brandon Routh as Superman was quite decent in the role. Of course he will never be able to equal the performance by Christopher Reeve, but I don't think anyone could for that matter.Still, as I watched Superman Returns I couldn't help but compare it to the 1978 film. Like the original, Superman Returns has a heart, but what it lacks, and that was something that the first film had no problem with, is in action. Sure there were some terrific scenes, but I don't believe there were any that could compare to the 1978 version when Superman saves Lois Lane by super-speeding around the earth to push back time.Another problem with this film was that secondary characters were pushed to the back burner so that the film could focus on Lois Lane and Superman. I would've enjoyed seeing a more sharp witted Perry White and even a more interesting Jimmy Olsen, but we didn't really get any of this. And then there's the part involving a child of Lois Lane's, who could've been used better then he was in this film. Even James Marsden, best known as Cyclops in the X-Men films, is not given enough to work with here even though his character was very likable in this movie.I also found myself comparing Margot Kidder and Kate Bosworth and discovered that I enjoyed Margot Kidder's Lois Lane more even though Kate Bosworth was more attractive. I enjoyed Kidder's wit, sassiness, and awe in that film, but Kate Bosworth didn't have that with Returns. Both her and Routh had good chemistry together though, and that's a plus, but it still can't match Reeve and Kidder who to me are still the ultimate Lois Lane and Superman couple.I would've also liked to have seen a little more originality with the new film. There was too much that was copied from the 1978 film. It was like Singer was playing homage to that film, which is quite a good thing, but he just went a little too over the top. I would've enjoyed seeing more creativity on his part instead of rehashing the older film so much. I guess that's why I enjoyed Batman Begins more than Superman Returns, because Christopher Nolan added a lot of his own creativity to the Batman film.With all that aside, I still enjoyed Superman Returns. It looked good and crisp, and the characters were not at all that bad for what they were all given to work with. It may not be the best comic adaption of Superman, but it was still pretty good and worth seeing. If I had to compare it with other comic book movies, it would fall somewhere between X3 and XMen 1. X2 was better.

Review Title: A Story Of Forbidden Love... oh, and the guy involved is Superman!

Review: I was prepared to be a little disappointed in "Superman Returns" but I ended up thrilled instead. Do not be put off by the film's length, 154 minutes, because it NEVER drags. The performances were excellent, too. The always delightful Parker Posey delivered another charming, funny performance and the leads, the very young Brandon Routh as Superman and Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane, could not have been better. For the first time in a long time, Kevin Spacey was given a meaty role, that of the villainous Lex Luthor, that he could knock out of the park and he did. Spacy's performance was spot-on. What a deliciously funny, evil, but incompetent bad guy Spacey made here! The special effects were great but, more importantly, the film told an exciting and satisfying story. This was a well crafted film from top to bottom It is not to be missed. 10 out of 10.

Review Title: Superman comes back to earth to confront his past.
Review: This movie in my opinion is very respectful of what has come before it and yet has its own flavor and style. For those who enjoyed the Christopher Reeve franchise you will also like this new version. It pays tribute to the good parts of what Reeve did with the character and for the image of Superman. The style of this movie has a texture and look that is in a way a result of the influence of director Singer. Some of the look is reminiscent of X-Men elements, but that is where the similarities end. Singer is very aware of the importance that these comic book influenced movies are the fans of those comic books. With all of the recent incarnations and other influences to the Superman saga this one stays true to the movie sensibilities of the treatment to the characters and storyline to a degree. Brandon Routh does a wonderful job making the character his own, while keeping some of the character choices Reeve innovated. Spacey's Lex Luther is fun and menacing. He finds a way to take a character that could become too light and is able to keep the fun and also be a real threat to truth, justice and the American way. Overall this new Superman is a great addition to its history and is refreshing in a time when most superhero movies seem to want to celebrate the dark characters. Superman is a optimistic and good, good guy.

Review Title: It's All About Nostalgia in 'Superman Returns'
Review: It sure can't be easy to live up to audience expectations set by movies generations have grown up with like 'Star Wars'. However, I think 'Superman Returns' succeeds where the new 'Star Wars' movies failed. After languishing for what seemed an eternity in development hell, 'Superman Returns',directed by Bryan Singer, is a credit to Singer and his crew, and quite a marvel to behold.Like with 'Star Wars', audiences have had more than twenty years to process, scrutinize and savor every moment of the 1978 movie version directed by Richard Donner and starring the unpretentious Christopher Reeve. In fact, I found myself at once nostalgic hearing the familiar score by John Williams and from watching the flying blue credits preceding the film. And for but a brief moment, I even expected Christopher Reeve to appear on the screen—just as he was remembered.Though Christopher Reeve did not appear, his presence was definitely felt. A relative unknown, Brandon Routh had an uncanny knack for capturing that which audiences loved about Reeve and adding some of his own personality to the dual roles of Clark Kent and Superman. Even Kate Bosworth brought her own to the role of Lois Lane, made famous on celluloid by Margot Kidder. Her Lois Lane appeared more conflicted than frazzled the way Kidder's Lane always appeared, and it was a welcome and fresh approach. Equally notable was the continuity of a story line from the second film of the original movie run; a perfect segue to this updated rendition. And as the CGI effects of this version dazzle and amaze, the third and fourth installments of the former franchise are easily dismissed like a bad dream.While in recent years iconic comic heroes have been brought to the screen with flair and heart, I think for the updated Superman franchise, the best is yet to come. Though it's clear the film is an homage to the director of the1978 version—with everything from the visual to the spoken echoing its former incarnation—Kevin Spacey's characterization of Lex Luthor was tiresome, trite, and just plain distracting. It was especially disappointing considering the complexity Michael Rosenbaum has given the television version in the 'Smallville' series. That Lex Luthor would have been a wonderfully frightening addition, considering the heart and soul of the 'Superman Returns' script; one in which takes pride in its portrayal of a more complex protagonist, and could have had an equally complex adversary. Instead of wondering what other scheme Luthor might concoct in future installments, I found myself wishing for an indefinite reprieve.But where this movie succeeds in revisiting the celluloid version introduced nearly thirty years ago is the wonderful marriage of special effects and storytelling. This relationship invokes a welcome nostalgia for the old while appreciating the new, complete with a story full of layers and action. Though the length of the movie may turn off some movie-goers, running at 154 minutes, it's well worth viewing for two reasons: first, for fans of the Christopher Reeve Superman, it will leave them feeling nostalgic for the kid who first sat before the giant screen hearing the resounding musical score and watching Reeve fly effortlessly as no one had done before. Secondly, even if you're not a fan of the original movie series, the ease with which Routh's Superman defies gravity, and the impossible task of stepping into roles made cinematically famous three decades ago handled capably, it makes it all too easy to get caught up in the Superman lore.Here's hoping this Superman stays a little while longer. And unlike the last set of films, only gets better with age.

Superman was not a disappointment. Aside from the Mr Mom who brought his irritable whining toddler to the afternoon matinée, it was one of the best times I have had in a theater in a few years. My date and I are ready to go find the nearest IMAX theater and see it again NOW. Of course if you wanted to you could pick it apart, but he movie didn't lag for long. It was not as gruelingly predictable as much of the rest of the crap coming out of Hollywood. I was a big fan of the first 2 Xmen films, and was a bit put off with the last one. Too bad Singer bailed on that project. I hope there is an X4 and A Superman Returns Again and he directs. Brandon Routh delivered. Props to Parker Posey! The audience loved her. Where's Noel Neil?Great Spiderman teaser!Tally-ho!

Saw it last night and I gotta say, wow. While the movie ran slightly longer than I felt necessary, Bryan Singer absolutely knocked it out of the park on this one. Brandon Routh consistently met the demands of playing the boldly brave Superman but also the awkwardly shy and stand-offish Clark Kent. Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor...brilliant casting. Aside from that, this movie was also able to maintain the same general tone of its predecessors (III and IV have been nixed from continuity, so essentially this is now being considered the third in the series), and obviously the effects were more incredible. Everybody will dig it. You can't help but get pulled in and wrapped up in the action, especially when Superman is lifting some enormous object while still healing from wounds and you're left sitting there blown away by his incredible feat. There's a major surprise in it that I absolutely refuse to spoil, all I know is that I wanna see what comes next for the Man of Steel, hopefully another villain thrown in the mix, Metallo or Brainiac, but always keep Lex Luthor in as a major player. Go see it.

This is an incredible movie. Routh and Spacey are the perfect comic book duo. SUPERMAN RETURNS is an amazing way to relaunch the franchise. My thanks to Bryan Singer. The special effects made me feel that Superman was truly real, and that he is waiting to save the day. It is nice to once again realize a world with a Superman. Superman Returns was a awesome follow up to last years Batman Begins. Brandon Routh and Kevin Spacey reminded me of the chemistry that Christopher Reeves and Gene Hackman shared back in 1978. This is the best cast superhero movie that has ever been filmed. I hope that Bryan Singer can recapture the magic in the Superman sequel that I am sure is going to follow.

Review Title: The Man of Steel has returned
not much characterization, kinda ridiculous plot, but all in all a FUN MOVIE
Review: Well, I never really did like Superman (Batman was my favorite). I never even saw any of the first four Superman movies. He's too ... perfect. But this movie did exceed my expectations. It really was a load of fun. The CGI was very nicely done. That airplane sequence you guys probably saw in the trailer was spectacular. The scale in which the special effects were done was phenomenal and almost scary in a way. The cinematography was terrific (loved the buildings at night), so basically the movie was a visual feast. The characterization was . . . decent. While I did like Routh's acting, there wasn't really much chemistry between the characters. I thought the kid was cool though, and I did think Luthor was awesome. The evil plot by Luthor was a bit far-fetched. It seemed really unrealistic, but hey, it's a movie. However, this is supposed to be a fun movie, and it really is. There are some references to gods and dieties, and Superman himself is almost portrayed as a god. I liked this a lot. A great movie. 8/10

Superman Returns was amazing, the cast did a great job. The plot was new and original, and i like the homage to the old Christopher Reeve movies. Brandon Routh did a fantastic job as well as Kevin Spacey, who played a very funny Lex Luthor. I enjoyed that the characters remained consistent from the other superman movies. My only problem with this movie is that superman didn't fight enough people. I would have liked for him to punch out more people like he does in the comics and TV shows, but that was OK the movie was still outstanding. The acting was great, the dialog was catchy and remember-able. I recommend it to all and think that you will appreciate the epic tale of one of the best super heroes.

Wow, I just saw the new movie today and it is absolutely AWESOME. Superman Returns is everything you like about Superman. A little romance, comedy, but lots of action. This version of the man of steel however, is a little bit more serious. Most of the comedy actually comes from Lex Luthor's goons. At first in the movie there isn't much action. Instead, we see all the heroics we love from the man of steel a little later on in the movie, but from then on, it's all superheroics, with the exception of a little romance with Lois Lane in between. All people, young and old should see this version of the man of steel. You won't be disappointed, and this movie will leave you on your seats the whole movie.

Review Title: Superman Returns not bad but not great - some SPOILERS
Review: Great: In the all-time pantheon of awesome superhero action scenes, there is the three-way lightsabre fight from Episode I, the shootout in the Lobby from the Matrix, and the airplane rescue from Superman Returns. Utterly amazing. A quick nod to Action Comics #1 in a photo was cool.Good: Brandon Routh and Kevin Spacey give excellent performances. I'm biased to Hackman and Reeves, but no complaints are justified here. Singer gets Superman's power level about right (maybe for the first time) and shows it in a convincing manner. The other action scenes are nicely done and they have the same feel as the original film. The special effects are really top notch.Bad: The story itself is not very compelling and the movie feels extremely long. Lex Luthor gets unlimited access to Kryptonian technology and nothing more interesting than using one of the crystals occurs? The effects of Kryptonite seem a lot less overpowering than I would've expected.A couple of nods to the original film would've been plenty. This movie takes wholesale from Superman: the Movie. Entire dialogues, quips, and countless subtleties makes it feel like Singer was torn between remaking the original and making his own film.

Review Title: Overall, a solid movie with solid performances
Review: Believe it or not, my only complaint would be the performance by Kate Bosworth, the actress who played Lois Lane. She was annoying, whining and superficial. I could not believe her character, who gave the impression of a twenty-something girl trying to be a grown woman.However, Brandon Routh's portrayal of Superman was nothing less than miraculous. When I first heard that this movie was going to be premiered, I felt it was an insult to Christopher Reeves, whom I have a great respect for as an actor.However, I breathed a sigh of relief by the first 10 minutes of the movie, when Routh appeared as Clark Kent and was as different from Superman as was when played by Reeves.Kevin Spacey and Parker Posey were impeccable. Great supporting cast.Worth it to see it on the big screen, people. Don't forget to take your hankie with you.

Review Title: An homage to Supernan: The Movie

Review: The part of Lex Luther would have been better if Kevin Spacey would have let his American Beauty side out. He was way too tame for the part of a psychotic killer. I know he can act, so what happened. Superman was so pretty it was almost surreal. He looked like one of those drawings in a video game. All in all the movie was enjoyable and transported me for about 45 minutes to another place and time. It was difficult not to think of Christopher Reeves, Gene Hackman, etc. Parker Posey was milk toast when comparing her to the original. Perhaps that is the trick to enjoying the film. Forget all you've seen of Superman before walking into the theater. Then sit down and enjoy the ride. The CGI was fantabulous. Go to watch the special effects, its worth the $6 or $9 depending upon where you are.

Review Title: Super in a lot of ways, not all of them good.
Review: Wow, I was one of the first to see Superman Returns at a special ten o'clock show...the crowd was rowdy and ready, and so was I. It was rather confusing to follow at the beginning, I wasn't sure of the time frame, however, it all started playing out. Superman had been gone five years, I am thinking it continues off from part two, however, I can't be totally sure of that. There are many changes when Superman returns, including Louis with a kid and new guy, however, he gets his old job back at the Daily Planet as Clark...he soon must release Superman back into the world, however, as he must make a daring and very cool plane rescue. What to say about the movie? The guy doing Superman is okay just as Reeves was, once again they could have gotten someone better, but then again they also could have gotten someone worse (Cage would have been worse). The movie is super familiar too, and it isn't really all that exciting after the plane rescue which I thought was the highlight of the film. Lex Luther's plan in this one is eerily similar to his plot from the first movie only on a more grand scheme. Same sort of Kryptonite scene, same female sidekick for Lex, the music sounds exactly the same there is just a bit to much that seems recycled from the first Superman movie for me here. I know some will call it a tribute, but I say it is just some lazy writing. The ending is also super long, to long, I just wanted it to end at one point as you knew basically what was going to happen...also most of the action consisted of Superman catching stuff or the ending action scene of throwing something. Let me just say Superman's strength was a bit inconsistent as he labored with smaller objects in earlier scenes. Holes and bad writing in the storyline were aplenty and there were many cutable scenes. Still the effects were great, Spacey as Lex Luthor was great and it had some very good moments...that plane scene was very memorable...So if you are a Superman fan go see it you will probably enjoy it a lot more than me, I thought it was just okay, nothing super though.

Review Title: How many reviews here are Studio Plants from Warners?
Not good, but at least there's the Spiderman 3 trailer!
Review: This movie was terrible! One of the worst films I had ever seen in the theater. To think they could only come up with this movie. Why does the plot go nowhere? We leave the theater in the exact same state we came in.The dialog was horrible…when they talked. The action was boring, and the continuity errors were atrocious.This lacks all the magic that made the first two Superman films. Where is the chemistry? The fun…? The story…? Kevin Spacey was the only good thing in this film, but not even he can save this stinker. Brandon Routh makes a decent Superman, though, his writing was a huge problem. If the film had better dialog and a better understanding of the Superman character then maybe he could have gone from okay to GREAT.I wanted to like this movie and hoped Singer could pull it off, but he has failed.He has successfully become the first director to ruin two franchises in two months.Superman Returns and X-men 3 (by not doing it) It is a shame that they will make sequels to this franchise. But at least we might get the humorous title "Superman Not So Superdad"

I've just recently seen the opening show of " Superman Returns " and it was everything I expected it to be; the hero vs. the villain. The action sequences were mind-blowing and the CGI was fantastic. The story was strongly built around its characters. Clark Kent/Superman returns to find the love of his life Louis Lane a mother and engaged to a fellow reporter. Lex Luther is still the same " Rule the World " villain who ends up finding a world similar to Krypton in Antartica. Over all, Superman's heroic rescues, Jesus-figure and shocking, but not obvious twists make this movie a must see for everybody. Don't listen to the critics, the Man of Steel is strong, confident and the savior for all these horrible remakes and phony movies of the 21st century.

I guess it's time to confess. I have not seen the previous superman movies. I have never read a comic book in my life. However, I have seen several of the more modern attempts at movies based on comic books, ranging from good (X-men 2, X-Men 3, Sin City) and some great ones (Sin City, Spiderman 2). All were cheesy, but in a stylish way that I could enjoy.I suspected the movie was in trouble when the asteroid that impacts earth is preceded by a loud rumble that shakes the house and trails off into the distance as it passes. Haven't the sound engineers ever heard of a sonic boom that accompanies objects traveling at supersonic speeds? Then there's the real opening action sequence that involves a 777 (the only passenger 777 in the world with one aisle) that falls to earth in the middle of a baseball stadium (out of respect for the international audience, this is the closest reference we get in the entire movie to that third thing that Superman supposedly stands for) and then everybody stand up and cheers, instead of fleeing to the exits. I think that sequence was the most ludicrous action sequence I've ever seen, and I've seen quite a few clunkers.I think Spacey is good as Lex, and enjoyed parts of it, but the end was long, drawn out, and choppy. The love-triangle thing between Superman, Lois Lane, and, oh that's another thing: Thy the hell does Lois Lane not seem to know that Superman is Clark Kent? Superman doesn't wear a mask, departs and arrives at the same time in her life, and yet she doesn't make the connection. Dumb chick. Oh, where was I? Yeah, it's serviceable to the story. Oh and who brings their kid along to do cold call reporting? I didn't read Ebert's roast until after I saw the movie, and he pointed out that no one would want to live on the island for the next million years. I would also point out that an island coming out of the ground as fast as that one was would have caused a tidal wave that would have made Dec 24, 2004 look like ripples in a bathtub. Appaently the special effects guys have never heard of Archimedes.One more thing: Superman is just not really that exiting a superhero to me: It's all or nothing with this guy: either he's all-powerful and can do anything. Or he's around Kryptonite and is more or less a regular Joe (or is he, since apparently Superman + Kryptonite can apparently take the longest fall anyone's ever taken, and survive). The fact that this substance is as debilitating to him as it is, doesn't make a heck of a lot of sense.I've got more. Piano-throwing do-nothing kid. Point where one minute he's dead, and the next minute he's in critical condition. Whatever. Despised the movie. Save your money.

Review Title: It's a Bird, It's a Plane..............No, It's Just a Bunch of Hot Air.
Review: Superman (Brandon Routh) returns after a five-year disappearance. It appears our hero was off trying to find out if there really were any remnants or survivors from his home planet. While away Lois Lane (a dark-haired Kate Bosworth) has had a son (Tristan Lake Leabu) with a new love (James Marsden). Meanwhile Routh's absence has meant that Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) has gotten out of prison and sustained the resources and backing (girlfriend Parker Posey and an entourage of former prison thugs) to become a world threat once again. Spacey has an elaborate scheme to take crystals from Superman's Fortress of Solitude to create new lands on Earth while simultaneously putting old continents under water. Thus Spacey would rule via real estate and alien technology. And of course that darn kryptonite keeps on popping up thanks to Spacey's past knowledge and advanced planning. "Superman Returns" is a huge bore to put it mildly. The film runs way too long (over 150 minutes), the plot is dumb, the characters seem lost in the venture and the direction (by the over-rated Bryan Singer who is still looking for a project to match "The Usual Suspects") is totally uninspired and sophomoric. Routh is a total wash as Superman, Bosworth seems out-of-place (to be fair though Margot Kidder was the weakest link in the four earlier films) and the supporters (namely Frank Langella and Eva Marie Saint) make absolutely no impression. Spacey and Posey do everything in their power to salvage the mess, but just cannot overcome the lack of a suitable screenplay and non-existent tone. Really I wanted a film on Lex Luthor rather than Superman because the villains are much more intriguing than the good guys. After 19 years in cinematic dormancy, "Superman Returns" ends up doing nothing to get me any more excited about the cinematic concept than I was after "Superman IV: The Quest for Peace". 2.5 out of 5 stars.

Review Title: If you don't get chills, you're not a Superman fan
Review: I have always been a Superman fan, for as long as I can remember. I grew up watching the old black and whites on CBS. I was always amazed at this guy that would burst through brick walls, get shot and not die and flying from here to there in a blink of an eye. Yeah, I was hooked.I saw the original movies when they came out, albeit I was just a young man. I thought Christopher Reeve was amazing. He was Superman in ever way. He sold the part like no other before him. I loved General Zod (Terrence Stamp) and the whole storyline. As I said… I'm a fan. With the other Superman movies, the scale of excellence seemed to slide a little and sure enough, by parts 3 and 4… well… the franchise seemed rather doomed.After the success of Spiderman on the big screen, followed by Spiderman 2, I knew it was only a matter of time before Kal-El would return to the big screen. I couldn't wait. Then came the rumors…. ah yes… Nick Cage as the favorite son of Krypton? Could it be? Please tell me this is a joke. Anyone, please, stop this from happening. Thankfully, it never took place. After several scripts, several directors and a several names mentioned for the part, Bryan Singer came on board.When this happened, not only did I know the story would be in good hands, I knew it'd be done like never before. Bryan worked his magic with Xmen and Xmen 2 and those were incredible as far as comic stories go. I knew the franchise was in good hands. Who will they get to play the part though? Who could possibly make me believe he was Superman as Chris Reeve did? Brandon Routh, a small town boy from the mid west enters the picture. He'd read for McG (earlier director) and Singer liked him so he was kept on. Brandon tried out for Smallville's lead role but lost that to Tom Welling. I myself am a huge Smallville fan, yes, I am a geek, I admit it. Brandon encompasses everything that is right and true about Clark Kent. He IS Clark Kent for crying out loud. He grew up in his own Smallville of sorts, he has the same morals/values and holy snike, does he ever look like a young Reeve. Brandon sells the role alright. I forgot I was watching yet another actor play Superman. Instead, Routh had me believing that he IS Superman.Watching the movie last night, I was thrilled to see what i saw. I said I wouldn't give anything away, so I won't, but when you see this, if you don't have chills at several parts in the movie… then my friend, you're just not a Superman fan.

Review Title: Not as Good as Batman Begins, but Still, A Great Film
Review: Just like what happened with Batman, making another Superman movie didn't sound like a good idea. In fact, I thought resurrecting Superman was even a worse idea because:A) IMO Quest for Peace was worse than Batman and Robin (at least B&R was hilarious) B) WB couldn't get this sequel off the ground for almost 15 years. C) Unlike Christian Bale, the comic book fans weren't very happy about the casting of Brandon Routh as Superman.And while SR isn't as good as Batman Begins (I never expected to be), it's good enough to restart the franchise.The film takes place 5 years after the incidents of Superman II. Superman comes back to earth. Lois (Kate Bosworth) now has a kid (Tristan Leabu) and is engaged to fellow journalist Richard (James Marsden). Lex Luther (Kevin Spacey) is out of prison and as usual, he's got a new plan to destroy Superman and take over the world.Obviously, Superman is nowhere as dark or edgy as Batman, Spiderman, or the X-Men, but that doesn't mean he's living in fairy tale world either. And I think that was the best thing about the script. The Man of Steel got a whole lot to deal with in this film. He's got no home; Krypton has become a "graveyard". He's got no love; Lois, the love of his life, is with another man and is mad at him (for leaving without saying goodbye). Luther is still determined to finish him off, and after all, Superman is still an "alien" trying to fit in this world. In addition, the script rightfully ignored the horrendous last 2 sequels, and tied nicely with Superman II.But the script also had its fair share of flaws. Luther's plan is somehow silly; I didn't like the direction the story took in the last 30 minutes or so, and I think the kid subplot was pointless.The film had some scenes among the best I've seen this year. Basically, every action sequence gave me huge goose bumps. Director Bryan Singer sure knows how to direct an action scene. The action was well executed, well edited, and had great FX. The love scenes between Supes and Lois were also handled very well. And of course, having John Williams' amazing score playing in the background doesn't hurt either.I was surprised by Routh. I didn't expect much, but he was very good as Superman, emotionally and physically. Bosworth was decent, and Spacey was a blast. He was very funny without losing the character's edge. It must be something about working with Singer because I don't recall Spacey having this much fun since The Usual Suspects. . So, I'd definitely recommend Superman Returns. It isn't flawless, but it's probably the best superhero film we're going to see this year.

Great return to the "good" Superman story line (forget about III & IV!). I liked how it picked up right from the end of II. Brandon Routh was a great choice to play Clark/Superman. He believably exuded the dopiness of Clark and the sheen 'superness' of Superman. Kate Bosworth just didn't do it for me as Lois though. I guess I am just partial to Margot Kidder. GREAT JOB to Bryan Singer, even if it did mean giving up X3 to do this. I wish he somehow could have done both. Brett Ratner just didn't have the right vision in my opinion. BTW, if you can, see Superman Returns on an IMAX screen. IT ROCKS!! Check it out. You won't be disappointed (Don't drink too much. It runs 2hrs 40 min.)!

Review Title: Superman Returns and it's good to have him back
Review: I just got back from a Wednesday afternoon showing, and have to say I'm relieved. Having seen (and loved) the first two Superman movies, and having suffered through the third and fourth, this should definitely be grouped with the first two. While it's not equal to Donner's classic, it's close in quality to Superman II.The key to this film's success is the characters. The effects are great, the story is acceptable, but the emotion between Superman, Louis, Lex Luthor, and all is what makes the movie. Singer and Routh do a great job of depicting a being who is pretty much invulnerable physically, who could take whatever he wanted if he chose to, but instead suffers his broken heart with quiet dignity.Action sequences are top notch, and epic all the way. The humor is there (I would have liked a bit more), the dialogue is there (it always is in a Brian Singer production - see "House" on Fox). The pace was a little off from my perspective - it seemed just a little slow.I recommend Superman Returns. It's not a classic, but it is definitely worthy. I can't wait until the next one. Brainiac? Metallo? Maybe Gilbert Godfried as Mr. Mxyzptlk? After this, I'm looking forward to it.

Review Title: This does justice to the original
Review: looking forward to this movie, grabbing some youth since I grew up on the original movies. Was scared they would botch it up, but wow great movie. The same music and credit effects took me back to 1978 the story was good and the casting wonderful. A must see comic book based movie. The acting was great and it kept us on our seat edges. If they make more i hope they don't fall into the trap they seem to, the one where they change directors. This is the same director who did the first X-Men movies. It has humanity and heart and a good mix of adventure. Its nice also not to have a "reimaging" of the idea too. This movie takes place 5 years after the last (unlike the real 15 or so) so its not a recreation of the franchise. The original I and II ( we will just skip 3&4) were great fun and this movie captures that same fun.

Where to start...This movie was so amazing on so many levels. The movie cannot be compartmentalized into JUST an action flick. This movie truly had it all. Drama, action, life....dealing with real life issues. Wow! I do not want to ruin it for anybody, but I will just say that the cast was on the money. There were no miscast parts. Brandon Routh truly can claim the Superman role from here on out. If Christopher Reeves were alive to witness this movie, he would have been proud.From beginning to end, I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. Watching the screen with my 7 and 5 year old boys, made me feel as if I were their age watching the original Superman for the very first time. Amazing! I have read some reviews, with some being too literal about character development and the age of the actors, just enjoy the movie for what it is...a movie! And a very good one at that!

I don't think I can express what I feel after seeing this movie. In lamest terms, this movie is down right is amazing. For all of us Superman fans that have been waiting all these years for a new movie, the wait is over. And you won't be disappointed. They keep the original score from the other movies and don't add any of the crappy teeny-bopper music that is played in "Smallville". The special effects are spectacular. Brandon Routh plays a marvelous Superman and Clark Kent that Christopher Reeve would have been proud of. Kevin Spacey as Lex Luther was all most to perfect as he played the most evil Luther yet still mixing some of the sarcasm that Gene Hackman had added to the role. I am not giving the storyline away so you are just going to have to see the movie for yourself. Whether you get anything out of this review or not, I don't care. I just wanted to express my feelings for such an amazing flick like this. Thank you Hollywood for not messing this one up! 10/10

Review Title: Good but but not what it could have been
Heartfelt, humorous, nice to look at... but runs a little long
Review: The following is absolutely spoiler free, but I am trying to give an idea of what to expect in terms of pacing, tone, and crowd-friendliness. If you go into it having read this and somewhat knowing what to expect, I think you'll end up liking it more.PROS: It's really amazing seeing Superman use his powers with modern special FX technology. It's got lots and lots of heart and humor. The cast is pretty solid. Great character piece for Superman. CONS: Unfortunately, there's not a hell of a lot more in the movie than what you see in the trailer. I mean, yes there is more, but it's not like there's some surprise, eye popping 30 minute finale with Supes fighting a squadron of super-enhanced bad guys, like you'd see in those fantastic Justice League cartoons- ripping apart half of Metropolis, knocking each other through buildings or punching so hard that the shock-waves alone cause mass destruction. Also, plot is for the most part secondary to character, and there is at least one major story point I doubt I'd have ever written into a Superman story... ever (not to say that said story point didn't work)! Lastly, the movie is nearly 2 1/2 hours long, and about 3/4 of the way into it you start to feel it, especially as it draws to something more anticlimactically character based than something viscerally crowd pleasing.OVERALL: I wanted to go into Superman Returns expecting a lot, and getting more than I'd hoped- and that didn't really happen- although I did like it a great deal. Outside of the comics and other Superman movies, this is a very well executed piece of work. Those with little patience will probably say the movie is boring. However, SR is so damn likable, humorous, and heartfelt, that it's almost impossible to say you didn't enjoy it. Certain friends would argue "What? Was it too smart for ya?", and for many I'm thinking it might be. In the grand scheme it's bold, and perhaps even innovative, to stick to such a personal level of storytelling for a tent-pole summer blockbuster superhero movie, while at the same time I wish they'd pulled a little more of a "Spider-Man" and met us closer to the half way mark of being a spectacle. Supes should do great business, but I don't think many will go see it more than once (unless it somehow locks into that 14 year-old teen girl crowd that Titanic nailed). I don't see it quite doing Spidey numbers, but it should reach 200 million with little effort... though Pirates Of The Caribbean opening the following weekend should definitely have an impact.

Review Title: Superman is little more than a frozen corpse in Bryan Singer's worst movie yet

Review: This movie is the reason why Bryan Singer is the new superhero director. The music from the original movies, an outstanding script & a powerhouse cast all made this movie 1 of the best superhero movies ever. GO SEE THIS MOVIE NOW!!!! Brandon Routh is incredible & the resemblance to Christopher Reeves is scary. If you are a fan of the Chris Reeves "Superman" movies you will not be disappointed. Special effects were flawless. Kevin Spacey played the role of Lex Luthor perfectly. He played the part as a complete psychopath, which just made it more fun. Kate Bosworth as "Lois Lane" was so much better than Margot Kidder. Finally we get a sexy Lois. Seeing James Marsden in a Bryan Singer movie without superpowers was a little weird, I kept waiting for the rose crystal shades to come out. This movie is definitely worth the $8, GO SEE IT NOW!!!

There are moments in this movie, where i was completely spellbound by the beauty of the pictures. Bryan Singer made two X-Men movies before this, learning how to do the Superman film, greatly inspired by the 1978 Donner film. In the end, he has a movie that has evolved to be something more, giant, expansive, compelling. For a lot of reasons I have always loved the character. He hits a bit of a darker note with this film, his virtue is a bit shadier, but in the end, he is still the same. Newcomer Brandon Routh soars with his performance, nuanced at times and he takes the part seriously, effortlessly, perhaps channeling the late Christopher Reeves, Routh is every bit as iconic. The reviews may have been mixed, but I honestly don't know any other way a Superman film could have been made. Except worse. The only real challenge this team had to do was be better than the films III and IV. I believe his flight, his strength. I believed it all.Spacey's Luthor is every bit as funny as Hackman's, but he is somehow more sinister. His crew of henchman are vicious, and I suppose Ned Beatty is thankfully dead somewhere, shivved in a prison shower for his incompetence. Parker Posey, brings an interesting turn to the sidekick role as does Sam Huntington as Jimmy Olsen.My biggest reservation was the Lois Lane character, but I thought this version was a bit harder, not as flighty as the Margot Kidder reporter. James Marsden also brings a warmth and heroic role as Richard White, her live in boyfriend. There are a lot of themes in this movie, some which the Religious Right may have problems with. Alas, a good film it is.

Review Title: I had to stop myself from cheering
Review: I'm not a superhero fan or a comic book fan, but from the moment that wonderful music started to play, this turned into the perfect summer movie experience. Spacey has great fun as Luther, but is almost upstaged by Posey as his tart-with-a-heart companion. Brandon Routh had me a little worried from the previews, but excels as a man struggling to accept that things have moved on in his absence. The effects were spectacular - the shuttle/jet sequence is simply astonishing. There are those who think that Bryan Singer is a genius, and then there are those who are wrong. Sit back and enjoy...

Review Title: Superman Returns stays true to the old
Review: As a huge fan of the old superman movies, I was excited about Superman Returns. Without saying to much about the plot, I would have to say that Superman Returns was a huge achievement for all involved in the work. Kevin Spacey did such a good job as Lex Luthor, that I could hardly tell it wasn't Gene Hackman. Newcomer Branon Routh did a fairly good job as superman as well( He wasn't as good as Christopher Reeves, but he still did a good job). While there was some cheesy comic laughs the movie was all in all a good movie, and a good sequel. The action was amazing, and Superman looked as if he were actually flying. All in all I would give the movie a 8.5, and its definitely worth a see.

Review Title: We need superman... Yes we do...
Review: This movie just came in the right time for me.I was thinking for years, why would they not producing a rerun for superman with these new technology. But now I understand better why it had to be wait so far.It is quite as classic as it could be possibly done.Good picture, recommend to everyone...Just watch it with the white curtain before you criticize. If possible watch it with a full audience, and listen the silence in the right moments.One mother was getting his children out, and it was quite interestingly good to see the children crying and hence that the legend is timeless.

Review Title: An excellent Movie - like an evening with an old friend
Review: I saw the Chris Reeves/Richard Donner "Superman" on opening night back in 1978. That was a big deal, and it was a wonderful experience giving all of us a chance to see a flesh and blood Son of Krypton. There were things that I loved and there were things that I disliked then, and have grown to detest in the subsequent years. Gene Hackman wasn't the real Lex Luthor. Margot Kidder wasn't the real Lois Lane. Still, we got to see a man fly, and the portions of the film portraying Krypton were very good, and those portraying Smallville were brilliant (particularly Glen Ford).Superman Returns borrowed from all the right parts of the original, and changed everything that I disliked. The special effects were special. As I watched it I thought about Peter Jackson's "King Kong," a film that cost about the same. Kong was a film that I didn't like, partially because I couldn't find a character I believed or cared about. Superman Returns had real people, and didn't take any short cuts on either the character aspect, nor the VFX.It was a move that made the long wait worth it, and it completely erased parts III and IV from the original series. Go see it.

will admit that my tastes in movies are weird.....maybe I expect too much or whatever, but in a big popcorn summer movie, it is all about the action and NOT about the bs SUPERMAN GLARE or the contrived bull that this movie leans on heavily. And, when you see it, WHAT THE HELL IS THE DEAL WITH HIS EYES? The effects were fairly cool. They stumble a bit in the first quarter of the movie, but after that, ya kind of really believe he is strong as an ox and that he can fly. He just doesn't do enough effin' flying! The "twists" don't twist and Kevin Spacey is a subtle as a gunshot blast to the brain pan! The Villain is weak! And, who decided Superman supposed to be a chick flick?

Review Title: A Vote for Truth, Justice and the American Way
Review: This was a very "human" movie. The characters were believable and the acting was not overly "dramatic". Kevin Spacey was an excellent villain. He did not overplay his role...he was just enough of an egomaniac, but one who also showed a tad of fear. His fate at the end was poetic justice. Superman's comment at the end that he will always be there appeals to all of us...sure a tad schmaltzy...but still part of our belief that good will be there when when need it. This is also a movie worth a second look. I saw it with the air conditioning pouring down on me, and I still enjoyed it. There were several children at the movie and I overheard parents explaining certain parts, but it was not overly frightening. I highly recommend Superman Returns...it represents truth, justice and the American Way!

I really enjoyed this movie. I honestly walked into the theater expecting to be disappointed but that wasn't the case at all. This movie really captured the whole essence of Superman and it really felt like I was a kid again watching the first Superman movie for the first time. The cinematography was incredible. It looked so real, not to the point where you can tell it's all CG. I really loved the actor who played Superman. It gave me the chills because he does look like Christopher Reeve. The only thing I would've liked to have seen more of is a deeper interaction between Superman and Lois Lane. That area was a little lacking but still, the chemistry between Kate Bosworth and Brandon Gouth is good. Overall, I'm very happy with this film. I'm hoping that there will be another Superman movie sometime in the future.

Review Title: Maybe someone will make a GREAT Superman film one day, but this isn't it.
Review: I'll make this quick because I hate long worded reviews: Was this movie great? No. Good? I suppose. Would I see it again? Maybe if it was on cable one day and I had nothing better to watch. Perhaps I went in with high expectations because Singer's X-men films were action packed, funny and downright enjoyable.First off let me say that this film relied too heavily on the Donner Superman films. I think its great when films will reference previous incarnations, or even things from the comics (Wolverine's yellow spandex in the first X-Men for example) but with this film enough is enough! Rehashing lines from Superman 1 just to get a laugh out of the audience was the worst! Give the audience more credit and write something original! Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor? Cool, right? No. Why can't anyone show Luthor as he is in the comic, an evil and powerful businessman. Here, as in the Donner films, he is a sad parody of himself. Gene Hackman wasn't a great Luthor and neither is Spacey. Parker Posey-What a waste of her talent as an actress. Brandon Routh- Great job as Superman, stepping out of any shadow cast by Chris Reeve but when he portrayed Clark Kent I wondered if we were watching Brandon Routh as Clark Kent or Brandon Routh doing his best imitation of Chris Reeve as Clark Kent.With that said, there is a "surprise" of sorts that is so unbelievably hokey and stupid that as I sat in the theater I actually said out loud "Give me a break." Don't hold your breath, you'll be disappointed. Special effects were pretty cool and overall I'd say see the movie, but don't expect anything fantastic.

Wow! Superman Returns brought excitement and fun to a new level on the big screen. The film brought superior entertainment, even from the opening credits, with the John Williams score and fantastic imagery of Superman's legendary flight from Krypton to Earth.Superman Returns includes the best acting performance of not one, but ALL Superman characters involved. Brandon Routh brought a touch of realism and a relate-ability to Superman and Clark. Kate Bosworth was charming and emotionally touching in her role as Lois. Kevin Spacey was down-right brilliant in his role as Lex Luthor – making it appear that Lex could be a real person! (not one that I would want living in my city).The spectacular quality of film and all the graphics involved made it easy on the eyes, which is not true for many "Superhero" movies.After 20 years without Superman on the big screen, Bryan Singer pulled off a flawless hit that is sure to be a legendary film mentioned in the ranks of "Star Wars" and "The Lord of the Rings".I can't wait to see it again!

Review Title: Thoroughly Satisfying and Engaging - Action, Drama, Romance, and more Action!!
Review: As it pertains to the past films (not the comics), let me just say first that I really enjoyed this new addition to the pantheon. I was really worried about how they'd mess with the characters and the ambiance of the world they inhabited at the time with this update. However, it's obvious that Brian Singer, having learned his lesson from the first two X-Men movies, knew that he could tweak and update but must keep true to the characters that readers and audiences have come to know and love so well over the years . Too bad Ang Lee didn't learn this in time (see The Hulk, rather don't see it) nor did the geniuses who wrote and directed Spawn. Let's not even start on the atrocities that occurred between Batman and Batman Begins.Anyway, they did more than pay homage to Christopher Reeves' stint in the suit. This was evident in the way Brandon Routh (more on him later) portrayal, the classic beginning credits with the blue laser block letters, the manicured hair with the little curly "S" of the forelock, and even Superman's frowning on Lois' smoking. In addition to this, they used a couple of themes written by John Williams for the original movies which really locked in the sense of nostalgia and renewal.It has been a while since I got the chills, goose bumps, or a lump in my throat at the start of a film. The last time it happened was when The Phantom Menace came out and I sat there, enthralled and enraptured at seeing, first, the green Lucasfilm logo, then the Fox drum roll fanfare, and finally, the blue text scrolling upward, disappearing into an apex. Of course, after the dreck that followed, George never gave me the goose bumps again.However, this time, as I sat there and heard the first few strains of John Williams' Superman Theme (the driving staccato of the strings and then the horns beaming triumphantly in unison), I got those chills and goose bumps! I was so excited that I started clapping my hands like a little girl who was getting exactly what she wanted under the Christmas tree. I felt silly doing it but I didn't care. Happy happy, joy joy.Now, the rest of the movie deals with Superman's return after going off to "find himself" for 5 years and the aftermath of his absence. I'll let you read the summaries elsewhere but he goes on to do the super stuff we expect from him. Though, I have to say, even though I knew he would come through and pull off some incredible feats, my palms were sweaty during the scenes without my even being aware. The action sequences were well done and, with the technology and graphics of today, Supes was given a much needed update on the exhibition and extent of his power and abilities. Another nice touch is Superman's struggle with the idea of being the only one left of his kind and the loneliness that ensues. There was a nice bridge made from Jor-El, to him, and on. Very touching.Brandon Routh, whom I'd never heard of until this movie, does a fine job of oscillating between geeky Clark (love geeky Clark!) and the Man of Steel. Somehow, he has managed to channel Christopher Reeves' tone and mannerisms to a tee. As I was watching, I didn't think of it as mimicking, rather I just saw it as a continuation of the character from before, which was terrific. Ir was new but comforable! I think he did great justice to the character. Some say his performance is a bit wooden, but the character is not human and doesn't deal with the same things in the same way humans do so I never expected him to break down and lose it or express happiness in a typical fashion. Some of his best acting occurs in the silence as he tries to grapple with his emotions and the expectation to always act accordingly. You be the judge.Kate Bosworth seemed a little miscast, though her performance was passable. Donning brown hair (badly permed, mind you), she did her best to bring brassiness and smarts to her usually cutesy frame. All in all, she was all "just okay" but they certainly could have cast someone who didn't have to try so hard at being the savvy, world-weary type. I'm not sure about the chemistry between her and Routh but I'll make sure to be more aware of it the next time around. On a side note, now that she's a mom, couldn't Lois have a nice, womanly body instead of that of a 90 lbs. 14 year old? Kevin Spacey phones in his role as Lex Luthor, the villain. I still believe he's one of the great actors of our time but he seemed to just coast through this role, though he a moment or two. Maybe it was just that easy for him. Parker Posey as his girl Friday, was engaging and interesting, and she continues to be an under rated actress Overall, this is a movie I will see over and over again. I thought it dealt very well with social and personal issues...such things even a super hero has to struggle with. Kudos to Brian Singer and the cast! Brandon Routh...you've surmounted all expectation and comparison. This is your role now and you deserve it!

I remember going to see "Superman: The Move" 28 years ago on its opening weekend. For weeks the advertising had said, "you will believe a man can fly". He did. And it did.I've always been a fan of Superman - I'm 48 and started with the comics 43 years ago after seeing reruns of the George Reeve TV series - and for nearly 3 decades I've waited for someone to make a movie that lived up to that first Richard Donner film. Bryan Singer has not only stepped up to the challenge, he has both embraced it and polished it to make the Man of Steel more luminous than ever. No doubt you have read that Singer wanted to stay faithful to the Donner film by making a sequel rather than a remake. Five stars right there. Singer even goes so far as to incorporate many elements of the first film into his own without appearing to force them in for familiarity's sake. All the visual and verbal references - including Marlon Brando's soliloquy, dialog between Superman and Lois, and the styling of the scenery - fit naturally. (There is even a sly visual reminder of the fate of the poor detective who trailed Otis in the subway tunnel.) That's 2 more stars. Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor! Who else? Two more stars. And Brandon Routh is somehow channeling Christopher Reeve while still managing to make the role his own with a quiet, confident performance that says this guy has enough talent not to get typecast. Final two stars.So how did I go from eleven stars to ten stars? Not her fault, but Kate Bosworth just doesn't convince me she is Lois Lane. Her performance is quite good, but her age, youth and overall style just don't fit the image of Lois. There is the one star deduction. Not a biggie and it's the worst that can be said about this otherwise remarkable film.The original film presented Superman as a gift to humanity from a dying planet. This film opens with Superman having been absent from Earth for five years and the uncertain claim that Superman is no longer needed. When you see this film, you will not only believe a man can fly, but you will no doubt leave the theater wishing there really was a Man of Steel. The world could really use a Superman!

Review Title: Superman fans, stick with the original.
Review: To Bryan Singer and the writers of Superman Returns, next time be original. This is nothing more than a knockoff of the original Superman movie from the opening title sequence to Superman's flying past the camera at the end. At least 25% of Superman's lines are verbatim from the original movie. There was no originality to Brandon Routh's Clark Kent or Superman; he was just a cheap imitation of Christopher Reeves. In addition, this story was boring, at times incoherent and frequently left a lot to be desired. Kevin Spacey is the only thing worth seeing this movie for. He played the mad villain superbly. If you are a fan off the original 2 movies, stick with them.

Review Title: I wish Kryptonite kept me away from the theater!
Review: This film was esthetically pleasing and well acted, but about an hour too long. The story was really drawn out for no apparent reason. I am going to have to go against critic opinion and give it three stars at best…just know that at heart this is a love story not an action film. Even though one must leave expectation behind and keep an open mind...I feel the film just failed to connect with the audience. Everyone walking out of the theater was mumbling the same sentiments. The film has substance but wasn't pieced together correctly to convey the story. By the way, as it's PG-13 rating suggests, this film is not for young children, not because of any violence, but because no young child could possibly sit through this 2 1/2 hour film and neither could some adults. When I left the theater the film didn't stay with me...Just my 10 buck opinion!

It was a rainy evening in south Detroit when a friend and I strolled into the local theater to see Superman Returns. My day had been alright: work, dinner, and a hopefully a good movie to close it all off. I paid my $7.50, grabbed a soda, and settled into a comfy chair amid a hundred more of its like inside a cool movie theater. I chatted and poked fun at the previews for the summer's upcoming films as a strange air of anticipation grew for the latest Man of Steel rendition. From the moment the opening credits rolled supported by the classic Superman score I knew this film was something special. From the first scene through to the last Superman Returns was exciting, gripping, humorous, and cinematically astute. From the ride away from the theater to my walk to the bedroom all I could think about was Superman and its wonderful blend of the classic coupled with new, innovative film styles and effects. This is a perfect film and will not disappoint old or new Superman fans. See this movie. See it twice. Then see it again.

Well everyone, guess what, Superman is back! And he's here to stay. I'm telling you, this film is absolutely amazing, and is exactly what the definition of summer blockbuster is. Director Bryan Singer, who made "X-Men 1 and 2", does the Superman franchise a great service by bringing the man of steel back into our movie-going lives. Props to you Bryan! "Superman Returns" is basically a continuation of the original Superman films. Superman aka Clark Kent goes away for five years trying to see if his planet of origin, Krypton, still exists. After he returns he finds everything turned upside down. His old nemesis Lex Luthor has concocted up another evil plan for power, and Clark's old flame Lois Lane has gone and married someone else, as well as writing a story called, "Why the World Doesn't Need Superman". It's up to him to save the world once more.Now it is time for me to go on and on about how super this movie is. Where to start? Newcomer Brandon Routh as Superman is great; he is like Christopher Reeve reborn. And Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor added an evil quality to the character while still being funny, while Gene Hackman from the originals was just funny and not evil. My favorite character though, was Sam Huntington as Jimmy Olsen who was absolutely hilarious in every scene he's in. His career will definitely skyrocket as will Brandon Rouths'. Another thing I loved are the opening credits, as the camera travels through space and witnesses the jaw dropping demise of Krypton. That brings me to the visual effects, to which I will say, "Wow". Need I say more? The music by John Ottman reinvents John Williams original score but at the same time staying true. It is beautiful.There was one thing that really bugged me though, there was a crackling noise coming from the screen the ENTIRE movie that annoyed me to no end. That happened with "Poseidon" too! We pay $8.00 and then are shown an amazing movie on a crappy screen. I will rejoice the day the theaters in Saginaw switch over to digital. Oh please be soon.Now it is time you get up and go to the theater to see this destined classic. And after the filmmakers spent 200 million dollars on this film, they're going to need lots of theatergoers.I give it a whopping 10 out of 10! "Superman Returns" is rated PG-13 for some intense action violence.Brian Ledtke, 16, lives in Thomas Township.

I am a big fan of all the comic movies (X-men, Spiderman, superman, etc.) and this movie didn't fail to please!!! The effects were jaw dropping, the movie had a good story behind it, and Brandon Routh had no problem filling the boots of Christopher Reeve! This was the first movie that I've watched since I was a kid that gave me tingles. Every time Clark Kent would strap on the cape, the tingles would be with me the whole time! Another great thing is that this movie can be for the girls too! Much like Spiderman, Superman has to foil his villain and get his swerve on with a lovely lady. Great flick! This movie was awesome and is definitely worth paying the full price!

By far, the best comic book movie I have ever seen. It is even better than Batman Begins (but not by much) and that is saying a lot! The sequel to Superman Returns can't come fast enough.Brandon Routh was just as good, if not better than Reeve(RIP). His Kal-el was good, Clark was great, but his Superman was just amazing! Spacey and the other characters were excellent also. The whole cast, and yes, even Parker Posey. For a 3 hr and 37 min movie, it sure did go by quicker than I would of thought.I must say that the success behind Superman Returns will be due to Bryan Singer. He made the movie what it is, GREAT! Singer and Co. took a good script, added a major twist, and the outcome was just amazing. I recommend everyone go see this as soon as you can!

Review Title: Great Movie, True to all Superman Fans
Review: This new Superman film was awesome. Brandon Routh makes a great superman. I don't there there is anyone out there today that could have played a better Superman. The whole film was perfect from beginning to end. It really staid true to the old superman film that we all love so much. For me Superman was Christopher Reeve, but now I am adding Brandon to the list. I am sure Christopher would be so proud that he did an amazing job as the Character that Christopher Reeve made worldly popular.Kevin Spacy was superb, as usual. Kate Bosworth was a really good Lois Lane. She was quiet and a little understated but I feel it added to her character.Brandon Routh was absolutely wonderful. I can not say enough good things about this film and his role in this film. Everything down to the way he flys is on key with the way I remember Superman.Many props to the Writer, Director, Cast and Crew of this film. I know it will be a huge box office hit. AWESOME job. I loved it!!!Superman is a must see!!!

WOW......WOW........WOW...Superman movies are back people..and this movie just raises their bar by a BIG MARGIN The movie is not only an action masterpiece, the Acting is just great for everybody.I must give Brandon Routh a big 10/10 for the acting...he really returned the memories of Christopher Reef in superman in an amazing way.One more thing...the sound effects and the Music are VERY emotional..not only the old Lovely Superman soundtrack but also different music that was just mixed in a very professional way with the old music.Don't miss this movie..if you are a superman fan, or even if you just want a GREAT action movies, a great emotional movie, it is great for everybody, and it is NOT a kids movie at all.

Incredibly good movie. The first trailer was awesome, but the second trailer kinda turned me off, but the movie was extremely well done(Director of X-men 2, directed this movie, so not surprised).Brandon Routh was an excellent Clark Kent/Superman, Kevin Spacey did a spectacular Lex Luthor and Lois lane, well, lois really isn't very hard to do, but i think Kate Bosworth did a good job.The plot i must admit seems very close to the other superman movies and cartoons, of course the clichéd catching things and people out of the air. But he does a couple of new things with his eyes, and there's a surprise in the movie that some of you may like.

Review Title: You know when James Marsden is the best actor, you are in trouble.
Review: I didn't like it. Maybe I grew up watching to much of the original- or the cartoons spoiled it for me on TV, but I didn't enjoy the film. In my mind, the perfect Lex Luther is calm, cool, and a dispassionate bad guy- the ultimate undefeatable super villain. In the movie he is a angry, childlike, whiny, bad-line spurting B villain. Now, one just can't blame Kevin Spacey (Ill always love American Beauty forever!) but he was the wrong choice. He wasn't.. Lex Luther. The other problem I had was Routh. Now, maybe he is young (this being the only movie I had ever seen him in) but Christopher Reeves would have wept! I mean, yes, he was beautiful (and my god, he beautiful) but he didn't have a superman quality. Actually, in my mind, he was more beautiful then Kate Brosworth (who didn't do a bad job herself). But a wonderful face and large, broad shoulders don't make the Superman-- the acting does. It takes talent to spurt off the corny lines, and talent the young lad has not been given time to acquire.My analysis? Good movie, bad actors.

'Supes Returns' is a re-tread of the first movie's plot - the only thing new is the romantic sub-plot, which is a good one, but that's it. There was zero dramatic tension; in other words, we were simply watching it all unfold. And there was zero Wow. For 270 mil I expect some Wow, and I saw it in 3-D IMAX! Note on that: the middle-field of the 3-D was often under-sized, which made things like trucks look like toys. And a really large mistake was not establishing how super this man was. Routh is shown in his big Clark-suit then the first time we see him as Superman, it's CGI! It seemed like those Fleisher cartoons, after all, and every time his muscles were too-bulging. Upon seeing Routh again after that in the costume, my thoughts were, is this another one of those padded costumes? -- which is the man, which the effects?The powers: where were they? Nearly everything was catching, throwing, and flying, as if the film's reduplification of "iconic" 30's comics covers is supposed to make us feel all exited in and of itself. The X-Ray Vision and Super-Breath were thrown away on unimaginative uses and the Heat Vision came out once in an only mildly interesting manner. So, we were subjected to rising heroic fanfares frustratingly accompanying very pedestrian action and effects. The first 45 minutes ground forward establishing canon with overly-painstaking effort and over-long scenes. omg and what brainiacs voted to retain the original's "lighthearted" 70's cutesy-humor? ...the very aspect that prevents the original from playing well to a modern audience!The other theater-goers in our showing seem to have agreed. Here we were, opening-day IMAX Supes-geeks with shirts n stuff, and after the film there was only scattered 'pity-applause'!I'm here to announce the actor chosen to bear the S-Shield has zero charisma. That's about all there is to say about it.And this was not any person's idea of Lois Lane. Jeez. No spine. No snark. No brains...what's up? Unlike some younger actors, Bosworth seems unable to play older or savvy. Not only do I have no interest in seeing this again, I wish I hadn't gone through the unpleasant experience.

Let me get this out of the way first - I am a huge Superman fanboy. One of my fondest childhood memories is watching the original Chris Reeve Superman with my family as a child and being awestruck in the scene where he catches the helicopter. The opening credits still give me goosebumps.Now, saying that, I will agree that this is an excellent movie. Its very entertaining, the characters are well developed and the FX are second to none. In short, I have no gripes with the movie. The references to the previous movies in character interactions and scenes filmed in the same style as the original Superman (practically take from the first and redone with Brandon Routh) added that final polish that most films lack. I was particularly impressed by Kate Bosworth's portrayal of Lois Lane - just the right amounts of anger, frustration, desire and hope all mixed into one. After the annoying performance by Katie Holmes in Batman Begins, one could imagine LL falling into the same pitfall. But, and this is testament to the writer's skill, you never hate Lois Lane. If anything, you feel for her, and how she's torn by the return of Superman.However, I have one criticism - no one really says anything. With the exception of Lex Luthor (brilliantly portrayed by Kevin Spacey), no one else says a whole lot. You do get a lot of emotion from the way the scenes are done, but there's something missing. Its really a minor flaw in an otherwise entertaining movie, but at times you're left wondering why you're rooting for Superman. However, I'm looking forward to a sequel - I have faith in Bryan Singer as a director.Superman has returned to the big screen. Congratulations guys, you did an amazing job.

I really enjoyed this movie. It was entertaining and fun. It is sadly not a great Superman movie. I wish that everyone who sees this film enjoys it and feels that they saw something worthwhile. I say this because it seems clear that the production worked very hard to achieve a great Superman movie and it is a good movie.Superheroes are not an easy chore and I think the production of Superman Returns did a grand job of bringing this guy back and yet it misses more from its ties to what happened before then what is presented as new. I walked out last night feeling that I had seen a good movie, but once again knowing that this material was not in the best of hands.It was a good effort.

Review Title: I can't believe people thought this was a good movie.
Review: First of all, those 3 points are for the effects. The acting? Amateurish. Parker Posey crying scenes? Don't make me laugh.And if you're going to have a love story subplot, make it at least lukewarm. Those two actors had absolutely no chemistry.As with most movies these days: NO CHAR. DEVELOPMENT! A previous poster stated that one did not feel for any of the characters. I felt the exact same way. Brandon played Superman like a robot in his dialogue...always seemed subdued. Granted his Clark persona was pretty good.There was no buildup, no suspense, and yes, even though it's a fantasy, let's stick to some of the obvious limitations of Superman from the comicbooks.Kryptonite is deadly to him, yet after being exposed to it, getting the crap beat out of him, and then a large blade of kryptonite stuck in his side, he still manages to tread water to be saved by his friends? Oh yeah, and then he takes the whole mini continent that is loaded with kryptonite, lifts it and casts it into space. According to my comic books, Superman just near kryptonite suddenly becomes weak. Please.Too many inconsistencies, gaps, the movie does not flow. Come on folks, let's keep the standards high, so these bloated producers stay on their toes and give us what we want...a well-made film.

This movie had all of the action/adventure that you'd expect from Superman, with none of the corny script-writing that we've come to expect and tolerate from Hollywood. They managed to avoid some expected cheezy conversations and as a bonus added in a lot of humor. Casting was perfect. Special effects were excellent without being over the top. Storyline was classic and unforgettable. This movie immediately makes my personal top 10 list and is nestled somewhere in between Usual Suspects and Star Wars. Bryan Singer is also nestled in between Johnny Depp and Kevin Spacey on my list of "I'll go see anything with his name on it." When does the sequel come out????

Review Title: Continues in the original spirit of Donner's while holding its own
Review: After a decade of false starts ranging from reboots to re-imaginings of the franchise, a new Superman movie has finally reached theaters; Superman has returned.The film certainly has its faults, as do all films that carry so much hype and emotion for those stepping through the door. The icon of Superman has become an American symbol and a legacy throughout the country and elicits its fair share of childhood nostalgia. So how does Bryan Singer's version hold up to past incarnations? Quite well. Built as a semi-sequel to the first and arguably the second of the original Superman films from the 70's and 80's, Superman Returns continues not only the stories of our favorite blue boy scout (Brandon Routh), the overzealous female reporter Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth), the young funny guy photographer Jimmy Olsen (Sam Huntington), Daily Planet Editor in Chief Perry White (Frank Langella), and bald super-baddie Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey), but the film also adds on to certain themes from Richard Donner's original 1978 film, such as the idea of passing on the family heritage from father to son, the ideas of adoption, of loneliness, of obligation to a greater good and more central, the idea of Superman as a savior to mankind. While Singer and his writers add to this legacy, they also map out their own, deepening the Lois/Superman relationship and adding some unsuspected twists and turns into the mythos.Overall, Returns has some problems - perhaps a bit too lengthy a running length for the average movie-goer, and some pacing issues in the beginning and end, but overall, the rebirth of this franchise was worth the wait. Great FX, great action, heartfelt moments. They hit all the right points out of the park, and the rest is more than forgivable. The beginning credits alone which hearken back to the original films was enough to give goosebumps. Superman's Back.

Review Title: The Man of Steel is Back!!!
Review: Outstanding movie!!! All Superman fans will love the new superman, Brandon Routh. He is the perfect choice to play the man of steel.
