The torch has been successfully passed from Christopher Reeve to Brandon Routh. Brandon gave an awesome outstanding performance. He is definitely a great actor and playing the man of steel is surly gonna make him a big star. I look for great things ahead of him in his future.Overall, HIGHLY Recommended!!! Lots of action, suspense, awesome visuals and special effects! This is definitely the big summer movie of 2006. Maybe even the best movie of 2006, but we will just have to wait and see.

Review Title: Superman returns to his old glory?
Review: The film opens slowly as it explains the five year absence of Superman. Clark returns to his old job only to find Lois is engaged to Richard with whom she has a child. Then as soon as Lois gets into trouble Bryan Singer does what he does best, creates a thrilling visual experience. Once the effects in the film start they continue on throughout the film with very few visible flicks of the digital wand. The movie is engaging and put together as well as any other recent comic movies, But was a superman plot ever all that suspenseful, thrilling, or relatable? This movie like the previous Superman movies suffers from the writing restraints it character creates. THE man of steel does two things in this movie... Casually save the day with only a small smirk, or become a worthless mess the moment kryptonite comes into play. This causes the movie to lack the tension of a Spiderman or batman script; sure we know they aren't going to die either but at least they bleed. But putting aside previous complaint the movie is worth 9.50. It is well written (baby mama drama) and seamlessly integrates stunning effects.

To be honest I was never truly a Superman fan; I was only interested in the mythos of the hero. Having known the general back story of Superman from what I knew from comic book encyclopedias, "Smallville", the first two movies, some of the comics themselves, and of course Wikipedia, I was looking forward to this film. Bryan Singer managed to pull off the X-men movies, revamping that comic books could become very good Hollywood materials, and he's proved that again with Superman Returns.The story, as many would know, takes place five years after Superman II. Our hero has returned from his journey to the remains of Krypton, and is greeted with much applause and excitement from the world. Well, except for Lois Lane. Returning back to the world as well is Lex Luthor, released from prison after the events of the previous film (the latter films, I suppose, are now excluded from the Superman movie canon?). He now has a new plan to overtake the world by force as well as eliminate Superman as well. After walking into the abandoned Fortress of Solitude, Lex gets a hold of a bunch of crystals that will grow into massive landmasses by imitating minerals that they are exposed to. Using water as a catalyst, the land masses would grow into full continents, wiping out, as Lex exclaims, "BILLIONS!" The film's visuals are compelling, now giving, for one, Superman's flight such an amazing sense of depth and realism. The first action sequence of the film, which involves our intrepid hero stopping a free-falling plane that had been attached to a malfunctioning rocket that was being launched into space (that's a mouthful) is just so spectacular. Yet when I saw and compared the flying sequences of this film to the previous ones, I realized just how well done the predecessors had done in terms of visuals. This is a film that has been long since coming, and I'm glad that Warner Bros. finally chose upon Bryan Singer. The last two Superman films, though not nearly as disastrous as Batman and Robin, did almost stain their protagonist's image in the mythos, however what Singer does here, knowing that the self-kidding hero had been pushed a little too much, makes this one a more serious, more toned story, just as Batman Begins does with its hero. What we now have is a superhero that returns to a world that, after his long absence, has become almost worse than it had been when he left it. Along with that, he now faces the challenges of being rejected by the one person he cared for the most out of all the world, Lois Lane. She has a fiancée and a son, but still remains deeply hurt by Superman's departure. As well, Lex Luthor is, as I said, more vicious and cunning as before, and there is a sequence in the film where his cruelty is unexpected but effective. I really liked Spacey's performance. He has a lot of sinister smiles in this film along with his dialogue, and it was great to see that familiar smile that we see in a lot of his villainous roles. Brandon Routh, a relative unknown, looks remarkably like his predecessor, the late Christopher Reeve. At first I was not sure about his effectiveness in continuing the role, however this film has confirmed that he was the perfect choice. With Clark Kent Routh plays him down, just as Reeves had, and perfectly portray's Kent's tendencies to say the wrong things at the wrong time, shy, and of course, try so hard to "hide" his feelings for Lois Lane. Bosworth's performance as Lane was wonderful, and I hope she will be returning in what I hope may be the sequel to this film. This film was long (as well as this comment), however it was so worth the time. What got to me, however, was the way the massive disaster that ensues with Luthor's plan seems to affect only Metropolis. As well, Kent completely vanishes in the latter parts of the film, and I began wondering why everyone was so concerned with Lois Lane if Clark Kent was also missing from work as well. But then again I suppose that was how Superman intended Clark to be-- played down so much that he appears invisible to everyone. But I digress. Superman Returns is everything that I expected it to be. The timing is excellent as well. In a time where the world seems like it may be heading downhill, it's great to see a film that returns the most heroic superhero of the twentieth century back into our minds. Like the people of Metropolis and the world it occupies, Superman is its beacon, and he "lights the way". If only that were so in our world.

Review Title: Singer true to the Superman character of all ages
Review: As he has demonstrated with his past films, Singer stays true to the Superman character of all ages while appearing to the mass audience of today. Building his main characters steadily, Singer makes us care about what happens to his protagonist and supporting cast. Mixing in humor and a twisting, turning love story, Singer's film is well rounded with few awkward moments, and a beautiful meld with computer generated effects.The comic aficionado will enjoy the special homage to the 1920s pages with frame shots. The honor and sentiment towards Christopher Reeve and John Williams is felt throughout. Routh wins us over with his tenderly believable performance, and his stoic strength is palpable. Spacey is a convincing Luthor with punchy lines and unmistakable intent. Brando's clips bear more and more weight as the story plays out, and remain echoing in the mind.I grew up a Superman fan having never seen any movies in any theatres. This movie displays the quintessential superhero of all time in a world not unlike ours today that needs a motivating figure to look up to. Even if you are not a Superman die-hard fan, you will appreciate the deeper threads that run through the movie.Thank you for such an exhilarating ride.

Review Title: Great movie, it is worth the watch! (spoiler free)
Review: Greetings fellow movie lovers. I just got back from seeing Superman Returns on this the night of it's opening, and I would have to say the experience was excellent as well as noteworthy. Once again I will add that there will be no spoilers here(only what you could get from previews or the main summary of the movie). I will also add that this is my first time writing a review of a movie on IMDb, so please bare with me. OK, as I was saying my girlfriend and I attended a showing of superman returns tonight and I would rate this movie very high. The effects, the acting, the cinematography, everything was done very well in this movie. In the movie, as you know we enter a modernized world of superman, and yet the film takes place from a point already into the saga, unlike batman begins(however this is definitely it's own movie). Bryan Singer has come into his own and has done a great job on this movie. Though I stated that it is it's own movie Singer's decisions in the movie show how much he appreciates and loves the older movies and superman epic, like his use of the original music and than some. There are signs everywhere in the film that reference the Christopher reeve era films. Though it is impossible to totally make some aspects of superman "uncheesy" Singer does a nice job of the real world feel. The movie is longer which is a plus since no movie of this type should ever feel rushed, although there were choice parts that I thought could be longer, but not many. Brandon Routh is a perfect new superman. He is able to make the part his own and yet you do see some reeve present. Kevin Spacey takes Lex Luthor from being a funny businessman who is sort of evil to being an intelligent tyrant out for revenge and personal gain...This film is definitely darker. Kate Bosworth, Sam Hungington, and the rest of the cast all do a great job. In fact there is really only one part of the plot that I thought was a tad unnecessary, or at least shouldn't have been done. Lets see if you all can figure out which part I meant. However it wasn't that bad, and the movie still flows well. Some more explanation on certain parts could be the only other flaw, but all in all this movie is worth seeing and hopefully not just the fans will fall in love with this modern epic. I hope this helped...Thanks!

I went into this theater expecting a fabulous, exciting movie, and I walked out utterly pleased. It was higher than my expectations! This movie was funny, it got you involved emotionally, it had enough action, amazing special-effects, and excellent acting.Brandon Routh was excellent as Superman, and as the adorably dorky Clark Kent. He has the looks, the muscle, and he doesn't look ridiculous in the blue and red suit. Kate Bosworth was lovely and vivacious as Lois Lane, and James Marsden was, well, so very normal compared to Superman, but he did a good job, too.Whatsisname was a good villain, a good Lex Luthor. He didn't overact the evilness; he got it just right. He got the power-hungry sense, and the wit and intelligence that Lex Luthor has; he didn't overdo it, but nor did he underplay it. He makes the viewers understand why this man has been doing so many horrible things.The only reason I give this 9 is because of the inconclusive ending. I hope that there are more Superman movies with Brandon Routh after this. Bryan Singer did a fabulous job with this.The plot line never lagged. It was always exciting and making the viewer ask questions. It was action packed and suspenseful; it didn't have too much action, nor too much non-action. It had a good balance of emotional conflict and action-type conflict.Also, this movie does not confuse the non-Supermanbuffs. I am not a Superman buff, but I was able to follow what was happening, and what Krypton was and why Superman left in the first place, etc. etc.I would advise this movie to anyone who is searching for a good reason to go to the theater, or for someone who wants to see a good action film, or for people who are wondering if Routh can be a good Superman. Go see this movie as soon as you can!

Review Title: Superman Returns: a decent family film
Superman has returned in a big way!
Review: As a life long Superman fan, I, like many others, was afraid that this movie would be a stinker. After seeing it twice, already, I can honestly say that this is already one of my favorite movies of all time and the best superhero flick I've ever seen. Brandon Routh had some massive shoes to fill with this flick and he did it with gusto. He portrayed a powerful, yet vulnerable being and after no time at all, I was totally convinced. Brian Singer did what only a few others might have been able to, he made a new Superman movie that beams with greatness. Man, I can't wait to see it again and again, not to mention it's sequels. Superman is back! Hooray!

Review Title: Disappointing and Darker than Expected...Sequel? Remake?
Great Characters in a sea of bad writing
Review: The premise of the movie is simply absurd. This movie is not in the excellent tradition of Batman Begins or Spiderman 1 & 2. The casting was relatively decent (although Brandon Routh looks like Jason Schwartzman on steroids). Jimmy Olsen was perfect. But the storyline was incoherent, leaving many loose ends untied. Brian Singer had the chance to make something great and he failed miserably. I was very disappointed that he made a mediocre movie out of good characters by employing a weak script, a foolish premise, and a stupid storyline. Keep the Christopher Reeve films and Smallville in your mind as a shining example of what Superman should really be like.

Review Title: At A Time When The World Needs a Hero Most, Superman Returns...and Delivers!
Review: Superman Returns essentially discards the events that transpired in the 3rd and fourth movies starring Christopher Reeve. To most fans, the first two in the series are the only ones that "count." Well, Superman fans, be prepared to add another to that list. Superman Returns is a modernized sequel to Superman 2, and it puts the series right back on track with excellent casting choices, a well-developed plot, and plenty of action that you'll see only in a movie starring the Man of Steel.The movie starts out just as the first one did. The Superman theme sounds as the credits roll exactly the way they did in the originals, with the camera going through space from the planet Krypton to Earth. It doesn't take long for Superman to...well, return. A brief flashback of a young Clark Kent sprinting and jumping through a field gives any newcomer the basic rundown of his childhood as he develops his powers over time. Clark Kent, played by Brandon Routh, gets his job at the Daily Planet after a five-year hiatus, and soon discovers that the world has moved on without him. Lois Lane has won a Pulitzer Prize for an article titled "Why The World Doesn't Need Superman." He also quickly discovers that Lois has a child, and is engaged to the newspaper chief's nephew (James Mardsen, X-Men). Just as Kent rejoins the newspaper, sure enough, Lois Lane's (Kate Bosworth) life is on the line. Superman makes his grand re-emergence as he takes a plane spiraling out of control and lands it in the middle of a packed ballpark. The world is glad to have Superman back, but what caused this catastrophe to happen? Lex Luthor, excellently played by Kevin Spacey, is the answer. Prior to Superman's return, Luthor plunders Superman's Fortress of Solitude and steals the entire collection of crystals Jor-El, Superman's biological father (Marlon Brando) sent with him on his voyage to Earth. The madman later reveals that these crystals are a key component to his plan to create a brand new continent, which, in turn, would send much of mainland America into the sea. In an attempt to keep Superman at bay, Luthor also steals Kryptonite from a museum and sends it into the sea with the crystal, lacing the entire landmass with Kryptonite. Luthor's female counterpart, Kitty Kowalski, is played by Parker Posey, and serves as a comic relief to the more darkened, less jester Luthor.The action is greater than any Superman movie ever. The awkward-looking flights are in the past, and in this film, Superman actually flies. Wind actually hits Superman, as opposed to Christopher Reeve just floating around, meeting no resistance at all. The special effects are amazing, and the scene that got the most "oohs" and "ahhs" at the showing I attended was when a thief pulled out a handgun and shot Superman from point blank, only to see the bullet get crushed like a tin can upon contact with his eye.Some may criticize Kate Bosworth for turning Lois Lane into a damsel in distress, but in this movie, I think it fits. She has attempted to get over Superman by putting her attention on an anti-Superman article, she has become engaged to another man, she has a child to attend to, but when he re-enters her life, she does not know what to do. She truly is a damsel in distress. She loves Richard, but at the same time, she has loved Superman for years. She tries to juggle what is right and what is wrong, and in the end does not know what she should do.Brandon Routh has Superman down. He has the swagger, he has the looks, he has the manliness. The only flaw I saw was his adaptation of Clark Kent. When Reeve played the part, there was a huge difference between Clark Kent and Superman. In this film, Routh's Kent is simply Superman with glasses and a different hair style. Reeve had the small things down to make them two completely different characters. Sure, Routh's speech patterns changed slightly, and his voice pitch went a little higher, but it wasn't enough to distinguish between the two.Kevin Spacey was the best cast of the group, in my opinion. Many critics did not like the fact that in the original movies, Lex Luthor was mainly comic relief, and less of a villain. In this film, Luthor still shows he has about 100 more IQ points than anyone else in the room with his short quips, but he also shows a much darker side than the Lex Luthor portrayed by Gene Hackman. He did an excellent job, and Parker Posey just added to his stellar performance like a sidekick should.All in all, this is one of the best superhero movies I've seen, by far. Nostalgia was a factor in my liking of the movie, but Bryan Singer has resurrected this seemingly-dead movie franchise.

Review Title: The Best Action Movie I've ever seen!
A good tribute to the original films and comics with originality
I think Christopher Reeve would be proud...
Review: Brian Singer is a great director. When he makes movies, his most powerful tool is subtlety. His X-Men movies were phenomenal, but this is the best Brian Singer movie I have ever seen. When the credits role in the beginning and the choice ending that Singer used to wrap it up, I had goosebumps. I got super emotional because everything was perfect. He cast great actors who carried themselves well throughout the whole movie. Young Brandon Routh was amazing, donning the S and carrying that mantle we all love so well. From start to finish, this movie deserves 4 stars. Each moment and scene was so powerful because of the actors, story and direction. I loved it. It helps to have seen the first two films, but it holds its own by itself. Batman Begins was very much the same way. I had high hopes for both of these movies, and they delivered. Christopher Reeve would be proud. This was a great film

Full credit to everyone associated with this project. After years of wondering whether a Superman movie would ever be as good without Christopher Reeve, the answer is definitely YES! Singer's direction has given all the contributors - actors, writers, special effects, musicians, costumers, set designers - the opportunity to showcase their skills to the 'max' in this epic blockbuster. Routh's Superman is perfect. Brandon is strikingly similar, physically, to Reeve - but at the same time has added a personal "warmth and glow" to the role. The script is strong, and enables the use of a plethora of effects, creating a visual package of award winning proportions. This is fantasy entertainment at its very best. Superman fans across the globe can be assured of a most worthy welcomed return of our greatest Superhero.

Review Title: All the buildup and not quuuiiite enough payoff
The Definitive Superman for this Century.
Review: Although it took 10 years to finally have made this film, the milestone in movie magic definitely made Superman Returns one of the top Superhero-isque movie which is (my personal opinion) on par to the greatness of Spiderman and Batman Begins.The Casting of Brandon Routh as Clark Kent/Superman bears uncanny resemblance and even the voice of Christopher Reeves, which to my fanboyishness is a great Homage to the man that made us believe someone could fly.The story fits closely to the Donner's Superman 2 movie in which (spoiler) a plot which my throws the continuity of the Superman franchise out the window or probably re-establish it.All in all, This is the definitive Superman movie for this century for the younger ones to enjoy and also for old fanboys to appreciate. Definitely a must watch.

Comic book movies are pretty much the standard in the film industry. There are so many comic books being crossed over to film that it is hard to keep count. And since Spiderman, the genre has made a huge comeback, with the Spiderman franchise, the X-Men franchise and Batman Begins, Superman Returns almost seems like too little too late. I don't think so. Superman started the trend back in 1978 with the release of Superman: The Movie. It was followed up with three sequels and a spin off called Supergirl. Superman IV:The Quest For Peace seems like ages ago though, probably because it has been over 20 years since Superman flew across the movie screen. The fan base has been ready for a new Superman film and they have been rewarded.Superman Returns is an outstanding comic book movie with a great story and deep characters. Brandon Routh is actually very good in this film to the point where you almost forget that Christopher Reeves and Brandon Routh are two different people. But as similar as they are, they are also two very different characters. Christopher Reeves played Clark and Superman as two complete opposites, Clark very goofy and clumsy and Superman as a serious caring guy. Christopher Reeves was known to have been very serious about not letting one character show in the other. Routh plays Clark as just your everyday small town innocent guy who lacks some confidence and Superman as someone who like most people, would love to have that life with a family. You can see Superman in Clark and Clark in Superman and for the first time, we get a first person point of view of what Superman must go through every waking moment of his life.Superman Returns is in someways and indirect sequel to Superman: The Movie and Superman II and as it is faithful to those two films, it also does well in creating a new identity for the series where the film can stand on it's own. In this film, Superman has been gone for five years, on an expedition to where Krypton once was to see if there are any survivors. When he returns, he sees that the world has moved on without him. Superman/Clark Kent is not ready for this change.To watch this film, one does not need to know the history of Superman's origin as it is explained in the first moments of the movie. It hopes that the viewer has seen the previous films but knowing that some of the viewers may be too young to have seen those films, it gives a brief history of Superman's past. With the hit WB show "Smallville" still on the air, there is no need for a long explanation. We get pushed right into the story which is great.Kate Bosworth is Lois Lane, the hard nosed reporter who even though she has a child and is engaged, still has her eyes on the man of steel. But like everyone else, she wants her answers as to why he has left. Bosworth plays Lois Lane with a bit of vulnerability. Though she has her family life she is still vulnerable to her feelings towards Superman. Routh and Bosworth seem to have decent chemistry together but I must admit, Reeves and Kidder seemed more believable as a romantic couple.Kevin Spacey is Lex Luthor. This Lex comes off as a cross between Gene Hackman's portrayal and as an older Michael Rosenbaum (Lex Luthor on Smallville.) I enjoyed this combination very much and added much depth to a once two dimensional character. Here is a man who not only wants to be the most powerful man on Earth, but his jealousy of Superman will drive him to do unthinkable things.Though I won't give any more details, I will say that this film does a very good job of keeping up that comic book feel while delivering a new twist to the story.As mentioned earlier, this film does a great job of being faithful to the original movies while creating it's own personality. Byan Singer (director of X-Men and X2:X-Men United)delivers a fresh new chapter in the Superman Saga, one that should make fans happy everywhere....

Review Title: I do believe a man can fly!
Review: I read the reviews. It was disheartening to me, who loved the original Superman: The Movie, that Bryan Singer had ruined the film. I sat down in the theater with my Superman Slurpie and my eyes stuck to the screen for 2 1/2 hours. When it was over, I was in awe. Sure, there was corny stuff, and a plot point that I didn't prefer, but the film was so overwhelmingly awesome that those are minor details in the big picture. Starting off with the march, the film doesn't stop for anyone to catch up. The visuals were in itself worth the 9 dollar ticket. IF YOU DO NOT SEE THIS ON THE BIG SCREEN, DO NOT SEE IT AT ALL. This is one of the films you'll want to tell your kids YOU saw it when it was first in theaters, just as my dad did for the original Superman: The Movie. Sure, its not the original, but the thing is when you're watching it, you don't really care. It keeps the camp of the 70's film, but takes it in a more serious direction as the film progresses. Finally, Kevin Spacy is spec-tac-ular as Lex Luthor. I could feel the Gene Hackman vibe with a dash of Spacey's wit and delivery. Superman has returned, and it seems that we really do need him after all. Top 5 movie of the year so far!

I just got back from seeing this movie on opening night in my town. I'll admit, I'm not a terribly big fan of Superman(Like Batman a bit more), but this movie was amazing to say the very LEAST. The effects were amazing, the plot was great, and even though some critics may not like Brandon Routh as Superman, he pulls it off amazingly well in this one. Speaking of acting, Kevin Spacey was especially great as Lex Luthor, and Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane. This movie has completely changed my mind about Superman. Overall, it's a fantastic movie that pretty much sums up what a superhero truly is. Do yourself a favor and go see this movie as soon as you can, you won't be disappointed at all.

Review Title: one of the best action movies i have ever seen
Review: this movie definitely fulfilled my expectations. some action movies have excessive action that eventually get boring, while other "action" movies have barely any, and you walk out feeling like you just flushed $10 right down the crap chute. This movie had a perfect mix of each, and it didn't lean too much on either extreme. Also, most action movies have a crappy screenplay, but Superman was well written, and also very well directed, with many incredible camera angles that are mind blowing, but not too crazy that you get dizzy and sick in your seat. There were also parts where i was expecting one thing and thought i had predicted what would happen, and then boom something happened that i didn't expect at all. the acting was also stellar, and in my opinion perfectly cast. I don't think there could have been a better Clark Kent, expect for maybe Christopher Reeves. Overall, this movie was pretty incredible. I'd see it again, and recommend others to see it as well.

Review Title: Exactly what I was waiting for
Review: What can I say? Plot: The story went back to the basics. Damsel in distress, Tragic Hero, "With Great Power Comes Great Responsibility"-kind-of-stuff. There is obvious references to Christian symbiology, but I didn't think it was played too hard. No "Nucleur Man" or what ever it was in Superman IV. Perfect for what it needed.Acting: Probably the best picks for characters. Routh who plays Superman, who I thought would be an "iffy" Superman, nailed the part. He really does look a lot like Reeves, but doesn't really imitate him. Still, he is faithful to the character. He definitely showed the difference between Kent and Superman. Probably the one character who I thought was perfect was the actor who played Jimmy Olsen. He serves as a great comic relief, but I wanted to hear more from him. Unfortunately, Cyclops from X-Men is in the movie, and that's all I could think of whenever I saw him.Action: Perfect. Effects were good. Fight scenes were not overplayed at all. I guess it was going to show that a fight with Superman cannot last more than like 5 seconds (it's an exaggeration, the fight scenes were more than 5 seconds). The focus was more on the action that Superman must do to become a hero again. Good all around.Overall: I saw this on the IMAX, so my only problem really was that the 3-D effects sometimes were a little out of focus (and that my friend blew 3 bucks on a soda that costs to refill.) Otherwise, this movie finally shows how good a superhero movie can be. It's a blockbuster guaranteed. I really can't think of a negative for this movie. Plus, it didn't have any stupid hang-ons on the end like X-3 or the League of Extraordinary Gentlemen. So, yeah, 10 out of 10 for me. Best movie of the year, to date.

I saw this movie last night and I was thinking to myself who is Brandon Routh. The movie starts off very interesting like Superman should start off. I had a problem with Clark's character I thought he wasn't that good but his Superman character was awesome. Kate Bosworth is amazing as Lois, she plays this character in her own way and it works.Lex Luther as Kevin Spacey is Fantastic.This movie was OK it kind of drags on towards the end for a bit but other than that I would recommend seeing it. The movie is not awesome but see it for the action, Kevin Spacey, and the beautiful Kate Bosworth.

One of the best superhero returns movie I have seen. As simple as that. Routh has done an excellent job and lived up to the expectations of superman fans. Kevin spacey suited perfect as lex Luther. I am sure from the story that more superman movies will be evolving which is exciting. I wish someone make a movie on He-Man. Thats one superhero remaining to take a film on. I can't remember how many times in my childhood I wished I could be one of those superheroes. After watching a cartoon on spider-man I don't know how many times I wished that spider bit me instead. LOL. I am sure you can enjoy this movie with your kids if not by yourself. People who say routh is too lean to fit the superman character should watch him. His facial expressions as Clark Kent as well as superman were perfect. Go watch it. Don't miss it. Enjoy..

Review Title: Superman Returns – You Will Believe a Man Can Cry
A Great Homage to Donner and Reeve
Review: When an iconic film is remade you can go two ways - totally go down a different road and destroy what made the previous film iconic - think "Poseidon", or you can do what Bryan Singer did and almost duplicate the feel and humanity from the first Superman series of the late 70's early 80's.This isn't just a rehash but Singer tips his hat enough to the Donner directed films to satisfy this old fan and bring enough of current culture to satisfy new fans.It starts with the return of the classic style for the opening credits and liberal amounts of the fantastic John Williams score. I did expect to hear some hip-hop or some bland pop music but luckily that wasn't the case.There are some additions to match where we are currently in pop culture - like having Perry White exclaim that the story isn't the black out but Superman - and the culture of celebrity that seems to infect news gathering today. Jimmy Olsen has a digital camera but he is still scooped by a kid with a cell phone for a picture of Superman.The special effects 30 years ago were cutting edge. The big deal about Superman the Movie back in 1978 was believing a man could fly. With today's CGI, it isn't a big deal. The special effects don't overwhelm the story which is good.In general the actors did a good job.Brandon Routh won the role of Superman in a long process much like Christopher Reeve was chosen back in the 70's. Routh makes the character his own although Reeve was better at the clumsy dork Clark Kent persona.Kate Bosworth did a fine job as Lois Lane. On first blush I thought she was too pretty to play a gritty reporter but in the end she held her own. I did think she was too young.Kevin Spacey oozed evil genius as Lex Luthor just as Gene Hackman did in the 1978 film. Although I did miss Otis - Lex's henchman in the first film, Parker Posey filled in nicely as Spacey's sidekick.James Marsden, Frank Langella, Sam Huntington, Eva Marie Saint round out the main cast. There are also cameos by Jack Larson and Noel Neill from the 1950's Superman TV show. Marlon Brando makes a return as Jor-El which was done by using footage shot for Superman II that wasn't used back in 1980.The plot of the film wasn't spectacular as it was another take on the plot of the first film - Lex Luthor wanting to create land where there is none. The love triangle between Lois, Superman, and Richard White (played by Marsden) doesn't drag the film at all and seems pretty realistic and adds even more to the humanity of Superman. Singer has said the time of this film takes place 5 years after the time of the 2nd film so the relationship is not fake in the least.There is also some funny dialog that helps balance the drama including some obvious double entendres and some plot holes but I think any of the ones I noticed didn't hurt the film at all.A plot twist, late in the film, will at first shock anyone who hasn't read any spoilers - like myself - but does add a new layer to the myth.Some people may have issues with one of the other themes in the film - a religious theme. A bit of Brando dialog used in the TV trailers said: "Even though you've been raised as a human being you're not one of them. They can be a great people, Kal-El, they wish to be. They only lack the light to show the way. For this reason above all, their capacity for good, I have sent them you... my only son" and bit further in the trailer Superman says to Lois: "You wrote that the world doesn't need a savior, but every day I hear people crying for one." That dialog is used in the film but the religious symbolism is not a main theme but might still upset some on the religious right.I do hope if there are more films, Singer or future directors add to the story rather than just doing another version of a past plot. It might help to have a different nemesis next time.This is still an excellent addition to the Superman franchise. Welcome back Superman.

Review Title: Unfortunately no Giant Spiders in this one...
Review: Tonight I saw Superman Returns and had an enjoyable time. I'd give the film *** out of four stars. The problem I had with the film is that I simply am not interested in Superman. I find his character and world boring. That said I think Brian Singer did an excellent job with the film. It is a direct sequel to Superman 2, forgetting that 3 and 4 ever existed. Superman returns to earth 5 years after the events of Superman 2 to find that nothing really has changed, that people have found a way to survive with out him. Lois Lane is engaged to a man, played by the cat who plays Cyclops in the X Men franchise which explains his absence from that film, and with a 5 year old child. Lex Luthor has been released from prison because of a genius loophole in the system where during his appeal they called Superman to testify as a witness but because he was gone they had no evidence to keep him in prison. Things in the world kind of suck for our favorite Kryptonian. Brandon Routh is swell as Clark Kent and exudes an enormous amount of power and grace as Superman. He really filled Christopher Reeves role well. Lois Lane is a lot less edgy this time around but surprisingly this didn't bother me. Kate Bosworth played her closer to the Noel Neil version from the 50's in that she was gentle and sweet. The real highlight in the film is Marlon Brando's scenes which were omitted from the original and were restored for this release. The film had entertaining action scenes, though a few too many, and some real shocks (all I have to say is "piano") which brought the film to a fitting dramatic conclusion. Overall it was the best of the Superman films and if you were a fan of the original 2 this one won't disappoint because it stays very true to the spirit of them.

Superman Returns is truly an amazing theatrical experience. From the very first scene, I was pinned to my seat. Buy your snacks and go to the bathroom before it starts, because you won't want to miss a second of this one! Just like the X-Men and Spiderman movies, you don't have to know the story before enjoying this movie. All I know before I saw it was that Superman was super in some way and that a character named Lois Lane was somehow involved in the plot. Oh yes, and there's a song called "Kryptonite" that seems to reference Superman.What separates this out from the rest of the superhero movies is that this one actually makes you feel good while watching it. Unlike other suspense/action films, this one doesn't make you anxious or uncomfortable...waiting for the plot to just "move along" for relief (I would provide examples but I don't want to give spoilers to other movies, but I'm mostly referring to Spiderman). The conflict is for the most part simple and to-the-point, without losing any action or entertainment value. If you're looking for an extremely edge-of-your-seat movie this summer, I suggest you check this out.

Review Title: why the world doesn't need superman
Review: well, superman was a fun movie to watch mainly because of all the special effects. however, certain parts in the film seem too dragged out while other parts seem like they got rushed to finish. the movie is also quite long. what bothered me the most is that the main evil plot / antagonist part of the movie was really lame and feeble. lex luthor is not a strong villain, and his evil scheme isn't that evil. it seems that the movie was 2 hours of watching superman lift heavy stuff and the ending was really anti-climactic. I'm giving the movie a 7 rating only because the acting was pretty good and the special effects were great. the plot was dumb and the movie score was repetitive. Batman begins was awesome, superman returns was not.

Even not being immersed in Superman lore, and having seen the older films long ago, it was still painfully obvious that this continuation from part two goes to great lengths in appeasing the original fan base and emulating all of the aspects that made Superman a household name to all the non-comic book reading viewers out there. By accentuating emotional connections and highlighting visual aesthetics associated with all the romantic notions of being the curled one, director Singer perhaps overshadows any unique spin he could have given the S in favor of paying homage to various historical scenes from previous installments. It is in this revamped homage to past conflict that the actual script looses steam in it's continual repetition. What this plot did in terms of providing something new was merely update previously explored concepts from parts one and two. Acting is cartoonishly acceptable. The much debated Routh integrity seems to fall more to his favor. While the lead lacks the downright charisma to be a versatile leading actor (hasn't stopped the lot of em), he certainly does his best to support the mannerisms and physicality Reeve helped pioneer, particularly on the Kent front. Spacey and Posey have formidable chemistry as the fun duo but really do not walk far past caricature, oddly enough only Bosworth's generically multi-layered performance echoes any actual human sentiment. What does take the cake of this film and purely separates it from sheer mediocrity however is the behind the scenes virtuosity of some of the most intense "motion" picturing yet captured. Yes, the flight of Superman far outweighs the plight of Superman, and Singer and crew clearly know this as lavish attention to detail + innovative new camera technology = the best articulation of flight yet captured on film. If anything this movie is worth seeing alone for this analysis into our collective unconscious, given the passionate ode to weightlessness. Matter of fact the poster image shown on this page represents to me the exact moment of the film's most profound relevance, where the shot as Superman lies suspended in space, the curved details in his stilled cape extraordinarily panned, as inner realities submerge into universal implications in any one single breathless moment- that archetypal moment right before a triumph of will that urges us all to harness our own inner super men.

Review Title: made me go home and watch Batman Begins
Review: Comic book movies can go one of two ways most of the time. In the case of Superman Returns, it was powerful, epic and moved me a great amount. Its movies like this and Batman Begins that make moviegoers step outside of themselves and just allow their minds to be in awe. It also makes me wish I could be a superhero!! Needless to say, with no spoilers, Superman Returns offers a super amount of heart as well as action and none overshadows the other. I'm watching Batman Begins right now as I'm writing this because I've got such a crave for more epic storytelling!! Bravo to Singer for bringing another comic book movie to life.

Review Title: Superman is 2.5 hours of suspenseless tedium, an uninspired love story, and mediocre graphics
Review: Superman Returns was horrible to say the least. My viewing experience ranged from bored to border. With an invincible main character capable of doing absolutely anything, yet without any semblance of character development or personality, the movie runs a staggering two and a half hours without even slight moments of suspense. One might hope at least to revel in the iconic glory of the (somewhat campy) all American hero, but you are so deluged by clichéd moments with Superman flying heroically in the sun that even that is not satisfying. Even the graphics are not particularly noteworthy, leaving superman constantly looking like a plastic action figure. Superman is about equal parts dull action as it is uninspired love story, and 100% tedious. Beyond being a thoroughly uninteresting movie, I believe this is the first time a movie so unabashedly has Goliath triumph over David. The invincible force of nature heroically defeats small pitiful Lex Luthor who tries to bring the technology of an advanced civilization to man, proving once again the age-old proverb that brawn always beat brains. It seems a very appropriate message when looking at current American affairs, but without a moment of self- reflection the character of Superman and the movie named after him were an epic failure. To its credit I will say that Kevin Spacey was brilliant as always.

Review Title: Thankfully a fine return to the big screen for the Man of Steel.

Review: I caught the first showing where I live and I was impressed! Obviously, it's not better than the first film...But Routh did a better job in the lead role than I thought he would, and Spacey is an awesome Luthor. And the story is great for two reasons..First, it pays a respectful tribute not only to the first two Reeve films, but the comics and even the old TV shows. In short, it is a film that will satisfy not only the casual fans, but the die-hard fans who have waited for this film for a very long time. It also has a nice twist at the end, leaving fans wanting the sequel to come out sooner than later.No question about it...Superman is back, and he's flying higher than ever!

Review Title: Why the world should see Superman.
Review: And..why not see the greatest superhero of all time? Truthfully, there is no reason why anyone should not see this movie.First off, the people who bashed Singer for leaving the X-Men franchise might cool off when they see this masterpiece. Singer's wonderful adaptation of this beloved figure will never be forgotten and will soon pass the great Richard Donner films as 'the' Superman movie(s).(Assuming Singer makes magic again..which in my mind, he will.) The Donner films, although great, still depicted Superman in a 'cheesy' light, and this is one of the edges Singer had over Donner. Singer also gave us wonderful high-def visuals and effects that will 'wow' audiences. But most of all it was his storytelling that was so brilliant. The way he portrayed the triangle of man, as Superman battled between being Superman, Kal-El, and the goofy, yet lovable Clark Kent, was just brilliance. Most of all the other triangle between Lois, Clark, and Superman. And unlike the Donner films, it did not feel cheesy, it felt real, and Singer is to thank for really gripping emotion that was brought to screen.And sorry Brandon Routh. Because you did such a wonderful job as Superman, you will forever be remembered for that roll, and it may be hard for people to depict you anywhere else, bravo. As I recall it was Singer's idea to cast an unknown. Well, bravo. How about Kate Bosworth as a beautiful Lois Lane? Who knew the surfer chick from Blue Crush could act so well? Parker Posey, a comic relief, playing alongside Lex Luthor. And well...the best for last...an absolutely brilliantly mesmerizing performance by Mr. Kevin Spacey. His humor mixed in with brilliance really captured the true villain that is Lex Luthor. By playing true to the comics with the bald head, Spacey truly embodied Lex Luthor and made it his own. Sorry Gene. Also great side rolls in the always funny Jimmy, Lois' fiancé, played by James Mardsen, and the cute little man that almost stole the show.As for the effects and story. Do not worry, it is all there. Whether you are a die hard comic fan, a popcorn movie loving guy, a chick flick gal, or someone who just wants to see a greatly directed movie, Superman Returns is the movie for you. Hats off to this new classic. Sorry Roger Ebert, America disagrees. The world needs Superman.

Review Title: Singer captures The Man of Steel...
Review: To talk about Superman Returns, I have to talk about the character, Superman...Every culture has a mythos. Every culture has legends and gods. Many good and many bad. Among the countless cultures and the countless legends, every mythos contains one being that seems to stand for the good hidden within the human soul. A being so like us but so different. A being deified for a set of morals that we all hold dear. The embodiment of hope and inspiration. This is Superman. This is the American mythos.I've had my criticisms of Brian Singer. But to capture the character of Superman is a task that earns my respect. Superman Returns strikes the chord at the very heart of what it is to be human and hope, even believe, in something greater than yourself. In a world with murder, rape, and war. It truly takes an unbiased set of morals and principles to be a hero. To do good for the sake of making someone's life better. To think of others before yourself. This is Superman and this is what Brian Singer brought us.I really have nothing bad to say about this film. This is one of the best pieces of American mythos to be committed to celluloid. I hope to see this mythos, that I hold so dear, grow and continue to inspire the generations.Charles Langbridge Morgan once said, "There are no heroes but in celluloid", and he couldn't be more wrong. You don't have to be Superman to show selfless courage and take action. The heart of Superman is the morals that we all innately know, it doesn't take super-powers to know right from wrong.

Review Title: Academy Award Best Pictures goes to Superman Returns
Review: My comment won't do the movie its justice, go out and see it! Over and over and over again. Bryan Singer did such and awesome job, Brandon Routh, holy crap! He did excellent for his first major film. Seriously I had goose bumps watching it. And it follows the comic books, unlike X-men! It paid homage to the old superman movies so well. Nothing looks fake or green screened at all. Plus it had great plot, and sets itself up for a sequel. It's so funny too, little thing that the characters play off of. Not to mention that the cinematography is out of this world. You guys also have to check out the video blogs from Bryan Singer himself. It gives you a look into what Hollywood is really like. Go see it NOW!

I followed Bryan Singer's video blog via iTunes earlier this year on the making of the new Superman and was compelled to go see it on opening day...something I rarely do.When John Williams score started at the opening credits I actually got a bit of a chill. The movie is incredibly well directed and there are great performances from Brandon Routh, Kevin Spacey, and Parker Posey.The effects are quite spectacular and I'm a special effects fanatic. There are a number of inside jokes for true Superman fans and readers of the comics.Afterward, I heard many people comment on how good they thought it was and five out of five of my clan liked it.I only wish now that I'd seen it on 3D IMAX and might actually see it again that way.

Review Title: A huge weight is off my shoulders!!!
Review: As soon as I heard that there was a new Superman film in the works, I had the most mixed of feelings. I was born in 1984, grew up on, and have watched the original four films more times than I can count, and am a fan of the comic series.Part of me said, "I can't wait to see Superman revisited on screen again!" Another, distinctly different, and far wiser part of me said, "Please don't take a large steaming dump upon my childhood." As more and more rumors about the film leaked out, I became more and more pensive about the upcoming sequel. (The exceptions being the two safe and obvious ones: the inclusion of an always brilliant Kevin Spacey as Luthor, and the attachment of Bryan Singer, a fellow fan, as director.) After seeing the film tonight, I can say safely that all of my fears were unjustified. It is brilliant, sincere, and more than worthy of the Superman name. Go and enjoy this film as soon as possible. I can't wait to see it again.

I was lucky enough to catch a special screening of this last night with a friend. It was unbelievable. I was enthralled from the moment it started (after the long credits) Brandon Routh was great as Superman. He was lovable and quirky as Clark Kent and ethereal as Superman. Kevin Spacey gave a superb performance as Lex Luther and was quite scary in some scenes.Go see this movie! The story will suck you in. It's packed full of excitement and intrigue with some humour in between. Me and my friend were talking about it non stop after we saw it. For people seeking action and just an overall really fun movie, you will not be disappointed.

At first I was very hesitant about seeing Superman Returns but after finally deciding to see it yesterday at a private screening i found it to be better than I expected. Although devoted fans are obviously going to find it somewhat disappointing, overall the movie was quite decent. You were always on the edge of your seat. The plot was very intriguing and Bryan Singer did a good job. There are points when it drags and the "secret" about the son is a little overdone. But overall the acting was really good and i was always enjoying it. As just a fan of the movie I cannot speak for those who are die-hard Superman fans but from them i've been told they expected more from the movie. So for those who did not read the comics as kids it's definitely a movie worth seeing but the superman comic fanatics I would try and go in with an open mind than Bryan Singer did do a great job with what he could and enjoy all!

This is one MUST SEE movie. For any fan of the franchise - be aware - SUPERMAN has RETURNED and in what style and grandeur. This is one movie that grips you from the familiar opening credits to the very end. Everything about this movie is exceptional. This has done what Batman Begins movie did for the Batman Franchise - it resurrected a hero. Just do yourself a favor and go see it and enjoy it for what it is - a purely fantastic movie experience with great acting, special effects and a storyline that fits our hero who has indeed returned. I am sure this film will blow audiences away all over the world and have young kids looking up into the sky for our favorite comic book hero

Review Title: Get rid of this Lois Lame!

Review: It was a very enjoyable experience in seeing the outcome of the absence of Superman for 5 years. This film has it all, non-stop action, great drama, incredible dialog, and powerful acting performances from everyone, especially Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor. Some believe that Brandon Routh could never fill the shoes of Christopher Reeve as Superman... well Brandon is now Superman, and do not judge, just watch the film, and you will see for yourself that Bryan Singer has made a wise choice for the new Man Of Steel. Its true that Superman is a bit more fragile in this film, knowing that Louis Lane has moved on, and met Richard White, but it still doesn't stop him from being unbelievable. Bryan Singer has indeed resurrected the Superman franchise with this amazing film. Superman has indeed Returned.

Now, I've been waiting forever for "them" to make a new Superman movie, but knew that no one could bring back Christopher Reeve, and since I can't spend the hours writing my review down, I'll give my synopsis without spoiling it for others. I had 3 gripes, and 2 of them had to do with computer graphics and them incorporating them into Superman's face and body when he was not Clark Kent--did not like that at all. Overall it's the best movie though I've seen this year, and they brought back the best lines, the wigs, the "stage-like" feel to the bad guys and even a good script! John Williams still did the music, the opening still used the same type of credits, and Kevin Spacey to my surprise was a very good Lex Luthor. Brandon lived up to the best Chris Reeve-like Superman I've seen as of yet, although no one can _be_ him, and it's a hard role to live up to, Lois Lane was not great but she wasn't overpowering and I could handle her--to my surprise she did not ruin the movie for me. I loved the kid in the movie. I loved the story. I loved how they brought "Will" (Chris Reeve's kid) somehow into it metaphorically and even Chris Reeve's story in some vague way. I can't wait to see it again.

I was so afraid after Spiderman and X-men that this would be a disappointment. I have been a fan of this group of films since I was a small child like most of the planet and finally a comic epic that the film industry did justice to. This film will surely be a memory for the next generation of kids to grow with. The plot gets back to the roots of what the comic book genre is all about. The ultimate hero returns after leaving Earth to seek answers to his origins. He finds that his new home is his true home. Superman is the epotime of everything that one could ever want in an idol to save the planet from the forces of evil. Kevin Spacey does justice to the sinister Lex Luther as well.

Review Title: A decent revival of a once great franchise.
Review: I had the privilege of watching the first two Superman movies on Sunday when they were aired on Space Channel (1978 and 1980). Movies certainly have come a long way since then in areas of special effects, cinematography and er... acting but these early manifestations of the D.C. comic book superhero were still landmark films in their own right. I still enjoy watching the earthquake scene in the first Superman and the scenes of Christopher Reeve flying around saving the denizens of the fictitious Metropolis. Christopher Reeve played Superman with a charming simplicity that never seemed over-the-top. He was a likable bumbling doofus as Clark Kent and the strong yet silent type as the man in blue tights, confident in his abilities but not brash. Margot Kidder's performance as the assertive journalist Lois Lane was also admirable while other performances such as Gene Hackmen's Lex Luthor were well, a little over-dramatic.Enter the cast of Superman Returns. Newcomer Brandon Routh is fantastic as Superman and at times I thought I was looking at Christopher Reeve. His performance definitely plays an ode to Christopher Reeve's portrayal with its simplicity and general likability as both the superhero and his alter-ego. Kevin Spacey plays a more plausible Lex Luthor, albeit with the same comical world domination plans involving the acquisition and marketing of real-estate. Kate Bosworth's Lois Lane seemed somewhat bland and one-dimensional as someone full of spite over the absence of Superman like a girl angry because her boyfriend hasn't called in a week. While this may have been a directorial suggestion I envisioned this role being played more maturely, perhaps by an older actress.Still, this movie is worth seeing. Bryan Singer's adaptation slowly blossoms toward the climax of the film and takes the time to introduce its characters and develop its plot. In the recent revival of superhero movies this time is a godsend, providing more layers and introspective glances at the characters instead of rushing into an action filled series of events. It also allows for some gorgeous visuals of Metropolis (New York City?) and some of the other architecture featured in the film. I expect more Superman movies will follow this one. While it is quite an accomplishment for a revival of a once great franchise let's hope that it goes nowhere else but up.

Review Title: This movie was a complete disgrace.
Review: This movie was a complete disgrace to the masterpiece Mario Puzo, Richard Donner and Christopher Reeve created. From the thoughtless underdeveloped and drawn out Lex Luthor scenes, to the RIDICULOUS relationship crisis that basically rips apart the very fiber of the worlds greatest superhero, this movie has left a scar on me of which I may never heal.This movie felt cramped and rushed at the start. Got your hopes up in the middle. And completely crushes any thought of it turning out to be any good in the end.The plot holes and lack of respect for the Superman character as a whole will bring tears to the eyes of anyone who has seen the first two Superman movies. Bryan Singer should get a 10 year ban from being involved in any cinematic endeavors for the attrocity he has created.The only positive factor were the special effects and Brandon Routh as Superman. (Very convincing.) REAL Superman fans STAY AWAY. For your own good.

Review Title: Greatest thing ever to ever happen ever
Review: Superman goes beyond mediums. He's an icon. Few Heroes have the iconic status of Superman, and Bryan Singer made you feel why. He made you watch in awe and feel almost proud. It's visually astonishing. There is not a single thing wrong with this movie. And everyone can and should enjoy it. I'm a comic book fan as well, I could've tore this movie apart I guess but Superman isn't about comic books, it's about a man from Krypton trying to do some good. And Bryan Singer was there with a camera. It's especially good in Imax format, the scenes converted to 3-d are perfect. Easily beats Spider-Man 2 as the best comic book movie ever made.

Review Title: I expected to think it was awesome . . .
Review: But I didn't expect to love it. This is the best movie I have seen in a long time. Sure, there are all the requisite one-liners and cheeseball throwbacks to Superman lore, but all in all this was a wonderfully constructed comic adaptation. Brandon Routh was perfect - there were a couple goosebump moments, like when he did a half smile or a dorky gawk and wave, that made me appreciate the tribute to Christopher Reeve in addition to making me glad that said tribute was not just one long impersonation.The sets were amazing, the action spectacular, and if there had ever been any doubt that Kevin Spacey was the right choice for Lex Luthor, that doubt is now completely groundless. He was brilliant.Lots of edge of your seat moments, plenty of goosebumps (but then again, I'm a comics nerd), awe inspiring landscapes . . . even the kid wasn't annoying! As an action movie, it was perfect. As a retelling that had the potential to go horribly wrong, as an interpretation of one of the most recognized American icons, it was darn close to perfect.

Review Title: I wanted to like it... and maybe I did.

Review: I was 6 years old when the Christopher Reeve movie came out back in the late 70's and I've grown up my entire life with the vision that Mr. Reeve was the face of Superman, when I saw the photos and bit and pieces leading up to "Superman Returns", my biggest problem was being able to accept Brandon Routh as Superman. Well...even though I think Mr. Reeve will always be "Superman" Mr. Routh did an AMAZING job that made me for almost three hours forget that it was supposed to be Christopher Reeve playing Superman. What a movie! The special effects are great and the flying sequences are of course of the most realistic flying scenes you have ever seen. What I liked the most about the picture was the notable respect they had for the original. The same music from the original Superman even the same music when Lois and Superman are on scene. Kevin Spacey is a great Lex Luther and a lot more evil than Gene Hackman. Great movie...absolutely super!

Review Title: I've Been Waiting For A Great Movie
Review: ... wait no longer.Well I don't know if I have the words to do this movie justice. First let me say that generally when there is hype around how successful a movie is going to be, I find that I am terribly disappointed once I've seen the flick. There is always something that disappoints me.Thankfully, Superman Returns delivered, and surpassed on my expectations created by all of the hype! The on screen chemistry between Lois and Clarke aka Kate and Brandon, was storybook and fairytale all wrapped up together with a pretty pink bow. The sultry kiss, the longing glances and the painful goodbyes... well you get the picture.Lex Luthor, or Kevin Spacey.... amazing! He is truly cast himself into one hell of a villain. His hencemen could use some work though... why are these guys always baffoons? The debate as to whether Brandon Routh would portray the role of Superman to the level of his great predecessor Christopher Reeve is certainly put to rest. I'll leave it to you to decide for yourself however Wink I thought that the new Superman suit was a bit, cheesy... the old suit seemed more real to me, but I'm a die hard for a guy in shimmery silk.... boxers or a one piece leotard lol I give this movie 8.5 'doggie cannibals' out of 10.http://www.suggestamovie.com

Review Title: Why We Need Superman?  : Now, More Than Ever! ; Super(b)!

Review: Saw this and thought the movie was highly respectable of the stories and plot lines from previous movies. True fans of Superman and Superman II will think this is a great movie and flows well with the previous ones. III and IV were atrocious as far as the stories are concerned. However, this movie puts Superman back on top with no disrespect to Christopher Reeve. The director is a fan of the early movies as well as versed in the comics and it shows throughout the movie. Better special effects than most, and without tons of computer animation - a lot of face time from the characters to give that realism that the first movies had. Casting was good and soundtrack is great. A thumbs up for this re-make.

Review Title: What can I say?  Superman has Returned!
Review: This movie is probably one of the best films I've seen in a while. All the negative reviews I heard seemed to be erased from my memory as I watched Superman Returns. The length of the film wasn't really that noticeable because I felt that time literally flew by as the movie progressed.Surprisingly, I also found this film very comical. There were a handful of times where I laughed out loud. Superman Returns had everything. Had action, adventure, comedy and romance all put into one movie.Singer did a great job with this film. While some fans of the comics may not enjoy it as much as I did, I felt the film has a lot going for it. Finally, the next generation can grow up with their Superman.Superman Returns - one of the best comic-based films out there. I'm definitely going to see it again.

Review Title: good flick .. not worth a 30 year wait
Review: All in all, the effects and action in Superman Returns were amazing, but few and far between. I prefer an action movie to jump head-first into the eye candy along with a compelling story. But Superman spends a good 40 minutes on back story you've only needed to see the trailer to already be aware of. The majority of the movie focuses on the Lois/Superman love-struggle, which I was never invested in in the first place. I suppose Singer is relying heavily on inheriting much of the pathos generated in the Reeve films. This primary focus causes the film to have few unique characters with little development. I enjoyed the film, but the epic length doesn't match with the basic storyline and two-dimensional characters. You've seen it all before, but through the lens of more primitive film technology. It was not worth the thirty-year wait, and if I never knew who Superman was, it would not be any more exciting of a movie than most DC and Marvel films coming out today.

Review Title: Superman returns is Everything I waited months for - this movie was
Review: Superman returns is Everything I waited months for - this movie was sensational. From the amazing effects, excellent costumes, great classic original music score, and superior storyline. I suggest catching it in IMAX 3-D if you can. It was quite a long movie so take your bathroom break beforehand because you will not want to miss a minute of this film. They did pretty well in condensing movie, however I do wish they had given more detail to the beginnings of his life (like how they did in Batman Returns) :). Brandon Routh did an excellent job portraying his character (as did the rest of the cast), and he looks, speaks, acts, and sounds just like the former superman. This movie will make superman fanatics very happy.

Since, everyone else already pretty much said what I feel about this movie let me just say I was very happy with the way the movie was done. Everyone (the actors and directors etc) kept the feel of the original movies while still managing to give some of their own. Routh and Spacey have kept subtle aspects of the Reeve and Hackman in the way they play the characters without imitating them either.As a kid I loved the original movies but after watching them again as an adult I noticed how much most movies at the time ignored certain aspects of physics that made them look rather unbelievable in some scenes. Not anymore, Superman Returns fixes that.The story was well done, lots of action, and the characters are well acted and developed (as was done in the first 2 X-men--not 2 dimensional like X-Men 3).If I had to find a flaw, I would only say that there was a lack in originality. Much borrowed from the original movies (which were well done as I said) but some scenes were also reminiscent of Spiderman and The Matrix. Fans of the comic books will also find the humour in the small references to the original comics (including the cover of the first issue).In all, I was very pleased to finally have Superman return to the big screen and be directed by Bryan Singer.

Review Title: Why the world needs another Superman...
Review: It was only when Lois started to type the follow up article to her article "Why the world doesn't need Superman" -- "Why the world needs Superman" -- that it hit me why I was so bored. She sits and looks at the screen blank. She doesn't know what to write - because not even Lois can answer why the world needs Superman. After investing 2hrs and 30mins I should be able to answer why the world needs Superman -- because Bryan Singer and team have been convincing me that we do need him. But do we? For me this film fails to live up to the hype because it has nothing new to say. Batman Begins had something new to say about character. XMEN had something of social relevance to say. But what is the underlying point of this Superman film? That if you don't testify in the witness box the person hell bent on world domination will get off and try again at world domination -- there isn't enough to sustain interest here. Especially a 2hr 30min film. It plays like the same old melodrama -- will Lois get with Superman -- will Superman stop the villain -- only with the new twist...is the kid Superman's --?? Of all the different directions this film could have taken, for me, it can't compete with the new offerings of comic book movies. From the guy that brought us XMEN - and XMEN 2 -- this film should have been better -- not just a rehash of the previous films -- and a showcase of new green screen special effects technology. And from what I could see on screen -- those flying background effects -- will not hold up well in the future.The acting was only as good as the material. Kate handled Lois well. But she wasn't suited for the role. She is just too young. Brandon will probably get better as the sequels churn out...Ultimately this movie didn't prove to me that the world needs another Superman. Yes he can push land mass into space - stop a plane from crashing to earth - and go weak at the knees to Kryptonite. But there has to be more to this character. And I didn't see that...at least not today -- hopefully when he returns again...

Superman Returns is magical; a two and a half hour epic adventure with plenty of amazing spectacles, but also packs a lot of heart and emotion to back it up. Bryan Singer pays a great and respectful homage to Richard Donner's 1978 original, and in doing so has also managed to top all of the previous Superman efforts. A large amount of credit has to go to Singer for pulling it all off, but a lot of credit also needs to go to new comer Brandon Routh, who does an absolutely amazing job in the title role. And if you ask me I'd say he does a much better job than any other previous actor who has played the role, and yes, that also includes Christopher Reeve. Routh plays his Clark Kent with a slight touch of klutziness, but it's the kind of klutziness that you know when your watching him it's all for show, it's not just him being a dummy. With Reeve's portrayal it was harder to tell if it was just good acting, or just an amateurish performance. Routh, who does look an awful lot like Reeve, does the Man of Steel justice by giving Superman a strong backbone and tries his best to fit in, but ultimately will always be looking through the window from the outside. There's a great presence about him, that much like Hugh Jackman in 2000's X-Men, just makes you go, "Damn, they really picked the right guy."Singer's directorial skills and previous experience with comic book films and Routh's performance isn't the only thing that Superman Returns has going for it. Kevin Spacey's portrayal of Lex Luthor is also another nice gem. He's so devilishly diabolical and mean. You can't help but hate him, but at the same time you just love him for it. And I think you can tell he's channeling the essence of Gene Hackman's performance in this film. Kate Bosworth also does a fine job as Lois Lane. I enjoyed her a lot more than Margot Kidder's loopy performance, but Bosworth really has some depth and strength that makes her character really work so well. And James Marsden aka "Cyclops" for those of you who don't know plays Lane's husband, Richard White. I loved the little love triangle between Lois, Richard and Superman throughout the film, it added just the right amount of heart and emotional depth to the big scale excitement.Right from the start the film hit me in the heart, with its amazing opening credits and blaring music; which was a great tribute to the original film. Thankfully Singer is a great director, and knows that if it isn't broke don't try and fix it. I'm glad that they were able to tie in John Williams' original theme (which I can't get out of my head as I write this, and I don't much want to either) as well as a little bit of Marlon Brando's performance, and that last shot of Superman at the end was a great nod to Christopher Reeve as well. I'd be lying if I said I didn't get a little misty eyed throughout the film. What can I say? This film hit me with a case of serious nostalgia like I've never felt before.So what's Superman Returns all about? Well it's about Superman… and his return to Earth, of course! The film isn't a sequel, prequel or remake; its set after 1980's Superman II, and ties into the first two films rather nicely. Their not exactly essential viewing in order to understand the plot of Returns, but I'm sure you could appreciate it more, or make it a little easier to follow if you saw the first two films. Superman returns to Earth after a mysterious absence of five years to find that the world might not need him. Well, at least that's the way Lois Lane sees things. But Superman shows the world once again that the world does need a savior and that no one's better suited for the job than the Man of Steel. Lex Luthor's back to his usual evil deeds, and he's out to destroy both the U.S. and Superman once and for all!Superman Returns is epic storytelling with grand spectacles and heart-felt emotion running through its veins, not seen since Jackson's King Kong. Singer remains faithful to spirit of the comics, and keeps the tension and suspense going from beginning to end. He doesn't feel the need to make things edgier, or darker, because that just wouldn't be Superman. After having seen what Singer has done on this film and the X-Men movies, I believe he could pretty much do any comic book superhero out there and make it a knockout film. I've always found the character of Superman to be a sign of great inspiration, and an icon to hold in high regard for doing the right thing, and fighting for justice and truth, and I still do. And as a die-hard fan I can say with confidence that I couldn't have ask for anything more than what I got. I can't wait to see what Superman will do next, and with Routh's great performance and Singer pulling out all the stops and pushing things to the max is what makes Superman Returns one of the year's best films. This is why I love going to the movies.

Review Title: For those nostalgic of 1978 Superman movie, not more
Review: In 1978, a ferocious Lex Luthor sought to destroy California to create a real estate boom in the desert. Christopher Reeve, not rippling with muscles, had exhibited confident strength, patriotism, and over-riding concern for his Daily Planet compatriots as he foils the evil plot using super-human prowess.In 2006, we now have more of the same. While filmed and released 30 years apart, the two scripts could have been written side-by-side. As a 2 1/2 hour film, there could have been so much more plot development. Instead, this film stretches out the action scenes to give them a more pregnant but punctuated resolution by the man of steel. Unlike Batman Begins, where viewers were rewarded by the protagonist working through and overcoming his adversities, Superman walks past them and leaves his character "dehumanized."As an "angelic" soldier his patriotism is inspiring, but his muted, nearly dispassionate interaction with others left me feeling that the script was only half-baked. I give this film a 6 because it executed well on the script it was handed, and I hope that a second film in this series is better.

The special effects were very good, Brandon Routh played Superman well, and hats off to Kevin Spacey for his performance as Lex Luthor.As far as the best comic movie villains of all time, however, I still rank them as the following:1.
