This movie is an absolute masterpiece. I was astounded by Brian Singer's vision. Every scene seemed to be well thought out, and well portrayed. This is as close to perfect as a Superman comic fan could ask for. Forget the few that claim that Lois had too much of a roll, or that there was too much romance. Those are the people who want to be bombarded with special effects the entire time, and not have any character development. Every single character was right on the money. I was hesitant to like Brandon Routh, but he inspired me as Supes, and was just as bumbling as Reeve when he was Clark. Parker Posey was ideal as the lovely assistant to Lex. She was hysterical, and dull witted, yet caring in the end. Kevin Spacey was great as Lex. I liked the idea of getting his $$ from the widow. He was diabolical, and brilliant. Jimmy Olsen had a small part, but he was eager and annoying. Perry wasn't expanded on too much, but I enjoyed his performance as well. The one and ONLY thing that i thought was a bit lacking was interaction between Supes, and Lex. They didn't even meet up until the end. That would have bumped it up to a 10 for me. The story was awesome, and the effects were top notch. As a superman comic fan for 20 years, i applaud you Brian Singer ( and all ) for bringing us this wonderful film!

With Batman Begins it was proved that a hobbled comic book film franchise could be resurrected and improved, overshadowing the mediocrity that had preceded it. When Bryan Singer took the reins of Superman Returns, he had a similar job, but a different vision than Christopher Nolan had with Begins: Singer, a reported huge fan of Richard Donner's original Superman, wished to revitalize Superman without ignoring the grand moments of his past, specifically Superman and Superman II. It was a tall order, but his two turns behind the camera of X-Men and X2 proved he had the chops to make it happen, if matched with the right script. The final result is as good as you could imagine, and better than some might expect, as Superman Returns proves to not only be the original Superman's equal, but in some ways outdistances it. It is rare to see a famous character returned to lofty heights so gloriously.Superman Returns opens with Superman (Brandon Routh) having gone missing from Earth for five years. He has sought out the remains of the planet Krypton, with a desire to find out if it was destroyed as thought. Upon returning to his adopted home planet, Superman, and his alter ego, Clark Kent, visits with his mother briefly (portrayed by Eva Marie Saint), and then returns to Metropolis, where he finds things very similar to when he left, with Perry White (Frank Langella) still running the paper, Jimmy Olsen (Sam Huntington) still snapping photographs, and Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth) still in search of the big story. However, time has not been completely kind to the Man of Steel: Lois has moved on, living with Richard White (James Marsden) and now a mother with a son, Jason (Tristan Lake Lebeau).Coincident with Superman's Return is that of Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey), out of prison and hatching a dastardly scheme: he raids Superman's Fortress of Solitude and steals the crystals that power it, with the intention to grow a new land mass that will supplant the United States and allow him to blackmail the world. Superman must now face this threat while trying to deal with the emotional aftermath of his long absence.Superman Returns delivers what you would expect from a comic book adaptation, complete with impressive action sequences, stunning visual effects, and some nice, sly humor at times. However, what is sometimes missing in other films is very much in place here: a strong emotional undercurrent, a respect for character and a moving romantic element. Superman Returns takes what was good about the original Superman and invests it with more depth and allows Superman to meet a challenge greater than any evil plot: the emotional fallout of losing that which is so dear to him, Lois Lane. Superman II investigated the love of Superman and Lois when they were together, here it is the longing when the one you love has moved on.Singer, with screenwriters Dan Harris and Michael Dougherty, have also stepped up the character of Lex Luthor significantly. Gene Hackman's performance as Luthor was a great treat, but the Luthor in Superman Returns is a much more worthy villain. Lex has been away in prison for years, and the resentment has festered, along with his still grand desire for power. This is an evil, dirty Luthor, who still quips off a one-liner or two, but has a lot more menace than he ever did before. Spacey delivers the role excellently, with the perfect sardonic, sarcastic tone when necessary, giving way to pure venom and hatred as appropriate.It is obvious throughout Superman Returns that Bryan Singer holds a strong reverence for Richard Donner's original. The film, in many ways, is almost something of a remake of Superman, hitting many of the same story beats, and in doing so the film proves to be very much of a piece with 1978 classic and it's sequel. Between familiar lines restated, and character motivations that match the earlier films, Singer boldly states his love of that original film and how much he is ensuring not to tarnish it.The big question that has to be asked is: Is Brandon Routh up to filling the red boots and blue tights? The answer is an unequivocal yes. He slips effortlessly into the part, embodying Christopher Reeve's original take so masterfully as to be almost unnoticed. He performance is spot on perfect, and he has the role for as long as he wants to keep it. Bosworth offers a somewhat different take on Lois than Margot Kidder, but not a poor one. She is still the crusading reporter, but now holding in a certain amount of resentment and heartbreak that give her character some new shadings.Another strength of Superman is the skillful blending of John Williams' original themes from Superman with new score by composer John Ottman. Unlike X2, where he chose to retain none of Michael Kamen's music from X-Men, Ottman is aware of the classic status of what he is dealing with, and shows appropriate respect and deference. The film's visual effects are also impressive, giving you a great sense of the wonder of Superman flying. Singer has used the effects to stage some great sequences, such as when Superman saves a plane in danger, but it doesn't just use spectacle for spectacle sake, there is meat to the attractive bones here.All that being said, Superman Returns isn't perfect. The first segment of the film bogs down a little bit, there are some plot holes that aren't appropriately plugged and Frank Langella is miscast as Perry White (he is a little too gruff as the Daily Planet editor). But aside from that, Superman Returns is as close to a masterstroke in comic book films as you get. This is one that is truly worth the title Superman.

Review Title: Best superhero movie of all time

Review: NO SPOILERS:: I went to watch this movie Tuesday night at IMAX 3D with mixed emotions. Review Title: Superman Returns very good, but in the end, not SUPER.
Review: I went into Superman Returns trying to keep low expectations, but I wanted to get excited. I had heard some of the plot lines (which I will NOT reveal here), and was mostly unimpressed, but thought Singer worked it out, although not spectacularly. I was not even that impressed by the effects. I was put off right away even by the opening credits, which felt a bit cheesy to me. The pace was very slow, and even so, the movie lacked depth in some areas that I feel were missed opportunities.There are opportunities to hear what is on Superman's mind, and he is basically reduced to one line of dialog. I think that is what is really missing here - there was no depth in the dialog for Superman. Lois has a bit, but it's not enough. Lex steals the show speaking wise (why not when you have Kevin Spacey), but in the end, I found this long plodding movie somehow lacking.

This was a very different Superman experience than I was expecting. There has been a lot of differing opinions both good and bad concerning this movie with obvious note given to this movie being so rooted in the original Richard Donner/Christopher Reeves movie. While this movie presented me with a nice assortment of action and save the day scenes, I would describe it as a human interest story about a troubled Superman searching for answers and trying to find his place. Bryan Singer of the X-Men movie fame has done a wonderful job of combining these concepts into the new Superman Returns.This is very much a story about Superman/Clark Kent (and I must say that Brandon Routh delivers a pleasantly and well crafted interpretation of the original Christopher Reeve style and performances from the Richard Donner movie).It opens as Superman has returned to Earth following a five-year absence This movie is more polished and correctly cut than the original that it continues with this new story line. This movie is obviously designed to emulate the original but has a nice combination of old 40's mixed with current look and feel appearances creating a much better look and is very believable. I found the production art work effective creating this nostalgic atmosphere that drew me into the whole feel of the comic book superman story. This was not campy or comical, it was charming and delightful. As I moved through the characters (and Singer does a nice job of carefully introducing the characters) I actually started to care. This movie is softer and more respective of how we are introduced to the feelings each character is struggling with. Now I will say that some characters are there to only support what is going on with the main characters and you don't get much out of them, but it doesn't really matter, the real focus is the main characters. That works reasonable well.Singer's decision to reuse the original John Williams' classic theme music from the original works rather well since it has been re-tooled and freshened up with a new arrangement. I was kind of taken back with a delighted sense of remembrance of when I first saw the original movie. Marlon Brando's original performance from the original movie is used sparingly and to appropriate use tin order to recreate the Jor-El father of Kal-El (Superman's real name). For people who remember, this will be a nice treat. For people that do not care, there is no distraction…it really works with or without your foreknowledge.Lex Luthor (played by Kevin Spacey) is back again having been released from jail on apparent technicalities. Many were afraid, as I was that this would revisit the campy and comical, but well played performance of Gene Hackman. It doesn't. Spacey is cold, smooth, insane and full of his own self-worth and alleged genius, but he delivers a nice wicked interpretation of Lex. This worked for me. I wanted a more established super villain as was created in the DC Comics where he was a multi-billionaire of vast corporate criminal schemes working behind the scenes. But this is clearly a tribute to the vision Richard Donner created for Lex Luther in the original movie. This as well also worked for me, because Bryan Singer leads you into his vision and carefully prepares the story to help you get caught up it this way.The Story is simple but never boring. The action is not driving, wall to wall demonstrations put there to fill space with action for thrill junkies. The action and special effects are there to support and tell the story and belong. It is filled with exciting scenes and amazing special effects, but I liked the fact that the special effects and action were not the stars of the movie, but that Superman and the main characters were.By the time the two and half hours were up, I said wow that went fast. I was not worn out. This is an uplifting and memorable film that will appeal to men and women alike. It is smart and emotional as well as fun and full of super heroic action.I would have liked a fresh and original take on Superman more closely related to the current exploits in DC comics today (there are several really amazing story lines) but this continuation of the Richard Donner Superman series is well done, nicely updated and true to the spirit that Christopher Reeves and Richard Donner created in that version. I enjoyed this movie surprisingly well. You will find it infectious and easy to be sucked into the story. I found it fairly easy to suspend disbelief during the film and enjoy Bryan Singers nostalgic trip into the Richard Donner Superman series with what really appears to be Superman III (you have to forget the original 3rd and 4th movies ever were made, which is not hard to do). Don't be scared away by the nay Sayers, this on is fun and worth seeing.

Review Title: Bad reviews for a Great movie...
Review: Before going to see this film I read about a half dozen reviews, all of which cast the film in a negative light. I had long worried that this film (as many late sequels tend to) would just add another bad story to one of the great iconic characters of our time (see Superman 3 and 4 for examples of what I mean). The reviews had told me that the movie started slow.. and after the opening credits were over, I began to agree.. for about 5 minutes.Before I give my actual opinion let me make it clear what type of person is giving it. I do NOT own any Superman items of any sort, I do not collect Superman comics or sit around watching Superman movies all the time (though I am a Smallville Fan). Furthermore I am an individual who almost never chooses a favorite... nothing to me is ever the 'best' or 'worst'.. merely good or bad. I am however an avid reader and movie goer with a fairly huge appreciation for good stories.Having established that, let me state plainly that this may be one of the best films I have ever seen in my life.This is a long movie...I will admit that after two hours had passed I began to look at my watch, but not because I was eager for the movie to end, because I wanted to know how much more of this film I had before me to enjoy.Everything about this film came together beautifully, the story, the writing, the acting, the effects, the editing, the direction, the continuity with the other films... I couldn't find anything truly wrong with it. Okay well.. I can always find SOMETHING to complain about and if I had to pick something in this film it would be that they don't spend much time on what Supes found or did while he was gone for a few years (maybe we can look forward to some deleted scenes on the DVD?).This movie has it all, for everybody. The action is amazing, the special effects are used with amazing fluidity, the love story is tragic and believable (once you buy in to the idea of a god like alien in the guise of a superhero in red underwear), the plot twists are just predictable enough to be easily accepted without being obvious and insulting to your intelligence... I could go on forever saying good things about this movie.Suffice it to say that I will be seeing it more than once in theaters and will DEFINITELY be buying it on DVD.

Review Title: One of the best but not quite the best!
Review: This was a very good superhero movie. I would say that it is one of the best behind Batman, Superman, X2 and Spiderman 2. Brandon Routh does a great job as Superman but not quite the bumbling Clark Kent that Christopher Reeve was. I think that Kate Bosworth was decent although a bit young looking as Lois Lane. I really liked James Marsden as Richard White and I thought that Kevin Spacey did a good job as Lex Luthor. It would have been nice to see even more of Lex. I also wish that they would have told more of why Superman left and what he was doing. I enjoyed the special effects as well as the touching twist at the end. Overall, an enjoyable superhero movie that should be spawning some sequels.

So, I went into this movie not really expecting much as the trailers didn't look that good. I'd say all in all it was a decently entertaining movie, worth watching if you have nothing else to do, but clearly not on par with Batman Begins or Spider-man. Unlike the other two, it just didn't have the same superhero feel. Bryan Singer tried to give Superman more of a human touch by making him more vulnerable, which is all well-and-good, but in doing so, he took away the things which makes a superhero movie fun in the first place......Anyways, I'd say it's worth watching in the theater just cause it's a Superman movie, but if that's not really a big deal for you, I'd wait for the rental.....

Review Title: Superman sequel or 3 hr film of recycled film.
Review: In my opinion the best part of this film was Marlon Brando's voice overs. Wait for DVD... this film is too long, to slow and its nothing you have not seen before. Brandon Routh was a nice pick but other that there is not much here for people who like good movies. This comment however is coming from a fan of Fassbinder, Michael Haneke's work. If you can stomach a film for the masses this film is right up your alley. Want to see a good movie go watch Dunstin Checks In. Thats a classy Story. A monkey and a boy causing crazy antics and making trouble. You have to love it. I know I do. So thats my review watch dustin checks in, not superman returns.

Review Title: "Superman Returns" is a Super Maniac Movie!
Review: Brian Signer's "Superman Returns" contains Gothic Elements in relation to the Seven Deadly Sins, High/overwrought Emotions, Storms, Death, Women threatened by a powerful and impulsive male, Supernatural events, Atmosphere of mystery and suspense, The outcast, Powerful Love, Madness, and finally the woman that is in distress.At the beginning of the movie we get to learn how Lex comes across his money. His betrayal to an old lady put the cash in his hand. Her castle and assets now belong to Lex. The first Gothic element that is seen is the Castle. This castle has Gothic architecture - including the ceilings, outside build of the castle, and finally where it is situated on the land. This dark and gloomy place is where Lex performs his first's experiments to wipe out North America.Upon view this movie I have noted that the opening scene is to be set in the 1960's. This evident due to the traffic cars and lifestyle. However, a boy is seen taking a picture of Superman with a camera phone.The Seven Deadly Sins in this movie were evident, however, only a few appeared to be actually in relation to this film. Lex Luthor as we know is avarice and has had this trait since the comic was started many years ago, in noting that he also has Pride, Anger, and is Sloth like. Lex's result in the movie is when he ends up stranded on the island to which he wanted to create - with no gas and that non omniscient woman he is always with. Lust was evident with Superman and Lois Lane, although this lust has always been there between the two of them it was the fact that we became more sentient to this. The result of this in the movie was that Lois once again was left alone. Envy was seen by the city people who Superman promptly saved when there was a problem - there was no result to this.Although this writer has never saw a Signer film before, I must say that his way of portraying Lex was extremely well done! Signer made Lex the perfect impulsive male. Lex has always been the manipulator in this series. His actions justified it so. Lex's role is like the juxtaposition where Hell and Earth meet.As we all know that the woman in distress is always going to be Lois Lane. It seems no matter where she is she just has bad luck. Superman conveniently is seen dashing in to save his damsel.You are probably thinking - "Who is the outcast"? Well, near the end of the movie there is literature left for us to believe that Lois' son is indeed that of Clark's as well. This child has no friends and probably never will. This is our outcast. Living his life to it fullest potential will be his goal and to be like Superman is what this boy desires.The only thing that I found about this movie that I really did not care for was the fact that the director did not seem to "run out of tape" - if you will. This movie was extensively long. Multiple times when I thought that the movie had ended it however, did not.All in all, if all of the elements above appear to you as something that is of interest - I strongly recommended viewing this movie. The writers and director of this film did a marvelous job!! If you honestly do not like comics or reading, you can still view this movie without difficulty in comprehending the events throughout this film.BRAVO BRIAN SIGNER!!! My sourcing: I recently completed a Gothic Literature course. This course and being analytical is what has created this review. Hopefully, my thoughts and knowledge have encouraged you to view this film.Note: This work was not cited from any other URL.

Ever since I was a kid, and I used to watch a beat up old copy of Superman 2 we had lying around the house, I've been a huge fan of the comic book-come-myth of the Man of Steel. Quoting lines from the first and second films became part of a daily routine. Certain series like 'Smallville' and 'Lois & Clark' kept the fans' flame warm for a long time, but over 20 years after we had a decent Superman movie, the expectations were set inexorably higher than what is expected from films in general these days, making the cast and crew's job even more difficult. Given these insurmountable tasks, and having set my standards quite high myself, I am glad to say that Singer has delivered (as he has many times in the past) a high-quality production. Especially from a directorial standpoint, Singer's work shines. A short description here would be far too inefficient to imagine the kind of mastery involved to make movies of this magnitude, but his attention to detail, innovation, and ability to coax the best from his actor's and crew, certainly increases my appreciation for this work and all his other endeavors. Cinematography was masterful, and special effects otherworldly... that having been said, I had a few misgivings about the film after my initial viewing. Filling the shoes of Academy Award Winner Gene Hackman seems a daunting enough task, but trying to create a character as likable yet devious as the original Lex Luthor, has proved nigh impossible. Though Spacey, a strong and thorough actor, has proved himself many times over, I felt his interpretation of Lex was a little over the top. He just seemed like a crazy cynic, bent on destroying everyone, with neither reason nor motive. His so-called "support", Kal Penn and Parker Posey, among others, did little for the film whatsoever, and deserved little if any credit (I was surprised to see their named displayed so prominently in the opening credits). Likewise, Frank Langella, a veteran in the film world, did little to reprise the role of Perry White, an important and quirky (for lack of a better word) character in the story. On the other hand, luckily, Routh and Bosworth both pulled through in their roles. Nothing too dynamic, but Routh did a great job emulating the geekiness and uncertainty of the Kent character, and simultaneously showing us (mostly through bulk and posture) the confident and invincible character of Superman. Bosworth, through certain subtleties was able to communicate Lois' fragility, masked by feelings of self-importance and strength, that she characteristically tends to show, (luckily, she ain't so hard on the eyes either). Overall, I wonderful film that I would recommend to all. Enjoyable on all levels, for all ages (which is always good for gross), and definitely, merits a second viewing. Though the memories of Reeve, Hackman and Kidder will forever live on, Singer's production pays homage to the original films, and carries forth the legend with competence, integrity and ingenuity. From an old fan, 8 of out 10 stars. - NV

Review Title: Superman is back in one of the best superhero movies ever.
Review: A message to all Super-Fans: this is one you do not want to miss. Superman has truly returned, and with him he has brought the hopes, fears and challenges of a new generation. Brandon Routh is superb as Superman and Clark Kent, lending an easy air of nobility to Superman, and affecting a Reeve-ian approach to Clark Kent- gentle and clumsy. Indeed, Chris Reeve's stamp can be felt in many places in this film. Brian Singer has done a marvelous job of paying homage to the original while branching off in a new direction. Supporting cast are all excellent: Kate Bosworth is better than expected as Lois Lane- steely, spurned and direct, but vulnerable where the script demands it. Kevin Spacey is delightfully evil as Lex Luthor, turning in a hammy performance. James Marsden is a welcome addition as Lois's love interest Richard White in his second superhero film this year, and Frank Langella makes a return to celluloid as Perry White, editor-in-chief of the Daily Planet. We saw the film last night at the AMC Empire in Times Square. Theater experience was just OK- would have been better in digital or IMAX (both were sold out weeks ago). Action sequences were incredible; it's rumored that the film cost almost $300 million, and all of it is up on the screen. The special effects were incredible and highly detailed, the score by John Ottman includes the venerated theme by John Williams and expands on it in a bombastic, powerful score. Opening credit sequence is a delight to watch, and the film is dedicated to Chris and Dana Reeve. If you're still reading this, stop what you're doing and go see it!!!!!

Review Title: Superman didn't need to return if this is the result
Super great for everyone who has seen and enjoyed the previous Superman movies, and GREAT for who hasn't
Review: After a long wait, I finally get to see the Superman Returns. I don't think I need to tell you the main plot here, you can see it for yourself.Let me break my comment down in two categories: First, to anyone who has seen previous Superman films, this movie is a very nolstalgic movie, especially to anyone who grew up in those years. The first Superman movie I saw was Superman IV: The Quest for Peace (1987). Well as a 7 years old kid, that movie completely blew me away. I mean, before the movie I knew Superman from the comic only and to see him to fly in action was out of this world. Anyhow, I finally got to see the other Superman movies and I can honestly agree that the first and second one were much better than the rest, but the fourth one with Nuclear Man was still like my first love.Well, let's get back to the Superman Returns, I said that it's super great since it retains the universe that was left in the first and second Superman and also the story continuity. It still has the same Daily Planet office (albeit with computers and plasma TVs, instead of just typewriters). The Metropolis feels like Metropolis we knew before. Even the clothes of the characters are still somewhat in a similar era of the first and second Superman. Ow yeah and the cars, I know it's a bit strange, but when I saw the movie I got the feeling that the cars are in the same time period of the previous Superman. I mean, I didn't see any modernly pimped out cars or any hybrid SUV's around, which didn't exist back in late 1970's-1980's. The cars look... classic, I guess, although I did recognise some obvious modern cars. I think Bryan Singer and the rest of the production crews had done a wonderful job in retaining the Superman we knew.Second, to anyone who has not seen previous Superman films, this movie is an excellent summer blockbuster movie. The visual effect is first rate. This means that the effect is enough to awe viewers without trying to be over the top and too out of this world. It has also something to do with the plot where the writers did such a great job. Without giving out anything, any new Superman viewer will be able to understand the story without watching the other Superman movies, but I recommend you to see the others (just the one and two only!). Everyone knows that Superman is a saviour, well in this movie he is one, too. But the threat to the world is enough to give him trouble, without being too silly, which is in conjunction with what I said about the visual effect.The actors were great. The cast selection was amazing. Brandon Routh is the new Superman for the new generation. He did a great job, as good as how Christian Bale delivered the new Batman in Batman Begins. Kevin Spacey is always ever a great actor. Parker Posey gave an enough presence without being too shiny, which is enough for her role. James Marsden did a great job, although I still portrayed him as the Cyclops from X-Men. Frank Langella was perfect as Perry White, although I was very excited to hear Hugh Laurie was the first choice. I guess it's cool to see the mad doctor House yells at a bunch of reporters to get news of Superman. Kate Bosworth, I love her. She's great. Every time I heard her name, it always reminded me of Blue Crush and her cute surfer chick character. But now... Kate Bosworth equals Superman Returns. One complaint though, I think the costume department should have given her a smaller outfit. I mean her clothes is fit, but there were some scenes, especially the outdoor ones, when she wears jacket and the jacket seems to be too large. I don't know, it's just my opinion though.But this film is not without any flaw. I find the length is a bit too long. I had to run out to pee, which I don't normally do. I don't really know why I complain about the length, because normally it's never enough for me. However, there were moments that I want to skip some part and get to the action. I guess all I wanted was more action for the Superman.So go and see it. It kicks ass. Ow yeah, make sure you enjoy the greatness of Panavision Genesis HD. I am gonna see Superman Returns again in IMAX.

Review Title: This review is dedicated to Christopher Reeve.* * * * *
Review: "Superman IV:The Quest for Peace" was a bomb back in 1987.The first two films were amazingly outstanding.But when it got to the third installment,there was nowhere for the film to go.It seemed that the "Superman" franchise was dead.Now after nearly two decades of going through "Batman","Spider-Man" and "X-Men",it seems that the franchise has returned.And thanks to director Bryan Singer,the franchise has returned with an explosive bang.This film is true at what it sets out to do.It reminds us ,or let us say,it reminded me of my childhood when I was watching 1978s "Superman:The Movie".The visual effects are better although I still prefer the flying effects in the 1978 version.In that version,you knew that Christopher Reeve was in front of a screen with background images with a specially designed camera that moved around him.In"Superman Returns",the technology has risen to a point to which we actually believe he could fly.Both films are as entertaining as the next.Brandon Routhe is incredible as Clark Kent and Superman.Watching the film,I could not help but notice how much of that Christopher Reeve Personality was in him.I am 34.I felt like a 6 year old watching the film."Superman Returns" flies high but at the same time it tries not to outdo the first two films.Watching both "Superman III"-"IV" sadly lacked what "Superman Returns" brought back.The humor is a crucial point to the film.I may be out of hand,but in my opinion,"Superman Returns" may be the best film of 2006.Brandon Routhe is the correct choice for the two roles that he plays.As Superman,he is truly one of the best actors to play the character.I thought I was looking at Christopher Reeve's twin.With Brandon Routhe donning the tights and Bryan Singer directing the sequels-hopefully-it would be interesting to see how far this series could go.With this film,I was convinced and I was happy."Superman Returns" is the most entertaining film of 2006.

Review Title: Who's the real hero: Superman or Singer?
Review: I haven't posted a comment in sometime, but after having watched Superman Returns opening night, I feel compelled.I admit I had my reservations upon reading the cast and seeing publicity photos. Being a big fan of the original, I wasn't convinced how it would measure up. But I also had faith in Bryan Singer's talent.I have to say this movie seemed to deliver on just about every level. It will appeal to almost any audience; fan's of the original, comic book fanboys (such as myself), and those young one's experiencing the spirit of the Man of Steel for the first time. My biggest reservation going into this was the cast. Let's face it, there will NEVER be another Christopher Reeve. But if Reeve was ever given an intern, the result would definitely be Brandon Routh and his performance. Routh seemed to capture the essence of the character throughout the majority of the movie. There were times his look resembled Reeve, and even times where his voice seemed eerily the same! Kate Bosworth didn't sell me on the character of Lois until the second half of the movie, but I was rooting for her by the end. Lex Luthor was a tough part to cast, and Kevin Spacey did a fine job, as did the rest of the supporting cast. The real hero here is Bryan Singer. This man is quickly becoming one of my fave directors. I know he won't be stuck solely in this genre, but I have to say the man has the heart of a true comic fan. After seeing the film, I'm not as upset at him for leaving X-3. He made a sequel all this time later in a manner that fits very well. The story, the look, the effects, the characters, the sets, and most of all...the heart in this movie all come together to make it a wonderful experience. I am truly relieved that he was able to successfully breath new life into a franchise that was much needed (much the same way the Batman Begins prequel was able to do). Like King Kong and Peter Jackson did in the winter, I was reminded of what a great experience going to the theater can be. This is what summertime at the movies is all about!

It was fantastic. I had a stupid grin on my face from the opening credits to the heartwarming dedication to Christopher and Dana Reeves at the end. Hearing John Williams' theme song sent chills down my spine! I didn't know if Bryan Singer would keep the original theme, but really, in retrospect, how could he not? The film was entirely respectful to the original films, yet he added new elements which I think will take the franchise far.Brandon Routh was stunning and perfectly cast. There were moments in the film when I thought I could see a bit of Christopher Reeves' spirit shining through Brandon's smile and gestures. The similarities were striking and a little eerie.Kevin Spacey ROCKED!!! I wasn't sure about Kate Bosworth playing Lois, but her chemistry with Brandon convinced me.All in all, a wonderful movie and I look forward to seeing it in IMAX!!

Review Title: Superman Returns Didn't Fly With Me
Review: You know, I can't bash Superman for what it is. It was a good story, the script could have been a little better. The actors were OK, except for Lois who seemed completely whiney through the whole movie, and Rouch just didn't have enough life in his character. I mean, he seemed a little mum through-out the whole movie. But altogether, I thought it was OK. Here's my problem, Bryan Singer. Just like in X-Men, He spends 2 hours trying to make you feel for the characters and spends only 30 minutes on action. THIS MOVIE NEEDED MORE ACTION TO IT! oh no, Lex stole a crystal, threw it in the ocean, and plans to take over the world, that's the best script they can come up with in 15 years? I don't know, I'm tired of paying good money and having my legends of my youth bashed by a director who wants me to feel the love between his characters. This is Superman not The Notebook. Seriously, maybe they need a gung-ho straight male to direct the next one, cause I need more action. P.S., the kid was a retarded idea.

Review Title: Bryan Singer Stay away from My Comic Book Heroes
Review: Despite all the money spent ($204 million) and the hype, Superman Returns, is unfortunately a big disappointment. The special effects are spectacular: Superman looks great flying around, better than we have ever seen him before (although I'm not sure about changing the colors of his suit). Too bad the plot and the characters suffer.The evil genius Lex Luther is downgraded to a mere con-artist who's diabolical scheme is, once you think about it, stupid and pointless. Despite having proved himself to be a supremely evil mastermind, Lex is out and free in the world (the explanation for how this occurs is, to put it lightly, lame). More attention is payed to Lois Lane and her life in this movie then ever before, yet I never grew close to Lois' character. She comes across as very 2 dimensional, essentially a flat character. There should be a massive struggle going on for Lois, but we're treated only to rare glimpses of this internal angst.As for Superman... well unfortunately the director and writers decided to focus largely on the first two Superman movies. Brandon Routh brings little to the Superman character that is different from what Christopher Reeves brought. Herein lies the mistake. Reeves was innovative in his approach to the role, especially what he did with "Clark," (the slumped shoulders, bumbling and clumsy manner). Routhe has admitted he greatly admires what Reeves did with the character, and its obvious to viewers that both Routhe and Singer (director) are doing their best to emulate Reeves' portrayal. The final product is just that, an attempt to copy Reeves that ultimately leaves you only wanting the original. Routhe's decision to change little is, however, not the worst blow to the Superman character.In "Superman Returns," Singer and the writers make the decision to focus on one of the worst parts of the original Superman movies---Superman's decision to sleep with Lois and then erase her memory afterwards. This kind of action is extremely out of character for Superman and never should have been done in the first place (I blame lazy writers). I mean, you can't just sleep with someone you're in love with and who's in love with you, and then just erase their memory afterwards without their knowledge or consent. That's just un-Supermanesque and should have been ignored in the later movies. Instead Singer and co decide to build on this week storyline. What we get in "Superman Returns" is a Superman character who acts very... normal (even petty)in his ongoing relationship with Lois.The end result of the director's over-focus on the original Superman movies is that there is little of anything that is new in this movie. Five movies later and Superman is still fighting Lex Luther... a man you would think the world authorities would be able to put away forever without Superman's help. Batman not only takes out criminals of the same magnitude as Superman does, but he does so with finality. It's obviously time for a new villain for Superman to face, but Singer offers up only a repeat of the past. Bottom line: don't expect anything new or original.

Review Title: An Amazing Film with 1 or 2 Exceptions
Review: In two words, "Loved it". From the clever handling of the Superman character (a character that, for all intents and purposes, must be the hardest superhero character to tackling) to the ingenious tie ins with the first two films (this film is technically the new Superman 3) all down to the surprisingly amazing performance of Kate Bosworth (who knew?). The visuals and photography are amazing. Kate Bosworth, Kevin Spacey, Parker Posey, and James Marsden are all incredible in the film. My only real complaint would be the performance of Brandon Routh. While his Clark Kent had moments of acting genius, his Superman left me lacking. He felt very disconnected to the character through most of it and his experience (or lack thereof) definitely showed through when put next to the aforementioned performances. Unfortunately, his best acting moments were when he stopped talking, or making facial gestures of any kind, and just flew around and did his thing. Many of you will say, "Well, that's the point" My response to that is, "Then couldn't any of us been Superman in this film and done just as well." That aside, still an incredible movie and I was completely blown away by it. Definitely a must see.

Review Title: The Whole Was Not Greater then the Sum of It's Parts
Review: Okay, so Superman (the first movie) is probably one of my favorite films of all time. So this film almost slavishly tried to recreate the feeling of the first movie, but to paraphrase Max Bialystock from "The original version of "The Producers"How could this happen? I was so careful. I picked the right movie, the right director, the right cast. Where did I go wrong?Well, first of all, yes Singer picked all the right things, but for some reason, the entire film never gels. You go "Gosh wow!" where you're supposed to, but those moments pass. Brandon Routh was wonderful as the Man of Steel, and had he been given the sort of script Chris Reeve was give, I have no doubt he could have carried it off as well. However, there was no taking off the glasses and saying: "Lois, I have something to tell you." There was no earth-shaking scream when he realizes Lois is dead, and There is no screw you Jorel when he goes back in time to undo her death. There is: "You have something of mine." How original.....NOT. Kevin Spacey I had no doubts about. He did not fail my high expectations. As good as Gene Hackman in his own way. Parker Posey is no Valery Perrine. Kate Bosworth? Well, not to shabby, but did take some getting used to. But she was still, to crib a line from "Lois and Clarke" "Galactically stupid". So, it works like this. If you want to enjoy lots of expensive special effects, by all means, see this movie. Otherwise, rent the first of the Donner versions.

Review Title: Good but not great (relatively spoiler free)
Review: This, of course, had the potential to either be one of the greatest, most inspiring movies ever or the horrendous destruction of an iconic character. Well, it was neither.To those who can religiously quote the 1978 Donner version, prepare yourselves for Superman the Movie Part Deux. From plot line to dialog, this is a remake of that original gem. Sure, different locations and motivations in some cases, but it is basically a newer, occasionally prettier version. For those who have a pedestrian memory of the original, prepare to be wowed. The movie is gorgeous and exciting, and it generated hearty applause at the end.Personally, I fit into the former of these 2 groups. I was not blown away by this movie except for Brandon Routh, who more than filled Christopher Reeve's red boots while, sadly, speaking far-too-few lines. He is exceptional as The Man of Steel. I didn't for one second buy Kate Bosworth's Lois Lane. Margot Kidder's gruff portrayal was infinitely more convincing and enjoyable. I would say the same for Lex Luthor. Spacey is a tremendous actor and his subtleties are what sets him apart from most, but he is nowhere near as good as Hackman. However, his shortcoming is due less to his own performance and more to the somewhat neutered role that he was portraying.Like I said, the movie is good but not great, but I expect that it will do tremendous business. I hope they amp up the action in the sequel and either make Lex a more worthy adversary or find someone who is...

I saw it last night. I can't stop thinking about it. I grew up with Superman, and now that I'm a young adult,I had practically forgotten how much I loved it. After seeing this, I feel like a five-year-old again! I thought it was extremely well done, and I'm not sure why so many critics don't' like it. I think it's the best of the entire series! Lex Luthor is extremely well played, and after a few minutes of watching the movie, I didn't feel as though I was watching a different movie from the originals. I felt right at home with all the characters. My one problem with the movie is that the originals took place in the 70's/80's (based off of the technology/fashions of the time), and this one seems to take place in the present. my problem is that Lois Lane looks younger than she does in the originals! How old is she?!? Other than that, I thought it was a solid movie.

First, a rant about 3-D movies. Let me say that I didn't mean to reserve tickets for a 3-D showing. I wanted to see Superman on the IMAX screen and didn't realize that the IMAX version was also a 3-D version. I find 3-D movie screenings really annoying. It makes sense that people in the 50s were into them because technology was so peachy-keen back then--people would try anything as long as it was new and cool. But high technology, to me at least, is a little more routine these days, so I want my high tech gadgets to have real impact. At the very least, the impact should far outweigh the inconvenience or sheer corniness. 3-D movies don't make the cut, as far as I'm concerned. Those disposable plastic glasses are uncomfortable--they cut into the bridge of my nose--plus, they don't fit well over my own glasses. Not only that but, hello, DISPOSABLE? In 2006, should we really be finding new plastic crap that we use for 2 hours and then dump in a landfill where they'll last for hundreds of years? Not the best use of precious petroleum, in my opinion. OK, so that's little picture suddenly becoming very big picture (no IMAX or 3-D puns intended). Also, there's something undeniably campy about 200 people all putting on their 3-D glasses at once when they see the little flashing signal on screen--which, I guess, could be either fun or annoying, or both. Add to that the fact that the 3-D effect made scenes with rapid action difficult to focus on, and you begin to see the problem. I would MUCH rather have seen the movie on a big huge screen with really loud surround sound. So, if given the option, DON'T see this film on 3-D--at least, that's my vote.But do see the movie. Superman Returns is exactly that, the return of a movie franchise that's fun for the whole family. Brandon Routh and Kate Bosworth are easy on the eyes, the special effects are quite good, and the Christian overtones are pretty overt and actually contribute just a little bit of moral heft to the picture, which I think I liked. Moreover, I think the movie avoided some of the production decisions that made the 1978 film age about 3 decades in 3 years.But I've determined that there is a first rule for making a comic book superhero movie. Somewhere down the list of rules, there are commandments like: have good special effects, get a John Williams score or something like one, get a hunky but wholesome male lead, get a lovely female lead, include a dog, call the city something else but let everyone know that it's really New York (even if you film it in Canada or Australia or wherever), etc. But Rule #1 should be: do whatever it takes, pay whatever is required, but get a top-notch actor to play the villain (a corollary of this rule should be to have only one villain). No offense to Christopher Reeve, but the liveliest moments in the 1978 Superman were scenes starring Gene Hackman. The same goes for Superman Returns. Brandon Routh is fine, but at best he's an "everyman" and at worst he's a cipher--he looks good in the costume, and he doesn't suck at acting Super. But Kevin Spacey is the guy in the movie who can act, and act he does. Spacey's performance here, as in so many other movies, is worth the price of admission. He's coldly sadistic, satirically humorous, brilliantly jaded, and, as Lex Luthor must inevitably be, ultimately bungling. Plus, he looks pretty good with no hair.I think we're in for more Superman movies. Let's hope the new franchise doesn't go the way of the Batman travesty. If the filmmakers remember the rules--especially Rule No. 1--they should be fine.P.S. Just a side note. It's hard to complain about looking at Kate Bosworth on a really big screen for 2 and half hours. The filmmakers knew this, and they included plenty of close-ups of all the film's leads. But she's no Lois Lane. Lois should be pretty and all, but she needs to have an edge to her, and Bosworth is all soft curves--no edges in sight. I'm not sure who should have played Lane, and Bosworth doesn't ruin the movie or anything, but she's just not quite right.

Review Title: You'll believe that a man can etc.
Review: Much better than expected. Superman Returns hits all the right notes and the casting is first rate. I had my doubts about Brandon Routh, but he pulls off the Superman/Clark Kent role and makes it look easy. Kevin Spacey is a better Lex Luthor than Gene Hackman, and Kitty may be Parker Posey's best work yet. Who knew she could act?The Lex Luthor story line is tightly plotted, which gives the Superman/Kent/Lois Lane story line time to develop into something more than you'd expect from a summer action movie. Subtle humor and good writing deliver a movie that doesn't condescend to the audience. Superman Returns blows the forgettable X-Men 3 out of the water. Definitely worth seeing twice.

Review Title: Super Man does indeed return in an almost super way.
Review: The movie was well put together and exceeded my expectations after seeing recent titles that try to adapt from comic books and while the Superman series has a lot more to build on than other comic book titles out nowadays, I was still expecting much more of a hodge podge mix that is so common at present.The story was quite cohesive and the on screen presence of all the actors was quite strong, esp Brandon Routh though at times overshadowed by James Marsden as a counterpart. I esp. liked how James Marsden did not have to project any role of the corny 'evil' counterpart to Clark Kent and instead was more true to life, inspiring even at times. I do think Lex Luthor aka Kevin Spacey could have used a stronger presence on screen which may have been compromised in part by his hapless assistant, who although I realize is supposed to be that way, may take away from his credentials as the man who can take on SuperMan.Additionally, as the viewer you will find many scenes of humanity and emotion overflowing in the movie and it is purely on your sense of perception whether you find them to be relevant and genuine or contradictory and superfluous. It all depends if you hold true to old skool or not i think. I'll let u decide that for yourself.As a final note, whilst I may not have walked away feeling totally inspired or blown away from the movie, altogether, I truly did enjoy it (ie certain scenes either by way of cinematography or cast and direction will not soon be forgotten) and think that this was a great comeback which paid respects where they were due and has set in motion a stage for sequels to come.

Review Title: Superman Should Return to Krypton For Good
Review: People need to realize that just because special effects these days are so incredibly awesome (like in Superman Returns) that it doesn't justify it to be a great movie. Kevin Spacey was the only decent performance in this movie, as his darker comedic portrayal of Lex Luthor versus the goofy Gene Hackman version. The story was so ridiculously bland and boring I found myself laughing at the screen. In fact, the entire theater had burst out into laughter from the Curdled cheese fed to us through a ten dollar admission. The few and far between action sequences..IE: CG, kept my eyes glued to the screen. So all in all if you want to pay ten bucks I'm not going to stop you, just be sure to buy popcorn so that you are distracted enough. Now I have crime to fight, hold on a sec. let me take off my glasses, OK yeah, now let me curl my bangs, good, there now I can fight evil doers..up, up and oh read a book.

Review Title: Worth the Free ticket I had

Review: Thank you Mr. Singer! I must admit, when I went to see Superman Returns, I went with some trepidation. Having enjoyed the X-men trilogy (though, not X-men 3 as much as the previous 2) I was a little concerned about the quality I would find in this latest vision of Superman. Fortunately, and somewhat surprisingly, there was no need for any kind of concern.I can honestly say that this movie is the best movie I have seen so far this year. The story was compelling (I found myself on the edge of my seat repeatedly), the acting was superb (Kevin Spacey was amazing), the characters were believable and extremely empathetic, and most importantly, Brandon Routh, if nothing else, was completely believable as Superman/Kal-el/Clark Kent. Perhaps he was just projecting himself in the blue-suit, or maybe it was just Singers phenomenal directing, but after about 15 minutes of watching the movie, I completely believed that I was watching Superman, not an actor 'playing' superman, as I did when I watched George Clooney 'playing' Batman. Thanks Mr. Singer for casting someone who we could envision as Superman...This movie has made my summer. Seriously, from start to finish I was awash in memories of my childhood, of watching Superman I & II -- this movie provides as seamless a bridge between my childhood, and my adulthood, as fluidly as any movie could.If you see one movie this summer... or even this year... make it Superman Returns, you will not regret it, and you just might be reminded of why we all wanted to 'fly like Superman' when we were children.

I will preface this review by saying that all good and great directors eventually lose their way and make a bad movie. Need proof just look at Steven Spielberg's resume. Bryan Singer has now joined the list."Superman Returns" is a debacle. A dull 2 and half hour, quarter of a billion dollar epic bore.Even the special effects fail to impress. Nothing super or special about them at all.The subplot involving his visit and return from Krypton is so unnecessary it just should have been Completely cut out. It was just a lazy excuse for his disappearance and the first example of poor storytelling.It's something that should have been shown. The audience is cheated out of this supposedly important subplot. It would have added some emotional substance. Visiting his home world for the first time and Impact it would have on his psyche.When in Smallville he barely speaks to his Mother, Martha and makes no attempt to visit Lana Lang.The first time we see Superman in action it is an amalgam of things we've seen before. The flight rescue sequence is a combination of two scenes from the original movie. The rescue of Lois and the helicopter and Air force One. The scene in the new movie is so uninspired it lacks any excitement.It's derivative, unoriginal and pedestrian. Just like everything else about this movie.Lois Lane is one of the problems in the movie. She has a Pulitzer Prize now, still smokes and has managed to retain the looks of a collage age Supermodel. Scenes with Clark and Superman are routine and lack chemistry.Making her a damsel in distress in 2006 is just another example of how the filmmakers just don't seem to care about the characters and story. There is no character development at all. Not that it would make any difference with the hollow ones that We are given. Brandon Routh is doing an impression of Christopher Reeve. This is not acting. It is caricature. It's Shallow…but not his fault since he is following Singer's direction.Lex Luthor is back as the villain, for the fourth time. His big plan this time is near copy of his first plan. It's all about Land. Again. Spacey's Lex is no more dangerous or threatening than Hackman's and he feels like he's imitating also.Parkey Posey's Kitty Character. Just a facsimile of Eve Teschmacher from the original movie.Luthor has speechless henchman. One with a tattoo on the back of his head. It looks silly, not scary.There are so many references to the first movie that it starts becoming less of an homage and begins to feel more like a retread. And like a retreaded tire. This movie flies apart and heads in various directions.It is a choppy and disjointed mess. On All levels. The story as well as the editing. Poor pacing impedes The movie throughout. Not that there is much of a story to hinder.This movie offers nothing new at all. It says nothing new at all. What can you say when the best dialog was written nearly 30 years ago.The flying scenes. Another fraud. Superman just zips back and forth on screen like a blur or is shown as a spec on the screen. He becomes insignificant.The savior subplot. It isn't intelligent or involving. It's dishonest and inane. The "big" surprise in the story can be seem a mile away. Superman seen in a hospital? Just plain bad.The gaps in the story continuity and logic throughout is enough to give any intelligent viewer cause to To roll their eyes. Lois Lane's award winning article is "Why The World Doesn't Need Superman" She seems to have hatred toward him in some scenes. Yet the password on her computer is… "Superman" If you don't want him in your head then why would you want to have a daily reminder of him? The viewer should feel Betrayed. Something of which Singer has a very bad habit of.First leaving the "X-Men" series and then making this drivel. It goes to show that sometimes when the budget is as extraordinarily high as it was on this movie and all creativity and originality disappear.They think we the audience are vulgar and stupid. Why else would they pander to us?Bryan Singer has fallen prey to the machine of Hollywood. No longer caring for the story , characters and certainly not the audience.Instead, he and everyone else involved with this sham has become like Lex. Only interested in his cut.He and his cohorts should be tried, found guilty and banished for all eternity in the Phantom Zone.It won't be Luthor or Kryptonite that does Superman in. It will be word of Mouth and Captain Jack.

Review Title: SUPERMAN RETURNS: One good action scene, dull characters & superb Special FX = a classic Hollywood letdown

Review: He gives us a character to Believe in. He supplies our imagination with a hint of what IS possible. On the giant screen, we all WANT to SEE him DO the impossible. AND you know what, he is so damned easy to root for.In this age of Sinicism and scrutiny in the movies we watch, Superman Returns delivers the goods, period. Brian Singer assembled this compelling story sequence-by-sequence, edit-by-edit. Spiderman 2 is the only other comic book motion picture to come close to suspending my disbelief along with being thoroughly entertaining. Plug in all the clichés that exist. The film is respectful of previous films, the comic books, and even to past actors that have played characters on film and television. And then, there's Brandon Routh. Imagine the pressure placed on his being, to not only play three characters, but also be CONVINCING as "the Man of Steel". Routh's and the Almighty Kevin Spacey's performances nearly made me forget, at times, the astonishing special effects, the length of the movie AND criticisms I have read on which actors should be playing which characters. You know what, What Ever. Whether you are a casual moviegoer, an avid fan of comic books and Superman, or a motion picture mutant, Superman Returns is THE definitive Superhero movie. Go see this motion picture.

I'm sure this film will get a lot of flack for the critics but I was really impressed. Routh was superb as both the Man of Steel and the geeky Clark Kent. Plus his chiseled looks are exactly what Superman should be. Spacey & Posey were terrific as villains. There was a lot of humor, touching scenes which made me cry and the action scenes blew me away! The opening action scene with the plane was enough to have earned the price of admission. This version showed a more human side of Superman. It was nice to see him in his human element as well as his superhero alter-ego.Visual effects were stunning. I hope this franchise will continue! The film was dedicated to Christopher and Dana Reeve which I thought was a touching tribute.

Review Title: Jon Monsarrat review: I was skeptical, but then! Fantastic!
Review: I'm not much of a comic book guy. The X-Men movies have all been a victim of their own ego. The Spiderman movies had too much special effects. I loved the original Superman movie -- but I was a kid. When I saw it Superman 2 recently as an adult, it's really corny.So I was prepared for an unbelievably cheesy Superman movie. I couldn't have been more surprised. Every time there is an opportunity for a melodramatic moment (think E.T., the alien dies not once but twice), or a corny moment (think Indiana Jones 2 when the overly cute and annoying kid saves Indiana Jones -- twice)... the film was understated instead. Yes, somebody finally made a movie in which the kid is not annoying.As a result, all the natural power of the Superman mythos, which is part personal power fantasy and part New Age God Metaphor, is not dragged down and is allowed to, well, fly! In addition, the ending was superb. Superman does not steal the glory entirely -- non-super humans get to help out, too. The special effects are spectacular without dominating the movie. Kevin Spacey, as usual, is fantastic.The only criticism I might make is that they didn't throw out some of the Superman story that's aging (Why does Lex Luther hang around with idiots as henchmen? Why should Kryptonite affect Superman?). And the doomsday scenario they invent is original but does not translate well onto the big screen.However, they do add a few original twists on the old story. Clark Kent's idiotic costume (his glasses) is questioned, we see a little of Superman's father, and the theme of how Superman impacts society and gives us hope and a moral compass is explored. That theme by the way, is still relevant even though Superman is fiction. I feel inspired and you should see this film, too.Who should see this movie:-- Everyone, and do it nowI'll give Superman a not-quite-perfect 9 out of 10.

To start off, I'm going to state that I'm not the hugest Superman fan and haven't read all of the comics. I'd also say that most viewers aren't familiar with the most intricate details of Superman's life, therefore aren't going to nitpick at minor details.I've been reading some of the comments that people have left this movie and most of them are extremely negative. People have been going so low as giving this movie a 2 out 10... NO WAY! If these people were so dissatisfied with the film and they're giving it a 2 out of 10, I'm wondering why they even stayed for the whole showing.THIS IS A GOOD MOVIE! All of these naysayers have been nitpicking with every single detail of the movie when there are a lot of positives. For one, the effects in this movie are fantastic and it's worth seeing this movie just for that. Second, people keep comparing Brandon Routh's performance to that of Christopher Reeves which is also a mistake. I admit that Brandon Routh is no Reeves, but that doesn't mean he gave a terrible performance. Spacey also does a fantastic job playing Lex Luthor and brings charisma and charm to the character. There are certain parts that are just drawn out to long lengths but look past this and appreciate the other parts of the film. This film is of epic proportions and I think it lives up to what it tries to create.

The Superman addicts who have seen every other movie, and know everything about Superman will take more away from this movie then those who don't.First of all, the movie was two and a half hours or so.....In my eyes, the movie was really boring for the first hour....I was thinking of walking out, but since I didn't pay to get in, I said what ever, I'll stay and watch. Eventually the movie picked up and when there were action parts it was a very good movie, but when there wasn't, it was really boring.The plot was a little weird.....I'm assuming the movie was supposed to revolve around Lex Luther trying to build islands out of crystals, but they only followed that for about thirty minutes of the movie. The rest of it was just Superman wandering around saving random people or it was boring character development.The acting was....rusty. They chose a good actor to play the roll of Superman, but there was really no emotion put into the movie by any of the actors. There were no emotional parts so there was no need to have to be a good actor. At times, when people are talking, you can't understand what they're saying which gets annoying after a while.The special effects were alright. The opening, where they do like 10 minutes of wandering through space of special effects were not the greatest I have seen. At times the special effects looked awkward....But other times they were quite well done.Overall, this was an alright movie but it definitely did not live up to the expectations I was expecting for this movie. I doubt I will see it again, because I do not want to sit through the first hour.

First of all the proper title of the film I am reviewing is Superman Returns: An IMAX 3D Experience. I can sum up my experience in one word, WOW! What an awesome, awesome movie. The visuals were top-notch and this was by far the most crystal-clear theatrical film I have ever seen. I can only assume that this IMAX film was filmed and projected in High Definition. The 3D aspect of the film was limited to about 4 or 5 scenes, but were very, very cool and were spaced out enough that they did not distract from the overall film.Brandon Routh emulates Superman, and in many ways Christopher Reeve as well. Having grown up watching all 4 original Superman movies in the theater I went into this one with guarded optimism and was rewarded with a fresh new look at a classic Superhero. I was pleasantly surprised over and over during the film when plot twists and dialogue actually went different directions than I expected and kept me guessing. Kate Bosworth puts in a good turn as a much more likable Lois Lane. While I loved the original films I always thought that Margot Kidder was kind of a hag and could not see what Superman would see in her. Kate Bosworth is a real beauty and did a great job of picking up where the other films left off while re-inventing Lois Lane a bit for us. James Marsden plays her new love interest, and does a commendable job as well, but I could not help thinking, "Hey isn't he Cyclops from X-men?", and "Hey you can't mix DC and Marvel Comics characters!". Kevin Spacey also makes a surprisingly excellent Lex Luthor.Overall I was blown away by this film both visually and emotionally. I actually got choked up after Superman's first big rescue at the start of the film and several of the 3D scenes had me on the edge of my seat. This was Awesome. Hats off to Bryan Singer for another great job. See it, and if you can, see it an IMAX theater, it is definitely worth the extra admission price. I would suggest seeing a later show to cut down on the little kid audience factor as my viewing would have been even better without all the toddlers talking, crying and walking the aisles during the movie.

It's not that the movie did not follow the story from the comics or even the series Smallville. It's just well, it was really not that good of a movie. Bosworth acted well, but she is no comic book heroin. She is to waif like and petite to be one. You cannot act curvaceous and voluptuous. Just bad casting on Singer's part nothing more nothing less. Routh looked more like Ken Whal from 80's show Wiseguy then he did Christopher Reeve and the only reason I make a comparison reference to Reeve's is because Singer's main reason for picking him for the role was because of his supposed look-alike appearance to him. Routh is under-whelming as Supe's but yet not bad as Clark. I guess it's because Clark plays more into the wimpy look he naturally has. Tom Welling probably would have done a better Superman but not as good a Clark. However the movie is called "Superman Returns" not "Clark, Welcome Back". Again just bad casting on Singer's part. The plot was ver similar to the the first movie (78). With Lex's evil vixen played tremendously well by Parker Posey eventually doing something similar to what Miss Teschmacher did in the first movie. Singer I feel is just extremely over-rated as a director. The only reason his X-men movies did so well in the theaters was because of the huge fan base the X-men have. People saw the first movie and were like "oh, uhm" and then saw the second hoping only to see if he did right. Both decent movies, but not extraordinary. Neither one of those movies can hold a candle to "X-Men The Last Stand" the only one not directed by him.The visual effects of the movie however were worth the price of admission. So I recommend it based on the strength of the visuals. Overall however just another super hero movie that will be forgotten about by next year when Spiderman 3 comes out. Sam Raimi rules. Bryan please call him for advise.

I liked the movie... solid, good story, decent acting considering.Routh plays Kent particularly well if you are familiar with the original Superman movies with Reeves. Spacey plays a comedic Luther and is convincing in his role. The story takes a while to coalesce but I found it made it more gripping.I never really liked superman as a comic (enough with the kryptonite!) but it is a good mythology and is represented well.Worthwhile to check out... The worst part was all the ads and !@#@Q@# before the film starts! I thought the film industry was trying to encourage people to go to the movies? Why subject us to numerous annoying advertisements... my favorite was for Bekham Cologne!

You know, if someone would have asked me before i saw this movie, "Are you going to see it?" I would have definitely said no. I was a big fan of the Christopher Reeve movies and really had hoped they would have left Superman alone. However, it seems the director really knew that the fans would not want to see a remake; Rather, they would want to see what they had once seen before. Superman, larger than life, living out a new adventure. I was really happy it wasn't a remake and that there are some things that are nostalgic, which just adds to the movies greatness. And these characters do a really good job being who they are suppose to be, not trying to act like the old ones did. All the characters did a super job with their characters, and the special affects were just so awesome. You just really felt that you were with Superman the whole time. So if your worried about seeing the movie, don't be. it was worth the money, and the two and a half hours. You wont be disappointed.

Review Title: No magic here for me disappointingly  =o(
Review: I was looking forward to this film because for one, I Love Superman and two, I really like Bryan Singer and what he's done. But I have to say... there was no magic here for me on most any level thought I really wanted there to be.Brandon did a decent job... Spacey was, well, he wasn't nearly as menacing as he could have been. Bosworth... she was so average in this film and Lois Lane needs to be anything but average.However the big let down here I believe was the script. And sorry to say, the directing and editing. There was too much time spent that really wasn't interesting, nothing magical. I didn't get that feeling of excitement or even that I watched a good story being told. It seemed a bit drug on. They would show you a segment, then segway to something else with out giving you anything to be excited about withing what you just watched.The only good thing the two writers did was X-Men II and it shows. I'm surprised Singer, with all of his talent, didn't bring us something more exciting. Even the plot was lacking majorly. And as far as Brandon (Superman), I believe he can do a good job with this however he needs to be a 'bit' more quirky when playing Clark, and a bit more emotional when playing Superman.In my opinion, this was a much anticipated film with inferior writing, directing and acting that leaves you, well me anyway, with no magical chemistry at all. And with the talent, there should have been much much more.=o(

Please....for the sake of people like me who at least try to read your reviews, watch a movie for what it is. If you expect every film to mirror your favourite movie of all time its just not going to happen....This is an action movie and that is all it is (it's superman...please, the original was not full of a amazing acting!). Go with the open mind of the type of film your going to watch, you'll enjoy it a lot more. Trust me :) By the way - for an action movie this ain't half bad and the best movie critics know that not every film is meant to have the same output.Thanks to some of you out there who managed to comment on this film enough to give the correct impression.Enjoy the movie, i did

Very entertaining. Good pace to the movie. All the super tasks seemed well thought out and not completely outrageous from a scientific point of view. When he is lifting something, he just doesn't take off with it, he does a gradual lift slowing increasing speed so as not to break what he is trying to lift. Nice twists to the movie near the end. I did have a small issue with some of the scenes as Superman -- his face almost was like a well-done cgi graphic as apposed to being really him. Though based on the making documentary I saw, it was supposed to be really him in the film. Just heavy make-up I suppose.Can't wait for the next one.

Review Title: Everything a hero movie should be
Review: After seeing this movie last night I am left with the warm fuzzy glow of having been thoroughly entertained, which to be honest is a feeling thats been lacking lately in my movie watching. Superman Returns has everything a good solid super-hero movie should have. A terrific hero (good job Brandon), a wonderfully nasty villain (yay (once again) Kevin) and a tough,no nonsense heroine (nicely done Kate), all thrown together in one kick-ass, well scripted, beautifully shot, nicely paced, exciting, touching,funny epic movie. Bryan Singer is no stranger to making awesome movies, and it's nice to see that he is yet to peak. His movie has an underlying sense of love and respect for all things Superman, without limiting it's appeal to Cape Wearing Middle-aged men and their sons.I love movies and I love escapism and this movie had it all. Great job!!

Review Title: Excellent and well worth the wait
Review: I would first like to say that anyone who complains about the homage that Mr. Singer made to the original film, simply doesn't understand the movie industry or the millions of Superman fans out there.Second. This movie was the best I have seen in a long while. The way it started with the introductions made tears come into my eyes thinking of the first time I saw the original film in a drive-in movie almost 30 years ago. I like the new twist that they put on this Superman. Coming from a comic book purist, this is a serious accomplishment. I hope that we can get this same creative team together again to see what else they can give us. I was worried that the choice of Kate Bosworth was bad for the part of Lois Lane, but I was even proved wrong on that. I am very pleased to have this new film added to the Superman Legacy!

The movie delivers pure entertainment. Brandon Rouths portrayal Of the Man of Steel was everything and more of what I expected. He took where Christopher Reeve(RIP) left off and made it his own. If people think he was similar to Reeve, that is because Reeve himself was right on cue for what the Ideal Superman should be. Routh is also on Cue with a little variance in attitude; and rightly so since we have evolve as a society since the late seventies. Gene Hackman was the Perfect Lex as the greatest criminal mind of our time,but out time being then has passed. Kevin Spacey blew me away and is now the greatest criminal mind of of his time. Kate Bosworth turned in a fantastic performance as Lois and Sam Huntington shutterly stoled all of his scenes.as Jimmy Olsen. James Marsden is always great, but was superb as the new character Richard White. Frank Langella fits the image of Perry White but didn't get enough screen time to strut his stuff. All in all it was the best movie I have seen in my adult life. The only con I can think of which really isn't a con is that they should have kept us dangling a little more on the idea of a SuperSon. I can't wait for the sequel, but I hope its not churned out too quickly, they need to take their time with the big daddy of all the super hero/comic book movie franchises.

I have to say I was very disappointed by this movie. It wasn't much of an action movie after the first sequence with the plane. As for drama or emotion, saying "Good night Lois" twice is about as emotonal as he gets (but if you're good at reading faces, you'll like it more perhaps. Also, Superman really needed someone to actually fight, to show that he can do more than lift heavy objects.Finally, after seeing the trailer for Spiderman 3, I must say that this trailer was better than the entire Superman film, I mean really! Sam (Raimi) can you please just do all comic book movies? Sam seems to be the only one who has got it (it takes more than just being a film maker). I wish he could have done Fantastic Four, X-men, X2, etc....

all i have got to say is wow. this movie was completely unbelievable. i enjoyed it the whole way through and love how it started out like the original with the opening credits. i will admit, i'm a fan of christopher reeve and i went seeing this with the intentions of having his shoes, or well boots to be left unfilled successfully; i was wrong. i found myself during the opening theme trying to hold a few tears back because to me, christopher reeve will ALWAYS be superman. brandon routh did an excellent job though and i was totally amazed by his performance. i found myself at many times finding myself thinking i was watching christopher reeve on screen, his similarities, mannerisms, hell even the way he looks and talks was almost dead on at some points, it was down right scary.the whole story developed well, though i would like to of had it last longer, it kept me on my seat the whole time and didn't bore me like other superhero movies (spiderman 2). with the blend of lois, and everyone else involved it was great. kate bosworth was an excellent lois lane, and of course, kevin spacey was a much better lex luthor in my opinion. he just has something about him that made him more believable and sinister towards superman.the inclusion of marlon brando footage was great and a flashback scene at the beginning was nice. the ending though which i won't spoil definitely made me go 'wow'. i can't think of any better movie i've seen in recent years than this. bar none, superman returns is the movie of the summer and the year.

A whole new take on Superman! From start to finish this film delivers all the goods that we've dreamed of seeing from a Superman film. Bryan Singer's take on the iconic character is different from the films of the late 70's and early 80's where Superman is portrayed as a boyscout who always has the answers and never doubts himself. This time around we see a Superman struggling to find his place in a society that has been without him for several years. Stunning visual effects, good writing, and great performances from Kevin Spacey and Brandon Routh make this film a must see. There has been a lot of questions about the casting of Superman, and even his new suit--those worries are quickly put to rest the first time Superman makes his appearance on screen. The archival addition of Marlon Brando as Jor-el ties the entire film together and helps those who aren't familiar with the mythology of Superman.
