Worth a rental but save your big screen admission for Cars!

I wanted to check this movie out on IMAX theaters but couldn't get a hold of a seat. So, I went to see it on the advanced large screen at Marcus. Anyhow, this movie was very excellent. Entertaining, good looking characters, very plausible acting, excellent plot. There were some surprises in the movie that I thought was very cool. I believe this movie stepped up to the plate. I believe it was well worth going to the theaters for this. Usually, I wait for movies to come out on DVD, but for superman, it's another story. Great special effects, It was nothing like the movie "the Hulk". The hulk was a terrible disaster in terms of "everything" specifically in the special effects area, but in Superman Returns, the special effects were astonishingly great. Overall I rate this movie in terms of entertaining ten out of ten. I would go to see this movie again. :)

Review Title: Awesome special effects, but horrible casting
Review: I would like to applaud the creators on the special effects they were out-standing. The over-all excitement and quality of this film deserves a 10, but then you need to take into consideration the cast and story line.I would just like to say that i thought Kevin Spacey did a terrific job as Lex. But as for the rest of the cast probably the biggest one superman himself was way off, I have always imagined superman as being more muscular and ripped but what you get is a paper doll superman that looks like he blows which ever way the wind goes. Also Louis Lane was a huge disappointment I was looking for a drop dead gorgeous girl and what you get is far from that. Also they took a risk of throwing all these no named actors in there and I'm sorry to say it didn't pay off, I thought the acting was absolutely horrible.Also the storyline and over all plot of this film was very unstructured and random. From the beginning to the very end of the film there were many holes and misunderstandings that were left unanswered.I don't recommend seeing this film in theaters but i recommend it for a lonely night at home when it comes out on DVD.

Review Title: Fair modern addition to the Superman franchise
Review: Superman returns for the new millennium! And it's clear from the technology that pops up in this movie that the characters are living in the modern era. Mobile phones, faxes, PC's and text-messaging, along with the appearance of a new space shuttle test design under-score the fact that this is a new version of the old legend.And the new version has all the charm and comic book thrills of the original. Brandon Routh is great as superman - in fact he's a dead-ringer for Christopher Reeve! And Kevin Spacy is perfect as Lex Luthor. Special effects have been updated too and some of the flying scenes really are quite spectacular and entertaining. The good acting of the leads combined with the flying scenes are the high-points.Yes, it's as good as the original, but the original was never that good. And therein lies the problem. 'Super-man Returns' has taken a legend and successfully re-told it in a contemporary setting. It's good solid entertainment. But it's more a copy of a legend than artistic advance.There is the odd touch of modern magic, for instance a memorable 'bullet-time' scene. And there's the right amount of humor.But too much of the plot is simply a re-working of ideas seen in earlier Superman movies. Indeed some lines of script have been taken word-for-word from earlier movies, which is disappointing. Lux has megalomaniac visions about owning land. Superman prevents disasters and saves people. Fun but nothing new. The really intriguing premise - Superman the alien who disappeared for 5 years into space and has now come back - isn't explored at all, which is very disappointing. There is a major plot 'reveal' which does show superman in a new light but it's not enough to infuse the superman legend with much new life.All in all it's a fair modern edition to the superman legend. Here is captured the charm and thrills of the original movie, and superman has indeed returned in spirit in the form of Brandon Routh. But the film is not in itself, original. It's entertaining, without being memorable.

Review Title: I believed a man could fly!
Review: I went along with the hope of some escapist entertainment and I didn't expect to be moved to tears as the movie started but I was. The opening credits and music set the scene for what was to come, the re-use of the original Superman soundtrack and opening credits style raises the bar for your expectations. This is obviously a carefully crafted movie made by someone who is greatly passionate and enthused about the content, and it showed. I saw flashes of Christopher Reeve everywhere. Bryan Singer must have said to Brandon Routh "Take the very best of what Christopher Reeve has left us and evolve it". That is exactly how this movie feels. Brandon Routh feels very "real" in the role, this is not a lightweight or flaky Superman. The leading character is strong, has depth and is well structured. You will care about him and what happens to him. Frankly I'd like to meet him. If you were ever wedged in a hopeless place, he is the guy you would most want to see.Kate Bosworth does an excellent job as Lois Lane. Again, she feels real – she smokes and argues with the boss. Thankfully Bryan Singer avoided the stereotypical dumb female screaming constantly and demanding to be rescued. Somehow I could never understand how "the man of steel" would hang out with some whining pathetic female who was hardly capable of boiling an egg for herself. She stands her own ground and that makes her relationship with Superman seem more balanced and more believable. James Marsden also turns in a creditable performance but it seems that he could only make the briefest of appearances in a sequel.Kevin Spacey, man, I'd hate to meet that guy in a dark alley… I disliked Lex Luthor pretty much straight away, he was a career weasel in a sharp suit. I felt an overwhelming urge to prod him with stake of Kryptonite myself. Parker Posey was grit to his mill and I enjoyed the dynamic of their relationship. I have to say they have some of the best and funniest dialog, it was a joy to watch.Finally Michael Dougherty and Dan Harris did an outstanding job of the screenplay. The dialog is fast, meaningful and uncluttered. Their use of humor should be taught to other screenwriters in Hollywood, I've rarely seen it used to such good effect. I saw this movie in New Zealand and I have to say the audience enjoyed it noisily! ...but then we've waited a long time for Superman to return...…and as to Bryan Singer re-assembling his team and doing a sequel? Yes please. I'd buy a ticket to that.

Review Title: may not be perfect, but overall EXCELLENT
Review: This is a terrific movie. The action scenes truly showcase all Supes powers and are a wonder to behold. Even better, every action scene is shot with a lyrical quality that is just one positive of the amazing cinematography here. The story is surprisingly poignant and Routh gives weight and depth to his godlike character...NOBODY could be a better follow up to Reeve than this guy here. Spacey is expectedly spot-on with Lex and Kitty and Jimmy are simply natural in their supporting roles. Bosworth lacks the "IT" factor that Kidder had, but also lacks the lines that give her the opportunity to be the quirky, spunky, unique character of the Donner film. Still, she does a very good job in the role and there were moments where i was impressed at her acting in reaction to Rouths masterful superman. There were some elements of the film i didn't like, such as the pacing, but with a second viewing the movie as a whole proves much better. Some griped about its length, but I actually wanted more. More exposition, more dialog, more Clark+Lois, and more Supe+Lex would have made it all perfect for me. Still, the movies storyline is captivating (very hard to do with the Superman character). The conflicts are beautifully resolved and the ending will simply leave u wanting more. Singer should be hailed for the mere feat of finding such a genuine successor to Reeve, but he also manages to construct a poetic, intense, beautiful, and faithful homecoming of a move. I highly recommend and anticipate a Director's Cut DVD with some of the cut footage to aid the pacing.

This movie is so boring that even writing about it is making me sleepy. Go ahead, vote my review as "un-helpful." I don't care. I'm going to bed. Poor acting by all except James Marsden (surprisingly enough), Parker Posey, and Brandon Routh. Spacey was acceptable, but did nothing more than reprise his role as slightly more mellowed-out Buddy Ackerman in Swimming With Sharks (a great movie, by the way). The plot was paper thin and uninspired. Lex Luthor's scheme was very lame and spartan coming from the world's "greatest criminal mind." The movie was plagued with family drama that seems to be supporting adultery. The sub plots went nowhere except were used as a simple device to leave the movie open to a sequel.

Review Title: Superman Returns but who really cares?
Review: Bryan's work with the first two X-Men were enough to get me out to see Superman in it's second day here in New Zealand. That and the fact that it's Superman... Being made in the era of amazing eye candy, who wouldn't wanna see it? Also I really wanted to see how they did with bringing him back and how the story would work out. Unfortunately, there's really nothing new here. They may as well of remade the original. The story is really empty. The Lois, Clarke and Superman triangle is really what the movie is about, which if you really give a darn about you can watch the Lois and Clarke series. Unfortunately, it didn't really work out so well in the end with that being the main pull. I will not throw out any spoilers but if I did I would go on for a few paragraphs about how these things didn't make the movie any better at all... Seeing as they aren't really anything new. All in all, it was fun to watch. But I really wanna know where all the money went.

Review Title: The worst movie ever?  Are you people RETARDED???
It was not what I expected...
Thank you For bringing back the real superman.
Pretty good overall, drama mostly, action a bit
Review: I couldn't help but get my hopes up for this movie. I know that's a mistake because with such high hopes I can only be disappointed.Well I was NOT disappointed. But I was not thrilled either. The story left me wanting more. In part, in a good way -- the way they intended, so as to set up any future sequel. But also in part in a not-so-good way.I felt the story was meandering. I prefer a good, tight story that makes the viewer feel as if strapped to a rocket hurling down the tracks to some inevitable confrontation. This story really just meandered. It could have gone anywhere, logical or not, and it did just that. I never felt that sense of "immediacy." But it was basically good stuff all around. They clearly put some thought into questions like, "How can we show Superman flying in an interesting new way?" Certain tricks like unique camera angles were used repeatedly. Even the opening credits were an homage to the original Superman movie while still being revamped and interesting.Individual scenes were good-to-great. I loved the drama of the story. That's what this is: a drama with some action sequences, not vice versa.Overall enjoyable, but it can be a long 2.5 hours.

Review Title: Good, mostly stays true to originals...
Review: The movie was good. I got to see it at the IMAX with 3D, that was well done.I have always liked Superman... the movie didn't flow great, there were parts were you wished they had cut more out, or trimmed, or made more interesting.Comparing to the originals, it just didn't keep you on the edge of your seat.Lots of great throwback one-liners.Strong acting. The actors weren't outstanding, but all were solid and surprisingly felt like I was watching Reeves at some points... voice or smile or something... it was a little weird, but nice (fond memories).Overall, the movie kept me interested and entertained for the majority of the time, with some laughs in there too, but it would have needed to keep my interest the WHOLE time if I were to rate higher than 7.

Review Title: The best time I ever had in the cinema
Review: Let's put it this way, I've been waiting for a new superman movie for the last...,well forever basically. And the first time I heard that they were making superman returns I was so happy, Its hard to explain. Any way after a long anticipated wait I finally went to see it on opening night. 5 minutes in to the movie I had goosebumps with the opening credits, I just loved how they kept the original score. Being a huge superman fan I extremely enjoyed the movie, full credit to all the cast especially Routh and Spacey. Routh in some scenes made me think that he was Chris Reeve even his voice sounds similar. And spacey was great as Lex Luthor. It was just amazing for me and I really recommend it to everyone who enjoys superhero movies, and you definitely can't miss the best superhero off all of them......SUPERMAN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!P.S: They are definitely making sequel

I thought the film was fantastic. It truly did justice to the character as portrayed by Reeve, and carries on the legacy superbly.The actors did fantastic jobs. Routh could pass as a voice double for Reeve, and Kevin Spacey portrays criminal real-estate broker Lex Luthor with flair. Kate Bosworth did a pretty good job at single-mom Lois Lane, even if it did take me a bit to wrap my mind around the concept.Superman continues to embody the greatest virtues of humanity, even if he is not exactly human. He is one of those heroes that is always needed by society, to be a symbol for everything that is good and just. The new film brought that symbolism home, without having to shove it in the viewer's face.If you have a place in your heart for Superman, then I believe you will enjoy this film.Go out and see it, and despite the PG-13 rating, take your kids.

Review Title: It's a bird! ... It's a Plane... No it's Superman
Review: This film did justice to the most powerful superhero of all time. It had that comic book aura, much like spiderman and batman begins, that many comic movies fail to capture. Picking up on the story line after superman 2, 5 years later Klark timely returns to planet earth only to find that the humans he left behind are in major need of his assistance. The movie progresses to create a plot that was not subordinate to the spectacular special effects present throughout the film. Brandon Routh and Kate Browsworth both did justice to their roles and kevin spacey made for a sinister and maniac Lex Luthor. The last 30 minutes of the movie ran a little dry for my liking and over the top, predictable Hollywood style scenes threw me off a bit. But I suppose that's what you have to expect when walking into a block buster film such as this one.

Review Title: WOW!! Batman Begins can eat the dirt
Review: WOW!! for those who were unsure whether to watch this movie, in case it might be a badly done super hero movie (catwoman,Electra), i insist u go watch it now!! its one of the best super hero movies made! Batman , Spiderman do not compare to this, i think this is probably Bryan Singer's best movie so far, well what can u expect from the guy who directed the Xmen and Xmen 2 movies? Brandon Routh and Kate Bosworth acts wonderfully,not to mention the great acting by Keven Spacy and for all u Kal Penn fans (Kumar from Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle) prepare to be dazzled by his....acting? The story line is great, and then some! my comment does this movie no justice - go out and watch it now !! trust me you wont be disappointed

Just to get the negative out of the way, there were some slow parts that could have been cut. Blah, blah, blah, artistic differences, etc, etc, etc.OH. MY. GAWD.Talk about a rousing return! Folks, you are in for a treat. Bryan Singer has brought that special touch of humanizing the unknown from the X-Men films to Superman Returns. NEVER has Superman been so real, so vulnerable, and at the same time so incredibly awesome. You'll laugh, you'll cry, you won't get up from your seat because you'll immediately want to watch it again.First, props on the opening title sequence. Singer does a great job of tying the old series into the new from beginning to end. You'll instantly be transported back to the 70s when you were a kid sitting in the theatre watching the opening title sequence. Make no mistake, my friend. This is a Superman movie. The sights and sounds are all so familiar that nostalgia grabs you and won't let go for the next 2 and a 1/2 hours.Next, the acting. I thought Spacey was a great cast for Luthor, and boy was I right. He has just enough star power, enjoyability, and acting talent to not only fill Gene Hackman's shoes, but to do for the role what Jack Nicholson did for the Joker in Batman. He makes Lex his own, and you love him for it. The hands down best call in the history of casting is Parker Posey as Kitty. She literally steals scenes with dead pan humor, lines from the past, and just grabs your attention as "What will she do/say now?" every time she is on the screen. And, yes, everything you have heard about Brandon Routh is 100% true. Not only does he do a great job in the role, he made the role who Christopher Reeve was, and there are flashes where you forget that isn't Reeve on the screen. Definitely a great tribute to an actor who will forever be remembered by those who saw the original as Superman. Kate Moss did an OK job as Lois, but audiences tend to agree they need some more strength from her character. A fantastic actress, she's no Margot Kidder. She has the stubborn thing down, but sounds more whiny when she does it, and defers to her fiancé to solve her problems instead of ripping the editor in chief herself. I know she can do a better job, she just didn't do it here. It was great to see Cyclops from X-Men playing a role here as Lois' fiancé. Carey Elwes would have also been a great choice for the role.The plot. Oh my goodness the plot. Without giving anything away in the terms of spoilers, let me just say this is the deepest plot of any superhero movie I have ever seen. There are at least two subplots going on here, which is different than having two different story lines going on at once like Singer did in X-Men. Just to fast forward through it all, our story takes place as though S3 and S4 never existed (which they shouldn't have). Superman has been gone for 5 years to see if his planet actually survived when astronomers find what they think might be Krypton. Superman returns just as he showed up the first time on the farm. After getting his old job back at the Daily Planet, tragedies begin taking place, and it's business as usual for Superman, who finds out Lois has new love interest and a son, as well as winning a PUlitzer Prize for her article, "Why the world doesn't need Superman" which is why you hear her say in the trailer that the world doesn't need a savior. Meanwhile, Lex is plotting and scheming Superman's demise as well as his own world domination plans. It all culminates off the coast of the US on a yacht and a surprise Lex has in store for the man of steel. Once again we pit the brains of a super villain against the strength of a superhero.Visually, this film is so good I can't even begin to describe it. The use of dark and light tones, the storms at sea, the clouds in the sky, sunsets... *gasp*. It's all so beautifully exhausting you just want to sit and watch. With something like 1,400 visual effects shots, you will be surprised how little you look at and go "hmmm....". While Titanic didn't hide its visual effects very well, it is the one movie that comes close to the wizardry and mastery of film-making we see here in Singer's vision of Superman Returns.Just to wrap up, this movie should so make $1billion dollars. If Titanic can do it, Superman Returns should definitely be able to duplicate that. I am not one much for repeat viewings of films, but this is one I will see at least 3-5 more times (cuz i still gotta see it in IMAX *grin*). The story just pulls you in and doesn't let go, all while Singer is reproducing a Y2K version of our childhood hero. The film is dedicated to Mr. and Mrs. Reeve, as one would expect, and I'll tell you right now, if Christopher were alive today he would have tears of joy in his eyes to tell us all that Superman has indeed returned...

I've been a fan of superman. He is one of my favorite comic book characters. I saw the first two X men, and really enjoyed those! Bryan Singer did a great job with him. Unfortunately, he left the trilogy(leaving Brett Ratner to destroy it) and he demolished this one.So what was good and bad? The actors did a fine job. The FX were quite stunning and good. The story was awful. I could remember countless times thinking, oh man, when is this going to end! The movie was so long, and it had to no flow. There was a basic plot and that was it. There was no was direction with the story, things just happened and then it ended. If I were to pinpoint where it went wrong, I would say the writing.I really had high hopes for this, seeing as Bryan left the X men trilogy to direct this, so I told myself, this better be good. Wow, 2 disappointing decisions. I'm sorry, but I was not impressed. But, I still have loads of respect for Bryan and his creativity. He is a brilliant director, and he just made a slight mistake. Hopefully, he will get back up and continue with his success.

Review Title: Maybe not the best film around, But Bryan definitely  brings the man of steel back home
Review: This movie has many people upset. Almost half of the critics out there are saying how bad this movie is. Well let me tell you something. Superman Returns definitely did not live up to all the hype around it. But this movie is pretty decent. The acting is great, the special effects are great, and the story is fantastic. For all superman fans alike, we should be rejoicing this film as Bryan Singer has done right to the superman universe. THe movie has love, action, and humor. Even though the major spoiler was a bit upsetting, it doesn't hurt the film too bad. Get ready for a sequel to tie up a lot of loose ends.So bottom line. This movie is probably in the top five comic movies ever made. Bryan Singer deserves some credit.

Review Title: Well I tried to get into it.

Review: i was very afraid of watching this movie at first. i thought this one is gonna be one of those wannabes! but i have to thank Bryan Singer and his very creative and rather interesting way of putting things into the eye of the viewers.to make things clear, this movie isn't about superman kicking lex Luther's ass. it is much deeper, way more humane than any other movie that i have watched recently. it is more serious, but still entertaining. looks into superman in a different angle. watching this movie felt like living a day or two in superman's life.Bryan Singer's choice of the cast is genius. superman almost feels like Christopher reeve. Lois lain, beautiful, bald, and .... what can i say... a woman.... and finally, Kevin spacey... i really liked his character. he wasn't as crazy (or childish) as Gene Hackman. he was more formed and genuine.it is good that they respected the laws of physics in this movie. and i would like it even more if they have keep doing so, or may be more, in all comic-to-movie pictures.all in all; the movie is fantastic in every way. don't expect a remake of the classics. this movie leaps into a new era. a more humane, loving, and dramatic era. it is slow at times, yet it roller coaster into breath taking rides.absolutely worth watching in the cinema... may be twice! and a must must have DVD... i hope a blue ray DVD or something.

Initially I was a bit skeptical if 'Superman Returns,' would recreate the magic of 1978, especially after its sequels always fell a bit short.However this movie scores well on effects (which had to be expected) and what adds to the allure is a human touch that makes superman a better hero to connect with.After a break, the man in blue is back to his office as the clumsy Clark Kent while one looks forward to him converting the elevator into his changing room before he takes to the sky.Brandon Routh as the man of steel foots the bill and brings back nostalgic memories of Christopher Reeve. Kevin Spacy as Lex Luther is great to watch, (as always his plots for destruction are unique and his dialogues with Kitty bring a smile) while Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane captures the frame as the ideal foil to her superhero with moments of substance exchanged between the two. After watching the movie the viewer gets the feeling that his old friend is back and tends to forgive him for his absence. The movie has its captivating moments that have one gripping the edge of the seat.Perhaps the movie could do with some slick editing at places where it drags at times and makes one look at the watch. But all said and done, it's Superman in his new avatar for the 21st century so grab the popcorn, take those few long drawn moments with a pinch of salt and enjoy our original superhero doing his breathtaking sequences as he goes about saving the world.

Let me start off by saying i have never been a big fan of super-hero movies, therefore you may find my opinion slightly biased. The first super-hero movie i liked at all was Spiderman, then i saw Batman Begins which completely blew my mind (constantly comparing this movie to batman begins may be another reason i didn't like it so much).I went into the movie with very high expectations: Kevin Spacey is my all time favourite actor (and was not a let down), Brian Singer was amazing with "the usual suspects" and i just thought the new generation of super-hero movies was something different.Kevin Spacey's acting is superb and is the high point of the movie. The rest of the acting is simply mediocre. The story is very very ordinary and predictable. The regular selfish super-villain trying to gain power while its superman's job to stop that.Anyway don't get me wrong the movie is pretty entertaining, especially the scenes with Kevin Spacey (more in the first half than the second).Conclusion: any fan of superhero movies or Kevin spacey should watch this film......otherwise you're not missing much.

Review Title: General Stuff about the movie- without any spoilers.
Review: OK, where do I start? After having seen superman 1, 2, and 3 at least 100 times, I can say that I know the Superman stories quite well. But this, was just extremely disappointing.Firstly, Who on earth decided to cast Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane? wrong move. She had absolutely nothing going for her. She was very bland,very boring, and had frizzy hair through the whole movie. I mean, couldn't they make her a little more sightly. I know that Lois Lane was never gorgeous, but it made her unlikeable, which is not how Lois Lane should be like.If you had a choice between Queen Latifa, Alexis Arquette, and Dennis Rodman, any of them could have probably done a better job of Lois, than Kate. Thats how bad she was.Secondly, Jimmy. He was cute and all, but just not like the original lovable Jimmy that we all grew to love.Thirdly, there was not enough action in this movie. The evil plot by Lex Luther was good, but did they really need to bore us for 1.5 hours before getting into it? I Don't think so.Next, What was with the line "Good Night Lois." Wasn't it enough that Superman only had 20 lines in the whole movie, without him having to repeat "Good Night Lois" (and once good night katherine) Approximately 8 times.There was Definitely not enough Superman in this movie. And I don't think they showed off Brandon as much as they could of.Unfortunately, i think the critics will be justly harsh. All in all, an OK movie, with crap casting, not enough superman or action, and boring in many parts.The upside? there was about 9 funny bits in the movie, which added a nice touch.Id give it 6 out of 10. But I Definitely wont be seeing Superman 2 at any movie theatres. I think i'll wait for it to come out on TV.

Review Title: Screw Ebert.....Why this movie was great:
Review: As a character, Superman's biggest flaw is his near invincibility. Most people that do not like Superman do not like him for the fact that they feel he is too powerful. His only weakness is an extremely rare mineral that hardly anyone knows about or can get a hold of. It seems unfair. To me that was the purpose of the movie: to show that Superman is actually quite vulnerable. Despite all of his powers, he can be weak and he cannot do anything he wants. He is not a God. This is shown very well in a couple of scenes. First when he is outside Lois' house and she tells richard that she didn't love Superman. For as powerful as Superman was, there was nothing he could do. His emotions are just as delicate as the next man's. You could tell how hurt he was when he flew off into space buried that pain in trying saving the world (the thing he knows he can succeed in). This idea is shown through out the movie and struck upon again when Lois, Richard and Jason save him. After his rescue, he looks at the 3 in the plane and realizes that Richard is a good guy and there is nothing he can do to change Lois' mind. So he leaves to save the day knowing full well that he could die by trying to move the island. You could see his desperation and pain. The most powerful example is when he is getting beat up. It is a powerful scene. For the 2 previous hours all that was shown was how strong and powerful Superman was. Within minutes he was being humiliated and beaten. Pain is something foreign to Superman, but you could see him experiencing it. It was hard to watch. You could see his sudden transformation from the most powerful man ever, to an ordinary man being picked on. These scenes were executed so well. They make this movie great.

Review Title: Almost perfect...if it wasn't for Spacey
Review: I'm sorry to say it but Brandon IS Superman...I'm sorry Christopher Reeve but he is.Now to the movie, this movie is probably the best movie of 2006 so far. Like I said ALMOST perfect. I think that the movie will average at about 8.2 making it on the top 250 movies, and it deserves it, it's a perfect mixture of romance and action, story line and humour. I like the fact that they cast an UN-known as Superman Brandon was the best thing in this movie, followed by Kate Bosworth, she did the best performance of her life, I don't think she was Lois Lane, but she did a heck of a job at playing her.Kevin, Kevin, Kevin, your performance was below the standards of this movie, you over acted it and I didn't like you, you annoyed me and I think you should've been re-cast.Returns has the best Special Effects I've EVER SEEN I think that it will win an Oscar for Special Effects, there is a scene in the first half of the movie that was visually stunning and really believable Bryan Singer you are my new favorite director and I'm happy you left X-Men: The Last Stand for this 9/10

really enjoyable reboot of the superman franchise. excellent portrayal of superman and all the others whilst providing a great stepping stone for any eventual sequels. a film with heart, emotion and action...check it out. brandon routh brings a little of christopher reeve to the party whilst also something new. being a sequel we couldn't have his character be a massive departure from the first two, otherwise that simply wouldn't fit. bosworth, despite fanboys rumblings, is fine as lois lane. margot kidder, also fine for the role, brought something that kate bosworth couldn't, that sass, whilst kidder could never, in my opinion be as stunning or indeed paternal as bosworth is here. great casting choice. no need talking about spacey, he is great in any role he picks up. much like morgan freeman. hopefully this makes a stack of money so we can see singer (like he did with X-MEN) really expand on the character, create and complete arcs and give us, the audience, a superman franchise to really savour and enjoy (like donner was shaping to) for generations to come.

Overall, it was awesome. Brandon Routh is my new Superman (it was Dean Cain and Tom Welling because I've grown up watching them). He does an excellent scene at the very end of the film that will tear your heart out. Kate Bosworth's performance left a little to be desired in spots,mostly in her scenes with Perry White, but overall, it was good. Tristan Lake Treudeau, who plays Lois' son, Jason,was a real bright spot. And for those James Marsden fans who think he got totally ripped off with the X-Men movies, he's got a big part in this film and he gets to look totally heroic, which is weird considering that he's not actually the hero. And Kevin Spacey is totally spot-on, but we didn't expect any less.It did, however, go on just a bit too long. Not King Kong too long, just a little too long. A few frames could have been snipped from some of the more lingering shots and it would have been perfect.The cinematography and special effects were amazing and beautiful. I loved how they went with a very classic 30s styling for the costumes of the main characters and for the sets in general. It was a wonderful touch that sort of takes you into the world of fantasy without taking you out of reality. The styling also makes the film look as though it could be set in any time, which will let the film be relatable to audiences in the future. This is definitely a film with longevity.I'm glad Bryan Singer got to direct his dream film. That's some bad hat, Harry.

I didn't know what to expect from this movie. Overall, I liked it. I might go back to see it a second time to catch some details. This movie is a continuation in the same universe as the Christopher Reeve movies, so they throw in some comments that are only understood if you saw the other movies. It had a nice plot twist. The special effects were good and there was actually some character development, something that was missing from X-men 3. I have to admit that it was slow in the beginning but held me in thrall for the rest of the movie. Lex Luthor was much more evil and diabolical in this movie. Less comic-like then how Hackman played the role in the late 70's and in the 80's movies. Kind of refreshing that. I had gotten used to the truly evilness of Lex in Smallville. Kate Bosworth actually did an awesome job. I wasn't sure about her as Lois, but she surprised me. I give the movie an 8. If I can see it a second time, then a movie is an 8 or better. Check it out, it's worth a viewing.

Review Title: The Best Superman Yet, I can't wait until another one is made
Review: I can't say how awesome this movie was. I'm going back to see it a 4th time this Thursday. My heart was pumping, I stayed on the edge of my seat the entire movie. It didn't seam like 2 hours and 30 some minutes. I wish it was longer. Great Job. This movie was just awesome amazing. It is a MUST see to any film enthuses. As a multi-million dollar movie maker myself, I can't say how good this movie made me feel. I'm defiantly going to buy it once it comes out on DVD. The movie was just crazy good. Great Job! Great Job to all who helped! I recommend this movie to everyone. I have so much to say about his movie I don't even know where to start. It's the movie everyone waits for to come out and change the way they live. It boosts there drive to make better and better movies.

As an expert on Superman and having a Masters degree in Cinema and Media Studies, I know a thing or two about movies AND the Man of Steel. I have never in my ENTIRE Life, seen ANYTHING quite like this movie. Brian Singer worships at the altar of Superman and this film is a PRAYER. 2 and 1/2 hours go by at super speed and I was left needing more. As the credits rolled my body shook, my heart palpitated and I had trouble breathing. It was a fantastic roller coaster ride, sex and a pasta dinner rolled into one. Superman Returns went in through my eyes and ears, reverberated around in my brain and attempted to escape through my pores. It's power still, this next morning, leaves me feeling like I am bursting at the seams. I have never had a religious epiphany where the spirit of whatever God you worship enters your body and enriches the soul. This film....well...now I know what such an epiphany feels like. Just go see this movie.

Review Title: Superman Return to disgrace his legend
Review: *** This comment may contain spoilers *** Man… I finally watched Superman Return…. Ya…. Wooo hooo….Now I have to say, before I went to see the movie I was disappointed about the choice of actors… The Superman played by Brandon Routh and Lois Lane played by Kate Bosworth just did not work for me. That was before I went to see the movie… right… right…. OK after I watched the movie it still don't work for me… it's a great thing that Routh's smiles like the Late great Christopher Reeve and it's a great thing they trying to bring some of that in but I just don't think he fit as "The Superman"… but hey thass just me… OK, the movie was so-so; nothing special it was like X-men, good movie to watch but the story is sad. There are few good scene and well one funny part and lots of cheap jocks. O and guess what Cyclops was in it haha that was funny... as I already said I really don't like the casting doesn't work with me. One thing that got me laughing all through the movie was this, Superman banged Lane and now Cyclops is banging her… but she don't seem to know if its superman's child, and if the movie continued from the last one why is that Lane don't seem to know that Clark is Superman… The movie has flaws… lots of them… one main one is that part where he lifts the Kryptonite Island and throws it into the space… what is up with that I though superman loses his power and goes weak when he is around The Kryptonite and the firkin island was full of it.The ending could have been better than what it was… my suggestion was that Superman is looking out from the space and he hears someone calling for help and as he is flying down it closes… another ending could've been when he was having the coma..haha.. just had to laugh on that one. Haha Good movie to watch but I was personally disappointed.

Review Title: John William's music started playing, and it just got better from there.
Review: I know fanboys nitpicked about the size of the "S", and they'll probably nitpick about the way kryptonite functions differently at different points in the film (won't say which of course), but to me, it was the score that was most important to me of all the minor details (the major being the acting and story).I loved that music all my life, and it would be even stupider to leave it out since this a pretty-much sequel to Superman II. But it was there, from the opening credits (with those awesome "3-D" titles) from liberal peppering of the cues from John William's score. John Ottman really knew what he was doing. He didn't try to show a comparison of his work to William's. Often, I could hardly tell when one started and the other began. That was partly due to Ottman's dual role as composer and co-film editor.His goal was evidently to blend the two scores together so that they complimented each other. Only in the long cues could you tell one from the other, but even then, Ottman stayed true to the original's heart. He did compose a couple "choir" moments that he's become infamous for, but this time it was graceful rather than operatic, especially when Superman hovers in front of the sun's light. Just beautiful.As for rest of the film, it stayed as true to the heart of I & II as well, damn good all around. And I have to give kudos to the writers for not making Richard White simply the "other guy" that a lesser film would have made him (like most cliché romantic comedies).

Effects: good, and used sparingly. The balance of CGI to filmed shots is well done. Acting: good across the board. Screenplay, feasible but confused. It acts like a continuation and a partial re-imagination at the same time. I think this is the main reason why the film is good , but not great. I felt confused. The only thing saving me from falling completely away from enjoying the film was the acting across the board ; in particular, the parts of Luthor and Superman. Now, was the story great? Not really. It smacks of 'first movie in a trilogy'; which usually I'm excited about, but I really wasn't taken somewhere new, wanting more at the end. Thats the bottom line. I wasn't overly 'impressed' by the story, it just wasn't written very well. (sorry writers**) It was good, not great. I rate movies usually in relationship to "How much would I pay?": Well, for this movie, it's worth paying full price to see it. Its a good movie. It is not worth seeing a second time, like I have for many 'blockbuster' films. This is not a 'blockbuster'. I will not buy it on DVD. I would recommend others see it, but I would not go with them :)

Having just returned from seeing "Superman Returns", I feel the urge to pen this comment while the details of the film are still fresh in my mind.First off, I'd just like to say that I was disappointed. Actually, that's an understatement. I was REALLY disappointed. I'm a Superman fan. I have been ever since I was a little kid. I'd be running around with my little brother, our hair styled into the famous "Superman curl". But alas, my dreams have been shattered. It seems that a big Hollywood budget and fantastic special effects can't save a sloppy script. Sure, "Superman 3" and "Superman 4: The Quest For Peace" were stinkers, but Christopher Reeve made them bearable. That brings me to my second point.Brandon Routh is no Christopher Reeve. He doesn't even compare. Now I know that Chris Reeve was not the first person to portray "The Man Of Steel", it was George Reeves, but the point I'm making here is that Chris Reeve IS Superman. There is just something about him. Something mystical, something magical that makes you believe: "Hey, this guy can really fly. He's Superman". I guess Reeve just had the right look, build and voice for Superman. He had a certain sincerity about him, accompanied by his beautiful blue eyes. I miss him.Brandon Routh does not even come close. I don't mean to bag him here, I'm sure he gave the role his all. But he's no Superman. I know that he is older than Chris Reeve was when he made the first Superman movie, but he still looks like a college kid. He facial structure resembles a "pretty boy". Also, I'm pretty sure he has brown eyes, which were digitally enhanced in the movie to make them blue. Watch it, and you can tell that they are not his natural eye colour. And another thing, I find Routh to be too tanned. It's weird, but it's just something that I noticed.The other key cast members were mediocre at best. Kate Bosworth did an okay job as Lois Lane, but Margot Kidder again did it better. I will take my hat off to Sam Huntington, who played Jimmy Olsen. He does a fantastic job, much better than Marc McClure. Also, Kevin Spacey is a great Lex Luthor. He's cold and cruel, but you just gotta love him.And so, I come to the conclusion of my review. "Superman Returns" is a mediocre movie at best. It will keep you entertained but it is not a great movie. Brian Singer is no Richard Donner, and Brandon Routh is no Christopher Reeve. I'm sure there are those of you whole will praise this movie, but most of you will find that it will in no way compare to the original 1978 classic.

Review Title: For all those who have bashed Superman Returns (Spoilers)

Review: This move far surpassed my expectations I had for it. As much as I was wanting to see Tom Welling reprise his role from "Smallville," I was not disappointed at all in Brandon Routh's performance. At times, when the cameras were at certain angles, I could almost see a young Christopher Reeve, even at times sounded like him. Everyone must see this movie in Theaters for its great special Effects and Storyline. I am going to see it again in the IMAX just because I want the full experience. If you are reluctant about seeing it in theaters because of it being 2 1/2 hours, don't be. It is well worth the time spent and you will come out of the theater very pleased with the time gone by.

Not the best movie of the summer, but still entertaining and exciting. Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor is... well... Kevin Spacey, good no matter what the role is. Brandon Routh is going to be a star, big time, he didn't over act (which can be a tendency for young actors) and he was very believable as both the dorky Clark Kent and Superman, two very different roles. It is also a coming out party for Kate Bosworth, a young and talented actress, who does a wonderful job as Lois Lane. The special effects were good, but not great (there was one scene in particular that looked like a painted background from a bad 80's action flick). I thought the plot line was fantastic, and original. I recommend this movie to anyone with a little money to spend and searching for something fun to do.

Review Title: The most epic/heartfelt SUPERMAN movie to date.
Review: There were a number of things that went wrong for this movie and a lot of things that went right. This film was labeled as a return for one of the greatest comic book superheroes of all-time, but this felt like a drama or romance film with little to no action sequences but I still don't think people were ready for the return of Superman. It's safe to assume that this movie is completely dedicated and inspired by the Donner universe and previous Superman films. It is a reinvention of the old films for the new audience of today. The entire movie is a little predictable for some (including myself). Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor was not as convincing as the late great Gene Hackman. And Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane felt like the wrong person was cast for the role. They brought in Brandon Routh to don the suit but it appears they were trying to get a Christopher Reeve look alike. After the classic opening credits in outerspace as soon as the first act begins, you really feel this is a different take on the Superman universe. The film itself is a perfect example of a summer movie caught in the hype, failing to deliver on all cylinders. There was too much emphasis on the backstory of Lois and Superman. There is a big surprise in the movie near the end which everyone pretty much saw coming but it really is hard to believe for die hard Superman fans. I rank this Superman movie behind Superman The Movie and Superman II. The Superman franchise really deserved a restart, i.e. Batman Begins/Incredible Hulk.

Reading the reviews of half hearted critics and no concrete details of why this movie is as apparently awful as they make it out to be, I find nothing wrong with the movie at all. Maybe they lack the imagination to fill in a couple of the outlandish topics, or maybe they're just stuck in the 70's with the original Superman. Honestly, it's an amazing event. Better than X-Men, better than Spiderman, just as great as Batman Begins. Besides worrying about what actor would fit what part, and that Routh supposedly "lacks charisma" (Roger Ebert) take the non-charismatic actor and their supporting thespians and step aside from their predecessors for just a minute, you may just find some emotion if you look hard enough. By the time the movie ends you will have stepped out of the theatre and find that after a literal 2 hours and 45 minutes later, time flew by. Superman gives one the sense that he is actually there, it gives one a sense beyond senses that any other Superman or Superhero movie has given. Great segways and excellent plot twists, what more could you ever want.

Having been an avid movie and comic book fan since childhood, I can honestly say that this movie was far from worth watching. Though the effects were beautiful, that doesn't distract from the lackluster plot filled with plot holes and lackluster performances. Kevin Spacey played an arguably uncomfortable Lex Luthor who was just plain boring to watch. At the beginning of the screening the audience in the packed theatre exploded with the sound of hands clapping. When the movie was over, less than quarter of the audience clapped, and some of them probably just clapped because it was over. I went to the theatre to watch someone play Superman, not to watch someone play Christopher Reeves playing Superman. Save your money and watch Elektra, sure it was horrible too, but at least it won't cost you three hours of your life.

WOW... The first Superman Movie i am seeing in the theater. So went inside the hall half-an-hour before it starts, First-Day First-Show and as expected the hall was full. The movie started with John Williams original theme music from the first part and then John Ottman(original music) takes full control after that. This film is set to take place where Superman II ends. But they confuse with the time period the film is actually set against. The news paper deceit it as 70's while we have people carrying cell phones and LCD TV hanging around. This edition of superman has taken lot of twists to make it to the big screen after 2 decades. Bryan Singer, has done a commendable job, making superman more HUMAN than SUPERHUMAN. Superman (Brandon Routh) love for Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth) takes the driver seat of the screenplay than fighting against Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey). Brandon looks good in the suit, but he looks too young to fill in Christopher Reeve, still manages to convince in the role. Kate was apt as Lois. Kevin Spacey was great as usual, now after the mind blowing performance from Gene Hackman it has take some like Spacey to repeat it, and he does it with ease. He was a lovable villain in the movie. The movie wanders from place to place in terms of screenplay, thought it really stretched towards the end, but then it did require such an ending to keep hopes for few more in this series. The Visual Effects are nice, and the stunts are mind blowing but too short. We actually don't get to see lot the relationship between Clark Kent and Lois Lane. Superman Returns has its moments through the film and small tear-jerks as you get to see the Human side of "SuperMan"

Gosh. Whether one likes this movie will be a matter of religion, I suppose. And within that choice will be the question of how cheaply your religious notions can be bought. For me, a summer movie needs to first provide sweep, spectacle, thrill. It needs to be cinematic. It needs to grab my optic nerve first, saturating it with precortex sense. Then all the other things fill that turbulent vessel. When it is a comic book-based project, there's the story and the grander cosmology. The cosmology is primary among these. It is the grander scheme of things that generates villains, threats and confusions about love. Perhaps there's some stuff about family or mentor in there. But this is mere disguise. The job of these things is to provide that visual world: first in what we see, and second in explaining (usually in words) some of the important laws about how that world works. "King Kong" is my "summer" touchstone in this, but I suppose "Lord of the Rings" would be a better example for most. That said, I consider this movie something of a disaster. I won't be recommending it to friends, and I will try to forget I saw it. The oddest thing is that I think it could have worked. It could have worked if they took out all the Jesus pandering. Yes, I know it works for smarmy politicians and their televangelist symbiotes, but its just not deep enough for a world. Not this way. I'll buy the other Reeves as the savior in "Matrix," but this is just too glib. It could have worked if they ditched Ottman. I know Singer was pressed for time, so wanted all his buddies for expediency sake. And the idea of editing and scoring in the same imagination is so attractive... but this guy is so dull in imagination that it is a double curse to have him in the room. Williams' original score was brilliant, meaning in a shiny, brassy crisp way. This moos. It could have worked if the villains were sharp. Think of Spacey in the one really good thing Singer has done, as one possibility for Keyser Soze. Think of Parker Posey in "House of Yes." I still dream about that. Now look at how blunt these characters are. The genius of the comics was that there were 4 worlds. That of Krypton, always cryptic; that of the Daily Planet, our folded device where the story is in the story and everything is woven tightly; the ordinary world of Metropolis, the canvas on which the play is drawn. And there's the fourth world, the world of LL, where all the real people live. All the people with names that start with LL. These are the Sherlocks and Mycrofts and Moriatys. These are the people who push here and there and make the world change. They are demigods in a way. Spacey and Posey could do it. This business about Lois as Mother Mary? Well, that in the comic books would be different, but is the right direction. Like the dull score, and the deliberately fuzzy CGI (to save time, we are told), the LLs of this movie don't sparkle. Ted's Evaluation: 1 of 3, You can find something better to do with this part of your life

Review Title: Half as good as Batman Begins
Review: Superman Returns, and it's a let down for me.I'm not surprised. Regardless of the hype and 10-star reviews on IMDb, I still had little faith in Bryan Singer's ability to create substance and depth with his films. After the fantastic, gritty Batman Begins, I was expecting something a little meaty and poignant. What I witnessed Thursday night at the IMAX was a popcorn movie that I will forget in two or three days.I loved Brandon Routh's performance, thought Lois Lane was cute but miscast, enjoyed Spacey as a somewhat darker Lex Luthor, loved Frank Langella as Perry. All the elements were there... expensive production, excellent SFX, good cast, decent acting all around. But somehow it just doesn't hold up very well - it's all over the place with no solid center, exactly my impression with other Bryan Singer films.Lex's evil plan is pretty dumb, though it does look impressive in 3D. I didn't enjoy the messianic overtones to Superman's character as insinuated into this film. It lends Superman an arrogance and self-importance that doesn't bring likability to the character. He's also portrayed as a bit of a peeping tom, which bothered me just a little.Much like everything else I've seen directed by Bryan Singer, there is a lot of eye candy without a lot of character substance. It almost felt like a Michael Bay film, and for me it fails as an homage to the original Christopher Reeve version. While nowhere near as bad as Superman IV, it just doesn't fully capture the spirit of the original two films or the comic hero that I admire. I am leaving out Superman III because I don't really remember it all too well!Superman's Return could have been much better in the hands of a creative and capable director. Unfortunately for me, because of the apparent success of this film at the box office, I will probably be witness to more of the same in the future, hoping that the next one gets it right.

The casting of Lois Lane was, to put it mildly, horrible. Kate Bosworth is, what, 16? And this is supposed to be five years after the last Superman? What were they thinking? It looks like Brandon Routh studied Chris Reeves and got his Superman/Clark down to a tee, but I don't think Kate Bosworth has ever seen the original Superman movies that so many of us have become endeared to. She doesn't look like a Lois Lane! There were times during the movie where I had to tell myself to get over it. Parker Posey would have made a wonderful Lois Lane, but then the age difference between her and Routh would be too noticeable.Other than that, the movie was great. The rest of the casting was great. Brandon Routh was terrific. Kevin Spacey, as always, a great performance. He gives Lex Luthor a more villainous persona, but I would imagine after all this time, Lex would be a bit frustrated at all his failures.

Review Title: It sank like a stone-rightfully so

Review: This version of the saga remained remarkably true to the original story line that was presented in the original Christopher Reeve version down to the look of the title, the John Williams theme music, Marlo Brando, repeated character lines, etc. I had just watched the original version with my son the week before and it picks up where Superman left off 5 years earlier. Would recommend doing the same. Lots of action and surprises. The thing I enjoyed most about 'Returns' is that it was more comic book, and not comical as in the original, which can be seen in how Lex Luthor is played - truly criminal with no redeeming or endearing qualities (sorry Mr. Hackman - but we know that was Richard Donner's fault anyway).

Review Title: Content to stand in the shadow of its predecessor

Review: The basic premise of Superman Returns is that Superman has returned from an unexplained 5-year absence to find a world that seems to be getting along fine without him, that the woman he loves has moved on and has a family, and that he is- at least in terms of any beings similar to him- completely alone. The amazing thing is, this is the least angst-filled, least melodramatic superhero film in the past 5 years or so. I think the recent trend has been to try to get audiences to empathize with their heroes more by making them more human and actually taking them seriously. Peter Parker battles some very serious demons and is in constant struggle with being Spider-man, the X-Men films are very serious and political and the latest instalment, "The Last Stand," featured some startling and emotionally wrenching revelations, and Batman, well, need I go on? So, here we have Superman in the first new film in almost 20 years. He has his issues, but unlike all the other Super heroes around, he seems to be very solemn about it all. After all, he is Superman, not Clark Kent; Clark Kent is his mask. Obviously a huge nitpick people will have is that Clark comes back the very, very same day as Superman and not one single idiot in the city of Metropolis seems to notice, right? Well, yes, that bugged me too, at first. But then, the more you think about it, that's just how Clark Kent is designed: completely forgettable (except by Jimmy), always in the background, and always overshadowed by the bigger story, which is Superman. David Carradine has a very great speech about Superman at the end of Kill Bill Volume 2 that justifies everything quite nicely to me, so I suggest seeing that if you haven't already. What this movie does a great job of doing is just showing this classic, iconic super hero doing what he does best: saving the day. There's something so refreshing about finally getting that clear view of Superman for the first time after he saves a planeload of passengers from certain doom, and saying with a smile: "Don't let this turn you off to flying, folks. Statistically it's still the safest mode of transportation." But that brings us to the actual plot. It goes for simple, safe, repetitive— tedious, even? And, honestly, it's the kind of plot that just doesn't justify the runtime. Lex Luthor comes up with a ridiculous plan that even in the world of comic books is pretty hard to swallow. He compares himself to Prometheus, how he is so generous with the "mortals" by sharing his wonderful discovery, though planning on killing billions in the process. Lex obviously forgot the last half of that story, where Prometheus is punished and confined to terrible pain for all of eternity. But maybe that's the point. I mean, we all know from the very beginning Lex won't win, he's doomed to lose, that's just how it's meant to be: Superman wins and Lex loses. Written in the scriptures: is, was, ever shall be, in comic strips, TV shows, feature films, living in an ageless universe, for all eternity.Bryan Singer is obviously aware of this. Singer also directed X-Men 1&2, and I think his biggest problem as a director is that he lacks a sense of completion in his works. X-Men is not the kind of movie that you watch, and then once it's over, you want to watch it over again. It's the kind of movie that you watch, and then once it's over, you want to see the next one. The X-Men films were each done with the presumption that there would be a next instalment, and that's fine I guess if you like always being on the edge of your seat waiting for the next one, but when his Superman movie does the same thing and drags past the 2-and-a-half hour mark, there's a problem. If nothing else, the movie establishes that Superman is indeed back, and we should expect to see more of him in the future.Superman Returns is definitely a grand film. It's big, it's loud, it's expensive. I usually don't think to myself, 'hey that looks expensive,' when watching a movie, but I did in this case. It doesn't try for anything new or bold, it doesn't want to, and it's nice to see a super hero movie where the hero is the generic do-gooder, and helps mankind because he really wants to. That's why I think Superman garners more universal appeal than any others. But, honestly, the angsty heroes can be much more interesting. Certainly so with last year's Batman Begins, which I thought was a great, perfect movie, while I though Superman Returns was really good, but probably could have been better.My rating: 7.5/10

Review Title: The Man of Steel is back!
Review: The room is dark, the popcorn is in your lap. You can feel the excitement in the room. Not since the dismal Superman IV, which unfortunately was Christopher Reeve's last portrayal of the last son of Krypton, have we seen the big man on a movie screen. I was so afraid as I am sure many other people had been that my expectations were to high for this film. Lets face it, who could help fill the gap that Reeve left so long ago. Then suddenly you hear the low strings begin the legendary John Williams score and the credits start flying at you in true Superman fashion and you are off on a 2.5 hour escape from reality. The acting was amazing. Not at any point in this film did you feel like you were watching a two dimensional film about paper characters. These were real people with real problems. Kevin Spacey played Lex Luthor brilliantly. Holding back the true dark side of the character until it just comes out of nowhere and grabs you by the throat. Brandon Routh took on the personae of the American icon like it was meant to be. No discredit to him but it helped the transition that the similarities to himself and Reeve were at times uncanny. His Clark Kent was dead on. You just wanted to root for the guy. Bosworth portrayed a more jaded Lois Lane that was bitter about the five year absence of Superman and had finally gotten on with her life. Not only is she engaged but also has a child which really tends to complicate things. Along with great supporting roles by Parker Posey who I loved as Kitty and Frank Langella who brought new life to the already great role started by Jackie Cooper. This was a true experience. If any part of any adult still has in them the little kid that would wrap the towel around their neck and jump off the bed and thought they could fly if they tried just hard enough. Then they will love this film.

I will be the first person to admit I have an obsession with Superman. Still, after re-watching the first two installments of the classic film franchise this week in preparation for Superman Returns, I could at best describe them as tedious. They did have their high points – Christopher Reeve's flawless portrayal of strong-willed Superman and socially-awkward Clark Kent chief among them – but on the whole, the films were dated, ill-conceived, and at most times, simply ridiculous. You've seen the Family Guy send-up on the cellophane "S" from Superman II, right? Yet somehow, Superman Returns embraces the series' somewhat sketchy past and creates wonders with it.Updating the series to the present day without explaining how we can go from 1978 to 2006 in the span of five years was mildly annoying, but worth it upon pay-off. Seeing the 1950s style architecture of the Daily Planet infused with plasma screens and fax machines was a visual treat. I had concerns about the new Super-costume while viewing the trailers – specifically, about the suit's texture and the trademark "S" being too small -- but they were put to rest early on in the film. The suit looks amazing and that "S" is the perfect size, along with Kal-El's infamous codpiece (surely you've heard the rumours?).Brandan Routh does a brilliant job as both Clark Kent and Superman, constantly reminding viewers of Christopher Reeve, while at the same time making the role his own. While Kent is still awkward and doesn't quite fit in, he has far more humanity than in any previous film. Clark is able to show a range of emotions, primarily concerning the ramifications of his five-year absence, but still manages to maintain the air of someone who can easily be written off; someone far too meek to ever be seriously considered as Superman's alter-ego despite his identical height, weight, and piercing, chiseled, vibrant blue eyes (yeah, I've got a new crush too, sue me!).Kevin Spacey retains the campiness of Gene Hackman's original performance as Lex Luthor without making the character ridiculous. While Luthor's plan clearly will remind you of his first scheme in the original Superman (give it time, it won't for long), you actually fear his character and believe he can indeed pull it off this time around. Spacey's portrayal of Luthor in this film is a wonderful transitional piece that means by the sequel, Lex will be far more ruthless and fearsome. I can't wait.Kate Bosworth does a great job updating Lois Lane, making her transition from marriage-loathing, mortgage-fearing, commitment-phobe reporter to engaged and devoted mother-slash-reporter a believable one. She is nothing like the damsel in distress of the first films, and gets beat up quite a bit while displaying feats of tremendous personal strength.With a tremendous support cast, Superman Returns has a jackpot of action scenes, and all flying sequences are simply breath-taking. But a movie is nothing without plot, and this film is concerned with that fact more than any recent superhero film. The science and reasoning behind the main conflict in this film is nothing short of genius, and subplots only add more layers to the alread endearing characters. The little details are attended to, like how Kent can get his job back so easily at the Daily Planet. As a result, you care about these characters, their carefully orchestrated development, and will leave the theatre desperately waiting to see what is in the future for this franchise. X-who? I've stated earlier that the first two films of this franchise are tedious to rewatch, but do yourself a favour: rewatch them. The benefits in doing so will be quite apparent when you get to the theatre for this film.In closing, I believe it goes without saying: This is formal offer to become Bryan Singer's ass monkey for life if I can, in some small way, be apart of the sequel(s).I know you're reading this, Bryan. I am deadly serious.

Maybe I was just the right age or that Christopher Reeves was just the right actor but, as a kid, I loved Superman! This time I wasn't quite sure what to expect. I saw no trailers or previews other than static ads so I went into the theater 'clean'.Was it perfect? No, but then again when compared to a beloved original what is? The casting was great, the writing was not over the top and the effects were amazing. I was a little disappointed in the overall look of the movie. It was a little to slick. Maybe it was just an 80's movie thing but the best part of the originals was the natural look.The number one reason to go see this movie? THE ACTING!!! Kate Bosworth(Lois) and Kevin Spacey(Lex) in particular took their roles to the edge of 'over-done' but successfully reigned them in to create improbable yet realistic characters. Moving Lois away from the original ditsy-girl image can easily be ascribed to the loss of her love and maturing/moving on with her life. Lex is more of a dramatic change but definitely one for the better. Spacey kept Lex from being a silly, demented, Batman-esquire villain instead portraying a sociopathic criminal genius.Brandon Routh(Superman) and James Marsden(Richard Whtie) were more subtle but achieved an amazing depth of emotion. Throughout the movie I was trying to figure out what was 'wrong' with Superman. Routh plays the role with an almost 'alien' distance emotionally. It helps remind us that Superman, as much as we love him, is not one of us. Which compliments the issues being dealt with in the movie perfectly.Marsden on the other hand is the most believable character in the film. At first you write him off as the storyline tie-in. Then he's the wimpy nice guy who doesn't assert himself. In the end you realize he's an average guy who, like any of us, can do great things when push comes to shove but still wants to live his life just not on the edge.All in all I liked this movie a lot. It's not an Oscar winner but it's moving and well done. Compared to the recent comic-book/superhero movies it's simply the only one on this level.

wow this film completely blew me out of the water! It is visually stunning and I was surprised at how good the acting was and how much heart is in this movie. Very little downside, but the movie looked very dark colored, not the subject matter, but the actual tint and color of the film its self was just really dark for some reason. Other than that, this movie rocks!! Brandon Routh has become my Superman for the new generation and I can not wait to see where they take this story in the sequel. I highly recommend you go see this film at least once and if you weren't sure if you liked it, go see it again because many people have said that it was even better the second time around.

Review Title: One of the best comic movies so far...
Review: WEll.. i'm a gr8 fan of super man.. nd for all of u other gr8 superman fans out there,this probably would be the best superman movie u have seen so far. The special effects are just amazing. If you have seen the trailer, there's lot more cool looking stuff in the movie which is worth watching. Looks totally realistic, and they also stuck to the actual character of superman.. like, the way he is in the comics. They din't make him funny or too childish, nor did they make it all serious. Its perfect for a superman movie. Dun't wanna spoil it for u guys. But it sure is worth watching.. U Dun't even have to think twice !

It may be my own fault for setting my expectations too high... but I expected to see an action packed "Return" of Superman. Instead all I received was 2 hours of "relationships" and about 20 total minutes of pretty cool action.Around every corner the pace of the movie crawled along at a snails pace and we are left trying to "care" about Lois and her feelings for Superman.Kevin Spacey does a good job of playing Lex Luthor and the new guy playing Superman does well. Kate Bosworth was BORRRRRRINNNGGGG. Man of Steel? ... More like Man of Steel Magnolias!

This movie blew every other superhero movie out of the water. Its got some great surprises and awesome action. this is by far gonna be the best movie of the summer if not the year. Brandon Routh was awesome to he acted just like Christopher Reeves RIP he looks like him to I saw it the first day it opened and I'm going again tonight. Because ya its that good. Another thing is it keeps to the story well also. All the actors did a fine job even the little boy that play Lois's son is a good actor. If anybody tells you that they didn't like this movie don't listen they must not like movies at all cause this is the not just a movie its the movie that you all need to do yourself a favor a go see it as soon as you can. you shouldn't miss it.

Review Title: So much money spent for so little
Review: As a big fan of the TV show from years ago, and one who really liked Superman I and II, I was looking forward to this version (really liked Singer and Spacey's work in "Suspects"). What a disappointment! Where to start? Well, it was really L--O--N--G. Where are some scissors?! The dead time just ground this to a halt, repeatedly, even out of the gate.Has anybody else figured out that cool FX do not alone a good movie make (George Lucas, you listening?) And in reality, apart from the space shuttle rescue early on, there's not much else that is that cool (what, big crystals growing out of the water--WOW!) Beyond that, almost everything seemed forced, never finding any kind of balance between action and humor--probably in part because it was all but humorless! I'm still of the opinion that this type of "Saturday matinée" fare must have some laughs (hear that George?) After all, that was part of what made S-I and S-II (like Star Wars 1-3) so much fun, some campiness. Totally missing in this latest iteration.I could to on, but others like me will have to see for themselves, but this thing is a total clinker. Oh sure, it looks good, no expense spared, but clearly more should have been spent on the script and E-D-I-T-I-N-G! Throughout I kept thinking of the earlier films, and could not help but think they maybe some movies just should not be remade.

Review Title: The sequel of Superman I & II, Kal-El continues his journey to save the earth and finding his true love.
Review: I went there on the day it opened (June 28th, 2006), and I thought it was well-worth the money. I thought the movie was great, especially my hat-off to Brandon for his great role. He resembles Christopher Reeve so much and his build is just right for the new Superman movie. Kevin spacey plays great as lex, and so the rest of the actors/actresses. The bottom line is, all the characters are played well. One thing I noticed though is that the movie seems to be too heavily emphasized on the story line. I mean, the story is great and all, but this is superhero movies we're talking about, and i think we should have more fun in it (ie. action). Besides this, it was a great movie and i will go again to see it.

Review Title: Held back from greatness by inexperienced screenwriters
Review: Routh, despite barely speaking a dozen lines in the whole movie, fits the role of Superman pretty well. He certainly looks like Superman. But he's really not given much to work with as his character, whether as Clark or Superman, is denied the possibility of exhibiting anything approaching a real emotion. Any chemistry with Kate Bosworth, so critical to the success of the Superman story, is completely absent, and it's hard for us to believe that these two ever loved each other, let alone, still do.The rest of the cast are universally underwritten, with Perry White and Jimmy Olsen being particularly weak. Spacey fails to bring any real originality to the role of Lex Luther and manages to be completely outclassed in every scene by the excellent and under-appreciated Parker Posey. The pychosexual dynamic of Louis-Richard-Superman, something that has the potential for genuine drama, is dismissed. Their child is not only a bad actor, but completely bland as a character. The dramatic potential of his parentage is again, completely wasted. And it beggars belief that the Louis Lane/Superman genepool could produce such a distinctly unattractive child. 'Superman Returns' makes the same mistake of several recent 'epics' – by placing the most dramatic and exciting scene so close to the beginning of the movie, the following two hours are a frustrating wait for an even bigger climax that never comes. Why the plunging aircraft was placed in the first act, and not the last, where it belongs, is a mystery that only the two inexperienced screenwriters can answer.The screenplay is full of such freshman flaws. Several scenes have nothing to do with the actual plot – the aforementioned aircraft of doom and the foiled bank robbery being only the most glaring examples. Such scenes exist to show off the powers of Superman, but shouldn't such scenes also service the plot?Lex Luther's plan for world domination – to produce a dead black rock of a continent in the middle of the freezing North Atlantic, the real estate of which he plans to sell for gazillions – is ludicrous. Who on earth would want to buy land on such an ugly and uninhabitable rock? The biggest question of the movie is how Lex could get so rich with such desperately poor business sense.The movie, however, is not without its successes. The action sequences are genuinely exciting, with the plunging aircraft scene one of the best ever put to film. The production design has its inspired moments, though fall back on the generic New York Art Deco aesthetic a little too often. There are more than a few beautifully composed images of Superman flying and floating around in space, and there is a genuine excitement and satisfaction to be had from the basic premise that an individual - infinitely good and humane and just, incorruptible and undefeatable – can save the world from itself. 'Superman Returns' isn't a bad film by any stretch of the imagination, but it fails to live up to its potential on almost all counts and is, ultimately, a highly disappointing experience.

Review Title: I hated this movie with a passion
Review: All I can say is WHAT THE F%$@#!!!!! This movie was pure garbage! I must confess that Routh did a great job with what he had, but a combination of poor directing, slow pacing, weak story and bad casting choices for Lois and Lex made this practically unwatchable. I was literally about to fall asleep after 20 minutes, I kid you not. And what was up with that kid? I sensed early on that there was a remote chance of him being the son of superman, and I was praying to god on my hands and knees that they weren't going to go there and they did. I walked out of the theater so depressed cause I spent the last year psyched as all hell to see this movie and was counting down the days until its release. When I got home I popped in Superman The Movie on DVD and felt so much better watching my man Reeve flying over Metropolis with John Williams' score...which reminds me the score for this movie was terrible...why didn't they just hire Williams? It was disappointment after disappointment. And they didn't even explain the whole plot of him returning to Krypton; that was very interesting to me and it was barely addressed...LAME! I can understand why so many people like this...its mindless entertainment with incredible CGI effects...I mean our society is over-saturated with this and no kid nowadays could appreciate the brilliance and subtleties of the original superman movie. Oh well, thats just my opinion.

Review Title: As Close to Perfection as I could Hope
Review: It was fantastic. From the effects, to the acting, to the plot. Some things are worth the wait, and this definitely was. You really felt for Superman all the way through. It's not easy being him, and I think this movie demonstrated that nicely. Bryan Singer has proved once again he is one of the go to directors for comic films. I was nervous beyond belief until I started seeing more and more material as the months progressed. I started to feel that Singer had the right idea. After finally seeing it last night, all of my doubts were put to rest. Bravo to the whole production crew. I found every aspect of the film satisfying.
