The film showed a lot of promise but seriously lacked in dialogue. Some of the lines were also re-used from the previous Superman movies, which was fine but.. couldn't they have thought of something more original? Routh was an okay superman, I felt he lacked Reeve's presence but he did a satisfactory job. I also feel there's a lack of chemistry between his character and bosworth's character. They could have developed the characters further, Lex's cronies hardly muttered any dialogue, jimmy olsen was mostly irrelevant and so was perry white. Lex's plot to take over the world was a bit simplistic. A real pity really, the movie could have been a lot better! On the other hand the CG effects were fantastic, great soundtrack and the intergalactic credits brings a tear to my eye. Overall, it's still a good movie and brings back the good ol' superman I and II days.

Review Title: By far my favorite movie of the summer
Review: I should preface this review by saying I'm a big fan of the first two Christopher Reeve Superman movies, but pretty much hate the other two. So the fact that this one is being made as a sequel to Superman 2 while ignoring 3 & 4 was just right up my alley.This film really gave me everything I wanted from a Superman movie, everything I'd hoped I was going to get. I thought all of the performances were great, I loved the story, I loved the fact that the action grew out of the story rather than the other way around. I can't think of anything I didn't like about the movie, to be honest. I can't fathom why so many people are giving it negative reviews.The biggest hurdle for any Superman movie is that he is so strong and so unstoppable that finding a credible threat to him, a hurdle for him to overcome, is very difficult to find and make entertaining. This film accomplishes that difficult task. It also gives a great love story, and some incredible action sequences. I haven't seen Pirates 2 yet, but this is by far my favorite movie of the summer to this point.

What a disappointment. From the opening credits, to the costumes, to the heavy dialog, to the special effects, to the plot, this movie goes out of its way to recreate nostalgia for the original superman movie series. What a stupid direction to take. I don't go to see movies to bring back the 1980s!! What were they thinking by making this new entry in the series feel like it was actually filmed in the 80s and left in the vault. There are a couple outstanding things in this movie. Kevin Spacey gives a great performance, hopefully reclaiming his reputation from the last few clunkers he's done. And Clark Kent(Brandon Routh) is well cast for his looks and charm. i wouldn't mind seeing him in another movie. However, lex's team of thugs are comical and unconvincing, having almost apelike stupidity--in one scene, one of them hides under a table when he is afraid!!!! i mean, come on. And parker poesy looks near tears from boredom in this miscast role. I find her funny in most other films, but why she was chosen for this ridiculous role makes no sense to me. Kate Bosworth isn't exactly a shining star. there are several moments in the movie where her dialog made me cringe, and more moments where it must have made the director cringe as well, and so she is left just nodding her head in response to other actors. there is no spark of romance between any of the actors. my advice is to wait a week and go see pirates of the Caribbean

I'll have to say, I was pretty unimpressed by this movie. I thought the action scenes were great, but I think they could have added another 20 minutes worth. The last half an hour just seemed to drag on and made the movie pretty anti-climatic. Although I loved seeing Lex beat the snot out of Superman, I also wish they'd feature another villain, someone who he could actually have a real fight. Another complaint I had was the choice to play Lois. Given she is very good looking, she was just way too young. This is supposed to be a later movie and she just didn't portray a mother of a toddler very well. I would still suggest this movie to anyone, because it is Superman and it was watchable, however it's probably on the low end of what I would comfortably suggest to someone to watch. The only other thing I can suggest is not to see it at an IMAX theater. The 3-D glasses were a very big distraction and I don't think it added very much to anything.

Review Title: Clichéd, repetitive, bland, onlY a few good moments
Review: I'll write a more detailed review later with more support for my inquiries about this movie, but for now i just want to say: This movie is mediocre. IT feels like every other superhero movie, and has tons of clichés and unbelievable parts, and things that don't make sense. Its very repetitive, it seems as if more than half the scenes are the exact same things: slow building disaster with stuff rattling and people getting scared, building music as Clark Kent becomes superman, him saving everyone, then quiet, ethereal music as he descends to the ground with everyone in awe. HOW MANY TIMES DO I HAVE TO SEE THAT? There are many things that are stupid and unbelievable, such as one scene where superman is saving everyone form their deaths, i wondered, "well what about the people on all the other city blocks? They're all dying right now!" OR when two cops unload on a criminal's back, not a single bullet goes into his head or neck or arms, every single bullet lands perfectly in the robber's bulletproof vest! And then the superhero fires his huge machine gun at superman for about half a minute as superman walks towards him, the bullets bouncing off Superman's chest. How long should it take to realize that shooting him Isn't FREAKING WORKING! Only a few things stand out in this movie: Kevin Spacey, who stands out in every movie, the architecture and art direction of some sets, such as the alien, desolate krypto-continent that springs up, and the ice cave. The 2 and a half hour should have been 90 minutes. Why do they half to stretch these films that are not that deep for so long? Why is every director afraid to try something new with these movies! Superman is bland and clichéd! WHAT HAS Happened TO Hollywood? WE DON'T NEED MORE SEQUELS OR REMAKES!

Alright...i'm not one of those comic book junkies but i do enjoy watching comics made into movies. I don't know if this movie was "true" to the comic book (most comic books made into movies aren't) but i do know that if you want to see a movie that has action, suspense, twists, and a little bit of romance then this is the movie to see. I was afraid that Brandon Routh wouldn't be able to fill the shoes left behind by Christopher Reeve but i believe that those shoes are now his! The movie was well written and directed...of course what else would you expect from the genius that is Bryan Singer? This movie ranks on my list of the top movies to see this summer. And FYI to girls who aren't interested in this kinda stuff...Brandon Routh has the sexiest voice i think i have ever heard. Brandon commands the screen and i can't wait to see him in the next Superman movie! This is definitely going to become a classic! Brandon Routh was born for the role of Superman...at least in my opinion. I urge everyone to go see it and enjoy! Trust me....it's worth the seven bucks. Let me know what you think of it after you see it! It blew my mind!!

I just saw Superman returns last night, and i think it is in my top 5 favorite movies ever, maybe top 2. The acting was tremendous, i just liked every aspect of this movie! Although i had to listen to some idiot snoring through the entire movie, that still didn't ruin it for me, I was just so intrigued by the entire film. I think every one (superman fan or not) should get out and see this movie, this film will turn you into a fan. I can't wait to see what his son does in the future!This was definitely better then any other super hero movie i've seen yet, better then that weak x-men 3, even better then spider man 2. I can't think of any equal to this movie.

Overall I liked the new special effects and action sequences, however, I went back and watched the original Superman and then i realized how much of the original script is in Superman Returns. It kind of disappointed me a bit. Many word for word speeches and storyline based events were near identical.I would of hoped for a Lex Luther more like the Lex Luther in Smallville, versus the original Lex Luther character. The Smallville version is more credible and realistic in many ways. The character used in the movie is, well, frankly, an idiot. I am not knocking the actors, I believe they played the roles perfectly. However the characters needed to be tweaked to be brought into realistic view in the 21st century. Yes, man flying is now credible, but not the villain. His counterparts are also complete idiots, although somewhat better than the original.The movie left room for improvement by introducing new sub plots and story lines that can be built upon in the next movie. Overall, I liked the movie, but it left me somewhat needy. Not completely satisfied.

I couldn't agree more...i have been one of the lucky few to watch the movie before its release in India as i have a jack on the censorship panel but never the less.. Bryan u have outdone yourself than ever before. The look and feel of the old superman movies has been maintained yet, the movie amazes u with the cgi wizardry and the composites and better yet , emotion. Brandon is definitely the next best thing to Christopher reeves and kudos for the perfect choice. He emotes precisely to the hilt for both the characters, Clark as well as Kal El. Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor is frankly better than Gene Hackman. 10 on 10 to him.The edit is superb and so is the background score. the story lacks slightly towards the end, in terms of showing superman as a superhero, but what the heck!! u don't even mind it(any ways its about his return not his heroics)...in fact i consider it an Honor to watch a superman movie to be made after my birth. Its just about everything that u wanted to see in a flick which starred your childhood hero. I got goosebumps while watching the superman entry seq. the vision shown by Bryan Singer is par excellence. And the best part is the dedication of the movie to Christopher and Dana Reeves in the end scroll.

Review Title: To those who compared it to Batman Begins...you were wrong
Review: I went into this movie with high expectations, despite what I had found to be rather disappointing trailers. I had heard from a friend who had seen another pre-showing of the movie that it was comparable to Batman Begins. I have to say, though, my friend was wrong. Superman Returns absolutely blew away Batman Begins. Despite the overly dramatic and under thought out evil plot conceived by Lex Luthor, the overall storyline and construction of the movie is one of the best I have ever seen. The movie had a poetry that Batman Begins lacked, and, more importantly, no Katie Homes-like love interest.Kate Bosworth played her role of Lois Lane impeccably...keeping the quirks of the former Lois Lane, namely, an inability to spell ("How many 'f's in catastrophic?"), while casting away the intense stupidity of Margot Kidder's Lois Lane.The spark between Bosworth and Routh deserves the highest praise for a movie romance...that is, it was believable.There was no over-played emotions or over-dramatized characterization, which was a relief. Given the situation Superman comes back to, it would have been easy for Routh to make his character a saggy sack of post-adolescent angst, which would make any movie of similar length intolerable.And, yes, this movie is long. It begins a little slow...but it's hard to think of something to make it much better. Beautiful cinematography, great character development, applaudable acting...definitely worth seeing again.

Review Title: Superman Returns sure wasn't fun to watch.

Review: That's where this stupid movie belongs! IN THE TRASH! See the excellent originals! This was one of the worst movies I've ever seen! So Called sequel! Whatever! I can't recommend this horrible movie to a dog! I hated this film with a passion! I can't believe they are "HONORING THE VISION OF RICHARD DONNER!"What the hell are they talking about? Now I know all of Hollywood is high as a kite! Or should I say Superman! GARBAGE! Anyone who can honestly say that this movie is good, has no idea what the hell a good movie is! SERIOUSLY! Easily of the the worst movies ever! No joke!Save yourself from wasting 3 hours of your precious life and at least see the originals!

Review Title: Truth, Justice, and...a lame story line
Review: Isn't Superman supposed to stand for, "Truth, Justice, and the American Way"? I thought he was, and that is what I believed growing up as a kid. In fact, his motto greatly influenced me and my sense of patriotism as a young American. But sadly, Superman returns to earth a lesser super hero. He no longer stands for truth, justice, and the American way. No, certainly not. And the movie clearly makes this statement. Now he stands for, (and I quote), "Truth, justice, and all that other stuff." The film makers CANNOT bring themselves to stand firm with an American Hero. Perhaps in the next installment of this crappy movie series Superman can team up with some Islamic villains or perhaps fight for the COMMUNIST way. He could go about the world forcing each person to give according to their means, and receive according to their needs. Besides that, Superman comes off as a CREEPY STALKER. Despite the fact that Lois Lane has moved on, gotten married, had a child, and appears to be happy with her new family, Superman attempts to woo her away from that. First by spying on her inside her house, and then by taking her for a flight...in a way that her mortal husband cannot possibly measure up to. Also, Lois Lane comes off as a terrible person. She seems completely distant from her loving husband and needy child. I found myself feeling sorry for "Cyclops" and his son. And she is rude, abrupt, and TOTALLY self centered. If I were the Man of Steel, I believe I could EASILY find a better gal than Lois Lane. Speaking of the son, in my opinion, "Cyclops" is his father, not Superman. Clearly, the movie suggests that Superman is his biological father, but it takes more than that to be a dad. And "Cyclops" comes off as a real father figure. Then there is Lex Luthor and his LAME PLOT. He wants to grow some crystals...why? He doesn't even really know. What he ends up doing is growing some crystals so that he and his henchman have a new place to hang out and play cards. Yes, you read that right. Their big plot is to grow a gigantic crystal island and sit around and play cards. Lex had a nice house that he stole from the old lady. Could they not have just been happy playing cards down in his basement? This movie was a total let down. Also, Brandon Routh is a re-incarnation of Christopher Reeves, and not a "New Superman." I think Routh is a good, talented actor, but they should have cast Michael O'hearn as Superman. He would have been much better. If you ever get a chance to see a digital short movie called "WORLD'S FINEST," you will see Michael O'hearn portraying both Clark Kent and Superman, and doing a great job. He looks more like the Superman I imagine. But then again, in my mind, Superman STILL stands for TRUTH, JUSTICE, AND THE American WAY.

Review Title: Stunning effects, sturdy Superman performances, good score...
A chick flick disguised as a superhero film
Review: This movie was boring. There, I've said it. Now you can get angry with me. There were several great action scenes in "Superman Returns" but they were strung together by a sappy and slow storyline. This movie is soft -- and on more than one level. Did anyone else wonder why there seemed to be a retro-look for the movie. When I write, retro, I mean it looked like it the set and costume designs were straight from the 1940s (e.g. Lois Lane was not dressed as a woman in the late twentieth to twenty-first century). Why was this? But the softness of which I write comes into play with the way Lois appears in the film. Director Bryan Singer seemed to choose the soft focus lenses that were used on actresses back in the 1940s. Check out a film from that period and you'll know what I mean. But the word, "soft", can also be applied to the storyline with it's heavy focus on the romance between the intrepid reporter and the "man of steel". Too much tenderness for a superhero film. If you enjoyed it, great, but for the rest of you who are expecting an "X-Men"/"Spiderman"/"Batman" type of film, save a bundle and rent the original "Superman" directed by Richard Donner. Much better than this sad return.

As mentioned by the previous commentator. I will not say anything about the plot of the movie, except for the fact that is without doubt the best superhero movie to date. I was 3 years old when the original came out and I've never stopped being a fan. I remember this movie being talked about for almost ten years. And believe it or not.. it has been worth it. A lot of hidden tributes in the movie as well, which only true Superman fans will notice. Hat off to Bryan Singer for pulling off a very very difficult task, and Brandon Routh for filling a very big pair of red boots! Awesome movie.... absolutely awesome! The only thing that I didn't like, and I say the only thing.. was that Kate Bosworth played the part of Lois Lane. I didn't think she fit the role if you ask me. She was to clean, proper, young, beautiful and the Lois Lane we all remember was somewhat a roughneck, older, normal looking. But other than that.. everyone in the movie has similarities to every original character.

Review Title: It's okay, but FAR from great thanks to weak script

Review: Super Returns- I loved this movie, plain and simple! The actors fit perfectly for their roles and did a great job. You really feel they are the actual characters, which is the difference between good and bad acting. The effects were stellar. It didn't look fake or anything. Tbe plot was good too. I found myself getting so emotional during certain scenes. The movie captivates you when you first meet Brandon Routh (Superman). He is the perfect Superman. Why? He actually looks like the very respected Christopher Reeves. It's uncanny really. He is also very believable. I admit I had my doubts since I never heard of Mr. Routh before. Also, my childhood favorite superhero was Superman. I never thought this movie would be able to capture all the elements of why Superman was the greatest, but it did! I just hope there is a sequel. I do not want to give anything away. When you see this movie, you will know why. There is so much more to tell!! We shall see.

Review Title: Superman - sheesh, what more can one say?
Review: You cannot go to this movie and think it's going to be either good or bad. You are going to be better off going only with knowledge this is a movie about Superman. Everything else falls into place.Why start a review this way? Knowing what I know about the Superman legacy and reading the other reviews tells me too much "personal perception" is applied.Go for the characters and the story. You will find satisfaction. Just brace yourself for some things that the average Superman fan may not expect or want to experience. But there is definitely a lot that satisfies the normal Superman fan. Love, hate, fear, comedy, drama excitement, anticipation, and even the occasional let-down.Now for my own personal perception. This was more than just excellent; more than just super! It was a great reunion with the man of steel and his friends and family - even his enemies. I loved the performances by everyone. Each character had a classic moment. You may have heard complaints about some of them but ignore the complaints. Posey had some very good comical and emotional moments although at times, her character was annoying, as I am sure it was intended. Kal Penn got his shots in, too. I think this was actually a great part for him and his career. Just getting his mug on the screen was enough to show that he does not have to stay committed to sophomoric comedy, although it appears, for now, that's all he is involved in except for Superman.OK, enough of the characters. The movie was in no way perfect. It was definitely an honor to the legacy and to the director. But I do have some misgivings which, because of the excitement of seeing "Supes" back in action, have no bearing against this event in anyway. The only thing is, well, heroes of any kind are never quite what we build them up to be.Being a fan of Smallville, I always have a problem with the fact that Kryptonite never seems to have the same impact on Superman/boy. As it is with the TV program, so it goes with the movie. And with that said, the only other questionable concern I had was Lex's unimaginable plot. For me, it nearly approached "unacceptable" for quality movie status. Still, this is the comics on screen, so it is somewhat forgivable.Well, that's enough. Thank you Brian Singer and Brandon Routh for bringing Superman back to life. Keep it real!

I was very pleased to see the opening with Marlon Brando's voice as Jor-El, and found the irony throughout the film between father and son to be quite interesting... Also, I was glad that the movie kept to the scores of John Williams from the original theme in the Christopher Reeves movies. The opening credits indeed were very familiar to the Superman movies most fans are used to seeing, but with a touch of updated technology-- the movie throughout carried incredible special effects. Brandon Routh not just looks, talks, but also acts like the Clark Kent everyone knows. Kate Bosworth as Lois was different, but different in a positive way for the new generation. And Kevin Spacey was excellent as Lex Luther! He was a combination of Lex from "Smallville" and a little Gene Hackman, but with more fury. All in all, incredibly fun to watch, and very realistic for the most part (even a sonic boom in the atmosphere as Superman takes off). I feel like there should have been a little more to the story. In several parts it felt like watching the first Superman from Richard Donner. However, I would easily see this one again, over, and over! And by all means, I hope this cast/crew continue on this successful franchise! The legendary Superman has been kept with the tradition and respect it deserves.

Review Title: Good, but not great, revival of the franchise
Review: As long as you're not expecting a mind-blowing, over-the-top experience, the first Superman sequel in many years is a pretty fair revival of the franchise. Brandon Routh looks and acts like he could have been cloned from Chris Reeve to play the Man of Steel, which works quite nicely for both continuity and dramatic quality. Kevin Spacey is actually an upgrade as nemesis Lex Luthor; but Kate Bosworth comes across as a relatively bland Lois Lane; Parker Posey (who clearly would have been a better choice for Lois) adds a delightful note of comic relief as Luthor's bimbo moll.The story opens five years after Supe abruptly zipped off to explore whatever remnants of his home planet, Krypton, might still exist in the universe. No one knew where he was, or if he would ever return, so the world moved on. Most notably, Lois did. When our hero shows up at the Daily Planet in his Clark Kent persona with his crush on her intact, he finds her with a son and a beau (James Marsden), who unfortunately is Perry White's nephew and a great guy in his own right. But they're not married, so hope remains for our lovelorn representative of Truth, Justice, etc. Meanwhile, Lex got out of jail and has started brewing yet another grand scheme for world domination. Killing the newly-returned Superman becomes another perk of his plot.The f/x are first-rate, including some variations on how Superman maneuvers in flight. Some of the epic-scale crises and heroics offer more in their look and sound than in the logic of the situation. Director Bryan Singer handled the first two X-Men movies (both superior to the third) nicely, and mixes in some fine elements for this adventure, including a fair number of laughs for a non-comedy. He wisely carries over John Williams' memorable score from the Reeves films, and honors the 1950s TV series many of us remember fondly with several references, and cameos for Jack Larson (Jimmy Olsen) and Noel Neill (one of two who played Lois).On the downside, there's more moping and mooning in the lengthy running time than we really needed - especially in the opening jumble of backstairs and setup; and again in the climactic battle and its aftermath. Also, Lex's latest exercise in megalomania makes even less sense than usual for such fantasies, in how he decided to use the powers he'd ever-so-evilly acquired. Perhaps he conferred with Austin Powers' Dr. Evil, when he should have consulted James Bond's Dr. No. Even with these shortcomings, I'll be ready for the promised sequel long before its likely release date.

Review Title: 'Superman Returns', to put it simply, comes up short
Review: Superman Returns;; The plot has Superman returning to Earth after disappearing five years earlier, without any explanation. He heard that astronomers discovered what's remaining of Krypton, his home planet, and he simply wanted to go and see if it was true for himself.In doing so, he left his romance with Daily Planet reporter Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth) out to dry. He didn't even say goodbye. Meanwhile, Lois was so upset at being dumped that she wrote an artice about why the world doesn't need Superman and won a Pulitzer for it.Meanwhile, master crook Lex Luthor has used Superman's absence to plot his criminal empire. Looking for advanced alien technology, he's even burgled our hero's Fortress of Solitude at the North Pole. There he takes crystals from Krypton, and plans to build his own continent in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean, which would result in the sinking of the America's. It's up to Superman to save the world, yet again.By the end of Superman, I'd realized something: Throughout the 150 minute running time, I had only about 20 minutes of fun. And for a superhero movie, that presents a big problem.With a budget of nearly 260 million, one should expect dazzling special effects, which it does, for the most part. The sequence pre-Supe's return has him rescuing a plummeting jet on which Lois is a passenger, and it's truly seamless. Also when Lex's continent grows up through the middle of a boat on which Lois and her son are aboard. It really is neat stuff. But they spent too much time of the flash and not enough on the fun.There are great superhero movies, like Batman Begins, or Spider-Man 2. There are the others on the other half of the chart, such as Elektra or The Punisher. 'Superman Returns' falls somewhere in between, off the fence of greatness, but steering clear of absurdity. I'm sure die-hard Superman fans will cherish this film, but I suppose I'm not a Superman fan.2.5 out of 4

As a Marvel comic book fan, I am interested in the plot and the main themes of any super hero movie that is available to watch. To me a excellent movie would stick to the plot and not jump to different subjects to make the story confusing to the viewers. The major theme of the movie to me is known as moral of the story and what it emphasizes and symbolizes through the whole movie. As a fan of the X men and X Men United, I give Bryan Singer two thumbs up for using hints or "metaphors" in order to extend the story. In Superman Returns there were various dialouges with Clark and Lois which really brought upon clues that would lead to the secret of Lois's child, Jason. Therefore, this signals the audience as a clue that will upbring a sequel to this movie.Therefore, the special effects and the physics used in this film didn't really made the movie seem real. I think that the computer animation and effects was the only thing that really saved the movie from being a flop. There were some parts of the film that really made Superman effects unreal and as common sense it didn't seem logical. Different times in the film Lois could have been seriously injured or died. She seemed too fine. ***************SPOILER**************** I thought the plot that led to Jason being Superman's son seemed very confusing. I really hadn't figured out whether or not this film is a continuation of the original Superman movies.This movie really didn't show Superman's well true personality. I think that Superman was used too much of a publicity and a big shot seeking for only glory and a attention seeker. This didn't show his true character. ***************SPOILER**************** I didn't really understand the subplot of how Richard came into Lois's life. There was definitely no background of Superman's past that led to him leaving Lois and the rest of mankind in order to find the remains of the Planet Krpyton. This story and the main plot really lacked emotions and heart. Well,lastly, what really troubled me was the main overall theme of the movie.*****************spoiler************************ Lois Lane lied about her appeal and love of Superman to Richard. Basically, I do not think that lying about her relationship was the best option. I guess you could say that the theme of this movie is hope for a savior to arise. But to tell you the truth, I really do not like how this movie is based on Christainty on comparisons to Jesus/Moses. That was one of Singer's plans for this movie to be enjoyable to everyone including religion... So yea this is my overall analysis on Superman Returns

Review Title: Superman saved by Spacey and special effects
Review: The man of steel has returned to the big screen with his first motion picture in over 20 years. But with a borderline corny script and head-scratching casting choices, will he have enough strength to save this movie from despair?In short, yes. Superman Returns is an exciting film with quirky moments of comic (no pun intended) relief and not-so-cheap thrills. The seemingly limitless abilities of the special effects team serve as much of the life support for the film. In what would be an otherwise laughable attempt to showcase Clark Kent's ability to fly, see through walls and lift airplanes, the effects team proves to be the real hero of Superman Returns.The real hit-or-miss part of the film is its cast. In an awkward attempt to flex his dramatic muscles, Kal Penn plays Stanford, one of Lex Luthor's partners in crime. With little to no lines (give or take 2 words), Penn nonsensically draws attention to himself if not only for his post Harold and Kumar fame, for a few long takes that, even if not on purpose, continue to stress the fact that he is in the film.With the choice of the relatively unknown Brandon Routh as Clark Kent, it is a wonder how they could find a virtual no name to play Superman but refused to for Lex Luthor's goons. In any event, Routh is a perfect example of being able to look but not play the part. His best moments come when he isn't saying anything at all. While his acting seems somewhat forced as Superman, he plays Kent's awkward antics with relatively comfortable ease.Rough casting aside, Kevin Spacey's portrayal of Lex Luthor outshines most of the cast put together. He is at once calm and vengeful, and not the least bit sympathetic. Bringing life to much of his scenes, his mere presence on screen puts the viewer on edge.Even with its flaws, the film doesn't cease to stay interesting...until the end. At least a half hour could have been cut out of its 154 minutes. Don't be surprised to find yourself arguing with your friends about when it SHOULD have ended.But if you cut out the lagging last portion, what is left is a film that accomplished what it set out to do. It is a simple and fun film that will have your heart racing at Superman's every attempt to save the world. While not always pleasing to the ears, Superman Returns is surely a feast for the eyes and is worth seeing once, but probably only once.

I admit to having some reservations about this movie...not that I dislike Superman. To the contrary, he's always been my favorite superhero. I grew up during the Man Of Steel's golden age era between the covers of DC Comics. No, I experienced trepidation because so much time had passed since the previous film, the horrendous "Superman IV, The Quest For Peace." Add to that, the fact that, with the exception of archival voice-over material from the late Marlon Brando, none of the original actors were returning to the franchise. I was not bolstered by the Prue-title sequence which seemed decadent, and shamelessly puerile considering that no one in the audience had any reason to have confidence in this movie.I'm elated to report that my fears had no basis. Bryan Singer did one hell of a job bringing Superman back to life (or back to relevance, depending on how you view the situation). By the end, I came to realize what this movie was really about. The opening hook did have its place--it was not meant to celebrate the grandeur of an aging, long underwear hero. To the contrary, it was a reaffirmation--a rededication. Superman had lost his place. This film was about the painful journey we all sometimes have to make; it's about finding your place in a world where you no longer seem to fit in. Brandon Routhe emotes this well, both as Kal-El, but somehow, even more profoundly, in his alter ego, Clark Kent. It's in the crestfallen looks...the bittersweet caesura. The notion that he may not be able to reintegrate into society overshadows every scene in the movie in a way that's poignant, and significant.The movie is long, but don't let that deter you. There's a huge payoff at the end. You will be well rewarded for the time you spend watching it.Kate Bosworth was awesome as Lois Lane. Perfect casting.Frank Langella was amazing in the unusual role, for him, of Perry White.Kevin Spacey is always top notch. He could do a commercial for Rolaids, and it would be a masterpiece.What can I say, I'm buying the DVD when it comes out.

I was skeptical after seeing the previews and then read how Bryan Singer and the two screenwriters were big fans of the original 1978 Classic by Richard Donner, so I wasn't sure what to expect when seeing the film.It is a great film - really captures the essence of the original,has fantastic action sequences and some good surprises thrown in.On the constructive side, my friend and I were asking ourselves, was the world really at stake, and perhaps it would've been nice to see more of a dilemma within Clark Kent when he returns, maybe a scene with Martha regarding his thinking about donning on the red cape and tights.Well worth watching.

Since I am such a huge Superman fan it's hard to say bad things about it. It did have a slow start, but it got better. I loved the movie.I was a little worried in the beginning. It began very slowly. But once Clark Kent arrived back in Metropolis, the story began to take off (like a speeding bullet). And then Superman arrived on screen and he saved the day. It is a little more of a chick flick (like the director said), but still has quite a few action packed sequences. I hope there is another sequel, because it was ended in such a way, that there could be more to come. I will head back to the theater to see it again (to catch anything I may have missed).

Review Title: Great special effects, but not that great
Review: OK, it's a good movie so it gets 7 out of 10. But it's dragged out far too long, and in my opinion, the key actors are too young to pull off their "perceived maturity". I mean, if Superman's been gone for the past 5 years, and we consider that it's a sequel to Superman II, how come he still looks like he's 18 years old, know what I mean? Bosworth herself is only 23 years old and she even looks younger than her age.But there are some nice surprises and Kevin Spacey's performance, although short, is very good. I like the plot though, I just wish they had characters (as opposed to playing characters) to deliver it a little better. Clark for example, spends almost all his on screen time just driving the point that he acts like a dork. (Clark = Superman? nah!).There's something missing about this movie - but I guess I let my love for the hero and my knowledge of the past superman movies/stories fill in the gaps. My hopes were up too high maybe. The special effects are great but that goes without saying for any Hollywood movie during the past decade - bigger and better to try to get you to buy that popcorn. Expect a good movie, and that's what you'll get - good.

Review Title: A fun little ride, if anything at all
Review: I didn't expect a whole lot from this movie, initially. I didn't like the trailers or spots except for one, which finally convinced me to see it anyway.In the end, it was...kinda worth it. I guess. The story and the acting are decent enough to take the entire family or "lady"/"guy" friends with you, but don't be expecting a whole lot of action and lots of impressive shots of Superman on the go. But at the same time, don't be expecting a lot for character development and a story that will separate Superman from the rest.In reality, its one of those slam bang summer movies that'll make you forget about it once you get out of the theater. Considering director Singer did the relatively entertaining X-MEN and X2 movies, that's a pretty big letdown. There are parts where they try to make Clark Kent into Peter Parker with the whole "pathetic nerd" stereotype, but it doesn't flow well here. Mostly in part because Peter is...well, human and believable. Clark obviously isn't, he's not even human for one. So there were some things that couldn't add or make up, instead of sticking with an "outsider" theme (which is much more appropriate), they did that instead.Lois Lane herself was pretty interesting...to look at, anyway. Kidding aside, she (being pretty critical to the plot) did her job and had some interesting moments to help balance out the whole Superman-Lois thing. The only other noteworthy character was Kevin Spacey as the infamous Lex Luthor, possibly the best actor in the entire movie. His lines and the jokes were worth most of my admission price, I can see why the fans really wanted him to be Lex.Jimmy Olsen, which is the only OTHER character I can think of that's worth mentioning, tries to be the comic relief here. Purely hit or miss, i'll let you decide on him.In short, if you don't like decent-development and writing, then you're not going to like this movie. I won't say anything about the story except for the fact its a cliché'd plot with average execution (and a nice little twist). It's not going to bring the house down like Spiderman or cause fans to just up with glee like Batman Begins, but it will provide average entertainment for those who just wanna casually see another Superhero film that's brought somewhat more faithfully to the big screen.But if you're expecting the big "Superman Comeback"...lemmie say this, don't give your hopes up. Just look for a decent movie to pass the time with your girl/boyfriend or family and you'll do just fine.

Review Title: The Legend Lives On! Sit back, relax and enjoy it.  The S is back!
Review: What an amazing job Bryan Singer has done with Superman Returns. Its hard to imagine anyone doing a better job of it. It has stayed very true to the 1978 Christopher Reeve version and also to Superman II. While I don't want to give anything away from the movie, all I can say is just see it. Brandon Routh is excellent as Clark Kent/Superman. After reading some of the rubbishing reports of Routh's performance, I cannot wonder but think if they had been watching the same movie. Routh has picked up so many of Reeve's Superman mannerisms/style that it is great to watch. Which was the most important part for me, being that Reeve has always been the definitive Superman in my eyes. The soundtrack is amazing as well. so well done and i was interested to see how a different composer would add his own unique style to the already John William's masterpiece. And John Otto has done it very well.The whole movie was a big nostalgia trip, being 27 years since I saw the 1978 version. The care that director Singer has shown in this movie is amazing. Now I cant wait for the news of the sequel!

It's a rather decent movie but I have to give it a rating of 4 because the Lois Lane character is rather bland and boring and a good deal of the film revolves around the Superman / Claark - Lois relationship. I'm disappointed in this area because all previous Lois Lane's have had a lot of back bone and spunk. They were strong women. This Lois as afore mentioned is just bland and without personality who has a boring child and husband or partner( a bit unclear). Otherwise it's quite an enjoyable film. The New superman is good, Kevin Spacey as Lex Luther is great and so is Parker Posey. Good to see Jack Larson & Noel Neal get some work out of it as well. Visual effects are excellent but the movie should have had a bit more action or been shorter or a better Lois. Cheers to all. Diego

Review Title: Bruce Ratner, this is how you make a good comic book movie
Review: I'm not great with words, so I'll be brief.By the time I was done watching this movie, I felt closer to people, closer to my friends/colleagues.I felt good about myself. I can't put a finger on why, but the movie made me feel this way.Even though I thought Kevin Spacey was sort of flat and the diabolical plan he came up with was sort of lame, it didn't faze me like a weak idea normally would.I spent $12.50 watching this movie (IMAX), and it was worth every cent.I spent $0 watching X3 and still felt cheated.

This is not a new, original movie... like "Batman Begins". In fact, little is new, and that is disappointing. The tired old footage of Marlon Brando was not an homage, it was a mistake. I would have preferred to see Jor-El re-cast, with maybe Paul Newman. It was a bad move. Next, they ripped of many of the musical themes from the first movie; those too were tired. I counted at least 3 themes borrowed. The title sequence was borrowed. There was yet another romantic flight scene. I felt like I was watching a re-make of the first movie, with few exceptions. Superman should have been entirely made from whole cloth. It would have made the difference between an average summer Hollyweird "blockbuster', and an epic. Singer chose average.That brings me to Singer, probably one of the worst directors in Hollyweird today. In addition to the mistakes above, Singer infused this movie with little soul. The emotions were plastic, and I never really cared for any of the characters by the end of the movie. The special effects are standard fare; nothing new or exciting. Yes, better than the original, but that is not saying much. Compared to other current movies, the effects were just as bland as the next one. Singer has a habit of making plastic films, like X-Men. There is little difference between Singer's Superman and X-Men.The plot sucked. Once again, we get the old Lex Luthor takes over the world plot. Christ.... imagine if they gave Lex a break, and focused on a different arch enemy. It would have made the franchise fresh. Nope. Can't do that. Gotta stick to the tired Lex Luthor world domination / kill Superman plot. Nothing real inventive in the plot, which again borrows from the first movie.Overall, a very forgettable movie. To make it worse, two mongoloided retards sat next to me and talked throughout the whole movie, even after they were asked to stop. When they weren't talking, one of them was sucking snot out of his nasal cavity and into his stomach. This went on and on. They were actually retards, so pointing that out to them might not have been the kindest thing I have ever done. It was satisfying after 2.5 hours of snot sucking, however.The best part of the movie was the hotdog I ate before it started.

Review Title: Alright,but was expecting a lot more!
I did not enjoy the movie
Review: I apologize for the honesty, but this movie did not move me-except to walk out.I will state that I am a huge fan of superheroics, but the whole production was meh. A rehash of the first Superman movie, in my opinion, that was only rectified by the second movie-just reminded me why Superman is a bankrupt property.To my mind Spacey was unwatchable, and the scenes he was in managed to make Parker Posey a drag...Dang, I won't waste your time, and I apologize again, but the Lex Luthor movie isn't the one I'd care to see-and for god's sake, don't take a gal to it!K all-have a great Fourth of July--maybe go watch "Click" or better yet "Cars"-anything... something...Peace! Go barbebeque and explode fireworks :-D

Okay, I was never a huge Superman fan but did enjoy them. I loved this one! I thought the special effects were amazing and Brandon Routh did an outstanding job! Perhaps some of the plot didn't make sense, but it seems like they are setting it up for a sequel and so forth. I loved X-Men and didn't go into this movie thinking I would love it, but I did. I'm glad they casted someone who isn't a huge movie star, rather than Josh Hartnett or anyone else who was considered to play the part. I am hoping the legacy of Superman will continue and I could only imagine how the special effects will be in future films. 4 stars for Warner Brothers and for Brandon.

Review Title: Not quite Batman Begins...but still good stuff!
Review: Here's all the negatives I heard about this movie before going in: (1) neither Bosworth nor Routh's performances were any good, (2) Spacey's Luthor was too circus-y, (3) the special effects were sub-par, and (4) the plot was weak and you didn't care about the characters. LET ME DISPEL ALL OF THOSE RUMORS NOW. This movie was great. I cared for the characters, and generally the acting was great. The special effects (aside from the opening credits sequence) were pretty impressive and almost seamless. True fans of the original movies will find numerous (funny) homages paid to those classics. They kept a lot of the original score composed by John Williams, who is without a doubt the greatest composer of our generation. Everyone recognizes this score...in a couple hundred years people will be talking about John Williams the way we talk about Mozart, Bach, Brahms, Beethoven, and Strauss.Aside from a couple of questionable plot points that the average movie-goer would never notice anyway, I thought this movie was a very good blockbuster. Is it THE blockbuster of the summer? Probably not...that title has to stick with X-Men: The Last Stand so far...we'll see if anyone unseats it this summer. But everyone knows who Superman is, and he is the reason that comic books are what they are today. The only real problem I had with the movie were the ages of the main characters played by Routh (27) and Bosworth (23)...they were much too young to be five years older than where the movie is supposed to pick up. The original Lois Lane played by Margot Kidder was 32 and the original Superman, Christopher Reeve was 28. I know the reasoning behind this, though and can accept it and grow with it...especially since I thought Routh and Bosworth did such a good job (especially Bosworth...boy do you feel for her character, had she been 10 years older, it would have been perfection). But, I imagine if this movie does well at the box office (and it should), there will be sequels and it takes a few years to churn out these huge blockbusters. We couldn't have 40+ year-old Superman and Lois Lane...and kids today will grow up with Routh and Bosworth the same way I grew up with Reeve and Kidder.I would recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys blockbusters, comic-book movies, Superman in general, action flicks, drama, and romance.

I will say that I was never much of a fan of the Superman movies as I was with the show. Superman 1 was very well done, 2 was decent, 3 was a complete mess, and 4 was probably one of the worst movies I have ever seen. I personally like to imagine it ended after 2. Do not get me wrong I thought Christopher Reeves was the best Superman anybody could ever be. I just thought that the story, dialouge etc. etc. was brutal in 3 and 4. Finally the Classic superman has come back as he is meant to be in my eyes. Brandon Routh was spectacular as the man of steel, and although for many years Terri Hatcher was always my vision of Lois Lane, Kate Bosworth nailed the role perfectly. Kevin Spacey however is a different story. I really enjoyed Mr. Spacey in movies like The Usual Suspects and American Beauty, but for some reason I just didn't think he was the right choice for Lex Luthor. I found his character to be a little cheesy and some of his lines really annoyed me. Bryan Singer did the best job that anybody could ever do on a Superman movie and the special effects were mind boggling. Anyways I advise anyone who likes superhero movies to see this movie. Let me rephrase that you must see this movie, it's Superman man people he's the one that started it all.

Review Title: this movie is not for children
Unnecessary, trendy, sequels on the way
"It's A Bird, It's A Plane, It's....One Great Movie"
Review: Superman leaves earth to see if there are any remains of his home planet, Krypton. Five years later, Superman returns...but now things are different. Lux Luthor is out of prison, Louis Lane has found a new love and has a child. Is there really a need for Superman anymore?Bryan Singer is no stranger to comic book films, after all he's directed two of them himself. Singer left the X-men series to try and tackle something bigger, something that would prove to be a challenge for him. In terms of superheros, you can't get any bigger then the Man of Steel himself, Superman.Many people will say to this day that Christopher Reeves is the one and only Superman. While he was good for the role, Brandon Routh does an exceptional job at resurrecting that character and breathing new life into him. At first some may be hesitant of the newcomer, but he does not disappoint. Not only does he do a great job with Superman, but also excels with Clark Kent. Looking almost identical as Reeves, Routh pulls off both identities of Superman. I guess you can say that the torch has been passed on now. Even though Routh is excellent as Superman, he is not the stand out performance in this film. Before you even see the film, you know who is going to "own" the film and he does. Kevin Spacey is Lex Luthor and he does it so incredibly well. You can't help but smile whenever his shinny bald head, which is a good look for Spacey, comes upon the screen. He plays Luthor with a little bit more evil then Hackman did, with a small humours side. Kate Bosworth plays the role as it is written, and nothing more. Margot Kidder is still the one and only Louis Lane. Bosworth was out of place and they could have found another actress to play her....Rachel McAdams anyone?The supporting cast, Frank Langella, Sam Huntington, James Marsden (I was waiting for him to shoot laser beams out of his eyes) all do very well in bringing back the vibe of the Daily Planet. Sam Huntington is the comic relief of the film, playing the dopey Jimmy Olsen, the only other comedy, comes from Spacey. Parker Posey was annoying in the film, she really doesn't serve a purpose other then crying on cue. Kal Penn is another character who doesn't do much but stand around.The special effects are great. With a man like Superman who has superhuman powers, you can have so much fun with it and they clearly do. Being able to see through walls was a neat addition to the film and the super hearing of people in other rooms. Of course, the plane sequence was a feat for the eyes and the final climatic scene. The film makes good use of the technique in which you convert the actor to CGI. Unlike Blade II and The MAtrix Reloaded, in which you can clearly tell the difference, here it's a little less noticeable. Granted it's not perfect, but you do have that "Look how fake that was" look on your face through the film.The story is very much like something that you can pull right out of the comics. Luthor trying to raise his own continent while the Kryptonite. Throughout the whole film though, the "how am I going to get out of this situation" seems to lack a bit, cause you know that at the last second Superman will come and all he has to do is fly here, stop that, or pull this. There's a little bit of tension with the characters, but you know at the end of the day that they are all going to live, because it IS Superman.I did get chills with the opening credits, hearing Brando's voice, then the old school Superman theme. It sends chills down the spine, in a good way. Then the names fly across the scene, much like the original. The theme is all over the movie and the score has that "comic book epic" tone to it. Although, after the climax of the film it does go on for awhile, so near the end of the film it does drag a bit. The whole Superman in hospital scene was "what the hell" moment.Overall this is a great film, with only one or two missteps. Singr does an excellent job at reinventing the Superman franchise, much like Nolan did with Batman. Superman is the best superhero film this year and one of the best all time. It is leaps and bounds over X-Men: The Last Stand. Returns is the summer event of the year and it's action and energy leaps over tall buildings. Pirates will be huge as well and great indeed, but Superman Returns is a film that people have been waiting for for years and it does not disappoint.

Superman Returns is a well made movie, with good action, and good acting. 6/10. Why do I only give it 6/10? The storyline dragged on and on and on and on like this sentence. The movie is 2 hours and 37 minutes, if it were cut down to 2 hours, which it easily could be, it would be vastly improved. The love story between Superman/Louis Lane was way too long and over-dramatic. I left the theater wanting more and slightly disappointed with its lack of "it". Nothing about the movie jumped out at me, it was well done but... it just lacked a story that kept me at the edge of my seat as I feel a superhero movie should be able to do.

Review Title: "Flying is statistically still the safest way to travel." Still got the kitsch and thats good.
Not a "chick flick" but not a comic book based movie either....
Review: At least not a successful one. Many early reviews stated that the movie was a complete chick flick which it is not, however that is not to say that the movie does not have those few moments of irrelevant romance that lack contribution to the general plot. Brandon Routh plays an excellent Superman despite what many people may believe. Kevin Spacey was the perfect Lex Luthor, the audience actually despises him at times. However, Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth) lacks a lot of the qualities that make her Lois Lane. She is a career woman yes, but not a sarcastic, busy woman who can actually be romantic at times, but rather more like a career woman who has no time for anyone and has the personality of a bitter ex-girlfriend who is slightly bipolar (maybe just a little too harsh). That said my original score was going to be a 7 had it not been for Bryan Singer's "misguided direction" for lack of a better term and to avoid calling him a horrible director. Simply put, he is overrated, and being so often makes people forgive him too easily, but not me. Although it is true that you should never walk into a movie that is based on a book or comic and expect a flawless transition from paper to film, there are little things that must be kept the same in order to preserve the things that make the character who he is. The problem, people said, with making Superman movies is that the man is almost perfect and therefore it is hard to find an enemy for him so writers were stumped. The problem with the direction is that unlike Spider-Man (Marvel, I know, but bare with me) and Batman (DC like Big Blue) the dilemma faced does not just affect NYC or Gotham it affects the world, and in doing so there is a complete lack of acknowledgement towards the DC universe, the Superheroes that make him who he is, both by complementing his weakness's and emphasizing his strengths are not even mentioned and it makes it seem as if Superman is the only hero. Things, that were contemplated in the comics, but were scrapped because of the inevitable results which had to be avoided are revived here in what seems to me, as some fan-boys sick dream (not necessarily Singer but most likely), although I won't spoil it for anyone, if you don't know yet, when you see the film you will instantly know what I am talking about. All in all the film earned a 5 for directing and a 7 for the acting but an 8 for special effects (not factored into my original score) so I will revise my vote to a 6 instead of a 5. The average movie goers seemed to like it, but if you know even a little tiny bit about comics, I doubt you will appreciate it.

Review Title: Good, but not as good as the first two films (Spoilers)
Review: I had waited almost 20 years for another Superman movie and nothing was going to stop me from seeing it today, even if the family had other plans!There are spoilers in this review, so stop now if you don't want to know any....------------------------------------------The opening was FRIGGIN AWESOME! The music made me weep it was so good to hear and see again on the big screen! Seeing the original-style titles with that *HUGE* Superman logo appear was just an indescribable feeling for me. It warmed my heart. :-)I wasn't bugged at all with Lex's plan. I think he must live by the motto, "If at first you don't succeed, try, try again." He failed with his land deal in the first movie, so he tries it again. And to him, it's not all about money. He would like to go down in the history books as the man who killed billions of people. He doesn't care how he does it. Spacey was excellent. No complaints there. He was basically Hackman with an edge. His best scene was with the toothbrush in his mouth. :-DSurprisingly, I wasn't all that bothered by Bosworth. She's still too young, but she filled the role okay.The kid wasn't as bad as I thought he'd be. I really like the relationship that started between him and Supes. Especially in light of the Jor-El speech Superman speaks to him when he's asleep. "The son becomes the father and the father the son." This should be interesting to see in the next few movies.Now to Routh... He was good. But he didn't hit it out of the park for me. Honestly, only Chris Reeve could do that. Chris had something special about him. His Superman really seemed like a *MAN*. Routh seems like a "young" man. Not all that confident. Where's the "General, would you care to step outside?" type confidence? He brooded over Lois too much. His line to Lex, "I see an old man's sick joke" was the most confident thing he said/did. That was great. Everything else was "Meh." (Well the mini-gun scene was cool too.) He can be great if he just adds more confidence to Superman next time.So, here's my Superman score:George Reeves: 8Christopher Reeve: 10Brandon Routh: 7As for the story itself, there wasn't a whole lot to it. Lex creates crystal continent, Superman tries to stop him & gets injured, then tries again and wins. There are no (okay, maybe one) "connect-the-dots" type of moments. I was hoping the guy with the mini-gun was one of Lex's henchmen stealing money for the expedition trip or something. It's really just an announcement movie saying, "I'm back!" but not much more. (And what happened to the mini-gun guy? At least in the original we see the fate of the different crooks.)Overall, I think the movie did what it needed to do. The important thing is that it furthered the characters and they grew. I think Superman grew with the knowledge of his son's existence. Now he understands Jor-El and Pa Kent in a whole different light. He's a changed person and does have a personal love and connection to someone like he's always yearned for. Lois too has changed... You could see how angry she was at the beginning, but realized she loved him after all. Enough to recant her whole "Why The World Doesn't Need Superman" article.Okay, so how many references to the originals did you notice? I saw a very tiny one that many would miss...* When Lex stole the Krypton meteor, the card read it had landed in "Addis Ababa" just like in the original. * The "Donner Dome" on Krypton does make an appearance! * Also, did you see the photo of Glenn Ford in the Kent house? * And Lois still smokes and can't spell (and finally won her Pulitzer.) * The line "I hope this incident hasn't put you off flying. Statistically speaking, it's still the safest way to travel." Oh, and Lois fainted right after Superman said that. * It was fun to see the TV show Jimmy and Lois again. I only wish George and Chris could have been around to do cameos too. * And I had read about the very end scene where he flies off into space a la Chris Reeve. That was PERFECT! Again, I wept when I saw that! FRIGGIN AWESOME! I want to see the whole movie again just for the opening and closing!So, here's my movie ratings:Superman: The Movie: 9.5Superman II: 10Superman III: 6Superman IV: 2Superman Returns: 7 (I just knocked it a point for taking out the "Truth, Justice and the American way." line. >:-( )Not as good as the first two movies, and just a bit better than III. (I know, a lot of people hate III, but c'mon, Clark Kent vs. Evil Superman fighting in the junkyard makes it worthwhile.)

This movie asks the question of it's characters, "does the world need Superman." In it's construction and execution, it asks of it's viewers, "does the world need a Superman movie?" I had goosebumps through the opening credits. There is a magic to the Superman myth, and from the get-go, Bryan Singer pretty must states that he's a big-league A-list director, but he's *NOT* going to make Superman his own. He's dealing with something bigger than himself here, and he's going to respect that.Batman and Spiderman have achieved great success as superheroes and as movie franchises by being quintessentially human. For all their power, their greatest weakness is their underlying humanity. For the movies, this struggle with humanity is what makes them successful. (I'm purposely considering only the bookend Batman movies here.) Superman's not human, and he doesn't have human weaknesses. He's a pretty flat character in a 21st century of back story, darkness, and closeted skeletons. That's a difficult sell, to be sure.The magic of the Superman story has always been the "nick of time" rescue. Singer uses this technique, but in a quid pro quo. Superman rescues, but at the same time, the side characters become self-reliant and do their fair share of rescuing themselves.I hear the comment, "something's missing." The piece that's missing is Superman at the center of this movie, and I'm not sure that it's a bad thing. Everybody is at the center of this movie, reacting to the presence or absence of Superman. It's a bold technique, given that it requires the audience to meet it halfway, and some people just don't do that. To watch this, and appreciate it, you have to watch with your heart.So back to the question, "Does the world need another Superman movie?" IMHO, there's an undeniable and unmatchable magic to be found in a movie that has a distinct lack of cynicism. It's fun and it's touching, but most of all, it's refreshing that a movie can reach heights such as these without having to find a new dark corner of the human soul. The movie is pure magic and can take us all back to the days when we were innocent and believed that good will win and bad will lose. For everybody who has lost touch with that innocence, a Superman is sorely needed.**** On a total side note, the age-old maxim should now read, "don't do scenes with kids, animals, or Parker Posey." She can do no wrong, and almost walked away with this whole movie in her back pocket.

Review Title: The Rebirth of Superman: A well made, yet flawed, homage of a sequel
Review: A new Superman movie has been in development hell for as far back as anyone can remember. Yes, Kevin Smith had some interesting anecdotes about his attempts at writing a screenplay for Jon Peters, but otherwise, we have endured many years of television shows and comics, but no new big screen adaptation. Finally, Bryan Singer, the man who made comic book movies "cool" again, was contracted and taken away from his beloved X-Men to create his interpretation of Superman. And while not perfect, it is definitely something to marvel at.Superman/Clark Kent (newcomer Brandon Routh) has been away from Metropolis for five years. Upon returning, he learns of how people got along without him, and how many people, like his love Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth), have moved on entirely. But while many are glad to see him back, his arch-nemesis Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) is not, and as could be predicted, has come up with a cunning plan to try and take over the world, and defeat the Man of Steel in the process.Understandably, the plot does not sound entirely too amazing, but the film has been hyped enough that it speaks for itself. It has officially brought Superman back to life, and like Batman Begins before it, has rejuvenated an otherwise dead franchise. Wisely choosing not to redo the franchise over, Singer has made an epic homage and true sequel to Superman II. Yes, it has a few flashback moments and blatant pieces of dialogue to help those new to the franchise, understand it better. Having never seen the films from beginning to end, but knowing enough about them, I found this to work great in the film, and make feel more original than it would have with anyone else.Routh is no Christopher Reeve, but he does great as the titular character. He fills the big shoes proudly, and has enough charisma and talent, to make us believe that he is Superman and Clark Kent. He looks throughout the entirety of the film that he is attempting to do the role justice, and it shows in the strength of his performance. Another wise decision on Singer's part. Bosworth, while nowhere near as strong a presence in the film, holds her own, and shows off the independence of Lois Lane. There are a few cases where she falters, but otherwise, she does a fairly admirable job. Both her and Routh play off each other well in their scenes together, and have great chemistry. While the love triangle involving their characters and Richard White (James Marsden, in a much bigger and much more rewarding role than in X-Men: The Last Stand) is only amped up slightly, they still work well and do not retract from the story.But, as expected, it's Spacey's Lex Luthor that shines the most out of any of the characters. His role is darkly humorous and devilishly evil at the same time. He takes away any joke Gene Hackman may have made of the character, and has made him downright sadistically evil. If you believed that Routh could make a man fly in tights, then Spacey downright epitomizes a man of pure evil. This is a true incantation of Luthor, and a key improvement in this sequel. The performance he makes here, ranks right up there with The Usual Suspects, American Beauty and Se7en.The rest of the supporting cast, from Marsden to Sam Huntington as Jimmy Olsen, to Frank Langella as Perry White, to even the young Tristan Lake Leabu as Lois' son Jason, all give terrific turns as their character. They complement the big stars around them, and strengthen their performances. The archived footage of Marlon Brando as Jor-El was a great addition to the cast as well. Kal Penn and Parker Posey turn out to be disappointments, as they basically stand and do very little, if anything, in the scheme of things. They are totally overshadowed by everyone, and just seem weak and useless by the finale.The special effects are absolutely top-notch. Every flying sequence is spectacular, and all the action going on looks even better. The effects are so good that it almost seems like Routh really can fly. The scenes showcasing Superman's powers like his super-hearing, his ability to see through objects, and more all take full advantage of the special effects, and all look equally as good as his flying. The opening credits are a particular standout (as both a good effects piece, and a great homage to the original films. The score is just as great, even though the original theme song is played a little too many times.But the film does have faults. Where some of the acting stalls, the storyline does too. It gets bogged down with a little too much going on, that it loses the edge it had at the beginning. The final forty-five minutes of the movie feels dragged right out, and just does not feel right in the entire scheme of things. It felt boring, unnecessary, and completely ill-fitting. I did not notice anything gay or Christ-like about it like I had heard in other reviews, it simply just does not work. It feels awkward, and is totally underwhelmed in comparison to everything else. Singer fumbles an otherwise great movie here, and it just does not totally recover by the end.Superman is reborn in 2006, and he comes out swinging. The finale is a bit of a disappointment, but Bryan Singer's creation is just too well made to completely crumble. Great performances, excellent effects and even better homages make for an otherwise good film that could have used a little bit of extra work. After seeing the care and devotion here, I can only imagine what Singer's version of X3 would have looked like.8/10.

After reading some really good reviews on this site. I actually went to see this movie. Honestly, I am not a big fan of Superman, but this movie proved me wrong. All the effects, all the visuals, blow me away. When I saw that the movie is 2 and a half hour long, I thought that it would be boring at some point but when I get in, I forgot the time and when the movie ended, I didn't even know it. I felt like its not enough for me, I want more and more of superman. I hope that they will make another superman movie. Brandon Routh is awesome, and I gotta give some credit to Kate Bosworth too. This movie will make their names two of the big names in Hollywood.Perfect. Rate 10/10

Review Title: Superman Returns and Apologizes for the last 2 movies...
Review: I was completely floored by this movie. I felt tingles in my body when I heard the beginning of John Williams' Superman fanfare and kept feeling them throughout the entire show. Superman Returns delivers. Brandon Routh is Superman just like Christopher Reeve was Superman and just like George Reeves was Superman. He is also Clark Kent. He is not carbon copy of Reeve's portrayal, but he IS the character. I believe he can fly. I believe he can catch an airplane. I believe he is bulletproof. Kevin Spacey was Lex Luthor. The best. Just the right mix of megalomania and psycosis. Kate Bosworth was Lois Lane. She was strong, a real woman. She didn't swoon at the sight of Superman after a 5 year absence, she just went, "Oh he's back, whatever, I have a life and it doesn't revolve around him." Bryan Singer rocked my socks off with his great composition! Long live Superman and I hope to see a few sequels.

I am just getting in from the theater. I still can't believe what I've seen. After the magnificent disappointment X-Men 3 turned out to be I was sure Superman Returns would best it even if it was marginally interesting. What I saw tonight was not only breathtaking, it was almost...beautiful. Yeah, I know I'm a guy but who the hell cares. The story, actors, special effects and everything else about this movie was first rate. There was moments of pure joy and moments of tremendous sadness. Most of these moments written on the face of the wonderful actors who took the role quiet seriously. "Superman" the movie made us believe a man could fly, "Superman Returns" will let us believe that he brings hope with him. Do yourself a favor and don't miss this movie. As a plus, if you have a Christian faith background, you will be pleased to know that some early reports were incorrect. This movie does not knock Christianity, in fact, I believe its actually pro-Christianity. Definitely a five (*****) star movie.

Review Title: This IS the best movie of the summer (and I can say that with a clear conscience...)
Review: Okay, I was one of those who was against the making of yet another Superman movie. I am more of a Bats-fan myself, and seeing a Superman movie... Well, I wasn't too thrilled. I thought it would be just a trounce through Metropolis with newcomer Brandon Routh as the Superman that Christopher Reeve portrayed, and Kevin Spacey as the Lex Luthor Gene Hackman portrayed in the originals. My personal thoughts on this particular movie were, "They should restart the series like they did with Batman Begins, that was much better than the rest of them, and they should do the same thing with Superman".Boy, was I wrong.From the very get-go, the movie grabs you and never lets go. From the very beginning, when you hear the original theme composed by John Williams, you are in awe that they actually kept that little bit. It wouldn't be Superman without it. After the opening credits, the story unfolds and you are caught up in this. Brandon Routh made for an excellent Clark Kent/Superman (both the hero and his alter-ego); as one person said, it was "Lex Luthor playing Kevin Spacey playing Lex Luthor"; Kevin Spacey was absolutely insane as Superman's arch-nemesis, in a good way. Kate Bosworth, while an odd choice for Lois Lane, Superman's love interest, made for an interesting interpretation of the character, which was great to see.Not only do the actors help to contribute to the excellence of the movie, but Bryan Singer's direction, and the story itself are absolutely great. The story should send traditional Superman fans into a tizzy, but it's still a good foray into Metropolis. The Return of Superman is definitely a movie to see this summer. One final comment: When I went, I bought my friend's ticket, and I told him it was on me. When we came out of the theater, he told me, "Dude, I'm definitely paying you back for this; thank you for inviting me". I've never had anyone offer to pay me back when I said it was on me. That's how good this movie is. DC is definitely two for two right now...

Wow just saw the movie and it was incredibly disappointing. First of all there was ZERO chemistry between Superman and Lois. Second of all ~ as Ebert pointed out ~ the character "Superman" didn't say anything. He acted like Christopher Reeve's Clark Kent but there was no warmth or character. When he did actually utter words as Superman he sounded like Christoper Reeve again. Call me old fashioned (I'm 34) but I don't like the fact that Lois has a kid and he doesn't know who his daddy is. Poor Richard thinks it's his kid. Kevin Spacey was great as usual but again his character didn't have the depth of Gene Hackman's Lex Luthor, he was just pure evil. The only two elements of the movie I enjoyed were the nostalgic theme music and the special effects..........which obviously blew the originals away. I grew up with Christopher Reeve's Superman so I have a special place for them but was really looking forward to "Superman Returns". I've seen others say that it isn't fair to compare this movie to the originals....BS. I could feel the crowd at the theatre waiting for something to grab on to in the movie but there was nothing. The opening special effects with the plane were cool though. Maybe the sure to come sequels will be better.

Review Title: The heart and soul of Superman Returns
Review: Expectations were heavy when I first saw the trailer for Superman Returns and desperately wished that the film could deliver some of the magic of the original Superman and its excellent sequel. Superman 3 and 4 were somewhat enjoyable but disconnected films which I couldn't embrace with the joy of the first two films which I saw at ages 5 and 7. I feared maybe I was too old for Superman. With Superman Returns, I discovered the magic was not gone.Bryan Singer has done a wonderful job putting Superman back in the emotional and visual context of the superior first two Christopher Reeve led Superman films. He is faithful and genuinely careful to reinvigorate the Superman legend but not without a super-twist which I won't spoil for impending viewers and which I would avoid seeking out as not knowing what was to come made this film a much better experience for me.What also made this film work for me was the careful balance of characterization and action which made the earlier films so magnificent in tone and pace. Kate Bosworth is no Margot Kidder and lacks the vibrant intensity of her predecessor, but she and Brandon Routh have chemistry and she does well to make the role her own in a slightly less edgy way. Its the only slight disappointment but it didn't hurt the film for me.Kevin Spacey runs riot with Lex Luthor in a way not dissimilar to Gene Hackman but with a more sadistic edge. I enjoyed and was thrilled by Superman Returns which offers all the fun and excitement of the films which I loved as a kid. Although I am older,it was nice to be roused and moved by the music, characters and skillful direction once again. Can't wait for more. Excellent.

In Director Bryan Singer's "Superman Returns", Superman (newcomer Brandon Routh) has been gone from Earth for 5 years searching the galaxy for the remains of his home world Krypton. Superman or Kal-El (son of Krypton Leader Jor-El) discovers that he is the last of his kind, an outcast. Upon returning to Earth in a fiery crash back in the fields of Smallville Kansas, he confides to his adoptive mother Martha Kent (very good Eva Marie Saint) that he is truly "all alone". During the hero's 5 year absence, the World continued on without Superman. So has the love of his life, Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth). Lois, now with Richard White (James Marsden), nephew of "The Daily Planet" Editor Perry White (Frank Langella), has a young son Jason (Tristan Lake Leabu). So Superman's alter ego Clark Kent (Routh) returns to Metropolis and his post at "The Daily Planet". Superman reunites with Lois in a visually breathtaking airline rescue, signifying his return. Superman/ Clark Kent is devastated that Lois perhaps is in love with another. Superman then recalls the words of his father Jor-El (the late Marlon Brando), "…They can be a great people, Kal-El, they wish to be. They only lack the light to show the way. For this reason above all, their capacity for good, I have sent them you... my only son." But for Superman his father's words hold little consolation.During the past 5 years, Lois won the Pulitzer Prize for writing the article, "Why the World Doesn't Need Superman". Superman and Lois meet atop "The Daily Planet" tower for a heart to heart. Lois tells Superman, "The world doesn't need a savior." Mostly she is angry that he didn't say good-bye before he left. So it is not so much that Superman left the World, it is that Superman left her. Also during his absence, Superman's mortal enemy Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) has been released from prison. Lex still obsessed with the Man of Steel, begins to unravel the mystery of his nemesis discovering the Fortress of Solitude near the North Pole and uncovering the secrets of the set of crystals from Krypton. Lex formulates his plans for global domination. Now standing in his way is in fact Superman.Bryan Singer and writers Michael Dougherty and Dan Harris have created an ingenious premise in this reinvention of Superman.
