This is interesting considering some of the press including articles in the Los Angeles Times regarding Superman in the context of a Christ figure or Gay icon. It occurred to me while watching "Superman Returns" that Superman may have been in his inception a Christ metaphor. Jor-El, the leader of an advanced and perhaps god-like race of a doomed world, sends his only son to Earth as a savior of Mankind. Singer dramatically uses the pose of a vulnerable Superman plummeting to Earth. Superman is willing to die for all of Mankind. Much like in his "X-Men" movies, Singer's theme of being alone and an outcast permeates through "Superman Returns". Superman has to pretend to be something that he is not—Clark Kent. As Clark he suffers because he can never tell the woman, who he loves, who he really is. Only as Superman does Clark have authentic self-expression. Superman lends compassion to anyone, who has pretended to be someone other than themselves."Superman Returns" is visually stunning. Bryan Singer truly captures the freedom of flight, and the spirit of the hero. Brandon Routh is amazing and powerful as Superman and Clark Kent. Routh is a great looking man with a commanding presence and lightness. He inhabits Clark with the right inept touch, understated. As Superman he has a great voice. He is strong and tempered with both compassion and courage. Comparisons to his predecessor are inevitable, and Routh is awesome. Kevin Spacey provides an unusual spin on Lex Luthor. In the beginning Lex seems more eccentric than threat. As the movie evolves Spacey harnesses a dark force and presence in Lex that is so compelling. This provides the explosive conflict between Superman and Lex. Kate Bosworth is miscast as Lois Lane. Bosworth, a talented actress, is unable to nuance the angry and hurt Lois. I think that even though Lois is the unaffected and callous reporter, deep down she is waiting for her knight in shining armor to return. That sense of regret or loss is missing in Bosworth's interpretation. An aside: From the comics either Lois is one of the stupidest people on the planet or Clark Kent is one of the greatest actors. The fact that Lois can't tell the difference between Superman and Clark Kent without the glasses and different hair part is completely boggling. At least Singer makes a joke regarding this narrative legacy."Superman Returns" is a great hero story. Bryan Singer masterfully tells his story of love, courage and redemption. Singer also crafts an amazing surprise in his reinvention of the Superman legend. Brandon Routh and Kevin Spacey are awesome. Veteran Spacey gives new life to Lex Luthor. Routh is the charismatic young star on the rise. "Superman Returns" is about reclaiming and inspiring greatness. "Superman Returns" is also a great movie.

Another overblown action movie with too many clean-looking CGs and not enough substance. The action sequences are watchable, but half an hour's worth of story has been extended to two and half hours. Singer wanted to show a lot of flying-superman scenes where the hero pretends to be real-cool, sort of like music video scenes. This is the main reason why the movie is so long.As for acting, Spacey does a decent job as Luthor, but other characters are instantly forgettable.As for comparisons with other superhero movies, 'Batman Begins' is way way better.It's not a complete waste of money since it's got better action scenes than an average B-action films. Instantly forgettable time-killer. Don't expect too much !

Review Title: A faithful movie in the vein of the old franchise...
Its a bird, its a plane, no its superman
Sadly I did not enjoy it.
Review: I have always been a big Superman fan. I suppose the idea of flying and having super human strength has always been appealing. And I always enjoyed Richard Donner's 1978 Superman movie -- I still find myself gladly dropping whatever I am doing if I see it on television. I guess you could say that it's a really heart-warming classic. So when I heard that they were (finally) making a new Superman film I was a bit divided. On one hand I would have loved to see a new Superman film. On the other hand I worried that the filmmakers are going to somehow muck it up a bit.Sadly in this case I have to say I thought the film was a bit of the latter and not enough of the former. At two hours and thirty-odd minutes it felt a bit too long. The filmmaker could have probably cut it down by 45 minutes and it would have been a better adventure. The story paces rather slowly at times and the tone often too serious for its own good and the sentimental moments are not as compelling -- mainly due to the rather poor choices (IMHO) in casting.Do not get me wrong. Kate Bosworth will always be lovely to look at. But with the brown hair she just looked like, well... Kate Bosworth with kinky brown hair and not someone I could easily accept as Lois Lane.Perhaps it was Margot Kidder's feisty Lois, or even Teri Hatcher's sassy version in Lois & Clark. Whatever the situation to me Lois will always be a bit of a statuesque siren with a journalist streak. Kate's wonderful. But not exactly the right fit.And Brandon Routh... Well, I think he did a pretty good job with the voice, but he still stuck me more as a kid and not as the kind of man needed to fill Christopher Reeve's shoes. Perhaps I am being too harsh here. After all, after Reeves whom could possibly compare? For most people who grew up in the seventies Reeves will always be Superman. Routh does a good job playing the part, but I think they could have still done a better job in casting.As far as the pacing is concerned, like I said, it runs a bit slow at times. Not all the scenes seem necessary for pushing the drama forward. And at times it also feels a bit gratuitous as the story seemed a bit too convoluted with too many strings to tie up by the end of the film.The symbolism in the film also seems to be a real problem in this case. Give me a nickel every time someone talks about "savior" and I think I would probably have enough to go buy a few lottery tickets. The savior theme is really something that is set to overkill as if Singer wanted to simply reach out into the audience and browbeat the viewer into submission. There is such a thing as overkill, and this would be a good example in my opinion.The tone of the film is also rather dark. Spacey's Lex Luther is much more serious than the Hackman version, and so the character is a lot less interesting. Yes, there are a few times when Spacey is more comical and during those moments the Lex Luther character works. But there are also some grotesque moments which are supposed to be humorous which I personally found less tasteful and unnecessary for pushing the story forward. Consequently the humor needed to punch up the film's darker elements is sorely lacking and so the fun factor of the film seems rather curtailed. In my opinion Donner did the right thing by making Lex Luther the source of humor -- on one hand we need a source of release from the tension in the film, on the other hand we need the humor to remind ourselves not to take anything so seriously. To me Superman films at their best were never to be taken too seriously and once the film did it stopped becoming a superman story and more of a Singer drama. As far as the inherent themes of the Superman films to me they were about dreams, ideals, and about the inherent goodness of mankind. Clark Kent (and for that matter Superman) is a good person because of this inherent goodness bred into him by his human parents and how that goodness survives despite the weakness of others (i.e. Lex Luther) is the real focus of the story -- not, in my opinion whether or not Superman is supposedly mankind's re-envisioned Christ-like savior. Yes, Singer does touch upon these themes somewhat, but overall the themes are not clearly explored within the story. It is rather convoluted due to the numerous issues being addressed in the film -- and perhaps it would have been a lot better if Singer had decided to take half of the movie's themes and saved them for a later sequel rather than to drop them all into the audience's lap. Other than that? Well, it was alright. I still expect it to make approximately $130 million by Tuesday, however what sort of staying power it has afterward remains to be seen.

Review Title: Superman flies high, Kevin Spacey higher
Review: Every once in a blue moon do we get the opportunity to see a movie like this. Bryan Singer, director of the Usual Suspects and Abandoner of the X-Men saga, has the rigorous task of bringing Superman back to life. Fortunately for him Kevin Spacey did all the work for him.Brandon Routh was entertaining, but as most of us suspected, he looked more like Superman than his acting told us. It's what is called role casting, and unlike fellow action man Christian Bale, Routh fails to bring the man of steel back to life. Co-star Kate Bosworth is another, yawn, unattractive female in an comic-book-movie, following the likes of Katie Holmes and Kirsten Dunst.Singer has enormous directing capability, which was partly covered by clouds for this film. The storyline was awkward and his emotional touch never completely gets through to the audience, leaving the viewer shedding a single tear or wondering how in the world did a superman movie include knocking up Lois(sp) Lane.If a movie wants to succeed it has to have someone that grabs your attention, especially in a action/adventure - esquire movie that looks to employ some quality. This has been apparent over the last several years. Ex; Johnny Depp in Pirates of the Caribbean, Christian Bale in Batman Begins, Steve Zahn in Sahara. This reason is the reason that such movies as X-Men II & III, and the 2nd Spiderman got great money but failed to deliver anything remarkable to the audience. Superman, however, had such a performance. Kevin Spacey blew my mind as Lex Luther. Spacey took a conventional character and turned him into a loosey goosey evil villain who is fun to watch and times who the audience is rooting for to win.In a nutshell this movie cannot be deemed a failure nor a success, but moreover as a building block. it all hangs in the next movie

First of all I'd like to say that the movie was nicely done...the cg, acting etc were good. However as a fan who grew up reading DC, and who has memorized almost all the story lines in the comics post 'Crisis on Infinite Earths', and also seen every Super-Hero movie (including Dolph Lundgren's Punisher) I was a bit disturbed by the movie. For starters if anyone has read the Superman Returns Prequel comic mini-series, the one with Lois has a frame where she screams at Richard in the Delivery room....and that left me confused as whether the movie is true or the comic. Lois and Clark are married in the comics, when will that happen in the movies? And the final Fly-by....Routh has huge shoes to fill in, that of the legendary Christopher Reeve, and the kid has made a genuine effort and should be commended, but doing the final fly-by with the smile and the nod should have been avoided....I would not want a rip-off from the earlier movies, and it looked to me as a effort to cash-in on sentiments rather than do it as a mark of respect to Mr. Reeve, the one and only Superman!

Review Title: People with High Hopes will be let down
Review: I wanted this movie to be fantastic. I am a huge Superman fan and have been waiting for a long time too see Bryan Singers take on (in my eyes) the greatest superhero of all time. About half way into the movie I started getting worried, quietly I prayed to myself the movie would improve...My prayers went unanswered. Don't get me wrong it had some great scenes - but most of them were shown in the trailers - leaving only kinda boring "filler" between each action scene. The group I went with all felt the same - and yes we are superhero geeks... Sorry Superman, you have taken a tumble on my favourite superhero list. Bring on Spiderman 3! In summary its not super bad, its just not good.

Superman is always in my mind a difficult character to bring to the silver screen. A near-flawless man ( or thing ), who can survive anything is not going to create the same sort of anxiety in the audience as group of outcasts like the X-Men, a conflicted youth in Spider-Man, or a vengeful angel in Batman. Having said that, however, Bryan Singer has done well to make an interesting story in a well-acted film, with only a couple of problems letting it down.The story revolves around a returning Superman ( Brendan Routh ) who has spent 5 years looking for his home world and has now returned to Earth, to find the world he knew has changed. Meanwhile Lex Luthor ( Kevin Spacey ) looks to the return of the Man of Steel with renewed vengeance. Caught up in this is Superman's former love, Lois Lane ( Kate Bosworth ) who's love for the former sees her as a trump card for the latter.The cast for the most part acts admirably with Brendan Routh stepping into the shoes of Christopher Reeve with ease and manages to move between Kent and his more public alias easily. Spacey shows the world again how well he can tap into a villain's character, showing a short of megalomaniacal humanity that treads a line between total amorality and scientific endeavour. The weak link is unfortunately a biggie and it comes in the form of Lois Lane. Kate Bosworth is infatuated with Superman but seems to treat Kent with a sort of friendly contempt, as if he's somewhat below her and her level of journalism. Apart from this, the fact is that...well...this is Superman. A man who apparently cannot be spotted because he takes of his glasses. Who is totally invulnerable to almost all human things. He doesn't have Batman's baggage nor his flaws.However maybe I'm being too hard this movie, because it is a good yarn, and the Brando speech holds up still after 20 years. Superman has indeed returned and we can only hope that it won't be the last time we see him.

The longer the movie went on, the more I liked it. There was plenty of story to go with the action.The major complaint I have is this: For a film that takes place in modern times in the major US city of Metropolis, which is based on New York, this is one of the most Caucasian films I've seen in a long time and I'm Caucasian. I know 'Superman Returns' was filmed in Australia and one of Lex Luther's minor henchmen was of Asian-Indian decent, but does Warner Brothers expect me to believe the were no qualified black actors to play any of the other minor roles. I am sure there are blacks in Australia who could have been taxi driver #2 or something.

Review Title: The strongest feature of the franchise yet
Its a bird..Its a plane ...no its SUPERB!!!!!......
Review: Superman has returned and has returned in style.The fifth installment of the famed super hero series from DC comics has made a lasting impact on the celluloid screens across the planet earth.Brandon Routh has given a "Performance of a life".At times, one can see glances of the Great Christopher Reeve in this "young man of Steel"!! All our Favourite characters are brought back to life with lots more to instill our spirits with passion.Its a complete movie spectacle for all kinds of audience from legendary Hard-core Superman Fans to Folks who say "Superman..Who?".Director Bryan Singer has once again proved his prowess in bringing our favorite comic heroes to life, as he did in "X-Men" and X-men 2".Viewers are blown away when the same old Superman Theme is once again brought back to life by the great John Williams.Visual Effects add a crisp layer of reality to Superman.Technology hasn't affected Superman and his ever continuing quest to know MAnkind more is still on in "Superman Returns".Watch it. It will take us beyond anything we can imagine...

Review Title: What an honor to the memory of Christopher Reeve's Superman
Review: I had originally seen the trailers for Superman Returns, and like any person who saw a man fly for the first time in the original "Superman" movie, I was actually rather outraged to see that they would even try to make a new Superman movie now that Christopher Reeves (may he rest in peace) was gone. But, my love for comics over-threw the idea to not see the movie. So, on opening day, I was there, as skeptical as can be. And as soon as the opening credits rolled, I knew that they were honoring Christoper Reeve's Superman. And a smile spread across my face. Then I saw how the new Superman acted as both Clark Kent and Superman, and the smile became wider. They really did do the right thing, not just in the fact that they made a new movie to continue the series (and make no mistake, this is not like Batman Begins, where they remake a series. Superman RETURNS is when Superman... RETURNS...) but they also made the right choice when they chose the actors for the movie. Not just the actor Brandon Routh, who does an amazing job not just mimicking Mr. Reeve's rendition of Clark Kent/Superman, but also by adding his own edge and charm to the character. And as for the Kevin Spacey/Lex Luthor, he was absolutely brilliant. I was worried that, like Chris Reeves, nobody could play Lex like Gene Hackman, but I was wrong. Kevin Spacey pulls yet another great movie off with his spectacular rendition of the villain who is as ruthless as he is hair-less. I thank Bryan Singer for once again an amazing flick that didn't screw up any of the legend and glory of the original comic.For those of your wondering... Superman truly has returned.

Ignoring parts III and IV, and picking up after the events of II, astronomers think they have found Krypton, alive and well. Superman leaves Earth for 5 years, only to discover Krypton gone. When he returns, his whole life has been flipped around. Worst of all is that Lois Lane is engaged to Perry White's nephew, and they have a child together. Also, Lex Luthor is out of prison, and he wants revenge, no matter what it takes. Superman Returns is for the Superman series as Batman Begins was to the Batman series.I have so much respect for what Brian Singer did here. He obviously has an immense amount of admiration for the first two films, because he took that style and he did it, spot on. The movie even opens up with the same cheesy but awesome opening credits sequence, John Williams score and all. Brian Singer made a smart decision by making this the new Superman III, because this is a Superman III that fans of Superman might actually be able to enjoy. He does it with the same style and charisma as Richard Donner did it 28 years ago, with the great mix of ambitious action, funny humour, and of course the obligatory sappy drama. What I liked about this movie was that it managed to be a popcorn action flick and a serious comic book film at the same time. Just like Superman started the comic book movie craze, I think Superman Returns, with the help of Batman Begins, should teach Hollywood how to get back to telling a story instead of glitzy action scenes.The acting was awesome. Brandon Routh made a really good Superman, for this being his first big film. He bears a resemblance to Christopher Reeve, which is good. Kate Bosworth was a much more attractive Lois Lane than Margot Kidder, and she did a fine job at acting too. I loved Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor. The way he played the role went right along with how Gene Hackman played it, but at the same time it was darker and more evil.Overall, Superman Returns was a very good film, and it saved the Superman series indefinitely. For any fans of the first film, see this one.8/10

Review Title: Long, slow, and not especially interesting
Review: In my opinion, this was a very bland movie - Lex Luthor wasn't memorable (if he's just an amoral con man why should the sight of his wigs terrify anyone?). There were too many pointless "rescue Lois" scenes, and the subplot with the child seemed to be dragged on far too long. Somehow I kept expecting something more to come from the rescue scenes, some further plot development, but nothing ever happened. And come on, could they really not come up with just one person who questioned the fact that Clark Kent and Superman were gone for the same length of time and reappeared on the same day? The only memorable moment was the "Alex Ross pose" in space, the rest we have seen before many times.

West Windsor High School's favorite son, Bryan Singer, is a genius. The movie is the best action/adventure/comic book adaptation I've ever seen. Move over, Spiderman, you've been trumped! Superman Returns is a faithful, loving homage to the genre, and to the memory of Superman stories past. Brandon Routh is an eerie reminder of Christopher Reeves, and Kevin Spacey's Lex Luthor will always be remembered. Parker Posey, as ever, is a delight, as Luthor's befuddled and bemused gun moll. In short, everyone in the film is delightful.Bravo, Bryan...may you live long and prosper...hey, wanna do the last three parts of the Star Wars saga? You've got MY vote! Give Superman Returns a TEN!

I don't want to give any spoilers as I saw this film with only the limited trailers available... and I loved it! As a Superman fan I was not disappointed, I could find nothing wrong with it. It brought Superman to life flawlessly. Bryan Singer got it right.My daughter had a little problem with the casting of Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane. She thought Lois should be played by a woman who more reflected the physical strength of Lois's character. The problem I think is more with the world and Hollywood in particular. The current standard of beauty expects women to be so thin that bones sticking out is inevitable.

Please note, there are NO SPOILERS in this review.I watched "Superman Returns" today.Just some of my thoughts on the movie:* The special effects are blended in very well. There were effects that made the film seem more hazy, and dream-like, a la "Batman Begins".* The movie did indeed seem that it was stretched out a bit too long, as many reviews have pointed out. It's about 2 1/2 hours long, and it shows when you're watching it.* I'm sure many people expected it to be an action flick, but it turned out to be more of a character analysis of Superman, and Clark Kent.* I felt that the final scenes took away from the impact of the film, up to that point. I'm not going to ruin it for you and tell you what happens, though.* Kevin Spacey, who played Lex Luthor, acted as too much of a goof to be the right villain of the movie.* Spacey either should have acted more sinister, or someone else who fit the role better should have played Luthor.* Adding in bits and pieces of previous Superman movies, specifically audio, and I believe, some video, of Marlon Brando, gave the movie a nicer touch of "authenticity" as it was able to somehow connect and tie in this movie with previous ones, in a way that improved the movie's experience, in my opinion.* I have not yet seen any other Superman movie yet (I know, I should!), so I can't compare with any of them.* Brandon Routh does look like a good fit for the Superman role.Final verdict: Recommended, but keep in mind that it's NOT entirely an action movie.

He leaves us for five years,returning to find the world, and the woman, he left behind have moved on. While the world takes him back with open arms, Lois Lane now has a son, a fiancé, and enough resentment towards the man of steel to win a Pulitzer. Now he must once again save us all from the ever notorious Lex Luther, and try to make peace with the woman he loves.Superman Returns is an amazing movie. Brian Singer's best film yet. It has everything, action, special effects, strong characters, and a plot that will keep you on the edge of your seat, all the while melting your heart. Brandon Routh offers an excellent portrayal of both the superhero, and of the mild mannered Clark Kent. He has the charm, the build, even the perfect voice. While Kevin Spacey holds nothing back as the ever masterful Lex Luther. Even Jimmy Olson is back fumbling about. Brian Singer does an extraordinary job of bringing the man of steel back into our lives, and into hearts.

I sat through the first two hours of this film believing I was seeing the finest superhero movie ever produced. I spent the last hour praying to God to let it end. 25 minutes of editing would have saved this film from itself. How many scenes can you just allow the camera to pan slowly across someones face? I loved the experience of this film, but didn't anyone speak up at a test-screening and comment on the unnecessary length? Without losing one single scene I could edit this down by 20-25 minutes easily. Crop 5 seconds here, 8 seconds there, and the film would have been far more entertaining. My only thought upon leaving the theater was "We get it, all ready!". An outstanding film, well worth the price of admission,,but make sure you go to the restroom 5 times before it starts. Would someone please tell Hollywood that just because "The Lord of the Rings" was epic in length that not every huge film requires 3 hours to be great! Didn't they learn anything from last years "King Kong"?

After years of false starts, rumors of Nicholas Cage and Tim Burton, and the hacks McG and Brett Ratner making a Superma movie all fanboy geeks can rest easy knowing that Singer not only stepped up to the plate, but drove the ball out of the park.While the movie runs over two and half hours, only my bladder noticed. Honestly, if you haven't seen a friend in 19 years, wouldn't you want to spend at least two and half hours with them? Routh and Spacey were spot on, and even though I'd been having doubts about Bosworth I actually ended up enjoying her take on Lois.I have only one small complaint, and it will probably get me flamed. "Truth, justice and all that stuff..." C'mon. I understand this film has to be bankable overseas, but even in the post-Watergate, post-Vietnam 70's Donner version of Superman he was allowed to fight for "Truth, Justice and The American Way." I comprehend that many people understandably chafe at the fact that the U.S.shoves a lot of its "culture?" down the world's throat. Often times I don't appreciate being exposed to much of my country's pop culture. But really, is there anything more American than Superman? Even if the movie tanks and no sequel is in the future, much thanks must go out to Bryan Singer for managing to update Supes for the 21st Century but keeping him as true to himself as he was in 1938!

Review Title: Superman Returns was a perfect movie.  This is why I go to the theatre.
Review: Superman Returns is the reason I go to the movie theatre. It is a big screen, big sound, big theatre movie in every sense. This is what movies are about! Superman Returns was a perfect movie.As a huge fan of the Man of Steel I was darn near vibrating with anticipation when the lights went down. That excitement was only escaladed by watching the opening titles. What a brilliant throw back! For anyone watching a Superman movie for the first time they thought "Wow, cool opening." And those of us who have fond memories of the original four feature films were instantly taken back to a great, great memory.The story was complex enough to keep my interest for the duration and yet simple enough that the young children in the auditorium were also in deep.Brandon Routh was near flawless as 'the man'. I really have no criticism for his performance. He looked the part. He sounded the part. He was the part. Both his clumsy Clark and his gallant Superman performance were spot on.Kevin Spacey played his role well, not stealing the show but complimenting it nicely. His over the top portrayal was what I expected from him. He did manage, very easily to make me forget that I was watching Kevin Spacey and think I was watching Lex Luthor, which is his job. Well done.Lois and the rest of the cast really fit well together. I find it darn difficult to see anything to criticize in the casting department.Frankly, I find it darn tough to find anything at all that I wouldn't say was great.While watching the film I found it pretty apparent that I was watching something from Bryan Singer. As we are now used to, he put the pieces together in grand fashion. This man is becoming untouchable in the comic genre.The length was great. It went by in a blink.I was inspired, excited and absolutely wired by this movie.SUPERMAN RETURNS with greatness!

Review Title: I don't understand the hatred for this film.....
Review: In the years that it has been said that Warner Brothers was going to resurrect the Superman franchise, I was both hopeful and skeptical. I love the 1978 Richard Donner film. That one and Superman II were the only good films in the series. Superman III and IV were utter embarrassments. So I thought that the new film could rectify the damage.Obviously, the new film would have the benefit of CGI. I had no doubt that the effects would be great. But would Brandon Routh succeed in the title role? Christopher Reeve is, and will always be the DEFINITIVE Superman, no one will ever be able to match what he brought to the role. Routh does what he can, he was chosen I think because he does look a little like Reeve, especially when he smiles. He does a good job, but the script doesn't give him much to say.Bryan Singer is obviously a fan of the Donner film, so he really creates an update of the Donner film. It is not a complete re-imagining of the series, a la Batman Begins. I think that is a good thing, this film positions itself really after Superman II. Superman returns after 5 years away, and Lois Lane has moved on. The film wants to explore his love for her, and also his loneliness, there are passages in the film where he is above the earth, alone. All of this is handled well, but there is a slight absence joy in the film. The Donner film took the character seriously enough to involve the viewer but the script and the actors all played there roles with a little bit of a wink, which made it all more fun. Especially Lex Luthor. Gene Hackman played the role for laughs, but was evil enough to make him a good villain. Here, Kevin Spacey plays Luthor more seriously, he is cruel and out for revenge, with an occasional funny one liner, I wish he would have chosen a lighter tone. Again, it works , but not as well as before.In general the cast is good but I think Kate Bisworth us not a good Lois Lane. She doesn't have the feistiness that I think Margot Kidder brought to the role. And there isn't great chemisrty between her and Routh. The relationship isn't fleshed out. The effects are great as expected, there is a great scene involving an airliner that is a show stopper. I think another couple action scenes would have been better.. The look of the film is taken from Bryan Singer's X-Men world. The movie is mostly shot in in blues and grays, a little more color would have been nice.All in all it is reverant to the vision laid down by Richard Donner in 1978. Perhaps too reverant. It could have used a couple of additional action scenes and Brandon Routh should have been given more of a chance to flesh out his Clark Kent. He does very little as Clark.After the pathetic films that were Superman 3 and 4 and not to mention Supergirl, this was a welcome addtion to the series for me. I wish that Bryan Singer would have been allowed to continue on with this series like it was originally planned. But because it wasnt a huge hit Warner Brothers pulled the plug. It wasntba bomb but I guess it didn't make enough money.Flawed but good film.Grade: B.

"You don't really love that guy you make it with now do you? I know you don't love that guy 'cause I can see right through you." – The Clique, Superman"You wrote that the world doesn't need a savior, but every day I hear people crying for one." – Superman, line of dialogue from the filmSuperman Returns comes to us nearly twenty years after the last Superman movie. The question on everybody's mind then: was this film worth the wait?The story opens with text on the screen informing us that after astronomers found Krypton, the planet of Superman's origin, Superman disappeared without any warning. We in the audience don't have to wait too long for him to come back, but the rest of the people in his life had to wait for five years. During that five years Lois Lane had a son, violent crime in the city rose dramatically, oh, yeah, and Lex Luthor got out of prison.Of course at the same time Superman comes back, so does Clark Kent (Brandon Routh) who informed his coworkers at the Daily Planet before he left that he'd be off globetrotting and doing some soul searching.Of course, not long after he gets back, Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth) gets into mortal peril. There was a funny moment in the Superman cartoon that was made during the late nineties where a group of terrorists hijack a plane on which Lois is a passenger. When she stumbles another passenger asks, "Are you okay, Miss Lane?" At this the hijackers adopt a stricken look. "Lane?" one of them says. "Lois Lane?" She nods. "The one that Superman is always saving?" Her lips curl up into a smug grin and she nods again. And of course, Superman saves the day. It wouldn't be a Superman movie if Lois Lane wasn't getting herself into life threatening situations every third scene or so. Indeed, one wonders how she lasted five years without him. But soon we stop caring because we get to see some spectacular effects as Superman makes his first public appearance in five years. And the people rejoice.And as usual, Superman is news, big news. As such, Perry White (Frank Langella) assigns his entire staff to find out everything that they can about Superman. In doing this, he pulls Lois off of another story that, really, is more important. Lois, being Lois, pursues the story anyway and gets herself kidnapped by Luthor (Kevin Spacey), who has a plan to *gasp* destroy Superman.The plan is better than any he had in the earlier films, which is no surprise, as in this film the script, acting and characterizations are all better as well. Routh delivers his lines in a style very similar to the late Christopher Reeve yet still makes the performance his own. Bosworth is far superior as Lois lane (not to mention better looking) than Margot Kidder and Kevin Spacey plays Luthor with just the right blend of sophistication and insanity. James Marsden (Cyclops from the X-Men films) also makes an appearance as Richard White, Perry's nephew and the future Mr. Lois Lane. I really didn't much care for Marsden as Cyclops, but his character here is believable. It would be easy, I suppose, to make Lois's new beau a thumb-sucking weenie to act as a convenient plot point to create tension, but director Bryan Singer (who brought us the first two X-Men films) rises above this temptation. The result is an intelligent film that pays tribute to what was good about the 1978 film while making it better, and not just as a special effects extravaganza, and brings Superman into the twenty-first century.I hope this team does more with Superman. "Superman Returns" is a solid, well done film, and it would be a shame to ignore the vast amount of talent that it brought together.

Review Title: A definite must see for Superman fans!
The Man of Steel is Back!
Review: ... with a BANG! Literally, there's no better way to describe the movie. It's been a while since I saw any of the first 4 Superman flicks but this one carried out the grace, the grandeur and the glamor the same way it's predecessors did. Even the opening credits were done the same way.OK, there was quite a bit of weirdness. Clark/Kent here looked much younger than where he left off in the last movie. Now you must know before watching Superman Returns that this movie is a continuation of the saga from Superman II, and not IV. III was a bad downfall, and IV was a continuation from II, ignoring III ever existed. Now V has done the same thing, and I pray that if there's a VI, the story continues from V.Getting back to Superman Returns, the movie was produced and shot entirely in Australia. Beautiful locales, less hassles compared to shooting in NYC, and cheaper overall production were probably the driving factors. However, the main city in the story was still good ol' Metropolis (the big apple near, Kansas?) and everything else was same as the comics - Daily Planet newspaper, Lex Luther, Martha Kent and Lois Lane. Would be a good idea to watch the first and second movies before moving on to this one. Even if you're an ardent Smallville fan.The casting - a totally unknown actor named Brandon Routh who appeared in some daytime soap opera played the lead role of Clark Kent/Kal-El/Superman. He was impressive, and justified replacing Christopher Reeve. Unfortunately he may also be type-casted and find less success in other roles the same way. In fact he looked very similar to Reeve in the outfit - they probably morphed him in the post-production to. Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane was adorable. She looked good, played her part well and carried the weight of the role very gracefully.The best actor in the movie, of course, was Kevin Spacey, playing S-Man's nemesis Lex Luther. For a change, he didn't try to be the same character Gene Hackman portrayed in the earlier movies, but instead improvised brilliantly and executed all sides of Luther with expertise. A villain may have greed for power, evil ideas and means to acquire that , still you can't really portray such a character in a movie to all in all bad bad bad, evil, kill the mofo type. It gets clichéd and seems like you're watching Fox News at that time if they drag the evil side too far.The script writers could have possibly borrowed some ideas to renovate Luther's character from the TV show Smallville (besides the shaved-head, yes) - but it worked all in all. Kudos to Spacey, yet again.The supporting cast of Frank Langella, James Marsden, Parker Posey and Kal Penn could be moderately commendable. Peta Wilson could be overlooked for playing the blonde MILF in the airplane escorting the shuttle, it was still nice to see her on screen again nonetheless. Even years after the show Le Femme Nikita concluded.Special Effects in this day and age were obviously dominated by CGI (like HULK), and the flying scenes were really well done. The only flaw in the movie could be it's length: over 2.5 hours long. Has a couple of slow moments. I know 2 of my friends in Dallas who fell asleep before it was halfway through, but I consider them narcoleptic anyway.Overall I rate this movie an 8.5 out of 10. Do not watch the last show if you're a morning person... you will probably not fall asleep but may also not appreciate the movie to its best.

Usually, I like to wait a few weeks after a big movie comes out to avoid the lines. I wished I had waited a few years after seeing this. This has to be one of the most disappointing movies I've seen in a while...especially after being pleasantly surprised by Batman Begins last year.Not everything is horrible...I thought the casting was great, Brandon Routh & Kevin Spacey pulled off great performances. The only problem was that there was nothing for them to perform. The movie was extremely slow, and nothing really happened. There never seemed to be any impending doom or any thought that "oh, how is he going to pull this off". The only thing I am more upset about than watching the movie is the fact that there is a great likelihood that there will be one or more sequels.

Review Title: What a waste of time and money!
Review: I am tired of film makers focusing so much on the visual presentation of their work, that they forget to tell a compelling story. What's more frustrating is so many people have gushed praises on this film and others like King Kong and X-Men 3 that it encourages the studios to continue with these spectacular visual productions with weak story lines and poor character development. It's even more frustrating that people in mass pay to see these films and turn them into blockbusters. And most frustrating of all, I am one of those people who paid to see this film. I wish I could take it back. Superman Returns will insult your intelligence. I love action/adventure films but some of my favorites from the last couple of years haven't been the biggest hits, like Sahara (now this was a fun film to watch), and Into the Blue. A couple of films I enjoyed that were also big hits are National Treasure and Pirates of the Caribbean.

this movie was a lot better than i thought it was going to be...i am not a superman fan (i like smallville, die-hard superman fans please don't kill me) but i am a fan of this movie...i like action movies.i wish kate bosworth wouldn't have died her hair back blonde as soon as they were done filming..it is so ugly...she made a pretty brunette i am very impressed by Brandon Routh's performance...he was the biggest dork ever as Clark Kent. He waved like a geek, he looked like a dork, and he was totally nerdy. Sort of cute, but really geeky. Then, when he became Superman, it was a complete change. He was so hott! Even his hair looked different. It was like he played two very different characters but both were totally believable this is so not a chick flick...in fact, i wish there would've been more romance, but there wasn't...i am a little disappointed in that...there were several heart-wrenching parts towards the end...all the effects are amazing...the flying is so cool, and i don't even know how they filmed some of those scenes...it was amazing all in all, a fantastic movie. the only question i have (this might be a small spoiler) could we please get a real kiss at the end???

Review Title: At least they use John William's theme music!
The Man Of Steel Is Indeed Back...

Review: Okay...I just got back from seeing Superman Returns. In a word, triumphant! Special effects have come a long way since the 'first' Superman movies, and all I can say is THANK GOODNESS. But besides special effects, I thought the entire cast did a great job of acting. But, and of course, the number one performance, hands down, and in my opinion, was turned in by Kevin Sapcey with his portrayal of Lex Luthor! Say what you will about 'comic book' hero movies, but if they ever handed out an Oscar to an actor who played in one, then Kevin Spacey is certainly worthy! The storyline and script were somewhat expected with a couple of 'new' twists added in for good measure. Lot's of action makes the 154 minute running time seem to 'fly' by, if you will. I probably could have sat through another viewing, easily!

It shouldn't come as any surprise that the 200 million plus "Superman Returns" has some of the best special effects and action sequences I've ever seen. What is surprising is the way in which the large expanses of quiet, emotional scenes kept me as alert and engrossed as any of the blood and thunder managed to. Bryan Singer makes Superman seem vulnerable and human without making him any less awe inspiring. Where a less talented filmmaker would have churned out something cheesy and manipulative, he constructs a tale with real feeling. The most surprising of the plot developments departed quite a bit from comic lore and had me feeling a bit odd at first, but I ended up finding it kind of inspiring. Singer managed to wrangle up a real surprise in a story that's basically been told repeatedly for seventy years. Another aspect of the film I appreciated was Singer's use of religious symbolism, which actually gave certain scenes more gravitas, and was very subdued compared to the "smack you over the head with a bat" subtexts of X3.Now, the best director in the world can't do much with a bad cast, and thankfully that's not a problem here. Brandon Routh channels Christopher Reeve in nearly all his scenes and does so very effectively, coupled with his physical resemblance this reinforces a sense of continuity with the previous films. Kate Bosworth manages to fill Lois Lane's shoes admirably (making me feel a bit foolish, as I was vocal in my displeasure at her casting), as does the rest of the cast in their respective roles. Kevin Spacy was impressive as Luthor, managing to remain menacing while spouting one-liners, a feat Gene Hackman didn't pull off quite as successfully.In the end, Superman Returns stands side by side with Batman Begins as the best of the recent comic book movies. A terrific melding of talent and tech that should satisfy any movie goer. I've heard some other comic fans lambasting the one aforementioned "departure" from previous tales of Superman. To them I say: accept the movie on it's own terms, and you'll leave the theater happy.

Review Title: Finally a realistic type of superhero movie
New believable technology, awesome powers with a strong human values
Review: Well done. Modernized and updated technology. All characterizations less hyperbole, and more believable. Excellent casting. Kevin Spacy as Lex Luther a more credible villain. Parker Posey although type cast again, still brings fresh dimension to her character. Kate Bosworth, less of a ditz and more of a dedicated professional with a love - hurt relationship with Superman. Brandon Routh makes a perfect transition from Christopher Reeves, while maintaining his own persona. Same familiar music in new arrangements. New twist to the Lois Lane relationship, love at its heart. Great photography, and blend of animation. The flying scenes at times had more wonder in them. Great family and human values at the core; right conquers wrong, good over evil. May be one of those the you can watch over and over again. An enjoyable film.

Review Title: A strange but powerful new vision of the Superman saga
Review: Superman Returns does things that no other Superman show has ever done and does other things far better than the shows that came before. For this reason alone, it is well worth watching.If you like Superman, you will probably love this movie. It treats Superman with a respect that few movies from comic books realize is possible and allows him to display his powers in a mature and credible fashion. Routh is engaging and believable throughout the movie, Spacey is the best Lex Luthor ever, and all of the other actors do an average job or better.The movie has two main problems. The first problem is the lack of a meaningful plot. Instead, there are several different sub-plots, most of which are executed superbly, that never come together in a coherent story line. In particular, as good as Spacey is, the sub-plot with Lex Luthor feels forced and is almost irrelevant, more of an excuse for things to happen than a worthwhile story on its own.The second problem is the overly liberal use of music. There are scenes where the music works, but for the most part it is laid on too thickly. The worst part of this problem is that every time (and I mean EVERY time) Superman is about to do something good, the scene is heralded by the Superman theme. The rest is the same problem that every movie (except Tarantino movies) has to some degree, in which the director tries to convey the emotion of the scene with music instead of allowing the audience to figure it out from the dialog, etc.I very much enjoyed watching the movie. But it will be a while before I watch it again.

Review Title: Not an action movie for guys, not a comic-book movie for kids
A great must-see with just a few minor mistakes which caused it to avoid a four star rating...
A Great Film with a Little Nostalgia
Review: I saw the film Friday night with my sister and I had previously read the rather unfair review by Roger Ebert. I actually enjoyed the film and I respected the fact that the film paid homage to the 1978 Superman film and to Christopher Reeve. Clark Kent aka Superman returns to Earth after five years of searching for his home planet or at least the remains of his people. He is reunited with his adopted mother, Martha Kent (Eva Marie Saint), and returns to his job as a reporter for the Daily Planet. He is also reunited and shocked to find that his long-time love, Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth, who is a lovely Lois Lane), has a child and is engaged to the handsome and all-around nice successful Richard White (James Mardsen). But to add insult to injury, Lois had won a Pulitzer Prize for an article she wrote entitled, "Why The World Doesn't Need Superman." Meanwhile, Lex Luthor (perfectly casted Kevin Spacey) is out of prison and has inherited a fortune by marrying an old, dying woman and funding a plan to create land that will inevitably destroy billions of lives. Superman is on the way and returns with a clean swoop from the sky. I actually enjoyed the film for the following reasons: 1. Brandon Routh...damn! Need I say more? No, really, he played the character beautifully knowing that it wasn't going to be easy to play the role made ten times famous by the late Christopher Reeve and he was a good Superman and I for one wouldn't mind seeing him again in a sequel. 2. For the sake of nostalgia and respect, the film pays a nice tribute to the comic book hero in a current time such as ours where there is a war and lack of leadership and a need for a hero. It is both uplifting, but at the same time sad that in times like ours we do wish for a Superman. 3. Excellent special effects makes the film intriguing to watch and fun. However, the following flaws weighed down the film (and if anyone knows the writers of this film this is an important criticism that should be taken as advice if they are thinking about a sequel): 1. the female characters were underdeveloped: Lois Lane comes off as a damsel in distress in this film compared to the 1978 version where Lois (played wonderfully by Margot Kidder) was spunky, plucky, and can fight back when threatened. In here, Lois is distant and at times acts like a deer on headlights. It's not Kate Bosworth's fault; its the script that doesn't give more to Lois in making her a real modern day female heroine and more importantly it would have been great if the writers showed us why Superman is so in love with her. Another one was the casting of Parker Posey as Lex's right hand woman and companion Kitty Kawolski: she is a clueless airhead in this film; there is no spunk or the cute sarcasm that was Valerie Perine as Miss Tretchmacher in the 1978 version. Martha Kent played by the lovely Ms. Eva Marie Saint (cool...isn't? Saint co-starred opposite Marlon Brando in the great On The Waterfront) had such a small part and it was also slightly underdeveloped. And the second flaw is I wish there were some flashbacks that could tell a little bit more of Superman and his relationship with Lois. Other than the flaws mentioned above, the film is worth watching and it is still fun, but in a way I walked away sad because the week before watching this film I had just watched another film called United 93. Yes, I wish we had a Superman and this is the closest we will ever get.

This thing is plot less drivel. Maybe a movie about special effects is all it takes to entertain some people, but anyone with any degree of intelligence is going to be bored to tears. Keven Spacey is completely unbelievable as a bad guy. His gf is flat, dull & boring. LL is skinny as a stick & twice as lifeless. Her husband might as well be a paper doll. But my biggest problem is that Hollywood markets this violence to children. It is, after all, BASED ON A COMIC BOOK. I was so disgusted by the violence that I finally just walked out. There was a little girl about 8 or 9 that walked out when I did. She was shaking & almost in tears. I asked her if she was OK & she said she could not stand the violence. In this country, we are wondering why we are seeing generation after generation of desensitized & violent young people. Is it any wonder when we are responsible for force feeding them this violent trash? If you make a movie for kids, make it a kids' movie. This is vile. Not for children.

Pretty impressive. A lot better than I originally thought. It's no Superman II but great on it's own. I had only one problem with the casting; Kate Bosworth. She's hot but she wouldn't have been my first choice to play Lois. She just looks way too young for the part. Brandon Routh however was very impressive despite this being only his first movie. Routh may share an uncanny resemblance to the late Christopher Reeve, but this Superman is his own. Kevin Spacey, to me, has never appeared in a bad role and does it again here as the diabolical Lex Luthor. Spacey's Luthor is the most evil and maniacal incarnation of the character yet. Gene Hackman's got nothing on him! This movie was not as good as Batman Begins or Spider-man 2 but I'd definitely rank it somewhere up there. Kudos to director Bryan Singer for taking Supes in the right direction!

Review Title: At least the opening credits were good.
Review: What better time to release this, than hot on the heels of Smallville? Why does Lois have a kid??? Because the whole hard working hottie single mom thing is in with Hollywood? How come Lois looks twenty years younger if this took place after the events in Superman II? Was Superman only seventeen when he disappeared for five years? He sure looks it! Why even bother with Ma Kent, a waste of a character? Lex Luthor AGAIN?!? Geez, the guy just never learns! And the twist near the end, painfully stupid and contrived. Of all the nerve! These are some of the burning questions that this utter borefest of two and half hours provides.At least some of the homages to the first two films were true to form. Thank God they kept the music intact too, no rap or emo! No sequels needed, please!

I just saw the movie and I'm still in shock about how great it was! It was so wonderful that the entire audience clapped and cheered when it was over! I consider Roger Ebert's review of the movie as a day old turd left in the toilet. He just didn't get it. It's time for him to retire. He seemed to have wanted the movie to be like Superman 1. But it didn't need to be. The story was new, different and held it's own. I was crying during the opening and whenever I heard the music because I was so moved. This movie had the perfect tone/feeling and was so respectful to Chris Reeve's movies. I'm going to go see this movie a few more times! Throughout the movie, my husband and I just kept saying "Wow!" and "So Cool!" Brandon Routh did a wonderful job and the director did a phenomenal job. Go see this movie!

Review Title: Went in with low expectations and Superman flew well below them.
Review: Superman has undergone many television and movie incarnations and this movie instead of starting fresh new start with new and young audiences it continues the story set forth by Christopher Reeve. While watching the movie you'll notice if you're not familiar with the Superman Mythos a lot will not be explained, though it seems the film makers have counted that the audience will know at least the basics.There will surely be a few moments that will take your breath away or even put a smile on your face as you watch with childlike wonder. All that soon fades away as the movie drags on to a long lasting two and a half hours.As far as story goes, there could have definitely have been better obstacles placed before the Man of Steel. Ultimately you are comforted/annoyed by the fact nothing besides green rocks can harm him. If you're looking forward to seeing Superman face a challenge that takes a lot more than brawn to overcome, go watch some Smallville. Which is definitely a better portrayal of the Superman.In closing, only spend money on this film if you truly enjoy Superman in any shape or form. Even then though, don't forget to set your expectations a little lower than you'd might so you're not too disappointed.

Review Title: Better than X3 but missing heart

Review: Coming from a Smallville perspective, I didn't think I would like this movie. But, I was very pleasantly surprised by this film. Brian Singer delivers up a fresh and spectacular vision of Superman for the modern era. The characters of this movie are very well done (except for Lois Lane ~Kate Bosworth~). Brandon Routh gives a very human performance for his role of Clark Kent, the bumbling Daily Planet Reporter. He also does the Man of Steel justice and surprisingly, the costume didn't look goofy. Next is Kevin Spacey for the role of Lex Luthor. And I have to say, another job well done. The only person I didn't like in this movie is Lois Lane. Kate Bosworth just doesn't deliver the sarcastic lines that Margot Kidder (Superman I-IV) did. She just doesn't give any life to the character. And finally Jimmy Olsen (Sam Huntington) gives a very hilarious performance. All in all, I give it a 8. The reason I'm not giving it a 10 is this. They dragged the movie out when they didn't need to. And also, I wish a villain was in it (besides Lex). But hey, I can't wait for a sequel!

Horrible superman movie. No action, no excitement. I had been anticipating this for a long time, what a huge let down!! Please don't get high expectations before you see this movie or you will be very very disappointed!Anyone who had been tagged to direct this should have. It's a very dull love story, and lacks any excitement!Please save yourself some money and wait for this on DVD. The effects aren't even worth paying money for!The acting was OK and he made a fine superman. I don't blame any of the actors for this pile of steaming crap. The few laughs i got out of it were hardly worth the lack of action and excitement i expect from a comic book movie.

After just viewing Hollywood's latest remake/comic book movie I have to say that it was pretty good. There was however, one thing that I didn't particularly like about the movie. What happened to the candy apple red colored cape and boots? There's nothing wrong with burgundy but the afore mentioned color is part of the cornerstone that is the identity of superman. I know, that's being a little picky but when I think of superman I think man of steel in bright red and blue. Enough complaining... the story and special effects were very well done. Routh was a good choice as the lead. Spacey's no Hackman but no one but Hackman could have done it better. It was a great Brian Singer effort... I just wish he would have done X-3.

Superman Returns is about Superman who after a 5 year disappearance suddenly reaper's to the surprise of everyone in Metropolis. So where has Superman been all these years? Visiting his old planet and catching up with some site seeing of the graveyard that was once his former planet, how that takes 5 years to do is beyond me but any who...Just as he comes back, Clark Kent just happens to be back in town and needs a job. He then runs into Lois Lain only to find out that his Queen has moved on and is now engaged with a kid. Whats more is that Lex Luthor our famed evil doer is out of jail because Superman wasn't there to testify against him in court.Lex Luthor has somehow discovered Superman's fathers lair, and by talking to a computer of SUperman's father he is able to learn what Superman's weakness's are and how he can use the crystals in the lair combined with kryptonite to take the mighty Superman down.The downside to this somewhat simple story is that its awfully cheesy, its like watching a kids flick only its rated pg-13 probably cause of the cheesy scenes that Bryan Singer felt the need to show us in order to see how Superman works or something. The chemistry between Brandon Routh and Kate Boworth are no Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan from You've got mail. Frank Langella is like watching a dead person move, he has no life at all just shouts a lot at everyone. James Marsden I would have liked to have seen some more of, all we saw was him playing the kid and a joke or two with Lois. I mean come on! Lois is practically drooling over Superman and Richard doesn't even flinch its almost as if since we know from history that Lois and Superman are supposed to be together so why even bother making her boyfriend get jealous, I mean after all who would? And last but not least Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor, I liked him. He was the only funny one and yet evil at the same time. I would have liked to have seen some more background on him though, like why was he in jail? What happened in the court room? I mean is everyone who watches this film supposed to have seen Superman from 1978? Not everyone has the luxury of doing that.So my final ruling is that if you want to see a kickass superhero movie, go see Spiderman 2, Batman Begins, or Daredevil. This movie was mediocre, now don't get me wrong it wasn't bad just not amazing.

I grew up in the age of Christopher Reeve being an awesome superman. I couldn't think of anyone else doing it. Kind of like there is only one actor that could play Indiana Jones perfectly. I cried in the movie, but I knew I would because it's sad to not see Christopher Reeve.I think they found a good actor for this part, heck I'd jump in his arms. This new kid does a great job. I'm impressed with the changes in the tone of his voice when he is Kent and when he is Superman. The movie has original music and artwork from the first movies. I think all the actors did a great job. I'd like to see it again and I look forward to seeing what they will do next.

Review Title: No it wasn't a bird, neither an airplane...it was Superman...
Review: It was Super..The movie was fantastic, the graphics, the sets, the dialogs, the performances, the story, the concept, they were all good… It's a complete worth money and time…I never thought I was gonna watch Superman returns in a movie theater well…my brothers just decided to somehow…I was so excited about it…I wore a red shirt and a blue jeans…and when we reached the theater…I saw most of the people wearing red...The movie makes you laugh makes you cry…it makes you just love Superman allover again…There's a lot of suspense…you can never guess what will be the ending…even when there's only one minute of the movie left…but you can watch it a lot more times..Now am like Superman in everything…I just wanna be Superman…the pain he carries...the love he receives from all the people around the world…except Lex Luther of course…its all that I want…when were speeding the bike I just wanna jump up and fly…And after the movie end…it's like we're thinking about Superman…the story…how it ended…and its like I want more! I hope they have a sequel to this part planed…My brother says that Spiderman is better than Superman…well I say there no match… They both are different…they have different powers…I like Spiderman too…I know this might not be the kinda comment you were looking for..but I don't wanna spoil it..I want everyone to go and watch it..you're never gonna hate it…So go and watch it! And after that you might look you in the sky and wonder

Review Title: one of the best in a long time
Review: From the night of the sneak preview throughout Saturday (so far) a number of people in our family have seen the movie and have loved it. Many have gone back a second time and if it is still on at the local theater come next week end will be back at it again. For anyone not around for the first two (out of four) Superman movies in the past this wonderful movie not only gives a great background but sets up many, many possibilities for future movies. The possibilities are endless. Hopefully TPTB will all continue to do their best with any and all sequels. The "new" superman is the main reason I will watch for sequels. He did a fantastic job!

Review Title: Should have been called stupid man
Review: I will admit up front that I went into this movie with a bias. I really didn't think much of the first four Superman movies. The first one was okay and second less than okay and the third and fourth were terrible. So when I saw the previews of this movie I moaned and I was right to moan. Where do I start? First this movie had the worst starring actor I have ever seen. I know that he was picked because of his resemblance to Christopher Reeves but he looked plastic, like an action figure, a real cartoon character, devoid of real facial expressions or emotions. His close ups were scary, really scary.Second the writing was just pitiful. Starting with the opening and then getting worse as the movie progressed. Bryan Singer gave Lois Lane selective amnesia and hoped that the rest of us had it too (concerning events from the other films). I guess he was trying to make X-men but Superman is not X-men and the dark, melodrama came off just plain laughable. This so-called savior Superman was all about personal accolades; he thrived on people loving him especially the women he should have left alone because she was already spoken for. And speaking of the whole Savior theme, I thought is was heavy handed and ridiculous. A real Savior does what he does cause it's right not because he wants everyone to have his name on their lips.Last, the whole ending was just plain stupid. Hello, where should Superman go to get healed, the fortress of solitude. Singer couldn't stop stealing from other movies i.e. The Matrix long enough to realize that. The people from DC comics should have given him a few of them to read. I just kept laughing during the whole supposed melodramatic ending, will he or won't he. Really I didn't care. Too bad that I already know there will be a sequel with the annoying child. I agree with Roger Ebert he looks like Damien, where were the 6's. 4/10

Long story short, what Bryan Singer did to Superman Returns is what Richard Donner did to Superman. He kept it true to the first 2 movies with some surprising plot twists.The movie was a bit slow for the first 10-15 minutes, out of 2 1/2 hours, but it really picked up into a must see movie. The story revolves around Superman returning after 5 years to Earth after trying to find his birth home, Krypton. And finding the world is different and desperately needs Superman. The story largely revolving around the love between Superman and Lois Lane was excellently portrayed. And of course Lex Luthor is back to his old tricks again from the 1978 movie.Brandon Routh did an excellent job succeeding the late Christopher Reeve. Not just as in appearance, but his portrayal of the Man of Steel. But for those who are critical about him being Superman, imagine if back in 1978 when Christopher Reeve was portraying the Man of Steel when George Reeves made him popular.As well as Kevin Spacy bringing Lex Luthor to life the way that Gene Hackman did. Another excellent successor. Kate Bosworth, not bad, she's no Margot Kidder, but not bad.Excellent visual effects, excellent story, Bryan Singer seems to be incapable of ruining Superman even if he tried. Definitely worth his time and effort.Review 17 months later....Not only this plays with the original Superman movies with Christopher Reeves, at least the first 2, but like Superman's 1 & 2, it plays with a part of Superman that in my opinion few realize he had. The man behind the Man of Steel. A reminder that Superman is more than someone who goes flying around and fights crime, but there is also a sentimental behind him. The man who loves Lois.I think that Superman Returns in terms of dependency is closely related to James Cameron's classic horror/sci-fi film "Aliens," which as you know is actually a sequel to the Ridley Scott classic, "Alien." All you needed was about 5 minutes worth of the basics on Alien which then James Cameron was able to bring forth a classic that can stand on its own.You don't desperately need Superman's 1 & 2 for Superman Returns, but just the basics of Superman. It only has "simple" scenes and dialogs to connect it to the original, but all of it were effective enough so that everyone can understand Superman. As an example, when Lois said, "I've done Superman before," Jimmy snorted humorously, indicating that she and Superman did indeed have, you know. You don't need to see Clark and Lois in bed from Superman 2.It is among the best things, like on Superman Returns, you don't need incredible amounts of detail for something so simple. If Superman Returns is dependent on anything, then it is the lore of Superman itself. The legend. Not doing a reboot saves us on more boring details, and have a "stand alone" sequel so you don't need the previous films to understand Superman.As well as the concept of the son is also excellent. Bring us to the man behind Superman. How he may be indeed the last survivor of the planet Krypton, but anyone who was orphaned, or lost family would understand. And returning to a world that has changed, like a soldier returning from a war.But one of the negatives about Superman Returns is the utter selfishness of the audience, especially the self-proclaimed experts. They believe that the World needs Superman to protect us from ourselves and clean up after ourselves so we don't have to. Or in English, it's Superman's problem, not ours. The world doesn't need Superman that way. The world needs Superman for his Symbology for good.When you get down to it, Superman can rarely get any better than this after Richard Donner at the helm.17 months ago, give Superman Returns ..... 9.5 out of 10. Today, give Superman Returns ..... 10/10.

Review Title: Superman returns is a genius work by Bryan
Review: Faster than a speeding bullet… more powerful than a locomotive… Everyone knows the legend . Everyone knows the scene the crowd that lifts it's collective eyes to the sky at the distinctive whine of rushing wind and calls out .''Look up in the sky! It's a bird. It's a plane ..its Superman'' The greatest Superhero who inspired both kids and adults {American soldiers in combat in world war 2} for centuries is back in action on big screen after a long wait of 20 years. The wait was worth. Superman returns is a lavish spectacle which do contains the classic ingredients of Superman. Director Bryan singer combines the fascinating action , score and pathos with an intimate portrait of Superman. Singer finds a truly original approach to tell the story. Even if Superman is conceived on a doomed, distant planet, Superman is complete with all the desires , problems and idiosyncrasies that you'd find in any living, breathing individual. He is not like us, but in his heart he thinks he is. The bond that exists for Clark, with the people he loves and the world that adopted him. Brandon Routh repaid the faith shown in him by perfectly stepping in the boots of Reeves. Kevin Spacey stands apart as Lex Luthor and his is the most pleasing performance. The mood of the movie is bit gloomy anyway edge of the seat action lights it up. The world definitely needs more Superman movies.

Review Title: A comics film with more heart than action, (and I'm thankful for it!)
Superman Returns and then leaves again
Very Entertaining Superhero Action Movie With Heart
Review: I saw it, and I loved it. I heard a little too much from naysayers before finally getting myself to the theater to see it, so I was apprehensive, but I had no reason to be. Bryan Singer is a fine director, good at pacing things, alternating the bullet bouncing off the superhero with the lump in the throat. He fills the two and a half hour running time with enough action to please action fans, prodigious and frequent use of Superman's many powers, a love story, and some genuine emotions from all the characters, including anonymous bystanders and Lex Luthor, the bad guy! I'm no Superman ignoramus, nor novice, having read about him with much gusto since about the time I learned to read at all. There is nothing in this movie that would be out of place in the Superman comics of the last few decades, and many an element you probably wouldn't see in the comics. Brandon Routh is a great Superman, fills the red boots with ease, and makes the role his own. I never thought anyone could follow Christopher Reeve; after all, I saw his version when I was nine years old, and he made quite an impression on me. Brandon does great things with the role, and I'd love to see him in many more Superman movies. Kate Bosworth was the biggest surprise, as I really expected her to be too young to pull it off, but I forgot about that as soon as the movie got underway. Her first scenes as Lois Lane are just bitchy enough to evoke the sassy star reporter even hardcore fans demand. Kevin Spacey was perfect as Lex Luthor, playing it a lot less wacky and more seriously. The effect was chillingly evil at times. The rest of the cast were great, with special credit going to Sam Huntington for being as realistically dorky as one could be without spoiling the Jimmy Olson character. He even wore a bow-tie. The special effects are phenomenal. The action is just as larger than life as it should be for Superman. The film is peppered with many references, including some very small subtle ones, to not only Supes' history but the DC Universe as well. All in all, a fun film that joins the ranks of superhero movies that get it right. Naysayers and nitpickers beware, even you may find yourself liking it. For a modern film at ten bucks for two and a half hours, you can't do better.

There I was on my seat waiting for the title to roll, and once it started happening I was anticipating something like when I watched the first part of the movie when i was a kid, but sadly it was disappointment in the end, considering the high inputs. What surprised me was, the acting. I didn't expect Routh or Bosworth to do so well, but it turns out they did a terrific job. Kevin Spacey...there isn't a role in which he becomes the character, the character becomes him!! Fantastic work as usual. Every actor in the movie did a good job, though the direction of the movie can be told it is "Bryanised", i failed to understand why he would let his dream project go out of character. And there is more saving superman, than him saving the others......and the relationship between Superman and Lois Lane makes no sense.....no continuation from second part(as it claims to be), she is not supposed to remember they had a reltionship(remember?) In the end, it is worth a watch, but the story isn't gonna satify you, great special effects and great acting.

I was excited about this movie, as I usually share similar sentiments to the IMDb median vote.This film was a total waste of time and money.Dreadful.Can't understand the positive reviews. What are people thinking?! Stupid.I lost interest after 15 minutes.The sad truth is the film will make a lot of money, and a sequel will be made even worse! A stinker.Hollywood can't even do schlock properly any more.Terrible! I won't bother saying any more.

When I was young there were a a few books, shows or movies that were incredibly special to me and that will always have a place in my heart: Dr Who, The Goodies, Star Wars, Narnia, LOTR and so on. These are my own personal myths, if you like, so it's been wonderful over the past few years to see the stories continue (or to see films made of them in the case of the books). Sometimes they were done well (Dr Who) and sometimes not so well (Star Wars) but I always got a real thrill at the start, when my hopes were still unspoiled, and those iconic tunes started to play. Even the first new Star Wars passed the test on that one - although I walked out disappointed, it was such a powerful moment when they cranked out the title theme after all those years of waiting. These are unforgettable moments for me - like when I finally saw Bowie play after waiting so many years for him to come out to Oz.The Superman movies (I never actually read the comics much) had a powerful impact on me as a child. I loved the first two so much - Christopher Reeve was fabulous, the effects were great and John William's superb score was as stirring as anything he ever did (Star Wars and Jaws included). Sure, looking back they seem a little hokey, but I will always love them, and that sequence where Superman catches the Helicopter and saves Lois Lane in the first movie is still one of my favourite movie moments of all time. It was Brilliantly conceived, choreographed, edited and scored. Wow.I remember being so excited when at the end of Superman II we were told that Superman ...would return in Superman III. I waited and waited - it just seemed to take forever to come out, leaving me with only my dreams and hopes of what it would be like. Unfortunately Superman III was a dud. It fell into the same traps that all the lesser superhero movies fall into. Superman IV was even worse - I was embarrassed to even watch it - so I just pretended they never happened (the same way I did with the 3rd and 4th Alien or the 3rd and 4th Batman movies).The years passed and I forgot about Superman. They made new Star Wars films, new Star Trek films. They made movie versions of The Lord of the Rings and The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe. They even managed to get the good Doctor back on the air, but when the new Superman Movie came out I must admit my prime motivation in seeing it was to share the experience with my girlfriend who is a big Superman fan because of Smallville (and dare I say it, Lois and Clark) but a funny thing happened...As the opening titles began and they rolled out the old Superman theme, it all of a sudden hit me how much I had missed Superman, and how much I hoped that they would get it right. I felt my cheeks moisten and my heart grow tight and I felt very much back in touch with that younger self, leaving me only with the question, "can the rest of the film live up to this?" Well, now that the film is done, it is very pleasant for me to say "Yes! Bryan Singer got it right." I can see the things that people have criticised about it, I know where they might feel that it falls down, but none of it bothered me at all. I was struck by the power of the myth, and love that Singer obviously had for the project. As he also didn't think much of the latter Superman Movies, they are totally ignored, meaning that finally, after all these years, I walked out of the cinema feeling like I had seen Superman III.

Review Title: Bryan Singer Revives the Franchise Beautifully
Fighting for truth and justice, as the Americans say
Review: I loved this film, not expecting it to be as good as it is, and still hit those targets that make it Superman. Lois is a difficult character to play and cast. She needs to straddle the divide of being canny as well as not noticing the resemblance of Kent to Superman. The casting of Bosworth for this role seemed perfect to me, partly because she is a good actress, but also because of her face, which resembles that of a girl I fell for over two decades ago. I never dated that girl (her choice), but over fifteen years hardly a day went by when I failed to think that my life might be made better were I to get her to change her mind. The upshot is I am totally sympathetic to her character :DSpacey is a brilliant actor. I don't like his politics, but I don't see his politics in his acting. As Lex, he personifies moody brilliance, flawed and evil genius. His callous disregard for his weak underlings made abundantly clear.Brandon's Superman is a good tribute to those past, and nicely brought into the 21st century. I sympathize with his indecision regarding Lois. Tristan Lake Leabu is believable in his role, and I look forward to his future work .. away from pianos.Nothing is missing from the legend, the story fits well with DC comic milieu and doesn't jar with Smallville. I look forward to a sequel .. ;)

I knew I was in for a treat when the original Superman theme (composed by John Williams) started playing after some text explaining Superman's being on Earth. I went in to the theater with some high expectations and left the theater gitty as a Japanese 16 year old school-girl at a kawaii convention.
