Wide open for a sequel and I surely hope that they get back to the big guy kicking butt and taking names because a namby pamby Superman just ain't my cup of tea!

Review Title: Its a good movie in it all, Superman is Back in great shape!!!

Review: Superman Returns Superman Returns highlights just that: After an absence of about five years, Superman (Brandon Routh) is back. Unknown to most of the citizens of earth, when astronomers discover what they believe to be the remnants of Krypton, Superman is unable to resist taking a trip to check it out for himself.When he finally returns, his mother, Martha (Eva Marie Saint) is happy to see him. His old boss, Perry White (Frank Langella) gives his alter ego, Clark Kent, his job back. Photographer Jimmy Olsen (Sam Huntington) is glad to see Clark, too. But the woman Superman/Clark loves, Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth), has moved on.Lois has a son and a fiancé (Perry's nephew, Richard White, played by James Marsden). She's also about to have a Pulitzer Prize for an editorial she wrote entitled "Why the World Doesn't Need Superman." Try as she might, though, the return of Superman has also brought the return of at least some of her feelings for him.Meanwhile, Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) has only had his own feelings toward Superman intensify over the past several years. And now he's got a plan to take Superman out for good and become rich and powerful beyond his wildest dreams. The fact that he'll have to kill millions — or even billions — of people to do so is just a minor detail to Lex. Along with his bimbo girlfriend, Kitty Kowalski (Parker Posey), Lex puts his plans into action even as Superman is doing his best to repair other much more personal things as best he can.There comes a time, though, when choices are made, losses are endured, and even Superman needs all the strength he can muster. While the world watches and waits, the very survival of relationships, humanity, and Superman himself hangs in the balance.Brandon Routh is eerily like the late Christopher Reeve. While we might expect Superman to look like, well, Superman (the "look" is well established), Routh looks so much like Reeve, sounds so much like him, and even acts a good deal like him that it's uncanny. The fact that he fills out a spandex suit very nicely doesn't hurt, either. Routh, while probably not the world's greatest actor (at least not yet — you'll recall Reeve himself grew well beyond his Superman role as time went on), is just fine in his portrayal of the relatively one-dimensional Superman.Kevin Spacey seems to be having a good time as Lex Luthor, and imbues the character with a hint of real insanity that we've not seen so clearly before; Parker Posey holds her own with the formidable Spacey — which is saying something. Other supporting cast members are fine, and an extra tip of the hat must go to the late Marlon Brando who appears briefly as Superman's father Jor-El thanks to archive footage of his earlier appearances.The one truly problematic performance is that of Kate Bosworth. It's not that she's a bad actress — she isn't. Instead, she's quite plainly woefully miscast. She looks even younger than she is (what, did she start working at the Daily Planet when she was, like, 14?), she doesn't have the forcefulness to play a top notch reporter let alone a Pulitzer Prize winner, and her chemistry with Routh is all but non-existent. It's not Bosworth's fault that she's the weak link here, but she's never-the-less the weak link.The direction is okay for the most part, and I can excuse moments of camp. This is, after all, a comic book! What's not to be excused are the poor edits, the dismally simplistic story, and a very ordinary script. The special effects are largely quite good — particularly those involving a plummeting jumbo jet — but they can't make up for the other shortcomings, and there are many.Superman Returns is okay, I suppose, but it's considerably less than "super," and certainly less than we had the right to expect.POLITICAL NOTES: Say what you will about the homosexual themes of Superman Returns (I frankly didn't see it) or the religious references (those are there, thanks to either lack of imagination or extraordinary hubris on the parts of the writers), there's something much more important offered up at one point in the film: Lex Luthor gleefully mentions an appeal of an earlier conviction that's based on the fact that Superman didn't give him his Miranda rights. Now while some might interpret this to mean that Miranda isn't all that important, especially not when it comes to the worst criminals, I see it differently. To me, this throwaway line says that no matter how altruistic your motivations, and no matter that you're merely working for "truth, justice, and the American way," the rights of even the baddest of bad guys simply must be upheld if the rest of us are to enjoy the privilege of the same. And that's something with which I thoroughly agree.FAMILY SUITABILITY: Superman Returns is rated PG-13 for "some intense action violence." While likely not suitable for the smallest children, I think those of about 10 or so and up will be just fine. I'd frankly be more concerned with the influence on them of the fact that Lois has an illegitimate child, and no one seems to care. Superman Returns will be enjoyed by more than a few people simply because Superman is finally back on the big screen. But for those who expect more from their theater-going experience than some high end effects and some pretty actors, well, you might want to save your anticipation — and your ticket money — for some other film that deserves it more.

Review Title: Great movie -- But some can't handle that it isn't about fighting.
Review: Umm... How come the negative reviews are repeated over and over? Is someone trying to make their less than average opinion count more or something.This movie was excellent in my opinion. I loved that it wasn't an action popcorn movie and was more about the loneliness that is Superman's role in his universe.As for the comments of "How is it that Lois doesn't remember sleeping with Superman?" and other such supposed continuity errors, the problem is not with the film but with the memory of those making the comments. For they are answered adequately by watching Superman II.There are plenty of non-raving reviews in these comments that go over the good and bad point of the film. All that I can added that I have now watched the film twice and enjoyed the touching feel of the whole film and cannot wait for another serving. I would love another battle of the titans for the next time around but loved the more touching story of loneliness that this one was.

I liked this movie quite well. The Lois Lane character needed a little more testosterone. I like the actress, but the casting could have used a little help. The Star of the movie was a great choice and I look forward to more sequels. There were several scenes where it is obvious he is digitized and looks like animation. There are a few flaws with continuity and the editing is a little choppy. I loved seeing Eva Marie Saint (North by North West). She is one of my favorite actresses of years gone by and I wish she had gotten more screen time. Perry White should have been a little more gruff, but overall the casting was done pretty well. Then, of course there is the cameo by the television Jimmy Olson.... What a treat!!!

Review Title: Superman's back...but do we want him?
Review: Well, Superman has returned. However, how long will he stay this time around? From my point of view, not very long.One thing I don't think people will like about this movie is Superman's attitude. He's just too...perfect. He's neatly dressed, very polite, and always there to save the day. But does our society really want a goody-goody after seeing the grittiness of Batman? Do we really need a hero who has no real weaknesses after seeing Spider-Man? Do we really want to see a hero that everybody loves after seeing X-Men? The main problem with bringing Superman back is this: does America really want a Boy Scout in tights, or do we want Wolverine? The movie opens with the feeling of a great sequel to Superman and Superman II, but it just goes downhill right after that.Superman/Clark Kent crash lands back on his childhood farm and begins life again as Clark Kent in the busy city of Metropolis. However, this time around, things aren't as he would have liked them to be. Example: Lois Lane is engaged to another man (JamesMarsden. Suprizingly, when you watch him perform, you hardly ever recognize him as Cyclops from X-Men, which proves how good his acting skills are)! Well, that and a space shuttle/airplane is going haywire in the atmosphere. Heck, all in a days work for Superman.Now, the special effects are top notch in this film. They really are...well...super! The acting is also very great. For his first film, Brandon Routh does a fantastic job as the Man of Steel, though don't expect an Oscar-winning performance. Kate Bosworth does a good job as Lois Lane, and when she and Brandon do a flight scene together, I truly feel like I'm watching Lois and Clark. The best actors in this film, in my opinion, are Sam Huntington as Jimmy Olsen and Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor. They are both highly energetic, funny, and realistic, which matches their characters perfectly.However, this movie is not a very good super hero movie. The storyline is bland and their is hardly any super hero-ing going on! Superman spends half of the movie saving random people's lives from random catastrophes. Sure, that's super, but when it comes to the "epic" fight between Lex and Superman, there's nothing.And the plot is lame. I won't give it away, but...let's just say that, halfway through the movie, all of the supposed "suprizes" will be exposed. No surprise ending. No big twist. Nothing. And that makes for a lame super hero movie.It's a good movie to go see if you seriously have nothing else better to do. The acting and special effects are enough to see it, though, but if you're wanting to see an action-packed epic, see X-Men 3 or wait for Pirates of the Caribbean 2.

Review Title: Worthy Sucessor, and a great movie, but let down by plot holes.
Flawed casting, often boring, too many liberties with source material
Review: Brandon Routh is great as Superman / Clarke Kent - a worthy successor to Christopher Reeve and a relief from Dean Cain, an out-and-out beefcake who couldn't play geeky Clarke Kent. Kevin Spacey is no match for Gene Hackman, although deserves credit for being more threatening. I always liked Hackman's line of playing Luthor as a real coward. Obviously this could be down to the writing. Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane is really miscast, very drippy and, whilst I hated Teri Hatcher's portrayal always getting into trouble and being oh-so-feisty, some of that personality wouldn't have gone amiss here. This is a film for grown-up fans of the original, and has very little to offer kids. Whilst the first was cheesy and the effects very dated or overdone (Superman wipe fading into his costume) it wasn't ever too boring once Krypton blew up. This is boring extensively. Certainly for adults who aren't obsessed fans of Superman, and especially for kids. And I watched the original on TV two weeks beforehand. As for the plot, the source material has been unnecessary distorted to accommodate a modern dysfunctional relationship (the main source of boredom), another cute long-haired American kid, and an underlying general disregard of the traditional logic structure of the Superman comics in order to modernise it in certain ways. It was part of the story's appeal that this all-powerful being can't have a normal relationship with a woman, and that us ordinary guys can! Not any more! I wish director Bryan Singer had finished off the X-Men trilogy, and maybe we'd have one good film in X-Men 3, instead of two average ones in that one and this.

Review Title: A good return to the Superman series which opens the door for many more...
Review: My first thought upon leaving the cinema was "I liked that, bit slow in places, but good all the same". Now I've had time to think about it a little more I think the 'bit slow' part was unjustified. There was a lot of story to get in and so there had to moments when Supe's wasn't deflecting bullets, catching signs, saving planes full of journo's etc... Otherwise the whole movie would have been one big special effect.I particularly like the way that it ignores the horrors that were Superman III and IV! Saying that there are a few holes in the story - What was that thing he flew back in from Krypton? Where did it come from? How did he hold his breath for 5 years (in the old cartoons didn't he have to take oxygen with him into space?) How come no body questions the fact that Clark and Supe's both disappear at the same time and come back at the same time? Just how deep can Lois dive while wearing a full ball gown? Towards the end, when Supes is carrying the rather large rock, and Luthor flys by, why didn't he xray vision the helicopter? There are others but I don't want to give things away for anyone who's not seen it, but the most important other continuity error - he appears to have left his yellow belt back in space, why haven't his pants fell down yet? Brandon Routh, Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworh fit their roles very well (especially Spacey - manic, power crazy and dark, just what Luthor should be). Not sure about Frank Langella as Perry White, something missing there. And Marlon Brando - how well has he aged!?! You wouldn't think he was dead, looks exactly like he did in the first film! ;-) My favourite part - the whole plane/shuttle thingy (again not wanting to give too much away). You almost feel like cheering along with the crowd in the stadium :-) Well worth the money to go and watch. And the best bit - the door is wide open for more Superman films (you'll know what I mean when Brutus gets his final music lesson). I hope Bryan Singer can be persuaded to stay on as I'm really looking forward to seeing more of ol' red pants and his amazing adventures.

I saw the movie, it was a pretty good movie - but was ruined by the fact that Superman was always about 3 things "TRUTH, JUSTICE and The American WAY and according to this movie he is now only about 2 things- Truth and Justice. What is wrong with the American Way?? It's movie makers like this that are destroying the American way! What are they thinking? Or are they thinking? I didn't see Superman growing up in Moscow or Berlin or Crete. How can you change a basic tenet like that? I grew up on Superman comics and Superman on TV and all the other Superman movies- Why now do we have to take out "the American Way". Why do you think we have so many illegal immigrants coming here if they don't want the "American Way".

Review Title: Days of Our Lives... With Superheroes
Review: I think it's more of them trying to make it seem less shallow than it actually is that broke this movie. If they hadn't pretended so much that their aim is nothing more than giving people a good time, I wouldn't have fallen asleep while trying to swim my way out of the pathetically melodramatic my-son-and-girlfriend-are-living-with-another-guy. Spiderman 2 was also over the top in the kitschy, meaning-of-life parts, but they didn't forget that their main objective was to kick butt. Bland acting, a nonexistent plot, this movie is little more than a collage of different superposes from the superhero. This Superman is more like the movie version of that whiny Five For Fighting song.

For the first hour I did really looked few time to my watch .It was beautiful that Superman is back, but that was all. To much spent to remind us who was Superman and what he did. I think a 6 years old kin knows who and what is Superman. I did see more action in 1 hour Smallvile that in S… return. The cast was good , but the action drug to much. Few thinks have been poorly realized as: - When crystals fall in the water supposedly will create more land ? Not on the second part , when she drops the crystals!?!?! - Kryptonite harms Superman ( at least on the island ) but not when he lifts an entire chunk of kryptonite and other?!?!?! - When he loses his power he sweets and can be hurt, but not when he falls from 80,000.00 meters ?! Any way will be more to say. Only for the love of the Superman I give a 6. He was my childhood hero and will remain hopefully for my grandsons.Sorry I was expecting more.

Review Title: Superman Returns- and it's not a remake
Review: I'll admit I was nervous about an unknown actor trying to fill the shoes of the great Christopher Reeves, But Brandon did the icon uncanny justice. At times it was a little freaky, and I was left with flash backs/ remembering the old Superman movies. Dare I say even worth the Mall movie prices. This was Most definitely a worthy film for all ages. The graphics, action and plot deserve much higher ratings than what the critics are giving it. It is not a remake but a continuation of the man of steel. The only movie this summer that I think will give this film trouble, is next weeks Pirates 2. PS Kate Bosgworth is a better blonde. Kevin Spacey is great as always. Rumor is that this is a series of 3. I can't wait!

Review Title: I got carried away talking about the actors...

Review: The latest addition to the Bat Man movies was truly excellent, and pulled that Franchise back up the slope of mediocrity. While the Superman movies of the past were by no means mediocre, this new Superman movie is truly a wonderful addition to the Superhero genre.The movie quickly explains what has happened since we last saw Superman, and allows the film to transition easily from the 1980s to the 2000s.The new choices for all the characters are excellent, with Routh making an excellent Superman. As "Clark Kent" he reminded the viewer of the late, great Christopher Reeves, and even bore some resemblance to Reeve at times. From geeky news reporter to Superhero, Routh did a great job. He was an excellent choice.I particularly enjoyed Kevin Spacey's Lex Luthour. Again, a fantastic choice of replacement. He really sold that role.With all due respect to the original Superman crew, the images of Superman flying and such like have really capitalized on today's technology, giving a very realistic feel to the film. Superman's body movement in flight, as well as the movement of the cape were clearly well studied and matched the flight patters very well.Within saying anything to give the story-line away, I would like to add that anyone who sees this movie will be truly surprised and delighted with this movie. When that Superman "theme" music hits, one is transported back to the 1970s/1980s, if you were around in that era, and it pulls at the heart strings. I am very glad that the kept that. Very glad.Excellent. Brilliant.

Review Title: Truth, Justice, and the American Way - Liberals strike again
Review: If you did not notice the Liberals in Hollywood removed Superman's Motto. They replaced it with Truth, Justice, and "all that stuff".After I did a little research I found out that the traitors behind this movie didn't want to offend international crowds by using his motto and holding America and what it stands for in the high place that it belongs.I wont say anymore but I wanted to make sure that this disgusting omission did not pass without mention. They think we are so stupid.I am sure that this will mean nothing to some that read this but to the rest of us it is just one more example of the problems with liberals.

Bryan Singer also directed X-Men 2 and is the executive producer for House, M.D. Both of those are, I consider, very good. Good scripts (House is great for that - most decent TV shows have a better script than most blockbuster films), good story, good action, good emotion. I'm really not sure what happened here with Superman Returns. Perhaps he was trying to be too close to the original (perhaps he was told to be close to the original).He's got Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor, the mad scientist set out to destroy lives for money. From the trailer, I was expecting lots of crazy antics reminiscent of Gene Hackman's role in the first Superman film. There was only one scene where Spacey was given something to work with, and he did that perfectly. Everything else he spoke was pretty much lame. And that sums up the rest of the script: scenes to drive the background story were given lame scripting, so instead of getting even slightly involved in the characters, you're thinking everything spoken is just too short. The plots of the movie require the characters to say more, and to say it well. Instead, you have the script of an action film: about 400 words total when the movie has the potential to be really moving. Lord, even the Incredibles was deeper than this.Anyway, unimaginative, uninspired, and save for about 3 memorable parts (the third being the ending credits playing the Superman Theme full on) and the fact that the lead must've studied Reeve's role because he is spot on with the facial expressions and voice (the female lead is pretty weak with Lois Lane, though 70% of that problem is, again, the script), the movie was a disappointment.Hollywood recycles movies and recycles directors. Give us something fresh in both areas, or at least don't give us both at once.

Review Title: When you enjoy watching the hero being kicked...
Review: OK, first the disclaimer, I am not a fan of the comic series (I was when I was 10, long looong ago) so I wasn't expecting the best movie ever, but I am disappointed.To enjoy a movie you need consistency, the world you outline must be consistent in every way or -if you are dealing with a demigod- as much as you can at least. When your world isn't consistent your plot falls piece by piece and, I'm afraid to say, that is what happens with this movie.The acting, well, even Spacey was weak. I have to admit that Brandon Routh does an amazing job as Clark Kent, the character of nerdy moron suits him quite well, sadly in that other role he is quite bland. As a technical note, if you want your actor speaking through his eyes, don't use contact lenses! Or at least cast someone with blue eyes if the script requires it.Reading reviews I realized what I liked most of this movie: the beat up in the island. Is crude, quite violent, and has a really dark atmosphere. Sadly for me (and for the benefit of the plot) Superman doesn't die there. Or perhaps he did because I'm not loosing more money on him.

Review Title: No Evil Mutants or Spider-EMO's  Just a Bullet proof Movie
Like a big game of "Remember This?"
Review: This movie was graphically stimulating but it wasn't much else. The storyline is derivative of the 1978 Superman film and ultimately mediocre in its development. Alas, it also adds a bit of deus ex machina just to push the storyline further and develop one character more than it ever needed to be.The performances were good enough but since the characters haven't evolved any since the first installment, its difficult to say it met any expectations and it made me long for the portrayals done by Dean Cain and Teri Hatcher. Clark is still an uber-geek. Superman is still the tall dark stranger. Jimmy Olsen is still a putz. Lois Lane still does the dumbest things to get the story - only now she brings her kid in tow to push her actions to an even higher level of irresponsibility. Luthor is still surrounded by incompetents and people with limited capacity for the unbridled carnage that Luthor's demented mind is capable of producing.Where Singer shines, however, is when the film shows the emotional connection between Superman and the people of Metropolis. These scenes really portray the bond between Superman and the people he helps. Unfortunately, when Singer focuses that emotional connection between Superman and Lois Lane, it makes Superman come across as more of a stalker than a romantic epic.This is a decent start to a potentially interesting new series of movies - hopefully one where we will see less of Luthor and more of the other villains that make up Superman's unique rogue's gallery. Unfortunately, as a stand alone film, Superman Returns is far from Super.

Superman really returns. The movie title really shows what is inside. It really focused on that topic and for that, I give two thumbs up.The story of how Superman got back to earth after 5 years searching for his original planet and how he tried to adapt to new situation with his work and Lois Lane really makes this new Superman more human. Especially in its fight scenes, Superman is no longer the super Superman, but more like a human Superman.But then, it's a little bit ambiguous. For general audience, it's too heavy and too little action while for adult audience, it's too light and too much action. For drama movie it's too much action and for action movie it's too dramatic. For that reason, I doubt many people would like to watch this movie again after watching it the first time. Maybe, unless for gay people. This new Superman has that gay charm that would attract gay people to watch it over and over again.

I am one of many movie junkies that frequent IMDb. I have seen countless movies over the past few years and I haven't been this jazzed after seeing a movie in a long time.I grew up with Superman. I knew Christopher Reeve's lines by heart when I was 5. I was Supergirl many Halloweens. I was so afraid Superman Returns wouldn't get past the whole idea of the curse, since it took so long to be made.I was not disappointed. The storyline was fresh and exciting, without reaching too far into the HUH? zone. It has left itself open for sequels much better than Batman Begins did. The subtle tributes to the original, even with something as basic as the font for the credits, makes the movie special.You did good, Mr. Singer. You did good.

Review Title: Superman returns to Earth to save the world.
Review: Superman Returns is not one of the better comic book movies to date. There is a tremendous desire on its part to have deep character development. Showing Superman's inner angst is apparently a time consuming proposition, too much time. There are some good visual effects and one good action sequence involving an airplane but too little, too long. The pace of the movie is slow, even Superman takes to the air slowly, very slowly. It seemed as though Superman is not the man of steel, but the man of feel. In theory, Kryptonite may be able to one day kill Superman but, in practice, his broken heart can definitely kill the pace of a comic book movie. I wanted to like this movie more but it seemed as though, at times, I was watching a super-stalker rather than a super-hero. X-Men III was a better popcorn movie and either of the Spiderman movies did a much better job of juggling romance and adventure. The new Superman may look the part but it doesn't take x-ray vision to see that this movie was let down by a bloated script and an overly long running time.

What a disappointment! I was expecting an exciting film similar to the Xmen trilogy, especially with the same director, but it was not to be. This film took itself too seriously...it tried to make him real,or heaven forbid, human, instead of being tongue-in-cheek as all these types of films need to be to succeed. So now the superhero is not really that super because he had (should I say it)intimate relations with Lois that produced a child. Mushy and boring! One of the few saving graces in this film is the delightful Kevin Spacey.What a wonderful villain, although even he could have been much worse.And of course the special effects were amazing and fantastic which only saves the film just a touch. Apart from Spacey, anyone could have played any of the parts of Superman, Lois, Jimmy etc they were all lifeless. No, sorry, I was very let down by this film and it is a shame as Singer is a good director.

I was very skeptical about seeing this movie as I am a HUGE Christopher Reeve Superman fan. I was afraid the new era of special effects and new screenplays would take away from what classics the Reeve movies are. But I was pleasantly surprised - the movie and Routh as Superman continued the tradition and the memory of Christopher Reeve. The story is good - effects are good - the acting is good - except in the case of Kevin Spacey where the acting is, as always, superb! The 2 1/2 hours of movie never dragged and kept the full theater entertained. Yes, it is a bit on the bubble gum side - but hasn't Superman always portrayed the wholesome, good guy who saves the world while being madly in love with "the girl"?! Brandon Routh does a good job and is very much the image and the mannerisms of Christopher Reeve. Kate Bosworth is decent as Lois Lane, and Kevin Spacey - is FANTASTIC as Lex Luthor - even better than Gene Hackman! The only problem I had is that when compared to the movies of the 70's - Lois and Superman have gotten younger. It is a fun and entertaining movie and definitely worth the time and money! I look forward to the sequel!

Review Title: It took $250 million to make this????
Very disappointed about the revival of an American Legend - The story
Review: The overall story is the main problem I have with this film. It's just not there, you pretty much had to be living on these boards the last year to know what was going on. I went in knowing, and not caring, that there wouldn't be a supervillian, that this film was being billed as a character driven film and I liked that. I like it when the characters, not the action, are at the front of the film. You need that sense of adventure and excitement as well, you need that in any fantasy film, but Ill touch upon that in a little bit. But where was the so called character driven/development story. Outside of Clark's conversation with Martha Kent, who was wasted by the way, the film didn't even touch on his loneliness. They didn't show the character grow at all from beginning to end, or having any touching, soul searching scenes. Clark just went back to Metropolis and back to work as Superman like it was nothing. There was no story to it. Oh, and by the way, there is a problem when Jimmy Olsen and Kitty have more lines than Clark Kent, who should be the heart of the movie, at least in this day and age. And also, it's lame how Clark can simply get his job back, show up for one hour, and then Superman Returns as well. Thats a nice crack team of journalists ya got there, chief. Why the film couldn't be more logical in areas like that is beyond me. The Lois Lane with a fiancé and a kid thing was meh. It wasn't awful but it wasn't truly needed either, it makes sense from the 5 year absence standpoint. They really didn't give Lois much to do though. She was just there, pouting over Superman. They didn't really develop her past a " I hate him, I love him again " story arc. No really, thats how it came off on screen. She granted forgiveness because he took her flying. Thats how it seemed. Honestly, the kid was fine. I didn't mind it within the context of the story. But the execution of the storyline was lame and unfulfilling. Where was the drama? I didn't see or feel any. There is more drama in an episode of L&C or Smallville. And as a friend of mine said, Superman and Lois Lane are a piece of American legend and they don't even share a kiss. Now on to Lex Luthor, my biggest pre-viewing problem with the film. Was Lex as comical in this film as in 78? No. I was wrong on that part. But he still wasn't exactly menacing outside of the NK beatdown, which I loved. Did Lex still make dumb, jokey comments. Yes. But it wasn't as bad as I thought. Luthor's big plot however was plain awful. I can't describe it in any other way. It's like Singer and his creative team sat down for a half hour and watched the Luthor scenes in Donner's film, and then came up with the New Krypton idea because of Luthors want for land. This was without a doubt the lamest part of a lame movie. NK was one of the most uncreative things I've ever seen in a comic book film, almost as lame as The Hulk's grand villain idea. With all the source material on Luthor, this was the best Singer could come up with? I'm disappointed and damn near disgusted at the lack of imagination. The NK plot alone is proof that corporate Lex was the way to go, at least from a standpoint of the overall threat in the film. A quick blurb about the Daily Planet, I longed for the days of Lane Smith and Justin Whalin, the Daily Planet crew didn't get an ounce of true character in the film. Yea Jimmy had more lines than Clark, which is screwed up might I once again add, but the character didn't really shine. Where was the talk of Jimmy worrying about his job, I didn't see it, it might have been implied, but not that well. OK, and now that we have addressed how the character driven drama failed, lets go to the fantasy element. Yes folks, Superman is a fantasy film. Good fantasy films require a true sense of awesome adventure and excitement. Superman Returns had none. There was no sense of thrilling excitement about this film, it was to busy getting wrapped in a drama that failed miserably. This film was not fun at all, and don't point to the lame humor throughout. The story wasn't designed to be a thrill ride, I knew that, but for god sakes. It doesn't help that the characters were forgettable and they didn't have that " don't leave " feel to them, but when that fails, blow some sh^t up. The cast had no chemistry, and thats key to an adventure film because like Star Wars, the originals mind you, the audience needs to feel the bond between characters. There was zip in terms of bonding. Btw, that is what POTC brings to the table that Superman doesn't, fun and excitement. It might be a different story if Superman Returns had a good story behind it, but it doesn't.

Review Title: Where Superman III should have begun !!!

Review: I enjoyed this. Art direction and the pure detail of it really took you away.However, I felt Kate Bosworth was miscast. Lois Lane is 23? A mother of a 5 year old and one of the best reporters in the world? That seemed even more far fetched then still nobody recognising Clark Kent as superman! Kate Bosworth is a nice actress. I acknowledge that the producers were at fault there.This was good fun though. I didn't even mind the indulgent 3 hour length of the film, that slowed the pace, or the over-the-top "Jesus Returns" underpin.

There's nothing quite like the big screen and watching Superman fly through fire or lift an entire continent. John Williams score builds to climax over and over and this is pretty amazing in a contemporary movie theater. Great eye candy. Yeah it's politics are worth taking about too.Interesting allusions to Prometheus and Christianity. There's a Saturday Night Live skit replacing Superman with Jesus flying through space. Isn't' that what people really hope Jesus could do. Go Jesus go.Superman even trys to get Lois to quit smoking.Did I say great special effects. Wow. The credits and blowing up of planet Krypton are great markers of the film's advance in technology.Boy that Williams song get's stuck in your head.PeaceGo with the kids for great entertainment then talk to them about whether the film is propaganda or not. Compare it to X3 with them. There's interesting brain candy as well

This movie doesn't have any comparison its previous films rival those of today such as Spiderman. However this film is different class of its own the love story is awesome and keeps you glued to understand why he left and what Lois has been going through obviously distraught but trying to keep her ego high.Jimmy Olsen Sam Hunnington is excellent and funny watching him in this movie actually made the load a whole a lot lighter.The comedy in this movie was right on spot. Lex Luthor very angry and evil those wigs sure do it.Parker Posey gorgeous and stupid she was more stupid than thew previous woman in his life something which I didn't like.Frank Langella the mature man of this movie keeps it all in one piece instructing Lois to write about Superman when she clearly doesn't want to but he knows only she can do that job.I'm not revealing spoilers but people who hate this are not fans or people who adore marvel.Me I'm just a normal person who loves movies.Superman Rocks!!!!!!!!

Review Title: Like Chinese food - we felt hungry an hour later
Fails to stand out in the light of other, better superhero movies.
Superman Returns is why I go to the movies
Review: I am a huge Comic book fan. Superman Returns is a movie that reminds me why. It is everything a Superhero movie should be. I was very excited but also apprehensive abut going to see this movie. My biggest fear was that this movie would be all action and corny one liners like so many Superhero films that are put out today. Superman is so much more than that, it is a love story, an inspirational movie, you should feel something when you watch it needed to be more than just eye-candy. I know it would have action but would it have Heart was my big question. And my conclusion after seeing the movie is that Bryan SInger delivered and from here on out should do all superhero movies.While watching the movie I was transported back to being a little kid watching the first two superman movies. I felt like a Little kid again and that is rear today given all the movies I see that all it seems to inspire me anymore are really emotionally draining and sad scenes like those in Saving Privat Ryan. Action and fun movies just don't feel fun anymore thats why Superman was so special for me I had fun. I sat there and wanted to put my superman PJ's on when I was a kid and fly around the theater. Brandon Routh is the reincarnation of Christopher Reeve. HE was fantastic as both superman and Clark Kent. Kevin Spacey WAs great as Lex Luthor he was evil but not scary unlike so many superhero villains. To many times the villains are over the top scary but Lex Luthor is a man that's what makes him so evil. He doesn't have powers he has his mind and desire and thats it. Kevin Spacey knows this and performs him exactly that way. Itruly love this movie action, heart, emotion, and if you want to be a kid again and forget about the world around you and be five years old again for about 2 and 1/2 hours get yourself one of those oversize bags of popcorn a large soda and go see Superman and if you are a Parent take your kids and show them why movies are made and how a good movie makes you feel.

Review Title: 30 minutes of the best Cinema I've ever seen, too bad the movie was over 2 hours long.
Review: Why does the plot take so long to develop?! It's a weak and silly plot that takes forever to come together! On the bright side, Brandon Routh does a nice job, he was so much like Christopher Reeves it was eerie. Parker Posey is very good as usual really stole the show in many respects. The rest of the cast's performances ranged from adequate to bland. I felt nothing for or from Lois at all, and the romance between her and superman fizzled at best. There is just no chemistry between the two. Margot Kidder really had that part tight.Honestly though, a good 45 minutes could be cut from the film and a little more superman action added. There were some spots that really just drug on and on. My 13 year old daughter and my 15 year old son both thought it was mostly boring.Bryan Singer would have done us a big favor if he would have fixed the mess they called X-Men 3 and waited for a better script to bring back Superman. As it is we got a lousy X-Men and a so-so Superman when just a little more effort, possibly in the editing, we could have enjoyed two really good films.It is important to remember that this is not the superman we all knew and loved. The Superman that only drank milk, and married Lois before he fathered a child is officially dead. I suspect that his truth justice and American way ethics are in the Hollywood coma ward with little hope of revival as well. This Superman is sort of morally not so super as he used to be. Just so you parents hoping for a role model for the kiddies don't get your hopes up too much.For some reason Hollywood seems hell bent on kicking Christ and Christians around when ever they get the chance. This film is no exception. Superman who is portrayed as a peeping tom that attempts to split a basically, happy family up, is taken through a mock passion episode. He subtly reenacts the points of the cross, is pierced through his side, is baptized nearly to his death and ascends to heaven. After he is rejuvenated by the Sun, he returns to carry an unbelievably huge chunk of earth, representing the sins of the world I guess and caste it into space. Several statements referring to Superman as the Savior of the world are made to help you connect the dots. No one would consider portraying Superman as a modern representation of Buda, or Allah or even Mohammed. The rest of us are fair game though so that only leaves Jesus. However, on Superman's best day he is no Jesus Christ. The whole comparison was childish and because Superman has no moral or emotional triumph to propel him to this messianic height the savior thing falls flat. As a result an already weak plot struggles along even more strained.I'm not sure why these people can't just make a fun summer movie without trying to make some silly social commentary. For all their efforts it's just another lousy film that could have been great if a few people's egos and agendas could have been put aside to make a quality movie. Too bad, but the results are clear in the box office returns.

Although the movie did keep the original feel and the continuation of the story. . . The acting was wooden. . . WAY TO MUCH ACTION. Where were the cute one liners for Superman and Lex. There was no humor from the old series. I won't see this movie again. Better luck on a sequel. The feeling I got about the whole movie was that they took an hour and forty five minute movie and pushed in an extra hour of just action. There should be a lot more development of the characters. I know that it is supposed to follow that you have seen the previous movies and know the back story of each. But a few flashbacks with the new set of actors and actresses would make the transition that much better. This movie should have had the script edited a few more times before the made it into a movie.

As I grew with the late Christopher Reeve's interpretation, I would sincerely say that I had the chance to say Brandon Routh can fill his shoes. He did it on a good way, sure wish for the next installments that he will still do the same job...For the rest of the movie, I noticed a lot of cross-over references upon the first two movies. It was refreshing that we forgot the following adventures of III and IV... (and even some footage of the late Marlon Brando...)However, I didn't get used to Kate Bosworth's interpretation of Lois Lane. She was not very much on scale, however, since she might be back, hopefully we can model the character to be more on the adventurous side...But, put Kevin Spacey anytime on the villain side and you got a great result. His portrayal of Lex Luthor made me forget Gene Hackman's first interpretation and of course, Luthor didn't have hair at this time ! Only other thing: film is a bit too long and should have been at a respectable limit of two hours. There were too much sequences that should have been taken off...But, hey, the movie's good anyway. Should restore the faith to the Man of Steel's fans who have still bitter memories of Superman IV: The Quest for Peace...

I saw an interview with Bryan Singer he said that this version of Superman was along the lines of a chick flick.This holds true.It was nice to see Noel Neill and Jack Larson have some screen time, however brief it was.There is also a dedication at the end of the movie to Christopher and Dana Reeves, which I thought, was a great touch.Brandon Routh does strike a resemblance to Chris Reeves at certain points in the movie, more when he is Clark Kevin Spacey did a good job as Lex Luthor. But he doesn't play it over the top like Gene Hackman did.Kate Bosworth does a fairly good job as Lois.Singer uses James Marsden as Lois's boyfriend in the movie He could have been a contender for Superman if only he hadn't played Cyclops in the X-Men Movies.I did enjoy this movie a lot however, it moved right along and I didn't have to look at my watch. Like I have done in other movies The question in the movie is, "Is Jason White , Richard Whites son or Supes? Only the true Superman fans will know As we, all have heard now they injected Brando into this movie from old screen footage. But also see if you can find Glenn Ford anywhere in the film I think Superman fans will like this movie , so long as they don't compare it to the other Superman films

Review Title: This was a waste of time.
Superman Returns has raised the bar for superhero movies
Review: If you are a fan of the first two (Christoper Reeves) Superman movies, then you have to see this. Superman Returns stays true to its roots. i.e. Theme music, Marlon Brando voice cameo, and story line. The visual effects in this movie will truly blow you away. I took my five year old son to it and we can't stop talking about it. I feel like a kid again. Casting Brandon Routh as the man of steel was a stroke of genius. Kevin Spacey could not have been a better Lex Luther. As for the storyline, Superman coming back to earth after a five year absence makes you feel like you just got done watching Superman 2. Don't wait for this one to come out on DVD to see. The audio effects are truly amazing as is the soundtrack. I have to quit writing, I'm off to see this one again.

I wanted to love this movie, but the kid thing just completely ruins it all for me. I cannot accept Superman as a deadbeat dad. He is above that.Episode I at least had the decency to be mediocre from start to finish... Superman Returns teases you with a *great* movie, and then poops all over it.I know that a sequel is inevitable. I just wish I could be excited for it. Unfortunately, this movie just so needlessly failed me.And that's just my personal dislike of the plot in general. There's other major inconsistencies, like Superman landing on an island of kryptonite and not even noticing it, then getting beaten up because all his powers are gone... yet then he can pick the whole island up with limited difficulty? That makes no sense.And I know the whole Clark Kent disguise thing is a bit of a wink-and-nudge joke anyway, but really... No one noticed that Clark and Superman returned on exactly the same day after having been gone for exactly the same amount of time?I wanted to love this movie. It's just not worth it though.

MANGORICK said everything I was thinking when I saw SUPERMAN RETURNS. It is a disappointing return. I was really looking forward to it because, hey, it's Superman! Also, because Bryan Singer was directing and his X-MEN movies are so good (haven't seen the 3rd one yet.) Physically, Brandon Routh has it all. I think he used the opportunities the story gave him well, but there was not much for him to do. He had very few lines and even the montages of him saving several people in a row were very short. The movie is called SUPERMAN, so let's be able to see him.Kate Bosworth was a terrible, terrible choice for Lois Lane. Lois Lane is not supposed to be conventionally beautiful--which Kate is--and she is supposed to be more plucky and self-reliant--which Kate's Lois wasn't. Physically, she was ALL WRONG. Personality-wise, all wrong. Someone like Marla Sokoloff would've been good--someone edgy and a little sarcastic.The same goes for casting Frank Langella as Perry White. Whose idea was that? He's too tall, too exotic, too expressionless. Bad, bad, choice. I thought the bartender looked more like our idea of Perry White. The bartender--who was the 50's Superman show's Jimmy Olsen.Kevin Spacey did a good job as Lex Luthor, although I think Lex Luthor would be disappointed with the thin plot line he was given. Hello? Creating your own spiky little country? One that, as Ebert said, a billy goat wouldn't live on. Give me a break.After the movie I came home and watched Christopher Reeve's SUPERMAN and SUPERMAN II. They are SOOoooo much better. The technology was lesser because of the time period, but it didn't matter because there was a great story, cast, and superior acting.The new movie's pacing was very off, spending too much time on unimportant action (i.e. Lois on the plane, Lois on the sea plane, Lois on the yacht.) I think we saw more Lois than Superman--and she wasn't that good. I also think they could've given Lois's kid A LOT more to do than just bumping into doors with a trashcan on his head and staring at everything through those shaggy bangs of his. Would someone please give that poor child a haircut? When I saw the photo on Lois's desk, I thought he was a girl at first.And poor James Marsden getting roped into playing the good-looking neglected fiancée. Sorry, Cyclops, that was a misfire.This is a movie worth missing, I'm afraid. 2 1/2 hours of Lois Lane with an occasional Superman is not the way to return the iconic character to the public. I think my favorite character was actually Parker Posey's Kitty and her cannibalistic dog. What does that say about the movie?

Review Title: Superman returns from Krypton & Lex Luthor's up to his old tricks
Truth, Justice, and all of that stuff????
Review: The movie was o.k. I was a little disappointed when Mr. White said, "Truth, Justice, and all of that stuff." Superman IS an American icon.I would like the phrase "Truth, Justice, and the American Way" in the DVD version. If you don't know what the "American Way" is I have two suggestions. First, spend some time in another country (i.e. Russia, China, or North Korea) and second, go to the Middle East and take a long visit with some REAL super heroes our fighting men and women…I think it will become obvious.Does Hollywood need to interject political correctness into every aspect of American culture?

Review Title: You've got to be kidding me . . .
Good, but it has its problems.
After 25 years, I once again believe that a man can fly.

Review: I'm a fan of superhero movies, and I watch a lot of chick flicks (wife), yet this was terrible on both accounts. It was just boring. The acting was OK, and the effects were pretty good, but the directing was terrible, and the storyline tedious. There were so many drawn out and forced moments where The audience was supposed to be entertained by the mere site of superman. Superman Iconic status was given too much focus, and his humanity was ignored. Yes he was a super-ex-boyfriend, and filled with super-regret because the super hot Lois was with another dude. But Dang he's supposed to be a superHERO. Cant we have a side order of failed romance, and make the main dish some action/drama? Also, the Jesus references were forced and awkward. The ending with the kid, -ridiculous, and every scene drawn-out too long.Anyway I cant imagine how this movie has an average rating of 7.7. I guess 250 million dollars can buy a lot of reviewers. Everyone I saw it with thought it stunk, and the people wandering out of the theatre were bemoaning how lame it was.

Review Title: One of the best movies i have ever seen!!
Review: Wow this movie was amazing I saw it opening day and i loved it so much I thought special effects was superb the acting the story the suspense everything was just off the charts Christoper Reeve would of given it a standing ovation.MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS. The story begins when our man of steel returns from a curious trip to Krypton and he has been gone for 5 long years he sees the world has definitely moved on without him and of course Lex Luthor is back and more sinister than everYou seem to get this wild feeling once you here that music again and see the o so familiar opening credits. Ladies and Gentelman i can not stress it enough go see this movie you will not be disappointed it was the best 20 million dollars anyone ever spent. Yes Superman is back and all his glory better than ever 10 out of 10 stars

Now first of all I want it to be known I am a huge fan of the older (Christopher Reeve) movies. That being said this iteration of Superman definitely continued in the same vein as the original but was its own movie. The acting was more than serviceable the direction & camera work were fantastic. A great story that I found to be original. For the fans of the comics you must know this is not straight of the comics, it is it's own entity. (Why would you go see a movie that you already know every little thing that would happen?) But I thought it was a great movie that was well worth the wait. Will this movie set box office records? Probably not but it is a great first step to becoming the powerhouse franchise it should be with Bryan Singer at the helm.

Ever since I heard a new Superman movie was in the making, I've been anxious to see it and fearful that it would continue in the vein of Superman III & IV.I am so glad Bryan Singer chose his approach to carry on rather than remake, that he cast as he did. All told we've gotten a movie that is faithful to the vision of Richard Donner. Brandon Routh's deliberate similarities to Christopher Reeves are incredible and make it even better. Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor is superb.I was completely pulled into the story, from the moment it opened with John Williams easily-recognized score and the credit style reminiscent of Superman and Superman II. The brief revisit to Smallville and Ma Kent played well to the Superman mythos as well as providing a good spring to the rest of the story.The rest balanced well between Lex Luthor's newest scheme for land while getting his revenge against Superman and the focus on the Superman/Lois Lane relationship. It was a refreshing realism to see Lois bitter about Superman's unexplained absence.

I realize that a lot of people have many quams with this movie, but despite all of those I couldn't help myself loving this movie.I Couldn't BELIEVE that they used the original Superman beginning with the flying letters AND the original theme in the amount that they did! I loved it! Admittedly I'm a huge huge huge Superman fan since I was a kid, but I enjoyed this just as much as the original with Christofer Reeve. I realize that some people may want to lynch me for this, but to a point I thought Brandon did a better job.Kevin Spacey was perfect for Lex Luthor.The story was pretty typical for a Superman type story, especially if you read the comic books of old.I've heard a lot of people talking about a Christ/Superman thing going on. I am a serious Evangelical Christian and the only thing that kinda twinged me was the "savior" conversation with him and Lois. Other than that I've heard people trying to connect some of his stances while flying or falling or whatever with the Cross. I'm here to say as both a Superman fan and Jesus freak that those stances are typical in the comic strip, and are not unusual to be seen. I have serious doubts about intentional correlation. And if there was, then shame on them.Anyway, thats my opinion. Loved it, and would recommend it to anybody.

Review Title: Cocky and clunky at the same time.
Surprisingly emotional for a summer film
This is one of my favorite Superhero movies
Review: I saw this yesterday and I was surprised, The acting was great, the humor made me laughing, the action scenes rocked, but the thing I liked about it was that there was barely any swearing. When the police cop was about to say the "S" word, they cut it out right when he was about to say "t".Kevin Spacey Rocked as Lex, Brandon Routh also rocked, all the others did also. The Boy who played Jason was adorable.The Plot was awesome and the person who cast the people did a great job. The sets were amazing also.You should see this movie. It is the must-see of the year. Well, the summer at least.

Review Title: Superman Returns To The Screen With Dignity Intact
Review: Lois Lane,the love of the Man Of Steel's life has written him off,has put him behind her and even won a Pulitzer Prize column for an article on why the world no longer needs Superman. By clearly,Lois Lane was wrong,dead wrong. The world needs Superman so much that Hollywood spent almost a decade on false starts to revive the franchise with some of the top directors in Hollywood to helm the project to bring the kid from the planet Krypton back to the big screen. The mysterious and fictional saga of Superman's departure has fill a void during the last decade. The last time Superman's adventures continued was on television with "Smallville",and "Lois and Clark:The New Adventures of Superman" not to mention various animated television series that featured the Man of Steel in different formats. However,Superman has become a forgotten man not only at the movies but in Hollywood as well where other comic book heroes had come to reign.In the 19 years since Christopher Reeve's fourth and final appearance as the hero in "Superman IV:The Quest For Peace",Hollywood has churned out five Batman flicks with four different actors in the title role. While Marvel Comics continue to dominate and flourish at the box office, DC Comics was struggling to stay a float of the box office reign of superheroes. While "Spider-Man" and "The X-Men" became the Cadillac of superhero franchises,DC Comics characters like "Batman" and others were catching hell. The last DC Comics character,last year's "Batman Begins" became the thrill ride of the summer thus saving the DC Comics from oblivion. Until now,Superman hasn't been since in over 19 years at the box office. The longer Superman with his good mannerisms and Boy Scout values languished in development at Warner Bors.,the more it looked as of his time has passed in favor of the darker,conflicted heroes that came from the pages of Marvel Comics("Spider-Man","X-Men")and DC Comics("Batman").All of that has change when director Bryan Singer,who directed the first two "X-Men" movies and passed on the third installment of the series to bring back an American icon out of retirement to save the planet once again from certain doom. "Superman Returns" is a grand achievement of this and what Singer has done was bring back a hero and brought him back with dignity intact and much more. This is a dazzling spectacle of technological proportions and director Bryan Singer was a ideal choice to bring back the beloved franchise. Singer gave it his own vision and retain key elements from the original 1978 "Superman" film including John Williams' Oscar-winning rousting score from the original movie not to mention archive footage of Marlon Brando as Superman's father Jor-El.Newcomer Brandon Routh takes over the role that was once played by Christopher Reeve and he does wonders with the part. Superman returns to Earth after a long mission to the lost remains of his home planet,Krypton,only to find the love of his life Lois Lane(Kate Bosworth)has gotten on fine without him. She has a son,and is engaged to her fiancé(James Marsden of "X-Men" fame)and has matured and moved on with her life. When Superman's arch-enemy Lex Luthor(Kevin Spacey)is released from prison to begin his diabolical plan for domination of the world it is up to Superman to return to Earth and save the planet from Luthor's total destruction,and to get back with the love of his life in the process. As the villain Lex Luthor,I got to say that was no better actor to revive the part better than Kevin Spacey and to me this his best work yet. He knows how to command an audience and it shows. Several scenes were excellent including the plane sequence which is jaw-dropping to behold. This is me was the long-awaited hype of the summer that has finally came and "Superman Returns" delivers. It's everything you wanted in a movie,non-stop thrills and unbelievable action at every turn. Truly,the one movie that is waiting in line at the theatres to see.

Review Title: Is this an episode of Maury?  **WARNING SPOILER***
Superman Returns and I left asking for my money back
My brief thoughts on Superman Returns
Review: A few Days ago I saw Superman Returns in the IMAX 3D. Just hearing the "John Williams" Superman Theme and seeing the beginning credits, brought tears to my eyes, at that point I knew I will be in for a ride. Brandon Routh does a very good job of portraying Superman, and Kate Bosworth portrayed Lois Lane very well, yet Lois Lane wasn't as high strong as I thought she would be in this film, but 5 years and a child could change a person. It doesn't really matter if Brandon Routh resembles the way Christopher Reeve portrayed Superman/Clark but he did a good job of it. Brandon Routh was a good choice for Superman. I also find this film had more of an emotional impact on the audience, which means the director, Bryan Singer, did an excellent job of telling the story on screen. There was just the right amount of action and story telling. The plot had met my expectations and it had it's surprises and twists. Kevin Spacey was a very convincing Lex Luthor and Parker Posey playing Kitty Kowalski was more of the comic relief in this film, showing the odd yet funny chemistry between Kitty and Lex. The rest of the cast also did a good job of portraying their characters. I give Bryan Singer 2 thumbs up for this film, it is not easy these days coming out with a film of this genre and the fact that it is a returning concept. Bryan Singer has created a great visual spectacle that I know everyone will enjoy, even if you are not a Superman Fan. Great job cast and crew on bringing Superman back to the big screen.

This movie was pretty good. Of coarse it had its cliché' moments, but you get that with any comic book movie. Having personally never seen any of the previous Superman movies, I found this one easy to follow. It was a bit long, but it all had to do with the plot, un-like King Kong, which was extremely dragged out. I'm glad the citizens of "I forget which city Superman protects" don't hate Superman for saving people, unlike Spiderman, where everyone pushes him around and they want to arrest him. Bryan Singer did an overall good job in this movie. If you like X-Men 1 and 2, most likely you'll like Superman Returns, so check it out...

Is it a bird? Is it a plane? No, it's Superman FILM REVIEW: SUPERMAN RETURNSCast: Brandon Routh, Kate Bosworth and Kevin Spacey Running time 154 minutes In what has been toted as the most anticipated DC Comics Superhero film of the decade, Superman Returns finally hit the big screens across South Africa! The Man of Steel is back in all his glory, to save the world from the iniquitous elements intent on its destruction.The caped-crusader and champion of justice, equality and the American way is back to save the world yet again. He has been in self-imposed exile for five years, seeking the truth about the whether or not his planet Krypton was destroyed. During his absence the world was beginning to lose faith in their hero, but now he has returned to guide humanity down an honourable path and to defend the inalienable rights of mankind.The film lends a dreamy air to the Superman theme. Most of the spotlight is directed at the ambiance and spectacular panoramas of the iconic figure's escapades, rather than actually focusing on his crime-fighting exploits. Make no error, Superman has his fair share of outrageous stunts to perform, but one feels that there are limited scenes where his awesome ability is shown. Having said that though, his strength, speed and dexterity are already well known to fans the world over.This film goes to great pains to focus on the emotional connection between Superman and Lois Lane. After his mysterious disappearance for five years, Lois moved on with her life and gave birth to a delightful little boy. Questions abound as to who his real father is, but that much is left to the final scenes of this enchanting tale.Lex Luthor is portrayed by the ever-versatile Kevin Spacey, who starts out with great potential to convince audiences of Luthor's vile conduct. The antipathy between Luthor and Superman is not sufficiently explored and it is perhaps at this very juncture that the director missed a trick or two. Lex becomes a rather static character, as do most of the characters in the film. Ultimately this film isn't a depiction of great cinematic acting ability or even spectacular special effects, but it succeeds in rehashing what was such an indelible and prominent component of many people's lives from yesteryear!

Did anyone else find it odd that supposedly the story takes place 5 years later after the prequels. Lois Lane moved on with her career and life. Casting Kate Bosworth was a mistake, cause for this to be true she must have been in high school when she first met Superman, by the looks of her. I know they tried to make her look a bit older but come on. She was completely miscast in my opinion, an actress closer to thirty would have been more believable. I even suggested to a friend of mine, that Superman and Lois should have been cast in their mid 30's. A great Lois Lane would have been Sandra Bullock, and Bryan Singer could have still had his 30 something no name Superman. Kevin Spacy was excellent but outside of that the story was drawn out and unsatisfying. It will still make a bundle though.

Review Title: Pretty good film -- Guess You can't Please Everyone
Review: I actually really enjoyed this film, and feel it is right up there with Spider-man 2 and Batman Begins in terms of entertainment.I don't understand some of the reviews that criticize the acting--I thought Routhe was fine as Superman (reserved yet confident), sexy Bosworth makes you forget Margot Kidder, and Spacey more evil than Hackman (though Hackman's portrayal was fun).True, the action scenes were limited, yet spectacular. I can only figure that some people who are so hard on this movie either A) Don't like Superman and turn this into a DC/Marvel thing (which I never understood, since I never considered myself either a DC or Marvel fan, but a COMIC fan), or B), the film did not fit how they wanted the sequel to be, such as, for example, they either wanted the self assured, competent Clark Kent as portrayed as Lois and Clark or Smallville. Personally, I am perfectly fine with the classic bumbling portrayal of Clark as portrayed in this movie.The only thing the film lacked was a knockout, spectacular final. I would have bumped it up to a 9 if it would have had that.This promising feature makes me wait with great anticipation for the sequel!

Review Title: Able to parallel Jesus in a single $250 million bound...
Decent but wouldn't care much for sequels
Review: The movie is not bad. Despite it's 2 hours 40 mins long, there's seldom a moment you'd find yourself checking your watch. But unless any sequels promise something very dramatic (e.g., some really interesting development of the twist revealed in this movie), as far as I am concerned this movie could well be the last of the Superman franchise.In terms of action, it's fine. But there's nothing new and breath-taking. Swinging up and down (like Spiderman) and showcasing cool gadgets (like Batman) can be fun. But flying and lifting (what Superman does most often) cannot be said to be spectacular from audience's point of view, I am afraid.In terms of romance, I am glad that the story has Lois Lane engaged to someone else. That at least presents a cross-road and makes things a little more interesting. But I think it's a missed opportunity. Nothing in the movie suggests to me that Lois Lane's love for her fiancé is anywhere close to what she has for Superman.Most of the joy of watching the movie comes from the villains. Most scenes with Lex Luthor and his sidekicks in them are fun. Unfortunately, overall, there's little in the movie to merit anything more than a "decent" rating.

Review Title: Not just bad, but a betrayal against all true fans
Review: I gave the screen the finger on my way out of the screening on opening night. That's how much I hated this movie.Brandon Routh does not have Superman in him. He's OK (and just OK) as Clark Kent, but every time we wee him as Superman, he looks nervous and tense, like he's wondering who's buying this. Kate Bosworth is just plain too young to play Lois Lane. She was 23 when this movie was made, and her Lois Lane looks like a teenager. I was really looking forward to Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor, but he was no fun at all. James Marsden and Parker Posey play two completely disposable and unnecessary characters which is interesting because had they cast Marsden as Superman and Posey as Lois Lane, you'd have the makings of a fine Superman movie.The movie is poorly thought out, dark, ugly, and no fun at all. It's not appropriate for kids, the tone is all wrong, and there is no action whatsoever in the whole last half-hour. No action at all in the last half-hour of a summer superhero movie. Superman is supposed to be high adventure, not high melodrama. This is not Superman for a new generation, this is Superman for the Usual Suspects audience. This is Superman done dark and dirty.We were sold on this movie being another go at a Superman III, but the plots are so similar that this can only be a full-on remake of Superman The Movie. My only guess is that the producers sold the studio on this movie as paying homage to the '78 Donner film, and then Singer and company panicked when time started getting tight and just went ahead with whatever they could hash out in an evening. If Donner's '78 Superman was a smooth Frank Sinatra ballad, Superman Returns is a dirty, revved-up cover version performed by a really bad punk band.I spent my early childhood with a red cape permanently attached around my neck, so you can imagine that I was pretty predisposed to liking this movie. But now I feel ripped off. I feel ripped off not for the $13 I spent on my ticket, and not even for the months spent being excited for this movie. I feel ripped off for all of the years spent calling Superman my hero.

Review Title: Don't be a puppet for people that hate this movie, make your own choice by watching this movie !
Review: I have seen this movie already, and I have enjoyed every minute of it. I know that Superman Returns is not doing well at the box office, it's not Warner Bros. fault, nor Singer's, nor the cast's fault, it's the comments made earlier about Superman being gay. Bryan Singer is an openly gay director. He directed X-Men and X-2, with no controversy whatsoever about his sexuality. Now that he left X-3 to do Superman, some jealous die-hard fan of the X-men franchise wanted Superman to fail, just because Singer left X-Men 3 to pursue another superhero, which happens to be a DC comics superhero, and not a Marvel comics one. Just because he did not do X-Men 3, the person thought that X-3 would flop, and Superman would break box office records. Well, vice versa. X-Men succeeded, and Superman failed. I am shocked to hear that Superman is not doing well at the box office. Now because one person said something negative about Superman, everyone believes that person, over a baseless rumor. If you have read this, and haven't seen Superman Returns, then go over to your local theater near you and watch this movie. Trust me, it's worth it. I also recommend you watching Superman the movie,(1978) and Superman II, (1980)for guides.

Review Title: I do not recommend this movie.
Review: The movie was boring. Superman was nothing like the hero I grew up with. I did not like the injection of the religious symbolism. When I saw the movie the theatre was sold out. The audience was older than usual. There were a lot of kids but many more women in their 6o's and 70's. There was not a single reaction during the movie either from the kids or the older audience. I think everyone was as bored as I was. The cast was great but the dialogue was woefully short of meaningful content. The only part I liked was the saving of the space shuttle. I'm a Star Trek TNG fan and any one hour episode was more exciting that this movie. Thirty minute MASH episodes are much better written. The special effects were something one would see 25 years ago.

Review Title: Finally a Superman "Sequel" that closely lives up to original

Review: I watched Superman Returns in Imax 3D. First, a discussion of the movie, then the Imax.The movie is long, but because of very good special effects, an excellent sound track, and strong visuals, the movie holds the viewer's interest most of the time. There are a couple of anti-climatic endings, but these were probably necessary to tie up loose ends, and to leave some things open for more sequels. There were scenes with enough comic relief to bring laughter from the audience. For the most part, the acting was good to adequate. Frank Langella is one exception. Langella is an excellent actor, and as a vampire excelled. In this movie, however, he was less than adequate as Perry White. He seemed considerate and almost gentle at times--not the gruff, cigar-smoking editor of the Daily Planet. The portrayal of Jimmie Olsen likewise more annoying, and less naive than the comic book version. Now for the major roles: Christopher Reeve was a very good Superman. Brandon Routh is a very good Christopher Reeve, meaning that he played the role well, but his physical appearance uncannily recalled Reeve. I'm not sure if that's detrimental or advantageous, but you definitely recall Christopher Reeve. Kate Bosworth performed well, but seems too young and definitely much better looking than Lois Lane of comic books. Kevin Spacey, one of my favorite actors, as Lex Luthor did not seem menacing enough. In summary, for acting 2 stars out of three.For film production, 3 stars out of three. For story, 2 stars of 3. Extra credit for holding my interest: 1 star. Total=8 stars out of 10.(That breakdown is just to reveal how an 8 rating was derived.)Now for the Imax 3-D. The 3-D sequences (there were only 3 major scenes in 3D) were a major disappointment. The scenes in 3D gave a very good 3D effect, but the scenes included a lot of high-speed action. This tended to give choppy 3D that gave an unpleasant viewing experience. The coming attractions for 3 upcoming animated features were all in 3D, and they had a better overall 3D effect. I would recommend the movie to anyone who enjoyed the first Reeve Superman, or the television version years ago. But I would recommend that you save some money and skip the Imax 3D. Of course, I'm entranced by 3D and would see it again. Just realize before you go that some of the best scenes that might lend themselves to 3D will not be in 3D; and some very choppy action scenes are shown in 3D.

Review Title: Does nothing new with the franchise, but still manages to be decent film.
Review: Superman has always been a big deal, but nowadays, his battles are no more than what they appear to be on the surface, and that's a shame. While many superheroes have their own inner battles and beliefs that conflict with their decisions to make interesting situations, Superman simply fights evil because he knows that's what he's there for, and that's just not fun to watch.I came to see Superman Returns wanting to see something new done with Superman to make him more than just a two-dimensional comic book character, but nothing more is done with this movie than what was done with the Christopher Reeve films. It's predictable, it's unevenly-paced, and none of the characters are really interesting, but this film pays homage to its predecessors in a charming way.It might just be me, but Lex Luthor doesn't seem to be the right villain to pit Superman against in Hollywood, and in spite of an excellent (as always) performance by Kevin Spacey, it's just not fun to watch. Let's face it: Luthor is not a super villain. He's just a exploiting madman looking to gain power. He has no real motivations towards evil, except for greed. He's no competition for the almost God-like strength of Superman.Superman is played by Brandon Routh, who does it justice just as Christopher Reeve did. It's unfortunate that he came after Reeve, because it's apparent that he just tried to copy the style already created by his predecessor. He did well, though, and I guess that's all that matters.The final main character, Lois Lane, was played in the exact same way by Kate Bosworth, who followed Margot Kidder's example perfectly, but was actually too young for the part. I can't hold that against her, though.I guess my main problem with this movie is that they really just rehashed pre-used material. Superman never encounters any solid competition, and hence, this movie becomes pointless. If you're looking for just a simple popcorn flick, this movie is great, but a "summer blockbuster" it is not.-DB

I'm not going to say this movie is very bad, because it's not. I saw it today with my 9yr. old son - he's never seen the original - and he thought it was just so-so. A terrible review from him, knowing him as I do.Acting - the new face of Superman is great, as a face, but he doesn't carry the role well. I never saw a strong, or determined, Superman. He did the Kent role OK, but I couldn't help thinking the director kept saying to himself and to the set, "OK, cut....do that grin a little bit more, yes, that's it - Now, you look just like Chris Reeves - let's try that again". The transition from the meek Kent to the strong silent Superman is missing. Period.Lois Lane - first I have to say that Kate B. is a babe - there's no argument about that. And, I thought her acting was good, because even though I wanted to, I never saw that beach babe that she is so familiar to all of us as. Good job with that. But, I miss the quirky Lois Lane, the investigative reporter Lois Lane, the look of awe and wonder as she interacts with Superman Lois Lane. It just didn't work for me, but again she did a good job with the script she had.Lex - the man, the bad boy - Kevin Spacey is a fantastic actor, probably the best in this film by far - but I saw him like this: He was to the Lex Luther played by Gene Hackman what Depp was to Gene Wilder's Wonka, a dilution and distortion of the character. He seemed trying to be more creepy and eccentric than evil. Hackman WAS Lex Luther - Spacey never got past being Spacey in a skull cap.The kid actor - never seen him before, and I'll never knock a cute kid, period. So I'll just say that he needed some direction he didn't get and leave it at that.Overall: The story was slapdash, cut-and-paste - a few, well, more than a few unnecessary scenes, and of those several were really, really unnecessarily long - very long. And, for what ? Nothing from what I saw.And the random save-the-poor citizen scenes - SO much more could have been do with this to entertain the audience. But they all seemed to be just thrown in as a needed feature, but they were boring, and basic, and just, well, dumb looking.See it if you want, you may like it. But it's not in the same league with the original IMHO.

Review Title: Superman Returns in the BEST movie ever
Review: i literally just saw this movie. i saw it in IMAX and i don't recommend the IMAX theater. IMAX doesn't change the movie and you only put the glasses on 3 or 4 times. This movie was great though.
