I loved it and it had GREAT suspension. and you will look at the time- 2hrs and 34 mins(memorized :) ) and think WOW thats too long. nope its not like king Kong which was a waste of 3hrs! great movie and definitely recommend it. for the kids- some blood or not suitable& also moments of abuse like killing someone by kicking and punching and stabbing. but for a 13 year old girl- great movie totally fun and i definitely Recommend IT!!!!!!

It's been ages since I've seen a movie that brings me back to my childhood, but, the director's obvious love of the material pays homage to the films of the 70's with the updated special effects we enjoy in 21st century film. I am a longtime fan of Superman; he was my favorite comic book hero, but I mention this only in passing; we could have been subjected to modern day cinema clichés, tired dialog and cheesy acting. Brandon Routh impressed me a great deal with his ability to show his inner turmoil and longing for a relationship he may never have. Kate Bosworth's Lois Lane surprised me, as well. She didn't brash us with a mouthy performance....I felt for her longing to distance herself from her absent "hero". And Spacey's Lex Luthor was restrained enough not to take it over the top and give us a campy villain. This film touches our longing for a real hero who can save us from our violent real world; we wish for a "Super" person to swoop down and make it all better. Thank you, Bryan, cast and crew.....I felt 12 years old again, and full of hope. Escpapist movie-making at it's best!

This movie was quite disappointing. The cinematography was absolutely gorgeous and the special effects were all quite nice. Superman was quite studly and all the buildings and people sparkled. However, the dialogue can best be described as contrite, forced and superficial. The obvious quickly tossed aside comparison between Clark Kent and Superman was there. I vividly remember a cringe-inducing one-liner by Mrs. Lois Lane that was so god-awful that I'm sure the theater beside us could have heard our chorus of groans. I think i threw up a little, but that could have been caused by the many other problems. Usually, a movie engrosses me during the experience and I almost always thoroughly enjoy myself without noticing faults. However, during the lulls when "actor" Brandon Routh started talking, i began thinking about the story. I won't give it away but let's just say that you've most likely seen it before. Countless times. I also began to look past the pretty pictures to what the filmmakers actually shot. The mood was quite undefined. This movie really didn't ever know what it wanted to be. The filmmakers tried for the darkness of the recent Batman Begins but never escaped the happy go lucky charm of Metropolis that Gotham never had. My final complaint is one thing that definitely could have saved this movie. Every character was 10 kinds of boring. Lois Lane wore drab suits and showed no emotion; I can't even picture Kate Bosworth's face the day afterward! Brandon Routh was handsome in a very boring way. He seemed like a complete doofus reading every line off of cue cards. All of his lines were delivered with an incredibly annoying and obviously feigned confidence. Great actors don't act, they do and they are. Brandon Routh has good looks and talent but he's still acting. He isn't Superman, although he tries to convince the audience as well as himself throughout the entire movie. Clark Kent was totally forgotten as a player as well. Superman is a great and deep character. Unfortunately, This movie forgot that. It lacks depth, it lacks the reality that other superhero movies have had, it lacks story, it lacks dialogue and it lacks originality. There are better superhero movies out there. Try watching the original superman or the great TV series, Smallville (it's not just for 12-year old girls). If you do watch this movie, do so for your own nostalgic purposes or for the pretty pictures. The thrills are lacking as well as the enjoyment. Maybe next time, folks.Tyler Wilson

Review Title: Lofty, ambitious, and amazing to look at, but short on fun
From a Galaxy far, far away.
A Superb Super Comeback For Superman
The Man of steel is made of cotton
Review: I went into this picture believing I would see an interesting and thought provoking film about large and massive men. Instead is was flourished with a feckless and lame picture about the interactions between stupid American pigs. Firstly the main character is a reporter for a paper (i forgot the name). He is not a very convincing reporter, as well as a convincing superman. He is one of the worst actors and quite a disgrace to thespians abroad.This film also features a female attraction. I forgot her name, she was quite a terrible and ugly woman.Getting back to the superman. I was quite unintimidated by the acting of Kevin spacey. He looked like an unforceful and silly actor. He tries to be antagonistic but bitterly fails.Now I shall return to Superman. Superman looked a like a man.

Review Title: Brandon Routh is Superman.  Be very thankful.
Review: Imagine you're an actor in his mid-20s and you sign on to play one of the most iconic roles in the history of popular culture, and no matter how good you are, there will always be those who will trash your performance. Everyone has ideas about their image and personality for Superman, and they tend to personalize them. I, for one, am glad to see that most critics and reviewers have accepted Brandon Routh as Superman, because he deserves every bit of praise he is receiving.Brandon Routh was picked because of his looks and build, everyone knows that. Nevertheless, he gives an earnest performance as Clark Kent with his mannerisms and is awkward and inherently likable without being clumsy. He is better as Superman, not just physically, but also in the stoic and serious presence he gives the character. He delivers the actions sequences with impressive physicality and stamina, but he is also quite believable when Superman shows his vulnerable side. As for his youthful appearance, the director wisely chose someone young enough who can still be believable several years from now in a franchise package.The inevitable and never-ending comparisons to Christopher Reeve are unfair and misguided. Reeve was awesome in the first two Superman films, but he was merely cashing a big paycheck for the last two dreadful films as he sought other "serious" roles, most of which went nowhere (anyone see "The Bostonians" lately? I didn't think so.) He didn't even bother to do the necessary sit-ups to make himself believable as Superman in the last installment, and his Clark Kent by that time was an embarrassing parody of its former self.Also, imagine if Nicolas Cage (yes, he was seriously considered at one point) or some other established actor was cast for the role of Superman, or if the role was played for camp or laughs. No one would take it seriously.So relax and enjoy the film and enjoy Routh as Superman. He has lived up to every expectation that has so far been hurled at him and has been largely accepted by the public as the new Man of Steel. And remember, actors do not own roles, they merely play them.

Review Title: Maybe I Expect more of the movie
What a disappointment of a movie.
Review: Man what a shame this movie was really Bad.Very few action sequences(they were good).But the most part of the movie was full of sentiment.They had to show the ugly female actress who was playing Lois lane form the starting till the end. The movie was filled with too much Sentiment.No one delivered a worthwhile performance in acting.The movies colors were too dull.They should have used colors like they use for spider-man it could have even been brighter than spider-man.I don't know what the hell they spent money on 200 million$.The guy playing superman is OK he could do a bit more emoting but wait i think he had very little screen time most of it was covered by ugly Louis lane.I should have gone to watch X-men 3 in the theater instead of this after seeing the trailer this looked promising so i went for it saw it in RDX also in theater still man how i regret it.The action scenes u see in the trailer thats the only action u get to see in the movie maybe 2 more boy was it disappointing.Maybe Christopher Reeves died soon so that he could avoid seeing this disappointment of a movie.

Review Title: Superman Returns really gets you into the movie, but at times it might disappoint you with inadequate pacing and under-developed characters.
Review: Honestly, I would have liked the movie more if it had better pacing. The many action scenes within the movie really grab you and immerse you into the action, giving you a sense of panic. However, some of the slower paced scenes were rather a bore, especially the epilogue. They tried adding depths to the story, but in the end felt dragged unnecessarily. Those scenes weren't terrible, but might have been better if they were shortened. The cinematography and special effects were excellent though. Every shot and action was astonishing.The character development between Lois, her family and Superman could be argued as not enough, but I felt it was a good place to leave it hanging. They have the audience experience the emotions that goes through the parties, but not necessarily tell you all of it in details. Lex Luthor and the villains however felt unnecessarily incompetent and weak, when compared to the strong figure of Superman. Lex Luthor was known to be an evil genius, however in the film you see him as an evil incompetence, since he was unable to gather useful people who would actually contribute to his cause actively and positively. To me, Lex Luthor the character did not seem to be a threat, whereas the consequences of his actions seemed more fittingly so. In simpler terms, Lex Luthor seemed more like an underdone, insane villain rather than a morbid evil genius with an insane scheme.Personally, I also disliked the overplayed undertone (more like an overtone really...) of the comparison between Superman and Christ. The overall theme was way to strong which felt like it was forced fed and choked down your throat. Superman is SUPER. We GET IT. It might have been better if it was toned down more when we aren't treated like incompetent thinkers who don't get the metaphor. I'll leave it to you to decide whether or not the metaphor was fitting between the two of them.A closing comment: Superman Return might have been better if they ditched some goofy humours that detracts realism from the movie, and replace with some more intelligence humours to relax audiences from the intense (and impressive) actions.

It's a tragedy how surprisingly low Supermans opening numbers were. It's a great movie, but even if it wasn't, it's Superman for crying out loud! I don't understand why people are so much more interested in spiderman or that stupid Xmen 3. Spiderman's great and all, but superman is the great comic book hero of all time. And I'm not just stating my opinion, I mean our culture just uses superman as the main reference to heroes. It's a fact. It just surprises me that's all. Especially since I liked the movie and appreciated it's focus on the characters and story and emotional tone, not just soul-less action like Xmen3. Especially with Xmen making 15million more than superman on opening. That movie was so cheesy, and once again, come on America... IT'S SUPERMAN FOR CRYING OUT LOUD!

Review Title: A decent restart on the Superdude's film series

Review: Superman Returns has the feel of the Christopher Reeve films. Except for the special effects, it could have been made 15 or twenty years ago. Routh was excellent casting as a successor to Reeve, and has a similar look and voice -- what little we hear of it. (Poor newcomer Routh is hardly given any lines to work with, and those few he has are less than super.) Unfortunately, there are a few significant flaws which prevent the film from being really good. The pacing is a bit off, and the movie could be trimmed by 15 minutes without losing anything but time. That's a bit forgivable, but a larger problem is off-key characterizations and relationships. Superman, always before a paragon of virtue, is shown performing a certain morally questionable activity (which is acceptable) but without showing any uncertainty or remorse (which is not). Also, any relationship between Clark and Lois seems to have been completely forgotten in the years since we last saw them. Where before, Lois had obvious affection for Clark, if only as a geeky brother or emasculate platonic friend, she now barely acknowledges his existence.Most of the other characters are similarly off-key. Routh and Spacey are eerily reminiscent of Reeve and Hackman in their portrayals, but the rest of the cast seemed to just miss the mark.I would say I would look forward to a director's cut, but the problems with the film should have been caught by the director before it hit the screen.However, if you're not a die-hard fan of the comics or the original movies, then you probably won't be terribly disappointed with this film. Of course, if you're not a big fan of the comics or original films, you probably won't be that interested in this one either...

I don't share my thoughts on movies, but this one in particular I felt compelled. I've been a fan of Superman for over 20 years enjoying the variations in character, script, and storyline. I will admit one thing is that the screenwriters certainly stuck to the history of Superman; however, than in itself is the biggest flaw of this movie. Basically, it's flat out boring, trite, and an insult to our creative minds. Brandon did a fabulous job mimicking the essence of Clark Kent, but Spacey was an utter waste as a villain and I will completely cast blame on a horrendous script. There was nothing compelling in the story line. The direction from our X-men fellow was contrived and left me cold in the theater. My lovely wife ( a fan of the original first two Superman and recent fan of the Smallville series was ready to leave after the first 45 minutes. Try to stay awake my friends… it's a struggle.

I really wanted to like this movie, and I give Bryan Singer full marks for his devotion to Superman, Richard Donner and Christopher Reeve. I also commend him for injecting a lot of human story into what could have been yet another bland, non-stop action summer movie.But alas, all his earnestness has resulted in a movie that is too self-important, too serious and too long.Brandon Routh does a reasonable job at invoking Christopher Reeve, but Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane is too young and can't hold a candle to Margot Kidder's sassy, love-struck super sleuth.The plot has so many holes, it's like watching a movie built on styrofoam. Lex Luthor creates a continent so uninhabitable that he thinks he's going to control the world? And just who, pray tell, gave him the title deed to this hideous island anyway? How does he intend to persuade the rest of the world that he "owns" it?In another moment of silliness, Superman's super-suit can withstand bullets, but it's literally ripped off him with ease in a later scene. I could go on, but don't want to get into spoiler territory.I don't mean to be cruel, because as I said, you can see the love that Bryan Singer and his cast and crew put into it. It's immaculately made, but ultimately bloated and dreary. A super shame.

Review Title: A super return for the Man of Steel
Review: Very faithful revival of the Superman movies; accomplishing a delicate balance between adapting information we've seen in the Christopher Reeve movies, and blending it with new story line elements. In short, this movie is a hybrid of remake and sequel, and pulls it off well.We meet a modern Superman (Brandon Routh) existing in the early 21st Century, yet endowed with the classic positive personality traits that have made the character so endearing by his many predecessors in the role. Routh not only resembles Reeve, but captures the friendly, boyishly charming, and kind hearted nature that Reeve brought to Superman.Kate Bosworth shines as the finest Lois Lane ever, capturing her ability to adapt to any challenge with an understated strength that is not in-your-face style, yet imposing all the same. It's easy to believe her as the resourceful reporter who touches the heart of the Man of Steel. The restrained power of their rekindled romance is appropriate to their situation, and you wonder how kind fate will be to them this time. The Lois/Superman chemistry has never been better. Kevin Spacey's Lex Luthor is magnificent. At once absurdly funny and malevolently vicious, Spacey's Luthor is equal to Gene Hackman's terrific job in the same role.The movie is successful in every area that counts: writing, directing, and acting. The airplane sequence is one of the most creative collection of scenes ever, especially its surprise ending location.The movie has done a more than an adequate job of taking a character that has been an icon for 70 years, while somehow contributing something new of artistic merit to the legacy. Highly recommended.

Thank goodness we have a director like Bryan Singer and a studio like Warner Brothers that has the cajones to stay true to the original source material. It shows great respect for the audiences that grew up with both the Christopher Reeve movies and the George Reeves TV series. Warner Brothers could have easily gone the alternate route and made this into a "reimagination" project. The word itself is scary, recent projects like Wild Wild West, Battlestar Galactica and The Dukes of Hazzard (yes I know Warner Bros. had their hands on a couple of those but this time they got it right). I only wish Bryan Singer would go back to his original intent and do a bigscreen Battlestar Galactica (the continuation angle that he developed). The only complaints I have is more of the pacing at the beginning and the end of the movie and Kate Bosworth's Lois Lane but those are just small issues. Well done Bryan Singer and Warner Brothers!

Review Title: good on the technicals, but utterly pointless
Could it be better than the original?
Review: Superman Returns is a pretty good movie.Though you still can't beat the original, it is still pretty good. The director bryan singer, who is one of my favorite directors, does a great job of creating suspense and filming all the action. Other than the great action sequences and the superb direction the acting in the film was excellent. Brandon Routh, in his big-screen debut,as superman/clark kent almost gives christopher reeve a run for his money. Though in my opinion the best acting in the film was kevin spacey's dark and sinister yet slightly comical version of superman's foe lex luther. Overall, superman returns is the best movie of the summer so far, I strongly recommend that you see it, if you haven't already :)

Review Title: Superman a powerful and visually intriguing adventure
Review: This movie was very well done in my mind, the fact that Bryan singer didn't have to introduce all the characters like in other movies made the story jump in a lot quicker. The actors were all very believable and Kevin spacey was fantastic as the psycho yet refined Lex Luthor, The special effects were amazing as well and the previews you see on T.V. do them no justice. The music by John Ottoman is a pure tribute to John Williams old score, he brings Williams beautiful scores to life with beautiful vocals and incredible instrumental scores, though adds his touch in as well. My suggestion is before you decide not to see this movie, remember most people who leave reviews are comic lovers and any slight change from the comic book makes them start to see only bad through the movie, so my suggestion is see the Movie

Review Title: Overall : Superman is A Great Film
Review: I saw the Preview Last Night and I got to tell you that I really enjoyed this film. Too many people are underestimating these brilliant actors, just from what they have seen on the trailers. Kevin Spacey seemed like a horrible Lex Luthor from what the Commercials but out, but in fact he does a great job portraying Luthor in this rendition of Superman. Brandon Routh did an outstanding job as Clark Kent/Superman. So did Sam Huntington as Jimmy Olsen, without Sam in the film I'd think that it would have been weaker. Just because Sam brings basically all the comedy to the film. Also, James Marsden does a decent job as Richard White, Lois Lane's boyfriend. Child actor Tristan Lake Leabu did a good job as Jason White, Lois' and James' child. It was also nice to see Marlon Brando in the role Jor-El for 1 last time, that was really unique. The only thing about the film that falls short is Kate Bosworth, because compared to all the other actors in the film she is nothing. Her acting does fall short at times, but not so much as too ruin or bring down the movie. The only flaw of this film would have to be that it is 20 Minutes longer than it should have been. Finally, the effects from Superman Returns, were so amazing and astounding, that you will only get to see such magnificent entertainment from this film, if you see it in Theatres.

Review Title: They should have stopped after the opening credits...
Review: ...because it was quite possibly the best part of the movie. I had high hopes for this film with Singer (who did a stellar job with the X-Men franchise) and Spacey attached to the project. Alas, this movie can only be termed as a disappointment. The movie was far too long for the little progression that happened in the plot. The plot mistakes are many, with an extremely illogical scene towards the film's conclusion that will make you slap yourself in the face for it's stupidity. Plus the chemistry between Routh and Bosworth was practically non-existent. To be fair, the action sequences are very well done, Superman's first appearance is absolutely breathtaking, but these scenes can only do so much for a film even when done this well. As I stated previously, they should have stopped after the opening title with John Williams's excellent score, it would have made the film far better in my eyes.Bottom Line: See it if you must, but do not expect much.

With superman being emotionally disheartened (i.e. Lois moved on); we can relate to the man of steel, we feel what he is going through, we feel his pain about his love, Lois. This is VERY important with the story of Superman. See people like batman and spider-man because they are human and we can relate to their dilemmas. Since the man of steel has unbelievable powers no one can relate to someone perfect, his troubles cant be just minor struggles with villains, the audience needs some thematic element that makes them feel for superman, love. love is everything. I'm so glad this movie was not just a summer action movie, rather, a great story. Brandom Routh and Kate Bosworth are PERFECT, no exaggeration, they both look the part as well as bringing their own flare of how they think their roles should be played as well as displaying such professionalism for both being so young. Their roles as well as Spacey as Luthor were perfectly convincing. And then all this directed by Singer is amazing. all those downgrading this movie, think it through, imagine a different director, imagine someone else as Superman, it might have been Nicholas Cage.. dear God. This is one of my favorite movies, and i cant wait for the next installment.

Review Title: Superman flies again, but not as high as he could have.

Review: Most young people today have no idea what a real movie is. They know nothing about narrative, antagonists, or what a hero actually is. Audience's want action and adventure without a plot. Audiences have lost the art of enjoying a movie.The original Superman as played by Christopher Reeve was more than just a movie when it came out. It utilized the blue screen in a way that would create a revolution in movie making style. Audience's actually thought Superman could really fly. Christopher Reeve became the modern day iconic physical representation of the comic character. None of the sequels ever captured what the first movie did. Even the original score became an anthem for fans.Superman Returns, once again captures the child in us all and makes us think that a man can actually fly. A hero that represents "truth and justice." Someone with great power that transcends racial and cultural barriers.Brandon Routh reminds us of Christopher Reeve and then adds to Superman with a bit of his own style. What more can any Superman movie fan ask for? Kevin Spacey reminds us of Gene Hackman. Both actors of substantial caliber, with Spacey's Luther equitable, and just as wonderful.Iconic and Christ similarities? Sure. Similar to the first movie? You bet. A stale score? Heck no. They even make it more appealing. Makes you believe in Superman? Yes! The movie makes you want to click your hills together and repeatedly say "I believe, I believe..." Forget the critics. You can't not like something about this movie!

This was way better than I expected. The actors were all excellent as was the special effects. I like the Christopher Reeve movie but I like all the actors in this one much better with the Superman role at least a draw. I mean, come on, Kate Bosworth or Margot Kidder. Frank Langella or Jackie Cooper. Both no contests as are the others. Lex Luthor was done really well by Kevin Spacy (big surprise) the guy is always great and the story line was interesting as well. The look was interesting and the costume of Superman didn't fall into the high tech trap they the Batman suits have done. Special effects are so superior today that you cant even compare. It does however always crack me up that nobody ever catches on with Clarks secret identity, but I guess that's the magic of the Superman story. Go see it with an open mind and you wont be disappointed.

Oh gads, what i could list that was horrible. Lets start from the beginning, they start off with some pathetic CGI, and continuing through the movie the cgi is continuously bad. In fact my high school friend has done CGI that could match the same quality. Next the actor for Superman/Clark Kent does not match the part, his acting was... blah... no emotion, then again the amount of lines that he had in the movie were VERY minimal, especially considering he is the alleged main character. Also it almost looks like they put on a muscle suit for when he was super man, which seemed to be the only change that was noticeable between him and his alter ego. This movie, of all the superman movies or shows, had the worst comparison, i mean it was so obvious that they were the same person, even their characterization seemed the same. There seemed no distinction between mild mannered reporter and super hero. For a two and a half hour movie, there was actually very little development and to much attempts on fancy shots of super man flying. The only characters that even seemed to develop were Lex Luthor and his girlfriend, who in fact i saw the most character development in. Which is pathetic because she is simply a supporting character, not even a villain mind you, but a simple supporting character. From what i gather the makers attempted to do a movie that both appealed to the comic/TV/old movie fans, so they could go off old stuff, as well as make a self sufficient movie. They failed at both for the sole reason that they attempted to do both. Also i saw way to many attempted biblical analogies. they were there and recognizable, but they seemed forced, and just didn't quite work. I rant and rave, and feel i should save you from any more of it. So thereby i rest my case. I mean it had SO MUCH potential. They could have made it great. But rather they gave us an overly predictable, overly cliché, poorly put together movie. And so i end my review, sparing you from any more rants upon this wasted movie.

I went into this movie feeling extreme dread. I did not, in fact, plan to see it at all. Everything I read about this movie really made me want to avoid it. Still, I couldn't turn down a free ticket so I went to see it. Admitting that I went into this with a jaundiced eye, I came out not hating it as much as I expected. There were things I didn't like about it, but they were not the things I expected. All of the actors gave solid performances. I was actually surprised by the quality of Bosworth's performance. Though I had heard complaints that Spacey's Luthor was over-the-top, I didn't find it so. Routh did a credible job. His Clark was a bit clumsy (the portrayal of the character, not the character itself which is supposed to be a bit clumsy). So far as the acting goes, I really can't find anything I can't overlook. I have mixed feelings about the continuity between the first two Salkind movies and this. One way to look at it is that they were being respectful of the previous series. Another way to look at is that the best parts of Superman Returns are drawn directly from the previous works. I thought the story itself was simplistic, without even the depth of Superman 3 or 4. One objection I had going in and which did not change having seen the movie is the treatment of the Superman-Clark-Lois romance. While the stated goal may be to 'update' the material or add a touch of realism, it just seems to be trite Hollywood studio gimmickry. From my perspective, it's the same as taking the magic and romance out of the Arthurian legends. While it may be some people's cup of tea, I don't find it very interesting, and this is what was bubbling around in my brain as I walked out of Superman Returns.

Brandon Routh (Superman/Clark Kent) - He had very big boots to fill after Christopher Reeve's legendary performance. I feel he incorporated some parts of Reeve's performance into his, but added his own feel to Superman to make the role his own. His Superman wasn't as soft (if that makes sense) as Reeve's and Brandon made his Superman a little edgier as well. Brandon was perfect in the role combining all of Superman's traits such as anger and vulnerability when it comes to Lois Lane and nailed his performance being so natural as Superman. He did a fine job as Clark Kent too.There's not much to say about Kevin Spacey, I expected him to be excellent and he certainly was! I was never a big fan of Gene Hackman's Lex Luthor (yes, while he was funny to watch, he was never a convincing villain), so I was extremely happy to see that this Lex Luthor was much more evil. Spacey managed to keep Lex as the wisecracking Lex we saw in the previous Superman movies, but also was a lot more threatening and menacing which was convincing as the insane evil genius that is Lex Luthor.Kate Bosworth - while there is a lot of negativity surrounding her performance as Lois Lane I feel she was perfect in the role and definitely surprised me the most and I was very satisfied with her performance. She shows us a more mature Lois Lane, which was a nice break from the over-confident, sometimes arrogant Lois Lane we've seen in previous portrayals who treat Clark Kent horribly for no particular reason (but the awkwardness in the Lois/Clark relationship was definitely there). While I am a fan of the sassy Lois Lane as well, the lack of one-liners from Bosworth's Lois does not detract from or ruin her performance. A lot of the negative comments coming towards her have to do with how young she is (23). I think if more people would look past the fact that she's 23 and focus on her performance they'd see how amazing her performance as Lois was. I give her kudos as well for not copying Margot Kidder, which would have been tempting.The Superman and Lois chemistry was present throughout the entire film, in my opinion topping the chemistry between Christopher Reeve and Margot Kidder.My only complaint would have to do with the Kitty character. I blatant clone of the Eve Teschmacher character from the original Superman movies. The actress playing Kitty did a wonderful job and I liked her character, but I have no idea why they felt the need to call her Kitty and just not bring back the Eve Teschmacher name.All in all, an excellent film not to be missed!

When I heard that Bryan Singer had left X-Men 3 to make a new Superman film, I had mixed emotions. Superman as a character was far less interesting to me because, Richard Donner's films aside, he seemed to lack a certain humanity that was waiting there to be exploited with the X-Men. Well, Singer should be brought in to direct every superhero film henceforth, because if there is one thing he excels at, it is taking the humanity of an extraordinary character and making an intelligent audience rally behind that. Superman Returns is everything that X-Men 3 should have been, almost everything that X-Men 2 was, and then some. Particularly in testament to Singer's skill as a filmmaker is that Superman Returns is neither better than nor inferior to Donner's 1978 adaptation. It is equal, and most importantly, *different*, a quality that will have Bryan Singer on a pedestal long after directors like Brett Ratner, Richard Lester, or Joel Schumacher are nothing more than some bad memory that true cinemaphiles only experience like a mild toothache.Only two problems mar this new film, and they are very minor in the grand scheme of things. First of all, the first thirty or so minutes of Superman Returns feel borderline incoherent, as Singer attempts to set up where Superman has been in the past twenty years, and why he is back. I get the feeling that Warners asked Singer to cut thirty minutes from the film, and Singer felt that the setup/exposition early on was the best place. While this does create a disjointed feel early on, Singer's judgement in this matter is as solid as his judgement that he is the best person to resurrect one of the most thoroughly-killed tentpole franchises in history. Once the film settles down into a groove, about the time that Lois goes to cover an experimental space shuttle launch that has to be seen to be believed, Singer delivers scene after scene in which Superman's human core is blended almost seamlessly with his über-human abilities. Only Bryan Singer would invent a scene in which Superman explains why Humanity needs him by pointing out all the cries of anguish that he can hear and Lois cannot.Speaking of Lois, I had mixed expectations when I knew that Kate Bosworth would be portraying her. I need not have worried, for Bosworth hits the nail on the head more times than a pneumatic hammer. Where Margot Kidder was a screechy, whiny prop for Christopher Reeve to rescue and bounce dialogue off, Bosworth becomes an integral part of the plot, and helps the plot move about in ingenious ways. James Marsden has a surprisingly expansive role as Richard White, the man Lois marries whilst Superman is off exploring what might be left of Krypton. Marsden does the side a big favour by portraying a simple human being, in a manner that speaks volumes about the species and why Superman wants to help them out. As they say, however, a hero is only as good as the antagonist, and Kevin Spacey provides one as effective as those of Brian Cox or Ian McKellen. I would even rate him as better in the role of Lex Luthor than Gene Hackman, simply because he gives the character a sleazy charm in place of a tiresome tendency to do nothing but put down those he considers inferior.Brandon Routh has the most thankless task of the film, which is ironic, given that he is the titular character. The Superman of Superman Returns is much like that portrayed by Christopher Reeve in four films. He speaks in an economy of words, is charming when he is being friendly, and still charming when he is exercising imposition. What makes Routh stand out is his performance as Clark Kent. Rather than emphasise the bumbling, farcical nature of the character, Clark in Superman Returns is a regular guy who just happens to be rather large. Singer and Routh play the character as if he is already aware that he does not need to apologise for his presence, which makes the transitions into the character of Superman all the more believable. Just as Superman the character finds a whole new strength in being grounded and real, so too does Kent. The issue of how people can look at Superman and not see Kent is still left without exploration, but Brandon is so effective in both roles that this issue takes a big back seat. This man could go places if he manages to avoid the traps that Reeve fell into.The only other problem I have with Superman Returns is that this is the first Bryan Singer film in which I have noticed the use of shaky-cam. In the interiors of vehicles when they are about to crash, or whatever the situation may be, the camera shakes about like a dog being electrocuted, and it throws one right out of the film. So, a memo to Singer: you are better than this. Fortunately, what Singer also brings to the film is a rousing score that recycles John Williams' signature theme, but replaces everything else with new compositions by John Ottman, who also edited the film. Although he tends to be bombastic at times when subtlety would suit the on screen action better, he also gives the film a quality where one could switch off the dialogue altogether, and still make sense of the story. Speaking of which, the special effects, although totally necessary to depict Superman's trademark abilities, are given exactly the kind of emphasis they need. In other words, they never get in the way of the story being told.I gave Superman Returns a ten out of ten. By shifting the focus of his film, Bryan Singer makes Superman as miraculous as he was in 1978. See it twice to get a good idea of what a superhero film done right looks like.

Greetings again from the darkness. This has to be one of the toughest franchises to cover, if for no other reason than the scrutiny from the mass of comic book and film devotees. Listening to these fanatics argue over the details of the boots and hair style will convince anyone that there is a certain responsibility for those involved with the project.Starting with the highest profile spot, TV bit role actor Brandon Routh provides the beefiest, darkest Superman yet. Sadly, Routh is infinitely more effective as Clark Kent than as the Caped Crusader. Part of this is the strange filter, director Singer used in filming. It makes his face look plastic - almost as if it is a store bought toy. The good news is, Routh is passable and does not bring the movie down. Does he come across as heroic? Not really. But he is not a major distraction either.The choice of Bryan Singer as director had many fans anxious from the day it was announced. His "X-Men" films put style over substance and really emphasize special effects. "Superman Returns" is right in line with this. It is a very pleasant movie to watch, in fact the sound is terrific. The special effects are kept to a minimum and two really stand out. Both the city crumbling scenes and the yacht disaster are very well done, action packed and not overly long. Where Singer misses are the "slower" scenes such as Superman and Lois' reunion tour of the city. It felt like 20 minutes, even though it was probably only 5.The real downside to the film is Kate Bosworth ("Remember the Titans" "Beyond the Sea"). Although, I didn't think it possible, she is every bit as horrible as Katie Holmes was in "Batman Begins". First of all, can anyone explain why this movie is based 5 years later, but Lois, Jimmy and Superman all appear YOUNGER? In fact, Margot Kidder (excellent as Lois Lane in 1978) was 30 when she first played Lois and Bosworth is 23. That in itself does not stifle the movie, but Bosworth's performance certainly does.As for the rest, there was entirely too much Jimmy Olsen in the first half. The entire plane sequence with Bosworth being tossed around like ice cubes in a blender is ludicrous. Not even a headache or bruise? Kevin Spacey has some brilliant scenes as Lex Luthor, but fans need to know this is an entirely different take than Gene Hackman's. Parker Posey has a couple of really cool moments, but mostly she just stands around batting her eyes. James Marsden (Cyclops from "X-Men") is fairly nondescript as Lois Lane's live-in mate and Perry White's (Frank Langella) nephew. Nice to see Eva Marie Saint as Clark's childhood mom (although the orange lipstick in the hospital scene was brutal). Pretty rare to see two actors born in 1928 make a mark on a film these days. In addition to Ms. Saint, Marlon Brando makes an appearance (archive footage from 1978) as Jar-El, Superman's dad.In one of the endless stream of tributes, Jack Larson and Noel Neill make brief appearances. In the original "Adventures of Superman" Larson was Jimmy Olsen and Neill was Lois Lane. Singer casts them here as a bartender and dying millionaire widow, who Lex Luthor scams out of her estate in order to fund his global takeover.Overall, a pretty true and fun adaptation of the brand without too many risks. Kids and adults can enjoy this one, even though it was a missed opportunity to give us some real depth in analyzing what Superman went through for the past 5 years.

Congratulations to Bryan Singer for making another film, under challenging conditions, that meets his own relatively high standards. Congratulations to Brandon Routh and Kate Bosworth, who fill a couple pairs of sizable shoes very well. Congratulations to Kevin Spacey for proving, once again, his versatility and competence within an ensemble cast. And finally, congratulations to Michael Dougherty and the rest of the writing team for Superman Returns, who have done the seemingly impossible by blending together several elements taken from disparate Superman stories over seventy or so years of the character's development in several DC comics titles into a true-to-character, intelligently written and themed, blend of romance and wild world-saving action.I can hear the film snobs now - "just what we need, another bombastic action flick loaded with CGI and cliché in place of a 'SERIOUS' human story." Yup, it's a bombastic action flick. Yes, it is crammed with special effects. And yes, if you consider simple and largely unexamined human emotions to be cliché, then Superman Returns is loaded with clichés. My advice to the film snobs is - don't review films you are predisposed to dislike. If you do not have a standard from which you are able to measure the worth of a certain genre, then you have no business reviewing in that genre.Let's examine this rationally. The whole point of the character of Superman is to provide a fantastic superhuman persona who is so alien and so vastly superior in terms of physical being, knowledge, and morality, that he becomes a mirror through which we are forced to critically examine our own social, political, emotional, and health problems. What kinds of problems would such a vastly superior being trouble himself with? Well, guess what, he might not have time for the day to day subtleties of social and sexual intrigues and ambiguities, the role of the media in political rhetoric or other "SERIOUS" concerns plaguing the modern intellectual elite. Superman is concerned with more fundamental issues such as whether half the world's population is going to live out the day. Yet he still manages to find time to rekindle a dysfunctional relationship with love interest Lois Lane, and to be inspired to prove himself with a flourish of light-speed heroic antics to regain his esteem among a people whose cynicism and self-contempt have apparently gotten the better of them (film snobs all?). in fact, he even MAKES MISTAKES!!!!Kal-El returns to earth just in time to confront his old arch-nemesis Lex Luther's plot to rebuild a chunk of Krypton off the coast of New Jersey as his own continent. He must also unexpectedly confront his own feelings for the people of earth and, in particular, for Lois Lane, now an unmarried mother with an asthmatic kid and a smoking habit. Lois is also engaged to a good guy, very competently acted by James Marsden, but the paternity of her son is suspect. Considering the fact that this is a "bombastic action film" a remarkable amount of time is taken up with developing the relationships between these characters and exploring their effects on one another. And at times, you even get the feeling that at least some of Superman's heroism is inspired by his feelings for Lois.The bigger problem is that Luther has Kryptonite, and plenty of it, and so, Superman is mortally vulnerable and must fight for his own life as well as those of his adoptive species.Ignore the geological inaccuracies (which are plenty), forget about the occasional continuity problems, and let yourself get sucked up into this very fine and well crafted example of the superhero action genre. If you're a hardened film snob, it's worth the effort of wriggling out of your fossilized suit of cynical armor just long enough to see what the value of a film with a positive, simple, message might be.

Review Title: Not a terrible film, but fell far short of expectations... (SPOILER!)

Review: Seriously, this movie was not what I expected. I went to the theatre expecting to see a piece of crap movie. But, instead I saw one of the best Super Hero renderings ever. Yeah, Brandon Routh isn't Christopher Reeve, but he is Superman. He is Clark Kent. There's no question that the casting for this role was perfect. The rest of the cast was really good as well. The only thing I missed was the likableness that Gene Hackman brought to Lex Luther. But Spacey does get the evilness of the character just right.From opening to closing, this movie has been everything I've been waiting for since that steaming pile known as Superman IV came out. I'm interested in seeing where the sequels to the new movie will go. The great thing about this movie was its willingness to take the Superman myth into unfarmiliar territory. I'm just glad this didn't suck. I think THE Superman, not the ONLY superman Chris Reeve would be proud. Thumbs up to Synger for keeping the opening sequence and ending the same as the Reeve's movies.

Review Title: What a great film both in Imax and not.  However...
Review: I first saw Superman Returns on opening day. I could only think of one word, Awesome. However a couple of times I found Superman himself looking a little too CG for my taste. I have seen this in countless other films and always to a much worse degree than Bryan Singers masterpiece. This film was so good, that I had no trouble at all letting the two sub par moments of CG slip past without ever looking back.The second time I saw SR, was the night of July 3rd, and this time I saw it in Imax 3D. While sitting in the theater surrounded by loud inconsiderate patrons, a woman who was never taught to cover her mouth or turn her head when she coughs, a young man who could not control the tapping of his feet, and another woman who seemed to think that shaking her bag of candy and her cup of ice during critical moments in the film helped to enhance the sound, I found the film to not only be better in general than the first time I saw it, but an entirely new movie. The 3D was done brilliantly and added an entirely new element to the film.So sorry for venting on here about my movie going experience, but this is not a rare occurrence for me. It seems that every time I go to the movies it's getting worse.The bottom line is that Superman was such a great movie that not even hacking, chomping, shaking, tapping, talking people surrounding could not take me out of it. Superman Returns is one of the best films I have seen in years. Bryan Singer is in my top 5 directors of all time.

Review Title: Believe the negative reviews here...They are right!

Review: The movie was great- with the Director from the first two X-men movies and Kevin Spacey, it was hard for it to be bad, but it even exceeded my expectations. All the parts were extremely well cast, and Brandon Routh, though a nobody, fit the new superman well. He was a nerdy Clark Kent, but not over the top, and a heroic superman. Sam Huntington, whom some of you may remember as Mimi-Siku in Jungle 2 Jungle, played a hilarious Jimmy Olsen. The story was captivating throughout the whole movie, and the technology creates spectacular scenes. Superman returns from his flight to Krypton, his home planet, after five years and has to repair some of his relationships. Simultaneously, Lex Luthor is let out of jail and obtains a large some of money and property to begin his next attempt to destroy superman and become powerful. Because of its captivating and action-packed plot, The movie doesn't feel as long and drawn out as earlier Superman films, though it certainly isn't short. It is one of the best superhero films that I have ever seen.

Review Title: This movie didn't fly, it floated!

Review: This movie is AMAZING! It is worth the costly theater prices, and much more! The special effects are fantastic and the acting is great! Brandon Routh (superman) did an incredible job considering that it is his first movie! Also, some parts of the movie he looks just like Christopher Reeve, one of the reasons he was chosen for the part of Superman.Kate Bosworth did a great job, she and Brandon had a good chemistry together which makes the movie even greater.Through the whole movie it kept you guessing on what was to happen next, there is a lot of action and romance ;) two things that make this/any movie great.This is such a great movie, one of the best i have seen in a very very long time. I hope you see it soon because its a movie that you have to see in the theaters before you buy it!

Review Title: Well Done Harris, Dougherty, and Singer
Review: This movie was visually stunning and packed with plot. It went through character development and gave Superman a weakness other than Kryptonite. Kevin Spacey was excellent as Lex Luthor and he made me laugh more than once. The "Let me hear you say it- WRONG!" part made my night. The allegory between the story and the Bible was apparent throughout. Basically if you know the Bible from after Jesus comes out of the desert, you know the story. Newcomer, Brandon Routh, did great as Superman mostly because he is the stereotypical looking Superman everybody knows. Above all, however, I tip my hat to the Lois Lane's kid. He was my favorite only because he threw the piano at the henchman and his facial expressions were great. I hardly go to the movies and I'm glad I didn't waste my money here. Overall well done.

Review Title: Do Not Waste Your Time On This Movie

Review: I watched this movie the day after it came to the theaters and I loved it. The suspense was great and shocking. I loved it. Brandon Routh ( who played Superman) was great in the movie. Kate Bosworth ( Lois Lane) wasn't. I feel that Bryan Singer could have given someone else a chance. That was the only negative thing. The stroyline revolves around a bad thing that happens to Superman that causes him to leave. Lex plots to destroy the world and Superman is brought back to save the world-again. Surprisingley there is a brain teaser. Lois has a son and it is hinted that it is indeed Supermans. James Marsden plays the boyfriend of Lois Lane and there is a love triangle. This was a great movie!

Review Title: I have a stack of diet pepsi Superman pop cans at my desk and..
Review: ...I still gave the movie an 8. I am sick of the super positive and negative reviews this movie is getting. It was a great movie filled with action and emotion, the characters were pitch perfect although yes, Bosworth looked a bit young. The problem was that Luthor should not have been the main and solo villain. Since this movie acknowledges Superman and Superman 2 as backstory, we've already seen Luthor going for a landgrab scam and using kryptonite on him. That being said, I am usually annoyed by kid parts (Blues Brother 2000, anyone?) but this kid didn't annoy me given they were acknowleding a history he had. It may not be how we think Superman's life should turn out, but sometimes life is life, and it just happens. I look more forward to Sueprman Returns II, hopefully with more colorful villains and schemes, and no General Zod. Again, been there done that. Note to producers... I and II hold up, don't repeat them. Overall a great movie! Oh and the music and the opening credits were terrific... nice updates.

Superman has returned and what a return it is. Bryan Singer, the man who brought amazing cult classics like "The Usual Suspects" and "Apt Pupil" and then went on to bring us the "X-Men" franchise has the utmost respect for the "Man of Steel." Singer has done for Superman what Christopher Nolan did for Batman. Didn't change his imagery rather focus on the things that make Superman so "Super." I have a confession to make; I was on the boat of many people not approving of this project when I heard it was being made. It hit a sore spot being Christopher Reeve, the original motion picture Superman had passed and I felt it was disrespectful to many of us comic book era readers. Could I have been more wrong? The film picks up years after "Superman II" ends. Superman has left Earth in search of his own identity on planet Krypton. During this duration Lois Lane has won the Pulitzer Prize for her acclaimed article "Why the World Doesn't Need Superman" and has moved on to build a family. She has a son and is in a non-matrimonial relationship with the Chief's nephew. Superman returns to Metropolis and has come to find out that a world has learned to live without him both in safety and security. Also, he learns that the diabolical Lex Luthor beat the system upon Superman's absence and is planning a scheme to take over the world and rid "The Man of Steel" for good.What makes Superman so "super"? His powers are a definite big part of it but Singer focuses on Superman's inner battle with Clark Kent. Clark's awkwardness around Lois Lane, his subtlety upon entering a room, and his mannerisms that show the dark force that is embedded inside of him is all portrayed brilliantly by newcomer Brandon Routh. Routh nailed Superman perfectly from all of the mannerisms to the way he speaks. His delivery of lines could have brought a Reeve family member to tears because you can see Christopher Reeve just peaking out of him. His study of the character is remarkable and makes a lot of Superman fans very proud.I was not excited about hearing that a young Kate Bosworth was chosen as Lois Lane. As the film continues on I got used to her in the role and she brought forth an admirable effort but she was no Margot Kidder. Lois Lane's battle with Superman has to do with his exit of earth without a thought or a word which leads her to write her prize-winning article. Bosworth gives Lois a life unlike in the others. Her feelings for Superman, love for her child and battle with marriage are tackled very well thanks to Bosworth.The rest of the supporting cast is magnificent. Sam Huntington as Jimmy is uplifting and a great comic relief as always. James Marsden as Lane's romantic partner is both great and sympathetic to the story. Frank Langella is a noble presence to the cast after just having a comeback success on George Clooney's "Good Night, and Good Luck." Langella is the Chief of the newspaper and makes a fine addition to a vastly unknown cast. Parker Posey is Kitty Kowalski, the girl-toy of the villainous Lex Luthor, who grabs her own inner battle throughout the film. But the standout of the film could be, no other, than the two-time Academy Award winner Kevin Spacey. He is like stated before diabolical, treacherous, villainous, wicked, and completely malevolent. Spacey is the pitch perfect best choice of the cast for playing their role. Gene Hackman was high-quality as Luthor but Spacey brings something we haven't seen before. We see in his eyes, his true hate for the Man of Steel, and his true willingness to take over the planet. It's definitely one of the best villainous performances of recent years.The special effects, sound, sound editing and everything you can think of mechanically of the film is flawless and unspoiled. The scene of Superman regaining his identity and taking on a falling airplane should be enough to gather consideration of three Oscars. John Williams' score in the opening credits are enough to pump you up for an enjoyable but rather long ride. The film rides on for two hours and thirty-four minutes and gets a little "draggy" in some spots but never did I feel compelled to hate, walk out or blink to see what was going to happen next. The film is a huge success and campaigning for Oscars should deal with it's effects and if their feeling extra bold, a supporting nomination for Kevin Spacey with a directing nod for Bryan Singer. Why Singer? Singer for bringing one of the best heroes of modern time to a century full of CGI, THX, and thought-provoking enhancements and still with holding all the respect for the franchise and a man who brought him to life; Christopher Reeve. Congratulations to the entire cast and crew for being the first film of the summer to live up to its hype.Grade: ***1/2/****

after almost 20 years away from the big screen, the Man of Steel is back! I haven't been a huge fan of Superman (I'm a bigger Batman fan) but I have always enjoyed the Christopher Reeve's Superman films. (Well, except 4) Brandon Routh takes over as Superman and does an incredible job. He reminds me s much of Christopher Reeves but at the same time, brings something new.The film is much darker then I was expecting. It's lighter then Batman Begins, but it's darker then Spider-Man... but even then, there are moments where the movie does get a little darker the Batman Begins... The film is very dramatic and emotional and it's not really your normal average superhero film. It's more less action and more on story.Anyways, I enjoyed the film a lot and I really hope Bryan Singer brings in a villain who could hit Superman without using Kryptonite in the next film.

I was never a superman fan. I started getting attached to superman after watching the TV-series "smallville".if you were like me, have not seen the first superman movies, you might have some unanswered questions. But despite all that, you can see the passion put by the producers and the cast in reviving the superman legend.Combined with a well-written story, the special & visual effects are just spectacular. The music brings an additional heroic touch to the legacy that superman has.As for the cast, Kevin Spacey proved to be one of the best actors by portraying the character of Lex Luthor by being a a vicious, manipulative person. He was born for that role. Kate Bosworth has been another successful pick for the character of Lois Lane. As for Brandon Routh, it was annoying that throughout the movie, he kept reminding me of Tom Cruise. He played the role of Clark Kent pretty well. But I felt that he didn't have the commanding and self-trust traits to make him qualified to be the Next Superman. Routh is still young and he has still a lot to learn, but I believe that he shouldn't play the "charming" card too often.If you were not a superman fan, you might find the movie long or over-rated. But if you are a superman fan, then this is a must see movie as it proved to be worth waiting and it has what every superman fan dreams of.one more thing..I think that this superman is racist.He only listens to problems in North America and Europe. Why doesn't he listen to the people who are suffering in Africa? the discriminating, son of a ****..hehehe

Review Title: Truth, Justice, but Absolutely NOT the American Way
Review: Taking a page from the Natalie Maines school of patriotism (i.e. Why should anybody be patriotic), this incarnation of SUPERMAN has any and all references to the DC Comics' classic series well-defined American patriotism eradicated like it was a prayer in a public school. A reflection of 2006 Hollywood's moral vacuum, Superman is reduced to a liberal girlie-man, without values; just nothing. While this sequel is not as dreadful as Peter Jackson's horrid King Kong mess, it's lack of mainstream American values dooms it to the ashcan of good ideas gone bad. For the record, the greatest Superman movie was the 1948 Columbia 15-part serial; made on a shoestring budget with very basic but nonetheless effective special effects, from Krypton's destruction to the final moment in Chapter 15, it was always engrossing, never forgot it was a comic strip movie, and was 100% faithful to the DC Comics concept. Too bad 2006 moviegoers can't see the 1948 version and have to settle for another overload of Hollywood's current commitment to garbage movie-making.

Those who wants plain action in a movie, Superman is not for you because this movie has more heart and value that viewers of simple standard for entertainment find it boring (because they tag "great" movie just for the fight scenes). It is unlike other superhero movies that is full of fight scenes, destructions, and other non-sense stuffs but the storyline sucks that at the end of the movie, a lot of things do not make sense. Superman is a superhero who is an alien but is driven by compassion for the human race, a race that is not his own. He is one Superhero that not only has the muscle, the power, the superhuman strength, THE MOST HANDSOME FACE AND BODY, but his most valuable asset is his strength of character (that his human parents influenced him with)and his deep sense of responsibility & value for mankind (which his biological father taught). With this excellent combination, he his considered the leader of many other superheros. HIS CHARACTER IS HIS STRENGTH that is why the underlying tone of the movie is not just to show off his abilities (thru action and fight scenes) but also to bring out CHARACTER VALUES that many people nowadays would consider boring, non-essential, and find it hard to comprehend (because good values are "alien" to them). SUPERMAN RETURNS is not for the simpletons but for those who has the brains and the heart---both are essential. I admire the people behind the movie because they showed RESPECT (another dyeing character of the human race) to the original movies of Superman when they continued on with the original storyline. CONGRATULATIONS!!!....LOOKING FORWARD FOR ITS PART 2. Note: the movie (just like any other movies) has room for improvement. It is not perfect but definitely IT IS NOT BAD (like other people claim it to be).

Review Title: Special FX  and nostalgia worth it?
Review: Wonderful upgrades in technology and modern day special FX make Superman's return to the silver screen a delight to witness. The recycled Williams musical score, use of Brando footage, and cliché references to the 1978 Richard Donner Superman movie pay tribute to more than just the director and composer of the original movie, but also respect the groundbreaking work of Christopher Reeve.Still, despite the pleasant nostalgia, the movie still disappoints even the most die hard DC Comics fans.Brian Singer wanted to paint his own canvas. This, his select cast of nobodies (the worst being Kate Bosworth & Sam Huntington), and the tribute to the 1978 Donner film seems to have lengthened and compromised the potential for Kal-El's return to Hollywood. Someone should tell the director that there are many more plot devices and epic Superman enemies at his disposal than just Lex Luthor. Still, since using LL seemed inevitable, many (including myself) would like to have seen Singer work with at least some of the Smallville cast. Nobody plays Lex Luthor better than Michael Rosenbaum from this smash series. The use of religious imagery and innuendo was disturbing and distracting. Superman was never penned a "savior" - rather just a Hero who wanted to give back something to his adopted home world. Politically, Superman now stands for, "Truth, Justice ... all that stuff" instead of the "American way". Singer's liberalism is difficult to veil in his painting of a Hero who is quintessentially American.Artistic license comes at a price. Apparently for this film it was 260 million dollars. I really hope Warner Brothers makes it back. My local grocer: Stop and Shop has already begun shelving the action figures. The die hards will purchase the DVD. Ironically, Singer may need to pray that WB breaks even if there is any hope to carry newcomer Routh into a sequel. Indeed, I hope the next one soars well enough to carry us with it.

I expected this to be a great movie...and that can lead to either a very good theater experience or a terrible one. Its a bold move to even try to make a sequel to a series which has already made its claim to excellence. Props to Mr. Singer...props to everyone. This film was a knockout punch. I want to give some credit to John Williams too. You know your musical score is masterful when remakes have included it. John Williams is the best movie music composer of all time. Does anyone remember the theme to Star Wars?...Jaws?..E.T.?...The Original Superman?? Yep...John Williams. His original score is played throughout this movie, making an already great superhero revival film into an epic adventure that wont soon be forgot.And by the way if you all read Roger Eberts reviews, u must be crazy cuz he is never right! When i go to IMDb.com my vote is usually closer to the average for most movies. So don't be afraid to go see this movie. It really is a 10 out of 10!

I have read comic books since I was a little kid. I have alway been fascinated with the idea of duality in these mythological characters. To me Superman is the ideal example of this and this film gave new light to the Superman mythos as well as making the character more human.Bryan Singer should direct every superhero movie! This guy really has a good grounding on where the character comes from and how he relates to our world.I have alway been a huge fan of the Dick Donner Superman film made in 1978. To me it is the greatest of all superhero films. I t is epic and the effects still hold up today. I must say that I was glad to see that Singer didn't decide to make a remake, but just continue to build on the first two classic films. Christopher Reeve has always been the quintessential Superman, but I have to admit, that despite my initial disdain for for the casting of Brandon Routh, he is a close second. The sincerity that he showed was excellent and I was very impressed with his acting ability.Kate Bosworth was a better Lois Lane to me than Margot Kidder with all due respect. One; she is ten time better looking, and two; I think she really had a grip on the character from the comics book.Kevin Spacey was ideal as Lex Luthor. The simultaneous wit and pure evil was well communicated and funny.The special effects were some of the best that I have seen in a long time. I read some of these other reviews and I think judging the scientific plausibility of some of these sequences is plain ludicrous. It's a movie for God's sakes!!! Another subtle thing that I like was how this movie sort of blended with Batman Begins. I think a "World's Finest" movie could be awesome. Christian Bale and Brandon Routh seem like they will play off each other well.The story of the film avoided a lot of common clichés which I was happy to see. The score was astounding and it was an overall fun and uplifting movie that was true to it's film and comic book predecessors. Well done Mr. Singer and Mr. Routh!

Bryan Singer's "Superman Returns" is an outstanding movie. It brought me back to 1978 where I viewed Richard Donner's original for the very first time. My problem with Donner's film is that it became too campy in scenes regarding Lex Luther. Kevin Spacey's Lex Luther is a worthy adversary for the Man of Steel. He's a darker foe and much more menacing."Superman Returns" could have been better with tighter editing. There were moments during the movie when I said to myself: "OK, get on with it." However, when the movie works it simply explodes! 'Superman Returns" deals with a hero who could never be a part of us. He will always be an outsider. Consider Jor-El's tacit warning: "Even though you've been raised as a human, you are not one of them." This is a story about dealing with rejection and burdensome responsibility.Yes, Brandon Routh brings back memories of Christopher Reeve. It was bound to happen and Routh does an exceptional job. However, the story adds a needed element and that is mystery. Do we really know Superman; this strange visitor from another planet?

Review Title: considering the wait it should have been so much more
Review: Lavish but meandering comic book adaptation from X-Men director Bryan Singer. Having been on his home planet and spent years away from Earth, the heroic man of steel Superman and his alter ago Clark Kent return to thwart the plan of an evil megalomaniac (Spacey), but more importantly to try and reclaim the love of former girlfriend and co-worker Lois Lane (Bosworth). Unbeknownst to him, she's already moved on with her life and his return only exacerbates the situation. Highly anticipated to be sure, especially given director Singer's recent track record, but this bland and expositionless saga offers little beyond elaborate special effects; action scenes really fall short in excitement, the two leads fail to generate any real chemistry, and star Routh's "performance" is anemic. Co-star Bosworth is unremarkable as his love interest, and the ever-impressive Spacey adds little to the proceedings as the vile and eccentric Lex Luthor. May entertain kids, but lacks the vitality, imagination, and breath of fresh air quality that it so desperately needs. **

Review Title: Special effects great, script and acting mediocre
Review: Okay, so this is a bad choice to see after the witty dialogue of The Devil Wears Prada, but is it too much to ask for a Superman movie to have witty dialogue and subtle acting as well as incredible special effects? You have to suspend all disbelief to avoid getting annoyed. And I'm someone who in childhood, with change jangling in my pocket, waited at the newsstand for the newest Superman comics to be delivered on Tuesdays and Thursdays.Brandon Routh has the air of an Eagle Scout, but no depth, as Superman. Kate Bosworth is a bit more nuanced as Lois Lane. Kevin Spacey is a characturized bad guy, as he should be.The special effects are perfect for big and loud Imax.

It is amazing that the through the years that the superman genre keeps getting stronger each time. Kirk Alyn first adorned the outfit in the superman serials in the 40's, then came George Reeves in The Adventures Of Superman(1952-1958), The late 1970's came 24 year old Christopher Reeve to wear the suit in the big budgeted Superman feature film, and would later reprise that role in three more sequels. The late 80's came the hit show Superboy(1988-1992), first played by John Newton, and later by Gerard Christopher. Then Dean Cain would donn the tights, in Lois and Clark:The New Adventures Of Superman(1993-1997). In 2001 came the hit show Smallville, the show that reflected on Supermans teenage years before the costume, played by Tom Welling, and it is still going strong.Now its 2006, and newcomer Brandon Routh Donn's the outfit as The man of steel. Superman returns to earth after five years away, as reclaims his old job as a reporter, and finds Lois Lane is engaged and has a kid from a previous marriage. Lois has mixed reactions about seeing him again. But Lex Luther has a crazy plan of his own.This film tries to bring back to the magic, that made the first Superman a hit. Brandon Routh doesn't do an imitation of Christopher Reeve, but plays Superman/Clark Kent at the same level that Reeve played it. Kate Bosworth was great as Lois Lane, but she did not have quite the quirkiness that Margot Kidder had. Kevin Spacey as Lex Luther was well played, more demented, not humorers this time. It has awesome effects, it is very well directed by Bryan Singer. So viewers go out and see it before it flies away.

For anyone who thinks that a 'comic book' character must, necessarily, be drawn in the most shallow respects imaginable, when brought to the screen, I have one word for you... Batman.There's a 'tradition' in Hollywood whereby a writer, called in to 'fix' some out-of-control picture, decides to bail out, and, assuming he/she has the Agent, the cash, and the 'pull', can actually have their names withdrawn from the so-called credits. It's not nearly as simple as all that for an actor wishing to slip out the back door, of course, given that their faces and voices are recognizable...and with that I offer my heartfelt condolences to Kevin Spacey and Frank Langella. With "Superman Returns" in his filmography, Mr. Spacey has probably single-handedly prevented any fisticuffs in arty film classes over arguments regarding his worst film ever. Thank you, Mr. Spacey.As for the fellow in the title role; anyone who thinks this guy is an actor, in the technical sense, must also be eagerly awaiting the handing of the Academy Award to one of those gay jocks in the Gillette razor commercials. It could happen, sure...The dialogue is a fine piece of work, and was obviously out-sourced to George Lucas, a fellow who has proved he knows nothing about the human species, nor its attempts to communicate. Tough luck for the 'nominal' writers, though, but, that's what happens when you don't have the clout to withdraw unobtrusively from a bomb under construction.From the over-wrought soundtrack, through the poorly-developed subplots, to the waste of celluloid over the Lois & Clark 'issue', which nobody cares about, anyway... it just has first-one-off-the-cliffs-of-Summer, written all over it, from end-to-end.Avoid.

Review Title: Superman Returns, but maybe he shouldn't have...

Review: SUPERMAN THE MOVIE with Christopher Reeve is a better movie...Yes the Special Effects are not nearly as good...Though for it's day it looked amazing. This Superman is deeper, more cerebral, more sophisticated. It is beautiful to look at and wonderful to behold. SUPERMAN RETURNS is what going to the movies is supposed to be. An entertaining, captivating two and half hours that leaves you wanting more. Bryan Singer is to be commended. He has truly outdone himself. And the casting? Top notch. Brandon Routh was a truly wonderful SUPERMAN/Clark Kent. He brought exactly what Christopher Reeve brought to the role. Seriousness. Believability. Honesty. Kate Bosworth, who never really caught my eye as an actress shows that shes the real deal here. Her Lois Lane is different than Margot Kidder, with the same frailties and spelling problems. Not to mention the chemistry she and Brandon Routh had together. Pure magic. The relationship, the longing between the two, really worked. And her being torn between SUPERMAN and her new fiancé...Fantastic. As Lex Luthor, Kevin Spacey does a fine job, not really as BIG as Gene Hackman's performance, and that may be due to the fact that they really didn't give him enough to do. I thought the subplot with Lex Luthor needed more development. We needed to see more of the irony of Luthor being out because of SUPERMAN's disappearance for five years. The Luthor subplot was merely okay, but could have been brought out and developed further. What this film was really about is the same thing that Bryan Singer fleshed out in his two X-MEN movies. The feeling of alienation. This SUPERMAN is more aware that he is, for all intents and purposes, alone in this world. He is the last one of his kind and it really hits home with him this time around, to beautiful effect I might add. He is caught between being who he is and wanting to be normal, what ever that is. And Brandon Routh does a beautiful job conveying that message. Overall this film is worth seeing more than once, I've already seen it twice and loved it more the second time around. It's truly epic film making.

Review Title: To those who thought it was awful...
Review: Yes, this movie was a disappointment in the sense that it did not compare to the old Superman movies; but that's the same mentality as people who don't watch remakes because it'll never be as good as the classics.Anyways, this movie wasn't as good as it could have been. Besides Brandon Routh, I disagree with most of the casting. Kevin Spacey did alright as Lex Luthor only because he's a good actor, but it could have been so much better.The main problem with this movie was it didn't grab my attention. The overall plot wasn't too interesting, but the actions scenes (which were rare) were fun to watch. It could also be because this was supposed to be more of a chick-flick...To sum up, this movie would be a 6.5, but I rounded up.And for the idiots, who voted "1," you're basically saying this movie was equivalent (or worse) than "Glitter"? If you are, then how can anything that you post hold any value?

I was hoping this would be the blockbuster hit of this summer, and it began that way, but the plot has too many holes in it. This movie which should have been the action movie we expected it to be whimpered and became a soap opera in disguise. I have always loved and respected the Man of Steel and his associates, but this left me feeling I had been used as a ticket stub. Most of us remember the "War of The Worlds" which should have been truly great with the amount of PR and money that went into it, well Superman Returns should be compared to that one. By the way, I wonder if James Marsden really thinks he traded up from Cyclops to another third person in a love triangle. You mean Wolverine was too much for him?

Review Title: Looks like Superman did not Return
Review: The movie left me totally cold. I hated the story and thought there were way too many characters which took away time for development of the real characters. I mean why did Martha Kent show up at all? Langella's Perry White could have had bite, but was relegated to the background for the most part. I won't put any spoilers in, but the plot twists were just too ridiculous. The movie also went too far trying to pay homage to Chris Reeve. At times, I thought I was watching scenes from Superman 1 being redone. Come on, Mr. Singer, after the X-Men I really thought you and your writers would deliver more than this maudlin attempt to copy the first movie. In fact, at times Mr. Routh's resemblance to Chris distracted me from the movie. It was kind of creepy. I felt that Bosworth's Lois was weak. Kevin Costner could have done a better job as Lois than Bosworth. I did love Spacey as a darker more violent Luthor, but Kitty his new sidekick could have been played by an Ewok. None of the excitement and sex appeal of Ms. Tessmacher or the bumbling Otis's chemistry with Lex was apparent. One or two bright spots are in this flick, but overall it will appeal to the starry eyed fans of the franchise, which I used to count myself as one, more than to a more discriminating viewer. Bryan Singer disappoints in this poorly written movie, with wooden performances from Bosworth and poor character development. The effects were decent, but the deviation from the Superman canon at times was not well thought out. I would say more, but that would include spoilers.

We saw it today on July 4th and thought it was great. Sad, happy, exciting, it had everything! Hooray for the red, white and blue.I don't want to say too much... Its hard to talk about the plot without giving something away. I say give it a 9 instead of a ten and Only because I wanted it to go on longer!Can't wait for the inevitable sequel.I think they were so smart in casting this kid.
