Review Title: A virtuoso American masterpiece of cinema
Review: Last year I saw Terrence Malick's "The New World", and after seeing it, I felt like I had experienced a wave of euphoria, having experienced one of the most breathtaking visual feasts with a deeply resonating emotional core that I have ever seen. Last week, I saw Superman Returns and was equally stricken by it's use of rich imagery and metaphor to take me to a place of unimaginable life, on the silver screen. While some make take aim at Superman's running time and slower character-centric pace, I find that is what movies are, and should be about. At it's heart, Superman is still the everyman immigrant, he is every one of us. He represents something, and through all that has changed since Superman has left us on film, this return is the juggernaut it needed to be. It is not only a slice of American pop culture, but a piece of fine art to behold and witness. It's beautiful grace enveloped me, the visual effects were seamless and the character points and arcs were dealt with extreme care. The moments in which Superman is feeling and thinking and reacting are truly one's of cinematic history. No longer is Superman just a comic book adaptation or a film, he is a symbol, and what he symbolizes here is the resurrection of the Phoenix, the life and death of Siegfried, and Jesus Christ. If you are looking for a no-hold's barred action film, this isn't for you. Go watch Bad Boys II, which is, in all due respects, a wonderful action/exploitation film with unrelenting action sequences. If you want a thoughtful story with some awesome action pieces that resonate with the characters and visual that go above and beyond anything we have ever seen, Superman Returns is for you. The acting is top notch, the plot is tremendous and the meaning is all there. Every action taken has meaning and impact. If you see one superhero film, make it Superman Returns.

Review Title: Great SFX, and not much else

Review: This movie blew away my expectations. I would not consider myself a huge fan of the old Superman movies although I have seen them all multiple times. They were good for their time and the first one captivated audiences by making them believe "a man could fly". Bryan Singer did a fantastic job directing and writing and producing this movie. The characters were perfectly cast. I wasn't so sure about Kate Bosworth going into it, but she was an excellent Lois Lane. She was headstrong, driven, great at her job and still managed to show how hurt she was that Superman had left unexpectedly. Kevin Spacey IS Lex Luther. Lex is brilliant, mean, loves irony, and has a perverse sense humor... which pretty much describes Kevin Spacey. It seems though that Bryan Singer gave James Marsden exactly the some role in this as he did in X-Men: he was one of two men torn over the same woman. This movie has without a doubt made Brandon Routh's career. His portrayal of Superman was great. In some scenes you could tell they deliberately were trying to remind you of Christopher Reeve, but in every other scene, Brandon Routh stood on his own. He put much more emotion into his part making Superman more believable as an alien-raised-by-humans-turned-superhero than Christopher Reeve ever did. I would say a 5 out of 5 on the "re-watchability" scale.

Review Title: What in the name of flying hell is the point of an action movie, if the hero is INVINCIBLE?
Review: Routh had NO EMOTIONAL PERFORMANCE whatsoever. The acting was horrible, and also... it's 2006! Men (even superheros) aren't supposed to wear red man-thongs over skin tight panties... Another point... WHY SUPERMAN? WHY? What is the point of a movie about 'the man of Steel' if he has 1. Super Strength 2. He can Fly... with a cape (WTF, how does that work) 3. He is invincible...What is the point of seeing an action movie, if the hero CANNOT be hurt? I say WTF. This movie is a total steaming piece of crap. I give it a one.Superman Returns: The absolutely retarded pointless flop of the summer!

Review Title: Singer Succeeds Again in Surprising Me
Review: I have become so bored by all of the action movies (actually most films in general) which, in the end, are all clones of each other in style, pacing, plotting, humor, acting style,etc and end up boring me to tears. Superman Returns stands out from the pack primarily because I didn't feel like I had seen this movie 10 times before even though the film does a nice job of continuing from the original. It also proved you could have an entertaining action movie without a constant 2 hours of explosions and unimaginative visual overload (I'm talking to you George Lucas).Each of Bryan Singer's films have a distinct flavor. He is able to be over the top without becoming a joke. He actually develops themes and ties them to imagery and plot and does it in a straightforward way. His films are totally accessible without being stupid. His big budget blockbusters still retain a homemade or independent feeling rather than being overblown overindulgent exhausting monsters (compare X-Men II to X-Men 3 for instance). Singer's signature is in the details...his slightly odd casting choices, his avoidance of schlocky pandering and his ability to work in a genre but not succumb to all of its cliché's and formulas, his success in getting a plot point across without feeling the need to beat you over the head 15 times. All this makes him possibly the best mainstream director working today.I'm sick of being assaulted and insulted when I go to the movies. Most big budget directors don't know the difference between dazzling an audience and crapping all over them (I'm talking to you Michael Bay!). I love Singer's movies because they respect the audience. The film is by no means perfect but it is a cut above the rest. Solid film-making. Just don't go in there expecting Superman to jump a jetski over a train while a "Don't your wish your girlfriend was Hot like me" remix plays.

Review Title: An Iconic Figure Presents a Taste of Something Different
Good Ole' Blue, Red, and Yellow
Review: Nice to see a beloved character back who has been away from the big screen for far too long. It's just such a shame so many of the cynics are determined to give Supe such a bitter reception. I really don't get that. These cynics just don't want to believe in a man who can fly and everything that comes with such a well-known comic character. Yes Supe definitely does come with his share of baggage but the key is too forget all about that. This latest installment is not a "restart" or a "redo" it is a "return". Superman comes back with lots of unanswered questions. Are they all going to be answered in this first film of the resurrected franchise? Of course not. That's why we have something called sequels. There are many excellent scenes showing Superman's vulnerable side as he tries to reconnect with this cynical world known as Earth and of course the love of his life, Lois Lane who has found herself a new man and a new life. There is great stuff here but don't go into this film trying to connect the dots with the previous Superman films. This is definitely not a sequel in the conventional sense but loosely continuing where Superman II left off. There is plenty of unexpected twists which I won't give away that is introduced to lead into the sequels.

The movie was very dull so I walked out about 40 minutes after the movie began. Some points to note from the first 40 minutes or so: When the plane landed in the baseball field and people got out of the plane, I don't think that it was a natural reaction the baseball crowd gave the people who got out of the plane (a joyful cheer). Something more realistic would be a cheer but not with the amount of joy the crowd gave it.Superman was a terrible actor (at least as Clark Kent). His face looked strange for Superman and he couldn't act as Clark Kent. He barely said anything.The Lex Luthor stuff in the beginning was boring and unclear.What a waste of a movie.

Review Title: Superman the Movie is still Superior.

Review: Great dazzling special effect scenes, character development with real depth, and an examination of a world that forgot about Superman. I really felt for Superman's dilemma. The feeling of isolation and loneliness and how to fit into a world that learned to live without him especially Lois Lane was heartbreaking. For those of you who were huge fans of the original 1978 Superman film like I was and the second Superman movie, you will find a few charming nods to those throughout. I won't give anything away but there is also a new surprise in the Superman/Lois love affair. It will leave you hanging but in a good way. Yes the movie is more than two hours long but I didn't think it hurt the film at all.

Review Title: Why this film is not a  two-hour snooze.
Review: Because the overly intrusive sound effects keep everyone awake. What a boring,fastidious, stupid, predictable, cliché-ridden, poorly-casted and acted film.I went to see the film a bit out of curiosity because I wondered how someone could make an interesting movie out of such an implausible character. After all, it had been done with Batman. Well, they couldn't,it turns out. They did not even try.I was also misled by the positive ratings the film received from reviewers. Whose judgement can one trust these days...?The film is a sequence of one ridiculous scene after another with no attempt at all to create any kind of internal logic. I am ready to suspend disbelief and go along with certain outlandish topics but only on the condition that there is some effort to establish a bit of logic between the elements of the storyline.Add to this the fact that the characters are nothing more than cardboard cut-outs reciting their lines.It is to be feared that the availability of computer software to create "dazzling" images of crashing planes and earth-moving tremors may spell the end of good cinema. Why bother with intelligent story lines and well-crafted screen plays when all you need to entertain are a few buttons to create monstrous scenes of destruction or pandemonium? It seems that movie goers are at the mercy of studios directed by people whose purpose in life is to collect as much money as possible from 12 year-olds !

In an era when movie makers are bent on reinventing and reimagining their superheroes and stories to match the tastes they themselves invented, there's one director out there who keeps true to the original content, and his name is Bryan Singer.Right from the beginning of the movie, with John Williams' original score triumphantly playing over the decidedly old fashioned opening credits, it's clear that Singer had no intention of changing the universe that the original Superman movies created. Sometimes reinvention is a good thing, if a universe or character gets stale. Such was the excuse for Batman Begins, with the franchise needing a fresh makeover after the disastrous last 2 installments directed by Joel Schumacher. But if you keep changing the universe in which a character that you're supposed to sympathize and connect with dwells, it tampers with the continuity of the franchise and you have to keep reconnecting with the character and its universe. That wasn't a problem in Superman Returns, because the director chose to make it a nonissue.There's no revenge driven plot, no gritty fight scenes meant to portray a darker side of the hero. There's just an old-fashioned values driven story, something that's become something of a rarity as of late. Although it's a feeling of something from the past, it almost feels refreshingly new.Brandon Routh does a very good Superman, very reminiscent of Christopher Reeves' interpretation. Kevin Spacey shines as Lex Luthor. Personally, I enjoyed his performance better than Gene Hackman's in the original.This was the feel good movie of the summer for me. In a superhero movie, you want the audience to leave the theater wishing that they could be a part of the universe of their hero, or that the hero could come be a part of theirs. I definitely felt that way after watching it. Because they didn't reinvent everything, I didn't feel like I had to reacquaint myself with Superman. He'd been gone for 5 years, much like the franchise has been gone for several, and the world missed him. I certainly look forward to his return.

Review Title: Good, but writing could have been better
Review: As a fan of Superman since the original TV show and having copies of all the Superman Movies, I went and saw Superman Returns.I did like the fact that it ignored the 3rd and 4th movies as they didn't really provide much to the saga and were pretty cheesy. The first and second were the best and this took it from there. I did find that the story was good and in fact a good love story.I did not find it quite as good as anticipated however. One of the things I liked about the character of the first two is not only did Superman have all his physical abilities he also had high intelligence and more importantly for his character, he had a lot of wisdom. Although Brandon did a fine job of acting out the character, I don't know how much input he had, but this superman lacked the same wisdom. His actions and the way he phrased his thoughts in one scene had the tone of being high and mighty. Of course he is high and mighty the previous superman was more humble about it. His way of dealing with the peoples response to his first big rescue since his return I found too egotistical for my taste. Perhaps because he had been away for a while and had not experienced it for some time, but I felt it went on longer than needed and I found it distasteful, or at least tacky.I didn't mind too much Lex Luther's scheme being so similar to the first movie, but did he have to take so much dialog to repeat from the first movie. Perhaps this was to benefit those who had not seen the first movie but I found it repetitious.I had read they would be using the footage of Marlon Brandon as Jor-El from the archive footage, but was hoping they would show some that had not been seen in the first movie. The collectors edition DVD of the first at least had that, was hoping they would include more in this one. Perhaps the DVD of this will have more. Or more will be shown in upcoming sequels.What I did like, that I've heard a lot of complaints about was the lack of action. Can anyone just sit back and enjoy a nice story for a change instead of constantly have non-stop action? They did have awesome special effects although I think I would have preferred more "Green screen" with the actual Brandon instead of so much computer generation of him. The CGI is really good these days and very good with photorealism, but common, we CAN tell the difference, but that's just a minor complaint. For the most part the special effects were great. What they did with the machine gun firing at him was probably the biggest hight of the SE team. The way they ended that with the the bullet falling to the ground was not only well done, but very humorous, if you can imagine a scene like that being funny.The story had some very neat twists regarding Lois's son and I look forward to what they do with that later. In fact I look forward to the next movie.My complaints aside I do recommend seeing this movie as it is good and very much worth seeing. I will get the DVD and hopefully there will be lots of bonus features as I'm sure there is plenty of material for them. But prepare to sit back, relax and enjoy it.

I must say first off before anything, Superman is one of the or maybe the greatest super hero of all super heroes. And with this film will continue his legacy. I enjoyed the movie very much and look forward to the sequels.Brandon Routh in my point of view played the role of Superman/ Clark Kent well. Don't get me wrong there will never be another Christopher Reeve, but he wasn't bad neither. At some points he kept with how Reeve's played Superman and kinda felt as if it was Reeve's.Maybe when it came to Lois Lane, they could have chose a better person but Kate Bosworth was "ok". We also have to except that it's not going to be the same as the original Superman.Kevin Spacey was great as Lex Luthor. He kept the darkness of the villain but was also comical at times. In the original Superman, Lex was more comical than serious. Which now it makes more sense to be serious, for the story to be more appealing. Now then in 1978 people like to know more about the story then it being comical, but that's just my opinion.The story is a bit confusing, but it made sense in the long run. Singer tried really hard to keep the feel as the original, but with his own ideas as well. The story is about the same as Richard Donner's plot but not totally which kept it interesting. The only thing I felt it lacked was about his childhood. Being that this is the first of few it should have shown more about his youth.All in all.. I feel that Superman Returns, was great and fits in with the super hero movies of this day an age. Also helps to continue into the story of Superman. Now the only thing that's left is if there are sequels.. will it be about Doomsday? Now that would be interesting, for those REAL Superman fans!!

I don't know where to begin! The beginning credits gave me a chill that still won't go away! Totally amazing! Rouths performance is absolute stunningly well portrayed. His Clark Kent is one of the funniest I've ever seen yet still isn't half a clumsy as Reeve was. This is great! A reporter for a great Metropolitan Newspaper cant be clumsy! His Superman rivals that of Reeve and at times surpasses him. Absolutely perfectly played. Strong silent Superman who just glows of goodness as Superman should do. Outstanding! Bossworth plays Lois Lanes role to a tee. Nowhere do I even doubt her age, looks or any of that. Amazing! Spacey... wow! I knew Singer did well in using him as Luthor. He IS Lex Luthor. I got chills when he beat up Superman. Cold, manipulative, cunning, evil. A Lex Luthor through and through! The Graphics were off the chart. I even had problems seeing the difference between CGI and real life at times.I can't go into detail as there are SO many elements that I wanted to talk about that were very well done.Music: I've heard the music beforehand and I must say it fit very well with the story. Especially where the Luthor theme transforms somewhat into the Superman theme in the latter part... Well done Ottman! Gripes My gripes with this movie can be cut down to one word... editing.Not in how the scenes displayed where done but what was left out.At times (especially in the beginning) I felt the editing knife had been used to much. I wanted to see more of Young Clark, some of the Krypton exploration, Clarks talks with his mother, more dialog from the villains, even Ben should have more dialog (!) I really hope most of the cut elements will be available on the Special edition DVD come November.I know Singer had to cut a lot seeing as the movie is 2.5 hours at it is, but the fanboy in me would still like to see a 3.5 hour long movie with all those elements intact!

Review Title: Solid restart and a great all-around film
Review: A worthy return for the Man of Steel. While not the comic book masterpiece that the original was, it is a great restart for the franchise and a pretty good film. Bryan Singer certainly loves the character of Superman, and especially the original film, as this one is chocked full of references and homages to it. The biggest problem with the film is the pacing - it drags far too much at times, and the ending is far too long. Cutting around 30 minutes would've done this film wonders. Still, it's very involving and entertaining, with great action, comedy, romance, and drama - it's got it all. Very well done.The general story itself is well executed, but parts of the plot (especially Lex's plan) are completely without logic or plausibility. But the whole idea with Superman returning, and the world learning to live without him, was quite interesting. The acting I was quite worried about going in, but it was one of the stronger points of the film. Routh was great, he embodied the character well without imitating Reeve. He really made it his own. I felt he was much better as Clark, however, and the film could've used more of him to balance all the seriousness and action. Bosworth was surprisingly good as Lois, bringing a new element to the character. Spacey was excellent as Lex, expectedly. He didn't ever overact or become silly - had just the right mix of evil and humour. No one else really stood out, but I didn't find anyone overtly annoying - not even Posey or the kid. I am glad they didn't make Marsden a jerk - made the love triangle more believable. On the whole, very good acting.The action is quite good, but there wasn't nearly enough of it. Too much melodrama and not enough plot development plagued parts of the beginning, but it cleared up and the film rolled along nicely. The climax could've have been a bit better built up, and not followed by even more melodrama, to further tighten up the story. The production design was quite good, as were the visual effects - not as obviously stunning as some other films, but very well done. In fact, all of the technical aspects of the film were solid - the shots were staged beautifully, and some of the wipes/dissolves were nicely used. The music was an excellent adaptation of the original score, and the opening credits sequence - incorporating the classic theme - was a nice nod to the original. And Singer's direction was fantastic - it's obvious he really loves the character of Superman.Overall, quite a good comic book adaptation - not as good as Batman Begins or Singer's own X-Men films, but certainly better than Spider-Man, Hulk, Fantastic Four, and the like. The plot could've used some work, the pacing was terrible at times, and the running time needed to be about 30 minutes shorter, but other than that, it was a solid film. Nothing that's going to win any awards, but very involving and entertaining, with well-staged action, comedy that felt natural, and a sufficient amount of romantic drama to balance it out. A well put together film.

I think the actor for superman did not appear old enough to fit the time line of the script. He looked only about 19 to me although I see now that he is a bit older. Also I found that Lois wasn't what I expected based on the first two Christopher Reeves movies. Lois didn't seem as spunky and vibrant as I thought she should. Maybe my expectations were off but they caused me to be disappointed. The story and the action scenes were good in my opinion. However, I would have gone with a different villain. Lex had already been done enough. Basically I got tired of being reminded of the Christopher Reeves movies and feeling that the actors in this movie didn't meet my expectations.

I was never looking forward to seeing this movie. The only Superman movie I have ever liked was the first and I had a bad feeling this would be disappointing. To my pleasant surprise this was extremely enjoyable. The acting was great, especially from Kevin Spacey and Parker Posey. The action was intense and most of the CGI was good.After a long visit to his home planet (Krypton) Superman (Brandon Routh) returns to earth to once again save the day as Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) is planning to create a new continent, which involves sinking half of the USA.Many people have been very harsh towards this movie. Although there are flaws (which action movie doesn't), it is still highly enjoyable popcorn fun. I though Routh's portrayal of Superman/Clarke Kent was fine and not an insult to Christopher Reeve. Kate Bosworth is great as Lois Lane, although Margot Kidder will always be the best. Kevin Spacey was his usual brilliant self and Parkey Posey was hilarious and great as Kitty. The look of the film is fantastic and most of the time the CGI was believable. This is a solid flick that should be enjoyed by most fans of action or just a mindless popcorn flick!3½/5.

Well, this movie was just terrible. We sat down last night to watch the return of Superman, and was awaiting some nice action scenes battling bat villains. However, what we get is over 2 hours with small talk - and a few glimpses of action.Hoe can Hollywood create a "summer blockbuster" where nothing happens? Seeing superman flying in the air isn't supposed to be action...Sure if you like dialog and slow pace this movie is for you, after all the movie has at the moment an overall of 7.5 in the ratings while I gave it a 2.People are obviously different!

I just saw the new Superman movie and I have to say that I am very satisfied with it. I have read same critics and I don't agree that it's bad.First of all I loved the idea that they ignored Superman III and IV, because those 2 films are same of the worst sequels I have ever seen ( my personal favorite of the series is Superman II ).I agree that no actor will ever replace Christopher Reeves and he will always remain Superman for me. But , let's face it , Brandon Routh isn't all that bad. He certainly looks like Reeves and has a very similar voice. He isn't a bad actor , so I do believe he was a good choice. Kevin Spacey is great as Lex Lutor . I never particularly loved Gine Hackman in that role (although I lake Hackman ). The only disappointment in the acting department is Kate Bosworth and not because she is bad ( she's quite good ) but because she seems little to young for the role , especially having a 5-6 year old son . She looks lake she can't be a day over 22 , maybe 23. The film has great special effects , but that is no real surprise . I really loved the flying, it does look very real . Another thing I really loved was all those references to the original films . First the opening credits are identical to the first movie , than the use of the original music score , appearance of the late Marlon Brando and many more details .All in all , I liked this movie and I think all people should see it . All I can say for the end , I can't wait for the sequel !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!If I have to rate it I would give it 8 out of 10.

Review Title: vulnerability and curly lock of hair...
Review: I have one thing to say about this film...Superman is made human in this film...It's the thing that I really liked about this film..How Lex and his cronies beat the hell out of The Man of Steel...I mean, Superman was really hurt and helpless with all the "green meteor rocks" around...I just got irritated with his curly thing in his hair!!I mean,when he was in the hospital bed after being stabbed with a made-up "green meteor rock" knife, you'd expect him to be all messy or something! His curly lock of hair was still there!! Very unharmed!! Even in serious or heroic moments, I find myself laughing at his curly lock of hair which seems to weather all conditions..it's quite absurd,really...I'm also surprised at how old Martha is in this film! I'm also surprised as to how Lex Luthor gains money... I definitely think Michael Rosenbaum in Smallville is the best! acting wise and looks and everything.. He is the ultimate persona of Lex Luthor! James Marsden is again the OTHER guy(means he is not preferred to end up with the lead actress)...I have noticed this in 3 films of his already... X-MEN series, the notebook and superman returns... what is it with him and being the other guy of the lead lady? But I guess people should watch this just to have something to talk about. And this film is just a prologue for the next one.Oh yeah, their(Superman and Lois') son is just the most adorable thing!! he is so cute!! I really thought he's Macaulay Culkin's brother.. He is so cute, I just want to crush him in a hug!

Review Title: Let's hope he hangs around a while...

Review: I have no idea why people are raving about this movie. While a big step up from earlier attempts in the Superman franchise, this plot has holes big enough to drive your pet blue whale through.. While it is definitely not easy to write a script for a Superman story considering his lack of vulnerabilities, they could have come up with something a little more interesting.The acting is generally just about par and the effects aren't really that impressive either. I did however think that Brandon Routh did a decent job, albeit he hardly got to say much.That said, kids < 16 years old will probably enjoy the movie. For the rest, this is just mindless entertainment.All in all 5/10.

I saw the movie, loved it and I would highly recommend it to others.For every person who is ripping apart this movie as 'not good' for its non-technical believability, GET A LIFE. Superman movies, as with the Batman and Spiderman ones, are entertainment, not docudramas.Superman if filled with excitement, great special effects and solid acting. Enjoy the movie for its two hours, come away feeling a little happier and relax more.In addition, people need to stop comparing Routh to Reeves. Each actor gives their own rendition to a certain character. I've sure heard a lot of people bad mouthing the other Superman movies to all of a sudden be singing the praises of those actors that they've condemned in the past.I give Superman four out of five stars.

Review Title: I was disappointed - and I am NOT  a fan boy

Review: WOW their was no dull moments in this movie, and the parts that got kind of slow they were very entertaining. i really wasn't a fan of superman until now, like i thought he was to gocky with all his powers! but this one showed un like the other superman's it showed the weakness he has towards people, and it showed how the most powerful superhero ever created by DC comics can be defeated by a Meir human. every other superhero has big bad villains this villain is just way smart and uses mind over matter. and their has never been a more greater risk toward the end. sure spider-man had that big sun thing pulling all the medal and crap but this was crazy!and the end didn't quite stop when you thought it would, but it didn't drag on. so i really enjoyed this movie I enjoy all of Bryan singers movies. Hes a brilliant director, hopefully one day ill be able to be his special effects supervisor for one of his movies.

Review Title: An enjoyable renewal of the franchise
Review: First up, Superman Returns is a very faithful continuation of the original series. I choose that phrase carefully. Superman here is not reinvented (like Bale's Batman) nor parodied (Clooney's). He follows in the footsteps of Reeve's big screen original.The opening titles - done in the style of the original but improved through CGI are a wonderful blend of retro nostalgia and future technology. It's all very pleasing... You get the goosebumps from awakening the childhood memory plus the satisfaction of a modern day CGI trip well done.Seeded throughout the film are little production design details that hark back to the Reeve era. The pointy spaceship that takes superman from Krypton... The palace of crystals and there's even a cast member from the past. As a viewer you feel very connected to the story, first hand from the screen in front of you and viscerally from the memories of the original. It all feels right.A lot's been said about "Unknown Brandon Routh" in the title role. I seem to recall that Christopher Reeve was an unknown before he landed the role of Superman. Routh turns in an excellent performance. His Clark Kent is a close facsimile of Reeve's. But he makes Superman his own. Herein lies the first shadow. Routh gets to show his physical vulnerability when there's Krypton around but I didn't see much emotional vulnerability at all in the 154 minutes. Yes there is back story between him and Lois but I the man of steel didn't bear his heart. He is however a talented actor, easy on the eye and possessed of the sort of heroic modesty that makes him a very enjoyable watch.The real disappointment for me was Kate Bosworth's Lois Lane. This Lois is rather pretty, rather shallow rather successful and rather distracted. And I think it's the "rather" in all of these which is the real Achilles heel. The performance just lacks commitment and gusto. Whatever you thought of Margot Kidder, she gave a convincingly emotional performance. I've no doubt it's terribly difficult carving out a defined niche as the protagonist's love interest, but I just wasn't engaged by Bosworth's "successful career woman-mother". She had no drive.Kevin Spacey's Lex Luthor inhabits the antagonist with grim driven determination. He's meaner and less camp than Hackman's original but lacking a foil like Hackman's Otis (Ned Beatty). He does however have his very own Miss Teschmacher in Kitty Kowalski (Parker Posey). He has some great lines, some great visual jokes, the kids will want to Boo him and if I had one criticism about his evil plans, they're just not quite evil enough. His world conquering plan was just a little bit "Dr. Evil" for me.The essential plot will be familiar to all those who remember the originals. I'm not going to give anything away. It's watchable, enjoyable and doesn't get our superhero doing anything that jars with our recollection of his character from the time before.The script is snappy and very contemporary. It has plenty of dialogue and visual jokes to amuse both the adults and the kids. The characters are given appropriate, amusing and engaging things to do and say. One of the biggest chuckles came from a very new take on the infamous "it's a bird, it's a plane". You'll know it when you've got there. Very very well done.The closing credits pay tribute to Christopher and Dana Reeve "with love and respect". And you know what, that captures the mood of the whole film perfectly.10/10 minus 2 for Bosworth's Lane and lack of emotional depth. This new franchise will continue and I will be looking forward to it.

Review Title: why superman should not have returned!!!  SPOILER ALERT!!!
Great Film for the Whole Family

Review: First of all, let me say this version was by far better than the previous versions of incarnations of Superman. Secondly - it's still a chick flick. If you were expecting something of the caliber of Spider-Man or the X-Men, you will be sorely disappointed. Special effects were much improved. The confrontation between Lex and Supes made the rest of the movie almost worthwhile. But at its core - it was still a chick flick. We won't even get into the incredibly glaring plot holes. If you were a fan of the original 3 or 4 flicks, this one is a step up. If you are a comic fan and enjoyed Spidey and X-Men, you'll wish you would have leaped over this flick in a single bound...

Review Title: Spiderman, Batman, Xmen will never have the elegance, style, charm, gracefulness, humility, awe inspiring feeling that is SUPERMAN
A very competent rendering of Superman
Review: When I heard that Superman Returns was about to be released, I went and watched the 1970's Superman. I was very disappointed, but probably because I had very high expectations graphically speaking (what with the Spider-Men, Batman Begins, Fantastic Four, X-Men). I was very reluctant to go see Superman Returns. But I must say, the director of this film has taken a very hard-to-portray super hero and instilled within him a sense of reality and darkness (a very subtle one, of course) that I failed to predict could be done. Superman was not goofy, and many times throughout the film, incredibly believable, providing you allow your imagination to guide you through the film. Critics of super-hero blockbusters will HATE it. Kevin Spacey plays a superb Luthor, far better than Hackman's slap-stick criminal. True, Spacey adds some humor to the role, as any good portrayer of Luthor should do, but he too incorporates a darkness that makes the film much more dramatic and eventually pulls you to the edge of the seat wondering what in the world, or worlds, is going to happen.

Superman Returns is a great summer film. Singer has done an incredible job bringing together all the amazingly complicated elements that go into blockbusters today without sacrificing the heart of the original Superman. Compared to the fairly enjoyable Pirates of the Caribbean sequel, Superman shows its strength. Of the two, Superman Returns is tighter and sharper and doesn't suffer from the as much self indulgentism that makes Pirates such a LONG wandering film.To enjoy the effort of the film even more I highly recommend the video pod cast released by Warner Brothers over the past year, titled "Bryan's journal." It follows Bryan and his crew throughout the film making process. Undoubtedly this "journal" will appear again on the DVD release, but check it out now while you can still appreciate the end result on the big screen!!

Review Title: Those who have seen the originals will be left expecting more and those who haven't will be unmoved.
The most action packed lifetime original family dram ever!!!

Review: Well its not really truly awful but compared to what it could of been and should have been - yes. Over 25 years since the definitive version and plenty of opportunity to evolve story lines and characters. Special effects barely workmanlike. Story ideas dismal and totally uninspired, a rehash of superman clichés and "been-there's" and "done-thats". Where was the Bryan Singer that made the X-men films? He sleep-walked through this. Laughs and chuckles, sly or otherwise?. Absent. The whole thing had a feel of a less then competent tribute to 80's disaster films. Everyone has their opinion and certainly most of the professional critics seem to like this picture but I cannot believe from their positive reviews that we saw the same film. Compare this turkey to the inventiveness, sheer exuberance, and witty dialogue of another summer movie like Pirates of the Caribbean 2. All good movies start with a great script and I've heard it said that if it ain't on the page it ain't on the screen. Someone certainly phoned home with this one.

If Batman can do it, why can't Superman? I'd have to guess that was the ideology behind actually making the return of Superman a reality. Sure, it has been in the works since what seems like the Crucifixion, but the push through the door had to have been the runaway success of Christopher Nolan's dark rebirth for the caped crusader. Hopefully, the same could be expected from the new Superman, unlike the camp the older films reduced themselves to. Unfortunately, Superman Returns doesn't have nearly the same quality as other recent comic books movies, running way too long and lacking any soul whatsoever.The movie isn't a reinvention of the series like Batman Begins was, but instead a direct continuation of the Christopher Reeve movies from the '80s. After visiting the ruins of his home planet Krypton, Superman (Routh) returns to Earth after a five year absence. He finds the world in pretty much the same state it was in before, and manages to get his job back at the Daily Planet as Clark Kent. The one change is that his eternal love, Lois Lane (Bosworth), is now a mother and a Pulitzer Prize winner for her article "Why the World Doesn't Need Superman." She is also long-time engaged to pilot Richard White (Marsden).Around the same time, Lex Luthor (Spacey) re-emerges after regaining a small fortune by marrying a dying widow. He then travels to the Fortress of Solitude and steals some crystals which can apparently create land. His evil scheme: to create a new continent and, in the process, drown the USA. It is now up to Superman to both stop Luthor and regain the love of Lois Lane.It isn't even worth going into how stupid Luthor's plan is. First and foremost, it is really vague as to how creating a new continent will gain him any capital. Maybe as a terrorist weapon, but the idea is so far-fetched that it doesn't seem likely. Secondly, the fact that there are crystals which create land is just so mind-bogglingly stupid that it takes you right out of the movie. Finally, the fact that Luthor avoided prison just because Superman couldn't make his court date is just stupid.The plot as a whole just doesn't really feel that important. The movie shortchanges Luthor to concentrate on the dynamic between Lois and Superman, making Superman out as a homewrecker, whisking Lois away from her presumably happy family. The sideplot involving Lois' child opens up a whole different batch of plot holes. The story never really manages to gain any interest because of a heavy dose of clichés and stupidity.At least some action would hopefully make up for the lack of plot, but the action really isn't all that great compared to other superhero movies. There isn't much of any fighting in the movie, so all the action is Superman saving people from various situations. Aside from a plane crash early in the movie, none of this is really all that exciting, as it is all too small-time for Superman. The plane crash is a very nice scene with some solid CGI, but the fact that the highlight of the film takes place roughly a half-hour into the movie makes the rest of the film quite boring.The main thing that makes the action boring is that there is never really a sense of danger. With characters like Batman or Spider-Man, we can feel their pain and with the X-Men it is always possible one of them could die. Superman is a seemingly invincible tank who can do just about anything and everything the writers can imagine, as long as he stays away from green rocks. Since the climax of the action occurs relatively early, we know that there is no danger of him failing simply because there is no way that Lois could be killed. Since Superman essentially can't die and we know that the writers won't kill off Lois, essentially all tension is gone from the movie.On the acting front, there are also many problems. Brandon Routh has a good look for Superman, but he doesn't really bring anything to the role, making him seem like more of a caricature than a character. As Clark Kent, he just seems to fade into the background, hardly attracting any attention from the audience. Kate Bosworth is quite flat as Lois Lane, not giving us any reason to care about her the way Superman does. In fact, to those who have never visited the world of Superman before, you'd be left wondering why Clark cares about Lois so much.The biggest disappointment (even if not the worst job) is Kevin Spacey, who plays Luthor more like a cartoon than a sinister villain. It really is a shame, as some of Spacey's best roles have been the sinister (Se7en, anyone?), but it seems more like Luthor is Elmer Fudd to Superman's Bugs Bunny. The extensive supporting cast is almost unnoticeable as Luthor chews up as much of the scenery as possible. On a side note, Kal Penn (Kumar himself) is completely shortchanged, having practically no lines and very little character. Nice way to treat a cult favourite actor.Overall, Superman's return is a fair bit of a mess. The plot is weak, the action is sparse, the tension is non-existent and the acting is all over the map. Sure, there is always the off-chance the next movie (because we all know there will be another one) will be better, but based on how this one, it is safe to say that we shouldn't get our hopes up. In a world that craves the darkness of Batman, the angst of Spider-Man and the rebellion of the X-Men, the underwear-on-the-outside Superman just can't fit in.34%

Superman Returns is set in the present day where it has been several years since Superman has been seen or saved anybody. We find out that for the past few years Superman has been investigating his dying home planet and that is why he has been away for so long. He ends up coming back to Earth and as his alter ago Clark Kent he gets his job back at the newspaper. Having saved some people already the town is very happy to have him back, but his old love interest Lois Lane is not having been mad at him for leaving before. Superman now finds out that Lois has a boyfriend and a son. Meanwhile, Superman's arch nemesis Lex Luthor is out of prison and hatching a new plan which will lead to the death of many people. Lex also has plans to stop Superman once and for all and it will be up to him to stop Lex and to change Lois's mind about him and save the city from disaster. Superman Returns has good direction, a good screenplay, good performances by the entire cast and good film editing. In my opinion the original Superman film from 1978 is the best superhero movie of all time. Having liked the original so much I wasn't sure how much I would like this fifth film in the series, but overall I was not disappointed. The film remains faithful to the characters of the original film and what I mean by that is Clark Kent is still a charming and nice guy as is Superman, Lois Lane still has a lot of spunk and attitude and Lex Luthor although being serious a lot of the time makes a joke out of himself and has amusing sidekicks to go along with him. These are several things I liked about the original so much and that this film captured faithfully. The film also doesn't always go for big action scenes and instead once again re-introduces us to these characters and shows us what is going on in their lives and shows their feelings of love and hurt especially between Superman and Lois Lane. I was just as compelled and entertained by the scenes with Clark Kent and Lois Lane or Superman and Lois Lane for that matter where there is no action, but just meaningful conversations and situations. But then when we get to the action scenes they are very entertaining and interesting and kept my attention. I also liked the pace of this film and thought it moved along well and just was a great addition to the Superman series. The original Superman, I still think is probably the greatest superhero movie of all time and this one does it justice by being a great sequel and probably the best superhero movie of at least the past ten years or so. I know I gave last year's Batman Begins a really good rating, but I liked this film even more. This film was a great achievement and a worthy addition to the series and die-hard Superman fans will not be disappointed. One of the best films so far this year.

Review Title: A must see for Superman Fans young and old.
Review: Great Movie!! Was everything the return of Superman to the big screen should be. The casting was perfect especially Kevin Spacey and Brandon Routh. They couldn't have chosen a better Lex and Superman. Brandon Routh embodied everything Superman should be. The special effects were awesome. I had the pleasure of watching it in an IMAX theater with some scenes being shown in 3-D and if anyone has the opportunity I would strongly recommend doing the same it just adds to an already great movie. I think the director took Superman in the right direction and hope that he comes back for the next one. A must see for any Superman fan. All I can say is I can't wait for the next installment.

Review Title: See it at a Budget- if even then.
Review: I had the misfortune of seeing this movie at full price.I know that's a strange thing to say, considering the ratings that other users have put on this particular movie- the amount of "10s" outweigh all other votes combined- but in my honest and humble opinion, the only breath of fresh air in the entire movie was Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey)- and even he overacted in the boat scene.Please don't get me wrong- Bryan Singer, Michael Dougherty, and Dan Harris wrote an excellent screenplay. I have no qualms about the direction of those three for where they are taking the Big S; they did write a screenplay that I felt I needed to sit through the entire movie in order to see what was coming up next.Still, I think that at least 45 minutes of this movie should have wound up on the cutting room floor. The "romantic" portion was shoved down our throats, time and time again. I'm sorry- I get enough saccharine in everything else, I don't need to feel as if I'm going into a diabetic coma when I'm in the theater. It would also have turned this 2 hour, 34 minute movie into something more palatable, with these particular actors/actress. (More on this below.) Brandon Routh (Clark Kent/Superman) and Kate Bosworth (Lois Lane) were miscast. Brandon captured the feel of Clark Kent to a "T" (reminiscent of the late Christopher Reeve), but he doesn't have the on-screen persona to pull off the Man of Steel, nor the acting ability to fully utilize the relationship and chemistry with Lois Lane. As far as Kate Bosworth is concerned, she was so wooden, I'm surprised she didn't sprout leaves. (If it had the chemistry we saw between Sam Raimi's Tobey Maguire (Peter Parker/Spiderman) / Kirsten Dunst (Mary Jane Watson), or even Brian Singer's Hugh Jackman (Wolverine) / Famke Janssen (Jean Grey) in X-Men, then this would have been a much better movie, overall.) Kevin Spacey literally stole the show; he was the only actor in the entire movie who had any 'oomph' to his character at all. I would sincerely welcome him into any future Superman movies; he does the cool, calculating Lex Luthor to perfection. He literally stole the movie, and his acting was enough to give this 3 stars. Unfortunately, he had a moment or two of overacting (Boat scene)- perhaps to make up for the wooden performances of Brandon and Kate.James Marsden (Richard "Perry" White) and Sam Huntington (Jimmy Olsen) did "okay" jobs; nothing to write about.Will I go back to the theater to see this movie again? NO.Will I purchase this DVD? NO. Kevin Spacey is the only redeeming actor in this particular movie, and even so, his on-screen time was limited, due to the romantic angle that felt (at best) like a teenage infatuation.Would I watch this on network or cable television? Doubtful.-- Steve

Superman comes back after five years, searching for the planet Krpyton, and has to save the world from Lex Luthor. This is the first Superman movie I've seen and it was a bad first impression of Superman movies for me. Forty minutes into it, I was already bored. It was ever so predictable. Of course your jaws will drop when you see the ridiculously amazing things he does, like landing a Boeing 747, but that won't last. You'll know that he'll be able to save them and stop this and the only thing that'll stop him is kryptonite. While watching this movie, I had a thought, superheroes can only save lives. They can't save souls. They can't save or treat a mentally disturbed person or someone who had a traumatic experience, unless they have a Phd. in psychology. I can say that Superman is superficial. Anyway, it's like there is nothing he can do , physically speaking, and that can get boring. There was nothing wrong with the actors' performances, but something was lacking between Clark Kent/Superman and Lois Lane, it felt dull. Superman fans might like the fact that the Daily Planet people not for once suspect Clark Kent to be Superman, but it does get old, because it does for me. I have to give credit to Bryan Singer for keeping the look of the original movies and Brandon Routh plays Superman just like Christopher Reeve did. Fans would probably enjoy this and will wonder if there will be a sequel: the ending does leave audiences suspended. Superman Returns is only eye candy and even though most superhero movies don't need an excellent story, the writers still have to try and they didn't try at all. It's not a waste of money, because you'll realize how bad it is and if you do, be wary of some corny scenes. Spiderman's a more interesting superhero and has better movies compared to this one.

Review: I just saw the movie and it was great. I was five years old when the original came out and had the same concerns as the other person who commented on this movie. I had the same feelings of wanting to see Christopher Reeve again as Superman. Brandon Routh brought a little of that back for me and a whole lot more. Review Title: At least they preserved the Sanctity of the Secret Identity.
Review: Interesting fact.WHILE I WAS GOING THROUGH THE DEMOGRAPHIC BREAKUP OF THE VOTES I REALISED THAT WHAT I WAS GOING TO SAY WAS ABSOLUETELY TRUE. WOMEN HAVE VOTED FAR HIGHER FOR THIS FILM THEN MEN. THE HIGHEST VOTE COMES FROM WOMEN UNDER 18. NOT YOUR STANDARD AUDIENCE FOR SUPERHERO FILMS.... BUT THIS WILL ILLUSTRATE WHAT I AM ABOUT TO SAY.For starters let me say that this is exactly what I expected........ in the quest for wider audiences and a better demographics. Movie makers are increasingly making so called action movies more and more emotional, dramatic and romantic they have blurred the line between all genres of films in the quest for better returns.Thus I automatically lowered my expectations and went into this movie expecting the same melodrama that I have come to expect from all action films.HOWEVER I HAD TO SEE THIS FILM THANKS TO MY OWN Curiosity AND THE HYPE SURROUNDING IT.This movie may have focused to much on the drama but other than that and a couple of other things this movie had a lot of things going right for it.The Airplane rescue scene was brilliant it had all the elements of suspense, action, technical wizardry and a dash of humour all of which make for a perfect beginning this for me was the best scene in the film.Other than that the show was mostly stolen by the brilliant Kevin Spacey and ABSOLUETELY SPECTACULAR PARKER POSEY. Much has been said about Kevin Spacey but Parker Posey for me was pure serendipity even the scenes with histrionics was carried out with élan. No overacting or over dramatization here, kitty has traditionally had a soft corner for superman, somehow she was able to play down even that, for me the villainous duo and their chemistry as also their henchmen stole the show.This may have been the only movie where the henchmen have spent so much time on screen yet have hardly uttered any words, deliberate or not the henchmen yet stood out especially the one with the tattoo. Indias own Kal Penn unfortunately was also at the receiving end although he is present throughout the movie his dialogues (which he claimed were many ) were cut.Compare to that the chemistry between superman and Lois lane was shoddy. This may have been the most romantic superman ever but even then either the casting (FOR ME THE DEMOGRAPHICALLY CORRECT KATE BOSWORTH WAS A MISTAKE SHE Neither HOT NOR PRETTY ENOUGH TO BE LOIS LANE) or the acting talents of Brandon Routh are to blame.This is by far the most unidimensional superman he feels only 2 emotions love and his sense of duty. Save for a couple of scenes the humour is non-existent. Superman takes himself way to seriously. Where is the comic book humor and bravado that we learned to love. Superman with issues is not superman hes batman. Hell even batman went through a phase where he was full of humour.Save for the airplane scene the action scenes are entertaining but nothing exceeds expectations for a movie where you expect at least the action scenes to be world class there is but one genuinely exciting scene. The rest of the movie is crammed full of good action scenes but none worth mentioning.The movie feels like a regular soap opera it even ends on a note of drama. A brilliant scene with Kevin and Posey towards the end would have been far more apt. Its filled with twists and turns and scenes that seem straight out of bold and the beautiful or EKTA KAPOORS K SERIALS. I couldn't help but laugh at implications of it and I'm sure other will see the humour in it too.The movie regularly hints at these and even though I always get them right I'm sure other to will see the early signs of it. THANKS TO MY FRIEND EVEN WON A BET. (THANKS FOR THE MONEY ABHISHEK).I am not a supporter of the Same old fashioned treatment to superhero movies but neither would I like to see a super sensitive superman instead of making every superhero vulnerable and emotional how about showing us scenes where he fails or needs help.Also the promotions for the mobile phone and digicam were far from subtle but sublime compare to Indian movies.SORRY BUT I WILL NOW STOP CRIBBING ABOUT THE SAD STATE OF MODERN DAY ACTION FILMS.Thankfully although superman has the worst disguise (hahah) unlike hulk and spider-man at least he still has his secret identity.Special mention for James Marsden ,Frank Langella and Sam Huntingtonwho played their supporting roles with panache. Frank and Sam especially gave us some much needed comic relief.In all an ordinary film that just about meets expectations thanks mainly due to great performances from the villains and the supporting cast and a couple of memorable scenes.Curiosity and hype are major reason for watching films and if you want to watch this film for these reasons then please lower your expectations and go and enjoy this film.+S great acting from the villains and supporting cast especially Posey. Couple of memorable scenes. top of the line special effects.+/- s Brandon Routh (looks like superman but has yet to display any acting talent), interesting but melodramatic twist -s Kate Bosworth, overly romantic and melodramatic, unidimensional superman.total 6/10 ( thanks to lowered expectations in absolute terms more of a 5) PS IN RETROSPECT WHEN YOU THINK ABOUT IT THIS MOVIE HAS At least A DOZEN LOGICAL AND SIMPLE PLOT HOLES SOME OF WHICH ARE PRETTY EVIDENT IN THE FILM HOWEVER THIS HARDLY AFFECTED THE OVERALL EXPERIENCE OF THE FILM.

Review Title: Superman Returns!! Now Go Back Home!!!

Review: I am a big fan of the superman franchise. I was kinda into the comic books, but comic books has never been my thing. I remember when I saw the very first Superman movie and it made me believe I could fly. And no that was not a shot out to R. Kelly. :P Then Superman II and III added even more wonderment to the man of steel and made him so human and so believable.Now in Superman Returns the journey returns in a powerful. The movie starts like 10 years or so after Superman III and Superman has just came back from a 5 year journey to Krypton and Lois is engaged with a child.Superman starts off so cool with a remake of the opening credits using the original score that you remember from all of the superman movies. This movies is fast, slick, creative and most importantly the scenes were Superman actually fly seem so real.A whole new generation of superman fans will be born in the generation that has been used to X Men, Spiderman, Fantastic Four, Electra, Dare Devil, Blade, and host of other comic book to screen superstars in the last decade. But Superman returns is in a league all of it's on.Superman and Spiderman I think are the best of the comic book to screen series because of the human element that you can relate to in each of them.In Superman returns Superman struggles with being the only person left from his planet. You know that is such a human thing so many people fell when they are the outcast in a situation. There was one scene with Lois that Superman took on an almost Jesus quality when they referred to him as being the savior of the world.This movie is not campy like the first superman movie, it's a little dark and intense at time, but overall I think this is the best Superman Movie since Superman I.

Review Title: This movie is much smarter than it's going to get credit for.
Faster, stronger and better than ever
Review: Bryan's Superman is a wonderful movie. The movie has everything you need: drama, comedy, love, amazing special effects, great story, talented actors and intense action. In this sequel (of the first two movies), superman leaves earth for five years in order to find his home planet, Krypton. The movie begins with his return which is very painful to him since the love of his life, Lois Lane, is a mother and it appears to him that she doesn't need him anymore. If you are wondering where he got that idea from, well that's because Ms. Lane got a Pulitzer prize for writing an article about "why the world doesn't need Superman". In the course of the movie Lois finds out that the world, just like her, needs Superman. A movie without a villain is not a movie, therefore we have Lex Luthor, who is a super villain and archenemy of Superman. Luthor, as always, wants to kill superman and take over the world. But as we all know, in movies, bad guys can't defeat heroes.The cast of this film is a great one. Every actor is so talented and gives dimension to his character. Brandon Routh is amazing as both Clark Kent and Superman. He is tough, strong, funny and looks good in that outfit. Kate Bosworth proves that she can be dramatic and funny (No doubt that she is Lois Lane). Kevin spacey looks great without hair. For those of you who have seen the previous Superman movies, you can see the resemblance between Kevin and Gene Hackman (act and appearance). NO doubt that they both did a good job. Frank Langella (Perry White) and Sam Huntington (Jimmy Olsen) do not disappoint us either.The amazing flying scenes are breathtaking and the special effects are fantastic. No doubt that the technology is much more advanced nowadays. This is definitely the best time for superman to return to the big screen. The sound, the picture and the scenes are unbelievably overwhelming. While watching this movie I couldn't move from my seat and for the first time I was barely talking during a movie.So all of you, Superman fans, boys and girls, out there: YOU MUST SEE THIS MOVIE ON A BIG SCREEN AND DON'T WAIT FOR THE DVD TO COME OUT BECAUSE THERE IS NO FUN IN THAT!

I was highly anticipating this film, as it is that i have been a big superman fan since i was a kid. The first time i saw the film i was sorely disappointed and very upset. I have seen it twice since, and the movie has improved each time. My three main concerns with the film are these: Bosworth as Lois had no panache, Routh could have been more endearing, the utter lack of American patriotism, and the refusal to admit Metropolis is essentially New York City. First off, i thought Bosworth was sufficient at best as Lois Lane, but she wasn't interesting nor captivating. Kidder in the role in Superman 78' had a ton of spunk and flavor, and Bosworth had very little. I know they were trying to make the character more mature, with a kid and more experience and all, but without her fire and quick wit , Lois was a bore and i really didn't care about her. Secondly I thought Brandon did just fine as Clark and Supes, but I didn't think, nor did i have the expectation, that he came close to surpassing the great Christopher Reeve as my superman. Reeve's performance was iconic: he hit Clark Kent out of the park and his Superman made me believe in heroes as a kid. He has a great warmth as the big man, and you felt as if he could jump into your life if you were to ever get into trouble. Brandon, as a pretty much unexperienced actor, did a good job, trying to emulate Reeve as much as possible. I just thought he wasn't given enough as Clark or Superman to really grab you out of your seat and make him win your heart. I think if there will be sequels, he will continue to improve. Thirdly, what the hell is with the lack of Americanism? Whether it's Singer's political views or a sellout attempt to win over a bigger chunk of the foreign market, either way i am really disappointed. "Does he still stand for truth, justice, all that stuff" ? Give me a break. Superman is the essential American superhero, and if the world can't deal with that, well that they can take a hike. He's for the American way all the way. Lastly, i admit i am a New Yorker at heart, and i loved the New York feel to Superman 78', and the reversal of that thinking made me mad. Without the NY feel, you lose the hustle of the city, the Daily Planet was virtually worthless, and it added to Bosworth and Langella's (Perry White) poor performances. All and all, after seeing it three times, i am somewhat satisfied with the movie. I thought Spacey was OK, he could have for sure done a much better job, but whatever. Sam as Jimmy Olsen was fantastic, James Marsden was great as always as Richard White, and i though Parker Posey was very funny as Kitty. I think Singer did a cakewalk with this one, going for a formula instead of really going for the gusto. The visuals were fantastic, as would be expected. The music was disappointing, I though Ottman missed a lot of opportunities for some great cues. Going back to Ottman, who also was co-editor, i thought the editing definitely put a dent in this film. So, i suggest you see it and find out for yourself. I'm just happy the man of steel is back, but lets get a better showing next time.

Review Title: Never much cared for Superman to begin with...
Why the world needs this movie
Review: I've seen this movie twice now. I really looked at this movie and compared it to many other so- called "superhero movies". Superman is a character that stands for good, and only that. The only flaw, if its even a flaw, is that he's in love. This is the complaint I get when talking about this movie withe others is: "why did they waist our time with that love story and pack it with more action?" When you pack action into a movie and slide the viewers along a roller-coaster you need to have moments of rest..just like a roller-coaster. That structure creates a pure, and exciting "superhero' movie, like Superman Returns. In contrast to Pirates of the...not waisting my time with the title, the pack action in left and right. The viewers are so sidetracked they ignore the little story that exists. Superman throws every right move from an incredible title sequence to some some of the most beautifully crafted action sequences ever created. With a fully constructed three-part epic story intertwined. If your going to portray a hugely followed and influential moral comic book hero like Superman, then deliver it right. Since there really isn't a Superman, then I guess we need this movie. Go in with this thought process and not just with the "dude, lets go check out that superman flick."

Now that I have seen the movie this was supposed to be competing with (POTC2) for our summer movie money, I think I am better able to comment on Superman Returns.Short review: This is the must see summer movie so far.Bryan Singer did an excellent job of revitalizing Superman. I fortunately caught the original on TV a few days before watching the movie, so was able to see how well Superman Returns works as a continuation on I and II. (I do think it is wise for everybody to forget that III and IV existed) Credit Brandon Routh with a performance that has the largest contribution to the success of the film. Generally, Brandon *is* superman. Occasionally, it seems like he is channeling Christopher Reeve directly in his performance. He is absolutely flawless as the geeky/clumsy Clark Kent (Probably my favourite parts of the film). As Superman, he goes beyond extremely convincing.Kevin Spacey was brilliant as Lex Luthor...and I believe he brought a more convincing, menacing and evil Lex to the big screen. No surprise really...Kevin Spacey is as close to a sure thing as you can get as a character actor.Everyone else was OK...anyone could have done what Kate Bosworth did, but I did enjoy Sam Huntington as Jimmy Olson.The story, with one exception, was good. There were a couple of choices as far as plot twists that I didn't like...but overall the storyline was enjoyable. (I would have liked to see more of the humour that Clark Kent provides, and less of the moody Superman with baggage that we see) Visually, this movie was amazing. If anything, I was looking forward to seeing what the special effects wizards were going to be able to do with this, and I was certainly not disappointed. There were a few times that the SuperCape looked a bit cartoony, but generally the CGI was fantastic.Definitely worth seeing at the theatre...but I'll be purchasing as well to revisit when it releases.

Within ten minutes of opening, it's evident that Superman, rather than returning to cinema, should have stayed put. This movie, helmed by comic movie whiz Bryan Singer, has nothing in common with his earlier and better films. Everyone hoping that Superman Returns is on the level with the excellent comic films X-Men, or Spiderman 2... Sorry. It's closer in relation to horrific CG dominated fare like Attack of the Clones and The Hulk.Superhero movies are never about the plot, but Superman's is just awful. After returning from his galactic journey to find his homeworld, The Man of Steel finds himself in the middle of this evil plot masterminded by none other, than Lex Luthor. After finding Superman's arctic hideout, Lex confiscates the alien technology hidden there, which allows him to "grow" his own continent, destroy the world, and charge people to live on his islands since there's nowhere else to live. The scheme, at best, is retarded. At worst, sounds like something RE/MAX might think up.I'm astounded at how bad the acting was for this movie. Even a versatile actor like Kevin Spacey, who is normally fantastic, was simply bad. I understand what he was trying to do, and how he was attempting to bring a sort of "insanity" to the character, but it fails. And because of that failure, we're left with a very muddled and confused interpretation of Lex Luthor. Kate Bosworth fairs better than most of the cast. She plays Lois Lane fine, but never taps into the deeper character. But, no one cares about them. Superman, is where it's all at. Sadly, it's arguably the movie's greatest failure. Brandon Routh never comes close to tapping into the emotions and flaws that make the character of Superman. He's all surface and good looks, and not once does he show a hint of emotion. Seriously, I think the casting director just looked for whoever looked best in the tights.Even considering the horrible story, and bad acting, that's not why Superman Returns is such a bore. The main reason is, that Bryan Singer was content to make a surface movie. One could say that it's because it's so predictable, but that's not it. All comic movies are predictable (save for Daredevil, which is very good) but what makes them worthwhile are two things: The action, which Superman fails miserably, and the deeper emotions of the heroes. Sam Raimi did it extraordinarily well with the Spiderman films, Mr. Singer did it himself with the first 2 X-Men movies, but not in Superman. Everything here is "flash over substance".One bright spot in this terrible movie, is Kitty. Or more specifically, Lex Luthor's "henchwoman", (hey, I don't make the words up, I just write with 'em) played to perfection by Parker Posey. Her wacky, energetic role, while hilarious and incredibly entertaining, is out of place. She belongs in a better, much more fun Superman film. If the filmmakers had built the movie around her energy, they would have had a smash hit on their hands.But sadly, they didn't and it isn't. What we have instead, is a CG driven mess that eerily resembles the Star Wars prequel films. Nothing works in this movie. Not a single thing. I'll be the first to admit, I've never liked Superman. I've always thought he paled in comparison to the more intriguing characters of Batman and Spiderman. This movie does nothing but prove me right. But, I know some of you die-hard fans will go see this, despite anything I say. Don't say I didn't warn you.

One doesn't have to travel very far now days to witness or experience man's inhumanity to man first hand. The nightly news is full of gruesome images and stories of tragedy and horror that often seem to challenge even the most forthright and experienced news anchor to maintain some semblance of calm detachment while reading the text. Watchers are numb to the horror as well, or so it seems. Many are simply sinking further into the cesspool of delayed stress syndrome that appears to have engulfed much of the civilized world since the fall of the twin towers. In the midst of all this, Americans prepare to set off Fourth of July fireworks that may be unsettling reminders of another horror to those of us who have just escaped the grip of a vicious conflict half way around the world. Enter, Superman, red cape flapping in the wind and his dark curl falling onto his forehead enticingly as he once again reaches out to rescue animals, children, adults, neighborhoods, cities and the world with little effort. I grew up with Superman. Class bullies and years of uncertainty and insecurity plagued my youth and drove me to seek refuge in the arms of someone invincible and untouched by the mundane struggles of mere mortals. No matter how tough things got, in fact… the tougher things got, a piece of my young soul was somehow strengthened by imagining that somewhere out there in the vast universe there could actually be a Superman… a man totally devoid of fear and uncorrupted by vice or greed… a man completely dedicated to fighting for the preservation of truth and consumed with the concept of justice for all.In my youth, Superman fought for truth, justice and the American way. This latest movie, Superman Returns, makes it very clear that Superman is fighting for truth and justice all over the world though. That may seem like an insignificant departure from the original script, but it is, in view of today's global unrest, extremely important. For it is indeed the world that needs Superman now, not just America.The world needs Superman (and Supermen) because the world needs hope. Hope that good can conquer evil. Hope that it does indeed pay off to be truthful, even when everyone around you is lying, hope that things will indeed get better, and hope that there will be another tomorrow. Superman does all of this without irritating anyone with religious or political beliefs.Superman is a concept, not just a figure in tights swinging from wires. Superman embodies the inner goodness that is an expression of the true nature of human beings. We loose track of that in times like this. We tend to get swept away by all the anger and horror. Superman has returned to remind us of some very important things. Excuse me while I drag my old Superman suit out of the trunk and brush the wrinkles away one more time…Michael Jaquish (Retired Police Officer) Gig Harbor, WA, USA

Review Title: Sorry, Singer totally missed the boat.

Review: I recently trekked to the theater to view "Superman Returns", unsure of what I would find. A long time fan of Christopher Reeve's film Superman, I felt that it would be nearly impossible to live up to it. In my heart I truly didn't want the new film to deviate so far off the original's track that it lost itself. In my eyes, Christopher Reeve is and will always be Superman, but I was willing to give the new actor a shot. I'm glad I did. He did a wonderful job above and beyond my expectations for the film. And I give a heartfelt thanks to Bryan Singer for adhering so closely to the first Superman films. Tears nearly came to my eyes when the original theme music played at the beginning. For over two hours, I sat in that theater, lost in another world that I hadn't had the privilege to visit in almost thirty years. A place where good conquers evil and a man in a cape can be counted on as a hero and a savior. I left wanting to see the movie again and again. Brandon Routh's Clark Kent was so similar to Christopher Reeve's that it was like coming home. He has made the role his own in a soulful, stolid portrayal of the Man of Steel without losing the basic characterization that Reeve brought to the role. Needless to say, I enjoyed the film beyond words and, though I sorely miss Reeve, I think we've gotten the next best thing. And the next best thing is pretty darn good.

Review Title: Basically a waste of time, money and creative talent
Too much move with too little to say
Review: For a superhero movie with so little action, you'd at least expect there to be a lot of character development in the 2 1/2+ hours of run time. Unfortunately, there isn't. The chemistry between Bosworth and Routh is non-existent. Spacy's Luthor is fairly impressive, though way over the top in many scenes. In many ways, Superman Returns is a rehashing of the original Superman movie, without any of the emotional attachment. This movie does little more than turn Superman from hero into a battered Christ analogy. If you want to see Clark Kent and Lex Luthor with some depth, stick with Smallville. Singer hits a sour note with this one.

Review Title: Could have been a classic as the original but alas....

Review: I found this to be a magnificent movie. The acting by Routh, Bosworth, and Marsden was perfect and dead-on. Routh has taken the legend of Superman to new level. I've always been a Reeves fan, but Routh more than holds his own. The movie had great pacing also. The action scene with the plane in the beginning was very special on the special effects. What I really loved about the movie was the artistic moments when Superman would just float for a moment (when he was listening to Earth, soaking up the sun to recharge, etc.). These looked great on the big screen. I've seen the movie twice already and plan on many more viewings.

Review: Having watched this movie I feel that it is not nearly as good as previous Superman films. The plot was so thin you could see right through it. The graphics although all good were too much in the dark.It was a waste of Kevin Spaceys time doing this as I still have problems discovering what his role was.
