Review Title: Good return, with both old and new fans satisfied.
Review: The fact about this awesome Brian Singer movie really reflected the golden ages of Superman in 1970's. So everything, everyone is just like before. Smiling of Clark Kent and Lux Luther's smiling are definitely the same with old ones. Returns just made the closest to the first one,and the first one in 1978 is still the best IMO. We see, a mixed one of new scenes and old scenes together. That is satisfying to both old and new audiences of Superman.All the cast are fine. But no one matches Kevin Spacey. He has done another great job by playing Gene Hackman's role. When you just see the funny face, you may easily mistake him with Hackman. That's remarkable because Gene also acted as Lux Luther at the age of 47 for the first time. Maybe we can also forecast Kevin's third Academy Award in his sixty's. Ha ha!Special effects are also very good. You won't be disappointed by the "lord of rings-like" scenes and their details. Superman's muscle seems a little softer than before, but it also shows what director wants to tell us,that is, Superman is also a human. To understand this movie in a more humanity way, you don't have to know any a bit of English. Because Singer's story-telling is better than most of drama films on show. And people laugh at what they are supposed to laugh at, no matter how much they received quotes.If you really want me to tell something not so satisfying, I'd say it's the complex. When everyone is waiting for some kick-ass actions like the old series, they see superman defeats bad guys without facing them. Maybe this is also arranged by our dear director Mr. Singer. Maybe he doesn't want superman to be somebody that wages violence on human flesh......Anyway it's one of the most rewarding big films on screen in 2006. Girls will love it, therefore don't forget to take your girlfriend to see it in theater.8/10

Review Title: Even though you were raised as a human being , you are not one of them......
Review: I am not a comic book reader. Not cause I didn't think they were cool, but because movies were just more interesting to me. Movies are my passion, not comic books. OK, introductions made.Superman. He has that name for a reason, 'nuff said. Bryan Singer. Well, you like the guy's work or you don't. I do. X-Men and X-2 were great movies; and Singer worked his charm for Superman Returns.First off, casting. Half of what a director does is cast his picture well. Great cast, Routh blended in seamlessly as the Man of Steel, Kate Bosworth had that feeling like you've seen her somewhere before (i.e. Remember the Titans and Blue Crush) but you couldn't remember where, so she was just Lois Lane to you. Now, Routh as Clark Kent; splendid. We've all been the geek at some point, or the weirdo, or just the outcast; and Clark is just fun to watch. Kevin Spacey, oh my holy god. Funny when its okay to be funny, and ruthless when its great to be ruthless. He fits effortlessly into the role of Lex Luthor, superb actor giving a great performance in a superb role. Casting highlights made, well what else can I say? Everyone else just fit. The cast fit well together, very well.Next, the crew. Cinematography-well played, some very good moments visually that I just can't ruin for you. VFX-Matrix eat your heart out. This is what believable human flight looks like to me. Especially next to a very real looking 777, but thats enough out of me on that one. Sound? Totally enthralling. Very theatrical.Most important - editing and music. John Williams' score is perfectly reused at the critical moments, but John Ottman's music is well worth noting. There are a couple of cues, particularly with Lex Luthor, that stood out just as much to me as Williams' superman march, and thats saying something. Elliot Graham and Ottman do a good job cutting the picture together, too. Not quite as memorable as Michael Ellis and Stuart Baird's cut of the original; but Ottman and Graham place the tension elsewhere rather than everywhere at once. Personally, I think its cut together more intensely than X-2 was, but thats me.Finally - Directing. Bryan Singer in the pilot's seat. Given the majority of films released to the public, less and less is capable of impressing me. Especially in terms of action. Return of the King and Batman Begins really ruined it for most movies, because I loved them and they kept me on edge so long and so well that they set the bar incredibly high. Having said that, Superman Returns impressed me. If this doesn't prove Bryan Singer as a very capable director, there's no hope for Hollywood.Many of those I know are now hyped up for the next summer blockbuster, but I just wanted to take this moment in time to express the impact this movie made on me. It won't change how I look at life, but it impressed me. Its everything you go to the theater for, even if you only see it once, I highly recommend the theater, there's no way home video will have the same feeling. A strong and well executed movie.Superman Returns.

I don't know what it was about this movie... but I found myself wanting to leave earlier than halfway through. I knew what was going to happen (these kinds of movie never surprise you) I thought, foolishly, that Kevin Spacey could make this film worth viewing - and while the best moments are with Luther, the movie overall makes my stomach want to work in reverse. The budget for this film would have been better spent making a sock-puppet movie. Sure, it looked great - and superman gets shot in the eyeball. Cool. But for how long it is, its amazing how little actually happens. Luther and Superman only see each other once for like a 3 minute sequence. Most of the movie is spent making up stupid reasons for Superman to use his powers. Most of the movies happenings' go down in the last half hour it seemed like. The most expensive boring pile of crap i've seen in a long time. Quick Review: POS!

It's been almost 20 years since the Man of Steel last saw the silver screen, and 10 of those (as well as a reported $40 million) had been spent trying to get this film off the ground. The project had many different people attached in that time, including Tim Burton, Kevin Smith, McG and Brett Ratner directing, and Nicolas Cage, Brenden Fraser and Ashton Kutcher all rumoured to play the Kryptonian. With all that talent and financial backing in the 10 year development stage, this was set to be the biggest movie of the year.Brett Ratner traded Bryan Singer for directing duties on X-Men: The Last Stand, and Singer went for unknown Brandon Routh to don the cape and tights.Superman Returns is about just that- Superman returning. We start with both Superman and Clark Kent returning from a five year absence (why no one put two and two together, I'll never know) to a world that has radically changed, and Superman now ponders if he should have even come back. The love of his life, Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth) is now engaged and has a young child. Kent is barely able to get his job back at the Daily Planet, and, oh by the way, Lane won the Pulitzer for writing an article entitled "Why the World Doesn't Need Superman." Of course trusty old Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) has been freed from jail, thanks to the absence of Superman at his appeals trial, and is up to his old tricks, only this time with the very same technology that Superman had been sent to Earth with from Krypton, which Luthor had stolen from the Fortress of Solitude.Superman has never been a multi-layered superhero. He never had the brooding angst which made Batman such an interesting hero. Superman had all the powers that could make him perfect. He invincible to everything except a rare metal that very few even knew existed. And he stood for truth, justice and the American way. Very one dimensional. And what broke down here was that they tried to infuse internal dilemmas into a story that never really had any. Warner Brothers wanted another Batman Begins without realizing that Superman is NOT Batman. And the story suffered for it.It also lacked the charm of the original film series. It fell victim to the 21st century and was too much action, not enough substance. All glitz and no glamour. The true appeal of Superman, at least for me, is concocting somewhat interesting stories out of this flat character. And I for one was not interested. The principal cast is where it really begins to break apart. Brandon Routh makes a fine Superman, but just wasn't there for Clark Kent. I didn't buy him. He was almost too good looking to be believable as a lovable dorky reporter and a handsome superhero. Christopher Reeve was just perfect for it.I really can't say enough negative things about Kate Bosworth. I've never been too fond of her in the first place, but Lois Lane is just as iconic as Superman, so she had some mighty big shoes to fill. And she didn't. When I was watching her, I felt like I was watching a bad imitation of all the Lois Lanes in the past, rather than watching Lois Lane. She lacked that inner spunk and naivety which made both Margot Kidder and Teri Hatcher shine in the role. And the thing is, Singer came oh so close to casting the right person. But instead of putting Parker Posey in as Lois Lane, she had squander her talent in the equally alliterative, yet less important role of Kitty Kowalski, Luthor's female henchman.But wouldn't you know it, Kevin Spacey really came from left field and played a perfect Lex Luthor. And I think he did it right. He acknowledged Gene Hackman's interpretation, but brought his own style to it, and played it a bit darker, a bit more megalomaniacal than Hackman's. And he stands as the saving grace of the film.Singer should have stuck with the X-Men franchise. I don't blame him for leaving it for his dream project, how often does that get dropped into your lap. But he was better there, and I think he had more to work with, and less pressure to deal with. Superman was just too big for him.He also faulted when it came to the construction of the film. He relied way too much on digital effects, what I dub the George Lucas trap. Plenty could have been done with set pieces and creative stunt work. But he opted to trust all that to a computer, and in the end he blurred the line between real-life and animation (pay attention to Superman's face, it's too perfect at times).It accomplishes being a fun, entertaining film. But I have a feeling that that's really not what they were aiming for. And since both the filmmaker's intentions and the audience's expectations were not met, it is ultimately and unfortunately a failure.

Review Title: Not The Superhero Experience Of The Summer...Returns Falls and Fails
Review: Superman Returns is a rabid trip through the dull and boring, keeping your hopes up and letting them drop quickly. While the movie does sport a few good scenes or at least one. The movie is stretched out to the death, way to long and very unnecessary scenes put into play to fill in gaps. Little to no character development, no cut loose scenes, boring dialouge, unintreaguing storyline, and with the exception of the actress of Lois Lane a bad cast.This summer acclaimed movie really disappointed movie Byran Singer should have stuck to the X-Men series and it's sad sales reflect the movie itself. It had petonital but sadly it was unused this movie trys to match Batman Begins but fails. Bryan Singer attempts to adopt a new style but falls faster than the movie itself. Nothing more than a lost petonital blockbuster. If you are looking for the true superhero experience check out X-Men 3: The Last Stand, holding on to the superhero movie of the summer.While Superman Returns may have faired decently in the reviews for reasons unknown, it is not the superhero movie of the summer. And drags on quite a bit the beginning is slow, the end and the climax is more of a low point in the film. Unless your a die hard Superman fan I suggest you pass on the 10 dollar addmision fee and put it to one of the better movies of the summer X-Men 3 or Pirates of the Caribbean 2.Superman Returns if must seen in your eyes is a movie you can wait for DVD release this I promise you.

Review Title: Don't get sucked in by the hype
Review: I usually don't write comments on movies but do always use IMDb as a good source for determining which movies to watch and after seeing the rating for this movie I was very excited. Unfortunately the movie did not live up to the rating it has on this site. It wasn't a terrible movie but it wasn't that good either.I was a comic book reader when I was a kid and tend to like the well done adaptations but much like the hulk, daredevil and fantastic four this movie was WAY more cheesy than expected and had less action than I had expected. The focus on the love interest of superman was a lot more important to the movie plot than I had expected. Overall a 6 out of 10 but do not go expecting an action packed movie.

This is obviously the best overall quality in the superman genre of movies. What was significant about the film was the effort put into the acting and storyline, and if not for that, it would have lost a lot of its luster. I do give Kate Bosworth an "A" on this because she captured the screen well enough - because the superman character is mainly a straight guy and needs expressive female emotion to contrast his image.Kevin Spacey always does a good job and I really liked how he played the Lex Luthor role. He may not be like Gene Hackman, but he put a nice spin on that part and I chuckled through some of it.A slight drawback is that the film is almost three hours, and that could make it "boring" to some folks, but it seemed to hold its own in spite of that. I have to give the special effects a high mark too. Good job, Singer!

Review Title: "A son becomes the father, and a father becomes the son."

Review: I would like to thank Bryan Singer for bringing back the Superman I love. When the opening credits rolled and the John Williams score began, I felt like I was sitting in the theater back in '78 getting ready to see Superman again for the first time.This is an excellent movie, an obvious tribute to Reeve and co. but establishing the new faces at the same time. I thought Routh was great as Superman ( in fact, in a couple of scenes better than Reeve ). The effects were amazing but it's the story, the dialogue, etc. that in time will make this the new standard for Superman.There's not many movies that make me want to personally thank the people involved, but this one did. GO SEE IT !

Review Title: If you only see this Superman maybe it's okay maybe
Review: This struck me as an odd quasi sequel mostly remake--though now without any of the actors from the first film. It rests so heavily on that film and ignores the mostly ignore worth sequels, that I can't imagine it working at all without seeing that first film, which maybe lots of the people who seem to like it have. But it just seemed odd to me, only Spacey as the villain did anything new, or was allowed to and scripted in a way that let him do something different, and the look of the film is all over the place with the actors mostly looking like they are made out of plastic wrap you'd put on frozen food and the colors being kind of muted. It has a muddy look because it's not shot on film folks.The films peaks about 20 minutes before it's over and has not much of an ending really, much of the editing seems random (the film was still being editing right up the last minute and feels like a rush job--certain things go on too long other things don't develop properly. Just kind of a big overlong mess. Not really enough new going on here to justify its existence, and what was the MOONRAKER space shuttle sequence doing in this film? And what are all those lines borrowed from the original film doing mixed in with an occasionally new story in a way that they don't make sense, to say nothing of the Marlon Brando footage being reused and the odd dedication to dead husband and wife Mr. and Mrs. Reeve who the filmmakers must be glad aren't around to bad mouth their feeble efforts to disguise this as new film-it's a rehash done rather poorly.

Review Title: Superman Returns (And brings a lot of camp back with him)
Whatever Happened To The Man Of Tomorrow?
Superman Returns is to Superman (1978) what The Phantom Menace is to Star Wars.
the best movie of the summer -- a must see on the big screen
Review: If you want to feel like a kid watching a movie for the first time, go see superman returns. It is a fun thrill ride that does not let up. It is even better seeing this movie in IMAX 3D! Don't wait to watch this on DVD, Superman Returns is meant to be seen on the big screen. Just check out the reviews at rottentomatoes.com and fan response at myspace.com/supermanreturns. It is a great and fun movie and it is the best movie of the summer. Brandon Routh is just perfect as the man of steel. For those of you who don't know the story of Superman Returns. He has been gone for 5 years and comes back to find Lois has moved on and now has a kid with another guy (James Marsden). Go see this movie, you won't regret it!

I thought this movie was great although my husband who is a Marvel fan did not like it. This version was much better than the first four. Brandon Routh was a much better Superman and Clark Kent. He plays the straight lines with more humanity and a less cartoon-like demeanor. His Superman was more real, acted more like a real person than past performances. I loved the nod to older versions using stars from the past and keeping important formula lines. But my favorite part was the portrayal of Lex Luthor by Kevin Spacey. He is such a great actor and delivers his lines with a great deal of humor or a certain malevolence that creates fear in the observer.

Review Title: Pale imitation of the original Superman movie
Review: Having seen the original Superman movie in the seventies and thinking it was one of the greatest movies I had seen. I took my kids along to see if they could reproduce the magic with a new cast and the biggest movie budget ever. Sadly they failed. It was hard to see where the gigantic budget went...the special effects looked like well..special effects. It made me realize how good the original cast were, Christopher Reeve, Margot Kidder, Gene Hackman, Valerie Perrine and Ned Beatty and the others supporting cast. The cast of Superman Returns are pale imitations compared to the originals, even Kevin Spacey who had the juicyest role didn't deliver. The plot was so-so and I can only lay the blame with the director who seemed unable to get the best out of the actors he cast. I think the best thing now is they forget about any sequels, I think the box-office will see to that, and let the Superman story lay dormant for 10-20 years and bring it back fresher for a different generation.

Straight off the bat, the movie takes you soaring through the sky and it hits you right in the heart with its superman feel. Starring Brandon Routh, Kate Bosworth and Kevin Spacey, Superman Returns really takes Superman to a new level. With the a new fully developed storyline, Superman returns after five years of searching for his homeland, to a motherly Lois Lane and Lex Luther on the loose ready to take over the world again.But the movie was truly amazing in that it intertwined our latest technological twist and tricks to the movie making it an up to date adventure in the skies. All of the scenes were beautifully choreographed and I must say Brandon Routh looked beautiful in all of them.I also have to give credit to Kevin Spacey, his great acting skills really gave a delightful sprinkle and taste to the film. There were moments I found myself laughing quite historically in the theater because of his acting skills.Completely full of surprises, one of a kind, uniquely put together, solid great film, Superman Returns is definitely a must see.

Review Title: Not the epic that was required.

Review: I can only say to all the bad reviewers out there - don't be so critical. Don't you go to the movies to be entertained. Why pick at the small things? No picture is ever perfect. But Superman Returns comes close! I consider it to be a better picture than the first Superman movie and that is saying a lot as Christopher Reeve had no equal then. However Brandon Routh is definitely his equal in his performance in this latest installment of the Superman legend. This was a stirring, thoughtful and engaging film from start to finish. It contained a great many layers to the overall story. I particularly enjoyed the 'inner' look at Superman - beyond his great powers and how he might feel and think. A class act of a movie, spectacular, thought provoking, sometimes a little over the top, but always, always engaging, entertaining and exciting. Don't listen to anyone who says differently. See this movie and sit back and enjoy a little over two hours of movie magic, simply stunning special effects, brilliant acting from the entire cast - particularly Brandon. This guy will go far!! Loved Superman Returns! Will go see it again!

Singer delivers again a great film - establishing himself as one of the best directors today. The movie is visually stunning probably surpassing even the visual effects of the 2 spiderman movies. The cast is also brilliant - highlights being Routh and Spacey, both bring in mind Christopher Reeve and Gene Hackman - with Spacey making Luthor a bit darker and more of a psycho, he probably even surpasses Hackman's performance.Moreover, the effects are -as above-mentioned- brilliant giving at last a movie that shows all of superman's strengths (unlike the old movies that could not include everything). "Returns" is a big homage to the 2 original movies - from the credits, to J.WIlliam's theme, Clark Kent's old fashioned expressions, the closing scene and actually all of the movie...Singer's (and his editor) construct a very well-structured, nicely paced (perhaps a bit slower than expected) movie that you do not feel its as long as it is (2,5 hours), although some flashback-Krypton-scenes that we expected to see (from some teaser posters) were absent, which could have been included...Except from a a bit of minor flaws that could have been eradicated it the cutting room, another minor flaw that actually is probably not the movie's fault but of the marketing campaign of it: the hype and expectations of the movie were high and as a Super-geek that I am I saw every trailer and TV spot prior to seeing the movie (more than 10) and this spoiled the experience - all the "WOW" scenes did not wow me... I really hope that production companies stop doing such a mixed up job on promoting movies... Lower your expectations and do not see more than one trailer - and you will be blown away by the movie...In addition, I believe that in a few years this will be remembered as the ultimate Superman movie and as a better cinematic example than the original Superman movies... Which were not as good as this - having the burden of bad structures, and a lot of people messing up with the director's vision whereas here Singer does not compromise his vision at all... The old Supeman movies will remain as nostalgic landmarks of what the movies can offer and the fact that they came in a time (1978) where movies were still learning what special effects were and still a lot of potential was not yet fulfilled...For now "Returns" is rated with a solid 8 and I believe that with subsequent viewings it will come closer to a 10... Highly recommended!

Review Title: Great Direction, Great Action, Lame Hero
Review: Brian Singer made a beautiful looking movie, and I enjoyed my one watch of it, but that will be it. The movie looks great and sounds great, and hell, even the acting is decent. But there's just one thing, there is no intrigue about the character, no attachment to him other than the fact he is the good and moral model citizen, making for a more empty movie than the likes of Batman, V for Vendetta or to a lesser extent Spider-man. Now don't get me wrong, its not a bad movie, but I don't think it will be one that a large audience will want to see again and again. I still think people should see it and enjoy it, but I think it will just be another Summer blockbuster.Like one of my good friends said, the movie was pretty well done, the action was kinda cool...but there's no possible way to be impressed or surprised by anything he does, thus taking away a lot of the fun one finds in these type movies!

He is the Man of Steel, the native son of Krypton, and the savior of humanity. He is Superman, and he has returned...Kind of. Superman Returns is the latest Superman flick starring Brandon Routh, Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth and it's been a while since the last Superman encounter which most are quick to forget. However, due to the enormous success of the X-Men and Spiderman movies as well as Batman Begins, we all knew it was a given that another Superman movie was on it's way. The only question is, just how much punch does this new Man of Steel pack? I'm going to start by going out on a limb and say that the first hour or so of the movie was not paced well or all that well put together. Unless you're a huge Superman nerd, you won't be able to help the fact that you're having trouble putting two and two together. Of course, all the Superman back story is eventually explained, but you'll have to wait a while to get it all. Too often at the beginning of the movie, the scene switches between Lex Luther (Spacey) and the returning Clark Kent (Routh). Normally this wouldn't be an issue, but it disrupted some of the flow that would have helped the movie establish itself more earlier.Perhaps the biggest problem with Superman Returns appears to be a case of identity crisis. This movie has a lot of trouble deciding what it wants to be. It shows flashes of brilliance in action and adventure but there's too much focus on the love square that has formed between Kent, Superman, Lois Lane (Bosworth) and her "fiancee" Richard White (played by James Marsden, most recognizable as Cyclops from the X-Men movies). However, any hope the movie has of being more of a drama is broken up by hilarious dialogue.Strangely enough though, this hodge podge of movie genres works rather well when it needs to. The action scenes are breathtaking, and the comedy element doesn't feel out of place. Bosworth and Routh work well together and Spacey plays Lex Luther as well as anyone could hope to. Superman Returns does a lot of things right, but considering how much better it could have been, it's a little disappointing. Returns is worth the price of admission and possibly a DVD purchase, but little else. The movie just suffers from too many little things.

I think this is one of the summer's best movies. It's a little slow at the beginning but doesn't come across as 'overdone'. It's definitely a worthy successor. Brandon Routh fills a very large pair of boots with aplomb and at times I wondered if they were showing footage of him or of Christopher Reeve their mannerisms and such were so similar. I know that some reviewers have referred to Kate Bosworth's performance as Lois Lane as rather dull, but personally as much as I liked the original Superman movie, I found Margot Kidder's Lois Lane so driven as to be almost obnoxious. Ms Bosworth's portrayal seemed more... realistic. If that's the right word. And Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor, he's definitely one of my favorite actors ever, he's so talented. I recommend seeing it, go expecting to entertained and you will not be disappointed. I would go see it again in a heartbeat, and that's not something I say about a lot of movies, not with ticket prices being what they are!

I can sum this movie up in just three words: Lois Lane Returns. I don't care how they change the story or about parts of the story that don't really jive with Superman's history. The only thing I care about is that when I go see something called Superman Returns I would actually like to see just that. There is way, way, way too much Lois Lane. There could not have been a worse choice than Kate Bosworth to play this part. Let's hope that Bryan Singer can deliver more Superman in the next film and less everything else. I don't mind the other characters, but they need to stay secondary where they are supposed to be. Just part of the scenery. At the end of this movie I was laughing because it just would not end.

Review Title: Well, he's back. And I for one am very happy.

Review: Superman Returns may be the most pompous and pretentious movie ever made in the history of cinema. Treating a comic-book character like he's Lawrence of Arabia or a virtual deity is ludicrous. Regarding the deity angle, let's not forget that no spirit or deity invested Superman with super powers. Rather Superman's super powers are the result of him being on a planet with a physical make up entirely different from the planet where he originated. Also, the acting in this movie is, like the movie itself, uninspiring and dull. Superman Returns contains what has to be the worst performance in Frank Langella's career. This is the first movie where the character Perry White is portrayed as being subdued and pensive, and a subdued and pensive Perry White is exactly what this movie could do without. Nobody in this movie is particularly exciting. Is this because of the director? Or the actors? Or the script? Who knows. Probably a combination of all three. But one thing is certain, if you decide to go watch this movie, don't forget to bring a pillow in case you doze off. Or better yet, bring a Superman comic book.

Review Title: "Superman" returns with a bang, and a few problems.
Review: Superman returns to the big screen with flashing colors and multi-million dollar special effects. In "Superman Returns", Brandon Routh fills the large shoes of Superman/ Clark Kent, and he does so well, although not as well as the late Christopher Reeve. Kevin Spacey takes on the notorious role of Lex Luthor, made famous by the legendary Gene Hackman. In the beginning, Superman returns to Earth from being in space for six years, investigating whether he is really the last of the Kryptons. When he finally returns, he finds that Lois Lane, the love of his life, has moved on and now has a fiancé and a son. Lex Luthor, Superman's old nemesis has devised a mastermind plan to wipe out most of the United States to create his own new continent with a crystal that came from Superman's home planet Kyripton. Superman must figure out a way to stop Lex Luthor, and at the same time win the heart of Lois Lane. Neither of these are an easy task...even for Superman. The movie as a whole is very entertaining. The movie seems to rely more on the visuals than on the drama, considering Superman gets very few speaking lines. I was a little disappointed about the lack of fighting scenes between Superman and villains. There was plenty of flying around in the clouds, but very little, if not no combat. There was really only one scene that brought the movie past the PG realm and into PG-13. Also the movie was a little bit longer than necessary, with a running time of over 2 and a half hours. The movie had it's moments, but there were a few that didn't seem needed in the final cut. It's very interesting to see an updated version of the world of Superman with state-of-the-art special effects, however it has some flaws like the above and also the poor casting and directing of Lois Lane, who brought pretty much nothing to the table above standing around. Don't get the wrong idea though. It is still a very good movie, but it's not by any means perfect. Even so, Superman will always marvel the audience. No matter what.

Review Title: Even Superman's fans will get bored on this one..
Review: This movie is so stupid it should be censored by law. Too bad it misses the blurb and the fart scene to make it a "perfect" American comedy. If you guys and gals have some brain left DON't watch this movie. Of course unless you get paid for it. I would rate it somewhere between 20 and 30 bucks and hour. Even Supermans fans will get bored on this one... Oh, IMDb forces me to put ten lines so I have to continue... With what? There is nothing else to say about this movie. It's ridiculous, makes no sense it has a bad, really bad story line. Even the actors have no fun playing it. Special effects? What special effects? Bottom line you don't have to be super-smart to understand how super-bad is superman returns.

I'm quoting from a friend of mine who saw the film and regretted it. I knew not to go see it after what he said. Here's what he said...Terrible. The movie casts Superman as someone who knocks up his girl friend, then skips out of town.... Lois Lane is a shack-up kinda girl after that.... and oh yes, Jimmy Olsen is gay.So - Superman is a Whore,Lois Lane is a Slut, Superboy is a bastard child,and Jimmy Olsen is gay,Welcome to Metroplois!Next episode: Lois and Superman have it out on Jerry Springer.

Review Title: The movie was good but boring at the same time.
Review: The movie was good because of the FX and cinematography. The movie itself was boring. The three way relationship took up too much screen time. I felt sorry for Richard. This dude been taking care of this kid for the past five years. Jason even calls him "daddy". Lois doesn't show any respect to this man. Supermans momma had to wait outside the hospital. That was amazing. Lex Luther's idea was ridiculous. The whole movie and that was it. Superman is the dude on the side. He doesn't plan on sticking' around, paying' child support or nothing'. He basically was happy the entire movie. Did he even hit anybody. He was too happy sucking in the media attention. The film had no excitement at all. And he stalked, and spied on, this lady like he was crazy.

I thoroughly enjoyed this film. I remember sitting in the theatre as a 12 year old with tears of excitement as Superman saved Lois Lane and the falling helicopter, thus introducing himself to the unsuspecting people of Metropolis. I felt the same way in Superman Returns as he announced his return in such a spectacular way. Well done on a great escape from the day to day reality of a world that could use a Superman to fight for truth, justice and the "International" way. We need heroes, we need to be able to escape the mundane, we need to be able to immerse ourselves in a film and to forget about the outside world for a couple of hours...hooray for the superhero movie.

Review Title: Old Superman movies were way better
Review: When I first saw the high rating of the movie I thought finally a good comeback of the famous MARVEL hero. But the whole movie was boring. Every next step of the characters were predictable. The action effects haven't been extraordinary at all. Good old superman could have done nearly the same. Even in Smallville I've seen as good or better effects.The only thing I liked about the movie was the quality and the selection of the actors. Everyone fits perfectly into their roles.I hope the next superman movie will be better, no it has to be, because Superman has never been that worse.

Review Title: Good Lord! It's Superman. Or is that vice versa?
Review: What a waste of two-plus hours.Script -- bad. How 'bout giving actors of Kevin Spacey's and Parker Posey's talents something to work with? And for the love of all that's good, 150 minutes?! You need Superman's kryptonic bladder for this. And for a movie that's likely going to Casting -- not much better. Kate Bosworth? Yeah, she seems like a Pulitzer-prize-winning journalist with a five-year-old. When did she have the kid -- when she was 12? And speaking of the kid - he needs a new agent. Give him some lines, for the love of Pete. Why hire Eva Marie Saint and then WASTE HER?! And tone down the violence. FOr a movie that is aimed at kids (at least I felt most of the script was very much aimed at kids) some of the violence in the latter part of the movie is way too graphic and unnecessary.Effects -- okay.Music -- I have to say, that Superman main theme is so fabulous. Stirring, upbeat, and lovely.Symbolism -- Oy vey! What was this, Mel Gibson's "The Passion of the Supes?!" Here's a helpful note for the director -- they spell it "Symbol" as opposed to "Cymbal" because it shouldn't ring in your ears like a clanging, clashing blast of cymbals.If you must, rent it on DVD. Or even better, rent Donner's Superman 1.

Review Title: A good return to the big screen.
Review: For chronological reasons in- and outside of the movie itself, "Superman Returns" is a unique sequel. This is not "Batman Begins", which ignored all previous incarnations and essentially started anew; nor is it "X2", which follows on the heels of the original; nor is it one of the first three "Batman" sequels, all of which trailed the 1989 version by an undefined but irrelevant period of time. Director Bryan Singer's film occurs five years after "Superman II", under the (wistful) pretenses that the third and fourth installments of the series never happened. Additionally the two predecessors that "Returns" does follow were released over a quarter century ago, so largely (and sadly) unknown to much of today's audience. Therefore the franchise is simultaneously continued and reinvented, a strange dichotomy upon which "Returns" finds both its strongest and weakest moments.Often a movie succeeds in telling its story well but falls short in the little areas that can push it several levels higher. The first two "Harry Potter" movies, for example, tell the books' stories and portray the universe effectively, but lack the character and cinematic touches that Alfonso Cuaron so brilliantly infused into "Prisoner of Azkaban". "Superman Returns" accomplishes the opposite, nailing the little things but sometimes missing the overall target. Writer/director Bryan Singer ("The Usual Suspects", "X-Men") and company clearly understand the Superman mythos established by previous incarnations of the hero. They wisely choose to borrow John Williams' original theme, imitate the original credits, and include plenty lines that refer to the first two films. Some lines are quoted directly (Superman's comment about the safety of flying), while other words reinforce previously established traits (like Lois' inability to spell). This attention to detail leaves fans of those movies with a sweet taste on their cinematic tongues, but one that may be indistinguishable to ignorant viewers.Brandon Routh's performance as the Man of Steel does likewise. He enthralls with an eerie ability to channel Christopher Reeve's presence, physical and vocal mannerisms, and charming clumsiness. Whether this is a testament to Routh's mimicry skills or to how well Reeve defined the role is debatable, but either way Routh deserves praise for filling the part well, as does Singer for casting an unknown, a fact that may have helped Routh match Superman's alien status. These components supply the high points of the film, as "Returns" captures the all-important mystique of Superman that was present in "I" and "II".The same cannot be said of many of the movie's choices, which lack the cohesion of a great film. Kevin Spacey provides a microcosm of the problem. Gene Hackman played Lex Luthor with a perfect concoction of darkness and comedy. Evil tinged his humor and humor tinged his evil. Spacey's Luthor possesses both qualities, but at disparate times, creating a distracting bipolar antagonist out of a single-minded villain. I'm not a big fan of Kate Bosworth's turn either. She embodies the hard-nosed journalist side of Lois Lane well, but her human side appears too intentionally cynical and invulnerable. Admittedly though, Lois should have changed over the missing five years, so perhaps I merely long for Margot Kidder's fantastic work. Bosworth tries hard, but never looks quite right or finds the balance of Lois as investigator and love interest.This thread of inconsistency snakes through the entire movie, even into the overall storyline, which is fairly standard superhero stuff: Superman...uh..returns to a retro-futuristic Metropolis, where he must confront his past with Lois while dealing with Luthor's nefarious schemes. That much is fine, but an anticipatory undercurrent flows beneath the waves. Singer was successful with the X-Men franchise in part because he told the story and did not over-emphasize the underlying built-in analogies of the mutants. Here he inserts a discordant arc that, as it surfaces, convolutes and stretches a simple story with twisted aspirations to a greater or more complex level of cinema. A noble effort, and one that may be more appreciated in the long run, but for now falls flat.Despite these flaws, "Superman Returns" is still an excellent movie experience, a fact that speaks to the nonpareil power of the Superman mythos. The movie's overwhelming Superman-ness saves it much like Superman looks to save humanity. He exhibits relatable characteristics taken from every other recent silver screen star: the outsider nature of the X-Men, the awkward everyman side of Peter Parker, Batman's seeming infallible desire to eliminate crime. Superman is good and uncomplicated. He stands for truth, justice, and the American way; he awkwardly seeks acceptance; he scarcely harms anyone; he grew up on an idyllic farm in Kansas. He is Norman Rockwell's superhero. Singer seems to understand this, doling out the full iconic treatment through classic framing, sweeping camera movement, and the aforementioned cinematic touches. The only misstep is in the overly dramatic tone of this deification, which drifts to the serious side. The original has a twinkle-in-the-eye attitude, one that winks at the silliness of a man in tights, one that is more uplifting in many respects, such as the way it conveys the joy of flying. "Returns" utilizes slightly too heavy a hand, failing to fully communicate the exhilarating experience, but definitely succeeding in portraying the grandness of Superman. In the superhero universe, I have long been a Batman guy, and I still am, but this movie reiterates what many already know: Superman is the best. End of discussion.Just as "Superman Returns" as a whole is a dynamic paradox of past, present, and future, many of its parts are a series of contradictions that do not completely find a proper middle ground. Although very entertaining, the end result does not strike as deep as it could have, leaving the viewer with a pleasant saccharine sensation that masks a lingering bitter aftertaste.Bottom Line: "Superman Returns" is magnetically appealing, a welcome adventure back into the world of Superman, one that ought to be seen on the big screen. 7 of 10.

Review Title: Thoroughly entertaining, but not without problems
Review: Bryan Singer established himself as the premiere visionary for comic book based movies with his take on the X-Men in the first two films. With Superman Returns, he changes the dynamics of his comic book perception, which becomes both a good and bad thing.Superman Returns continues the flow of the Richard Donner line of films, continuing from where Superman II left off. But, instead of focusing on nothing but action, Superman Returns focuses on the relationship between Superman/Clark Kent and Lois Lane and how sometimes the most painful thing to an invulnerable creature is that which tears at its heart. In this aspect, Superman Returns is a refreshing view of comic book sensibilities, exposing a great deal of depth that is usually overlooked when translating comic characters to the big screen.The drawback to all the added focus to the emotional side of the story is that the action scenes play out almost dutifully with a major lack of sensibility. The action scenes seem almost used only to move the story along rather than being critical to the overall picture. In fact, after several weeks I can barely remember much about the action scenes whereas the human interaction scenes I can recall with great detail. As well, there are some major leaps in logic in how the final action scene plays out, making it almost disappointing.The other major drawback is in trying to update the film to modern times without putting enough thought into context. While Perry White talks about "truth, justice and all that other stuff" (more on that gaffe later) in a modernized newspaper environment, the notion that any newspaper in modern times would have as much gleam and glisten as this film's Daily Planet has is beyond credible. With televisions hanging from every other support column in the Daily Planet office, one must question why the screenwriters would choose to update the minor stuff like famous catchphrases while ignoring the obvious fact that in modern times the Daily Planet of the stature we see in this film would more likely be a cable news station than a newspaper. In this, some of the updates just simply don't make sense compared to things left untouched.There has been much criticism leveled at the film for its abandonment of the classic catchphrase, "truth, justice and the American way." The screenwriters' response was tepid at best in suggesting that the reasoning had to do with Superman being an international hero and that the "American way" has a different modern meaning that might not sit with some. I'm a Canadian, so it's not like that really affected me on a patriotic level. But, there is obviously more to it than what the writers allude to in that when Lex Luthor talked about fire being stolen from the Gods and given to humanity in the form of technology, saying roads gave the Romans power and ships gave Britain its power, they ignored the flow that would yield American power based on airplanes or the space program in favor of mentioning the atom bomb. Obviously, the screenwriters felt that focusing on anything nice in particular about America would be a bad thing.It is unfortunate that the screenwriters and Bryan Singer were embarrassed enough of their heritage and politically obsessed enough that they had to force a political issue when it never would have arisen otherwise, as -- like a fart in a taxi cab -- it became a big, useless distraction in both enjoyment and discussion of this film. This could be the perfect example of how sometimes screenwriters should learn to leave well enough alone and realize that taking the smallest things too seriously can ruin things for their intended audience. Not everybody is as obsessed over every element in their lives being about political considerations, so to make such a major change (let's face it... changing a slogan is a BIG change) for such a minor reason just leaves a bad taste.Considering the underwhelming box-office take of Superman Returns thus far ($140 million domestically against a $250-$300 million budget), these may be some lessons to be heeded in the future. Overall, Superman Returns is a fun film to watch as long as you don't take it too seriously. Compared to Bryan Singer's X-Men films, Sam Raimi's Spider-Man films or Christopher Nolan's take on the Dark Knight in Batman Begins, it doesn't really stand up. But as a film you can kick back and enjoy, it certainly fills that need.

I thought some scenes could have been a little brighter, and a little less plotting by Lex, but all in all LOVED the movie. Did anyone else notice the circle mist around Superman when he broke the sound barrier??? This is what really happens when a jet does the same thing. Great move on their part. I think they should have let you have a better look at Noel if they were going to use her , unlike Jimmy Olson ( the bartender Jack Larson) who got lots of good screen time. I would really like to know why it only brought in 57 million the first week, and what was this with opening june 30 2006 and then opening june 28 2006??? and in one documentary I saw in early they talked of how well it did when it opened June 30 and this was early June.

In the beginning,I was very worried about how this movie was going to be depicted and filmed, but they did a great job. I loved it just as much as the ones starring the late Christopher Reeves. At first, I wasn't sure if anyone would have been able to fill those tights as well as he did, but Brandon Routh did an amazing performance. And there was this one moment with Perry where I thought it may have been off with his character. Other than that,the story was very interesting, (there were just a few things I wish they could have shown) and I cannot wait until the sequel comes out, but for now I will probably see it one more time in the theaters before I have to wait for it on DVD. Review Title: Well made, though with too much Hollywood cultural indoctrination
Terrific change break from comic-book-to-movie genre
Review: This movie will not have the latest Dashboard Confessional, JET, or some other alternative rock band playing for all the fight scenes and sure it starts out slow but I truly enjoyed it. Spiderman is great and all, but I think the differences between the two are what makes Superman really good.Kate Bosworth makes a really great Lois Lane and Brandon Routh will remind you of Tom Cruise in some scenes. Kevin Spacey is amazing as the bald Lex Luther. He truly knows how to capture the evil & sinister character. Parker Posey is Lex's sidekick as Kitty. She seems to be in with his evil plan for the money but has a side of compassion that Posey is really good at expressing.There are some really great parts of Superman Returns that emphasize the importance of heroes. Lois Lane writes an article in the movie, "Why the World Doesn't Need Superman" while it is quite evident that it does.I would definitely see this in theaters for the cool effects and not wait till it hits your local Blockbuster.

I saw Superman Returns this afternoon. Boringly safe. That's how Singer played it. Continued where the 70/80's movies left off. With a Superman/Clark Kent that looks a lot like Christopher Reeve. But less in this case would have been more. Now, I kept comparing. I've never felt myself doing that during 'Lois & Clark', with Dean Cain. And Brandon Routh looks younger than Christopher Reeve in his first Superman movie. Couldn't the producers find an actor in his mid-thirties? I liked Reeve's performance better - here, you feel like Routh wants to fill somebody else's shoes and boots, instead of playing the part(s) like he wants to. And is it me, or was there any chemistry between Lois and Clark at all? I didn't sense it anyway. Not like between Terri Hatcher and Dean Cain; or Christopher Reeve and Margot Kidder. Kate Bosworth is very pretty, but lacked the spunk, the zest of the other two. Maybe having a son does that to an intrepid female reporter? Kevin Spacey was very good, although they gave him a second hand plot to work with. And I must say I understood Gene Hackman's diabolic plan, but here, it's kind of convoluted. Besides, the comic, Lois & Clark and Smallville have redefined Luthor: he's a shrewd business man. Not some kind of megalomanic con artist. Kitty whatshername: miss Teschmacher with black hair. Dumb, and compassionate. Instead of making her a character that made Lex Luthor look like a choirboy. Good thing about the movie: Superman has a son. Hopefully, we're in for a more interesting sequel. The special effects are great. But that's hardly a surprise in this day and age, is it? Very much appreciated: they kept the Superman theme. Goosebumps every time I hear it... Bottom line: this one was only so-so, but I can hardly wait for the next one. It's a flaw, I know...

Review: I heard in the t.v,newspapers,and talking about Superman Returns saying that it was good so I wanted to see it. So I went and I saw it and I have to saw this was not very good like I heard and what they told me. This had great and wonderful effects and action that was perfect.But some of the talking parts and the beginning didn't fit in with the movie .Many people say it was a great movie for the family,I say rent it on DVD or VHS instead of watching it in the theater.Nothing against the movie and the director but just giving the director a tip,if you make a bit understanding in the movie I will give it 4,but it didn't.Other than that enjoy Superman's strength and action against Lex Luthor.Which Lex Luther and his crew did a great job in the movie,funny but serious at the same time.And scary part when one of the dogs ate the other dog,creepy.

Superman Returns wasn't what I expected it to be. Yes, I did want to see this, and yes, it's probably the best movie I've seen in awhile. I thought that this film would be just 'okay,' not much of a thriller, but boy, was I wrong or what! Watching Superman-goodness on the big screen satisfied me. Action packed, and dramatic scenes kept me awake. As for the heartbreaking, and heart-mending scenes, they made me cry. This film has what I'm looking for in films. But nonetheless, I think that Superman Returns has opened up a new world for our newbie, Brandon Routh.Superman Returns is one of the best movies of 2006, in my opinion.06-28-06: Look up in the sky. He's always there.

Review Title: Superman vs. Lex Luthor? Been there, done that.
Send this version to Krypton and outta here!

Review: I have never really been a huge fan of Superman. I watched the Adventures of Lois and Clark and Smallville when they were on TV, but I never really got into the character. Superman was to impervious for me. He wasn't real enough. Not that a man fusing with a spider was any more believable. Superman just seemed too untouchable for me. His only weakness is Kyptonite, which isn't readily available all the time. My mind has changed after seeing this movie. I walked into the theatre not expecting much. I walked out wanting to see it again. So, I went and rented Superman 1 and 2, then I went and saw it again a week later.I was so amazed at everything about the movie: the colors, the acting, the sound effects, but most of all I was impressed by the Visual Effects. They were breathtaking. They were the best that I have ever seen(and I see a lot of movies). So if you just want to see really cool special effects then go to this movie. I also like the love story.

Review Title: A Perfect Sequel, From Paper To Production
Superman III, Part 2: An Argument Against "Superman Returns"
Review: If fellow IMDb voters are basing their rave reviews of "Superman Returns" on the mere fact that it's better than the FIRST attempt at a Superman III (the one with Richard Pyror, remember?), then indeed this movie is superb; make that FANTASTIC: the greatest, most fulfilling superhero movie to date. However, to my monumental disappointment, it isn't. At over 150 minutes, we are offered nothing new in comparison to the previous installments besides a longer running time. No new ground is covered that wasn't already four times before. Lex Luthor is STILL the bad guy, while the diverse Superman rogue gallery (Bizarro, Braniac, Metallo, Darkseid, and Doomsday to name a few) remains completely untouched. Did the producers of "Superman Returns" not realize that this formula had been all tapped out by parts 3 and 4? This film proves that the solution for making up for Supermans III and IV is NOT to pretend as if they never existed, but to start a new franchise."Superman Returns" is religiously devoted to the Donner-Superman, so much so that it copies it. For some inexplicable reason, it attempts to pick-up the story from Superman II and worse, resurrect Marlon Brando's famous "lost footage". It also manages to mangle any chances of a decent sequel by giving Superman a kid, something so cheap and opportunistic that even DC Comics hasn't thought of it. But what's missing from this devout mistake is the irreplaceable presence of Christopher Reeve and Margot Kidder as Lois Lane. This movie is so badly miscast in its two leads that you could say this Superman III has TWO Gus Gormans instead of one. Make that two Nuclear Men: Brandon Routh is completely without presence, an emotionally challenged amateur. While Kidder's Lois Lane was sassy, Kate Bosworth has no character to work with. Lois is as lifeless as Superman, not that she is absolved of any guilt: Bosworth herself proves she is talented only at gracing CVS make-up displays, furthuring the notion that dating Orlando Bloom is part of a resume. Given her performance in this film, I'm inclined to say it is her best part yet. And one has to feel sorry for poor Kevin Spacey, who's given the unfortunate task of playing a rich villain like Lex Luthor with the one-notedness that Singer's writers give him. Spacey plays Luthor so over the top that you begin to appreciate how, even in the midst of such cinematic bile as "Superman IV: The Quest for Peace", Gene Hackman towed the line between humor and chutzpah. As for the Luthor character himself, why do the films insist on making him the sole villain time and time again? Why always make him a jester obsessed with real estate? These were FAULTS of the earlier films, not strengths. If you're unfamiliar with these criticisms, then look no further than the "Man of Steel" comic (or even Smallville for that matter) from 1986 and you'll see what I mean. Lex Luthor's comics persona is so much more interesting that it truly is a shame that Singer refuses to give him these pernicious touches and instead prefers a lightweight caricature. Why does this film not start from the beginning and start anew? What is the purpose of making Superman Returns a sequel, besides causing confusion in some viewers and to remind others of how much this film pales in comparison to Superman's I and II. After something as fulfilling and as involving as "Batman Begins", how can anyone find this good? I suspect that part of the basis for a positive review is 50% based on the mere fact that Superman is on screen and you're alive to sit down and watch him in a theater. In that case, you will love this movie. Or if you're looking for a "Beyond the Sea" reunion, then you also might like this movie. Otherwise there doesn't seem to be a legitimate reason to. Bryan Singer, who made two great movies out of the X-Men comic books, fails at Superman because he offers no new interpretation of it. You'll derive more entertainment from a John Byrne comic, because truthfully, there's more life in the ink version of Superman then there is in this entire 154-minute chore of a movie. Superman does indeed return, but with nothing to offer but a rehash of the more lively Christopher Reeve films.

I didn't expect to enjoy Superman Returns 2006 as much as I did. The acting was excellent and the new superman showed a softer more human side. The villain, played by Kevin Spacey was outstanding. The story reflects changes in our modern day values that were completely different from the days of the original TV superman. Although it's two and a half hours long, it never got boring. From beginning to end, I was completely captivated by a well written story, and the special effects that were exceptional. The scene on the airplane deserves your undivided attention because I found it very intense and especially amusing after I thought about it for a while.

Two and a Half Hours i can never get back
Review: I will make this as short and simple as possible.I love Superman.......BUT this film was horrible1)The story had more holes in it than Fifty cents face. 2)The only 3D scene that was worth putting my glasses on was the airplane scene. 3)superman needing an oxygen mask in the hospital???????? "You'll be different. Sometimes, you will feel like an outcast. But you'll never be alone. You will make my strength your own. You will see my life through your eyes - as your life will be seen through mine.The son becomes the father, and the father becomes the son."Can Superman really die? Yes! But like us all he can be saved too.Brandon Routh makes an admirable Superman - I really liked him over all the other characters. Frank Langella is a great Perry White but Lois is a bit meh.And Lex Luthor - Kevin Spacey was always going to struggle against Gene Hackman's performance in the original Superman films - a few lines are even ripped from the earlier scripts.Special effects are impressive - especially the opening credits which takes the groundbreaking style of the original movie and really runs with it. It must have been one of the hardest sequences to make for the film.I really hope a new Routh as Superman movie is made as he was the best thing about the film, which is admirably dedicated to the memory of Christopher and Dana Reeve.Nice to know Superman will "always be around".

Review Title: disappointing and dragging when at its worst
A fine film finally back on the big screen!
Review: After waiting all my childhood to see another superman movie on the silver screen, it was definitely worth the wait. After more than a decade of development hell, the project finally got off the ground and took flight. As i heard the news of this, i was in usual disbelief, but not only was it real it was unreal that Bryan Singer was taking the helm of the man of steel, now you know that the movie was in good hands if his name is attached! Sitting in the theater I couldn't help but smile through the whole movie, it was a pretty long smile! Brandon Routh was fantastic, he surpassed my expectations, Kevin Spacey added just what Lex Luthor lacked in the original films and of course my hometown Sydney Australia acted as the backdrop for Metropolis. A 2 1/2 hour fun ride finally here for our turn to enjoy, as well generating a new fan base for the younger viewers. Nothing negative about this film, sure as hell looking forward to the next one =)

Review Title: Superman Returns and its about time
Thanks Bryan - Superman is simply an excellent superhero movie !
Review: Everything fits and it is a beautiful reminiscence to the original movies! Imagine there is a great superhero movie with a calm speed, a straight story and a perfect casting. Voila - you've found Superman returns! Great action and simply a great cast of actors. Bryan Singer did simply everything right! Shame it's not THAT successful - especially compared to the dull PIRATES sequel (but that's another story). Beginning with the title and use of the original score and a fantastic cinematography, everything is quiet perfect. And never forget Christopher Reeve - the real life hero who died all to soon! I hope there will be more Superman movies!

I saw Superman Returns opening weekend. I thought that the action was really well done, and that the characters were some what well developed. There was only one thing i really had a problem with that i will not discuss because it can be classified as a spoiler. Lets just say that a certain portion of the film was sprung on the viewing audience and made us think about where the hell they got this information from. Other then that "minor" detail the movie was enjoyable and the tribute to Christopher Reeves was done really well. I also liked the fact that they used the same music and the same credit style in the beginning of the film which was well intended i believe to convey a sense of continuation from the original films to transit into this one. I think that a sequel might be in order, since I'm pretty sure lots of people might be tired of seeing Lex Luther on the screen, maybe they should try Braniac?

Review Title: Better than films no. 3 and 4 at least !!
Review: I was surprised to see that they were gonna remake Superman, I didn't think it was time. But then this Superman returns theme kicked in (well, I read more about it and found out) and I bought it. I thought it was a little bit odd, but okay. However, I was more surprised by the rave reviews it seemed to get instantly from many critics, and I am comparing this for example to X-Men: The Last Stand... since Bryan Singer departed from X-men to do Superman. I found X-Men 3 to be a much more fun picture than Superman Returns. I think the X-Men trilogy is a great one, and I believe the Superman franchise is great as well. But I didn't have many expectations for this movie and I wasn't completely disappointed, but I wanted more. Brandon Routh is awesome in his dual role and striking resemblance to Christopher Reeve, but since I started comparing and thinking about the four other Superman movies, I cannot help to think that Bosworth was okay as Lois but I liked Kidder better, Spacey is funny and good as Luthor but I liked Hackman better, other familiar figures were equally fun, but the storyline to pictures no. 1 and 2 is much better than in Superman Returns.I am not gonna write details about the storyline, because that would give up too much. But the climax and ending for me were a bit disappointing for me. The possibility of a sequel is there, no problem, but will it be done? It is hard to improve a great score by John Williams, and it is certainly not done here. The cinematography though is great and the new costume looks cool. Special effects naturally better (one wonders how they managed to have the fourth movie with such bad effects!) and well ... quite honestly: the film looked really really good.In the end, you gotta give credit to all people involved (Singer and the actors and all the crew...) for reviving this series. Out of the five movies this one is strongly no. 3, with the original being no. 1 and the second one no. 2. I had fun despite I thought it was lacking in some ways. Cannot describe any clearer, it has an 8 in my book now.

I may ramble on here but heres my take on Superman Returns.I am a 38 year old male, married with three children. In 1978 I pestered my parents to take me to see 'Superman The Movie'. Over about a twelve month period I had seen Star Wars, Grease and a couple of other fliks I can't really remember. I was about ten years old at the time and I wasn't a real comic book fan. I remember watching Superman the Movie had a profound effect on me which stays with me to this day. I can't really say what it was but I just loved that movie. I moved towns not long after and a few years down the line Superman II was released. I was old enough now to visit the local cinema on my own and must have viewed both Superman II and Empire Strikes Back numerous times (staying in the toilets between showings). Up until my mid-teens I had a poster of Christopher Reeve on my bedroom wall, the head shot smile, sort of looking back. I went to see Superman III and IV and did enjoy them but I always remember reading a newspaper or mag that said Reeve cried when he saw what they did with IV and I agreed. When it was announced Singer and Warners had agreed I was like a man walking over hot coals. My wife has suffered me since the teaser trailer came out around Xmas time. My kids think I'm just 'plain ol' crazy' I think, but suffer it.Now the history is out of the way here we go.Routh...Masterful choice. I loved Reeve as Superman and I guess a lot of my generation will always think of him as 'the' Superman. My wife sat there (shes ten years my junior) and I had tears in my eyes when Routh entered that plane and asked Lois 'Are you OK?' my wife nudged me as though to ask 'What the f~~?'. 'The f~~' was the fact I had waited twenty years for this moment. I thought Routh was everything I hoped he would be. I loved him as Superman and I thought he played Clark better than Reeve. I loved the superlistening bits and xray sight thru things to look at the women he loves. I WOULD DO IT! A lot of people say 'he looks and acts to much like Reeve', these are the same people who are saying 'there is only one Superman - Reeve'. If any one of us had met Routh and were casting this flik - THEY WOULD HAVE CAST HIM. Last line on Routh - loved you Brandon...You are this generations Clark and Superman. Fantastic Performance all round!!!!!!Bosworth...Nice. OK, all the crap going round - 'She's too young' to play Lois and the rest of the crap. I thought she played it well. It was never going to be easy for any of the cast and crew on Returns. She looked so much better with the dark hair it was unbelievable. Great choice simply because Singer and Warners know there is at least a good couple of sequels here between Routh and Bosworth. The scene on the plane where Lois sees Superman flash past the window for the first time in years was brilliant.Spacey...When announced - I knew he would deliver and he did. I always thought Hackman was just a bit too camp at times and ultimately a bit unbelievable as a threat. Spacey delivers the Lex I wanted. When his thugs are beating the crap out of Superman the look in his eye is awesome.Singer...Thanks. I have waited for this for so long and you didn't disappoint. As I said, I am not a comic book fan, I am a fan of the Superman movies and Singer has presented a heart felt production that carries on what I felt for those films. I just knew from the off when the Warners logo and music started and he added the Superman touch it was going to be something special.Flik...I loved it. Routh totally owned his roles. Bosworth was convincing. Spacey WAS Lex. Supporting cast did a great job. I felt the story continued on from Superman II well. I agree with the way Singer went. He could have totally revamped it but didn't. When you look back now at Supes I & II, especially II they look really dated. The way Singer has weaved his magic on this is to take the best elements of the first two fliks and reinvent them in a way but adding his own touch. I really enjoyed this to the point of tears and if it was twice as long I would have been happy. I always wished that they would almost 'remake' the first two fliks with todays advancements and I felt Singer and crew achieved this with Returns. I went with real expectation and just sat there and was blown away. My Superman has Returned!

I watched this film last night at work (cinema) and i thought it was garbage. It was too long and drawn out for what actually happened. Lex Luthor could have been more evil as to be honest there wasn't really a clear divide between good and evil after all its based on a comic so the divide is important. The concept of superman having a child is beyond reason as his sperm would most likely shoot through Lois like a bullet. yes yes yes i know he was changed into a mortal in Superman 2 and slept with Lois but if this child was his then he wouldn't have super powers that we see touched upon in the film. He was mortal therefore would pass on his mortal self!

I'm a big fan of superhero movies. I really loved Batman Begins last summer. I've enjoyed the Spider Man movies, and I thought Brian Singer did a wonderful job with the first two X- Men movies.Singer did an amazing job with Superman Returns. He has made Superman my favorite superhero. He develops the characters beautifully. I really had a lot of sympathy for Superman and what he was going through emotionally, intellectually, physically and even spiritually. Brandon Routh is an absolutely superb Superman. He was perfect in fact! I appreciated that there was not the emphasis on his being some muscle-bound superhero. He didn't need it. Brandon played the nerdy Clark Kent very convincingly and then switched to the confident Superman seamlessly.In fact, I thought the whole movie was seamless. The effects were amazing, and they only added to the overall mood without dominating the film. I still can't get the view of Superman hovering in space with his cape floating without gravity's effects. The stillness and quiet of the space while Superman looks down and listens to all the sounds coming from earth—that was a beautiful sight. I'm so glad that swooshing sounds were not added to Superman flying at faster than a bullet speed!I really loved this movie! It left me feeling great at the end of it all. I want to see it again which is a rare thing for me to admit. Thanks Brian Singer. I've never been one to really go to a particular movie just because someone stars in it or has a particular director, but I definitely will pay attention to a film just because you directed it. Thanks so much.

Superman Returns was a really good movie but do not read this if you have not seen the movie yet.
Review: Well Superman Returns was a great movie to me and I hope they will make more movies of it. But one thing that bugged me a bit was that the kid had powers and now there's Superboy and I really don't like Superboy. Superman is the great one. So if you have not seen Superman returns yet you should see it soon because it is a great movie other then everything else that happened in the whole movie. So Superman Returns was great movie and I am going to buy that movie the first day it comes out on DVD.
