Superman Returns is OK, but not awesome. I liked the fact they used the original music and i liked how they linked it to the original Superman movies. The special effects are very good and there's some good insights into Superman's character. Brandon Routh makes a decent Superman, but not a great one. Basically, he's imitating the Christopher Reeve Superman, which is fine, I suppose. The only problem is when you spend your time imitating someone else you'll always be second best. If there's another movie, I'd kind of like to see Routh put his own spin on Superman, rather than just trying to be the new Christopher Reeve.As others have pointed out, there's a lot of Christian symbolism in this movie. They seem to be presenting Superman as a sort of Christ figure. Never thought of that angle before, but strangely enough it was these parts of the movie worked the best.Now a superhero movie wouldn't be a superhero movie without some type of threat to humanity to deal with and this "threat" is where most of my criticisms are centred. Overall, I didn't care much for Kevin Spacey's portrayal of Lex Luthor, he just didn't seem to have much depth as a character. I never really understood just what Luthor was hoping to accomplish with his scheme. To me, the whole "new land mass" plot kind of, well...sucked.

Review Title: Wish I could get a refund

Review: The superhuman analogies in the movie are an excellent reminder where, as humans, we have to go to and where we come from. The movie contains many subtle references to civilizations as there are the Greeks, Romans and even the still doubted Atlantis. The superhuman respect and love expressed by superman is a beautiful association to great individuals like Christ or mythological figures like Hercules and atlas.In fact what would bring humanity into motion? All great individuals in history could not do it. It's the job of an evil being, like the seductive, cruel, vicious, heartless Lex Luthor, to bring out the superhuman powers.I left the theater with a feeling of let's do it, let's prove that we still can achieve some great things which will lift us above the mediocre level this current civilization has. I'm a fan.

Overall, it was OK. But for a movie 2 decades in the waiting that is just not good enough. We see some interesting stuff put in by the makers, but the storyline still lacked some needed edge. Although somewhat leaving something for movie-goers to look forward too in the next installment.Brandon Routh looked like a geek out of HS, good for the Clark Kent character, bad for Superman. Superman was supposed to be the MAN, not a geek wearing a cape. Routh's portrayal didn't look "super" enough, didn't look powerful enough. Not too masculine. I guess he was a little too baby-faced to be a convincing all-powerful superhero we all know. Again, an OK performance, but not good enough. Hopefully they do something about it in the next movie.I've always loved Kevin Spacey. He was entertaining, to say the least. Not the best Lex in my opinion, but somehow pulled out a convincing performance. look forward to seeing his character develop in the next installment.

Review Title: See it, but don't expect much magic!
Review: After years of struggle and debate Hollywood has finally seen to it that Superman once again takes to the big screen. The producers spared little expense and delivered in creating yet another superbly crafted comic strip, larger than life movie. In the same vain as X-Men and Spiderman, Superman Returns is visually stunning and perhaps outdoes any predecessor in the genre with the score. John Williams was again forced out of retirement to pen the score for the film and as usual he wrote magic.The music is critical and usually sets the tone for the entire film, but it turned out to be a bit of a tease in this case. From the opening credits we are swept into a Superman fanfare that is riveting and reminiscent of a past cinematic era. I was filled with anticipation, believing that the music was proof enough that this was a true, old-fashioned Hollywood blockbuster. And yet, as soon as the movie begins the air begins to leak from the excitement until it is nearly flat.While I agree with the creators that this movie needed to be a sequel in the long series of Superman movies and not another attempt to reinvent the wheel, I simply didn't believe the story and especially the way it was told. The film begins with a world without Superman. He has been MIA for five years as he 'retired' to return to his home planet to observe the destruction. When he returns he is down-trodden, guilt ridden, and introspective about the meaning of life and his duty to fulfill destiny. Superman is cast in a Christ-like manner, as the 'savior' and redeemer of the 'sin of the world.' The religious overtones run throughout the film. And yet, just as we are led to believe that excitement is around the corner we are instead forced to tolerate Clark Kent's awkward return to work and his realization that even his beloved Lois Lane has moved on and is with Richard and now has a son.Kevin Spacey brings the only drama and suspense to the film in his portrayal of Lex Luther. And yet, even he and his haphazard posse are weak. Spacey's Luther was more of an angry imbecile instead of an evil genius. For most of the movie we are left to laugh as he and the gang devise a ridiculous scheme to rule the world. And not once do we really consider that they might just be successful. This is due to the fact that Routh's depressed Superman finally comes to life as he combats his inner demons and realizes his ultimate role in society. Yet here again is another weak performance. He appeared more like a child playing dress-up than the man of steel himself. The same goes for Kate Bosworth's portrayal of Lois Lane. By the end of the film I was begging for Gene Hackman, Margot Kidder, and of course, Christopher Reeve. This latest attempt is merely fodder under the feat of the original! Having said all of this, Superman Returns, like all of the others of the genre, is a moral story fit for audiences of all ages. He stands as the noble hero for all of us to admire and emulate. Receiving even more positive points is that the film is drug/sex/language free, thus suitable for all.

Review Title: Does some things good, but fails at lots of others

Review: Yes, I am one of the true believers in Superman. What most people are forgetting is that the movie remains true to everything that is Superman. Furthermore, the special effects in this movie are awesome. Brandon Routh really shines as Superman/Clark Kent. Superman leaves to visit his home world and when he returns he finds that Lois has moved on with her life. She has a new boyfriend and a young son. What I give this movie credit for is showing that life is complicated even if you're Superman and things don't always go your way. Spacey is great as Lex Luther. If you're looking for great entertainment this movie is for you.

I work for the UK's largest cinema chain and was lucky enough to see Superman Returns yesterday morning. I have been eagerly awaiting the arrival of the Man of Steel and I was not disappointed! From the very start of the film as the opening credits began to roll I knew I was going to be in for a treat. The opening bars of John Williams score filled me with anticipation, my first Super size treat was waiting for me. The titles had been given a 21st century make over yet retained the same visual and font style of the first Superman film in 1978.As I sat watching the film I knew that people would be comparing this film to the original Christopher Reeve film, however this is a new version for a new generation. A colleague of mine said he felt 12yrs old again when he watched it, and that is what it is all about.My only worries with this film is that there is not enough Superman and the film tries to build a strong story from a potentially weak script. However saying that I very much enjoyed it and will be watching it again.

I found the story very boring and predictable. I did not find the special effects all that exciting either. I thought the movie stayed short for a summer blockbuster movie. I usually enjoy science fiction movies such as the matrix and the x-men but this one really sucked.I guess if you are a kid 7 and below you will like it but I think is really not all that.All I say is that the movie was suppose to be the best of 2006 and the fact that the movie did not even last two weeks in number one is a good sign that the movie sucks.Thanks

Review Title: Da Kent Code or The Usual Plot holes

Review: It is an excellent superman! I've seen the superman movies when I was younger and its the best I may forget each storyline but it was relived when I saw Superman returns. Brandon Routh is amazing, it felt like Christopher reeves was born to life. The similarities were uncanny! I especially love the special effects most of all the episode wherein he was about to get shot and the bullet was just centimeters from his eyeball! thats was super! I graded it 8 out of 10 because I think there is another actress who can portray the role of Lois Lane. not that i like Kate Bosworth but I just think someone else can be perfect and believe it or not I could see the blonde roots.

Review Title: It's an OK movie  with many missed opportunities

Review: The film was entertaining and visually stunning, but the acting was only mediocre and the story showed no innovation, just the same old superhero plot. Melodramatic and without conviction, the story seemed contrived and the screenplay was often laughably over-the-top.Bosworth does well with a slightly feistier Lois Lane, but Routh's abilities were largely limited to his resemblance to previous "Superman" actors. Spacey isn't very convincing as overt villain Lex Luther (he's much more suitable for subtle evil). I came in expecting a psychological bent to account for the 154 minute length - a la "Batman Begins" - but came out realizing that I had been seated an hour longer than necessary.See this movie if you're a buff of the genre or the franchise, or alternatively if you're satiated with large explosions and impressive effects. I wasn't.

I have just seen the Superman Returns movie after a bit of refection here what I think. This film without question has the most beautiful cinematography of any Hollywood blockbuster this year that I have seen X3, MI3 and POTCDMC (The Da Vinci Code, some dude hanging around some painting looking for God is not my bag). The special effects although functional and not very imaginative compared to the competition where well polished. The production design was first rate but again a little uninspired by reusing a lot of what had gone before. As for the cast there's a lot of talent on show that has not been pushed hard enough to take chances and make their characters their own rather than compete with previous in carnations. There is one exception as casting goes they should of made Parker Posey Louis Lane then she would of had some balls and spirit. The script is a mess that feels rushed yet plodding at the same time with no soul. It turns Superman into a signal parent. My only question is that dose he have too pay child support now that he knows and dose he have to take the second weekends of every mouth to see his son. My major problem with Lex Luther is that he has had fives year without Superman to come up with a plan. All he can think of is throwing a bit of rock into the sea for Ocean fronted apartments. He should stop shagging old lady's for money and get with the program maybe get in touch with General Zod for some advice. I saw flashes in this film that could of made this Superman a Crackin beating man of steel yet something was missing thought-out, in a word, fun. I think back to films such as the original Stars Wars, Indy Jones, and to Spiderman to some extent that took you on a ride that was cheesy, a little bit camp and that had you fist pumping at the screen. At the end of the day you can put a turd in a Superman out fit and people will be happy just to see him fly. I don't understand why the people behind this movie where so afraid of change. It has been 19 years since a Quest of Pace it could be anther 10 years after Superman Returns before they get it right. I like know what you think...now.

Review Title: Bryan Singer Has Found His Childhood Superhero!
Another case of a hyped up movie equaling dissatisfaction

Review: ...the most important of them being plot! Okay, he's been away for five years, okay things will have changed... and.... what? Lex Luthor (played brimming with madness by Kevin Spacey, but only really scary in one moment) has some crazy idea, but please, its not for a minute believable, doesn't look good and doesn't need two and a half hours to flesh it out.This film would have been so much better if it was 100 minutes, shorn of all the twiddle and concentrating on the action. Then maybe it would have constructed a few more set-pieces like the one where he first meets Lois again (I won't give it away, but that's the stuff.. more please!) Speaking of Lois... who on earth is this woman? She's supposed to have a five year old child but she doesn't look older than a teenager herself. How can she have held a meaningful relationship with Superman five years ago? Casting's all wrong. Nicolas Cage would have given us a much darker, more soul-searching portrayal and Lois needs to be a feisty, intelligent woman (she's supposed to have won a Pulitzer prize), which Teri Hatcher and Margot Kidder both pulled off.Biggest problem with this film though... its dull! A big disappointment from Bryan Singer, now leave the franchise (and franchise films in general) alone and do a good proper adult picture again.

He >>>HAS<<< Returned It blew me away I think Singer has Struck gold on young Brandon Routh he was Amazing, he really took the character to the next level I have no complaints about Kate Bosworth either i thought she was terrific and a good choice for the role tho I do admit having the child with her all the time made it difficult for her to really break out of the shell the Whole scene where they are kicking the crap out of him was very powerful and emotional, I really felt for him i love to see those sort of scenes it reminds me of a similar scene in Robocop two because it reminds you that you can be all powerful but at the end of the day we really are all human beings Lex Luthor was sadistic i loved Spaceys performance People say a lot could have been cut, i admit it was fairly long which i wont complain i would be still watching it now if i could but for those who don't it wasn't that it could be cut it was simply that the film had a lot to put across since it was the first film in 20 years if it was up to me not one of the scenes would have been cut including those that were my only complaint was all the old dialogue from the first film this film is 10 times better than the original We must make sure Singer makes us a sequel because now he has got his case across Superman has returns he can really expand the story and the character he needs to do it soon it he wants to involve his kid because if their not quick they may have to recast him since you all know how fast they grow up My rating 9.9 out 10

First, up until I saw this, Superman The Movie, was the superhero film by which all following superhero films were judged. That is still a great film, but this goes a bit further. First, it cements Bryan Singer as the greatest Superhero Director of all time. X-Men, X2 and now Superman Returns are all excellent, viewable and enjoyable films. The humanity he brings to the film while grounding them in reality and yet still giving us the viewers the superheroics we want, are simply amazing. Brandon Routh was a tremendous Superman, bringing (even though he's not 'human') humanity to the character as did Chris Reeves (Who I think would have been very happy with this film, and had he lived likely gotten a cameo). The homages to Donners films are so beautiful and wonderful, Singers love for the material so evident that it makes this film just an everlasting joy. Another thing is that in this film, Superman is just that, SUPER. He uses all of his powers and they finally got the fact that he can really fly - I mean superfast down as well. This is just such a great movie that I can hardly wait to see it again - and the sequel as well. Perhaps Brainiac is in our future? Great job Bryan, now keep it up, up and awaaaaaaay!

Review Title: Inspirational, a true gem of modern cinema. Thank you.
Review: Superman Returns starring the fresh faced Brandon Routh as the Man of Steel. It is an excellently written and directed piece of work. From the opening credits through to the truly magical flying sequences and well places tense, climatic stages. Superman Returns I believe will become the benchmark of all movies of its genre. It far surpasses the likes of any Marvel/DC comic book to big screen adaption I have seen so far, and I believe many of you may agree it is "a true gem of modern cinema".Being a huge Superman fan myself (only recently becoming one might I add) I thoroughly enjoyed Routh's performance as he made for a convincing Clark Kent. His performance can be almost directly linked to the late great REAL LIFE SUPERMAN of Chrisopther Reeves. Routh I believe is worthy of donning the great red cape and suit. Kate Bosworth and James Marsden offered their support, fulfilling their roles more than that of a satisfactory standard.To be frank with you readers, Superman Returns is a masterpiece of Computer graphic technology merging with up to date issues relating to current affairs that we can all relate to in our lives.Superman Returns does fulfil its biggest target, accomplishing the heavy task of relating to its audience as we all understand that at some point in our lives, we need help, we need a saviour and during our journey within the theatre we need Superman.If you let this movie into your heart, I assure you, you will come out of that theatre content and a bigger Superman fan then you ever thought possible.A great movie, wherever and whoever you are.Thank you for helping me escape reality and being brought into this fantasy world where anything is possible.10/10.

I cannot remember how long I have been waiting for this film to be released but as the day got closer I couldn't help thinking I was going to be very, very disappointed. The pictures that had been release and the teaser trailers just didn't do it for me.......I needn't have worried - this film is quality and finds itself up there with the original and Superman ii & iii (which I think gets a bad name). All major cast members are excellent and have their own way of portraying their characters. Kevin Spacey makes a nice change to the Luthor that we have seen most recently on Smallville and Gene Hackman's comedic portrayal. Routh has a new take on Clarke Kent - not as clumsy as Reeve but still has laugh out loud moments. There is enough references to the original films to keep the older viewer entertained and the visual effects are stunning. I haven't been to see a film twice since the original Jurrassic Park but I think I will find myself back at the pictures for this one!! Now all I have to do is wait for the next film!!!!

Review Title: Is it a bird? Is it a plane? No It's SUPERMAN!!!!!
Review: Well this film was certainly no flop...it captured the action, adventure, and romance set down by the old Superman movies, and although Brandon Routh must have been a gamble (being a previously unknown actor) he pulled off a stunning performance as the new Superman. The movie is filled with special effects, and it works tremendously well with fast paced speed shots with our hero, stunning fly-through shots, and great blue-screen shots of our hero in outer space. The effects in this film are phenomenal. I can't wait for the next instalment of Superman (whenver it shall be released)although I read somewhere that we shall be seeing many years worth of Superman as it is an ongoing ten year contract (but I could be wrong). The storyline in this movie had a splendid twist in the identity of Lois Lane's son Jason. No need for DNA testing on that one (when you see the film you'll know what I mean). Go and see it. Old fans shall not be disappointed and new ones will be hooked instantly. It's always nice to think that someone is up there as a guardian to humanity protecting and watching over us from the stars.

Well opening night here in the UK and I went to see it and I have to say it doesn't disappoint, it was well worth the wait and it's the only film I have seen in recent times that people actually applauded when it finished and what was also a nice touch was in the end credits it said Dedicated to Christopher and Dana Reeve :), so my advice is go and see this movie then go and see it again it's that good and also buy the DVD when it comes out, also the similarity between Brandon Routh and Christopher Reeve is uncanny even when he says Goodnight Lois in the film he sounds exactly like Christopher Reeve!! which is really weird they couldn't have picked a better actor to replace Mr Reeve if they tried.

Superman Returns is almost perfect, it needs just a bit more action and a little faster pace at the end. Otherwise this movie is great. Brandon Routh gave a wonderful and convincing performance as the man of steel. Wonderful direction by Mr. Singer. The X Men were truly hurt by his absence, but it was Superman's gain. This movie has plenty of character moments that are genuine , you feel for Superman and you see his pain on an emotional level that anyone who has been in love can relate to. And it is all done without making Superman look weak or like a whiner. The next movie I am sure that the stakes will be higher and there will be a lot more action, but this is a very good start.

Review Title: Must see it at IMAX - PROMISE ME!!
Review: You MUST see this movie at an IMAX theater. To do otherwise really does it an injustice. This is a big movie and it is spectacular. I loved the original and was worried that it would not compare. I never thought I would say this - but it was right on the level. This movie respected the older version and still managed to give it a refreshing take. I saw the original when I was 6 and Christopher Reeve was my first boy crush. Now Brandon Routh is capturing my imagination again with his own take on Superman - the man is just ridiculously good looking, just as he should be! He also does an excellent job in both roles - and those were big tights to fill. Please, please see it at the IMAX only - what a treat! I just got back and I'm going back for the midnight show!! Every one of my senses were invaded and all emotions pushed to their limit. I still have not recovered. I LOVE THIS MOVIE!!!!

Don't waste your money--go rent Chris Reeve's version. This movie did not add anything that hadn't already been explored in the previous film. I thought I would have problems with Routh's mimicking Reeve's acting, but he did an OK job pretending he was Chris Reeve doing Superman. OK I know what you're thinking there's not much to flesh out in the character, but look what Depp did for Willie Wonka-he was wise not to do a carbon copy of Gene Wilder's performance. Next there was the annoying Spacey's performance, don't get me wrong Spacey is a brilliant actor but he can't hack(excuse my pun) Hackman's brilliant performance as Luther. The film makers had great opportunity to introduce us some more mythology and lord knows there is a lot on Superman but they did not.The Film makers chose to take the safe route the only difference was adding a hokey sub-plot on Lois's personal life,who cares! Poor Kate saddled with that truly awful looking wig-- no wonder her acting was bad. I have other concerns but I can't address them now because they contain spoilers. But I can say this-- the actors had large shoes to fill and none filled them!

The man of steel has returned, bigger, faster and stronger than ever before. I have to say that I had my doubts about this film ever since I heard it was in production. These were for a variety of reasons, one of them being the death of Christopher Reeves and Dana Reeves. However the film is fantastic. Brandon Routh completely blew me away. What a performance from him. He delivered the performance with elegance and poise. Also he has a natural charisma for the role and he has a presence about him on screen similar to Christopher Reeves. Brandon delivers Clark Kent with the same poise and elegance. He is extremely similar to Christopher Reeves, actually the similarities are haunting but wonderful.Kate Bosworth is a bit young for the role of Lois Lane, however this does not detract from her performance. She was good, not brilliant. Kevin Spacey was excellent. He adds a new dimension to the character of Lex Luthor. The story is very clever, the locations are fantastic. And also there are a few twists along the way, along with a few emotional moments.All in all Bryan Singer has done an amazing job. He has stayed true to the original films, but added a modern day suave to the Man of Steel. Well done to all involved in the movie.Jason McCutcheon (Limerick, Ireland)

I never thought any comic book film would be as bad as "Hulk." I should have never underestimated Hollywood.Bryan Singer has virtually done the impossible: destroy a blooming career and turn into Michael Bay. It's not that this film is a train wreck, it's a capsized beacon out in the middle of space. It takes a lot of talent to completely destroy a franchise, and this film once again proves that someone is always willing to do the heavy lifting for such an accomplishment. Let's start with Brandon Routh. Tall, handsome, and clearly fit for the role. But unfortunately, he's just not an accomplished actor, and it was obvious that Singer did little to help in his development. For this fact alone, it was a shame because Routh is a rare commodity in Hollywood---a strapping man that isn't some boney androgynous girly boy that women seem to love (paging Colin Farrell, Johnny Depp and Brad Pitt). While Routh seemed perfect for his role, everyone else was just so out of place in this film. James Marsden was clueless within his role, Kate Bosworth was too young and proved she's a fraud of an actress and Kevin Spacey was a joke as Lex Luthor. If Parker Posey hadn't already made a fool of herself in that commercial with Jimmy Fallon, I would have said this was her worst role ever. While acting is often on the head of the actors themselves, the director has be taken into account considering actors have to be constantly directed.What I was especially disappointed with was the special effects. With a budget of some 200 million (which was largely blamed on the FX), you think this film would have the best effects ever. Instead, we get rather sad retreads of previous films that made better use of their lesser resources. Nothing about this film really stood out visually as the filmmakers tried painting a nouveau-noir landscape to add some grittiness. I could go one for years about this film, but let's just say it didn't work on a great many levels.

So what's the verdict? Singer has lost it! What a sorry piece of script writing this was, and what's all this with super boy? Also did you notice we didn't really have much of that Brandon Routh being Clark - was this because the guy was just a walking plank on screen? And don't get me started on that costume!!! Even when the plank was doing Super things like saving the plane or taking on that bad guy with the Terminator's machine gun I still didn't care. The main problem for me was that the script didn't take time to invest in the characters therefore making me not caring about anyone – the only saving grace was Kate Bosworth who in my opinion did a great job being broken hearted although she's a little young to play Lois Lane.There's some impressive sfx (as usual) and a few amusing references to Superman I and II. My problem with it was the story (which was kinda lame and lacked originality) and Lex Luthor's evil scheme (which was really daft).Kevin was fighting against a really under written part and what was the point of Parker Posey being in it, Miss Teschmacher anyone? What was lacking from the whole sorry affair? Even though it looked big and great the epic quality that Superman the movie had was missing. All in all I was rather disappointed and under whelmed by the whole thing. For me, Donner's movie was better and it was wasn't as satisfying as Batman Begins nor as cool as Spiderman 1 and 2.Make mine Marvel, Nuff said!

Review Title: It had me on the edge of my seat it was so EXCELLENT
Superman Returns...but to his former glory?
Review: Superman Returns flew into cinemas nationwide on Friday the 14th of July, and I can say I was one of those who flocked to the cinema the day it hit cinema screens. I sat down with my large portion of popcorn with high expectations for the Lycra-clad man's new adventure, and to be completely honest, it fell slightly short.When the opening credits began, with the familiar theme blaring, I shuffled excitedly as the audience was taken on a journey through space and important names, before landing with a crash at Clark Kent's childhood home. With a short introduction to his powers (for those who may not remember, or be old enough to), we are soon back into thriving Metropolis, as Clark (Newcomer Brandon Routh) Returns to the Daily Planet, home to his ridiculous (and unbelievably obvious) disguise. But when he discovers that his former love, Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth), is not only spoken for but has a son as well, everything starts to go downhill.Routh takes a lot of expectation onto his shoulders as the Superman himself, and though he does remind me of Christopher Reeves' original performance, he doesn't quite convince me. It may be because he seemed to be lacking a lot of dialogue, and didn't get a real chance to prove himself. Most of his screen time appeared to be taken up with him grimacing or smiling slightly. However, he definitely looks the part, after spending a lot of his time buffing up for the role.Bosworth plays a reasonable Lois Lane, but I fear that she was cast too young and lacked the real fire that Miss Lane once had in the original movies. She annoyed me mostly, but that can be commended, as I have always seen Lois as someone who would try my patience.Kevin Spacey takes the role of Lex Luthor, one of Superman's greatest enemies, and turns in one of the better performances. However, he doesn't seem quite as villainous as I'd imagine him to be, and is upstaged by his companion, Kitty, played by Posey Parker. She turns in a fantastic performance, and raises the most laughs.Overall, the film could have done with having at least 30 minutes shaved off it's running time, and it's plot could have been thickened out much more (the dialogue was very straightforward and lack-lustre), but I did enjoy myself, and my love for Superman has returned with passion. I hope they consider making a sequel, but with a bit more concentration on the plot. With it's amazing special effects, and entertainment value, I recommend it to anyone in need of a good summer blockbuster. Not even Kryptonite should stop you from getting to see it!

Review Title: Superman Returns! It misses a few beats but hits the mark.
Review: I'm not going to mention the plot at all in this mini review. All I am going to say is that director Brian Singer has finally revived the Superman franchise with a film that shares the same style and ideas of Richard Donners original classic. It doesn't however surpass Donners film (which is still, in my opinion, the greatest superhero film ever made). The pacing of the film is not up to scratch and the story is a bit thin on the ground. We could have done with a bit more of supes getting along with his daily business of saving people and perhaps a bit more of Kal El shifting between his two identities. Which brings me onto Brandon Routh. Routh is excellent as Kent/Superman/Kal El. Because he's an unknown you only get the impression that he IS all of those characters. Back to the pacing that I mentioned earlier, I got the feeling in several scenes that they could do with holding some of the shots for a little longer. If there is another problem with Hollywood films these days is the editing is all over the place. Superman Returns is no exception. I felt it could have done with a few more epic wide shots and longer cuts. The editing was done by the same fella that scored the music, John Ottman, I don't think Ottman had a very good grasp of John Williams original themes, we need more of the Superman theme, thats what its all about!I am nit picking to the extreme here. Superman Returns is an Excellent film and sits head and shoulders above your Fantastic Fours and your Sin City's. When you buy it on video, place it on the same shelve as the first two films, Batman, Batman Begins and the two Spiderman films.4 out of 5

I thoroughly enjoyed the movie. I felt it is brilliant and is as near a masterpiece as any superhero movie can get. (BTW I belong to those who were not too impressed with the Spiderman movies).The world a movie with a emotional core comes to mind. However, it is also a riveting superhero movie. I think the airplane sequence had been heralded by many as worthy of the entrance ticket price alone. I totally agree. The minute Superman appeared, it was like going back to my childhood days again. The impact was that amazing to me. The way he used his heat vision, lifted the space shuttle and sent it flying away is incredible. No one else does a rescue scene like Supes. He's a league of his own. What can I say when he landed the plane on the baseball stadium? Sheer awe. It was finished off beautifully with Supes walking into the plane and reassuring everyone with his calm voice. That was the moment for me that Superman totally came alive.Brandon Routh is indeed Superman - or should we say, a Superman for a new generation. His looks, physique, voice and carriage is definitely Superman. There is a human and vulnerable side to his Superman that Christopher Reeves did not have.I liked the movie in every way. Kevin Spacey was wicked and delicious as Luthor. Kate Bosworth's Lois Lane was thoroughly convincing and I felt she had great chemistry with Brandon Routh. Also, the romance was moving.I love the movie. From the casts, the set designs, the costumes, the script, the special effects, the cinematography, the soundtrack and most of all, the direction. This is in the word of one critic, a magisterial direction. Bryan Singer is at the full maturity of his craft and he should be rightly proud of this movie. Who cares if Superman Returns doesn't compare with the Pirates of the Caribbean 2 in terms of box office records? What's important is that it'll still be a good movie a few years down the line and it'll definitely stand the test of time.What I didn't like was the ending. I agreed with most critics that the ending was a bit too draggy and it spoiled the pace of the overall movie. There is a hint of a drag in the first 20 minutes. But that's most probably because I got impatient for Superman to appear.Also, I am a bit uncertain about having a Super-Kid. Will this return to haunt the future movies in the Superman franchise? However, he is a plot element that can be overlooked should they continue the franchise. After all, Superman can get a new love interest.I give this a high rating of 9/10. In one word, this movie is magnificent.

Review Title: OK if you like this kind of thing
Review: I don't know whether it's much of a recommendation, but "Superman Returns" is a better vehicle for this clapped-out quasi-character than poor Christopher Reeve's well-meaning but appalling finale, "The Quest for Peace", not least in the realm of visual effects. There are also a few improvements in the supporting cast, Langella's Perry White and Huntington's Jimmy Olsen in particular. The inclusion of a husband for Lois Lane is a good idea, and James Marsden gives him a credibility that the script doesn't. Spacey is Spacey, Parker Posey is a hoot but her character is not given the screen time her talent deserves. The first catastrophe is terrific, the climactic one much delayed and overstretched in a ludicrously over-long movie. Kate Bosworth is less crazy than Kidder - it's an altogether more modern, Rachel Weisz-ish performance, which is good as far as it goes. Routh's casting does the opposite of expunge the memory of Reeve: there is more than just a passing resemblance. Given that someone had to do it, and with no disrespect to Routh, who makes a decent stab at this impossible role, it might have been better to throw continuity to the winds and go for someone way different.For those of us of a certain age, the greatest pleasure of the movie is the appearance of Eva Marie Saint, whose serene beauty seems only to have increased, a challenge to the passage of time. What an amazing presence she has, even in this small role. And it's great that, more than fifty years after On The Waterfront, as the final credits roll, there's her name next to Marlon Brando's again.

Review Title: Very Enjoyable but a little long.
Review: Really enjoyed the movie, from the beginning to the end.It was so nice to hear John Williams Superman theme again and out of the three blockbusters this year, X-Men 3, Pirates and Superman I thought this was the best.Could of been about 20 - 30 minutes shorter but at least the film didn't plod along like Pirates did at times.It had Bryan Singers directorial style which was missing from X-Men 3 , the special effects were very good however, as normal the CGI characters were very noticeable at times; but as this seems to be a common theme in the three big films this year.This is only a slight moan because overall the director and cast should be congratulated on an very good production.

This movie sought to answer two questions: whether the fictional world of Metropolis still needs Superman; and whether the Man of Steel, essentially an overgrown boy scout, can compete with the darker heroes and anti-heroes dominating the silver screen today (such as Batman and the heroes of the Marvel universe). Thus, the question for both worlds is, "Do we still need Superman?" After seeing the film, I am happy to report that the answer is a resounding, "Yes!" Essentially, this movie pays tribute to that first great film in every single way. While a few myopically see this as "ripping off" the first film or as laziness on the part of the filmmakers, the filmmakers saw themselves as paying tribute to that great film that made us believe that a man could fly (containing as it did everything that makes us love the movies). Thus, it helps to see the film in this context. Thus, if you loved the first film, you will almost certainly love this one.Much as he did for X-Men and X2, Singer injected the story both with emotional depth and an intriguing and highly relevant thematic subtext that made what could have been just another summer blockbuster filled with mindless action sequences into something much more. Singer made more effective use of the messianic motif than even the first film did, and although I am not a particularly religious person myself, this fits the Superman mythos like a glove, as this is essentially who the character is: a secular messiah.The high quality acting helped Singer bring this ambitious vision to life. Brandon Routh more than adequately filled the large shoes left by Christopher Reeve, and Richard Donner, the director of Superman: The Movie, wholeheartedly agrees (having said so in an interview with the BBC). Bosworth fittingly played the part of a woman who truly moved on with her life after the man she loved ditched her without so much as a goodbye and displayed true confusion and even bitterness over his vaunted return. Spacey actually outdid Hackman as Luthor, having made him a serious villain that simply exuded hate for the Man of Steel. Finally, Frank Langella and Sam Huntington perfectly filled the roles of Perry White and Jimmy Olsen, respectively.Still, viewers need to know a few things before watching the movie. Although the movie itself fails to make this explicit, press releases make it quite clear that Singer chose to ignore Superman 3 and 4 and instead concentrate on building a story that takes place following Superman I and II. Keep this in mind when viewing the film, and you will not feel lost.Also, try to watch the first two films before watching this one. This film pays tribute to Superman: The Movie in every single way (and Superman II in a more subtle way), and picking up on these references will greatly enhance your experience.Finally, as I hinted before, do not expect a movie jam packed with action sequences. Although the movie certainly contains awe-inspiring special effects and plenty of eye candy in the form of incredible action sequences, the film seeks to make an emotional connection with fans instead of merely titillating them. Much like in the first film, the effects are wisely understated and thus serve the story rather than vice versa. Expect a film of emotional depth instead of a mere action movie.Enjoy the movie, and happy flying!

First of all i'd like to congratulate young Brandon Routh on a good portrayal of superman.i very much doubt film makers could have found anyone more like the original superman Christopher Reeve.Secondly i think Spacey who was the star of the show for me does the part of Lex Luthor justice as well,without meaning to knock Gene Hackman great actor that he is,i think his Lex was more panto villain than arch Nemesis to superman.Spacey most definitely portrays an evil villain far more convincingly and helps give the movie a more menacing feel about it.My only complaint about this movie is that it was a little drawn out in places,i'm all for filling in the gaps and then catching up on some of the original characters but i think too much time was spent on this and therefor when we got down to the nitty gritty it did seem like a bit of an anti climax.still it's a decent enough remake with some awesome sfx and decent acting,overall worth killing a couple of hours on a Saturday afternoon with.

I thought the acting was poor across the board, the quality of the special effects was inconsistent and I was just plain bored for most of the film. I didn't care whether any of the characters lived or died and found none of it emotionally engaging. The whole enterprise seemed indulgent, sloppily plotted and poorly edited. No doubt a sequel will be made and millions will go and see it. For me Superman Returns was yet another example of the contempt Hollywood has for the intelligence of its audience. Now I know it's a summer blockbuster and not Chekhov and I know that a film about an alien who looks human and who can fly isn't exactly based on reality but it should at least allow a viewer to suspend disbelief until it's over. A complete waste of time and money.

Hey, its Superman!! What more needs to be said really, he's back and he don't disappoint.. forget "louis and clark", this is one that Christopher Reeves would be proud of.Lets hope the soon to be made sequels live up to this! Unlike the recent Batman Begins, this is no reinvention of a superhero; it is instead more a continuation, or updating, of the franchise made great by the late Christopher Reeve. Set after Superman II, (thankfully assuming that instalments III and IV never happened, and were both results of very bad dreams) Superman Returns has taken the world that director Richard Donner created and has given it a 21st century sheen. And it works because it does feel like a genuine sequel to the Christopher Reeve films, whilst at the same time successfully updating the look of the film to give us one of the finest superhero films in memory.Of course, no Superman film would work without the Man Of Steel himself putting in a noteworthy show, and newcomer Brandon Routh is no less than perfect. The moment you first see him, most notably as Clark Kent, you'll think you were looking back to the past – the resemblance is uncanny. Some critics have said that they think that Routh should create his own identity rather than merely copy the performance that Christopher Reeve gave, but this is misleading. Firstly, Routh does give the role his own identity; and secondly, seeing Routh being so much like Reeve is actually a good thing – it instantly makes us comfortable with the character; it is arguable that change here would have been a damaging move.Routh is also clearly having fun as the kindly and clumsy Clark Kent, whilst switching instantly to the majestic power that embodies Superman. His reactions when he returns to earth after a five year trip to Krypton are made entirely believable (from finding out Lois is a mother to discovering Lex Luthor is out of prison) because we utterly believe in him. Also, the writers have done the character justice by not changing him – he is torn by emotions inside him, but the film never feels as dark as films like Hulk or Batman Begins. It has its moments, but Superman is still portrayed as the clean-cut hero that he is, and in a world where summer blockbusters are becoming ever more "gritty", it is a nice relief to see one that doesn't need to follow that trend.The film is all about heart; whilst there are action sequences – and there are some staggering effects which create some frankly mind-blowing sequences – the majority of the story concerns Superman's and others' reactions to his return. However, even at over two and a half hours, it never feels too long (except maybe a little over-egged at the end), and the emotional scenes are well handled without become too soppy or clichéd. Of course, this eventually gives way to concentrate on Lex Luthor's plan to grow a new continent – using stolen technology from Superman's Fortress of Solitude – in his constant ploy to own real estate (and given that he is only human, this plot is actually understandable, despite many claims to the contrary). There is a brutal scene which pushes the limits of its 12A rating, and the whole segment is thrilling and gripping – finally the "invulnerable" superhero actually might be in for more than even he can handle.Kevin Spacey seems to be relishing his role as Lex, giving Gene Hackman a run for his money. He retains a certain element of "camp", but he is also much more sinister than Hackman ever seemed. He also has some great interplay with Posey's Kitty, bringing back memories of Miss Teschmacher from Superman I, with more humour. The other supporting cast are all okay, though not given huge amounts of screen time. Lois Lane, as played by Kate Bosworth is good, but she's no Margot Kidder – she's not as feisty and seems too slight to truly capture the original Lois, but she portrays Lois' bitterness at Superman's departure well.In the end, one wishes they had included more of Superman being super, but it is to Bryan Singer's credit that he doesn't need to fall back on another action sequence to keep our attention, unlike other blockbusters. Fans of the original films will enjoy the many nods to the franchise, from the same introduction title sequences, to that score integrated wonderfully with John Ottman's new score (it will give you goosebumps!), to the use of dialogue lifted from the Donner films. The action sequences are all extremely well done, from a bank robbery sequence to an amazing mid-air rescue of a stricken passenger plane, and they are combined nicely with the plot and emotional scenes.Superman Returns sets itself up nicely for a sequel (which is currently being written), and one cannot help but wish that the time in between the two films would fly past ever more quickly. Superman Returns has reset the bar for superhero films, and is easily the best blockbuster of the year.Rated: 9/10 More reviews at: http://www.thelazylounge.net

Its a bird, its a plane, its... a terribly overrated movie
Review: OK, firstly, i am not a great fan of superman. I think he is ridiculously over-powerful, and frankly unimaginative. The movie contained only one of these traits. I wasn't intending to see this movie, as i believe superman isn't very interesting, but my friend had managed to get me free tickets. Even then i was debating whether to see it, so i searched it up on my trusty IMDb, and with a rating of 7.3, i was willing to clear my mind and view it. Oh what a bad mistake that was.So the movie, what was wrong with it? I suppose the special effects were fairly decent, although definitely nothing special. The acting was below average, but i sympathise with Brandon Routh, his script and character left him cornered into a bland performance. However, even this would not have made it a bad movie, that honour would go to the storyline. One word: cliché. It was predictable, and generic. A "Hero returns, nearly dies, but comes back and saves the world" with a laughable bit of love thrown in.Yes, OK, i will admit that my bias against superman didn't help, but c'mon people, he is (essentially) invincible! Can move at nearly the speed of light, super strong, can fly, heat vision, breathe in space, breathe underwater... honestly. His one weakness, a little chunk of kryptonite, which he is "vulnerable" to. I wont say anymore for fear of spoilers.One last qualm; the time period?? One minute the cars and clothes made it seem like a 1980s new york, and then the next, a kid pulls out a camera phone. It was confusing for me at least..The beginning was not so spectacular, the middle was dull and predictable, and the ending was just icing on a very cheesy cheese cake....

This movie is a good one.Brandon Routh has done a good job as Superman, although not as strong as Christopher Reeve. Christopher was more believable when he acted as a dumb reporter, Clark Kent. Brandon gives the impression that he is a clever guy when being Clark Kent.It depends on your liking, but I like Christopher's version. Some dumb down-to-earth reporter who nobody would have guessed as Superman. I guess, it is not Brandon's fault. The director and scriptwriters should have done a better job in this area.The first action in this movie is very very impressive, although it is done with very much American flavour. You will know what I mean if you see this movie. Hint: what is the most popular game in US? Other hint: aeroplane.This movie shows the other side of Superman as a normal human being with emotion. Brandon acts very well when he drops a tear upon hearing Lois Lane "confession" (read: lie ) to Richard White. I can actually feel the sadness inside Superman's heart. He flies away to the outer space to mollify his sadness.Not so subtle difference between this movie and the first Superman movie is the way Brandon standing tall and just flies away. Christopher Reeve had to make a bit of a jump and flew. In this movie, Superman flies more smoothly and it seems that Earth gravity doesn't affect him at all. He can fly whenever he wants. No preparation to fly.I don't quite agree with the director's choice for Lois' part played by Kate Bosworth. She reminds me of Victoria Beckham: long and beautiful hair, slim body, glamorous face, too sexy to become a reporter; and yet here is a woman who won Pulitzer Prize. For me personally, Kate is not convincing as a top reporter. (Search in pulitzer.org to see the people who won Pulitzer Prize.) Apart from her appearance, she is not convincing either as a mother whose only son is a product with the man she truly loves. In a scene where she and her son and Richard are struggling under water, she doesn't make an attempt to put her son as the first priority. Instead, Richard holds her son, while Lois is trying to escape.If Superman does belong to human race, not only America or Europe, where on earth does it show that he is helping Asian countries? African countries? Australia? I can't blame the director because the movie will be far too long with those scenes, I guess.Now, what about Lex Luthor? Is Kevin Spacey any good? Well, not bad, but not as powerful as his other roles, especially in The Usual Suspects. I can't find malicious intent in his eyes. He is convincing as a clever and talented man, but not as an evil. Gene Hackman was not convincing either as an evil man. Too much laugh.Should you see this movie? Yes, why not. It's worth your money. Under 3 hours for £6.95 is not bad, is it? But, most of all, this is a Brian Singer film. You can enjoy the experience. Trust me. Before the film started everybody in the theatre is talking, eating popcorn and making all sort of noises. Once the film started until the end, everybody seems to enjoy it. Silence throughout.

Review Title: Fulfilling Film, but a tad short of the original
Review: When I saw Superman Returns, I had some pretty high expectations. Actually they were more like hopes of this film reviving the saga like Batman Begins did for Batman. And it came close to doing just that. The story was a little more complicated than the first, which may have downed the mood a bit. But the acting was pretty good indeed. Brandon Routh did a fantastic job as the man of steel, but sadly he lacked the feel and charisma that Christopher Reeve had. He was superman, and nobody will probably ever replace him. Kevin Spacey did a captivating job expressing Luthor's evil side as good as Gene Hackman did with his comedian side. The other actors were pretty good and believable. But I think personally what may have downed this movie the most is that it was meant to be a continuation from the second, but i did not feel that at all at any moment. but this movie was still a great reprising experience. 7/10

Review Title: Great revival of the Christopher Reeve classic

Review: Surprisingly, I found this to be the best of all Superman movies, even the first. Very powerful, very intense. The attitude of the "people on the street" has changed in this movie to be almost reverent and awed. And Superman has achieved more global responsibility and appeal. He helps people on other continents now! I recommend that everyone (over the age of about 8 or so) go to see this movie! It is probably too intense and violent for anyone younger.The touches of continuity with Superman I and Superman II were well-appreciated. Superman is definitely and lonelier and more mature person now. You can feel his emotion as he struggles with Lois Lane and her new life situation.

I went in expecting this to be a teeny bopper version of Superman. Well, I was surprised (and shouldn't have been, being Bryan Singer was on it). Essentially, this is more a continuance of the original series rather than a complete rehash (which is also what I expected). First, big kudos to Kevin Spacey, who gives a more accurate Lex Luthor than Gene Hackman ever did (not to mention funnier). Second, the new Superman pretty much holds his own against Christopher Reeve's portrayal, with a little more goofiness as Clark. Everyone else pretty much did a great job.However, one noticeable improvement over the first 4: the effects. I recently saw Superman 3, and looking at the effects now, they were pretty lame (good for their time, though). We all know CGI has come a long way, and let's face it: looking back at the first 4, while technological marvels of their time, they were not the most convincing things. So the effects would be like comparing the Harryhausen dinosaurs from King Kong to the CGI dinosaurs from Jurassic Park. Similarly, the effects help propel the story.Only negative comment: it is long--2.5 hours at my count (see IMDb for more accurate timing), which made the film drag at times, but otherwise, great popcorn flick.

Contrary to other reviewers on this site, i thought this was a terrible film. Brandon Routh deserved no more than his $1 million fee, for as far as i can tell he actually did no acting, simply looking dorkish as Clark and pulling poses as superman. Bosworth was a horrible Lois Lane not a patch on Teri Hatcher in the TV series. The plot was terrible and i simply couldn't wait for it to finish. Without Spacey this would go down as one of the worst films i have ever seen,(It still isn't much better than the worst). All i can hope for now is that other people wont go to see this in an effort to hold back its box office takings, however unlikely that may be. I just hope that people will judge this film on its individual merits rather than instantly deciding upon its excellence simply by being a "superman" movie.

Review Title: superman goes on a diet and loves a razzie contender

Review: I'm not a great fan of Bryan Singer. I never really liked the X Men movies. I just didn't. I found them lacking something, it's like the visuals without the meat.And Superman Returns is exactly the same. The story is weak, the acting and casting relatively poor (although Routh does an admirable job as Superman / Kent), and the whole film seems to hang on an emotional centre. It's more like Dawson's Creek than Superman. It ambles along with lots of very slow points and Superman is relegated to something of an emotional plot piece.It's overly sentimental and there are some scenes (like the hospital scene) I just found a little grating. It's like a nod to the original movies, but a paler and somewhat hollow version.It's a good movie, but it's not a great movie. It's no Richard Donner movie! It's Superman Lite!

Review Title: I wish I was Lois Lane, I wish Superman is real, I do!
Review: I watched Superman Returns today, and there's only one thing I wanted afterwards: I wish he was real! The story is okay.. I mean.. you know what's going to happen anyway, but hey, I was biting my nails all through the movie, going "Quick, Superman!! Quick!!! Aaaaa!!!!" I was a bit bothered by the fact that this version of Superman went a bit off-track from the original story of Superman, with Lois Lane not knowing Clark Kent's real identity and such.. and another part of the story which I won't say because it's a spoiler (something to do with the kid).The ending of the movie was also a bit unsatisfying because it ended just there. Just there. It doesn't end-END. It doesn't end with maybe-there's-a-second-movie-coming-END. It doesn't end with Lois-will-be-with-Superman-END. It just ENDS there, not at the beginning of another story, not in the middle of any story, and not at the end of any story either... It just bothers me.. because with Spiderman you know there's another movie coming, with X-men III you know that's the end of X-men movies unless they make another X-men movie with a bunch of other x-men characters..And I was really disturbed with the fact that Lois doesn't find out about Clark.. because it just.. urgh! You know!? Actually the whole movie really talked about Superman more than Clark Kent. I can really count the scenes where there was Clark using my 5 fingers. But i guess it's OK, i mean.. it IS titled Superman Returns, not Lois & Clark's Adventures.BUT! I just fell in loveeee with Superman! And no, not Brandon Routh, even though I bet I would fall over heels too if I see him in real life. But Superman... tsk tsk tsk.. I just wished I was Lois Lane. And I wished that Superman was real! After I finished the movie and was waiting for the bus, I actually looked up (it was a cloudy sky) and .. ahem... looked.. for.. the Man of Steel, to see if he would just fly over the buildings over my head.The movie is soooo good at making sure this hero icon is as real as he can be. And man, is he a hero! At times I even think the movie sort of overdid it a little because it made Superman looked like God.. landing down from the sky in such peacefulness (with the choir music in the background), being at so many places to save ppl in one night, that rare shy smile Superman gives after helping people.... They also did a bit too much on the publicity thing. The movie made Superman looked like he's got a large ego to match his muscles. Waving his hand at a bunch of baseball spectators while he's on camera. I mean, wouldn't it be better if he just smiled and flew, but no, he had to wave, then smile and flew away.Brandon is a bit too young for a Superman that fights with the Lex Luthor of Kevin Spacey's age. But it really doesn't hurt because Brandon IS good looking. Eh.. I don't mind. Superman just bowled Spiderman - and X-men and Daredevil and Batman (not that he's got any super powers..) or any other superhero - over, because SUPERMAN IS THE SUPEREST SUPERHERO, EVER! The movie tag is "You'll believe a man can fly... again", well, I DO!

Review Title: 'We Don't Need Another Hero' by Tina Turner
Review: 'We Don't Need Another Hero' by Tina Turner summed by the beginning of this one. Lois Lane wins an award for writing a paper on 'Why the world doesn't need Superman' and from then on in it becomes typically cheesy and predictable.Now maybe we should start on a negative note so I may end on a high. This film goes on for much too long; if you have an opportunity to miss the first hour take it! How the director thought he would entertain an audience after putting them in such a bad mood is beyond me?! Some of the actors aren't up to the requirements of their part either, Kate Bosworth (Lois Lane) looks completely out of place, her character is awkward and I don't think she has learnt how to make the balance between an alpha female and a female who is passionately in love trying to run from her feelings - she looks like a fish out of water to me. Sam Huntington (Jimmy) is also rather poor, again I would like to see someone who tries and means well but just can't make it (like the original Jimmy) but this new version seems to fit in line with egalitarian issues surrounding the workplace. To put it frankly, he looks like someone who is not up to the job but has been recruited to represent minority groups – not what I expect from Jimmy.Onto a more positive note though, after taking some aspirin to get over the first hour of the film it does begin to pick up. The tradition of superman has been well carried by the director (Bryan Singer) and some characters more than make up for others. Brandon Routh is a brilliant actor and well worthy of the superman part he plays and Kevin Spacey proves to us once again that he truly is one of the greatest living actors in this day-and-age. Despite a reasonably predictable ending the film isn't too bad and the idea is very good. The storyline is Lex Luthor takes crystals from one a superman's layers' and uses it to create land, however, in doing so he is going to send the rest of the world under sea and kill millions/billions of people in doing so. It's a clever idea and definitely believable, again something typical of the old superman films. Predictably you get the old cliché of good versus evil etc. In all honesty if this film was better casted and they cut the first hour out it would have been a much better film. After giving the first third of the film 0/3 and taking a mark of for the poor casting we are left with a pretty average 6/10 for a film that was billed to be the greatest film this year. Certainly, not as good as The Pirates of Caribbean 2!

I seem to be in the minority on this but (and I'll avoid spoilers)... The plot seemed almost an afterthought next to the set pieces. And ultimately, as fantastic as these are they do not make a great movie. Routh was perfect as Superman. Too perfect perhaps as he evoked Reeves in just about every aspect of his performance. Regardless, it certainly doesn't disappoint on account of him. However, Spacey fails to even manage 2 dimensions as Lex Luthor - and the script seems to treat him as an incidental character by comparison to the same characters portrayal by Gene Hackman. Lois is too young. And her other half would have been better off as Cyclops! But the biggest problem for me - the film just dragged! It could easily have been half an hour shorter... Can't say that I'll be waiting for the next instalment with baited breath... A shame since the director is capable of so much more.

Review Title: You'll believe a man can fly...
Review: Superman Returns! Singer has done it! He has brought Superman back to our screens! The way Supe flies is just awe-inspiring and there were many small details of the flying that just blew me away. His cape steals the show! Brandon Routh is very good as Superman, he knows how to hit the right notes and looks great in the suit. He has the 'Superwalk' and the 'Superpose' down! Kate Bosworth looks a lot better compared to Margot Kidder who I never thought was that great looking but saying this, Bosworth's performance isn't a touch on Kidder's. She doesn't do very much with the little she's given. The action sequences were handled very well and Routh makes a formidable Man of Steel, his performance is at times a sensitive one. Considering this is a sequel to the Reeve's films of the 70s I can be forgiven for making comparisons to those films and I think the biggest let down is Routh's and Singer's handling of Clark Kent. Kent is pretty much inconsequential and they've gone down the Clark Kent as the alter ego route which takes away much from the Daily Planet sequences which may have humorous moments but seem empty in comparison to the original films. Clark Kent doesn't get enough screen time for my liking and is far too two dimensional as there is literally ZERO tension between Kent and Lane which shouldn't be the case this far into the relationship. I think Kevin Spacey makes a great Lex Luthor taking away much of the cartoony buffoonery of Gene Hackman's performance which I always found was a little too ham-fisted for Superman's arch nemesis although Spacey still suitably has fun with playing the bad guy. This film is definitely worth seeing just for the Superman sequences even if some of the liberties taken with the story would annoy some comic book fans... Personally it was such a pleasure to see Superman in action again that I was able to ignore some of the slightly dodgier plot areas particularly with regards to the fruits of Superman and Clark Kent's labors... I think the biggest advantage of following through the films of the 70s is that Singer got to keep the score of the original two which still shimmers and brings goosebumps even to the hardest of film going hearts. Its may not be perfect but is certainly worth a look.

Review Title: made to be put in a McDonald's happy meal
Review: This was such a disappointment and I really wasn't expecting much. The basic problem is that the director (who not surprisingly also was involved in the script) doesn't seem to care about anything more than superficiality. The whole thing is about as interesting as the little plastic merchandising this film seems to have been made in order to flog, rather than as a film to be enjoyed by audiences. The story made very little sense with nothing explained and great gaping inconsistencies created because the director seemed determined to have a cast of 23 year olds in all the main parts. The result is that Lois Lane would have had to be 16 years old when she joined the daily planet, 18 when she had her child and still managed to hold down a very prestigious job at a major newspaper. OK OK it's not supposed to be completely realistic but COME ON! If the whole premise is that Superman has been gone for five years then surely something could have actually happened in that time?Lois wins a Pulitzer prize for a fluff piece titled "Why the world doesn't need Superman" and although we never actually hear her argument for this award winning insight... the fact is that it quite obvious that the world is getting along quite well. When Superman does get back he gets his curl in a knot protecting the world from bank robbers (apparently there are no major civil wars, starving millions, AiDS epidemic or weapons of mass destruction in the world of Superman so again you gotta wonder why the world ever needed him in the first place and certainly no one would have noticed his absence.)Added to the impossibly young age of Lois is the fact that she also looks like a gust of wind would knock her down... where oh where are the feisty strong looking women who had a bit of upper body strength??? Karen Allen where are you? (Yes I know I think she's in an insane asylum too but can you blame her the way real women are treated in Hollywood.)Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor had very little to do and again believability just wasn't there. we were meant to believe he got to serve only 5 years on a double life sentence because superman didn't turn up to a court date???? Plus his dastardly plan made absolutely no sense... sure he can build a land mass out of crystals but it's hardly fertile ground... people would be as well off living in the north pole or the Simpson desert. I could go on and on about the stupidity and pointlessness of the story and problems with every single scene... but basically it's simply another example of Hollywood ignoring story for special effects and creating a blockbuster of a failure.

Imagine you've been asked to make a 21st-century Superman movie, but you can't upset the stalwart comic book fans of the last 60 years, you can't upset the long-time Christopher Reeve fans, you can't upset the action-loving movie-going audiences, nor the "Smallville" fans, and balance that against the fact that most superhero action movies have either been "inside job" movies which ring hollow, or lame plots (specifically, "Superman III").This movie succeeds if you wanted a "re-imaginging" of the original movie; and yet, the characters are true to everything you've grown up with, plus incredible special effects (watch the concussion in the jet as it makes its "landing") and the additional constraint that everyone agree's that it's probably time to get Superman past Lois.It also succeeded if you wanted something new. Lois and son; Richard is neither weasel nor killed; the screenwriters took the high road and made Richard competition without being an enemy; Perry White is actually a nice guy in his old age without letting up on the "tough boss" image. But to me, Richard wins hands-down as the the surprise character in the entire movie. The most disappointing script support in the movie was for Jimmy Olsen, though. A big opportunity missed, there.Parker Posey's character, "Kitty," is left with a lot of potential for the next movie. She didn't do much and certainly didn't do as much for the plot as Gene Hackman's sidekick in the original movie, but to me, her character's strength lies in the potential she has to "get motivated to get smart" and oppose Lex. It was also a little creepy how they made her look like Margot Kidder. It did constrain her character too much.As far as plot goes, the screenwriters did a nice job: Lex Luthor does the unthinkable and takes something of Superman's that we've taken completely for granted over the last 30 years and uses it to potentially destructive and horrible consequences--and yet still in its own way, mimicking the plot of the original "Superman" movie. The difference is, this movie won't date itself in 20 years.And they even paid the requisite homage to Christopher Reeve in the last 30 seconds of the movie, without having to sully any memories or even admit that the first "Superman" movie sure didn't stand up well to the sands of time.To succeed, the franchise is going to have to stay true to the comics though, but needs to avoid the "Batman/Mr. Freeze" phase that ruined the Batman franchise.With the creators of "House, M.D." on the scene behind the production of this movie, I think the franchise is in great hands.The best inside joke: "It's like an Academy Award--people don't remember what you won it for, only that you won it." That missive sums up the task that the entire cast and crew had in making this movie!

To start i have to say i was impressed when i saw this film, simply because i am a big fan of the originals (1&2), and this film stayed true to the old styles but with a bit more romance in it (and a bit more budget i have to say). Everyone asks how the hell can you replace Christopher Reeve, you cant, but what you do get is a very similar and brilliant performance from Brandon Routh who gets Christopher Reeves mannerisms of Clark Kent down to a T. Not only does he look the part he plays the part as well. Kevin Spacey is like in any other film, just brilliant and Kate Bosworth As Lois is good but for me too nice and weak compared to Margot Kidders character.The plot which i wont go into is again like the first in a sense in that Lex Luther is after land/real estate but it is completely different to the first in its execution and outcome. The effects are superb and the flying is totally convincing (you'll remember the double plane rescue for a while).Die hard fans of the original will love the opening credits, an exact recreation of the original and hearing the music in the cinema bought a tear to my eye. That said the end has been exactly recreated where superman is in space sways from left to right, smiles at the camera and flys off, superb. A big impact is the archive footage of Marlon Brando which was definitely needed in the film, and also a few phrases from the original thrown in as well.All in all acting was great, action was superb, and probably wont win any awards for the plot, but every superman fan thinking the worst for this film can lay those thoughts to rest because this was a fantastic film rivalling or even beating the originals. A must see for fans and non fans alike.

Note 10 to the Brandon Routh.

John Williams full time on the score, a believable story and most importantly, decent film editing might raise this movie above my rating of 5. Overly long with no great dramatic moments, it's just one scene tied to another. Brandon Routh is terrific, but wasted. Kate Bosworth is badly mis-cast, as is Frank Langella. Shannon Dougherty in the Lois part would bring the prickly quality Margot Kidder had but Bosworth totally lacks. Good editing and a decent musical score would help provide some drama as the double jeopardy save Lois and catch the helicopter sequence brought to Superman the Movie. This movie misses each and every chance to inspire. Great special effects must be believable. Lowering a jetliner from vertical to horizontal by holding one tiny spot on the nose isn't believable. Flying up under a bad engine (per Superman the movie) is. Lifting an island ... well, that's hard to quantify in it's superness.. but bringing a boat to a police station... not so hard. My point? Just because you can do things with a computer.. don't you first ask if they further the story and the overall experience? Perhaps "super" scenes involving something closer to the reality would bring the gut wrenching quality missing from this version. Bottom line...special effects can't replace editing, storytelling and a great score. If Richard Donner had the tools available for this version, who knows what would have resulted, but it definitely would be something I want to watch more than once, rather than struggle to stay awake through.Hope the next chapter is better!
