I did my best to ignore hype and drivel about this movie, I wanted to see it for myself and enjoy the next installment in what I remember from my childhood as the most amazing set of movies I ever saw.I remember seeing the Supmerman movies and thinking like many other kids, 'Wow, this guy flies. He's cute and he's just such a nice guy. I want to be Superman when I grow up'. Don't roll your eyes, Superman is a truly inspirational character, and Christopher Reeves will always be remembered for his awesome part in bringing this character to so many viewers in such a way that you feel like you're right there with him.I was excited sitting in the cinema waiting for my first glimpse at this fresh face playing my childhood hero. The opening credits were just great, they take you back to the original movies, the music and the sweeping text is just great.Routh does a superb job, there are close-up shots of Superman in this film where you can swear you're looking into Reeves' face, Routh masters the bumbling Clark Kent to perfection, tripping over his thoughts and words just like old times.Lastly, the new suit is great. A modern version of the old spandex suit with all the hero suit aspects of recent films (Spiderman, X-men etc) and Routh wears it well, possibly not as bulky build as Reeves but certainly some eye candy to be enjoyed.I simply cannot wait to see more Superman movies come now, Routh is a great actor and would do well to continue in the roll for at least a few more movies.The world does need Superman. Thanks Christopher and Brandon.

Review Title: Superman does some heavy lifting, but doesn't throw a single punch!
Review: I saw this the Tuesday night it opened, and I was really disappointed. At the time, I had read only the ravest of rave reviews, so I was expecting something really special. Why not? Filmmakers like Sam Raimi have finally figured out how to bring comic book heroes to the big screen. Even the weak entries into the Marvel/DC et al inspired genre, like the Hulk and the Fanatastic Four, have had their inspired moments. But the critics didn't line up for those like they did this colossal miscue. SR's inspired moment happens early on, when Krypton's greatest son thwarts an airplane disaster. It's his comeback to the world stage after five years of self imposed exile. It involves a lot of heavy lifting, and is the template for almost every damn thing SMan does in the rest of the movie. Something heavy is about to fall, SMan shows up just in time, and moves it somewhere else. UHaul should have been the sponsor for this film. Each time, Singer needle drops the old John Williams' score. After an hour of this repetition, the film becomes a bore. Superman doesn't throw one punch. Which is really an odd filmmaker choice for the greatest of superheroes. All the other superheroes in all those other movies throw punches. Or if they're like Storm or Cyclops, and punches aren't their strong suit, then they lightning, or flames, or laser beams. In this one, Lex Luther throws more punches than SMan. Singer's vision of SMan as the superhuman dolly wears thin, but could have been a more exciting watch if the threat was better defined. I can't give this plot point away, but the world menace is about the most unexciting, unsexy, uninspired piece of science class slide show bullshit you could imagine. I don't understand how Singer could have thought this wearying danger could crystallize into a fun watch. It's never really explained how this danger effects power sources, but it does. Singer's X-Men bad guys, his Usual Suspects antagonist, are real delights. What happened here? If Superman would have battled evil robots from Krypton, or just about anything else nasty and violent, this would have been so much better. It doesn't help that we never really get to know this new Superman. Sure, the facts about him are given; he loves Lois, he's a stranger in a strange land, etc. The camera spends so little time on him when it should, you don't get a feel for what's happening in SMan's head. A good example of this is a scene early on when Clark and Jimmy go to a bar. SMan has just got his old job back, he's just learned some important news about Lois, and now we get to settle in with him and see how this new world is making him feel. Except the editor (John Ottman) cuts to everyone BUT SMan. He actually spends more time on the bartender, a cameo role, then on our protagonist. It's not the actor's fault. The old Superman movie spends time on CReeve's. We get to know him. By the end, we like him. But this new SMan is treated like a mannequin, with little time allotted to close-ups. The editing is blender-ific, chop-city madness. It's called storytelling, folks, and you really dropped the ball here. Raimi spends time on Peter Parker's FACE. You know this kid so well by the end. You really care about him. Same is true for the latest Batman. But not here. How do filmmakers this big, with the kind of resources they're given, foul up the basic rule of letting the audience get to know the protagonist? Some filmmakers get so big they forget that they are storytellers first. They make a film or two that is a big disappointment, and then they return to their old form. I hope that's the case here.

Review Title: Laws of Physics is not in this film, Newton would of gone MAD if he saw this.
Review: This Film is great for kids, but awful for adults, the laws of physics is just not in this film, newton would turn in his grave, also in real life people get hurt from the most casual and silly things in life, I.E. last week i gave my self a paper cut, and i was bleeding, the action sequences in this film are a joke when it comes to reality, no one gets hurt, the plane sequence, is just so for children, as laws of physics is completely thrown out and forgotten, don't want to create a spoiler so i won't go into detail, but needless to say unlike spiderman, or X-men, people just don't really get hurt where they should, whip lash is clearly something they forgot to look up, because so many in this film should of had whip lash and been injured for quite a while, but no, everyone is still OK and running around like nothing has actually happened.all i can say is for this film, every one in a way is superman/girl, because where people should be bleeding, there not, also objects and structures don't apply correctly to laws of physics which take all reality away from the film, and your left with just fiction only, and no chance of buying into the film, children will love this film, adults who are not objective will again appreciate the film, but anyone who likes to see some real life elements from life in this film are going to be shocked, and disheartened to see super man returns to a world where no one gets hurt when they clearly should, the death toll in this film should of been sky high, but again, a clear example on how studios have there hands wrapped so tight around the people making the film that the essence is lost, and all you get is great special effects, brilliant sound, and NO reality, i don't understand why Hollywood studios hire directors, but then tell the directors how to direct the film, stick with the spiderman trilogy if you like to see real elements of life, at least in spiderman you see people actually get hurt,

Today I saw Superman Returns, in the Morning... Now I wont get into how I saw it, where, with who, the time or even the reason why I was there watching it! When doing a review somethings are just best left not said... You know helps build up a bit of mystery. :)But lets just start of by saying that well for the last year, and a half I have been reading up info on this movie, and checking out Singers Blogs, and like a lot of others out there I also bitched in forums about the colors on the suit, the age of these actors, especially Brandon who looks WAY to young for the role, and yeah about the kid being a bad idea to put in this movie, and if its Superman's Son that its even a worse idea, so on, and so on, etc...You know the normal stuff people have been bitching about...I was a bit excited when Roger Ebert panned this movie because I tend to love movies that he hates.. I mean he loved Charlies Angels, Garfield 1, and part 2! I mean the guy has really let his taste in movies go down the drain in the last few years so here I thought that I would probably love the movie, and that it would help bring back my favorite comic book hero into the collective conscious... Or at least to the big screen for a few more sequels... Hell I would have even been happy if it were on the level of Daredevil or the Blade trilogy... But the whole time I was wishing that all my fears would be put to rest when the movie started playing.I can say that For a single minute I felt like a kid again watching Superman for the first time! Then something happened! The movie started playing... It was all downhill from there!Now I'm going to try, and stay spoiler free because I know how you Fanboys hate spoilers! HehI saw the movie with as much open mindedness (is that a word?) as possible, and I really tried to clear my mind out of all the negative buzz this movie has had from the start, and my own personal feelings on the cast, and what not... The results were still what I had expected.The movie's first act is very slow in pace, and it really takes a long time to build to any sort of action, and this helped put the person who I saw the movie to asleep... He said he was tired but we both knew the real reason! The first ACT IS BORING!!! After a long, and some what 3rd rock from the sun looking intro which used the same text for the names as the original movies we get to see Smallville, and Martha Kent on the farm, and a ball of fire shoots from the sky into the corn fields.. Martha along with her dog rushes to see if its her son who she hasn't seen in 5 years.I wonder now how bad the footage that was cut in the start of the film might have been for it to be cut!? After the intro credit the movies look is very close to the Donner pictures, and Singer did a nice job of matching this movie to those movies. Everything is actually pretty decent until we get Clark to the Daily Planet... This is where the movie really goes downhill.Brandon As Superman himself has times where he does a good enough job but those are when he has almost no lines AT ALL! But then we have times where he does speak, and boy is he stiff, and wooden as an actor, and this makes him look out of place as Superman, and to top it off at times when he's saying his lines if you look at his eyes I swear its like he's following along in a cue card... Also doesn't help that the storyline makes Superman out to be a deadbeat dad, a Liar, and a fool!IF you really sit there, and go scene by scene, and try to pick apart the movie It seemed to be at least to me just a re-telling of the first movie with a few added or changed story points to help make it seem like its a sequel to the first 2 movies, and not a remake... But there's A lot of the same elements which Donner used in his origins in this movie.. The flashback scenes while not many at all were also not needed, and actually badly done! Clark doesn't wear glasses as a kid, and someone should have told Bryan Singer this bit of info before he made the movie.. You know since we all know he doesn't read the comics he might not know this.One would think that with a reported 260million dollar budget that they could have at least got better writers in this thing, and not a bunch of hacks (Dan Harris, and Michael Dougherty) if the movie makes back its budget, (Which I really doubt!) and is seen worthy of a sequel I hope that Bryan Singer is not brought back, and neither is this cast... Just forget this storyline please, and MOVE ON!

This movie was just what I wanted. Escape at its best. From the very beginning there's an excitement in hearing the old John Williams theme, updated quite nicely actually, and in seeing the beginning credits mimic the ones form 25 years ago. This movie certainly respects its predecessors. What's great is that it does so while one-upping them.The beginning is where the film is truly weak. I would have loved to see the whole cornfield and barn scenes work instead at the beginning of the movie as introduction, rather than twenty minutes in as flashback. I hated the written explanation at the beginning of the film. Totally unnecessary.But all is forgiven quite quickly. The cast is gorgeous and Lex is evil, though perhaps just a little boring, but Parker Posey does just wonderful things with her character. The special effects are really unparalleled and above all, the humor is spot on. All these things work together to carry us through the, at times, slow pacing. I trust, though, that Bryan Singer knows what he's doing, using this film to set up number two, giving us lots of characterization, just as he did with X-Men.Regardless, the film is still action packed, and without a single true fight scene. I was literally on the edge of my seat twice; first with the airplane and then again when the White family was trapped on the boat. Loved the maturity and restraint Singer used in storytelling, not exploiting Jason White's big secret and not conveniently killing off the less plot tidy characters. Routh was perfect, absolutely perfect. He took control of the role and really made the film work picking up where others, Bosworth in particular, might have slightly lacked.This was by far the best film of the summer. I can't help but compare it to X-Men 3. This film was FUNNY, made as much SENSE as is possible for a comic book made into a movie, and had a phenomenal score, even memorable. All things the other movie lacked.Why, oh why, wouldn't any studio wait for Singer?

Review Title: Superman Returns, but not as expected.
Spectacular return for the man in blue tights
Review: I loved this film. Simpley put it was excellent. It stayed true to the original and Routh was outstanding as Clark and superman. A worthy replacement for the late great Chris Reeve. Spacey as Luthor was an inspired choice. However, I wasn't too sure about Kate bosworths Lois, but this didn't detract from this amazing story. Review Title: Superman Soars or is he just Sore?
Review: Some 20 years on since the last of the ever-diminishing sequels, Supes returns to revitalise long dead superhero franchise. The original Christopher Reeve incarnation was rightly recognised as one of the 1st feature films to really do justice to a comic superhero.I have to say I was a little deflated by the end, after all how could it live up to the nostalgic memories of a child who really believed a man could fly in 1978? Comic book movies have grown up a great deal in recent years and benefited from the greatest advances special effects and CGI, thereby stealing some of the thunder of this latest superhero entry.The story is very much a re-tread of Reeve's 1st outing, Lex Luthor's plans of creating his own devious "real estate" deal (without planning permission!), offing Supes with a dose of radioactive Kryptonite- all along with the help of his "tart-with-a-heart" accomplice.I guess I can show some sympathy to Bryan Singer directorial approach- he has to re-establish the franchise as well as make a new film- so that new generations can appreciate it. However, I think they played it a little safe by relying so heavily on the 1978 story template. He does try to make us remember that Superman is actually an "alien" and outsider- it does worry me slightly that this fairly clean cut bastion of morality resorts to sneaking about to spy on Lois Lane and family like a Super Stalker! "I never lie Lois," said Reeve in the "78" original. Now she can reply "No. But you do follow me around stalking me with your x-ray vision and super hearing!" The good news is they have found a great new unknown to play Clark and Superman in Brandon Routh. There is no question that he has similar qualities, mannerisms and speaks in a similar tone to Reeve, without it being a copycat performance. He may not play Clark as such a bumbling fool; here he's a much plainer, ordinary Joe who is a bit of a non-entity. Which makes sense, if you are trying to blend in and avoid public attention! Bosworth plays her part okay, but is too young to convince as a wily reporter.Spacey is under-used to a degree, but carries off the part with some humour and definitely more menace when called for than Hackman did. So he should given his psychotically, impersonal reaction to killing "billions" as a direct result of his own "home grown continent" experiment! The story and characters are not played with the same level of playfulness and somewhat silly humour we had in the past. This is grounded in a more realistic world. The dialogue can fall a little flat at times and there is not as much intensity to these scenes that the film makers were going for.The special effects are fabulous, and I would like to think that seeing some of it in IMAX 3-D would add to the experience. Superman is as physically strong as you would want him to be and the plane/shuttle rescue highlights this fact very early on. In fact this action sequence is probably the best in the film, and its hard to top.There is one sequence towards the end which evokes stronger emotions, Supes taking on a magnificent feat of strength, whilst putting himself in mortal danger with no thought of the consequences- now thats what hero's are made of! It also cleverly taps into the very real images that will always be remembered from 9/11- the cities population staring in shock at the events unfolding, an "impact" causing dirt and dust to travel through the streets and park etc.All in all, I cannot say it blew me away, but I can say that the next one- if directed by Singer- will likely up the ante in the same way "X2" did for the 1st X-men movie.With so many recent and decent superhero movies out there (X-men's, Spiderman's and the excellent Batman Begins) this comes in as a Solid 7 out of 10.

I've always been a fan of superman; comics, cartoons, and the earlier movies with the late Christopher Reeve. I shared the same feelings as any other superman fan out there; I have had a lot of expectations about this film, and a little pessimistic due to Byran Singer's intent. Nevertheless, I was excited and I wanted this movie to do extremely well at the box office. However, I was extremely underwhelmed with Bryan's final work. Come on, with a budget of over 200 million dollars they could have at least added an extra villain to improve the action sequences? I honestly don't see where the money went in production. Yes the movie was shot in high definition, but every fan who had saw the film was hugely disappointed by it with the reused Lex quest for real estate.I read several articles circling the internet that big boys at Warner Brothers are not going to make another sequel unless the movie clock in 200 million dollars in gross profit, domestically. Sadly, I don't think the movie is going to make that much because of Pirates the Caribbean 2, now that is a real summer blockbuster which did pretty well, stealing some of Superman's thunder with 132 million dollars in the first few opening days.It seems I did nothing but say negative views about Superman returns. Nevertheless, it is a well done film that has a lot of fan service for those who loved the first two old movies with Christopher Reeve. Review Title: It is forbidden for you to interfere with Hollywood history
Review: "Where did you go" Lois asked Brandon Routh's Superman an hour into this Super-sort of Sequel. Development hell, that's where. And there, like a creative phantom zone, he languished for nigh on twenty years. Burton proposed cracking the zone by relieving the man of his power of flight – good idea: Remove the characters one defining characteristic. Ratner also caught the revisionist bug, suggesting such howlers as remaking the first film with a surviving planet Krypton. Thus a sense emerged that there were more Otis' in Hollywood than Lex Luthors and the these geniuses blew $40M trying to work out a viable way of making a new Superman film when the perfect template was languishing in their vaults all the time – available for the cost of a viewing theatre. The name of this obscure super-template? Superman! It took Bryan Singer to work out that if it ain't broke, don't fix it. Thus Superman's Return is modelled with an unprecedented level of reverence for a modern remake on Richard Donner's original Reeve duo. As a tribute act it works well enough – Williams music is reused, Jon Barry's design carried over and the plot of the first film is alluded to ever so often so as to create an eery impression we're watching a direct sequel, though this is evidently not quite the case. This means that Returns is neither fair nor foul – a sequel to an imaginary version of Donner's film set in the noughties with this new cast. It requires a collective leap of imagination to work and almost succeeds except that Singer's version fails to capture the warmth and humour of the original films. Routh's performance oscillates between stiff and quietly dignified. He understates his Superman as Reeve did but lacks his predecessor's intelligence, wit and affability. Spacey, replacing Hackman, plays for menace in keeping with the film's more somber tone and presents a Lex more dangerous but possibly too brutal for what essentially should be a family film. Just as Routh's costume favours darker tones than Reeve's, his Superman isn't as colourful. The replicated closing shot of Superman soaring in orbit round the Earth vividly shows the difference between the classic and revival. Reeve looked down on the Earth and smiled, satisfied all was well. Routh replicates the movement but stays straight faced, a cold fish to the end. Singer's love for the material isn't in doubt but somewhere he and his cast have forgotten about the comic in comic book. A glossy update with a centre the temperature of the fortress of solitude.

Review Title: Based on a whole of the movie ... Not a spoiler but it'll spoil it.

Review: Last night I went to see Superman Returns with my 7 year old son and my ex-wife. I approached the film with anticipation despite not being the world's biggest Superman fan, as we were going to watch it at the 8 storey high, 1000 stereo equivalent IMAX cinema IN 3D.The version we saw has additional 3D scenes only available in the northwest. There were only two 3D editions released in the UK, one in London and one with the additional scenes in Manchester.I have a few beefs with Superman as a protagonist hero for a start he's too bloody perfect by far, He's invulnerable, he's a bit of a pretty boy and he's all bright and shiny. He can fly, shoot lasers from his eyes etc. He never really suffers except in the presence of Kryptonite, which rather handily is always going to fall into the hands of which ever arch nemesis he happens to battle in any film made about him, which is bound to take away much of the surprise for any viewer.Superman represents an odd dichotomy in that he's more of a symbol than a hero. He stands for truth, justice and err… the American way, aye and therein lies the rub. In these days of Bush, McDonalds and moral uncertainty, can there ever be a (and notice I'm not using the word believable obviously) a relatable Superman character? Well not in the comics to any extent, which doesn't matter so much as due to the particular creative medium, fans of comics have a heightened sense of suspended disbelief. Good comics are analysed as artistic expressions with the plots having as much to do with the characters physical rendering as much as the storyline itself. Good comics that are genre defining are common as the standards set by the industry are high. Great comics that redefine the genre however are rare.Making the new superman film, must have been a real tightrope walk, for Bryan Singer. How does he keep film fans, comic fans, neutrals and movie goers alike all happy?How would you go about making Superman interesting? Well for a start I'd use lots and lots of cutting edge special effects. The bigger, the more magnificent the better, for after all this is the most powerful superhero on the planet bar none so let's go all out.Then I'd concentrate on showing him as 'normal' as possible. Despite the power despite and despite the truer than true blue personality, I'd want to illustrate the doubt that resides in all of us as to the purpose we'd put ourselves too if we had those marvellous powers. I'd show him as an alien alone in a world gone a tad mad and bad, surrounded by media attention and the difficulties in maintaining relationships whether romantic or platonic.Either way I'd want to show that despite his powers the frailties of humanity are what makes Superman truly Super, the fact that despite feeling the same things, anger, passion, jealousy, loneliness etc (the things that make us all truly alike) he uses his position of power to fight evil wherever he finds it. Always, despite his alienation and difference as an individual he still manages to resist temptation and stands up as the best example of a lax intergalactic immigration policy ever.Bryan Singer does some of these things in his film and all in all I'd say it's easily in the same league as it's fore-running predecessors, Blade, Spiderman, Batman Begins and other recent comic films that have brought icons of the 50's and 60'sinto modern day. They've all managed to escape the common pitfalls and mistakes of their original made for TV films and mini-series. They've reinvented characters, whilst staying true to they're core natures and justified their motives and actions in a way that doesn't stick in the craw of a world of nurtured cynics.As much as I wanted light sabre after watching Starwars, much as I wanted a hat and a whip like Indy after seeing Raiders of the lost ark, as much as I wanted to be able to shoot webbing from my wrists after watching Spiderman, as much as I wanted to dress up in black leather and beat people up after Batman. . . ahem we'll stop there. I think you get the picture.Brandon Routh makes a fine Superman easily worthy of the role and after a slew of pallid, just here for the looks female leads, it's about time we had a worthy female lead. Kate Bosworth is great. Also James Marsden plays well a much understated performance in a fine supporting role. I felt he anchored the film emotionally ad that it would have been quite 2 dimensional without him doing it so well.Spacey for me was the weakest link, playing for Pacino like menace but ending up falling just short of camp. He displays none of the charisma that I feel Smallvilles Michael Rosenbaum, perhaps would have brought to the role, but perhaps that was too crossover for Hollywood.Superman Returns is a great interpretation of a classic socio-urban myth, retaining the dignity, slight cheese and lantern jawed rightness of the original hero, but bringing enough 'human' interest as to hold interest of a modern day audience. 8.7 out of 10.

Review Title: Nice picture shame about the anaemic casting

Review: The recent spate of Comic-book action films has now turned full circle. This is most surprisingly the last and also the most overdue considering some recent tripe within the genre (Hellboy, The Punisher et al). Superman has finally arrived, and, starting with excellent extended space-swooping opening credits, entertains a magnificent sense of scope. It is fitting that the king of Superheroes gets a film of such grandiose scale and spectacle, and director Bryan Singer clearly wants to utilise all the resources available, signalling his intentions early, furthered by a breathtaking aeroplane-in-peril rescue sequence around twenty minutes in. Inevitably, in direct contrast to the original film, special effects hold no bounds here, and there are wondrous set-pieces intermittent throughout.However fantastical the CGI however, the curse of the remake and all of it's connotations haunts the film. Singer is caught between the dilemma of whether to keep the theme of the film as simple as possible to appease traditionalists or to extend the intricacies of the plot and give it the modern complexities and sub-stories that todays audiences demand. The concept and attitudes of the characters generally seem dated but their actions belong to a much more contemporary landscape, resulting in a contradictory film which feels ultimately unsure of itself. The majority of remakes are similarly burdened with this fate but there are some notable exceptions, such as Spiderman which is a perfect example of a film of it's type rising above it's station due to the addition of an excellent script. Superman lacks the layered sub-plots combined with the emotional undertow of it's characters present in Sam Raimi's film, so your interest tends to lull between the action. The introduction of Lois Lane's child who may or may not actually be the son of Superman from his previous relationship with her is predictable, and hence this subsidiary becomes tiresome very quickly.The actors do a capable a job as possible with the means at their disposal, and Kevin Spacey turns in a surprisingly modest performance; he resists the temptation to ham his way through and comes out of the film with some credit. Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane goes through the motions but she can hardly be blamed and the introduction of her spurned and retaliatory attitude towards Superman (after she had been deserted for 5 years) is well played. The standout performance though is Brandon Routh as Clark/Superman- he effortlessly maintains the fresh-faced, all-American innocence of Reeve and fits snugly into a role for which he now seems the ideal preference, and although he lacks the overall charisma of his predecessor, he does indeed do a good job.Another big disappointment however is the lack of chemistry between the two leads. Symptomatic of the writings inability to fathom anything approaching meaningful, their scenes together are devoid of the same spark and plausible romanticism generated between Reeve and Kidder in the 1978 version. I found myself yawning whenever conversations within the film exceeded a couple of minutes; In these times, we ask for more, and this weakness is indicative of the overall problem. Such a surprise for the same director that crafted the superb Usual Suspects, it is easy to forget that he is hamstrung by the towering influence if the original.These gripes apart, on the whole, Singer has made a relatively entertaining film which will undoubtedly be a big success at the Box Office on either side of the Atlantic, and this, combined with the open-ended denouement will surely provide a(nother) sequel before long. The film isn't without it's strengths, and the sense of something grand surrounds proceedings, but the use of eye-popping CGI coupled with some decent performances just doesn't paper over the cracks.At least with the next picture, if the same production team take on the project, the shackles of the previous effort will provide an opportunity for ascendancy rather than anything else. A motion picture hampered by more insecurities than the Man Of Steel deserves.

Review Title: Is it a bird?, is it a plane?, is it a .... oh who cares?

Review: Bryan Singer's Superman Returns is a masterful restarting of the Superman franchise. While advancing the characters in surprising ways, particularly the relationship between Superman and Lois Lane, the film pays respectful homage to the 1978 classic Superman: the Movie. Think of everything you liked about Richard Donner's film: the quotable script, the mix of humor and spectacle, the antagonistic relationship between hero and villain, then amp it up. Instead of one chunk of Kryptonite there is an island of it; instead of a glance of Noel Neill there is an important scene with her, instead of a near fatal accident/rescue with a helicopter, there is an entire jetliner at risk, etc.Brandon Routh makes a spectacular film debut as the most super-powered yet most poignant Superman ever. Routh's interpretation of the Man of Steel and Clark Kent are wonderfully similar in earnestness to Christopher's Reeve's, yet there is a subtlety in Routh's depiction of the very human, charming Clark Kent that is humorous without being cartoony. The special effects are eye-popping and thrilling. The brutal treatment of Superman by Kevin Spacey's awesomely evil Lex Luthor is nearly terrifying. Superman's unbelievable feats of strength are the stuff of new iconographic imagery. The memorable script by Michael Dougherty and Dan Harris is well written and respectful with no cringe-inducing silliness. John Ottman's symphonic score remaking John Williams' music from the '70s is inspiring. New characters like Lois's child Jason and her fiancé Richard White are sensitively played by Tristan Lake Leabu and James Marsden; Parker Posey is highly amusing as Kitty, and Kate Bosworth's Lois has many of the film's best scenes. With stunning art direction and HD cinematography this a terrific and satisfying movie. Superman's cape rippling in the wind is a thing of beauty and so is this movie. Bryan Singer should get an Oscar nomination and he and Brandon Routh should be proud.

Review Title: I really, really wanted to like (even love) this movie.
Review: I really liked many things ABOUT Superman Returns. I think Singer and writers definitely had their heart in the right place with their whole approach to re-starting/continuing the franchise. I loved the old-school feel (including using the old score.) I loved that they didn't make Superman edgy, neurotic, or otherwise post-modern. I loved the '5 years after' premise of the movie, and how they were able to humanize Superman and give his character some great dramatic story material (hard to do with a practically invincible superhero!)Unfortunately, I didn't enjoy the actual movie so much. I thought it dragged and didn't really go anywhere, and ultimately failed to deliver on its great potential. After half an hour I was excited, after 2 hours I was wondering if anything significant would really happen. Superman loves Lois. Lois loves Superman. The boyfriend loves Lois. Clark is shy and clumsy. All the elements are in check, ready to go. But then nothing really happens. No one commits to anything or really acts, it felt like all set up and no resolution. Luthor's evil plot was pretty good, but the ending felt anti-climactic to me. I think there were so big missed opportunities that I won't go into since it would involve spoilers.It felt like Singer wanted to set up a trilogy, so used this movie to 'set the stage'. Except 2 and a half hours of stage-setting is a really long time. More judicious editing would have helped here- I think this was a 2-hour movie max. But regardless of the length, I'd much rather have 1 or 2 great movies, than 3 so-so ones.The cast is good on the whole. I liked Brandon Routh, but started getting put off by the underacting thing near the end. But I'd like to see him continue the role. I thought Kate Bosworth was fine, but wonder about the script in regards to Lois. She seemed to change from being bold and independent (in earlier movies) to flighty and contrary. Many people seemed to dislike Bosworth, but I am not sure if it is her shortcoming or the script's. Spacey and Posey were very solid, as expected.There were some really great moments in the movie- when Superman saves the Shuttle and the whole world welcomes him back, and also what happens when Luthor faces Superman. And if they make a sequel, I will watch it in the theater. But while I loved what they tried to do with Superman Returns, unfortunately the actual movie was a mixed experience for me.

I thought this was going to be great. The return of Superman. After all how could it fail to beat Superman IV: The Quest For Peace? I don't grumble at every movie that is released, but the story and plot were confused and made little sense. Little emotion was conveyed through the characters and an original John Williams score absent. (John Ottman filling in for him). It does have some good special effects but with a budget this huge, you'd expect it. It has a missing charm and magic, perhaps that was the late Christopher Reeve. The cast feel too young. One of the elder actors, Kevin Spacey, did a good job as Lex Luthor though, very menacing, if a little camp. But hey, that's what Superman is."See you in 20 years said Superman at the end of Quest For Peace" Well it's been 19, I could have held out for 20.Peter

Brandon Routh, the new superman, puts in a great deal of effort and portrays the essence of the character very well comparing favourably to the superman of the past Christopher reeves. Unfortunately the mega budget and good acting is seemingly wasted on a weak plot line and bad scripting... As it has been said in the past you can make a bad film out of a good script but not a great film out of a bad one - again this is the case.Due credit should and indeed must be given to Routh though as he fills the role as perfectly and proves to be a talented actor. The shoes he had to fill were super in so many ways as was his predecessor Reeves and HE unlike the script manages not to disappoint.### All in all not a great movie but regardless it will have very good success in the box offices and is worth watching just to see Superman back in the sky's once again###

Review Title: My Most anticipated film of ALL TIME!!  Did I like it??
Mr. Clark! I mean, Kent. Mr. Kent! You're back. I don't believe it. Wow.
The writers of this movie should have been fired
Review: This is summer time. Many people are on holidays while many other keep working despite of the hot weather. In both cases, many of us need a moment to go and offer our brains a moment of rest with some typical summer flick, i.e. a movie we hope to be not too complicated but quite entertaining. Good action, hilarious jokes or sweet stories usually make it. Alas, some movie writers, probably hurried to go for their own holidays, decide to write a dull script with haste and let the producers design nice advertisements (posters, trailers...) so that summer moviegoers get fooled and pay their tickets. Superman Returns is a typical example of those "works".Let's summarize very shortly. After looking for remains of his home planet, Superman returns to Earth. He obviously finds back his former love Lois while an evil character prepares...his dramatically evil plans. So far so good: we expect a mix of a (not too complicated) love story and a (not too complicated) action/superhero story. The movie is 2 1/2 hour long, so there is pretty much room for both aspects: you say "this is going to be a great summer flick". Well, not! I am probably unfair, but I had the feeling that the action only lasted about 1/2 hour, and the problem that I am not too keen on love stories, or at least on that much simplified (simplistic?) ones. So, I had to bear what seemed to be 2 hours of Superman/Clark Kent and Lois Lane turning around in a very stupid, dull and unconvincing way. Actually, all the "sentimental" part of Superman Returns could have been shrunk to what was left to the action part, that's to say, half an hour. The movie would have been then much more equilibrated and entertaining, and my friends and I would not have felt totally conned.Now, I have to admit that the movie had one good point: Kevin Spacey was the perfect fit for the arrogant and maniac Lex Luthor character. The 3 points I give to the movie go to him. The other main actors, as dull and smooth as Barbie and Kent dolls, only deserve to fall in the Hollywood oblivion.

Review Title: Yet another remake, but it IS Superman:
Review: I watched in anguish this summer as our nation's big screens were over-inundated yet again with a plethora of sequels and remakes. What should I see first? Superman was my role model of choice as a youngster, whether it be the George Reeves or Christopher Reeve version. I admired and looked up to both actors, as they both gave a touch of their own personality and artistic flavor to whom the Man of Steel was supposed to be. I'm a bit disappointed in Brandon Routh, as he seemed to be more of a copycat of Reeve than anything else.A movie with so much potential was thankfully not full of the average clichés that tend to destroy most sequels and remakes, but this one didn't quite have enough originality to make the cut. There is one cliché involved, though, that most are hailing as the greatest pot twist ever.Kevin Spacey is brilliant as Lex Luthor, and the toothbrush scene is the one that will forever be emblazoned on my mind. He's not quite Gene Hackman, though, and it is unfortunate that Spacey has to compete with one of the greatest bad-guy character players of all time when attempting this role. Spacey just about makes the cut.I wasn't impressed with Kate Bosworth's portrayal of Lois Lane, and Richard White's (James Marsden) relationship with her was just not believable.I will give Bryan White some kudos, though. The intro to the movie, with the stock footage of Marlon Brando, was definitely well done. Not much was changed from the original with a slight exception of juicing up the intro credits. I thought I was going back in time to 1979 where I watched the first Superman, and its awesome intro special effects, for the first time on the big screen.When it comes down to it, though, this is just another remake, albeit a well done one. However, it is Superman. That is what leads me to give it an above average grade.

Review Title: One of the greatest Superhero movies of all time....
Superman didn't reach the high orbite.
The man of steel has returned........
Has Superman always been allegory for Christ?
Gets a whole lot better on the 2nd viewing
So-so reintroduction of an old friend
Review: I have to say that Superman Returns was not as bad as some have said and certainly not as good as others have. I'll admit, Superman I and II were hard acts to follow and so my disappointment may have something to do with unrealistic expectations.On the plus side, this movie had casting down pat. All of the actors were great for their roles and their performances made the movie work better than it would have otherwise.That having been said, they were given some pretty good stuff to work with. Not perfect, but good. I recall groaning out loud when I saw that Lois Lane had a kid, but the good folks in charge (director and writers) never once pulled a lame-o kid moment ala "The Mummy Returns" when junior declares, "My dad's gonna kick your a**." The interpersonal relationship between Lois and Clark was kept real and I only wish they had spent more time on it.Which brings us to the bad points. I can see why they did it, but I wish they hadn't. The filmmakers threw a great big world-threatening plot by Lex Luthor into what was otherwise an entertaining yarn about the incredibly complex situation that Superman finds himself in when he returns after an unannounced five year hiatus. Sure a movie without a villain threatening to blow the world to bits may have been too story-driven, too character-driven, too intelligently entertaining, but, you gotta get the kids in there somehow. I just wish they had managed to mesh the two story lines together a little more seamlessly, because to be quite frank, Luthor's whole plot seemed a little too last minute for my tastes.But, someone, somewhere decided that they needed to waste a whole bunch of time re-introducing us to a man all of us should know and love by now. I did find myself entertained by it, just not as much as I had hoped. That having been said, I do hope they make more and what better tribute could there be to Christopher Reeve than to continue entertaining millions with the character he helped make come alive?

Why is it these days, when films like this hit the horizon of release that we feel a little concerned? So many let downs with Hollywood chucking loads of remakes that just embarrass themselves more. Then you get the sequels or maybe horror films with CGI's which just DON'T work.However, this film does and it does it in style.I don't think it is as good as Superman 2 but it's good. Great effects for a start that look and sound great. The acting roles all fill in well and what a difficult task to wear the cape of the late Christopher Reeve. Kevin Spacey I thought was superb. His evil nature that lay dormant under a disturbingly intelligent and crazy individual, he played the part with brilliance.Don't think there's much more to say and there can't be when there are only minor flaws such as a few holes in the storyline but it doesn't matter.One thing I did notice and that was a couple of young kids with those smiles on their faces after the show. Took me back to when I first saw Superman as child with my family. Come to think of it, I also saw a few elderly people there as well and that was interesting as you don't get many going to the cinema in my area. It's a great atmosphere so my suggestion is go to the cinema and watch it. Superman MUST be watched at the cinema.The best thing out of all this is...Superman has returned

Review Title: oh dear,oh dear, what a waste of a good idea.
Review: no spoilers here, except the obvious one that this movie was extremely disappointing. i personally love the first two superman films and i have great respect for Mr singer, who in my opinion has never made a bad film. and to tell the truth he has not made a bad film here. its just so underwhelming. i mean superman is supposed to be super right? all i wanted was to see something new that i had not seen before i did not and i'm really sad to say i don't think any of you will either. file superman returns under "waste of some good ideas" although credit must be given for the central performances and i must admit the film is beautifully made, but sad to say its not the sum of its parts it just does not work as a piece of entertainment.

Ever so slight spoiler alert.I wonder who stopped Jon Peters from messing this film up. Ever since hearing about him gaining the rights to Superman i have been "bricking it". Whoever managed to stop him making his crazy changes to the Superman lore, should be knighted. Brandon Routh was spot on, Kevins Spacey was also spot on. The Twist was completely unexpected and Kate Bosworth was a very good Lois Lane, less spunky and head strong than other renditions of the character, but then again she is a mother.The only fault i can think of is that you never hear any mention of other characters out of the JLA or whatever, i know Rights are a problem, but its a major part of Supermans existence. Over all, I thought it was the best Comic book movie ever... i think.

The latest Superman reincarnation picks up the plot strings left from the Christopher Reeve films and even includes a couple of actors from the old Superman TV series of the 50's. Noel Neil, the original Lois, plays a dying woman in the beginning of the film, and Jack Larsen, the original Jimmy, plays a bartender and has an interesting dialog with the current Jimmy. Of course, for such an expensive film, the special effects are awesome but the plot more than keeps up with the FX so that you get the feeling of watching a real story unfold rather than a collection of computer geek extravaganzas. Brandon Roush, where do they come up with these unknowns?, is good in the role and is reminiscent of a Reeve, especially when he plays bumbling Clark Kent. Kevin Spacey probably plays the best Lex Luthor in Superman history, eclipsing Gene Hackman from the Reeve movies. Kate Bosworth has been updated from clinging female to modern woman but keeps the movie moving along nicely. All in all, an ideal film for a hot summer day when you want to escape the heat with a perfect popcorn movie. I give this one 4 out of 4 stars.

It's been a while and I never thought I would ever see another Superman film, but I am so relieved that Brian Singer made this.Being a huge Superman fan, I had high expectations going into this and wasn't disappointed. Every time I heard the iconic Superman fanfare my face lit up and I was taken back to the original 1978 classic.I am so grateful to Brian for making such a beautiful and spectacular film, his Superman was much more dynamic and the action pieces were so much more fluid. There were throwbacks to the original movies of course, some references were made to previous movies for the sake of consistency.Verbal Kint's Lex Luthor is just the right amount of evil for Supermans nemesis, Kevin Spacey gave Lex a sense of weight and danger to the plot.I'm now off to see it again.

Review Title: a down to earth superman ( pun intended )

Review: I just saw Superman Returns today, curious how Brandon would compare to Christopher Reeve.Being a new actor, I think he did a good job. He has an intense yet somewhat caring stare which is what Christopher Reeve had.The opening sequence with the plane and shuttle was amazing. I think to liven this up it needed more jaw dropping sequences such as that. However upon more thought I realised that this is called "Superman Returns" for a reason.This movie is to set the foundation for the upcoming sequels. He disappeared for five years and everyone has learned to cope without him. This whole movie is mainly about him repairing his relationships and re-establishing himself into human society. The whole Lex thing is more of a side story which I didn't really enjoy but Kevin Spacey does do a good job as always.The music was awesome. It brought back memories and emotions from the original.Now that Superman has returned and everyone has accepted him back, it will be exciting to see (hopefully) some action packed sequels to build on what happened in this movie.

Review Title: My Mission: To Save Superman Returns
Review: It seems that for some reason this movie is not getting the respect and viewership that it deserves. While a drunken Pirate (now please note I am not saying that Pirates of the Caribbean is not a good movie) smashes box office records, no one is going to see a movie about a cultural icon and a true hero, not to mention a good movie. So I have taken it upon myself to save Superman Returns, or at least try to get the point across that it is a good movie that anyone can enjoy. I am simply going to say, being a Superman fan, that I really enjoyed this movie. However I am not a homer when it comes to the things that I like. I can be critical, when being critical is required. However I don't have many things critical to say about this movie. Sure it starts a little slowly. But once it gets started it is a great ride with good acting, great special effects,and great action. Yes, Christopher Reeve was Superman, but that doesn't mean that Brandon Routh doesn't do a good job as Superman. He is just a different Superman. Just like, in my opinion, Sean Connery was the best James Bond, I still enjoy the other people that were James Bond. The rest of the cast is very good, including Kate Bosworth, who I was a bit skeptical of at first. This movie is for everyone. It actually has twists that old and new fans of the Superman can enjoy, and you really will believe that a man can fly. In this time when people need heroes, and our world and our movies seem full of villains and "anti-heroes" Superman Returns is a movie that shows us a true hero, regardless of if he is a fictional character or not, and we see him in a great movie.

Review Title: A worthy, if slightly unnecessary, addition to the series.
Review: Superman is undoubtedly the most loved and well known superhero ever to grace the big screen. I have never been a great fan personally, but the return of such an iconic figure promises a higher than average quality summer blockbuster, as well as raising the bar on the recent spate of big-screen superhero appearances, which has, in my opinion, largely only produced slightly above average films (the only exceptions being Batman Begins and Spiderman 2).I remember watching the original films as a kid, and as the credits rolled at the start of Superman Returns I felt shivers down my spine as the familiar John Williams theme tune pounded out during the opening credits. Bryan Singer has been very sensible with this film, essentially changing very little in terms of formula, but taking full advantage of the recent developments in technology to create a more satisfying portrayal of kypton's favourite son. That said, you have to wonder whether the whole exercise is worth it, when so little is added to the superman story.After a five year hiatus, searching for the remains of his ancestor's civilisation, Superman returns to earth to find things have moved on a little in his absence. The people of earth have had to cope without their saviour and their anger is given a voice through Louis Lane and her Pulitzer winning article 'Why the world doesn't need Superman'. She is in denial, of course. The world needs Superman, and so does she. Despite having a fiancé and young child, her heart belongs to her ex-colleague Clark Kent's world famous alter-ego.Which leads us on to the most pressing question; does Brandon Routh compare to Superman's most famous recent portrayal by Christopher Reeve? Overall, Routh does a great job filling Reeve's shoes. He certainly looks the part, and as Superman he conveys that sense of strength and protection that lies at the heart of the character. The script, however, gives him few opportunities to stretch himself, particularly when he is disguised as Clark Kent. As Kent he comes across as a little dull, and is less successful at capturing the bumbling comedy than Christopher Reeve. Other performances are also a little lacking; Kate Bosworth offers nothing to hold the attention, and Kevin Spacey is given little chance to stretch his crazy muscle, which is a shame, because Spacey as Lex Luthor was one of the main draws of the film for me.In terms of action, effects and spectacle, the film succeeds on most levels. Seeing Superman fly is more breathtaking than ever. As he drifts through the city, pierces the clouds and leaves the earth's atmosphere, he is now more graceful and enjoyable to watch than ever. Most of the action sequences are spot on, particularly the plane crash early in the film, which ends in the sort of American grandstanding that one expects from this hero. Much of the excitement toward the end of the film hits the right buttons, although I found the final showpiece to be excessive and a little unimaginative.Despite its shortcomings, Superman Returns marks a clear return to form for the series after the massively flawed third and fourth additions to the series. The film is directed with confidence and ease by Singer, and Superman may have found a new face with Routh. In terms of a cinematic event, it doesn't really get much more exciting, as Superman once again sweeps Louis off her feet, catches some large things before they crush people, and rockets around the world (apparently faster than a speeding bullet) saving all and sundry. The film offers nothing new, but perhaps it was time to see Superman back where he belongs, dominating the summer blockbuster schedule.

Review Title: SR is Movie Perfection!  Thank you Bryan, Brandon, Kate, and WB!
Review: SR is Movie Perfection! Thank you Bryan, Brandon, Kate, and WB! After two more viewings last weekend (including 1st time in IMAX), I've now see SR five times. I may be a little obsessed, but who can blame me? It's just that good. I've never - ever - seen another movie in theaters five times (and only once before saw one four times).I truly LOVE this film and enjoy it even more with each new viewing. It's like movie nirvana from beginning to end. Everything about this film is perfect to me: the story, the direction and feel of the film, the visuals and effects, the music, the action, the romance, and especially Brandon Routh as Clark/Superman. It's exciting, fun, engrossing, entertaining, and very satisfying.I've been a long time fan of the original Superman movies (well, not so much 3 of 4) and both the Lois & Clark and Smallville TV series. I've also loved all of the actors who've played CK/SM, especially Chris Reeve, but Brandon is absolutely perfect. His look, his voice, his acting, and just the physical presence he brings the character are simply amazing. As others have said, I think he was born for this role, and we viewers are blessed that he was chosen and that he put so much effort and heart into really being Superman.Bryan Singer's story, vision and direction resulted in a movie that will forever be close to my heart. The film is breathtakingly beautiful and deeply engrossing. It's a very moving and emotional story. I can't take my eyes off the screen and the 2.5 hour run time flies by as fast as Superman himself.Kate also did a very good job as Lois. Her whole performance was great, but she sold me with the look on her face as she hid her true feelings after she told Superman on the rooftop that she didn't need him anymore.I can't wait to buy the DVD(s), and I'm hopeful there will be an extended directors cut version with the omitted scenes of Clark's trip to Krypton and the additional scenes on the Kent farm. I'm even more hopeful that there will be several blockbuster sequels in the coming years. Thank you to everyone who was involved with making this movie a reality.

Superman Returns is a Lazy Plagiarizing Rehash

Review: I have never been a Superman fan. Sorry, but I can not relate to him just because I was born and raised on Planet Earth and to get the Super attached is something I will never get. Yet, when Warner delivered their 1978 movie, I really enjoyed the film. So I did in 1980 with the second part, which by the way is one of those rare pictures that are better than the first one. I was 15 at that time. 26 years later, you would expect an improvement, don't you ? I mean, Christopher Reeve was not exactly the Actor of his generation, in fact, it seemed that his acting coach was a brick from the Brooklyn Bridge. Well Brandon Routh, makes Christopher Reeve look like Marlon Brando compared to him.He is plain, and boring and his acting on screen seems as fake as his eye contacts. Also Bosworth is disappointing as Lois Lane, and certainly you would expect more from Kevin Spacey but his Lex Luthor is more dull and never seems threatening or capable to inspire fear in any sense. It looks like a Hackman's Luthor decaffeinated. The main problem is that Singer tried too hard to have this superman more humanized, and yet as a Mesias (Brando's voice over: I sent you my only son to guide them etc.... )Even in some takes he resembles a cross (Sam Reimi already did that with Spidey in part II with much better results). The special effects also are not astounding at all. The aerial sequence in King Kong was far better done, than any on this movie, and also any Harry Potter/Narnia /Lord of the Rings has more creative effects also. The only two aspects that are outstanding in this movie are the main Titles and the Music. Taken directly from the 78 movie, they are the only reason why I gave this flop its two stars.

Review Title: Emotional trip, forget the rest the best is back
For those of us who miss Reeve and Kidder

Review: Go out and see this movie it is Phenomenal, it is very reminiscent of the old Christopher Reeve movies. This film will make you laugh and cry, it is a very enjoyable experience.Bryan Singer did a really excellent job with this film, it was both a fitting tribute to both Christopher Reeve and Marlon Brando.This film was dedicated to the Memory of Christopher and Dana Reeve. It was not dedicated to Marlon Brando, however using the old footage was a small dedication in itself.This film plays off as a sequel to Superman: The Movie and Superman II, however it doesn't clearly ignore the other two sequels. Bryan Singer was absolutely correct with his comment "If Smallville is superman for you this movie will work, if the Christopher Reeve movies are Superman for you this movie will still work". I tend to think this movie leans more towards the Christopher Reeve movies than Smallville, however there were small moments that did make you think of Smallville a little bit.Kevin Spacey gives a very good performance as Lex Luthor, he was definitely more evil than Gene Hackman, however at times Spacey proved like Routh to be reminiscent of his Predecessor. Overall see this movie you will not be disappointed, go out and rent or buy the DVD!I had to update this commentary by saying that there are far too many arrogant people on IMDb giving this movie negative reviews that are entirely uncalled for. The Message boards for this film are purely a disgrace and I would not waste my time responding to the smut that has been placed there. The negative comments I have been reading about this film are all biased and are apparently being placed by people who are quite narrow-minded and can't seem to see or understand the big picture of it all. Watch Superman II: The Donner Cut, you'll understand what Singer was trying to do with this film a little better.

Review Title: Superman Returns is the best movie of 2006
Review: Yep! SR is the best movie of this year. Forget Spiderman, Batman and others..SUPERMAN IS BACK. When i was a kid, i thought Superman actually did existed. Now i am a doctor and SR made me believe once again that Superman actually exists. Bryan singer's movie is so cool. Yeah he have made Superman bit emotional but who cares. He is still the biggest Superhero of all.Special effects are so real and great that the plane crash scene made everyone actually scared of flying again. Review Title: Not as super as I expected
Review: I was surprisingly disappointed in this film. Kevin spacey was great (wow, there's a shock - not. I actually liked him in K-Pax!!) I thought the actor playing Clark Kent/Superman was good, but I thought Bosworth was a very weak link in the "Lois' legacy. Lois is a spitfire -always ready to move, take an action, be involved. But I thought Bosworth's presentation was too reserved, too 'careful.' Rather than being pro-actively involved, I felt like Bosworth's "Lois" was dragging her feet, waiting to react - and then react very, very slowly, kind of like the way a person will run on slick ice. There might be motion, but the motion doesn't actually move the person forward gracefully or effectively. I also thought that the storyline was...pointless. Lex Luthor is being a pain - that's not new. Lex is out for revenge - that's not new. What, in my opinion, SHOULD have been the focus was the conflict between Lois and Superman - but there didn't seem to be any at all. Rather than dealing with their feelings, they seemed to gloss over them. "Oh, my heart was broken, now your back, let's have a chai latte!" There is no back story as to either why Superman left, what he did while he was gone, or how he felt about his discoveries (they summed up the entire adventure in about 2 sentences), or how he felt about his return. And because the discord wasn't there, neither was there an effective resolution, in my opinion. Visually, the film was as beautifully done as any I've ever seen, but the pace was pokey and overly drawn-out. The actions sequences were REAL heart-thumpers, but they were not in any way the focus of the movie, and only provided momentary breaks in the tedium. Superman, you may have returned, but frankly, I'm sticking with Smallville.

In my opinion this had to be one of the worst superhero films of all time. First, the cast selection was completely inappropriate. The feel here was like watching a brat pack movie. The entire cast was either too young, or just appeared and acted as such. Not one of the characters fit the bill as prescribed by the long history of comics and/or features preceding this flop.Superman/Clark Kent (Brandon Routh) was the worst fit of them all. Many other reviews have supported the age problem and many have stated that Routh was much too young for the role. The truth is that he is exactly the same age as was Christopher Reeve when he first appeared as the man from Krypton. However, Christopher Reeve was much more of manly figure with a more distinguished look, demeanor, and appeal. Though Routh could probably do well in a Teen-Beat magazine, he just can't escape his boyish persona and most likely will never match the Charisma of Reeve.Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth) also appeared much too young for the role in general, but also for the time frame for which this specific story is set. Her role and performance were nothing like the busy-body, always pressed for the scoop, reporter that Lois Lane has become known for.Perry White and Jimmy Olsen couldn't have been worse either. I just have to ask... What were the casting crew thinking? Or better yet, what were they smoking? Obviously they didn't do their homework on the characters of this legendary hero story and made a feeble attempt at creating the lineup.Now as for Kevin Spacey, I like the guy a lot and believe him to be a multi-talented performer. However, when I look at him in this film, I just can't see the sinister genius, Lex Luther. Maybe it was the directing, or again, just a bad fit for the part, but he just didn't cut it as Luther.The plot was terribly weak and the story itself was nothing more than shallow. Furthermore, the 2.5 hours of film time was pathetic and filled with little more than fluff. There was nothing to this film that couldn't have been shown in a substantially reduced time frame. In contrast, Saturday morning cartoons have more story and appeal than this product, and get more action across in a half hour versus the way too lengthy time period here. All in all, I believe it to be clear that this film was entirely slopped together for some quick bucks and relied purely on the premise that the public would jump at the opportunity to see Superman on the silver screen once more.The last disappointment in a long list was the Superman costume. First, you can't tell if the thing is supposed to be some type of leather, plastic, or rubber. Regardless, my opinion is that it looked ridiculous and is a failed attempt to bring Superman to the new millennium. Additionally, the effect of making the "S" on his chest and belt into dimensional objects was equally ridiculous. The product in whole looks more like something someone would wear to some wild sex party.Aside from some fair CGI, the entire film was a waste of their time and my money. For all those who haven't seen this film yet, rest assured that it won't take long to make it to DVD and ultimately to the cheap sales bin. Unless you just like to throw your money away, wait!11/28/06: Now the DVD is out and by it's initial price alone, proves what a dud this film was for the public. I stopped in the local Walmart to shop and passed by the display for this product. The price... a whopping $13, a value much cheaper than most films of lessor names. It's unfortunate that after almost 20 years since the last Superman film, this one did little to rekindle the story's flame.

When young Mr Kent returns to earth, his 'mother' is doing the washing up and listening to the radio, which, along with everything else, shakes. From memory this scene was filmed in western New South Wales, Australia - to look like rural America.I only spotted it at the last few seconds, but I am fairly sure said radio had Australian radio stations marked on the dial - such as 2BL in New South Wales and 4KQ in Queensland. These radio sets are history now. Media is not 'set in stone' as it used to be in those long-gone days.I would appreciate any other viewers of a film I thoroughly enjoyed giving me some feedback. I suspect only Australians will have picked up on this. I would appreciate a response to dick@tadaust.org.au

I was a bit disappointed with the movie, the actor playing Superman doesn't make me believe in the character, though Kate Bosworth is credible as Lois Lane. But i didn't really feel the chemistry between Superman and Lois, something is missing, then i would definitely choose the Spiderman movies. The evil Lex Luthor/Kevin Spacey is a deceiving 'bad guy' and the confrontation Luthor/Superman looks overall very fake.

Superman Returns director Bryan Singer is fast becoming something of an authority of the whys and wherefores of adapting comic books for the big screen. His hugely successful stabs at the X Men franchise produced two of the genre's high points and with Superman Returns, he once again demonstrates his unique ability to transfer characters and stories from page to screen yet still be able to bend story lines to his whim without angering the salivating Internet fan-boys for whom the phrase "artistic licence" is tantamount to racism. Yes, his dream of crafting a Superman film is another impressive title to add to the CV and sends a clear message that X-Men 2 was no fluke.Taking place five years after Superman 2 (and completely ignoring the lacklustre third and fourth entries into the series), the film sees Superman returning (obviously) to earth after a long trip into space to seek out the remains of his home planet. Arriving back in New York and reprising his hidden identity as the journalist Clark Kent, he finds that while the world is still in as much chaos as when he first arrived, his one-time squeeze Lois Lane has moved on to a new lover (James 'Cyclops' Marsden no less) and had a son in his absence. Initially, he tries to lead a quiet life but soon, events conspire to force him to don the iconic costume and fight for truth and justice once more which is incredibly well-timed given that Lex Luthor is lurking just round the corner with yet another Armageddon-inducing scheme.And from the pulse-pounding air-rescue to the jaw-dropping finale, the film delivers on it's promise as perfect summertime entertainment. Thankfully resisting the urge to reinvent the man of steel by adding too much darkness, it succeeds precisely because it knows what it is; a sequel, not a remake. As such, it stays faithful to the tone of the original and retains its sense of charm while the benefit of a twenty year advance in the field of special effects ensures that this is still a film for the X-Box generation.One of the best decisions Singer has made of course is by re-using the incredibly-hummable John Williams soundtrack. Blasting out the cinema speakers with the full power of twenty-first century sound, it evokes the square-jawed melodrama necessary to maintain the atmosphere as we cheer on our new hero. Listening to it again twenty years since the S man last graced cinemas serves as a reminder as to how good it really was all that time ago.Not that Superman Returns is all misty-eyed nostalgia mind you as we now have a brand new hero to cheer on. The previously unknown Brandon Routh makes for an ideal successor to his forerunner Christopher Reeve, striking just the right balance between muscle-bound indestructibility and the bumbling likability of his secret identity. Occasionally he has a second or two where a rabbit-in-the-headlights expression crosses his face as if the enormity of the acting job he's taken on has just occurred, but otherwise the man is perfectly cast. Plus, just to add sugar to the cake, he even looks like Reeve...And then we have Kevin Spacey who is clearly having an absolute whale of a time playing a maniacal super-villain. Striding around in a series of increasingly ridiculous wigs and blessed with lines like "Gods are selfish beings who fly around in little red capes and don't share their power with mankind," his role as Lex Luthor is another piece of inspired casting that makes you want to promote someone. Come to think of it, only Kelsey Grammar as Beast in the last X Men movie makes more sense.True, the movie isn't entirely made out of diamonds as Superman comes across as a bit too much like a stalker in one scene and Lois Lane is granted way more screen time than the character deserves, but these are small gripes in what is otherwise an excellent movie. Plus, as Luthor has very few expendable henchmen, the biggest set pieces come from battles against the elements which makes a pleasant change from the usual comic-book scraps against evil versions of the title characters. And while some may be put off by the lack of explanation for Superman's back-story, this is still a thrilling epic that barely feels like two hours, never mind the actual running time which is just shy of three. Highly recommended.

Review Title: SO SO SO SO.....BAD, I'm glad they did this....
This movie is just as good as the clothes the emperor wore.
This truly is one film not to be missed!!
this is no special over the top effects no plot film THIS IS THE RESURRECTION OF THE BIGGEST CLASSIC EVER
Review: I've NEVER WRITTEN A REVIEW BEFORE SO I'LL KEEP THIS SHORT, this is the best super hero film ever, i would go as far as to describe it as cinematic poetry, i have to stress to all, if you think your gonna go see something like spider man or or x-men you need to think again, whilst they were decent films in their own right I've been constantly disappointed by the the over the top special effect and tenuous story line, this film tells the story of superman's return, its an emotional, superbly written and cast resurrection of the superman story, there's far to much to comment on as far the film goes and i don't wanna spoil it for anyone, but i recommend it to all "except people that like films with no story and stupid special effects" please go see this with an open mind and be ready to enjoy one the best well thought out films for years.enjoy =o)

Review Title: This movie is one of the best I have ever seen!
Review: This comment is my opinion of the movie, I really don't want to reveal too much about the story, so if you want to know about it...go see it. I saw the movie in Imax 3D last night and I have to tell you, that was an adventure! I really enjoyed every bit of this movie. The characters were preformed by some terrific actors and I want to give my kudos to each and every one of them. Brandon Routh is amazing as the famous Man of Steel. He had a big suit to fill and he pulls it off with a wonderful performance. There were some scenes that I could almost see Christopher Reeves in Brandon.
