Review Title: Richard Donner said he loved this movie
some people just don't get what superman is about
No "Batman Begins", but still quite good
Review: Well, it certainly wasn't quite the amazing level that "Batman Begins" was last summer. But for all that, it still goes a long, long way toward resurrecting a previously comatose DC Comics franchise.There were some quibbles to be had with the film, to be sure - in fact, some quibbles that many had with BB last summer. For one, there are many things that you would think Superman would know better than to do that he goes ahead and does anyway. Now, last summer's Batman did the same thing, but here's the big difference - Bruce Wayne was just then starting out as Batman, whereas Clark Kent has been Superman for quite some time at this point. Truly he should have a better grasp on certain laws of physics than he seems to.All complaints aside, though, this movie was brilliant. Brian Singer deserves a round of applause for yet another fantastic superhero feather in his cap.

I'm nostalgic, and a big fan of the original films, so it would simply be against my very being to give this film a rating lower than 7 out of 10. And in fact I enjoyed the film enough to genuinely warrant that score, but there were some slippery moments! Everyone else has mentioned it so I won't linger on the point, but I'm repeatedly frustrated by the casting of actors in the wrong role for their age - and Loise Lane in this instance is a perfect example. Kate Bosworth is very attractive, and looks good on screen, but the fact is that when the film was shot she was barley 23 and she looks every inch of it. I just can't buy into her as Lois Lane; she's far, far too young. This film is supposed to be 5 years after the 1st and 2nd films. Margot Kidder was 29 when they shot those films. The maths speak for themselves.Perry White was nothing like Jackie Cooper's incarnation in the '78 films. Everything about the character is different. Frank Langella's 'White' is calm, softly spoken and looks more like a CEO than a Newspaper 'Chief'. I also felt that Jimmy Olsen was miscast, he just didn't look or feel right.On the plus side, as most everyone else has stated, Brandon Routh makes a very good Superman and an even better Clark Kent. A very good choice to follow-up Christopher Reeve. Reeve was a very hard act to follow, and I think this brave casting choice really works.A good film, worth watching and if you're a fan of the Superman films then you will enjoy it. Just be prepared to be flexible with some of the casting!

Man of Steel new adventure glides without energy, thought, Brian Singer's direction has style and strength.After waiting more than 10 years Superman fifth adventure has finally arrived to our screens. But this new movie hasn't got any kind of charm. And more important, "Superman Returns" doesn't invite anybody to dream as the original movie. The weakest point of this movie is its screenplay. And the reason-why is the overlong preproduction of this movie, that involved many directors from Tim Burton, to Kevin Smith or Wolfang Petersen. At the end, the screenplay was written by two many hands and the story lost his sense.On other hand, Brian Singer is a good director. He has enough sense of style and humor to make a good Superman adventure. As the director of X-Men 1 & 2, Singer proved as a good blockbuster director and more important, his movie had fine screenplays full of intelligence and humor. Superman Returns flacks both: the movie has a poor sense of humor (a childish humor) and absolutely no intelligence. Worst, the movie has a confused plot between a family drama, romance story and adventure.The other weak point is starring Brandon Ruth as the new Superman actor. The 26 years-old actor doesn't have the same irony and spicy humor as Christopher Reeve, the first and eternal Superman in the big screen. But, the worst cast selection is Lois Lane actress performance Kate Bosworth. The young actress (she is only 23) doesn't communicate the same power and energy as the original Lois Lane (starred by Margot Kidder). These two cast mistakes are forgiven by the excellent Kevin Spacey's Lex Luthor performance. The Academy-Award winner makes a histrionic performance, full of humor and sympathy with the audience.The excellent visual effects, art direction, original score, cinematography are the strong point of this vain adventure that the director, Brian Singer, uses with intelligence and extraordinary splendor (like a movie with a 260$ millions budget). John Ottman's score respects the original William's theme and adds more powerful themes that support the action and drama sequences.

As a rule, I'm fairly critical of superhero movies since passing the age of 25. However, Batman Begins in 2005 changed my perception of this genre, and Superman Returns has continued the trend.This movie was fantastic - exactly what it said on the tin. Brandon Routh was so similar to Christopher Reeve, I would have believed anyone who told me he was his son. The body language, the voice inflections - everything was perfect.The movie followed the traditional Superman format, was fairly restrained with it's use of CGI, and was great fun from start to finish. I was initially concerned about the introduction of a "kid", but he was adorable, and didn't irritate like most movie kids do.I'd recommend this movie to anyone, and I for one will be going again!

Review Title: Very Close To Perfect, but not.
Review: After years of waiting we have gotten a Superman film to be proud of and with that pride has come the question,"Was The Wait Too Long?" I don't think it was and I know that this is a film that deserves a sequel and also to be seen as one of the best movies of the Summer of 2006. You have to experience it your self to fully understand where I am coming from and what I am trying to get across. To watch this film is to witness a thing of beauty crafted with love and care and given to the audience as a gift to be cherished and admired. I am not saying that this film is perfect. It has its faults and in some cases glaring blemishes which leads to questions that beg to be answered, but they in no way detract from the pure movie going enjoyment you get from Superman Returns. My words do not do justice to my feeling about this movie. It can be seen by people who have followed the Superman moths for years or newcomers to it, but it must be seen.

This movie bored me in the first half an hour. With tens of millions of dollars spent they couldn't come up with anything better.I saw this 9 million dollar Indian movie called KRRISH which was 50 times better then superman.I was totally disappointed with the Superman Movie that they should have called it Superman Bore. The story was totally whack and the special effects (WHAT DID ALL THE MILLIONS GO ON) they could have been 10 times better.Compare the New Superman Movie to the Christopher Reeve's I'd have to say that the old movies were better then this new movie.I give it a 3 for a good try on the Special effects.

I have seen superman returns and I enjoyed it a lot. I was disappointed by the character of Richard as although he plays a part of a good man he steals the romantic part between Lois and superman. Brandon Routh plays his part brilliantly. I was and still am a great fan of Christofer Reeve and thought that no one would play superman again and be as good as Reeve was, but Brandon did not let the fans down. I think he was perfect for the role and I am glad that he was chosen. I liked the part of the son.....hopefully the next film would be more about him and superman....father and son. I hope this will not be the last of superman films.

With high expectations I'm not let down, to start off with, but as the film progresses it just becomes ludicrous and to be honest a little boring. If your going to make a modern Superman film why not lose the cape? All it does is flap around doing nothing much like the supporting cast. Routh is a good superman and could easily demand millions for a follow up. But the film is flat it lacks the emotional depth of say Spiderman, yes it has amazing CGI but that aside not much else. People are talking about Kevin Spacey's turn as Lex Luther but it is his dim-witted partner in crime Kitty (Parker Posey) who steals the show, she has all the best lines and preens her way excellently throughout all her scenes. The main thing wrong with superman is that there is nothing new here, I know technically it's a remake/new-version so there can't be, but everything here has been seen a hundred times before. Singer's inner geek/fan-boy lets him add some nice little touches like Marlon Brando as superman's dad (despite the fact he's dead!) but he also nicks bits from Titanic, The Matrix and even Batman Begins. It also uses probably the most overused cliché in cinema the 'sleeping beauty affect' and it is just lazy film-making and cheese of the highest order. The plane set piece is amazing to behold just like the rex fight was in King Kong, but it is also a let down because it leaves you with a feeling of what could have been. Sadly this is one off those films where all the best bits are either in the trailer or that advert for piracy you get before any film. Something just doesn't feel right about it, it lacks the edge that a superhero movie should have. Superman returns then but not with a bang.

As they say the "man of steel", well this film was 100% solid. Superman was played outstandingly by Brandon Routh. I thought his performance was brilliant and i could see and hear Christopher Reeve in him. His mannerisms were exactly like the original Superman. His arch enemy Lex Luther was funny as well as evil played by Kevin Spacey. He was great and able to continue the role that Gene Hackman played similar to that of Brandon and Christopher. Both actors were playing off each others reactions with great conviction and I hope they create another film based on this one.Well Done to all involved in the film * * * * * * * * * * 10 out of 10

Review Title: Good, but not even close to Great.
Review: The first thing that comes to mind when I think of this movie is the word: "unexpected." What was it exactly that the audience weren't totally expecting? Well, the Superman suit, which was revealed for sometime before the release of the movie, was a disaster. The colors are darker, and for the first time ever: Superman's cape looks like my shower curtain! Performances by the characters were sub-par. Probably the one who played his character best was Kevin Spacey. That may be a shock to those who haven't watched the movie yet; but in all honesty, Brandon Routh wasn't as good of an actor as I expected him to be. Maybe the script just didn't call for believable acting. I don't know.Kate Bosworth as Lois Lane? First off, don't expect the same Lois Lane from the 70's movies. Nope. This one is far removed from the Lois we have came to know and love from the comics. That is not good, at least not the way Bryan Singer did it. Bosworth is emotionless, bland, and acts like she doesn't really want to be in the movie all that much.The action? That is the redeeming quality of the movie. The action sequences are few and far between, but for example: the airplane action was great! Superman must save both a space-shuttle and airplane from exploding and killing all the passenger within. I must say, this whole scene was what made me think this movie was 'good'.But in truth: the story is plodding, not believable (in a bad way), and has no real color or pizazz. The greatest controversy comes from the fact that Superman has a son ... SUPERMAN HAS A SON! And not a very good one at that: Jason is sickly, weak, and well, just plain weird.Bryan Singer, I was kind to you and very lenient in giving this movie a '5/10'. God knows it didn't deserve a 6. But your intentions were good, and there are a few redeeming qualities about the movie ... but do better with the sequel, please!

We've waited for this film for a while now... Superman IV: The quest for peace finished filming in 1986. 20 years is a long time to wait. I wanted to love Superman Returns, but essentially it should have been called Superman Remade, or Superman Re-Hashed. It's simply a remake of Richard Donner's Superman (1978) Almost scene for scene in some cases. Dubed by bored critics as a "requel" I have to reluctantly agree, Singer does the fundamentals well, the action sequences particularly the Plane crash sequence are breathtaking, the love story between Lois Lane & Superman has been suitably complicated (for the sake of a sequel) although at times slightly 'soapy', there is fine line between a motion picture event and a two and half hour episode of "Lois & Clark: The new adventures of Superman". The cast had big shoes to fill and have acquitted themselves expertly; Routh copy's enough of the Reeve mannerisms and charm to get away with it. Bosworth is a more fragile Lois Lane but being decent eye-candy manages to see her through. Both have bright futures. Spacey does his textbook No #43 bad guy routine effortlessly with a special mention for the scene stealing Parker Posey.However I believe Singer and team chose to wrap themselves up in the mythology and popularity of the franchise and have robbed us of a chance of a NEW interpretation of a beloved superhero.

When I first went to see Superman Returns I have to admit my expectations were not very high. As many have realized there have been a lot of big budget movies that have been lacking (Poseidon, Xmen3 etc). I was greatly surprised though, the movie is definitely one of the best of the year. Bryan Singer, the mastermind behind the first two Xmen movies, has definitely proved himself as one of the best directors toady. He without a doubt did not squander the 260 million dollars he was given to shoot the movie creating a great film. Additionally the casting is excellent with Brandon Routh in his first main Hollywood role. Routh is almost identical with his portrayal of Superman/Clark Kent to Christopher Reeve. However the greatest strength of this movie is without a doubt the visual effects. The effects in this movie are so unbelievable, the filmmakers find the equilibrium of effects not over the top like Matrix Reloaded but completely realistic. The storyline in the movie is not the most elaborate but still good enough to keep the attention of the audience. Overall the movie is very good and is recommended for anyone action movie buff.

Review Title: Superman Returns is a great sequel to Superman II
Review: This review does NOT contain spoilers. There is nothing in this review that is not in the trailers.I was surprised by the amount of references to the 1978 movie, there is no doubt that this film was not just an homage to Richard Donner's film(s)…Superman Returns is a bonafide sequel to Superman: The Movie & Superman II! The cinematic abortions that were Superman III & IV can now be wiped from memory. This film is the real Superman III.And in making an actual sequel I think Bryan Singer pulled off a pretty difficult task.In order to re-introduce Superman to a new generation, he had to essentially rehash some of the old plot points from I and II, throw in the Superman lore basics, yet still manage to make a movie that felt fresh, taking a slightly different spin on the old threads, and introducing some new ones…all set years after the events of I and II.In the end I think Singer pulled it off…but there's no way he can afford to try that again.The next Superman movie should now be free to be a completely new story altogether, a proper sequel to Superman Returns with no more need for concrete ties to Donner's original.As for the actors, Brandon Routh was great…and at times he looked and sounded eerily like Christopher Reeve. They were difficult boots to step into but Routh handled it perfectly.Kate Bosworth on the other hand wasn't as perfect a fit for Lois as Routh was for Superman. While she's nicer to look at…she's not actually as enjoyable to watch. Margot Kidder played the role perfectly…she was always feisty as hell and hard as a nail when it came to dealing with people, but whenever she was around Superman she completely melted. The "I spent the night with Superman" scene from the 78 movie, referenced in this new one, is still the best scene from any Superman flick. Reeve and Kidder killed in that scene. But unfortunately Bosworth's Lois didn't resemble Kidder's at all and she didn't add much to the character in this film. I guess having the kid softened her up, but while that created some good ideas, it didn't make for a good Lois Lane.Spacey was great as Luthor, much less light hearted and witty than Gene Hackman was, but much more vicious, which was cool. I don't think Hackman's Lex would play well with today's audiences…as it was very cartoonish. Spacey did a good job.Overall I loved the movie…Superman flying around never looked as believable as it did in this film and the use of his powers were cool. The opening sequence is the best opening sequence I've seen since…well, Superman: The Movie…and for anyone who loves that movie the final shot of this film is killer.Also great is the retention of the Jesus Christ\Superman allegory from Donner's film, though while it was subtle enough in '78, this film smacks you in the face with it. But it's always been a cool idea so who cares?Superman has Returned!

At 26 years of age i went into the cinema not really expecting a great deal but confident i was going to see a good movie, how wrong was i.From the moment the opening credits rolled i was transfixed into an 8 year old, i had waited 19 years to see the re-birth of superman and i was not disappointed in the slightest.Brandon Routh had some pretty big shoes to fill and man does he fill them his portrayal of Clark is warm , funny and sincere and he brings an edge to Superman that we have never seen.Routh's Superman has Human emotions that we all feel pain, hurt, the fact that the woman he loves may have moved on and does not share the love that they once had, you actually feel for Routh's Superman and feel his hurt.This film has been accused of being more of a chick flick and i'll be honest i would share that sentiment but, i wouldn't have this film any other way as we have to appreciate after 5 years gone it was never going to be wine and roses for Superman and he could never just reappear as if nothing had ever happened and the focal point of this movie is the relationship between Superman and Lois Lane and this needed to be examined in the movie for Superman in a sense to be reborn in the movie and not lead us to believe in the 5 years he was gone his disappearance did not mean something to the woman he loved and woman who loved him back.Enough of that now , can i just say Kevin Spacey is Lex Luthor, Gene Hackman was good but Kevin Spacey rocks and you can tell he enjoyed his role and has taken Lex to a whole new Level, i can't say to much but when you view this movie you will see what i mean.I cannot fault any of the cast in this movie and Bryan Singer has stayed true to Donners vision of Superman that is updated for the audience of 2006 and in my opinion is simply the only man that could of carried off a revival of the superman franchise.In closing i would like to add that i was the last one to leave the cinema, my friends were pleading to go and i wouldn't go anywhere till i had heard the closing Superman theme so they waited outside.Last week a 26 year old man became an 8 year old boy and i realised something, the movie going world still needs superman because he makes us all feel better about the world.10/10

Review Title: Super Superman and Lame Lois....Much better title.....
Review: This past weekend I finally got a chance to go "Superman Returns" and with lots of expectations within, found myself applauding a lot of the performances, incredible CG, and a mostly talented cast. Brandon Routh was the perfect casting for the Man of Steel to carry on a the role. From his hometown boy smile to his "I'm the Man" attitude he pulled it off and did credit for his predecessors. A bit young for the role, but I think we all have to keep in mind the timeline of things. I'd actually read the book prior to seeing the screen version and naturally found that Bryan Singer had taken a lot of changes from print to screen, but that's okay. It's the name of the game.I'm not sure how or why they found Kate Bosworth, but of the whole movies disappointments, she lead the pack. Not because she's not Margot Kidder, but because her youth, inexperience and lack of screen presence were so obvious that it nearly pulled the movie down the tubes. She looked more like she was from Kansas than Clark Kent! Whether you're reading a comic or watching an early version, this woman was no Lois Lane. I mean, put Phyllis Coates, Noel Neill, Margot Kidder, Terry Hatcher, and finally Kate Bosworth next to each other and you'll find yourself singing "One of these things is not like the others"! It's not that she's a terrible actor, just truly not suited for this role and it's hard to believe that this fact slipped by when casting this person. Animated, spunky, charismatic, full of energy, and intelligent came natural for all of the others Lois's, but Kate somehow managed to make the role seem like a bowl of oatmeal without any sugar, fruit or butter. Anyway, I just couldn't see her pulling it off and please keep in mind, I wanted so badly to find nothing but positives about anything about this movie and the hard work put into bringing it to us, but Kate……..ya gotta go in the sequel honey!Kevin Spacey is one of my all-time favorite actors and it really wasn't a stretch to see him portray Lex Luthor. The man has got skills! Lex is someone we love to hate in a big way and bringing Mr. Spacey into the project helped keep things afloat and interesting for us!Sam Huntington was another good pick because he made the belief that he really was the lovable shutterbug we've come to love over the decades. Great job Sam!Hmmm, Frank Langella is another of my favorite screen actors, but as Perry White? Talented as the man is, he was just a little watered down for the Perry White I remember in books and screen. I could be totally off base, but since I've been reading "Superman" for over 35 yrs, I found the man to be loud, direct, focused, rude and generally doesn't care about others opinions about anything he's got going for himself. Frank tried, but came across as more of a wolf in sheep clothing. Go figure! Over all, it was okay and I did enjoy it, but couldn't also help but feel let down a little and found myself hoping that the sequel will pick up the slack for all of us.

Review Title: 154 minutes of my life I can never get back
Review: If I could meet Bryan Singer I would say one thing. "I want the last 154 minutes of my life back". Then I would beat him for 154 minutes, to make up for the tragic loss of my life during this turd of a film.You have a great cast. Watching Brandon Routh is like watching Reeves reincarnate!!(hence 3 out of 10 not 0) Spacey is perfect as the crazy Luther. Even Kate Bosworth is OK, wet but OK.You have some great action scenes and effects.But the script is so bad that predictable does not begin to describe it. The Story line is interesting but again, so clichéd and predictable that it is painful. All the parts were there for him, but he fails to knit them together.Singer is trying so hard to make this an intelligent film, that he forgets to make it entertaining. If I want intellectual I will watch Schindlers list. I wanted all out action and heroics. That is what Superman is all about, not this over scripted, badly written emotional crap.Sorry, I had such high hopes that I feel crushed with disappointment. Even the "twist" is so predictable you see it coming in the first 15 minutes.Singer you owe me and my wife 154 minutes.And X-Men was so good.

Review Title: The man of steel is back, and what a return it is!
Review: I think the thing I liked the most about this film, is that you can't be indifferent to the characters and to (most of) the events taking place in the film. I think that what made me give this movie an 8, is because I was emotionally drawn into some of the scenes of the movie. It's not a classical action packed film like mission impossible 2. It is more of a drama than the classical Comic action movie (like x-men 1 or the fantastic 4). Who will like this movie? If you liked Spider man 2 and 1, you'll probably enjoy this one as well. if you liked the original Superman movies, you'll feel at home here. The plot it self is not so original and pretty simple. There are a lot of emotions between the two main characters of the film, and I actually felt great sympathy to the man of steel and all he goes through. I was worried, I was even a little moved by some of the final scenes. The musical score, partially based on the original John Williams Score is outstanding and serves the plot very well. The visuals are great as well. except for one or two shots where it is obvious that CG was used, everything looks very authentic. 400 millions the movie cost, and you can certainly see where it went. I really liked the shots of superman in outer space.Who will not like this film? Well, if you didn't enjoy Spider man2 you can leave this one behind. if you're not into comic super heroes type of films or you didn't like the original Superman films- you can leave it behind too. I think the reason I gave it an 8 and not a 9 or a 10 is because of lack of depth in the plot. But all in all - It is anything but easy to bring Superman to the screen after 14 years break. I think that Bryan singer did it respectfully.I liked the words of Jor Al, Superman's father (The voice of Marlan Brando), which is heard at the end of the teaser trailer (and in the movie) as well... an optimistic view on humanity and man kind... Call it stupid but for me it Feels like an added value. I feel like watching it all over again...

Review Title: Stunning revival of The Man Of Steel.
Why the world doesn't need Superman (Returns)

Review: I was skeptical at first about going to see this movie, as I am so use to seeing Christopher Reeve play the part of Superman for so many years now. But I was very pleased with the movie and the actor Brandon Routh who portrayed Superman. And I was very touched and very overwhelmed that at the end with the credits, they dedicated in memory of Christopher and Dana Reeve. That touched me so much that it made me cry.I am so glad to see that you remembered Christopher and Dana Reeve when you made another Superman movie.They both are greatly missed. I liked seeing that you tried to pick someone who resembled a close look to Christopher Reeve.

Review Title: i was expecting more from the Superman Returns movie
A fantastic, grown up super hero movie
Review: This is a movie that, similar to Peter Jacksons efforts, concentrates on elements of story that we sort of already know, throws in a few intelligent twists, and lets the CGI complement the story. Obviously comparisons will be drawn with other super hero movies such as X-men, Spiderman, Fantastic 4, etc but those were movies aimed squarely at today's youth that like a good bit of hour and a half popcorn accompaniment. It wasn't until the 2nd or 3rd sequels that they really get into their character based stride. If you must make a comparison then this is more akin to the last Batman movie. The acting is absolutely as good as it needed to be for this type of film, with a brilliantly cast Kevin Spacey, and a brilliantly mis-cast Kate Bosworth, who just manages to be a bit Lois like near the end. Brandon Routh is a movie find in a million, bringing to the roll the elements that the comic book hero exuded from every atom. He's sculpted rather than born, beautiful and handsome mixed, super in every way. If the had to cast David then Routh is your boy. The plot is very comic book, and it won't win an Oscar for originality. However the underlying story about the loss of love, the pain of realising your heroes don't exist anymore, and then the rebirth of hope, rekindling of feelings, and acceptance of the now rather than past is where Singer, Dougherty, and Harris really make the biggest impression. In one heartstoppingly dramatic moment I have never heard s cinema so quiet, and I mean not even a breath. Two and a half hours flew past. The balance of action/front story/backstory is a little out. There are some great action scenes, and I'd have liked to see a couple more. The Lex Luthor story is a little underplayed, and almost second to the relationship drama (so take your girlfriend, she'll like that...). Overall though, there is a fantastic sense of wellbeing when the film ends. It's OK, he's back. See it, there's nothing wrong with it, and very, very much right with it.

Review Title: Superman 'Returns' from a five year absence to discover Lois has gone off with anther man...
Review: 'Superman Returns Disastrously' would be a more apt title for this shambolic, self-indulgent, overly-serious, dark and forbidding nightmare-world Brian Singer seems compelled to create whenever he ventures into the world of Superhero-dom. What he hopes to achieve by making everything so god-damned serious, I simply don't know, though I'm sure he believes he's done a great job restoring the character to his original 'moody' roots... Either way, the result of this 'restoration' is a masterpiece (or should that be 'crassterpiece'?) of formal, modern, wooden cinema that's worthy of an place alongside his other notable contribution toward world boredom, X-Men 1.Sorry for the negativity but there are lots and lots of problems with this film and I'm sure the people who've stupidly given this film a high rating will come to hate it with time - just like they did when they brought themselves a copy of Star Wars III on DVD and realised finally that the whole prequel 'experiment' had been a shambles from the start...It's not that I'm against Superman - I loved the previous films and Christopher Reeve was a legend in the role... But Brandon Routh ain't no Christopher Reeve and never will be. The same applies for Kate Bosworth, Kevin Spacey and the rest of the 'clones' they've hired for the project (seemingly on looks alone, for certain cast-members). But this isn't the actors fault - it goes deeper than this. The real fault lies with the producers. They're the ones that chose Bryan Singer to direct; they're the ones that okeyed the boring, tiresome script, and they're the ones that didn't demand the necessary changes to the yawn-inducing two-and-a-half hour story that focuses more on the characters 'feelings' rather than giving us the healthy dose of action, adventure and invention we expect from a Superman film. It hurts me to say this but what this picture really needed was Jerry Brockheimer at the helm. At least then Superman could have spoke with actions... and not the tension-ridden 'facial expressions' Bryan Singer seems to obsessed with.I can just picture the scene on set...Bryan Singer: "OK Brandon, give me 'heartbreak'! Brandon Routh: (gurns his face) "Grrr!" Bryan Singer: "More! That's good! Now throw in a bit of tension... Great! Now furrow your brow like this... OK, more!" Brandon Routh: "I'm furrowing as much as I can!" Bryan Singer: "Bulls**t! - There can never be 'too much' furrowing! If only Hugh Jackman hadn't turned down the role - now he's a man that can furrow, I tell thee!"Tom Richards

Superman Returns...from his home planet, Krypton, the destruction of which years earlier sent Superbaby to Earth. (How the now-grown Superman visits a destroyed planet in the first place is another story.) During the course of the movie, Superman ascends to and hangs in outer space to survey which crisis to resolve and which people on Earth to save next, proving that he can either breathe in outer space (hey, if George Lucas can stage space battles with sound effects where no atmosphere exists...) or else hold his breath for a very long time. Yes, it's a comic, Folks. Case closed.But beyond the comics, despite a slow, lingering start (one can but imagine what scenes may be "edited for time" to fit into a two-hour TV time slot) the movie eventually revs up to blood-hot excitement with Superman's first save of the day. (Some reviewers have wondered how nobody in the movie noticed that Superman and Clark Kent returned at the same time after a five year absence. My wonderment is how Lois Lane managed to avoid certain-death situations during that same time period.) The one problem I had with this movie, although every actor turned in a fine performance, was that it was hard for me to get excited about, or involved with the characters in, any scene that didn't include Superman. Also of note, but not a problem, per se, is that I often found myself wondering, "What's going on here?"...but director Bryan Singer managed to resolve most, if not all, such questions eventually.Having watched George Reeves' Superman on TV as a child, I was looking forward to seeing the actors who played Lois Lane and Jimmy Olsen (Noel Neill and Jack Larson, respectively) from that series in this movie. I love it when I see actors older than I, like these (along with Eva Marie Saint as Martha Kent) still alive and kicking...and performing! I just wish they could have found a part that would have made Ms. Niell more "recognizable." (Saying more might give something away.) As for the principal actors, I found the new Superman, Brandon Routh, to be quite acceptable, although I thought some of his lines could have been delivered with a bit more nuance. And of the half dozen or so actresses I've seen portray Lois Lane, I found Kate Bosworth as competent and captivating as any of them. Veteran Kevin Spacey makes an ideal Lex Luthor -- evil inside but deceptive in demeanor (except when riled) -- while Frank Langella as editor Perry White, and Parker Posey as bad-girl-with-a-soft-heart Kitty Kowalski are equally well-cast. (I saw James Karen in the credits but not in the movie. Perhaps they're saving his scenes for the DVD.) In the end, director Singer effectively combines action and romance to make this comic into a thoroughly human movie. The scenes between Lois and Superman are particularly touching.(One has to pity poor James Marsden as Perry White's nephew, Richard, and Lois' live-in partner. In vying for the heart of The Daily Planet's star reporter, Superman doesn't play fair merely by being himself.) I'm definitely looking forward to a sequel!

Mr. Singer you have done us proud.I'll keep my comments on the film itself brief- straight forward story, great casting, great score (winning idea to retain Williams' themes, but Ottman added some great moments of his own), great pacing, beautifully, romantically and iconically shot and it left me with a great feeling at the end. Countless spine-tingly moments. By far the best critically reviewed blockbuster of the Summer and for once I agree with the critics.Now down to the nitty gritty- The reason for its box office slump? An extremely poor marketing campaign and general cynicism. I haven't met one person who didn't love this movie having seen it, but unfortunately I have met many more who didn't even know a new Superman film was coming out. THAT IS RIDICULOUS- the biggest and most well known superhero of them all and nobody knows about the characters' major new motion picture? Why do they not know? Poor marketing, as I've said.Warner, you have a lot of explaining to do- you may well have single-handedly destroyed your strongest franchise. For months my brother and I have been wondering "Where is the big push?" We could see Pirates and X-3 posters and trailers everywhere since last year, awareness was way up and everybody went to see them. The trailers were available for Superman, but they weren't being screened, the posters and standee's only went up weeks before release in cinemas, billboard posters in my home town were non-existent and as a result, awareness was way down. Even fans of Smallville I spoke to, weren't aware that a new Superman movie was coming out!!! Warner have done this twice now- once with Batman Begins and now with Superman Returns- easily 2 of the best superhero movies around and neither one did the box office that was expected. Why?!!! Poor marketing. I wonder if the Matrix debacle has something to do with this. Heavily hyped and subsequently, Reloaded did well because EVERYBODY and his dog went to see it once, but not many people liked it- the 3rd movie therefore failed. Maybe because of this, Warner are afraid to pump money into marketing big movies in a big way in case poor word of mouth brings the film to its knees- They needn't have worried with Batman and Superman- both are great movies.Warner, pull your socks up and give Bryan Singer the chance to make another Superman movie and this time, market the sh*t out of it. It's either your arrogance or fear which has lead to this movie not bringing in the expected receipts and neither Singer nor the film is to blame. Take some responsibility, admit you were wrong in how you handled the marketing and get cracking with the next movie. Singer and the fans deserve it.

Review Title: The Man Of Steel is back !!!
Review: Just saw it (an hour ago) and I highly recommend the movie. Great casting, great shooting and computer graphics well used. Me and Orna (my girlfriend) were so excited to hear Marlon Brando and see Superman flies again after all this time. When I first heard that Superman returns, I wasn't sure that he can fly again. After two and half hours, we discovered that the man of steel is back ! Watching Superman fly, the explosions and his miracle powers are just wonderful and will forever be in the mind of movie goers. Christopher Reeve, thank you for your legacy. Brandon Routh - bravo ! There is no way to be disappointed. Go and see it.

What hasn't been said about this movie in the last couple of weeks? Well, I think this is one of the best films I have seen in a very long time and to be honest, you have to watch it on the big screen. The special effects, the acting, the story are all excellent. The Direction is seamless and the CGI's are cleverly done. I'm not going to describe what's in the film, but the overall sensation of watching it is an uplifting one - you want to believe a man can fly and most certainly with the special effects in this film, you take it for granted that he can.Brandon Routh is an excellent Superman, very reminiscent of Christopher Reeve, Kevin Spacey plays a genuinely unnerving Lex Luthor and Kate Bosworth gives a touching performance as Lois Lane. From the moment the film starts with a very definite nod to Donner's original and the rousing John Williams score, you know you're in for a good time. And boy do you get it! Simply put - go see this film. It's not perfect, it's not the best film of the last decade or any of that nonsense, it's just pure entertainment from start to finish. Thank you, Bryan Singer.

Review Title: Let the child in you out when you go and this movie

Review: It's been over 19 years since Superman last graced our screens. The All American Icon, portrayed by the memorable and unfortunate late Christopher Reeve, won over audiences in the 70's and 80's with his action, effects, characters and plots. The WB has spent years, and nearly 260mil dollars trying to bring the most loved Superhero back to our screen, and with Bryan Singer leaving X-Men- it seems they have. Filmed right here in Australia, no movie is more anticipated this year, then the year that Superman Returns.Following a mysterious absence of several years, the Man of Steel comes back to Earth in the epic Superman Returns. While an old enemy plots to render him powerless once and for all, Superman faces the heartbreaking realization that the woman he loves, Lois Lane, has moved on with her life. Or has she? Superman's bittersweet return challenges him to bridge the distance between them while finding a place in a society that has learned to survive without him. In an attempt to protect the world he loves from cataclysmic destruction, Superman embarks on an epic journey of redemption that takes him from the depths of the ocean to the far reaches of outer space.While no one can replace Christopher Reeve, when Brandon Routh turns around as Clark Kent and Superman, you could swear it was 1978. Kate Bosworth is a little aggressive and not as quirky as Lois Lane, but she makes up for it in making Lois more then a victim. The highlight performance for me though was Kevin Spacey- who shows no compassion, reason or sense as the ultimate villain. He masters the role.While no movie can rely on special effects, Superman Returns certainly has plenty of it. From the most amazing plane sequence in cinema history, to the saving of Metropolis with his powers- the effects show us the action and keep it as real as possible. Another amazing feature of production is that Superman Returns was shot entirely digitally, with no film. It gives the film as pastel look, that's suits well with a 21st century Superman.The film also dives into a couple of themes like father/son relationships between alien and human. Some of the stuff is deep, not what you'd expect from a Superman film. Also, crowd reactions to disaster of a sense of doom. This is a post 9/11 Superman.Although it took over 19 years for Superman to Return- he has. He has flown in and won over the hearts of fans and casual movie goers alike. While at times suffering from some slow scenes, Superman Returns maintains the grace and standard of Richard Donners 1978 film. Go and witness the rebirth of a global icon. Witness Superman's return. 9/10

Although Brandon Routh is beautiful, Chris Reeve had more charisma from his wheelchair. I just watched S1 again and the comparison is unfortunate for the 'new' superman. Not to mention all of the lines and situations that were flat out stolen from the original movie. Keven Spacey, however, is brilliant and Parker Posey is quite amusing, particularly when compared to Kate Bosworth's mushy Lois Lane. What about Mr. Spacey and Ms. Posey as Superman and Lois and leave the other two out of the next movie? Yeah, the FX are cool, but the movie drags badly, with pacing sacrificed to FX. They tried to make up for a bland Superman and Lois with the FX - I was bored after 30 minutes with 2.5 hours to go...

Review Title: With the planet on his shoulders…Daily
Review: Superman Returns. The name says it all. Our Man of Steel returns to our collective consciousness after almost 20 years. Has he arrived with the big bang all the hype has culled together? Unfortunately, not even close. Bryan Singer leaves his flourishing X-Men saga to helm an obligatory bridge episode in an already watered down series. While Chris Nolan had a ton of success with his reinvention of the Batman chronicles, Singer is hindered by the fact that this is a continuation two decades later. The heart and emotion is there, the acting is there, the story could have been rewritten with slight changes—all for a rebirth of the legendary hero. Instead, we as an audience go into the movie knowing its place in history, occurring after the first two installments as movies three and four have been all but erased from the echelon of cinema. Too many callbacks to the original, too much unwarranted camp in an otherwise serious drama, too muddled of a story where we as an audience are reminded by characters about a plot point before we are whisked off to continue that story thread. There is some intelligence in the movie going public, we know the story of Superman and didn't need a handholding session in a sequel, which they decided for this to be.Maybe it's the fact that we have been given the brilliantly handled television drama Smallville, which delves into Clark Kent's psyche and opens our eyes to the real trouble his dual life creates. It seems the filmmakers also have this in the back of their heads—besides the fact that even though we have moved Metropolis back to the east coast, a train set still contains the obscure town sign of Smallville, Kansas—as they seem to want to take a serious tone, although they won't quite take it the distance. Sprinkled in we have Kevin Spacey's Lex Luthor, with great shades of sinisterness, trying too hard to do his best Gene Hackman impression. The camp just didn't fit the character we are introduced to, a man much eviler than Hackman's incarnation who would con an old millionaire woman on her deathbed to signing over her estate while the family waited outside. The indecision to pick a consistent tone with Lex made it hard to really see him as someone capable of mass-genocide; we desperately needed Ned Beatty's bumbling Otis to play him off of, instead of the stoic, hardened criminals he accompanies. Also, Parker Posey is an annoying, thrice-removed Xerox copy of the old Mrs. Teschmacher; and did Kal Penn get paid for this movie or did he remove himself from the film and they decided not to redub his lines with another actor as they did for Gene Hackman in Superman 2—I don't think he spoke one word in the entire movie.The film was not without its merits, however. Brandon Routh does an amazing job filling the large shoes left by the late Christopher Reeves. He isn't given much of an opportunity to run with the Clark persona, hopefully subsequent films will bring out more of this, but his portrayal of the conflicted Kal-El is well played. Props also go to Kate Bosworth with a nice turn as Lois Lane. Having really only seen her in the likes of Blue Crush, with exception to a good performance in Wonderland, I was pleasantly surprised to see her pull off playing a character beyond her years, (a 23 year old actress playing a Pulitzer Prize winning star reporter for the biggest paper in the country's biggest city), a stretch for most as seen with Katie Holmes' dismal portrayal of an Assistant DA in Batman Begins. The twenty-first century also helped usher in some gorgeous special effects, with detailed set pieces and action scenes, (the airplane/shuttle rescue was well executed visually). Instances of see-through vision also sparked my attention, most evident in Clark following Lois through the Daily Planet doors, up the elevator to the roof.Singer seemed to have had all the elements there for a successful restart in a dead series. He should have created a new world as he did with X-Men's tie to reality instead of trying to build upon a 20-year old movie. Callbacks in movies of this kind are good fodder for laughs to the fans of a series. Short quips like Jimmy Olsen's initial "Mr. Clark! Kent…I mean Clark Kent" and Clark's "swell" remind you of scenes from the original and bring a small to your face. However, having a moment like this every 10 minutes gets old and very unoriginal, from Lex's speech about his father's advice to gather land, Superman's "flying is still the safest way to travel", and his "Lois you really shouldn't smoke", we are beaten over the head with these allusions to past greatness. (And on the smoking front, is our society so without faith in our parenting skills on teaching kids not to smoke that we have to put smoking as a rating point. It's as if our favorite chain-smoker Lois Lane would have died instantly, or at the very least caused an R-rating had she actually lit that cigarette; it's a part of her character. Being weak and taking that out was a public service announcement that took me out of the film a bit, especially when it is then OK to show Lex puffing on his cigar.) I won't even mention the unnecessary plot-device of Lois's child or the few discrepancies to the previous two films we are to believe this follows, or the multiple Jesus allusions—well I guess I just did. The makings of a great installment were there, but expectations were not fulfilled. Hopefully the Return has happened and now Singer and company can sink their teeth into a real Superhero masterpiece. The dream is still alive.

Review Title: I wasn't expecting much, so it wasn't too bad
Review: Movies are terrible anymore, but I still occasionally like to go to theaters (especially when the weather is forecast at 96 degrees) so I have been reduced to seeing movies like "Superman," even though I don't like action films, or read comic books, and two hour and 49 minute running times are not exactly a turn on, either...In spite of that, this wasn't the worst movie ever made. Like about 90% of the movie going public, I had never heard of Brandon Routh, and since he's a young "pretty boy," I was expecting him to be pretty awful, so while I don't exactly expect him to clean up at that Academy Awards (as if that's really a measure of talent anymore, anyway) he wasn't that bad. Kevin Spacey, as evil Lex Luthor, was a little happy and over-the-top, but was kind of written as such and I enjoyed the 'team' of Parker Posey and him. (I think the film could have saved a couple of million dollars in the budget by eliminating Luthor's other friends, however (except perhaps that man with the skeleton tattoo) as they mostly just stood around and scowled.) As for Kate Bosworth... I didn't exactly find her endearing, though a little of that may have been the character of Lois Lane. This wasn't exactly my first exposure to "Superman," but it came close enough, and, well... I can only hope Lois Lane was more likable in the older versions. I couldn't imagine why one man would find her appealing, let alone two...As I cannot judge a movie on acting and characters alone, this one was fair. Movies like "Superman" are never made for their wonderful scripts and this one... wasn't the best, my biggest complaint being lack of development. While I will credit "Superman" above such films as "War of the Worlds" with having at least SOME development and continuity, there were definitely a lot of things that went unanswered. I didn't especially care for all of the past tense referrals in the beginning, which, combined with the somewhat strange title of what is assumingly part one of a series made me feel like I was actually seeing a sequel first. I also would have liked to have seen more Clark Kent, who I felt was hideously underdeveloped. I would have gladly traded the numerous scenes of rocks flying through the sky (what was with that?) for more scenes of Clark and "Earth" mother(especially an explanation of his first scene where he came falling into the farmhouse yard appearing on the verge of death... and was completely fine and suddenly in "Metropolis" in the next scene.) I wouldn't have minded learning more about the Lex Luthor character, who vaguely moved about with no rhyme or reason. While I was entertained enough by Lex Luthor, and I don't exactly mind 'not' being scared by a villain, the character was almost a little bit too silly and not exactly a role Kevin Spacey is going to get taken seriously for.I don't think "Superman Returns" will ever be taken seriously by anybody and it doesn't exactly have the makings of a film that will even be much remembered in years to come. With it's (needlessly) long running time, I honestly don't even know if I'll be watching it again (at least not in its entirety), but it was likely better than most of the other junk that's out these days and was a perfectly inoffensive way to spend a 90+ degree afternoon.

Like many other people, the character of Superman has always been a firm favourite of mine dating back to my childhood. Christopher Reeve's Superman made me believe a man could fly with the light-hearted 'Lois and Clark' series seeing me through the Nineties. I was sceptical as the next Supes fan when I heard they were to bring back the character, recast and revitalised for a twenty-first century audience. But having seen 'Superman Returns', those fears were instantly pushed back as I now eagerly await a sequel.'Superman Returns' is set five years after Christopher Reeve's 'Superman II' (thankfully ignoring the events in the lacklustre 'Superman III and IV'). Superman, after five years of searching for the remains of his homeplanet Krypton, has returned to Earth to resume his life as Clark Kent only to find things moved on without him. Lois Lane is now mother to five-year-old son Jason and engaged to Perry White's nephew Richard. She is also thoroughly disenchanted with Superman although it soon becomes clear there is much unresolved feelings between the two. But between juggling his conflicting emotions for Lois and his duties to protecting the population, Superman has to face his arch-enemy Lex Luthor, who has stolen the crystals from the Fortress of Solitude and is intent on using them to rule the world.It was never going to be easy Brandon Routh to step into Christopher Reeve's shoes but he takes it in his stride, managing to capture the bumbling but kindly nature of Clark and the strong, reserved demeanour of a Superman who strives to find a balance between his alien heritage and the life he has made for himself on Earth. He both makes the role his own yet does well in succeeding where Reeve left off. Kate Bosworth was also another surprise. I was very disappointed in her casting initially but seeing her perform in the film left me realising that she was perfect for the job as she portrays the cocky and determined yet vulnerable Lois to a tee. Kevin Spacey was great as the obsessive, slightly unhinged Luthor who possesses a real hatred for our hero while Parker Posey gave us a nicely-portrayed 'shades of grey' character in Kitty, a villain with a heart. Even the little moppet who played Jason gave a decent performance without being wooden or grating.What I loved most about the film is that it delivered an interesting storyline that didn't reject the first two 'Superman' films, which are classics in the heart of any Superman fan and had already done a good job in covering the origins story. But at the same time, it didn't shirk in giving us deeper insights into the character of Superman, the solitary hero and the man who just wants to fit in. What was a pleasant surprise was that the film also refused to dumb down to small children in the audience, which is a growing problem with many Hollywood films that over-dose on infantile humour to appeal to kids resulting in boredom for anyone over fourteen. There was humour, some on a level to make children laugh, but overall there was a nice mix of action, romance and darkness aimed more at an older audience. They even avoid the clichéd pitfall of portraying Lois' love interest to be a sanctimonious twit and instead he came across as a genuinely nice guy who shows that it's understandable why she has problems choosing between him and SupermanIn fact, my only real problem was that there wasn't enough interaction between Lois and Clark, which would have been nice as Clark's jealousy towards his alter-ego and the attention Lois lavishes on him is a large part of the story yet in the film, you felt as if Clark and Superman really were two different people with Clark just being some rather random guy. However, it can be over-looked by the fact that Clark was so happy to just have Lois' attention that he didn't care whether it was projected onto himself in his real personality or on Superman.For anyone who has yet to see the film, I do recommend it and don't allow yourself to be put off by nitpickers complaining about the actors' being too young (better they be a shade on the younger side than going the 'Smallville' route where you have adults in their late twenties and thirties prancing around pretending to be teens and just looking ridiculous for it) or that the film is too long (even the eight-year-olds in the audience sat quietly, glued to the screen, for the entire film) or that it's bland (no more so than 'Spiderman'). I, for one, thoroughly enjoyed it and am looking forward to a sequel. After a rather dull summer at the cinema, this film renewed my faith in the summer blockbuster!

In this sequel to Superman, Routh and Spacey mimic the roles played by Christopher Reeve and Gene Hackman in the original but they are not as good as the original and neither is the film as enjoyable as the original. The 1978 film, hardly a classic itself, at least had a sense of fun and did not take itself too seriously. Singer attempts a darker mood but ends up sucking all the joy out of it. The action scenes are too drawn out, loud, confusing, and laden with special effects. The best parts of the movie are the scenes between Clark and Lois but there are few such scenes and they are not mined for all their comic potential. The acting is OK but the film is a disappointment because the plot is lame and the direction is misguided.

Review Title: The movie sets up a sequel better than it tells a story.
Review: I am a huge Superman fan. I went to see the movie on its premier night, but was not impressed. I enjoyed seeing the film because it has been a long time since the last Superman movie, but not because I thought it was a good movie. I just enjoyed seeing Superman again. The movie sets up a sequel better than it tells a story, it is unfortunate and unnecessary. I guess the writers felt they had loose ends to mend, attempting to revive the storyline, they created more of a cliff notes movie sequel to the Christopher Reeves movies rather than a movie that could stand on it's own. Movie making technology has improved so much that on that basis alone fans should see the film, but it pales in comparison to the Spiderman movies. Why do the writers feel compelled to carry forward the same storyline as the Christopher Reeves movies? Everyone knows it's a completely new cast of actors playing the roles, so why not start fresh with a new storyline? It's disappointing. I've seen the movie once and probably will not see it again.

Review Title: Super Boring, Super Bad, Super Mess
It was the Superman of my teenage days, but ...
Faster then a speeding locomotive?  Try slower than molasses.
Review: Superman Returns is a groan-inducing film. You'll want to boo at the screen as you're exiting the movie theater. The main problem is how it was edited. The final cut is two hours and fifty four minutes long and simply doesn't need to be. Just for example: There a far too many pregnant pauses between lines of dialog; There are ten second character reaction shots when a one second shot would have sufficed; Characters take thirty seconds to walk across a room and open a door when the action could be edited down to two seconds. It's a shame, really. Tighter editing might easily have trimmed 20 to 30 needless minutes, and faster pacing would have helped to camouflage the film's various other shortcomings. Chief among them: Kate Bosworth's terrible acting, clunky dialog, and an often murky plot.To be fair, Superman Returns does have a few things going for it. First off, Brandon Routh. In person, the actor seems to lack charisma or sex appeal. Even on screen, in his Clark Kent persona, he fails to make much of an impression. But about forty minutes into the movie, when he first dons those blue tights and red cape, you at last understand why Routh was cast. He actually looks like a superhero. What Routh has -- its not sex appeal exactly -- its a sort of idealized, masculine beauty. It's probably the most memorable thing about the film.The film also has at least one exciting, well-choreographed CGI action sequence involving a jumbo jet in a fiery tailspin. Brief, close-up jump cuts back and forth between Superman flying outside the plane and the passengers tumbling around inside the plane's cabin help to build suspense. No doubt this CGI sequence was storyboarded down to the last frame. Perhaps that limited the film editors' influence over this scene's pacing. Regardless, it was exciting and fast-paced-- standing out in an otherwise maddeningly slow film.The film also gets a boost from Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor. Compared to Gene Hackman's hammy take on the character in the original Superman movie, Spacey's performance here is understated, subtle, and downright sinister. You really believe this Luthor can and will kill Superman. Unfortunately, Spacey isn't given enough screen time. (He has only one scene with Superman and it is arguably the best scene in the movie.)

Review Title: If you like two hours of special effects....
Review: Although most of the reviews for Superman Returns have been good or even excellent, I must disagree. The storyline is - to be blunt - ridiculous, and, although Brandon Routh looks almost exactly like Christopher Reeve (Who played Clarke Kent in the original shows), this is the only similarity that the two shows share. I thought that both Kate Bosworth and Kevin Spacey did exceedingly well, considering the material they had to work with. What amazes me is that when there are no constraints for the storyline (Superman can do anything) Michael Dougherty & Dan Harris (Screenplay) still manage to complicate the plot in such a way that it is very confusing at some points during the film. Another major flaw in this film is that the hero does not have a fault. In Spiderman, Peter Parker is always trying to juggle his life as a superhero with his life as a normal human, and this usually leads to some problem that he needs to overcome. However, in Superman Returns, no one seems to bat an eyelid when Clarke Kent disappears at exactly the same time as Superman, and so it is easy for Kent to lead a normal social life. As for any suspense in the film, Superman can fly, take an unlimited number of bullets to the torso and not be remotely injured, and is able to extinguish fire with his eyes- so where is the challenge in that? In conclusion this film, massively over-budgeted was not exciting, the simple plot did not work and was at some points extremely confusing. On the plus side however, the special effects (70% of the film) were amazing... but after an hour or so they do get a little repetitive, or maybe thats just me.

Review Title: True to its roots, but modern to boot
Review: Superman Returns is an excellent film, not least because of director Bryn Singer's respect for the original four films (1978-1989) but because they are now wrapped so tightly in CGI and bullet-time as to be thoroughly modern. Sometimes the story is a little predictable, but even so it is done with such style as to be instantly forgiven. All the characters are strong, but there wasn't enough Clark Kent. I've always loved Kent for his stumbling, bumbling ways; the real antithesis of Superman. There are also a couple of nods to the film's DC Comics roots - referring to Gotham city in a news report for example - which adds interest for the knowledgeable viewer. I think this film will be a very personal thing for those who see it, either liking it, hating it, being ambivalent about it - so see it you should.

The are good and bad comic book movies. There are bad ones with some eye candy, and bad ones without any. This one is the former. Frankly I expected a lot more from this movie.The late 70s, early 80s Superman flicks with Reeve were something I enjoyed watching as a kid, but now as I look back at those I find them pretty cheesy. "Superman Returns" seems a continuation of the last 4 movies, only a bit less cheesy (just a little bit).There is nothing exciting about this movie, there are only a few nice CGI sequences and general acting is pretty much average at most.My final opinion:

Brian Singer is reported on this site as being unwilling to do this movie if he couldn't use John Williams' score. I think this is the key to understanding the tone and motivation of this 'sequel' to Superman 2. The leisurely way in which the characters are introduced, the scenes beautifully lit and detailed with references to the earlier Salkind productions reveal Singer's reverence and affection. If you went to see the first Superman movie at an impressionable age (as I did) it is difficult to be objective as you sit with a little reminiscent smile on your face. However, it is too long and the co-stars are not sufficiently exploited, leaving it a little short on humour. HOWEVER, Brandon Routh's performance lingered in the memory after I had left the cinema - not given much to say, he is a powerful and haunting presence, the sense of his loneliness and central goodness is persuasive and only surprising if you forget that he had clearly modelled his performance on the late Christopher Reeve. Once you recollect this blighted man's freshness and sincerity in the role do you forgive the missed opportunities of this feature and look forward to the sequel. Brian Singer has proved himself a safe pair of hands.

I do think I need to say too much about this film. I think a lot of people will see it for themselves, and if you're any kind or Superman/comic book hero/action/adventure fan go out tonight and enjoy. I cannot begin to imagine how hard it was for the writers/director/actors to make this. Unlike Batman Begins (also excellent), they didn't just have to deal with the legacy of the character, they had to deal with the loyal following and tragic demise of Christopher Reeve who owned Superman on film for so many. Simply put, they couldn't have done better. It's a credit to everyone, respectful to Reeve's legacy with a massive nod to his mannerisms for Kent, his look, everything. Routh is a joy to watch, his face is perfect, flawless as you imagine Superman's would, and the mixture of strength and vulnerability he brings is spot on. It's all about him and you could watch him as Superman or Kent for the full 2 hours alone! Spacey is a hoot as Lex, he always has this undercurrent of manic evil under the giddy gentleman exterior. I have no complaint with Bosworth either, having heard she was awful - she is fine. The effects are great, the music is fabulous, the plot line keeps things ticking along and I can't wait for more!

Review Title: i couldn't quite put my finger on it.....
Review: I am not sure what direction this movie was supposed to go, but for over 2 hours; I personally feel the film maker should have something to show, i.e. a story, in depth, perhaps with a few twists. This was pretty predictable, and I don't merely mean the story, even the comedic quips and one liners the characters used would be mouthed by young teenagers watching the film for the first time.The plot wasn't even two-dimensional; and the one dimension it possessed was time. I left the theatre thinking the most visually impressive item in the movie was the yacht (not when it split in 2 before that after all, anyone see Titanic?), even the crystal retreat lacked any kind of visual allure.Possibly more Underwhelming than Batman Forever. This is a shame, I liked Kevin Spacey as Lex, his rapport with Kitty was excellent. I wasn't even disappointed by Brandon Routh. The actors were great. Direction, Editing and distinct lack of special effects made this film less than mediocre. I felt dizzy every time Superman took off.To sum it up, if you do feel the need to watch this film, "Don't believe the hype" and you may feel whelmed.

But I digress. There are adequate villains to search from to make the story more interesting. Like Doomsday for instance who ended up killing Superman, not winning the fight but... To begin with a disclaimer : I don't usually like Superman. Yes, like most teens of my generation I fell for muscular Dean Cain and bubbly Teri Hatcher's cute antics in Lois & Clark, but the man in tights never truly blew my mind.this may have to do with 1) my love of geeks (I'd pick Clark anytime) 2) the fact that I'm not American , when, let's face it, you just can't get more American that Superman (sorry, there is a guy with a cape / no cape named Captain America somewhere ?)I also don't have a comics' education, my contact with superheroes is through films only and I just went to see that one because I was is a state of shock after United 93 and just couldn't stand on my feet anymore.All this being said : Superman returns is an amazing film! Not only is it a great superhero film but it is also a wonderful piece of popular entertainment, every bit as wonderful as X Men 2 (Singer's previous venture into the field).Superman returns is an action film because there are plenty of special effects, a bunch of heavy things that get lifted and thrown into space and some regular old style thrashing going on. But he who comes here looking for cheap thrills will go back frustrated because what SR is first and foremost is a very melancholy musing on love and loss, and alienation.This is a guy's film that I found fully and unabashedly directed towards women. It is extremely romantic in it's treatment of Lois and Kal El's relationship, but what makes it oh so precious is the poetry that pervades most of its shots and gives it its distinct tone.The film and Brandon Routh's excellent performance communicates a sense of sensual yearning, yet a composed, almost distant yearning, the one that Kal El feels for his planet but also the one he feels for Lois. All too human feelings felt by a "man" whose mission is so inhumanely to be a role model and show us the light like his father appointed him to.This crafty psychological construction of Superman made me find him the most fascinating character in the film and for the first time he took poor little Clark's place in my heart.For me to write this, there must really be some magic at work here and ... yes, ... Routh's to die for features are not totally foreign to that effect, but Singer's pure talent is to praise even for that !

Review Title: I'm a baby boomer who loved it!!
Review: Thank you for this film. I grew up with the television Superman and I loved him and it. Though I liked Christopher Reeve, I didn't care for the Superman movie. Superman Returns is more of what I was looking for. First of all, the actors could actually act. Kate Bosworth is the first Lois Lane I've liked since I was small. Margot Kidder's Lois Lane was written with very little charm. Mr. Routh was quite good. He seemed to have been born to play the role. Kevin Spacey was the Lex Luthor of my comic book years. I loved his cold-blooded portrayal. The dialog was something worth listening to and was delivered well. Not too much info . . . just enough. Some parts of the film, the more intimate ones, reminded me of theater. I'm glad they kept the theme music from the Reeve film. It sounded even better here. Though the running time was long, I didn't notice. If the viewer remembers to suspend disbelief, Superman Returns is a wonderful ride. Great story!

Review Title: Superman: Back In All His Glory
Review: It's been twenty years since Superman was last seen in the movies. Now, the Man of Steel is back in "Superman Returns," directed by Bryan Singer. In this story, Superman had gone off for five years in search of traces of Krypton, his home planet. In his absence, Lois Lane has become a mother, while archenemy Lex Luthor is planning his next criminal empire. The latest chapter in the Superman saga makes an impressive splash! Brandon Routh is well cast as Superman, proving himself a worthy successor to the late Christopher Reeve. Kevin Spacey makes a fine Lex Luthor as well. The filmmakers give us many facets of the Superman legacy, referencing the character's first appearance in the comics, and even reviving John William's memorable score from 1978's "Superman." All these factors have made the wait worth it for fans.

As an avid Superman fan of the first two films and expecting a great follow on from Superman 2, I came away from this film feeling unimpressed. It had a similar feel to it as the two X-Men films that Singer had done. The airplane part of the film was the best and as this was early on in the film, it went downhill after. There was no sense of excitement, the feeling that you were shouting for Superman and shouting against Lex Luthor like the original films. The fact that Brandon Routh more or less did an impersonation of Christopher Reeve didn't feel right. Too big on slow moments and not enough action. Superman shouldn't return if Singer is to fly the next installment into the cinemas.

Let me cast your mind back to a time where Superman was the top dog, he was the super hero of super heroes. From batman we had a poxy (yet somehow entertaining) series, from spider-man we had a cheap o' nasty series and some cartoons but from superman we had full-length feature films starring Christopher Reeve who for several generations will always be Superman. Now all was going well, Superman was a hit and so was Superman 2 but then by the 3rd film things started (as they usually do) to take a dive. Superman 3 was out of ideas, some pretty lame baddies and a bit more of a comedy than a proper Superman film, then Superman 4 : the quest for peace. Frankly the title says it all, Superman has to fight Nuclear man, a really poor enemy for the man of steel, it was a complete flop and Superman's 15 minutes of fame was over. So we enter the late 80's/early 90's Batman is the superhero to be but then he suffers the same fate after 2 good films comes a poor 3rd and an awful 4th, but as we get to the new millennium a new superhero emerges as the best. Spiderman comes out at the pictures and is amazing followed by an even better Spiderman 2, but Batman makes a come back with the best film of the lot, so with these to superhero heavyweights battling it out where is the daddy of superheroes?? Well he doesn't take it lying down and comes back with Superman returns, and return he does, after about 10 minutes of getting back to earth he's having a pint with Jimmy Olsen then he's saving a jumbo jet from crashing to earth, he puts on a show and a half not only does he have to stop a jumbo jet but after Lex Luthor (played to perfection by Kevin Spacey) hatches his latest evil plan he has to save the whole of Metropolis, now can Batman and Spiderman do that, I don't think so. Brandon Routh looking like the late great Christopher Reeve helps make this film seem like a sequel and with a performance like Spacey's it's got to be the best Superman yet. So I advise you to watch this film as you won't be disappointed, Superman has returned and he's here to stay.

Review Title: OK, here's what I think of Superman returns

Review: I particularly enjoyed all the homage lines of dialogue. Luthor - "Kitty, what did my father used to say to me?" Kitty - "You're losing your hair!" Luthor - "Before that!" Kitty - "Get out!" Luthor - "He said: You can print money, manufacture diamonds, [...] but they'll always need land!..."Brandon Routh slips into Christopher Reeve's shoes very well and brings a new touch of vulnerability to the character that suits me very well as a fan of both the early comics and the original movie.I was both very impatient and nervous to see what they would do with my favourite superhero. I am very happy overall with the result. It will be a great addition to my selective video collection. Hopefully, by then, the Hight Definition format for DVD's will have been agreed upon too.
