I just need to clarify after years of seeing superman reruns as a kid it dawned on me while watching superman returns that this is an allegory for Jesus Christ in many ways,is this right or am i hallucinating? and is there word on another film, and apparently Bryan singer described this as a chick flick, i see what he means. and Kevin spacey was excellent as lex Luther, i didn't like his girlfriend though, she didn't have as much sparkle or humor as his other girlfriends.

From Bryan Singer I expected a better movie. Even if you have seen the first two movies with Christopher Reeve this one doesn't make any sense. There is no real story. Only Lex Luthor causing trouble as always! I have to admit that when i heard the title Superman Returns i was anticipating and expecting one of the most daring plot twists in the superman comics. The storyline in which superman fights an almost indestructible super villain and dies defeating him and returning as a weaker superman (superman who cannot fly). But instead it is about a superman who went to see the remains of krypton and returns to earth (boring!!!!!!) I missed tension and action and humor. And normally I don't even pay attention to the length of movies in a negative sense(normally when a good movie is long it takes time to tell a story which can improve the movie), but in this case the movie is too long and boring. There were some action scenes I liked,but like I said earlier this movies lacks action! Which in a superhero movie must be the main attraction! I dare even to say that superman 3 and superman 4:the quest for peace are more enjoyable than this one. Ignore this movie and go watch the first three movies with Christopher Reeve because they are much better than this one!

Review Title: You will believe a man can fly... again !!
Review: I've already seen this movie twice and i can say it's getting better more you're watching it because you can see things you didn't noticed.First of all, Superman Returns is the more touching, poetic, and visually stunning film you have ever seen. The casting is Solid, Brandon Routh is SUPERMAN. Even if Christopher Reeve remains the best actor for the part, Brandon Routh was the good choice to play the role. The story romance works very well between Loïs and Clark/Superman, even better than between Peter Parker and Mary Jane in Spiderman. I mean it's more touching. The style of Bryan Singer deserves a magnificent realistic film, he succeeds to make us believe Superman exists for real during 2h35. The music is SUPERB !! And one of the best thing in Superman Returns is the fact that it doesn't look like any other Super hero movies. It is unique in his genre because Bryan Singer directed this movie with his heart and not with the box office in his mind, so there is no action scenes for no reasons, there is very interesting issues like solitude and devotion. The only thing a bit disappointing is the evil plan of Lex Luthor( very well performed by Kevin Spacey by the way( which is a bit hard to believe and too much similar to the first Superman. But this is only a little point compare to this Masterpeace which celebrate the Returns of the only Man of Steel.

Review Title: Do not use Singer for the Superman Return sequel
Review: There will definitely be a superman sequel. It is just a matter of time. However, although Bryan Singer is a good director and producer, he should not direct the sequel. The job he did on Superman return was horrible and unacceptable for a movie of a budget of $200 million and a man of his talent. The plot sounds good at first hearing but a further examination will reveal it is of poor quality. Good directors like Speiberg never do this, thats something amateur do instead. I question some actor-casting decisions like that of Lois Lane and some characters like Jason White. The end of the movies bordered on stupidity in my opinion. I felt I did not get my money's worth out of the movie. I do give Singer credit on the graphics used in the movie and some story lines were good-ideas. But overall, Singer should of had done better.

Review Title: Not worth the price of admission
Review: With the exception of Kevin Spacey's performance as Lex Luthor and some rather pretty visual effects, this movie was not worth the price of admission, much less the time it took to watch it. The plot during the first half of the movie is so drawn out and boring, I had trouble staying awake. The second half picked things up a bit, but bordered on the ridiculous as far as the story is concerned. Kevin Spacey did a wonderful job playing a neurotic, delusional, and genius Lex Luthor. Also, at times it seems that Christopher Reeves is on the screen, great job Brandon Routh. However, not the performances nor the special effects can save this movie, not even close.

Review Title: A Spectacular, Thrilling, Funny, and Emotional Popcorn Flick
Review: Bryan Singer has saved the day once again. This film under any other director, be it McG, Tim Burton, or Brett Ratner, would have flopped beyond belief. It took a long time to get a Superman sequel off the ground, but it was worth the wait. The casting, plot, and economical risks have all paid off. Superman Returns is up with Batman Begins and Spiderman 2 as one of the best superhero films ever.One of the things this film does best is use the classic '78 Superman and its sequel as a base for the film. The original John Williams music is still as triumphant and incredible as ever, and Marlon Brando's disembodied head and voice are used to great effect. But don't let that fool you: SR is anything but a remake. The creative minds behind the film did wonders in updating Metropolis as well as making the idea of why the world needs Superman relevant to today.Don't let his anonymity fool you: Brandon Routh was an absolutely perfect choice to play Superman. Not only does he have striking resemblance to the late great Christopher Reeve, but he does as good of a job owning the role that Reeve made. He's hilarious to watch as the awkward Clark Kent, and you can really see the pain and emotion that he carries with him as he returns from his home planet. His kind are all gone, Lois Lane has moved on, and he is once again given the burden to guide the people of earth. You couldn't have asked for a better choice Superman.The rest of the cast shines, too. Kate Bosworth (despite drawing the most criticism from everyone else) does great at being the fearless Lois Lane and shows amazing vulnerability when she realized that she may still love Superman. She lacks the big personality that Margot Kidder brought to the role, but that's a minor complaint. Kevin Spacey, Parker Posey, and the rest of the cast also play their parts to perfection and bring a lot of humor and heart to the film. Not to mention the little boy who played Jason, who I thought was a perfect choice.Despite Singer saying that SR was the closest thing to a chick flick he has ever done, don't let that fool you into thinking the film lacks the action. Seeing Superman rescue a plummeting airplane from the sky is classic, as is Superman deflecting a bullet off of his eyeball. You'll be pinned to your seat the whole time, you'll have no idea that the film is two and a half hours long. And the movie is a beauty to watch. The special effects are jaw-dropping throughout, and the atmosphere is done superbly. Watching Superman and Lois fly through the sky at night is hauntingly beautiful, as Superman tells her that everyday he hears people crying out for a savior.And that brings me to perhaps the most essential part of the movie: heart. Recent superhero outings like Fantastic 4 and X-Men: The "Last" Stand had none of it, playing out like Saturday morning specials with nothing but bombast and uninteresting characters. It's obvious that Bryan Singer but his heart and soul into this movie. The last half hour of SR is pure drama, and you feel the intensity for every second of it. Any other director would have ruined the movie by now, but Singer makes these characters living and breathing. It's near impossible not to get caught up in it.Though SR may not be the most successful movie of the summer, being out performed by mindless wastes of celluloid like "X3" and "The DaVinci Code", it stands out as one of the best. The film's scope, action, visuals, humor, and heart make it a must-see for any and all moviegoers. SR completely redeems the old Superman saga and hopefully promised a start for more Superman films to come.10/10

Review Title: No wonder this flew out of the theaters as fast as a speeding bullet.
Review: I'm going to rate this in comparison with the other 4 Superman films, though it only acknowledges the first two, and that's because it's less good than the first one, WAY less good than the second, and about on par with 3 and 4. I always liked 4 more than 3 because Chris Reeve wanted to make that one, and by gosh he deserved to. Anyway, it's a great beginning with the return of the wonderful Superman music (that is solidly based on the TV show music, if you couldn't tell) and the great titles, and a really well-done re-introduction to Superman and the rest of the characters. They're all performed in good style by the cast, sadly Lois is the weakest of the lot. Margot Kidder was the right blend of tough and feminine, and this new girl tries but is just short of that. Spacey makes me think that it's Hackman wearing a Spacey mask, he's that much on target. Routh is just a tad less of a Superman than Reeve was, but it's almost negligible. It's all very nicely done, and great action, but it's just TOO DARN LONG. The first half is fine, the second half drags it down. And I really think it would have been better to leave out the whole father is the son, etc, mumbo jumbo. It just seems silly. I also think it would have been better to let Lois be a single Mom, but then that would have given away the whole son of Superman thing right away. And it's NEVER going to be believable that nobody can see Clark Kent is Superman, but after all, it's comics and the movies, isn't it?

Wow! Superman can lift heavy objects, and then, ever so slowly, let them down! This might as well be a spoiler, because that's pretty much all the super one does in this badly conceived, over long entry into the comic book movie genre. The mighty son of Krypton doesn't throw a punch, he doesn't even really explain what happened on his sabbatical. Too bad, because photos from his trip would've been more exciting than this. I give it a couple stars because I thoroughly enjoyed the SpiderMan trailer that played before. Oh yeah, and there was some joker in the audience who had a flashlight that would shine the bat signal. That was pretty funny. Anyway...Congratulations, Singer! You just made Sam Raimi look like the biggest genius on the face of the planet.

I can't say the movie was disappointing, it was quite good for a Superman movie in 2006, but I felt something was lacking. Too much Superman and not enough Clark in my opinion. After all, Clark Kent is the real character, not Superman(just like Peter Parker/Spiderman). I thought Brandon Routh played an excellent Clark/Superman, best acting in the movie. Kate Bosworth wasn't that bad herself. She played Lois just like I imagined her to be. As for Spacey. For me he was disappointing. I think because he's to famous of an actor to play Lex Luthor. It was very hard for me to see Lex and not Kevin Spacey when I looked at him. Still, if I wouldn't have known him so well, I think I would have loved him.All in all, a good start for a new Superman series. I think there's definitely place for a sequel and I hope that future movies, if the case may be, will show more of Clarke and his relationship with everyone else, especially Lois, of course :)My rating: 8/10 (for it's potential)

Predicated on the ludicrous idea that Superman has finally deigned to return to the Earth he abandoned (in favor of a five year stint in space hoping to find some relics and survivors hurdling thru the void on the decades-old rubble of his home planet), Singer's Superman goes up, up and absolutely nowhere. No scratch that, it manages to go back in time to rehash the original Donner-helmed movies, which work as a fond fan-boy recollection, but not as the jumping off point of a modern or compelling story.In choosing to directly continue these events, Superman Returns negates much of its audience, those who are too young to recall them, and those who may not remember them with the studied reverence that Singer adopts in lieu of bringing anything new to the table. Returns rehashes the plots of these films to point of not bothering to develop the characters within the context of its own: how would a newcomer to the story know what motivates Lex Luthor beyond the fact that he is a criminal who Superman once apprehended? A disinteresting and needlessly convoluted love story is tacked on in the form of some banter back between Supes and the now single-but-betrothed-mother that is Lois Lane, all of which leads to a logical and obvious "revelation" about her child's paternity, that also doesn't read true to the Man of Steel.Singer has reinvisioned the Big Blue Boy Scout as an Emasculated Brain Dead Dolt, whose decisions, actions and powers are consistently deferred and undermined throughout the film. In what we can only assume was an attempt to make Superman more relevant to a modern audience by portraying him as more 'human', Singer's Superman spends so much of the film absent, restrained, infirmed or otherwise disabled, that one wonders what's so Super about him, and why we should even care anymore. Perhaps Lois Lane was right all along: the World doesn't need Superman.

Review Title: *WARNING: spoilers within* Too long, too inconsistent, too far-fetched.
Simply put, this is NOT Superman
Review: Golly. Let me just say that again: GOLLY. This was terrible. Not only did Brian Singer crap all over the X-Men franchise by skipping on the third installment, but he made this...I don't know, something. Personally, I detect the foul hand of producer John Peters in making this movie a total stinker. Both visually and thematically dark, and overhanging sense of depression pervades every cell of this film. Both derivative and slow, I really can't see anyone who is a fan of the first movies, Smallville, or even the comics enjoying this fracas. I mean, it seems like they decided to do Superman 1 with better effects. The best scene in the entire film--a hair-raising confrontation between Lois Lane her 6 yr. old son, and a child molester--Downs't even involve Superman. I still believe Singer is great director, but maybe he's done his thing with this genre and is ready to move on. I know I am.

Review Title: Boring, Bad, Terrible, American Cliché at its best. (contains very very slight spoilers)
This film is blasphemous and very very poor
Bryan Singer and his team are genius
Review: Sob Sob... It brings back so many darn memories. So Superman is here to stay and Brandon Routh's acting, mimicking so many of Christopher Reeves moves is genius. Bryan Singer could have easily made this film his own but instead showed a love for the older Superman movies except now he has digital effects which makes it really cool. I'm not sure how it would fare with comic fans. Superman appears constantly breaking up the drama with action. watching this film now will bring the older films into vogue for a while because there is so much of them in this film. Brandon reminded me so much of Reeves that I cried for the poor guy. I wish him well. Spaceys Lex Luther is darker more evil and the poorly dressed kitty is a good replacement for Miss Tessmocker. The music themes have been kept in tact from the original films as are credits and ending sequences. Daggy jokes and sequences have been replaced with a smooth story and a real tribute to Superman 2. There are some surprises and thrills. After seeing it I also can't wait to see what Brandon will do next. Can't wait for the next one.

I live in Madrid(Spain) and I'd like to say that in spite of I don't like so much the director Brian Singer I think that he had made THE BEST FILM OF ALL HIS FILMOGRAPHY. I enjoy so much seeing Superman Returns.The best of the film: --- Superman(Brandom Routh) A very good choice!!! --- The especial effects AMAZING!!! --- The storyline --- The "human side" of supermanI'm very exiting because of I wish to come Christmas for to buy the DVD of this film. Brian Singer Well Done!!! Congratulations!!! Best regards from Spain

Review Title: Boring to the point of tears

Review: Not a fan of the comics (though I read them, like everyone my age). Not a fan of the earlier movies with Christopher Reeve (though I watched them, like everyone back then).Bryan Singer manages to do something with this movie that the comics and earlier movies didn't - he made me sympathise with Superman. He showed me the loneliness, isolation and alienation that the last survivor of Krypton, living on Earth, must feel. A vulnerability that has nothing to do with kryptonite.Clark Kent's trademark clumsiness becomes a side effect of him trying to live in a more fragile human world, instead of a deliberate "disguise". Brandon Routh's Clark Kent is a much more sympathetic character than Reeve's.

Whilst its good to see Superman back, unfortunately this film doesn't do him justice. Its a plodding piece, concentrating more on the relationship between Kent/Superman and Louis - and this does not make for a good (or interesting film).You cant fault the SFX - they were very good. Shame the same couldn't be said about the story.Lex Luthor is good - having a darker side to the usual comical character, does add an extra edge to the film.The only other good thing left to say is the John William's theme tune is back.

For years there has been no Superman, then they bring him back.... In my opinion i found this movie to be quite boring. Yeah the plane scene is good and maybe the....... wait no i think thats it. So many continuity errors, was furious. I want to know how superman can pick up a Krytonite Island...How? HOw? HOW?!! The mere sight or unseen presence of the stone makes him weak at the bloody knees but he can lift the island...? I HATE LOIS LANE, her character is appalling. she has a kid and puts them both in danger. What got me was how unrealistic the plane scene was with her. I mean if i was to get thrown around a plane which was being pulled out to space and there was no seat belt holding me down. i am pretty sure you would either pass out with a concussion, has serious internal bleeding or at least a bruise...But no the not so pretty Lois lane comes away unharmed. yet when when she bangs her head on a kitchen item she is out for the count. Movie is OK... Its like the first Spiderman, Boring with a few nice action sequences. Its gonna take the second movie to make a real impact. 1st Movies are always about setting the scene, making sure everyone begins on the same page. Very disappointed with the ending though- I saw that 1 coming a mile off.

Review Title: Super Superman thanks to Singer and Routh
Review: Superman Returns is a fabulous telling of the essence of the Superman character as an alien god. Routh is superb both as an essentially lonely and sad Superman and as the (not so) bumbling Clark Kent. Give that man an Oscar right now. The action, set pieces, cinematography, and CGI are all breathtaking and seamlessly blended. Kudos to Singer. Marsden and Spacey are both excellent, but (in the film's only weakness) our new Lois Lane is just too self-absorbed to be entirely sympathetic as a character. Her vicious Pulitzer piece was unnecessary and spiteful, as if she "knew" that Superman's disappearance was all about her. Forget it lady. Men leave for lots of reasons, and you are not the center of the universe. Get over it. Apart from that, Singer's exploration of the lonely god amongst us is superb.

Review Title: Superman has definitely returned with this one.
Review: There's a lot that could have been done wrong with Superman Returns. Bryan Singer was walking a thin line when he took over this project after a whole number of directors failed to make a good story with a character as complex as Superman. Some of the suggestions that the other directors had - * Retell the origin story of Superman. * Give Superman a futuristic look by completely changing his costume to black latex. * Make it an all out action movie complete with alien invasions and Metallo. * Make it an all out children's movie. (Fantastic 4)It's not an easy task making a movie in today's day and age about an overgrown boy-scout like Superman, but Bryan took a great personal perspective to the character and told a story that perfectly gels with everything that Superman stands for.Bryan has rightly shown that even with all the power in the world, Kal-El, the last son of Krypton is still alone in the universe. He is a lone survivor of a planet that does not exist. When he hears that astronomers have discovered remains of his home world, he left immediately without saying his goodbyes in hope of finding another like him. The loneliness of the character is subtly evident throughout the movie. This is something that most 'movie critics' missed out. Brandon Routh has perfectly handled the legacy passed on to him. The more you watch the movie, the more convinced you are that he was the perfect choice for the man of steel. With that said, Routh still needs to work on his Clark Kent skills. Instead of playing the meek, bumbling reporter, he played 'Superman with glasses'.Kate Bosworth was a pretty bad choice as Lois Lane. She definitely doesn't look like a person who'd go to any lengths for a saucy story or even as someone capable of wooing Superman. Kevin Spacey, however, takes Lex Luthor to a whole new level of evil. The evil genius of the character is far more evident this time than in all prior attempts. Even the goons he hires this time are dependable tough guys instead of inept, fat comedians.The action sequences completely deliver, with Superman saving people of Metropolis (and the world) in ways that could have never been shown in a movie before this. The sequences between Superman and Lois Lane are very well handled without making things too mushy. The addition of Lois Lane's kid to the movie may seem blasphemous at first, but it fits well with the story eventually. John Ottman's latest additions to the movies soundtrack are good but don't hold as strong as compared to the original theme by John Williams. Luckily the movie's soundtrack is a mixed collaboration of both, which works out well. Bryan Singer did a great job by using the original two movies as source and continued telling the story from a point where it was still relevant. He redid a lot of things that Richard Donner had done in the original movies, and this time he did them right. He removed the "American Hero" angle or any patriotic elements that were pretty strong in the earlier films, and he gave the fans a magical Superman and Lois Lane flying sequence as a nod to the original.I suggest you keep an open mind, and watch this movie without the intention of comparing it to the original. The movie has a universal appeal and can be enjoyed just as much by people of all ages.

Review Title: Donner's film is superior but this still hits the spot!
Review: Bryan Singer moves from his Marvel franchise of the X-Men, to DC Comics very own Man of Steel. The fine work that Singer did with Wolverine and co, is clearly evident in this enjoyable summer blockbusters, although it never quite captures the heart and character shown in particular in X Men 2. Superman Returns still delivers what we'd expect from a Superman movie, and delivers it fully in the 21st century wizardry we all expect. When Superman fly's we believe he's flying.The film no doubt will be consistently compared to the original Superman movie, by Richard Donner, and while Singer has been keen to do his own vision of the man of steel, he has made sure to keep much of what made the original film so successful, in what is a kind of unofficial sequel, or perhaps a follow on. This film takes place sometime after Superman 2, and also quite rightly dismisses the disastrous third and the diabolical fourth. However while Singer has no doubt crafted a top draw summer film, this movie will not have the timeless appeal of Donner's 1978 original. In my mind and many others, the first Superman film is one of the most underrated films of all time. Simply dismissed as a good comic book family film. But Donner's film actually has more character than it's given credit for by some, and also is one of the most witty and funny films ever made. It's a film of comical genius that keeps the audience laughing, and it's and impressive feat for a film that is not actually classified as a comedy. It's just a very funny film with some of the most superbly timed gags in moviedom. Singer captures some moments of comedy, but not to the same degree. However it's an attempt to create a more dark Superman movie, which he does quite well, without ever quite doing what Chris Nolan did for Batman.Now the main comparison point will undoubtedly be Brandon Routh and Christopher Reeve's portrayals as Supes and of course his alter ego Clark Kent. Routh firstly is good. It's a debut that's impressive and he could have easily been out of his depth, or mismanaged as Hayden Christiansen was in Star Wars 2 and 3. Routh though captures both Supes and Kent very well, at times eerily reminiscent of Reeves. There's no doubt that Routh will be a big star now, probably in these kind of movies more than anything else, but while he's good, he is no Chris Reeve. Reeve delivered a fantastic performance that is one of the greatest ever in a "blockbuster" film. Sorely under appreciated for what it was, and that was performance of great charm, subtlety and depth, both in his emotive performance but also his physical performance. Reeve is and will probably always be the ultimate Superman, and would be even without his real life courage and heroism. This is in no way a disrespect to Routh, it's simply just how good Reeve was. Ditto to Kate Bosworth who is decent as Lois without ever capturing the verve and vivacity of Margot Kidder. Kevin Spacey was actually a bit of a disappointment in all truth. His Lex Luthor is more threatening than swaggering Gene Hackman (whose association with blithering imbeciles works in detriment to his criminal genius). Spacey has done far more chilling villainy in his career, while his Luthor is a little bit clichéd. Really the majority of the cast do well without capturing the magic that their 1978 counterparts did for Donner, but the exception here is Sam Huntington who creates the ultimate Jimmy yet.Technically the film is great in all respects. It looks great, sounds great and the action is superb. John Ottman edits and scores the film brilliantly, of course taking many of the cues from John Williams classic creation from 1978. The film is perhaps a little long for it's own good but never drags too much and while this won't be wearing out DVD players quite like the Donner film, this will certainly stand up to repeat viewings. It's well worth watching following a thus far disappointing summer of sequels. ****

Review Title: Superman Returns: But it was a bit of an anti-climax.
Review: When I first heard of Superman Returns I had mixed feelings of what I would think. On one hand, I love superhero movies, (Not all) but I do love them. Even if there crap, there's something great about them, but this, meh. It was average, for quite a few reasons.The plot was, to sum up in one word, poor. In my opinion, superhero movies should either have a basic storyline (eg. good guy fights bad guy, good guy wins, like Spiderman) or something deep and meaningful and full of metaphors (Such as Sin City) yet still retaining the comic book theme. I don't think this movie had a good plot, having all these really sub-standard side stories. Of course I expected going into the movie that there'd be the whole Lois Lane/Clark Kent sub-story line, but how it was done was pretty boring and frankly, unnecessary. *MAJOR SPOILER* I also found that the realization that Superman and Lois Lane have a son that turns out be some mini superman was laughable, and how it's BEGGING for some made-for-TV series on the many capers of his sons adventures. You know its going to happen, and it makes me shudder every time I think about it, and how it was done so many times before. And also, the boyfriend (Soon to be husband) of Lois Lane seems to be one of the more important figure to help Supermans troubles (Saves Loise lane and son from boat, flies helicopter to Supermans aid, drives Lois and son to Supermans Aid whilst in hospital) and yet his actions are dismissed and ignored, and Lois Lane almost cheats on him with Superman. That's not very moral is it?? *MAJOR SPOILER* Also, what the hell were they thinking putting Superman, (Yes SUPERMAN) into a Coma?? What the hell? He's Superman for Christs sake, yet he needs to be hooked up to a breathing machine?? That certainly wouldn't have happened in any of the other superman movies or comics, and trying to comprehend how someone thought of putting that in the movie is just comical. "Yes! let's put SuperMan into a coma! Great idea!" Superman didn't even really help the demise of Lex Luther that much, which prompts the question, "Who gives a s**t about Superman?".The acting was excellent in some aspects, not in other aspects. Kevin Spacey was the highlight of the movie I thought, his acting was just a joy to watch. The kid was a bit too "Hollywood" for my liking, although you can't really blame the kid, just the dialog. Superman himself wasn't actually too bad an actor, neither was Lois, just nothing special.The special effects were great, visually fantastic, and I do like my special effects in movies. I heard the budget wasn't massive, but I didn't really notice any lack of quality. Top notch, maybe some more action scenes would've been nice.So in a nutshell, I was disappointed, I expected more. It wasn't memorable, but it wasn't awful either. Maybe a new scriptwriter and a few experienced actors would've been nice.

saw "Superman Returns" last night in a plush Hollywood movie theater surrounded by devoted Superman fans. That in itself, I must admit, was part of the fun. Brandon Routh is breathtakingly, impossibly beautiful and you can trust that in a Bryan Singer movie stunning looking people will populate the screen. Here, the hero with the sensational eyelashes, works wonders in every single way. There is a hint of Superman as Jesus. Cucifixtion, resurrection, from Father to Son and I bought it wholeheartedly because it deserves to be bought. Kevin Spacey is a fun arch villain. There is nobody as convincingly evil as Kevin Spacey. It was strange, however, to see the lovely Kate Bosworth who played Sandra Dee to Spacey's Bobby Darin in "Beyond The Sea" to be so extremely at odds with each other but I bought Luthor and Lane much more than Darin and Dee. Ultimately Superman Returns is a classy, classic rendition of a perennial tale by one of the most successful aesthetes working on film today. Recommend it.

Review Title: Better than the original movies, but far from Lois&Clark
Review: Well. What can I say about this one? "Superman Returns" is a good deal better than the original movies.I feel the director took the old movies and incorporated some of the feel from "New Adventures of Lois&Clark". Thankfully Brendan portrayed a much more believable Superman than Christopher Reeves ever did. I breathed out in relief when the bumbling fool Clark Kent never showed up in this movie. Instead we got a somewhat darker, much more smooth and definitely brighter Clark Kent. Kate Bosworth also did a pretty good figure as Lois Lane. Not up to the standards of Terri Hatcher, but far better than Margot Kidder from the old movies. She just stood there like a fool, screaming for help all the time. While Terri actually managed to help herself, and Superman quite a few times. Kate compares much more to Terri, but still falls a bit short.Kevin spacey is pretty good as Lex Luthor. He is a lot better than Gene Hackman who just were Jarjar Binx annoying and stupid. Yes, Kevin comes dangerously close to being better than John Shea in the role as Lex, and would have been, if the script had been up to the standards of the TV-series. But all in all, Kevin did a good job. the only two characters i were disappointed with was Jake Olsen and Perry White. Jake could go, but Perry was so completely insignificant. He was like a blank canvas. There just wasn't anything at all, of the bubbling powerhouse of an editor Perry White is supposed to be. It has to be the lousiest choice of actor in quite a few years.The flying sequences followed tradition, yet were smoother and more stylish. And of cause the special effects were a whole lot better than the old movies, even the TV-series. Sound Track was as always very good. But I got a sneaking suspicion that the composer is the same Lucas used for the Starwars theme. I never noticed that when i saw the old movies. I am not sure whether i like or dislike that they dropped the glow of the Kryptonite, but it may be for the better of the movie. I haven't decided yet. Superman's sickness, helped the credibility of the movie, but should have been taken further. when he finally left the hospital, we should have seen some lingering weakness in him. The boy, were a nice, if hot exactly unexpected twist. But Clark should have told Lois about is double life. Especially now that they have a son. Guess who is going to go completely ballistics when she finds out. Kryptonite got nothing on a furious Lois Lane. Lois's fiancé made me grin a few times, I can't believe they used James Marsden. I just kept waiting for the first beam coming out of his eyes,he he. Well at least I had a few chuckles.All in all this movie is well worth watching, but as revitalizing of an old franchise goes, it doesn't come close to what they did in Batman Begins. Now that ladies and gents, is how you revitalize a dying movie series.Well that's all folks.

Review Title: Brandon Routh made a great Superman
Kal-El, Son of Krypton, is back!

Review: I remember that I had just settled into my seat when my friend and I agreed not to be too harsh. We had seen a great deal of movies and were, well in my opinion great judges when it comes to such superhero films. I had read few reviews that gave a real boost to this movie at all - there was even a magazine that was so highly against this movie that it kept bragging about the worst qualities Superman owned. In the end I settled that well if it sucked it sucked.I was surprised when it didn't - Bryan Singer (X-MEN 1 & 2) did exactly what I expected him to do. He's always been the sort of type who loves to build everything up, and that's just what he does. He makes a movie that could have had a great deal of simplicity to it - greater and bigger. The thing that impressed me was the humor and the actors. Lex Luthor was perfect - he was a genius who knew how to ruin the world yet he kept a billiard table in a boat. Superman was just plain super - Lois Lane was not bad either, but I feel we'll get more out of her in the next one - if there is one, and I hope it really is.To be entirely honest - we always need a Superman out there. And as the other supers are fading off, well - what better than the man himself?

Seeing a summer blockbuster movie on the big screen is great fun. Seeing it on an IMAX screen with some scenes in 3D is awesome. But that was my experience with "Superman Returns". I'm a real fan of superhero films, so I loved "Superman" and "Superman II" and tolerated "Superman III" and "Superman IV". After an interval of 19 years, it's good to have him back. After all, he is the coolest of the superheroes because he can fly and, post 9/11, we need someone heroic to help us out.This is a somewhat sombre story, set five years after "Superman II" as even Lois Lois has decided that the world does not need Superman. When our hero returns, however, he is subject to almost Christ-like images: 'nailed' with kyptonite shards, 'crucified' with arms outstretched, and above all 'dying' only to rise from the dead.Newcomer Brandon Routh is virtually the same age as Christopher Reeve when he first donned the blue cape and the similarities in looks and voice are remarkable. Kate Bosworth is winsome enough as Lois Lane who now has a five year old son. But it's Kevin Spacey as the maniacal Lex Luthor who offers the best performance of the piece.Director Bryan Singer - who gave us the first two "X-Men" movies - and scriptwriters Michael Dougherty & Dan Harris have ensured that there are countless visual and verbal allusions to the original "Superman" in 1978, but the special effects have come a long way since the start of the franchise. Metropolis looks like an amalgam of 1930s architecture and present-day technology and there are some splendid sets and scenes, including a new version of the shuttle and the creation of a new continent, with a personal favourite being a huge train set.Two things spoil the show. First, as so often with blockbusters, the whole thing is too long (154 minutes). Second, a stronger narrative with more tension is needed to lift this above the pedestrian and make it really fly. But the man of steel is definitely back, the franchise is successfully revived, and I'll be in the stalls next time round too.

The early vibes coming out about this film were that it was very good. I was therefore disappointed when I saw the film. Even though it's quite a few years since the last Superman movie, there really didn't seem anything new in the movie.Brandon Routh fills the Superman boots as would be expected. He's equally as wooden as the sadly departed Christopher Reeves when it comes to acting. Bosworth is a bit of an improvement in the playing of Lane though, and the film is at it's best when she's around. Spacey goes through the motions as Luther and the plot is pretty similar to the previous Superman movies. Undoubtedly there will be further Superman movies in the pipeline and we'll have to hope they up the ante!

Yes, Yes, Yes...He is back, the man of steel, the man from Krypton. He is back and Lois Lane got a surprise for him. I just saw it. Loved it, but I missed some humor. I wish Lex Luthor would have been more like when Gene Hackman played him. Because now he was ultra bad, and had no humor. When Gene Hackman played him it was great, because Lex Luthor was a genius, but realized sometimes if he had done something really wrong, but then he found a new way to exploit what happened. But now in this movie he was only ultra bad. But Kevin Spacey was great, except for the lack of humor.So I missed the humor.But Superman played by Brandon Routh was great. He is very similar to Christopher Reeves, but also himself. He was true to the films. I hope they never make things like in the serial Smallville and Lois & Clark. They must stay true to the films, not the serial. The serial are great, but Superman movies are Superman movies.See it. It's great!

Review Title: Just another dull, generic, CGI laden Hollywood action film! (I'd rather watch Superman IV: The quest for peace!)
Review: I cannot believe this film currently has an equal 'star' rating to the original superman movie and scores higher than Superman II and III.The original superman films were so full of character, excitement and sass. When watching this film I found it difficult to stay awake. Superman films are always going to be predictable in the sense that Superman will always 'win' against 'evil' and his extreme powers give writers free reign to get him to do anything without raising objections of absurdity from audiences, but this film doe nothing interesting or original, there are no interesting plot twists or story lines. The only story line 'suprise' is that Lois Lane has had a child and she has transformed into a characterless pretty Hollywood face! Kate Bosworth brings nothing interesting to the role of Lois Lane, she's just so wet and dull. Margaret Kidder gave the part of Lois Lane so much more 'balls', the attempt at showing Lois' edginess in this film is portrayed by Kater Bosworth getting a cigarette out of a packet and then deciding against if and slipping it back in the the packet (how edgy! yawn!)It amazes me that Hollywood continue to overuse CGI 3D graphics, if used sparingly and at appropriate times (inconjunction with blue screen, model-work and other tried and tested staples of special effects) it could be great, but in many new action films, including this one, they just swamp films in CGI, but it seem to me that it leaves the film looking unbelievable. The effects and camera angles become too overblown and all subtlety is thrown out of the window. In the final scene of this film, superman soars off into space and around the world looking triumphant (echoing the final scenes of previous all superman films) but it is so CGI enhanced that it looks like a cartoon, even superman himself has been modelled in CGI, and it's looks so obvious, it just doesn't look real, such a weak finale. I know that it must save Hollywood a fortune programming in CGI as opposed to making things by hand but it makes no sense to me that 30years on from the original Superman film the final scene can actually look worse.This film has nothing of any substance to offer, it's not exciting, it's not interesting or funny/quirky. I hoped that the inclusion of Kevin Spacey would give the film weight and although he plays the part well, it doesn't really do anything to lift the film. In fact all the main actors are good and reasonably well cast (with the exception of Bosworth) and act well enough but the film isn't very well written and it just feels like a money making sequel and doesn't have any of the Hollywood magic the original films possessed.Surprisingly disappointing.

'Superman Returns' is an average tale of the superhero coming to terms with his relationship with Lois Lane and protecting the world from evil Lex Luther. The film has its moments, and the computer animation and graphics are impressive. While the film does have its moments of action, I felt that some of the story did drag on. There were a lot of areas where the impressive graphics seemed to be displayed that seemed to last longer than they probably should have. I felt the storyline was also slow and weak in that it tended to follow Superman and his relationship with Lois. I actually felt bored waiting for the next events to happen. Better pacing would have made a better film, and some of the scenes could have been edited, but I cannot fault the animation.

I never really liked Superman because it was like he was invincible. But for some reason, I wanted to see this. I thought this movie was good. I have more respect for Superman now, than I ever have.I think that Jason White kind of got annoying, BUT I'm waiting to see in the Superman Returns sequel if he has a part of not. The one part where they used the word "sex" over and over, I thought that was unneeded. Superman was done well, Lois Lane was done well, and Lex Luther was very...evil. Overall I enjoyed this movie. This movie was good. There isn't to much swearing, not horrifying scenes, thus it is good for your whole family :)

I'm always been a fan of Superman movies (both in the big screen and the small screen)....and this new Superman movie just blew me away....Bryan Singer, you've done it again!!The acting is superb and the new Superman Brandon Routh is absolutely born to fit the man in tights. I really enjoy this film. Although, the movie is not "perfect" like what the rest of the critics world is expecting,it started rightfully where the Superman 2 ended. There are dislikes of why Routh, Bosworth, etc.. looks so young...but fans around the world you must remember that this is a movie franchise. The producers need actors who can grow with their roles. Because if they're going to hire someone in their late 30s, Superman will definitely look so old and tired by time they finish the rest of the sequels.....OK???

Review Title: ... so loved the world he gave his only begotten son ...
Review: The whole Superman franchise has always fascinated me. I had what one might call an epiphany one day when reading a Superman comic when I was about 8 or 9 years old. It was an especially juicy revelation being coupled as it was with the consumption of the forbidden evil comic book secreted from a distracted cousin. More on that later. That was in the "Golden Age" of Superman; when George Reeves was the capped crusader and the heroics where more realistic.Given this long history of exposure, including the last round of movies by the dear departed Christopher Reeve, I had more than a few expectations before seeing this. Actually, the scenario was that there was nothing else on at the local tiny theater I hadn't already seen so this was the night's selection by default of elimination.What we find is the strangely plastic/perfect looking personage of Superman played by an unknown Brandon Routh. His portrayal was no better or no worse that many others who have donned the cape; which, in this particular instance, was an odd color of off-maroon rather than the traditional patriotic RED dictated by the character's long-standing persona of standing for "... truth, justice, and the American way...". Come to think of it, the whole costume was a bit surreal compared to tradition. Some things just shouldn't be messed with. Perhaps they feared no mere pretty boy could ever hope to equal the jaw-dropping image of Terry Hatcher wrapped in the red version... we may never know.Other than missing what should have been a slam-dunk for the costume department, they went on to miss taking advantage of one of the most visually stunning things in movies today... namely Kate Bosworth's eyes. Who could not be captivated by them? Still, they all but completely missed playing to that visual delight. Even without that, Ms. Bosworth made a better than average Lois Lane. That was a relief at least.Others in the film were the great Frank Langella as Perry White and Kevin Spacey wasting his considerable talent while doing a better than great rendition of a bad guy. Why do I think he was wasted? Because almost anyone can play bad. Everyone knows what bad is and it's the evil that stars, not the actor. Still, he is almost worth the price of admission just to see his version of it. Parker Posey played his obligatory sex-kitten to a tee. She is equally good in a completely unsympathetic role.The special effects were, well, modern special effects. Nothing surprising but extremely overdone to the point of being ridiculous. The rest, sets, costumes, art direction, cinematography, etc, were all first rate but lost in the details of the overblown effects.What else is there? Well back to my little discovery, circa 1958... it is my assertion - or observation if you will, that the Superman character is the comic representation of Jesus Christ. This movie just underscored that impression even more so with it's heightened use of effects. He is shown as the savior of mankind, all knowing, all seeing, all hearing... swathed in flowing robes, unrealistically good-looking and adored by one and all - except for the emissaries of Satin, of course. His portrayal as a god-like being has never been more pronounced as it is in this film.

Review Title: Why is people so mean with this great movie?
Review: I just read lot of comments telling how crap this movie is and I gotta jump and defend it cuz people can just bring into disrepute a movie that has such great special effects, great cast, great performances, good story. For me it's quite amazing to see Superman back on screens. I also liked the story; how he took off for a while and see Lois' disappointment and how she moved on with her life though she still felt love for S. And what about S' son? OK the story could have ended better and still have more action. But I think we all shall be able to see all they skipped this time in the sequel in 2009. I just ask everyone to enjoy the story how it was cuz sure it wasn't "crap". It has lot of good things to talk about and sure millions of fans loved it.

Review Title: not good, not good at all
You mean, he returned for this movie???
A Fresh Franchise in the making...Superman Returns!

Review: Super schmaltzy Hallmark/Family Circle overall feeling throughout, with way too many hokey family hug scenes with the blah, blank-eyed, and nearly mute little son thrown in for the "Awwwwwww" effect, ruined this mediocre at best movie for me. "OK, time for another family hug scene!" Super Ugggg. Also, Superman was so bland and totally lacking in male, no, human, charisma as to not even appear to be the main character in the film. That belonged to Kevin Spacey as Lex Luther, and even he wasn't nearly as good as Gene Hackman was in the other Supe flicks. Even the scenes where The Supe saved something or somebody were flat and lifeless and mostly not exiting. This was really a poor sequel except for the special effects in the kryptonite land mass scenes, and that wasn't enough to save it for me. This movie brand should now be killed off for good as it's getting worse with each sequel. What more can they ruin by making another one? Kate Bosworth was a cutie as Lois Lane but is either a real bad actress or was badly mis-directed as she seemed like she was reading her lines directly off of cue cards, with little shown facial or word emotion along with unrealistically quick responses, kind of like she didn't have to think of her answers and just read them off cue cards.....Oh, right, that's just what she was doing! Really lame and amateurish.Frank Langella, as the Daily Planet Editor, was the bright spot in a small and thankless role, just as he was as the TV CEO in Good Night And Good Luck. He deserves a lot bigger part in films.Lois' new super-caring husband-instead-of-Superman was also in the film way too much. Isn't Superman supposed to be a love story between The Supe and Lois? Why did the filmmakers throw a way-too-concerned-about-precious-Lois-and-kid husband that was way too much in touch with his feminine side, and their dopey kid into the mix? Crummy idea throughout, and it ruined the story as the filmmaker really pushed the family schmaltz angle that was common in 1940's films and is badly outdated now(except for the Disney junk).See Supe 1 and 2 over and over, and forget this crummy flop. It's a waste of money, and also what's worse, over 2 hours of your life!

Review Title: Excellent movie, so long as you leave the microscope at home

Review: I wasn't expecting to like this film nearly as much as I did. I only went because my brother convinced me and offered to pay for my ticket, boy am I glad I did! It was great. It was exciting, but not pure action, it had a lot of feeling to it. It also had a whole lot of humour, there were some great lines in there which had the whole cinema laughing hard. If you like a film with action and heart then this film's for you.Brandon Routh was a great Superman in my opinion, and Kevin Spacey as Lex Luther was just fantastic.Go watch the film, sit back and enjoy the ride!

A very good film. Fantastic believable effects.Strong emotional storyline. Slows the film up at times, but relevant and deals with Superman's absence.I had totally forgotten the music to Superman... gave me goosebumps on a number of occasions as things hotted up. Even stayed behind to watch the credits (as I like to anyway) so that I could get it again.Clear subtext and imagery concerning the soteriology of superman.Kevin Spacey superb as the villain; struck me as a role very much cut out for Patrick Stewart even down to the bald head, and reduced American accent.Lois Lane - gorgeous, especially that evening dress in last 1/3 of film.Very touching to see a dedication to Christopher & Dana Reeve in the credits too. He was Superman to me when I was a kid; rest in peace.Yes, I would recommend it. 9/10 I reckon.

I just saw Superman Returns and The movie was OK but not what I expected(a lot of action). So if you like, drama, romance etc, you should definitely go and see Superman Returns. I ain't saying that the movie totally sucked but it was not just that good.I still like the old Superman movies a lot better and I don't think that you even can compare this movie to the old ones. However...The actors did a great performance and the special effects were amazing but still TO MUCH ROMANCE!!!!! I usually like movies with drama but Superman Returns had too much of it. Like someone else already said: Using the original music was one of the smartest things they could have done, it's far too iconic to have a Superman movie without it.

After a long journey Superman returned to metropolis but with immorality. He uses his power's to voyeur people, to listen them without their awareness, to show off. It seems that he lost his special features. These habits could not be suit with Christopher Reeves. The new Superman likes to take pride in himself more than to stop crimes. When he stops the bullets from the machine gun with his chest and with his eye, we understood that his ego went up to the sky. In spite of improvement in techniques, in this series we could not see variety actions in scenes. Actions scenes are not sufficient and most of parts are a little bit boring. I had been checking my watch again and again toward the end and I got sleepy. Lex Luthor were not skillful in this series. He did bad things but with his luck not with his talent. If you did not watch the Superman up to now, please do not get trouble, it is not the end of universe.

To be honest, I was almost determined not to like it. I'd come to regard Reeve as iconic. Replacing him was verging on bad taste. It took a while to warm to Reeve anyway. He was a little on the "small" side compared with the comic-book imagery I'd been brought up with. To keep the Action Comics feel would have required a bodybuilder at least the size of Arnold at his most bulked up, and that would be barely making the grade. However, Reeve's presence generally made up for his chest size and he was so charismatic that... he WAS Superman. Add the real life tragedy and the thought of following with a new actor was almost blasphemously daring.This movie had better work or it would fail horribly.From seeing film posters, Routh was frankly too underdeveloped physically, a trend since that TV series with Terri Hatcher opposite the dwarf. I had the distinct impression that the casting brief was to find someone to play Christopher Reeve rather than act the part of Superman.Once past the spine-tingling homage credits, I was sucked in/blown away by an astonishing film. The legacy problem was handled sensitively (dedicated to... ) which was a huge relief. Routh's performance was a revelation. His resemblance to Reeve in certain shots - and in certain mannerisms - was unsettling, yet he managed to capitalise on these assets without overplaying his hand. Overall, I could forgive his "too slight" physique for the sake of the acting. I don't think we've seen his last, and even if he's a one trick pony - which I seriously doubt - he's still got a long way to go in this franchise. Yeah, I'd like to see him 50lb heavier, but that's a huge lifestyle (and pharmaceutical) commitment, and maybe not for him.Kevin Spacey stole the show. I always rated Hackman, but thought his Luthor interpretation just a touch too camp; the teeniest touch, not a shaven-headed Kenneth Wiliiams. Spacey was every bit as insane yet managed to be more believably menacing. I'd bung him the statuette for this one, I think.The ladies, in comparison, didn't quite cut it. "Lois" felt right - a beautifully played part - but the wrong look. Sorry. Looked very tasty walking out of shot and crawling on her hands and knees though I don't think these were designed to be memorable moments. Likewise "Kitty" the obligatory moll. What went wrong here? I suppose "doesn't work" for me just means the character isn't appealing. The character was too neutral and uninvolving without the bimbo appeal of a Jessica Rabbit or the verse of a Bonnie Parker. I see the logic in the screenplay, but it still doesn't feel right. She shouldn't present as disposable even if Luthor sees all women that way. It's HIS personal aberration which we don't need to share to appreciate - indeed, our revulsion to Luthor is lessened because of it, and that makes a poor decision in direction.James Marsden - Richard - and Eva Marie Saint as Martha Kent. Perfect. Nothing more to say, really, but Richard was successfully appealing and worked on all the right levels. Not too cardboardy (that would have been SO easy) and not too mawkishly handled either. Finely played and well written. Martha was gorgeous. Age aside, the best-looking woman in the film. All the other support characters were well cast and well played. Even the kid (we all want to hate kids in films like this) was attractive, charming and.. just right. Tristan Leabu in 20 yrs time? Could be #1 box office.Downsides. I'll happily suspending disbelief and knowledge of physics for most of this stuff - e.g. there's no leverage consideration when flying and dealing with Large Objects. Superman usually behaves like an object of infinite mass, sometimes with zero inertia and sometimes with infinite inertia depending on the writer's scene requirement.Nevetheless, there are things that irk me. Compared with the weirdness above, this may seem illogical, but I can accept the behaviour of an utterly alien thing/being thrust into our physical continuum, and this is best if there is no great attempt to explain it in other than phenomenological ways - "Superman came from a HUGE planet so has a denser, impenetrable structure. Our yellow sun gives him super vision, hearing and.. stuff." Bunkum, but good enough for the job. Far better than the pseudo-science of TNG Star Trek's " By re-routing the nerdular matrix through the outfeed oscillators I can re-bias the resonant positronic mass to give a precisely 0.326 seconds window to fire a photon torpedo, velocity-matched to the yaw angle pulsator. The transparaluminary widget will activate again if the matter-anti-matter bypass-integrator circuit doesn't burn out." THAT kind of thing offends me far more than being told that Superman is "Super' because he's not hampered by a big planet's gravity and a red sun.Where it goes wrong for me is laws of physics changing inexplicably for otherwise familiar situations. I can accept Superman walking into a hail of midi-gun bullets which bounce of him without the impact knocking him backwards even though this is utterly inconceivable in any universe but a magical or SFX one. I can't accept things which aren't "super" behaving oddly. Seeing someone carried through the air, sightseeing - and their eyes not streaming and stinging from everything being blasted into them. As anyone who skydives or rides motorcycles will know, she gotta wear shades - or stick a cape over the head. Nowhere in the listed superpowers is "invisible force field." Superman descends ex-celestia, upright. His cape hangs DOWN. How? Fishing weights sewn into the hem? Minor niggles, I know, but I'm sure many will understand the logic to my objection.Such aside, I THOROUGHLY enjoyed the film which finished with a "proper" ending not leaving us hanging, baffled.I wanted more.Recommended.

First of all, I am a die-hard Superman fan, so it kinda feels weird that I did not give it a perfect 10.....to be honest, I shouldn't have given it a 9. This movie was beautifully done and realized by Bryan Singer. I am sure it will make more money than it did to create it. But I felt that there were times that the movie tried too hard to be the Reeve era movies we remembered and loved. I think the director should have made it more fresh, but I love the fact her respected the past material. Brandon Routh was completely flawless as Superman/Clark Kent, constantly fooling us into believing that it was Reeve up on the screen....but that,too, is a set-back. I love Routh's acting, but I would love to see his superman, not him acting out the old. Kevin Spacey OWNS the Lex Luthor character. The right amount of darkness and humor to make Luthor seem more memorable than Hackmans. I think the plot twists thrown in kept the franchise fresh, and allows for something more to be built upon in this story. Kate Bosworth's Lois Lane certainly gives us hope for some interesting stories in the future between her and Superman. I encourage everyone to see the movie about the character that started it ALL! I have seen it 4 times and will watch it again as soon as I can.

I can hear the film snobs now - "just what we need, another bombastic action flick loaded with CGI and cliché in place of a 'SERIOUS' human story." Yup, it's a bombastic action flick. Yes, it is crammed with special effects. And yes, if you consider simple and largely unexamined human emotions to be cliché, then Superman Returns is loaded with clichés. My advice to the film snobs is - don't review films you are predisposed to dislike. If you do not have a standard from which you are able to measure the worth of a certain genre, then you have no business reviewing in that genre.Let's examine this rationally. The whole point of the character of Superman is to provide a fantastic superhuman persona who is so alien and so vastly superior in terms of physical being, knowledge, and morality, that he becomes a mirror through which we are forced to critically examine our own social, political, emotional, and health problems. What kinds of problems would such a vastly superior being trouble himself with? Well, guess what, he might not have time for the day to day subtleties of social and sexual intrigues and ambiguities, the role of the media in political rhetoric or other "SERIOUS" concerns plaguing the modern intellectual elite. Superman is concerned with more fundamental issues such as whether half the world's population is going to live out the day. Yet he still manages to find time to rekindle a dysfunctional relationship with love interest Lois Lane, and to be inspired to prove himself with a flourish of light-speed heroic antics to regain his esteem among a people whose cynicism and self-contempt have apparently gotten the better of them (film snobs all?).Kal-El returns to earth just in time to confront his old arch-nemesis Lex Luther's plot to rebuild a chunk of Krypton off the coast of New Jersey as his own continent. He must also unexpectedly confront his own feelings for the people of earth and, in particular, for Lois Lane, now an unmarried mother with an asthmatic kid and a smoking habit. Lois is also engaged to a good guy, very competently acted by James Marsden, but the paternity of her son is suspect. Considering the fact that this is a "bombastic action film" a remarkable amount of time is taken up with developing the relationships between these characters and exploring their effects on one another. And at times, you even get the feeling that at least some of Superman's heroism is inspired by his feelings for Lois.The bigger problem is that Luther has Kryptonite, and plenty of it, and so, Superman is mortally vulnerable and must fight for his own life as well as those of his adoptive species.Ignore the geological inaccuracies (which are plenty), forget about the occasional continuity problems, and let yourself get sucked up into this very fine and well crafted example of the superhero action genre. If you're a hardened film snob, it's worth the effort of wriggling out of your fossilized suit of cynical armor just long enough to see what the value of a film with a positive, simple, message might be.evren buyruk

Review Title: Did he return just for this???
Review: **watch for spoilers**I was disappointed. The story was lame, the dialogs were plain simple, bad acting, like Lois Lane for example (who told her new boyfriend that her son was his knowing he wasn't, very classy) You never connect with her, she expresses no emotions whatsoever. Brandon was OK, but the problem is Reeves was toooo handsome, and had REAL blue eyes, (Brandon's blue contacts were too obvious, they needed better job there) it is not easy to fill in those boots.
