The movie tasted a little to the old ones, but not as good, they worked great for the 70's but hellooo were are in 2006! we need something fresh, modern and creative. I mean did Superman return just for this? if they were going to do something new, please be a little more imaginative. 70% of the movie was CG or maybe more, that's why the film makers think they don't need a story, nowadays, because they have the visual effects to fill 70 to 80% of the movie. some of the scenes with visual effects were good, tho. And what is this constant comparison of Superman with Jesus???? Even the scene when superman is beaten up by Lex and his guys reminded me of "the passion of Christ", that was a little too much violent. Remember this movie is more for kids because with a plot so simple and predictable, it can only be meant for kids. Why did they make this movie when they had nothing new to offer???

Don't listen to the detractors: Superman Returns is a great film, and arguably Bryan Singer's best since The Usual Suspects. It does to the last son of Krypton what Christopher Nolan did to Batman, only less dark.In order to successfully bring the Man of Steel back to cinemas, Singer chooses to ignore the existence of Superman III and IV (and so does a very satisfied audience), as his movie takes place after the first two S-flicks. And his love for those two movies is evident from the very beginning: after the Warner Bros. and DC Comics logos, we hear a monologue spoken by the late Jor-El (Marlon Brando, digitally resurrected), followed by the opening credits. Yes, it's basically the same credits used in 1978, with a few adjustments. And yes, it's John Williams'unforgotten Superman theme we hear in that sequence. All that can mean only one thing: this will be a memorable return. And indeed it is.The first glimpse of our hero looks like it was made to grab the interest of people who have come to know the character through his most recent TV incarnation, Smallville: Clark Kent (Brandon Routh) lands in the middle of the family farm's corn field after being gone for five years (a similar thing happened in the popular show's Season 4 premiere). We're also offered a beautiful flashback showing how he discovered he could fly (note to Alfred Gough and Miles Millar: the super-speed looks a lot better here than in the TV reboot), before Clark decides to return to Metropolis and try to get his job back. He succeeds, only to learn from old friend Jimmy Olsen (Sam Huntington, a comic tour de force) that things have changed dramatically in five years: Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth), who Clark/Superman still loves, has a son, Jason (coincidentally, the boy is five years old...) and is engaged to her boss's (Frank Langella) nephew, Richard White (James Marsden). On top of that, she's about to win the Pulitzer prize for the article "Why the world doesn't need Superman". While there isn't much he can do on the sentimental front (Richard is, after all, a nice guy), Supes can still prove the world needs him. And boy, does it need him: evil deeds are in the air, and the recently out-of-jail Lex Luthor (Kevin Spacey) has something to do with it. Once again, he has a plan. Once again, he won't let anyone stop him. And once again, a certain superhero will be in the way...The reason Superman Returns works is Singer has understood the movie can't just rely on visual effects and action scenes. Like in the franchise's first two installments, there has to be something else: a believable, "human" protagonist. Superman is unique because he's an outsider, a character who will never fully consider himself one of us ("Even though you've been raised as a human you're not one of them" he's repeatedly reminded by Jor-El). Nonetheless, he cares for mankind, and fights every day to protect our planet. That's why everybody loves him. That's why, in spite of Lois' article, the world needs him more than any other hero.Of course, the movie would fall apart if the lead actor didn't pull off the job convincingly. Luckily, there's no need to worry: Brandon Routh impresses both as the clumsy, mumbling Clark and the invincible Superman. He can behave like a nerd at the Daily Planet and then prevent an airplane from crashing with the same ease. And, most importantly, he has a touching resemblance to the great Christopher Reeve, to whom the movie is dedicated (it's damn near impossible to read that caption and leave the theater unaffected). Bosworth does a good job too, giving her character, and the movie, the appropriate emotion (she's so good she made me forget she's a bit, eh, too young for the part).As for Spacey, well... He makes Gene Hackman's Luthor look like a nice guy. Working with Singer for the second time (after his Oscar-winning performance in The Usual Suspects), the American Beauty star ditches his predecessor's wig (minus a brief in-joke at the beginning of the film) and funny mannerisms, giving us a portrayal much closer to what younger fans are seeing on Smallville, with just a touch of extra madness (when Lois tells him he'll kill millions of people, he corrects her: "Billions! Once again the press underestimates me."). Having not played a villain in some time, Spacey has a terrific time returning to what he does best, and the audience has a great deal of fun watching him.Thanks to its inspired director, smart script and brilliant cast, Superman Returns does exactly the same thing Batman Begins did last summer: it gloriously revives the franchise. A sequel has already been announced, and considering Bryan Singer's X2 was ten times better than the first X-Men film, the next Superman movie will undoubtedly confirm, once again, that not only is he the first superhero, he's also the best.

I was intrigued by this film. I love Bryan Singers X Mens and right from the start this film caught me. I'm not a fan of superman at-all, i think he is too indestructible and unbelievable. But this film made me love him.I didn't know what it was, definitely not the plot, definitely not the NOT AS GOOD AS GENE HACKMAN KEVIN SPACEY LEX LUTHOR. Not the over done romance. I think it was genuinely because it was a new superman, a softer one. I cant explain it, but all i have to say for this is well done Bryan you have done superman fans proud. This is a good film. I loved it.

Review Title: What you need for the first in hopefully a number of Superman films.

Review: After the astonishing X-Men franchise, I had high hopes for this movie. But, Singer managed to only disappoint me. His first mistake was instead of making this movie able to stand on its own, he focused too much on making it an homage to Richard Donner. It felt too much like a rehash of the first movie just with updated special effects. Seriously, go through both scene by scene; so many parallels it's not funny. The problem with this approach gives us a way too powerful Superman and elements that are completely outdated by now, eg a campy Lex Luthor. There was also a bit of miscasting with Bosworth and the main character himself had very little lines throughout the whole movie.The plot was severely lacking. Luthor's scheme made no sense and was just very poorly executed. The ending defied all logic and pre-established canon...especially within the universe Singer was emulating. On top of that, the movie was extremely dull. There were only inconsequential action scenes to show off the new and improved special effects and otherwise no real challenge for Superman.Yes, the first two movies were hardly perfect, but given the time they were made they are quite enjoyable. Supes Returns, however, is not. It's just an empty shell of what could and SHOULD have been in an era where comic movies are dominating. Superman is called an epic character, it's time for them to give him an epic challenge and no more of these stalemate battles with Lex Luthor.

Rating: 12A Main Cast: Brandon Routh, Kate Bosworth, Kevin Spacey, James Marsden Director: Bryan SingerThe good: Brandon Routh was a brilliant find, Kevin Spacey, some great comedy moments, great effects!The bad: brings up sad memories about Christopher Reeve and his wife , film moved a bit slow in places, Lois Lane not how she should be.Quick Summary: First of all Id like to say that I thought that this would be awful when I walked into the screening. Bow was I wrong, this film was great! And the thing that I was surprised about the most was how dark the villains were, but also how it could be light hearted with some great comedy. Brandon Routh was very good in his first major role and Kevein Spacey was great as always. However Lois Lane was a bit of a let down. But who cares when the effects are so great! Lois was OK, just not how she was in the old films and comics. Anyway, this is definitely the best film I've seen this summer and I cant wait for a sequel!

Without a doubt this is the best comic book movie I have seen since Nolan's Batman Begins. I was surprised with Brandon Routh's outstanding performance. Singer took a big risk when introducing an unexperienced actor in a high budget film. Spacy takes a major role in the movie, Lex Luthor, showing the viewers the new face of Gene Hackman's original villain in Superman I.Though the movie lacks on action sequences, the plane seen is the most amazing action sequence with the use of visual effects to date in film history. Singer is without a doubt one of the most outstanding modern directors to date. The soundtrack is a mixture of original scores from past superman movies, but with a modern age, perfect for the movie.The only big flaw of this film, is Kate Bowthsworth. She does deliver a strong performance in the movie, but her casting as Louis Lane is weak. Excluding this problem, you should all go see these movie.

Review Title: Routh is Superman. Film is very disjointed and disappointing.

Review: Terrible 3 hour love story, like watching the best action movie you have ever seen stripped of all the best bits and replaced with scenes from the English patient. i loved superman as a kid, comics and films equally, and i feel let down by this bore-fest of a movie and let down by the thousands that voted it highly JUST because its superman. i even admit when the music started and the guy took to the sky it brought back great memories but then the movie just spiralled into drabness beyond belief. go and watch this movie expecting a deeper more boring superman with an overly witty and unmenacing lex. kevin spaceys worst performance and Superman's worst outing. bring on the sequel lol.

As a die-hard Superman fan I wanted to love this movie. I grew up with the 50s TV show, saw the wonderful Christopher Reeve and I even watched Lois & Clark back in the 90s-- unfortunately, any of those renditions of the Superman story are better than this movie. There was not a single moment of fun and it completely lacked charm. If you are a Superman fan, do me a favor: go see this film and then immediately rent the 1st and 2nd Superman movies with Christopher Reeve. It will show you just how great the late Mr. Reeves was, and why Brian Singer's vision of this character is the wrong one.Aside from the lack of fun, the story is mediocre. My God, why must they always use the first draft in every bad blockbuster??? I won't rip Brandon Routh--he did OK and had a tough act to follow--but Kevin Spacey is not in the same league as Gene Hackman. And in my opinion, if they used archival footage of Marlon Brando in the film, they certainly could have brought back Hackman--he might have saved the movie. The rest of the characters...well...they just didn't do anything. They slept-walked through the movie.The special effects were decent, especially the flying sequences, but again, go watch what they did in 1980 with Superman II without CGIs. Remember how they destroyed Metropolis? The only reason I gave this a 4 is for Kate Bosworth, who is scorching hot to look at.

I've always loved superman, wanted to be him, to fly, to have super strength etc,. But for some reason I wasn't really looking forward to seeing this movie, i dunno why, OK maybe it was the previews, they weren't that spectacular to me. But i felt it was my duty to honor the latest installment since I was such a huge fan. To make a long story short Brian Singer has once again reduced super heroes to total wimps. Just plain wimpy. Just like he did to the first 2 Xmen movies, there were all pussies except for magneto. storm was a wimp she barely did anything, rogue, cyclops, the professor, shooot all the Xmen were pathetic when it came to using their powers. X3 may have been terrible but at least my muties were powerful and I have to say Brett has balls . Back to Superman Returns, Really awful move, way to long, I kept looking at my watch. Way too much drama with bits of action in between. there's cool action sequences here and their but it was pretty much boring and I wouldn't recommend it to my worst enemy.

Review Title: No more than an average film
Review: Special effects are nothing special, In fact some are increasable cheesy. Acting is well average at best (I am being kind). Kevin Spacey is the best thing in the movie, he makes an excellent Lex, shame the rest of the cast let him down. True the likeness to Christopher Reeve is there but that is no basis to allow a wooden actor get the job. Should have went straight to DVD. Save your money, eventually it will be on Sky. The film has a highly predictable plot line. At no point is there a surprise or twist you wouldn't have seen. Very Disappointed, if you have seen the trailer you have seen the film. I was hoping I could have said some good things and was looking forward to seeing it however this is not the case.

Review Title: Wow, I thought I was watching a comic book hero actually come to life
Review: I liked the original Superman films and I thought that no one could replace Christopher Reeves (although to be honest, I didn't think he truly portrayed the Superman of the comic books).And having seen many previous comic book heroes butchered on screen, Daredevil, Catwoman etc, I thought that this film would continue the trend of destroying yet another comic book hero during the transition to film.Well here is a film which captures the dignity which I thought a Superman would have.Brandon Routh is one of the most convincing comic heroes to date and he portrayed Superman as both super and as a man.Kevin spacey was almost convincing as Lex Luthor but I would have liked his character to have been a bit more serious and less comic, but he was sufficiently evil to be an almost worthy adversary for Superman.My only criticism is that the story line was a little underdeveloped and should have contained a lot more action.Whilst the comic book always gave us the idea that Superman and Lois Lane were almost meant to be, I think most of the film (as have it's predecessors) dwells too much on the love interest and not enough on Superman as an action hero.I for one would like to see more of Brandon Routh in action as Superman and I would like to see him battle some truly evil characters in future, because that's what Superman did for most of the comic book stories (he fought baddies).I hope the next Superman film starring Brandon Routh shows us the true Superman because I think Brandon has come the closest to becoming the Superman of the comic books.Definitely worth a watch in my view and I hope it's a promise of better things to come.

Review Title: An unimaginative , unoriginal, and joyless remake of a superior film
Review: I will keep my review short and simple. Superman Returns is by far the biggest disappointment of the year. After a self imposed five year exile to search for remnants of his home world, Superman returns to Earth only to find out that Lois Lane has moved on with her life. Lex Luther is released from prison and conjures up a scheme to destroy Superman once and for all. Sounds like the premise for a good film right? Wrong!!!!!!! This film plays out like a two and a half hour horrible soap opera. The plot all too often makes no sense. To simply put it, the entire film is nothing but a rehash of the 1978 film but without the charm. Superman arrives on Earth, check. Superman saves Lois Lane from certain doom on an aircraft, check. Lex Luther is the main villain, check. There is absolutely no chemistry between the two leads, Brandon Routh and Kate Bosworth. There's enough continuity problems and plot holes to fly a jetliner through them. The special effects are unimpressive, I've seen much better films with smaller budgets that have better effects than this train wreck. Excluding an impressive scene at the beginning of the film, *SPOILER* that has Superman rescuing an airplane as it plunges out of control towards Earth, this film has no action. Bryan Singer, the director of this film has publicly admitted saying that this is his "first chick flick". If you are looking for a fun, exciting, and thrilling film, this is definitely not the film you want to watch. Overall, this is a pretentious, dull, boring, unimaginative, unoriginal , and soulless film that should have never been released in the first place. Don't listen to the critics and their biased reviews, take it from me. This film is a massive disappointment, this is why it's struggling to make a profit at the Box Office.

I have no idea why people have dissed this movie so much. i guess people are just getting tired of remakes. Honestly i was too until i saw this movie. Almost everybody i knew told me not to see this movie you will be disappointed if you do. Well that just made me want to see it all the more and i did and i thought it was a wonderful movie. Of course i had my doubts i thought it was just a pretty boy running around in tights but as i saw more of the movie i began to think that Brandon Routh was more than a pretty boy. The graphics in this movie are amazing. Throughout the whole movie i was blown away by the drama, action, graphics and the acting as well. Don't let the critics stop you from seeing this movie because it really is a wonderful film.

"Superman Returns", why? After seeing this I wish he hadn't. And what an overblown lackluster return. I'll bet Marlon Brando is really happy he's dead, 'cuz if he wasn't, this would have probably killed him. If you saw the trailer with the Super Man trying to save the jet airliner in distress, then you've seen the most exciting part. I watched it thinking that after seeing the trailer, this must be packed with really amazing action sequences. As I watched further I surmised that Superman having returned, must still be suffering from jet-lag. The guy acts like a wimp rather than a amped up hero. I longed for the early Flescher cartoons or the 1950's George Reeves TV show and the way he did things there. In this film he acts like he's returned from finishing school, and any emergency is dealt with with just enough energy to get the job done. He's not Superman, he's Just Enough Man. If one expects him to act more powerful than a speeding locomotive, forget it. He's more like Herbie the Volkswagon with sensitivity. And because he's modeled after a comic book (yeah, yeah, I know it's a sequel), many think the relationships and character development must be superficial. But the creators of this limp biscuit should study Spiderman 1 and 2. It had excellent character development amid a lot of heart, yet I still felt like I was watching a comic book! Superman on the other comes up empty. I hope he leaves again, and soon, only to return when he's got the right stuff.

Superman is indeed back, and the delight Bryan Singer obviously felt in being responsible for his return is communicated through a film that is as rich and subtle as it is visually exciting. This is action movie-making with both a heart and a brain: plus around $200m to play with.Part of the delight is that Singer deploys his train set in many ways which fans would do themselves, many of whom have nostalgic childhood memories of being taken to Richard Donner's 1978 original version. From the blood-quickening homage to its comet-like opening credits roll, to the posthumous reprisal of Brando as Jor-el it's an affectionate and deferential reworking of Donner's original gilded with spectacular and extend cgi sequences which envision those superhuman qualities in a way wires and blue-screen filming never could.There is some long-delayed directorial truth and justice in this, as Donner was unfairly sacked from the helm of Superman II because the producing Salkinds wished to take the franchise down a 'campier'; route that led to the critical and financial debacle of Superman III and the absolute farce that was Superman IV, which was the artistic equivalent of kryptonite to the franchise in Hollywood.But Warners and Singer combined realise just what a fantastic creative source the Superman myth is, and all that it needs is lots of money and healthy dose of respect, Warners supplied around $200m of the former and Singer does the latter by not attempting to undermine or update the character's core values.Apart from the much discussed religious allegory/symbolism, there are other interesting themes. Singer takes delight in representing applied physics, which is at the heart of how the superhuman fantasy first engages the young: As they become fully aware of their own human limitations of strength, speed and agility, imagining what it would be like to be completely unrestricted by those laws and expanding on that, what that would make them in a society of normal men. The sense of space, time mass, velocity and vibration is conducted brilliantly throughout the film, not just via special effects but also by the imagination of screenplay and cinematography.Brandon Routh matches the youthful Christopher Reeve curl for curl, but it is Kevin Spacey who offers a truly great performance as Lex Luthor. The buffoon crook portrayed by Gene Hackman, entertaining for all that, is replaced by a complex, psychopathic personality, given the space to expand on his own delusional self-vision as a modern day Prometheus 'bringing fire to the people'.Superman and Luthor represent the spectrum of alienation from humanity; one distanced by all aspects of his identity and physiology, the other by his complete absence of empathy. Spacey plays it straight throughout and succeeds in recreating Luthor with a new sense of menace, even as he reprises the same basic plot ideal of the original movie.A huge amount of thought has gone into the art direction and dialogue which are peppered with references to Superman plots and images harking back to the earliest comic book days. The movie is also more beautiful than a superhero action flick desires to be, as beautifully composed as it is dynamically stirring.The overall length, periods of character exposition and old-fashioned feel (Space Shuttles in peril?) may have contributed to Superman Returns under-performing, just a little, its backers expectations. The sequel hangs in the balance by just a few million box office, but it is likely to be green-lighted given Singer's obvious enthusiasm (he promises a sequel as spectacular as Star Trek II was to the original movie) and the fact its mediocre performance was due to unhappy release timing in competition with the Pirates of the Caribbean juggernaut and Pixar's Cars.If that prediction is borne out, good news, as Superman very much deserves to return again.

Review Title: Superman a cross between Appollo and JC
Review: When I was a teenager I discovered Superman with Christopher Reeve; I found it extremely entertaining and fun but the characters had no psychological depth and that was OK ; Today (no longer a teenager- the mother of 2) I enjoy watching Smallville . Before Superman Returns was released I read nothing on the subject and didn't expect anything , I was just curious and open-minded ; when I first went to see it with my children the theater was to my surprise only half full and at the end I felt just very slightly disappointed - I thought there was a lack of humor and not enough of Clark Kent but I didn't think I'd seen many other films of such visual beauty - so I went once again - and again , and the pleasure grew with each viewing; of course there are some inconsistencies (the effects of the Kriptonite!)and probably some weaknesses in the scenario , but the direction was perfect, Brandon Routh is a wonder both as Superman and as Clark Kent - by the way I found it easier than with C.Reeve to accept that Lois or other people didn't recognize him . The flights are powerful,majestic and yet graceful ; the Christian connotations were OK for me but I understand that some people were annoyed by them. This Superman is incredibly human ;witout being in the least neurotic, he's sensitive, lonely, vulnerable ; this, combined with his (inner and physical) strength and love for humanity makes him a more attractive and likable character than the Superman portrayed by CR. Singer ( maybe he didn't invent this but I don't know the comics - they are not available in France) has not only made him become more human than any Superman before him; he has also made him a god - an improbable cross between Apollo ( the Greek god of beauty and light) and Jesus. I know this movie hasn't (yet) been as successful as expected and I don't understand it; It made me pass through a lot of various emotions and at the end there is peace and joy and enthusiasm !

There are going to be people who dislike the approach Singer has taken with this continuation of the Superman story. I for one am certainly not one of them. Skimming over everything, Spacey is excellent as Luthor, combining elements (mainly visual) of Gene Hackman and a touch of Michael Rosenbaums'(Smallville) take on Lex, but also a touch of his own creepy evil streak. Brandon Routh is excellent as Clark/Superman. Very good as both Clark and Superman. And very much like Christopher Reeve's Superman which I think may have been a controversial decision, but it has been pulled off very well. Credit to Routh.Kate Bosworth is good as Lois, but really lacks the true spunky side of Margot Kidder as she never seems to kick up enough of a fuss and comes across as much moany as she is persistent. Some may disagree, but hey this is my comment :D Action scenes are truly top notch and better almost anything else I've seen for sheer impact. My hair was standing on end and my heart racing in a couple of scenes (something that never really happens to me) Music is especially good in places thanks to Ottman's wonderful composition and orchestration of themes while weaving them with new, more introspective material. The story isn't amazing, but the storyTELLING is again awesome. Singer allows the film to lean back when it needs to in a similar way that HULK does, allowing the viewer to immerse in the characters and develop the personal conflicts. There is little in the way of conflict between Superman and Clark.In fact, there is not much Clark Kent time in the film - it's more about Superman, and his struggle to find his place back in a world where so much he held close has changed... for the worse. Singer really shows us his alienation from humans and really makes you root for him on so many levels as he fights and defends people who he is not one of, but so desperately wants to be, mainly driven by his love of Lois. Not having someone you want because you're from a different world is probably something that resonates with a lot of people from different backgrounds and certainly did with me. It's more a love story at heart, but disguises it well until you think back on it and it becomes more apparent.A few nice twists make you think of where the Singer may take this. Of course you'll have to see for yourself :D All in all, the best film I've seen since Batman Begins. Has grown on me a lot.

On the whole this is a nice film with an outstanding opening credit sequence. I hope that isn't damning it with faint praise. Brandon Routh was extremely good however particularly in the scenes where it was necessary for him to demonstrate his vulnerability. Unfortunately the story is the same old Superman stuff and the characterisation of Lex Luther was paper thin and unconvincing (I think this had something to do with a bad case of miscasting). By far the best Luther around is to be found in the television series "Smallville". My main grouse with the movie was the overt references to Superman's similarity to (or perhaps he is supposed to be) Christ. In the floating down to earth section apart from being stretched out on his back in a crucifix configuration he then turned over on to his stomach and began to take on Dali's "Christ of St John of the Cross" before, thank heaven, the director must have decided he was over doing the allusions. As to be expected the special effects are excellent and, Kevn Spacey to one side, the acting was convincing throughout.

Superman Returns is Bryan Singer's first truly remarkable action film. This picture is all the more enjoyable if you remember the original Superman with Christopher Reeve. This new, altered version contains many references, story plots, characters and even dialogue as the original - but not in a cheap way for quick effect or easy laughs. Bryan Singer has managed to infuse this film with dignified 'homages' to the original which work superbly.As you would expect, there are a few astounding set, action pieces but the strength of the film definitely lies in Brandon Routh. Any film fan would be a little apprehensive going into this film hoping the unknown and untried lead actor wouldn't embarrass himself a-la Hayden Christensen but this guy really pulls it off! He doesn't play Clark Kent quite as nerdy as Reeve but he equals him as a believable, dignified, worldly savior. He magnificently pulls off that neat trick where you deftly play a subtle vocal change for each character.The only disappointing point would be the film's anti-climax of a conclusion but I suppose Singer was compelled by the studio to quietly sew the seeds for the inevitable sequel.Not as good as the original Spiderman but this gives it a damn good run for it's money!

I went to see this movie in a digital Dolby theater the day it opened (in Iceland) and the opening credits nearly brought tears to my eyes. When I was a kid I truly believed Superman was invincible, the man of steel. Seeing the opening credits and hearing the opening theme brought back all the fond memories of the man we all know to be super.I loved the movie, plain and simple. Most of my friends didn't have the patience to sit through this seemingly long movie. But me, growing up alongside Superman, thought the movie was too short. The first real action scene is one of the most amazing feats of cinema I've ever witnessed. I was so awestruck at the pure action and CGI that I started to sweat uncontrollably, I got tense, wound my toes and clung on to my seat. The sound, the action, the amazing visuals, the acting and the good old Superman style all generated an awesome movie.Brandon Routh was great at adapting Christopher Reeves' style and the hair made me laugh out loud. The change from Clark Kent to Superman was good and he looked quite like a younger Christopher in a way. Kevin Spacey made an excellent performance as Lex and really seemed like an arrogant powerhungry villain. Those two stood out the most.Even though the movie was a bit on the long side (for most not-brainwashed-superman-fans) it is a great movie none the less. Bryan Singer shows his true talent in taking a comic book and making a great movie.I will truly be looking up into the sky for the next Superman movie.9 / 10

Review Title: Why the world doesn't need Superman?
Review: I was waiting for this movie for a long time. The last Superman movie 'The Quest for Peace' had been filmed before I was born. When I first heard that a new movie was being done, I tried to guess how was it going to be. Of course, the villain was going to be Lex Luthor, the girl Lois Lane. But there was one thing that made me think: Was the new movie going to be a sequel of Smallville? I thought it would be wonderful, Tom Welling as a Superman. I learned that it was a free movie, free from Smallville, free from the first four movies. And I wondered about this movie.Many people thought that it will be a full-action-movie. Superman will use his muscles and save the world. We can say as a common viewer that that's true, but on the other hand, if we look beyond the usual movie structure, we can recognize what makes a superhero movie good: the emotions.Love, fear, respect, hope. These feelings look like what every superhero movie has, but they aren't.Lois Lane is still in love with the man you know, her son's father, but she is married with Richard White and although Superman returns, she didn't return to him. Director and one of the writers Bryan Singer didn't let that has a cliché screenplay. Lois didn't return to Superman, Superman didn't turn to life when she kissed him in the hospital, or Lois' cigarette lighter didn't deflate at the end. In addition, I feel the great directing of Bryan Singer at every moment of the movie.He showed us his whole abilities, and made a great flying man's film. There is another thing in the screenplay I like very much. Superman was closer the death than all other superheroes were, although he is the one who is furthest from the death. He threw the earth peace to the space and fell to the ground. He was about to die, thousands of people were in the hospital praying for Superman.Now Superman has a child. It means, in the future there will be more saviors of the world, and maybe a new mixed race. That was a new and mighty move for the Superman mythology. We'll see what will happen.Brandon Routh is a good Superman,and he looks like his predecessor, Christopher Reeve. Kevin Spacey fits the role of Lex Luthor, but I think there can be better Lois Lane, and that was good to see Marlon Brando again, but the star of this picture is Bryan Singer. I am waiting for a sequel from him, and the others.We have learned Superman's purpose of coming to the earth from Jor-el, but I wish we learn from Lois Lane why the world doesn't need Superman?

Review Title: A Welcome Return from the man of steel - we have missed you
Review: I think there were always going to be reservations about this film. In the wake of the death of the wonderful Christopher Reeve, the thought of there being a superman that wasn't played by him was a little unbearable. My congratulations go to both Bryan Singer and his wonderful cast and crew for making Superman Returns a faithful but modern version of the the man in blue tights. This film is fantastic. The plot, effects, acting, direction. My biggest surprise was reserved for the considerable skills of Brandon Routh and Kate Bosworth. Brandon had the bumbling adorable Clarke Kent down to a tee and the strong confident but vulnerable superman was played beautifully by him. Bosworth was even more surprising. I typically underate her as an actress and yet she pulled off Lois Lane brilliantly. She was every bit as annoying, inquisitive, rude, endearing and feisty as the Lois that Margot Kidder played her in the original films. She even went as far as to make the role her own. I wont give one thing away. I made sure I knew nothing about the film before I went and enjoyed it even more as a result of that. If you are looking for the WOW factor go.

I was skeptical at best to go and see this movie and I am delighted to say I was surprised about the great plot, the fantastic acting and the wonderful effects. This movie had everything riding against it; telling a story that was fresh and different from all of the others, bringing out aspects of the characters that were new and interesting enough to make the film feel like the actors weren't just "filling the shoes of their predecessors" and in that sense it was a huge risk to make this film knowing that the generation that grew up with and ironically buried 'Superman'Christopher Reeves feel a sense of betrayal in accepting a new guy on the big screen. Each of the actors made the characters their own setting it apart from all of the other portrayals of Superman in TV and Movies. The movie never lagged or felt long. It was very well done and brought out a new aspect to all of the characters and I'm going to see it again in the theaters!

Review Title: Look, up in the sky: it's a burden, it's a pain, it's Bryan Singer's Superdepression!
Review: This movies has a serious amount of problems and one of it is the script. It's lacks excitement and has many links to Donner's superman II which makes it difficult for the younger audience (who didn't see Donners version) to understand. The plot is terrible lame, director Singer uses the real estate thing Luthor already pulled in Donner's Supes only this time they make it all too serious. Like anyone would be able en would like to live on a dead green rock. I mean common! This idea is also dragged out during the entire movie but never becomes exciting.The beginning and the end of the movie are the worst. The film starts with Superman turning up after 5 years of absence after which he picks up his depressing role as superman which seems to be a burden to him. The ending of the film is SO disappointing I can't even begin to describe it. Yuck! There are some scenes in the film which are pretty good except for the flying which i'll refer to later.Problem 2 is the casting. Routh isn't a bad superman, but he portrays Superman very dull and without any emotion and he fails as Clark Kent. Christopher Reeve had the ability to portray Superman and Clark Kent as two totally different persons which made it believable and he also took the roles not to serious. Routh isn't able to do that by far and lacks charisma. Kate Bosworth is another problem. She looks like a 19 year old teenager and can't carry the role of late in her twenty's Lois Lane with a child. It all just isn't believable. There's is also no chemistry whatsoever between the two actors. Kevin Spacey is the only one who performs good but his character is turned into the totally crap lowlife most sadistic version of Lex Luthor we've ever seen in the Superman Universe.With that said I come to the worst problem of all: the way Singer portrayed the superman universe. He literally ruined it. Het uses so many bad idea's that it's painfully to watch this movie. At some point it made me even sick to the stomach and very uncomfortable. Superman flies in a awful cartoon like way and the CGI looks so fake at some times it's even worse than the blue screen flying in Richard Lesters old versions. Superman takes off vertically in a straight line every time, not like the ballet kind of take off we would expect like in the old superman movies. Also we don't see a transformation from Clark to his alter ego. And what's with the dark atmosphere? Metropolis looks like Gotham city, Superman is portrayed as a weak depressed teenager who doesn't laugh, sores, en doesn't seem to take any pleasure in what he does. Superman also doesn't get many lines in this movie and what he does say makes him seem depressed en burdened. Lois Lane is angry the whole time but doesn't convince a bit while Luthor is to evil and serious but never interesting although at one point in the film it made me want to turn off the movie because of the sarcastic Luthor. Luthor fails to kill off superman in the movie but Singer finishes the job for him introducing Lois Lanes Child, the dark metropolis, a depressed superman with too dark an outfit, a terrible plot, a scene between Supeman en Luthor and his thugs that makes you sick and finally the most disappointing ending of a superman movie i've ever seen. While you are expecting a grand finale you'll be confronted with the biggest anti-climax since Paris Hilton put her own made home video on the internet.There's not one moment in the movie where I felt the magic, awe and sparks I felt with Donner's version. But hey there's hope for all the fans out there! Donners version of Superman II is coming out in November. Now thats the Superman we've all been waiting for for 28 years or so, not this piece of crap Singer delivered us.

I'll confess that I was never a really big Superman fan, but since seeing this my 13 year old has suddenly discovered comics, and we've seen Spiderman, the Hulk, Batman (old and new) and the X-Men movies previous to this. None of them caused the same reaction, which should say something about this movie, or perhaps just Superman as a character.Routh looked so much like the late Christopher Reeve that it was poignant; at one point I had to gasp at the likeness. And I liked that they dedicated the movie to Chris and his late wife, Dana. That showed class, something lacking these days in movies. It's how fast and how loud the next movie can be, period.As you can tell, I'm not big on action movies, for the above reason. FX are the main thing (look at all the special features - all they do is tell you how a stunt is set up!), not plot. But comic book movies have more plot than they can do with, usually. I guess that is why I like them. Fans know the story well enough to tell you if you've done it wrong! I'm sorry this did not do as well in the theaters as they wanted. Unfortunately, it is all about money, and now a second movie with these actors is in danger. That's a real shame.I have only one complaint, and it is about the *age* of the actors. I know only 18-35 year olds count these days, but after a lay-over of 5 years, these people look 10 years younger! Umn, that's a problem, if you ask me.Otherwise, if you don't mind your Clark Kents literally right off the farm, the movie was fantastic, and I'd tell everyone to see it, if they haven't already done so! Maybe then we'll get another.

Review Title: Choses to be sentimental instead of entertaining.
Review: OK Superman is back (and I'm glad he is)! But not with a blast.It's a recent trend in superhero movies to give the story and its character a deeper meaning and more realistic emotions. Most recent example of this is of course "Batman Begins" and other examples are "Spider-Man" and "Hulk". "Superman Returns" also tries to put this in the movie. It however does not suit the main character and is not true to the spirit and atmosphere of the other original previous Superman movies. The movie takes itself far too serious with as a result that it isn't always a fun or entertaining one to watch. It tries to be more than just another superhero movie but it never knows to fully convince.The movie in the beginning takes it time to explain the story for the viewers who haven't seen the '78 original and its sequel, on which this movie is a direct sequel again. I can't say that I think this was the right choice. The movie would had been better of if the action, so to speak, started off immediately and didn't wasted any time on re-introducing all of the characters. The movie does however still show lots of respect to the original, mainly with its use of music. The opening credits are done in the exact same style as the original and they also didn't changed a not with its music, which really was the right thing to do. Let's be honest, the opening credits of the original '78 "Superman" movie are perhaps the most spectacular and most awesome opening credits of all time, which is mainly thanks to the John Williams music. Director Bryan Singer and John Ottman also seemed to realize and understand this and they use the John Williams at the exact right moments in the movie. John Ottman, on his turn, also composed a wonderful and suiting musical score on his own, complete with a wonderful new Superman theme.The movie feels like two separate stories. One story concentrates on Superman/Clark Kent and the other on his eternal villain Lex Luthor, who is out of prison again, due to the absence of Superman during his court hearing. The movie doesn't feel as a complete whole and it is not until when the two stories mix that the movie starts to take pace and become truly interesting to watch. This however happens too late into the movie to completely save it.The story itself is also very simple, a bit too simple for my taste. It also lacks some of the fundamental things a Superman movie needs. Superman movie needs to be fun, colorful and perhaps even a bit campy. Bryan Singer's Superman world is mostly dark. Also the humor is wrong. The movie does have humor in it but not the right kind. Superman movies needs slapstick, over-the-top sort of humor. The humor and atmosphere in this movie really doesn't suit the Superman character. It makes you wonder; Perhaps isn't the Superman character a bit too old fashioned for the 21th century? The movie concentrates too much on the dramatic and realistic aspects of the movie, such as the whole love triangle and problems between Superman, Lois Lane and her fiancée played by James Marsden, which is far from interesting or compelling.The movie still could had a great one, despite its plot, if it had been a more entertaining one. The movie is lacking in some real good action. Basically the biggest and most spectacular action sequence of the movie is already in the beginning (the plane sequence). After that the movie and its action slows down and the end of the movie could had really used a big and spectacular finale. Instead now the movie doesn't know how and when to end. The ending is overlong, over-dramatic and completely unnecessary. They could had basically summed things up in 5 minutes but the movie chooses an overlong sentimental ending instead.Brandon Routh is perfectly cast as Superman and he also really looks like Christopher Reeve. As expected Kevin Spacey steals the show as Lex Luthor but his presence is perhaps not as spectacular or as memorable as Gene Hackman's. Kate Bosworth is really miscast as Lois Lane. Lois Lane should be a strong, independent woman with lots of life experience. With all respect but Kate Bosworth looks like a fragile teenager.Visually the movie is great and spectacular. All of the special effects are top-class (Oscar nod, no doubt) and they provide the movie with its best moments.I'm glad Superman is back on the silver screen but the the movie itself is nothing too remarkable. In the end it's a pretty forgettable, overlong movie, that is too simple, even while it tries to be so much more than just a superhero movie. I don't mean to sound cruel but you're better of waiting for the DVD. It's not really a movie worth seeing in cinemas.6/10http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

I just don't get it.How is it that you go to the cinema to watch an entertaining movie, and the only thing you get for your money is boredom? The main downside of the movie is the length. The genre is action/adventure/fantasy... but in 60% of the time nothing really happens. The action is mediocre, though the visual/audio effect are awesome. Lex Luthor is annoying(they've ruined the character), although Kevin Spacey did his acting superb. It's just like Chronicles of Narnia(which is neither movie for children, nor for grown-ups). You go to see some action, you get instead drama and some flying.Actually if I weren't with company, I would've left the cinema in the first 10 to 15 minutes. I also tried to sleep through it, but the air conditioner was keeping the room too cold. Bottom line: i seriously doubt that any non-die-hard fan would like it. If the movie was 110 minutes, it would be quite good.

Review Title: Brandon routh is good pick but..
Review: i thought that Brandon Routh was a good choice for the role of Superman and can be compared with the late Chris Reeve. But kate Bosworth was not in the same league as other love interests from both film and TV series, so my 12 year old son and i sadly found this hard going as the 154 minutes seemed to go on forever. Kevin Spacey was not a good choice to play Lex Luther and the story line was asking the viewer to stretch reality a bit too far in my view. once again as in many 'super hero' movies the special effects stole the show, with the plane scene proving the highlight of the movie for me.i suspect i will think again about splashing the cash for the next instalment.

"Superman II" was the first movie I watched over and over, (the first one was awesome too, but the second was my favorite) so I am very critical of anything Superman. Especially when someone is trying to pick up where Christopher Reeve left off -I consider "Smallville" and "Lois and Clark" a different take on the story-. I was leery of seeing Kevin Spacey as Lex Luthor, as I love his other work so much I was afraid I'd see that but, boy was I gratefully wrong. I think that both Kevin Spacey and Brandon Routh played their characters perfectly. They "channeled" enough of Gene Hackman and Christopher Reeve, respectively, while adding their own characteristics to make them exactly what I think this movie was going for. I enjoyed the other characters as well, though I wish they had gotten a little older Lois. Eva Marie Saint was a charming touch too. The story was great and the continuity from the second movie was pretty close. Hearing John Williams music again made me almost jump up right then and there and cheer. That music makes "Superman", "SUPERMAN"!

This movie made me really mad. The only reason I didn't leave the theater was because it was too hot outside. I also felt that it would somehow redeem itself somewhere along the way. Boo hoo! It didn't! A friend saw it in Imax 3D and said the effects were amazing. I guess its cool to perfect a film element like 3D (3D has almost become a myth!) but that's not enough. Great effects just don't carry a movie for me anymore. It doesn't excuse a lazy script, especially when dealing with an icon. I heard people express concerns about the cast of this movie, but they are all fine - merely wasted by this forgettable story. For a few dollars more than the ticket price, I could have purchased the 2 disc Christopher Reeve Superman movie and there would be no complaints. I give this movie the finger. Bryan Singer fumbled the ball. He took one of America's biggest mythical characters and mailed it in 4th Class. Nobody cheered in the packed audience, no applause. That says something. The audience seemed confused but not me. Bryan, don't touch the china! You break it, you pay for it!

Its difficult for me to say anything at this point really...I'm still trying to collect myself. I normally don't write anything on IMDb, I just read what others write, but I have to say something this time.Superman Returns is what going to the movies is all about..Its why they invented cinemas. Its just that good. You feel its big from the very intro, It has style. I guess I'm saying that the visuals of the film still sticks with me..damn, the colors, the scenes.. the entire movie just looked and felt incredibly cool! ..I feel I gotta say something more.I liked especially the way Singer portrays the relationship between Superman and Lois Lane (and no, Kate Bosworth is not too young to play this role!). The way he longs for her, and even spies on her from the shadows, knowing that he can never really be with her, is perfectly visualized and you really feel sad for the Superdude.Romance and love in a movie like this could easily have gone wrong, but It doesn't. The relationship between the two of them never becomes too tacky, Its just perfectly balanced all the way through.Also the flight scenes in the movie are just incredible..again the visuals are beautifully realized and almost spiritual...wow The comic reliefs are many, but never makes the movie feel too light or lame, and thats because the funny things are once again, perfectly executed and timed. Also, when the action is on I found myself on the edge of my seat with the rest of the audience..the action scenes were literally that exiting and intense, so when the laughs came you felt relieved...a roller-coaster ride, thats what the movie felt like, up and down, up and down....and you wanna go again believe me! I was supposed to stop there, but I just have to mention one of the best scenes of the movie, to me at least..SPOILER AHEAD!...Its when Superman lifts an entire continent (its a small continent, but still)...It's been awhile since I remember being that amazed and gob-smacked in the cinema, but that did it for me...what a scene..how the hell did you visualize such a scene Mr. Singer...my hats of to you sir. This is a movie!

Review Title: Lots of good individual moments but it lacks depth and the plot is unconvincing
Review: It has been five years since Superman disappeared into the skies having returned power to the White House. He left to seek out the remnants of his home planet but he returns to Earth having failed to find anything that survived the planet Krypton. As Clark Kent he returns to his old life and job but finds that Lois has moved on from Superman and Clark and is living with Daily Planet editor Richard White and has had a son. Meanwhile Lex Luther has also moved on, or at least "out". Having won his appeal due to a witness no-show, Lex has inherited his way back into power and is concocting his next evil plan.With a massive budget and a massive hype campaign behind it I decided to skip this film for the opening few weekends simply because the opening weekends tend to bring out the talkers and other inconsiderate b*stards in a cinema audience. When I saw it the crowd had only one pair of these so I wasn't too distracted, however I found that the film sadly wasn't actually that good. Scattered liberally across the film are lots of good moments but they are framed by an average film that isn't able to bring them all together. A big failing is the actual story which is a big wodge of nonsense about Luthor getting land – this side doesn't convince and, because it is the backbone to everything else then it causes balance problems across the film. There are good and interesting things in there though. Kent's emotions relating to the loss of Lois are interesting, the action is mainly impressive and individual performances are good. It is a shame that the script lacks the quality to have real depth to support the action and a good story to make it lighter and more enjoyable.I will be honest and say that the character of Superman has never interested me that much (compared to some of the darker and more complex heroes). However I had hoped that Singer would be able to drag out a lot of depth in his character but, aside from quite a few good goes, he doesn't really manage it. It is a shame because Routh is actually pretty good in the lead role. He is good humoured as Kent and also interesting as Superman, however he can only do so much with the material given to him. Bosworth is better though and she works well as Lois. Spacey is a great bit of casting as Luthor but the material prevents him from having as much fun as Hackman once did. He gets close to it but takes himself and the material too seriously. Posey is good support for him but again she loses touch of the fun thanks to the script. Singer makes up for screwing Mardsen in X-Men and gives him a good character here with plenty to do – and he pays him back with a solid turn. Huntington, Langella and a few others turn in solid support turns but nobody draws out any depth or produces a consistent amount of fun. Singer's direction is good though, drawing out his actors as well as he deals with the massive special effects shots – the weaknesses in the film are more to do with the material and not so much him.Overall this is a good film but nothing as special as the hype or budget would suggest. It is better and more interesting than some of the other Superman films but it is not that great. The effects shots look expensive and are quite exciting but the depth of character isn't there and the main plot is rather silly and unconvincing. Good enough for blockbuster audiences and some Superman fans but it should have been so much more.

Review Title: Superman Returns, and it was a long journey back.
Review: First of all its the first good superman movie in like 20 years. Brandon Routh looks like Reeves(may god rest his soul) but Routh also acts like a good superman and a good Clark Kent. As Clark Kent he was clumsy and a push over, so even if people tried to make the connection between Clark and superman, they would get thrown off by his personality. Ms. Bosworth was very intelligent as Lois lane, Kevin Spacey was an insane villain, probably the best villain role in any superhero movie to date(Jack as Joker was on par). The plot in my eyes was quite good, but i didn't like the whole Kryptonite island that much but it was very original, and smart. The flying was mostly computer generated but there were a lot of scenes with Routh on a harness, and i liked the fact that Singer used both. The flying was very realistic and the best in any movie that has attempted to do CG flying, i.e. Matrix trilogy. I think Bryan Singer did an excellent job with Superman and i hope to see more sequels.

Review Title: some great moments in a disappointing long blockbuster
My world can do without Superman Returns

Review: It's sad, but sometimes life can be exceedingly cruel! You hang around for twenty odd years waiting for a decent sequel and then just when you think things can't wrong....Guess what? Bryan Singer what have you done?'Superman Returns' is just no fun.Metropolis now is grim and dark, Like the Man of Steel it's lost its spark.What's more your plot is full of holes, The cast just wooden in their roles.Action scenes all C.G.I.The rest so boring you could cry.In short your film has got no bite You've laced this turkey with Kryptonite.

Review Title: Brandon Routh is Christopher Reeve, but Christopher Reeve IS Superman

Review: First out. I always been kind of negative inclined to Superman as a Superheo. I mean, a superhero that could stand anything, stronger than everything and is just totally invincible, except krypton-it. I don't realize how you can make a story and all these comics out of that character.Even if I aren't the biggest Superman-fan, I'm already tired of the Clark Kent-Louis Lane part. There love story is just uninteresting and pathetic. And it do not developed into something better in the movie either.However, I really like the action in this movie, but that is almost as far as it goes. The ms is one of the most boring and quiet I ever experience. Lex Luthor/Kevin Spacey is the only character that makes any kind of impression on you, but that is Kevin Spaceys own profit.If you watch the trailer, you can learn all Clark Kent/Superman lines by heart and if you got the right body and appearance, you can be the next superman! *yawn*

SUPERMAN RETURNS, is a welcome return of comic favorite man in tights! It's great to see that this was handled perfectly well in the wonderfully capable hands of Bryan Singer, After 1987's REALLY terrible Superman 4 the quest for peace, Story has Superman, literally 'Fly' off only to make a dramatic return, where life has indeed moved on, his only true love Lois Lane, played by Kate Bosworth, has a child and is happily in love and has a child,the evil lex Luther played ever superbly by Kevin Spacey,(who emulate's Gene Hackman well) is recently released from prison, and with the help of some recently plundered Kryptonite plan's to create his very own Civilisation, which will see Luther attempt to destroying half of Metorpolis! Unknown,Brandon Routh, uncannily fill's the Late Christopher Reeve's red boot's well, Kate Bosworth, sadly IS No Margot Kidder, It's great to see old timer Eve Marie Saint, feature as Ma Kent, Frank Langella, play's Perry White, but sadly lacks the charm of Jackie Cooper,The Special Visual Effect's(Albeit are still in their infancy) but still will convince you that 'You'll believe that a man can FLY!

Review Title: SUPERMAN RETURNS : We Don't Need Another Bruce Wayne, We Simply Want Our "Man Of Steel"
The Legend of the Man of Steel Returns
Review: This new SUPERMAN movie brings back the mythical origins took place for years and years that the people on planet earth haven't seen The Man of Steel at all. Til he came back. Brandon Routh who plays this Daily Planet News Reporter Clark Kent who is so happy to see his beloved Lois Lane (Played by Kate Bosworth). Who moved on to her new life with her new beloved fiancé Perry White's son Richard White (Played by James Marsden) who originally played Cyclops from (X-MEN I, II, III). She and Richard had a Child.And also Kevin Spacey plays this wicked arrogant villain Lex Luther as Superman's arch-nemesis enemy. Who takes revenge on the Man of Steel for years. He wanted to take over the world. But Superman had to stop him for taken over the world. Kevin Spacey looks so similar to Gene Hackman's character Lex Luther. But Hackman's character playing Lex Luther from the Original Superman films. Because,he played a goofball villain who makes a joke out of Superman. But Lex Luther has evil plans to kill Superman. He is both an addictator and a big bad bully.Also, Brandon Routh (as Kal-El: The Last Son of Krypton) lands on a rocket ship in Smallville, Kansas where his adoptive foster mother Martha Kent (Played by Eva Marie Saint). Who is sadly grieving about her son's disappearance from earth for years and years.This movie carries the beloved memories of Christopher Reeve who wanted some actors in the future to play his role in the upcoming Superman 5. So, SUPERMAN 5 became a new legend back in the theatres again.This is my first time I seen Superman coming back to the movies in theatres.

I was more-or-less dragged to this by my daughter, who is a big Smallville fan. I got sucked in right away. Kevin Spacey simply WAS Lex Luther. He can always carry a movie, and he pulled everyone along with him this time. I have seen the Batmans, Spidermans, and other Supermans. This movie is in a class by itself.The realism of the effects was superb. I rarely felt like I was watching an effect at all. The "hover" is the coolest technique. Having grown up hearing the roar of Superman's flight in the old b&w TV show, the silent approaches and departures put a smile on my face every time. It was flying redefined.Somehow, they managed to keep the pacing quite constant throughout the movie. I was paying attention to the hospital room scenes just about as much as the near-earth-destruction sequences. There was little of the frenetic rush between things exploding so common to the genre. Of course, having the leading lady being such serious eye-candy may have carried me through some slow parts...Now, if only the critics will take a close enough look to give Spacey another nomination.

I'll be focusing on the main character himself more than the movie. Superman Returns is, in style, a similar movie to Batman Begins. The story is vastly different, as are the events, characters and drama. But the director's attempt to make the hero more appealing through a realistic emphasis to the movie is the same.In Batman Begins, a big selling point was to make Batman believable. They succeeded better. Superman Returns doesn't fall too far off the mark though. Actually, it succeeded quite perfectly, and that's the problem.Superman is an icon, a perfect being. Handsome, intelligent, wise, with an almost absolute power and incredible perception of all things. And of course, he never lies.Then, he's reduced to the reality drama of modern day TV. Lois has another man, with a kid, and has an angst towards Supes. In ways I cannot tell without spoiling, Superman is forced down to a human level in too many ways. Emotionally, mentally, and physically. That's not what he's about, it never was. Don't get me wrong, the effects are better than anything anyone has ever seen before. You'll believe you saw a real Superman doing all the amazing stuff he does in this film, but unfortunately that's not enough.Whether it's the actor, or the director, or both (and I wager both, more director than actor though), the Supes in this movie fails to live up to what Superman was like when displayed by Christopher Reeve. He no longer commands the incredible aura of supremacy, of the humble but unwavering charisma and absolute power. His powers are that of a Superman, but his physical and psychological demeanor are more akin to a human with a righteous heart, but still just a human. He no longer enjoys the respect and self-esteem he did before. And to me, that's bad. Because Superman was supposed to be Super in that as well, above all else, it was his charisma and personality that made him appealing. *That* was the part that should've been the selling point. *That* was the part that made the first Superman movie as big as it was, namely: Christopher Reeve's portrayal of "Superman". It never was about making him human, not this much.The actors all do a decent job, nothing remarkable, but good nevertheless. Routh fits the role quite likely better than anyone else could have, but he's not Reeve. I'm not a major Reeve fan, but to me Routh's Clark and Supes were far too similar. That, too, may be more thanks to the director than the actor. When I first saw Reeve's Superman 1 & 2, I didn't think they were that amazing. It was in retrospect after growing up, that I started to respect the tremendous difference in how he played the two characters. He had the unexplained mystical way of changing his gestures and demeanor in such a dramatic way (most notably, the extreme difference in self-esteem and charisma) that Clark and Superman appeared two entirely different beings. Routh doesn't manage to do this, Supes is too close to Clark, and Clark is too close to Supes. Perhaps that's the modern way, thanks to Smallville and whatnot. But it doesn't work for me.The musical score was good in that it was faithful to the original. It was bad in that much of what was modernized, didn't really work all that well. The score suffered from a similar problem that Terminator 3 did: at times the continuity suffered as a result of poor rhythm and instruments, and at other times there was no music at all when it was clearly needed. Still, it was nowhere near the failure T3's score was. And thanks to the few essential highly emotional scores played in key parts of the movie, I can say the overall soundtrack and its use is well enough above average.As you see by the score, I was satisfied. Perhaps I give this movie extra because it's a Superman flick, but I don't think so. I would say this: My expectations were extremely high, and as such I was disappointed. But only by a little. The movie is solid, and although it's rather long, for anyone with an adult's attention spam it delivers quite well enough. Unlike with Peter Jackson's mammoth films though, here you can rather clearly point out the ~20-30 minutes that could've been cut out to make the movie shorter and more to the point.I definitely hope there will be a sequel. And I fully believe the director and the crew can make that sequel work better than this one. They just happened to have a wrong approach here. Nevertheless, their skill and dedication is obvious. This *IS* a good movie, even if not as godly as I may have expected. A movie focused only on the showoff of incredible effects and no depth of plot or character would have received a 5 from me. I'm glad this wasn't like that, at least.

Action, violence, super-hero: all the qualities of a great summer movie. And, surprise!, a good script too. This movie was peopled with believable characters, real relationships, and still paid homage to those that preceded it. For me, it dwelt too much on the rocks and crystals, and the creations grown from them, but otherwise a terrific film. I saw it at a moviehouse with 3D and the 3D wasn't working so I look forward to renting it and seeing it again without that distraction. I loved the mythological imagery that was sprinkled into the movie. I am also hoping for a sequel. Overall I considered this a much better movie than Pirates.

I saw the original movie when i was a kid and thought i would find again the same entertainment as an adult.I was wrong: if my values take weight, Superman remains the same... That's the first problem here: what's exactly is this movie: homage, sequel, remake? You got the same ingredients: music, the classic triangle: Superman/Clark – Lois – Lex Luthor, the airplane crash, the environmental plot...But, as a mature audience now, I wish the concept of Superman would be used with philosophy. Unfortunately, it's only targeted with an US cultural background (as if there was nothing outside the "small"ville or the "metropolis"). Well, the director Harold Ramis says it better than me: "how can Superman spends all his time with Lois while the world is upside-down ?" The problem with super-heroes today is that they lack super-scripts & the productors don't go for comics writer: for example, when Frank Miller writes about Superman, he is a lackey for the President & fights international wars for him. Paul Dini tells about "peace on earth". What a change !Well, I don't call Superman, "Super – egocentric" but big powers means big scope. If you got Superman, you got the super threats from all over the world... and nowadays, it isn't Luthor the worst nightmare on Earth...That's why I have never been a big fan of Superman & I prefer Batman or Spiderman comics and movies!

Review Title: One of the best films i've seen
Review: Great, Great, and again Great. What a work of art. The special effects are crazy....the new face of superman is superb. Great job. I didn't think it was going to be this good!!! And it wasn't only special effects. The story was captivating, the music, the sound, the art directions, everything. The emotional level throughout the movie is also very strong, I actually found myself almost tearing a couple of times :) Thanks for a Great movie! For sure we're going to see at least two more follow-ups, I HOPE! GO SUPERMAN! And I don't really know why I saw some negative feedback on the film. I thought it was more of a worthy follow-up to a great trilogy.

The contrast between Superman on the big or small screen and Superman in the original comic books has always been too great for my liking. The main series of Superman films from the 1970s and 1980s (well the first two anyway) were good attempts, but still fell short of the comics in many ways. The latest opus in the genre doesn't seem to have learned much from the earlier entries in the catalogue.My main problem with the film is that the characters are flat - there is little attempt to develop any of the main roles beyond cardboard cutouts. I found it impossible to really care what happened to anyone, since they didn't seem to care much themselves.The other problem (as with the 1970s films) is that Luthor is still portrayed much as a villain from the 1960s Batman TV shows. He is supposed to be a cosmic genius, and yet he surrounds himself with henchmen that probably never went to high school. Luthor himself comes across as more of a comedian than an evil super-villain. I kept expecting a fight scene interspersed with frames saying BIFF! POW! ZAPP! As with any Superman film, the plot holes are large and numerous, but we tend to ignore those for the sake of the story. But please, movie people, let's try to put enough intelligence into the dialogue and characterization to give those of us who aren't sated entirely by dazzling special effects something to get our teeth into.

Review Title: A wonderful tribute to Chris Reeve
Review: Superman Returns is quite simply a beautiful film. Full of heart, wonder, fun and exhilaration. I guess part of it is due to simple nostalgia, brought on by the familiar title sequence and the fantastic musical themes made immortal by John Williams. But it remains a fact that Bryan Singer has managed to capture everything that made the two first Superman movies so memorable - there are moments of silly comedy, there are elegant romantic sequences and action set-pieces so spectacular, I found myself going 'Woah!' at the screen over and over. And then there's that childish grin that wouldn't leave my face for the entire running time. Seriously, my face was hurting at the end.Upon first view, one might be tempted to hand the film's success firmly in the hands of Kevin Spacey. He simply chews up every single second he's on the screen. Delightfully evil, and with enough intelligence to not make the character one-dimensional. Simply a joy to watch.But - it is Brandon Routh who makes the film shine. He is every bit as charming and believable as Superman/Clark Kent as Christopher Reeve was. His voice, his looks and even the mannerisms are so much like the late great actor, it's uncanny.I see this as the ultimate tribute to my childhood hero. 9/10 - go see it. One of the best films of the year.
